column1: Karnataka boasts no. of splendid waterfalls situated in various spots of Western Ghat Region. Best time to enjoy the waterfalls is during monsoon. Last week the news of monsoon spreading towards Coastal Karnataka was highlighted in various media channels. We were in two minds
column2: whether this would be the right time to visit that region
column3: particularly by road. Ultimately
column4: last Friday (19thJune
column5: 2015) late evening
column6: we made up our minds and booked on line accommodation in Jog Falls.

column1: Next day myself along with my wife and son started in our Car towards JOG FALLs. It is one of the highest waterfall in India (around 900ft) located around 400 KMs from Bangalore.Our destination was Hotel MayuraGerusoppaJogfalls of Karnataka Tourism. We started a bit late (around 6.15 AM) since the program was made suddenly and without much planning. After filling petrol when we reached near Yeshwantpur it was past seven.My wife helped to navigate me with “Google” and GPS in hand. My son joined the navigation occasionally.
Our route plan was to reach near Chitradurga via NH 4 (Bangalore Mumbai Highway) then take
On the way to Jog Falls
left turn towards Shimoga thru NH 13 (Sholapur Mangalore Highway)and finally take NH 206 (Bangalore – Honnavar Highway) to reach Jog Falls via Sagar.
From Yaswantpurupto near Neelamangala there was morning traffic. After crossing the second Toll Gate (Rs 18
column2: First Toll gate we paid Rs 20)
column3: no of vehicles considerably reduced and we could drive fast. It was a pleasure to drive through NH4
column4: which was a four lane Highway and well maintained.

column1: After reaching Sira (8.35 AM) thru Tumkur
column2: followed by Patterhalli (8.55 AM) and Hiriyur (9 AM)
column3: we reached our first destination near Chitradurga(9.30 AM) where we took left turn after a lake and enter NH 13 (Sholapur Mangalore Highway). On the way there were hundreds of Windmills installed in the hilltop which provided a nice view.

column1: Weather was cloudy with small showers in between.
Felt hungry and finished breakfast at a roadside hotel immediately after Chitradurga town(10 AM). This area was surrounded by small hills with big boulders
column2: no vegetation.

column1: Road condition of NH 13 was not at all conducive for smooth driving. The road was getting broadened (two lane) for which construction work was going on
at various places. Road materials mixed with rainwater made matters worse. Above all the road was broken in some places. Negotiating all these
column2: when we reached Chennagiri (11AM) and Shimoga(12 AM) crossing Tunga River
column3: already the car was very dirty with wheels and lower part becoming red mingled with debris.

column1: Stopped at TungaRiver to decide the next destination. Crossing two three circles
column2: few Medical Colleges finally touched NH 206 (Honnavar Highway). This road although not very broad but was well maintained.

column1: From Shimoga to Sagar was around 90 Kms. Thereafter we entered a sanctuary. Forest started. Now the scenario changed. Hilly tracks
column2: in between villages. We saw a big village market on the road including Fish market also.
Rain
column3: Rain

column2: rain started. Incessant rain
column3: as if the whole sky was releasing its deposits on our car and on the road. Car wiper at its maximum speed
column4: Windscreen flooded with waterflow
column5: only the sound of rain on all sides.

column2: may be risky

column1: We pierced the rain and entered our ultimate destination for the day

106 Kms from Shimoga
column3: 26 Km from Sagar).

column2: Karanataka Tourism was well maintained. I came here around ten years back. It was renovated. Inside room was cosy and spacious. Most important
column3: the falls were just in front of the hotel. Nice location to enjoy the waterfall. No private hotel was allowed adjacent to that area.

column3: Tata Sumo
column4: Hired vehicle and of course private vehicles. These enthusiastic people enjoyed getting soaked by rain and of course the view of waterfalls.

by the river. KSTDC Hotels where we were staying was on Shimoga District

column1: Dinner we had in a nearby stall with fish curry. Night sleep was enjoyable with sound of the waterfall.
Morning started with heavy rain. Falls were mostly not visible. The contest between “cloud” and the “waterfall” was in full swing. We thought of starting early but “late-latif” as usual.

After breakfast at KSTDC restaurant we bagan our journey towards Honnavar thru NH 206 and ultimately to Murudeswar.Meanwhile dark clouds covered almost entire place including Hotel area. Hardly anything was visible.
was around 80 Kms from Jog Falls
column2: Honnavaren-route was around 50 Kms. NH 206 which goes to Honnavarwas narrow but road condition was more or less ok. Honnavar is located on the Arabian Sea coast.We had to cross the Western Ghatmountains to reach our destination.

column1: Heavy Rain with storm at the Ghat Section
Immediately after crossing the Saravatyriver in Jog Falls
column2: thick forest started. A few kilometres later Ghat Section road began. The road was zig zag with large no of curves and it neededcareful driving to negotiate. All those were known
column3: but to our disadvantage
column4: heavy rain started with stormy winds. Heavy fogs made visibility near to zero even with fog light. Falling trees in various places narrowed down the road passage. I switched on all the headlights of my car while proceeding slowly. Gradually
column5: we reached the plain land after driving around 25 Kms on the Ghat section. It was a breath taking journey.

column1: NH 206 touched NH 17 after going further down. NH 17 comes from Mumbai on the North and goes beyond Mangalore on the south. Honnavar is basically a fishing port located on the Arabian Sea. We stopped there for
Raja & Rani two separate sources outof four

a while. The two KM long Honnavar road bridge on the way to Murudeswar is one of the longest bridges in India. The bridge is constructed on the Sharavatiriver near the confluence of the Arabian sea. The backwater of the Arabian Sea gives a magnificent view of the whole place.
This wonderful place is the abode of Lord Shiva and located on the coast of Arabian Sea. The giant Statute (122 Ft) of Lord Shiva
column2: one of the tallest in the world was built on a big rock on the seashore. The area has other beautiful statutes and the temple.One can directly drive near the statute or visit by walk. The area is well planned and beautifully maintained. There are no of hotels in the vicinity. The entire place including hotels belong to a private RNShetty Group.

this temple has the linkage of Ravanas worship to Lord Shiva to acquire Atma-linga (soul of Shiva) to gain immortality.He was unable to do so due to tricks by other gods like Lord Ganesha and Narada to save the universe. On his failure
column3: Ravana threw his

column1: Ghat section from Jog to Honnavar
belongings in anger to this place. Original temple was re-built by businessman R N Shetty.Gopuram of the temple was more than 20 storey tall
column2: one of the tallest in the world. There is lift arrangement for reaching the top floor to have abirds eye view of the surrounding area.

column1: We reached Murudeswar at around 2 PM. There was no rain
column2: but sea was very rough and roaring. We selected Hotel RNS Residency Hotel for staying. Location of the hotel was unique since it was constructed on an area which was extended to the sea. Thus almost three sides of the hotels were surrounded by the sea. It is one of the best location I have ever seen anywhere particularly for staying on sea-side.

column1: The hotel tariff was low since it was off-season and very few visitors were occupying the rooms. We selected a sea-side room on the fifth floor. However
column2: the flip side was absence of proper maintenance. Furnishing
column3: cleaning of the hotel were not of that standard. But definitely a great feeling for one day experience.

column1: Rest of the day spent by visiting the temple
column2: Shiva Statute and surrounding places and enjoying

column1: Ghat section from Jog to Honnavar 2

evening coffee in the wonderfully placed restaurant surrounded by sea. We were standing at the front-side of the hotel where roaring sea weaves just few feets below relentlessly attempting to break the cement structure with enormous energydue to inclement weather. Observing from the hotel balcony that tonnes of water waves dashingbeneath the hotel structure in roaring defiance of destruction was a frightening but worth experiencing. Also viewing the sea at night from the hotel balcony was a memorable experience.

Time for returning to Bangalore. Complimentary breakfast time of the hotel was 7.30 AM onwards. Previous night we thought of starting immediately after taking breakfast. But after finishing breakfast and check out formalities when we started it was around 8.45 AM
column2: already one hour late from our schedule.

column1: Weather was far better today. After expressing its anger
column2: Sea was calm and cool today. Offered “pranaam” to Lord Shiva and our journey began.

column1: We were in two minds whether to visit Gokarna
column2: but my wife insisted that we should not miss it. For Gokarna
column3: the route was same uptoHonnavar. Distance between Murudeswar and Gokarna is around 80 Km

column1: thru NH 17. This road was quite good to drive with wonderful natural beauties on the way. After crossing Honnavar
column2: Gangavalli river was giving us company on her voyage to sea. The river was in spate
column3: a splendid view to watch on the way.

column2: but we thought of visiting “Om Beach” first
column3: which was around 20 Kms from the main highway
column4: around half an hour journey. It was a pleasant journey with the narrow road gradually increasing in height havingseveral twists and turns. Around four Km away from the beach we had the first glimpse of the sea from the top. Sea and the beach were located around 200 ft down below
column5: amidst hills in the surroundings. An excellent panoramic view to enjoy. Gradually we came nearer with Resorts and Cottages in between. The beach looked like “OM” from the top
column6: a spectacular sight. It was around 11 AM.

column1: We stopped the car and trekked down below to the beach. This beach was different with rocky areas in various places. Sea was once again looking furious with mighty waves falling on the rocks. It was wonderful to watch the big waves and beauty of

column2: Gokarna
Gokarna of Lord Shiva was auspicious and a must visit. The Atmalinga or Shiva linga is said to bestow immense blessings to the devotees who took even aglimpse of it. According to mythology
column3: the deity was placed by Ravana when he carried it from Mount Kailash. The temple according to legend was originally built more than thousand years ago and subsequently re-built during Vijaynagara period. The temple is claimed to be as pious as the Shiva Temple of Varanasi.

column1: Gents visitors have to remove theirbanian to enter the temple.Luckily there was no rush
column2: we visited the Lord
column3: collected Prasad.

column1: Now we had to start at the earliest for reaching Bangalore within the day. According to Google map
column2: there were no. of routes for going back to Bangalore. I wanted to take the same route thru which we came here.But the map showed a different preferred route for reaching early. With some hesitation we decided to take that route . The distance to be covered was around 600 Kms. It was 12.30 PM.
Mundgod and Bankapur

column1: We took left turn thru NH

17 for around twenty kms further down towards Karwar. Thentook a right turn to reach NH 63 towards Yellapur. Reached Yellapur at 2.30 PM. The road passed thru absolutely green forests in Western Ghat with occasional view of waterfalls from nearby hills. There were some risky turns but overall road condition was good. There was not much traffic en-route. We passed around 60 Kms thru forest&Ghat section like these.

Throughout our journey the “Google Map” followed thru GPS dictated us which route to take as well as the distances to be covered. Suddenly we observed that there was not enough “Charge” in our mobile. We forgot to charge our mobile last night. That was a big mistake. We had bought a charger to recharge the mobile from the Car itself. But when we needed it most
column2: we found out that it was not working. So the immediate requirement was to conserve the charge remaining in the mobile as much as possible.

column1: Reached Mundgod and observed Tibetan Monasteries
column2: villagers and their habitats on the way. We love Tibetan food but there was no time to search for eateries.

column1: Our immediate objective was to touch NH 4 near Bankapur.

column2: Rani
column3: Rocket Jog Falls

column2: near Bankapur we lost the way and erroneously entered a remote village road with large potholes. That was a nightmare and I waspraying that our car would somehow pass that road (around five kms) without any trouble.
near Bankapur we reached NH 4 with a sigh of relief. We had crossed around 200 Kms already. There will be another nearly 400 Kmsdrive to reach Bangalore. It was around 4 PM.
there was a Toll gate atBankapur (Rs. 70/-). Afterwords

column4: HebbaluRs 75/-
column5: GuilaluRs 55/-
column6: TumkurRs 18/-
column7: NeelamangalaRs 18/-). In many tollgates they ask for exact change and then return one rupee less in absence of change. But had no regets
column8: since we could cover around 375 Kms within four hours with one stop in between. As I explained NH4 is one of the best roads to drive. Around 8.15PM we passedYashvantpurRailway station and reached home at around 9 PM.

column1: Asia » India » Karnataka » Bandipur National Park
I’ve been back on the land for two weeks and all kinds of things have happened since
column2: but let me use this post to explain the few weeks I spent at Auroville.

column1: After a few more days with the Auroville guys
column2: I left with Ilango and Vikram in the Bolero with all their gear and we drove to Auroville in 10 hours. The trip was mostly uneventful as we listened to a broken Bob Marley cd with the two main highlights being another twister passing us on the road and a very
column3: very tight descent down the mountains with 27 needle pin bends.

column1: We arrived at the AV youth centre in the evening. The first few days there were kind of boring to me but then I decided to go out and explore on my own. Mostaba let me use his bicycle the entire time (thanks so much!) so I was able to go out whenever I wanted. I checked out the visitors centre first and got a very different impression of the place than I’d had from just being in the YC the first few days

column2: Auroville is a town of over 2000 people that was started in 1968
column3: based upon the idea of human unity
column4: as described by two somewhat mysterious (or perhaps mythical) persons generally referred to as ‘The Mother’ and Sri Aurobindo. As such
column5: there are a lot of people from all over the world (especially many Europeans) who have contributed to the place and have basically built a life for themselves. At the centre of Auroville there is a huge golden globe
column6: called The Matrimandir
column7: which is the symbol of Auroville and is a place used for tourguides and meditation. I guess occasionally ceremonies and things of such nature are held in or around as well
column8: though I didn’t get to see any. Inside the matrimandir it looks and feels like a 70’s sci-fi movie. You have to wear white socks in order to keep the carpeted spiral walkway up to the inner chamber pristinely white. Inside the inner chamber is a huge crystal ball
column9: and underneath the entire thing is a smaller crystal ball
column10: surrounded by marble slabs with water flowing over them. I found it all both beautiful and absurd.

column1: I actually kinda knew about a lot of this before coming to India as I had been referred to AV as a potential place for my placement
column2: but the impression I’d gotten through various online sources made me think it was either a tourist destination or a place for seriously floaty people. Plus they didn’t reply to my second email... At any rate
column3: I can say that my assumptions were misplaced and I’m very glad to have been able to go there for a short while anyway. In fact
column4: I highly recommend anyone to visit and learn about an alternative way to life (it is apparently the world’s largest eco-village) and I think I would have really enjoyed interning at one of their permaculture/reforestation projects. There are literally all kinds of people there
column5: including many volunteers and travellers passing through
column6: even outside of the tourist season.

column1: The first two weeks I still hung out mostly at the youth centre. It’s actually one of the most unlikely parts of AV. Although mostly inhabited and visited by Aurovillan teenagers
column2: there were 3 other visitors staying there at the same time I was. The rent is cheap (200 rps plus some volunteer work per day) and so I worked a bit now and then on digging a pool
column3: building a treehouse and a gameroom
column4: together with various of the AV gang
column5: as well as some European travellers (Aemon
column6: Alex & Mihael). Every Saturday they have a Farmer’s Market and a Pizza Night at YC which attract all kinds of people. The first time I met some people volunteering at Buddha Garden who invited me to join them the following Monday. I also met some Norwegian students who study at a Norwegian university in Pondicherry and eventually went with them to a party there.

column1: At Buddha Garden I met several of the people who had invited me
column2: but I also met quite a few others. These people seemed far more interested in sharing stories with me and as time went on at AV the group seemed to grow larger as people mingled with one another and got more familiar with the area. I felt relieved to have found people who were in a somewhat similar place as me and could therefore connect with. I spent some days hanging out with various crowds
column3: doing some work at the youth centre
column4: exploring the area
column5: visiting a permaculture farm called Solitude (where they host concerts and offer meals cooked with a lot of their own vegetables)
column6: the Matrimandir and so on. There was also a big meeting (about 200 attendees) I attended where people discussed the issue of building a road through a place called Pony Farm. Basically there is a masterplan for Auroville’s development
column7: which doesn’t seem to take into account the community of people already living there. It was very interesting to see how the whole meeting was set up and I thought the facilitator did a great job of giving everyone a chance to talk. Unfortunately I was unable to visit Pony Farm.

column1: Then on Friday I met up with Lev and Lucie to go to the Pebble Garden tour. Since I was the only one on a bicycle I quickly had to learn how to drive a TVS (a small scooter with no gears) which was no problem. The tour was really great! Basically Pebble Garden is one of several reforestation projects that have been going on at and around Auroville in the past 20-30 years. The main person
column2: Bernard
column3: is a very excited storyteller and explained the history of the place before we went out to have a look around. They use an interesting technique for their garden beds
column4: mimicking the behaviour of termites to create nutrient-rich soil. I also learnt that the entire area used to be a forests
column5: before the British and French cut down all the trees and the topsoil was washed away into the Bay of Bengal
column6: turning the area into a desert. Thanks to the efforts of people like Bernard
column7: Auroville is now a very forested area with lots of shade. The weather is a bit different than at Swayyam. It’s very humid and quite exhausting
column8: especially with having to use a bicycle most of the time.

column1: The next day I met up with some Buddha Garden people at one of the lodging areas
column2: called Reve and met an American girl named Madi and everything changed. We went to a lake and things clicked so we hung out at the pizza night at the youth centre. After that we hung out every day and had amazing times together. I drove her TVS all over the place which was awesome until one night when we had way too many problems with getting several TVS’s to start. After that night I couldn’t help but feel sad at the thought that it would all be over soon
column3: but this prompted me to make the most of our last few days and change my attitude. We drove to Pondicherry the next day and had a great time
column4: taking rickshaws and walking around the Botanical Gardens (featured briefly in The Life Of Pi) before getting my busticket for the coming Saturday. It’s really helpful to have someone around who’s more familiar with the way things work in India (haggling with the rickshaw drivers especially).

column1: The next Friday I visited Pebble Garden again to get some seeds from Bernard for Malvikaa and after that I went with Paul (a German guy I met) to the Sadhana Forest tour. Sadhana Forest is an all-vegan reforestation/restoration project with over 1000 volunteers per year. I didn't like the tour as much as Bernard’s but it was still good to see everything and afterwards there were several videos explaining their projects (also in Kenya
column2: Haiti and another location in India) and then we watched the first part of a documentary on all kinds of issues mankind is experiencing nowadays. It was inspiring but tiring. Afterwards we went to Brother’s Pizza place where we met up with Madi and Cris.

column1: The last day I hung out with Madi before the taxi showed up at the Youth Centre to take me away to the Pondicherry bus station. Reluctantly I got in after saying my goodbyes. The bus left at 11pm to arrive at Bangalore around 6am the next day. It was a bumpy ride and the guy next to me kept nodding off on my shoulder. Needless to say
column2: I didn’t sleep much. When I got to Bangalore I tried to get a rickshaw driver to take me to the train station so I could get to Mysore the way Madi had advised
column3: but instead he argued I should take a taxi. I was tired and in no mood to argue so I figured I would check out how much it would be. 150 rupees to get to Mysore is not a whole lot of money so I took the taxi (which fit 10 people) and got to Mysore about 3 hours later. I thought of doing some sight-seeing in Mysore but touristing with my house on my back and lack of sleep didn’t seem like a fun idea so instead I went to a hotel where they had wifi and I could charge my laptop and phone. They treated me like a special customer
column4: even going so far as to tell the guy who was on the toilet to hurry up since I needed to go. I got to the bus station and then took a bus to Gundlupet and then to Yelachatti where I arrived around 4.30pm
column5: feeling very alone. The land had gotten very green and beautiful though and it was clear I was in for the next stage of my stay in India.

column1: Wide empty road- can't imagine in the city.
Goa is a known name to Domestic and Overseas travelers. It has one of the finest beaches of India and many old age churches. The carefree and lively atmosphere
column2: mouth watering Sea food delicacies
column3: Casino parlors
column4: Jewellery are some of the attractions.

column1: Generally I do a kind of research when I visit any place. But when I visited Goa for the first time in April 2014
column2: I had nothing to research before the visit. Because I might be the only first time visitor to the place among my known circle. In fact it was just a much awaited trip for my son.
to give a bit of excitement to the trip
column3: we decided to drive down. So that we could stop wherever we wanted
column4: could eat at our choice of eatery and could leisurely spend time on the roadside.

column1: We started our journey at around 6am in the morning. It took one hour to cross the city including a railway crossing which itself took 30mins to cross.
It is always eye soothing to go out of the city; then only we can enjoy the real beauty of nature.
Bangalore is a city of lakes and
greenery. We can see trees on both sides of the roads many times the top of the trees kissing each other making a complete shade over the busy roads
column2: being having awesome weather throughout the year some trees are always laden with beautiful flowers. But the population
column3: high rise buildings
column4: pollution has shielded the natural beauty.

column2: once we crossed the busiest and newly developed part of the city
column3: we could see double storied traditional houses painted with bright yellow
column4: blue and other colors separated by a patch of greenery from the neighboring house. There was breathing space for every house
column5: many has small garden at the front.

column1: As we further moved we could see houses with more open areas
column2: temples. The temple of each state and region is uniquely different in India. In the southern states
column3: the outer wall of the temple building also has different sizes idols built on it.

column1: We stopped for breakfast at a famous south Indian food chain joint. We always prefer to have local cuisine. We were required to cover 12 hours journey hence
column2: had quite heavy breakfast of Idli and Dosa.

column1: Now we were quite out of the city

column2: wind mills
column3: power stations at the foothills
column4: long stretch of dry fields. The memories of these natural beauty remains in the heart and mind for long and gives us enthusiasm to go back to our work of daily life and makes our wait sweet for the next venture.

column1: We got out of our car
column2: just to feel the freshness of air and see the beauty. We walked around
column3: clicked photos
column4: looked at the passers by and restarted after 15-20 mins.

column1: By now we had crossed Bangalore and its outskirts; were passing small towns of Karnataka. Though there is a distinct difference between the two
column2: but the small places we crossed looked quite prosperous in its own way of having cemented houses
column3: TV and internet cables
column4: local public transport etc..

column1: We enjoyed every bit of it. Like temple
column2: houses and its colour
column3: local shops ambience
column4: women’s accessories are also uniquely different of every state of India.

column2: villages
column3: long stretch of paddy fields
column4: some empty stretches where neither crops nor people were seen
column5: between two villages.

column1: Then we reached to the forest area. It’s a long stretch mixture
of good and bad roads. Small habitats are also there but less crowded. It’s the area along the western ghat and the forest is a deciduous one. It was early summer time
column2: some trees have shredded their leaves
column3: some has got new leaves. Altogether it was a beautiful view with a wide range of green shades. The sunlight was peeping through the gaps of trees mainly without the leaves one. We could see upto the depth of the forest through the trunks of the trees. We could see the boards “Drive slowly animals may cross the road
column4: ” There could be wild animals deep inside the jungle
column5: might roam around on to the roads but during day time it would have been a rare sight. Still we all live with hope and we kept our hopes on. We had to content ourselves with one fox crossing the road.

column1: Lunch time was approaching and our stomach started growling. We started hunting for the restaurant. Being forest area only with small villages we were not able to locate one though locals were directing us but not satisfying us. 45 minutes passed
column2: no food joint found. We thought of stopping now
column3: the first

column2: Sky - sunset and a coconut tree

column1: one we find. In between we saw one sweet lime juice seller. We satisfied ourselves with that.

column2: nothing was found. We were sure that we have to take lunch only after reaching Goa around 3pm. We diverted ourselves from this search. All of a sudden we saw a small hotel beside a shop. We stopped and ordered for Rice
column3: Roti
column4: Dal and Chicken Curry. It was a smallest joint I would ever had lunch at
column5: but unbelievable taste of the food. Home grind-ed spices by traditional method
column6: no adulteration
column7: no short cut during preparation. As we say "" yummy "".The taste still lies on my taste buds. Same day dinner at Taj also could beat it.

column1: We were so happy and satisfied after the lunch that we spent some time roaming around. We were almost reaching to the Goa state. Within an hour we crossed the forest area and reached Goa.
We will love to come back to Goa by this route again and obviously stop for the lunch there.

column1: Asia » India » Karnataka » Bandipur National Park
So it’s been almost 3 weeks since my first blog-post. By now I can say I’ve settled in quite nicely out here. Malvikaa left to the US a few days ago though she left the land last Sunday morning
column2: so since then I’ve been ‘alone’ with the guys from Auroville. I hope to be travelling a little bit with them when they leave but it depends on whether there’s space in the cars.

that’s all in the future. In the past so many days I’ve only been off the land twice – once to visit a local furniture maker who’s ‘factory’ is just down the road and another time to the town of Gundlupet to buy groceries. It’s good to be with some other white people who can show me how they do their everyday activities
column3: since English isn’t actually that common around this area.

column1: Most of my days have looked like this: I wake up in my tent around 5.30 and get out about 10 minutes later to go over to the house to switch off the electric fence so Nagappa can come in and bring fresh milk. Then I go back to bed and sleep until the heat forces me out again between 8 and 9am. I wash my clothes in a bucket and wash my bum with with my left hand
column2: leaving the right available to eat with. I wash the rest of my body with a ‘bucket bath’
column3: though perhaps this should be called a bucket shower since there’s no actual bathing in anything. Breakfast is around 9am
column4: lunch usually 2pmish and dinner... 9pmish. At least that’s how it’s been the past week or so.

column1: The work I do tends to involve a lot of water – watering plants
column2: filling up tanks and barrels and curing cement. I’ve also helped the auroville guys a few times though
column3: including making a treehouse (during which we saw a miniature tornado cruise through the land!) and doing various other things. Yesterday Philip helped me make ‘my first steps in natural building’. Literally
column4: I made some steps with just sticks
column5: rocks and soil from the bund down to where my tent is and I feel quite proud of it. Pics will have to come later though. Also
column6: today I made cement!

column1: I’ve also been working together with Nagappa and Nagesh
column2: usually digging things or assisting the laying and connecting of water pipes. We recently finished installing the 5000 litre water tank though! This will make the whole land more resistant to anything that might go wrong
column3: like the few days when we didn’t have much power so we couldn’t pump water and had to have Nagappa bring some drinking water from the village
column4: just in case...

column1: I’ve also just about read all of Brad Warner’s excellent book ‘There is no God and He is always with you’ (highly recommended
column2: regardless of what your thoughts about God are
column3: or aren’t) and been doing zazen almost daily
column4: which has really helped me focus on being where I am. Especially the first 10 days or so I was experiencing some mood swings and missing some things about home
column5: especially people and certain luxuries. But I feel much better now. Not to say I don’t miss hanging out with my friends back home and I spend quite a bit of time thinking about my band or what kind of cool things in Wageningen and Utrecht I’m missing out on!

column1: But I also feel that being here is in line with what I want to be doing. Perhaps not forever
column2: perhaps not in India
column3: or the US
column4: but I like the concepts of land restoration and permaculture and I’m noticing how much of a difference to the land (and to the people working on it) a place like Swayyam makes and how damn important it is that we all take better care of ourselves
column5: each other and the environment (it’s all one thing really anyway).

column1: So to add something ‘educational’ to this blogpost
column2: here’s how I understand some of what’s happening here: There’s only a small amount of usable fresh water on the planet (less than 3%!
column3: (MISSING) look up peak water) and in many places it’s used tremendously stupidly and a lot of it runs off into places we can’t reach it
column4: it gets polluted
column5: or it goes into the oceans where it becomes salt water and therefore not so useful to us humans
column6: who depend on fresh water to survive (like many
column7: if not all
column8: other species). Desertification (the process by which a fertile piece of land degrades until there is only desert left) happens for a variety of reasons
column9: not in the least because of humans causing deforestation (particularly for agricultural purposes
column10: though also for instance to build fleets of ships in Europe
column11: back in the 16th and 17th centuries and so on). Trees retain moisture deep in the soil
column12: allowing water to stay in one place
column13: feeding the micro-organisms in the soil and allowing other plants and animals and so on to live as well. So a major step in land restoration is to plant trees
column14: which is why I carry so much water around to make sure all the planted saplings and things get to survive out here in the dry
column15: dry sun. From about May til about July there will be lots of rain (the monsoon period) here and then it will be important to try to keep as much of the water as possible here on the land. For this there are also certain techniques
column16: such as the building of swales
column17: check dams and placing rocks lower than the plants and digging higher than the plants so as much of the water will stay around the plants as long as possible. It’s all a matter of designing things so that the natural occurrences will ‘automatically’ allow the area to restore itself.

column2: that should also sorta explain the title of this blogpost. That and the fact that Neurosis are an amazing band and you should all check them out even though 95%!o(MISSING)f you will probably hate them. Oh well. Also check out Shrinebuilder
column3: and Pelican
column4: and The Pixies
column5: and Dead Meadow and Sleep. All excellent desert music.

column1: We have spent the past three days in Mysore. We toured the palace which was built in the early 1900's
column2: and is absolutely beautiful. It is so opulent with colorful murals on the walls and high domed ceilings with carvings and paintings. At night the whole outside is lit up with thousands of lights.Will post some pictures
column3: but unfortunately we were not allowed to take pictures inside.

column2: all good things must come to an end
column3: so now our time in incredible India is done. Words cannot describe the experiences we have had. India is a country of contrasts
column4: from richness and opulence to squaller and rubble. The people are warm and friendly
column5: willing to help and always smiling. We have seen and experienced so much in our short time here
column6: and yet there is so much more. I just may have to come back. Anybody want to come with me?

column1: Thanks for reading and for the comments. See you all soon.

column1: My car fitted with the new BnB bicycle rack
I recently re-discovered a childhood craze of mine. As a kid
column2: I would literally beg anyone I could find with a cycle to lend it to me for a few minutes. Those were not the days of speciality kids cycles (or at least we could not afford one)
column3: so a lot of us would 'half pedal' on adult cycles - yes
column4: the big black heavy ones. Since we did not have one in our house
column5: any guest or neighbour who had one fell victim to my persistent pleading. Well
column6: 30 years later
column7: I can afford a much better cycle
column8: and don't need to plead anyone any more. I makes me wonder why I did not re-start cycling earlier.

column1: Anyway - I got myself a Schnell Jaguar 2.0 MTB about a month ago
column2: and after a couple of 35-40 km rides over the last few weekends
column3: on insistence of my good friend Tatha
column4: we ventured to ride from Bangalore to Nandi hills
column5: about 68 km from my house. Tatha has been cycling for about a year now
column6: and had recently come back from a 130 km trip to Coorg. On the other hand
column7: I had been cycling for only a month

column1: Almost there.. that's my friend Tatha
and had no hill climbing experience whatsoever. Riding the first 60 km on largely flat good roads (with light slopes at times) seemed doable
column2: but I was definitely unsure of the 8 km climb of about a 1000 m. I had read in some blogs that it was a moderately difficult climb (I had NO idea what that really meant - moderately difficult for whom ???)
column3: especially if one is cycling from Bangalore
column4: and not just from the foothills. We'll never know till we try - so we set off one Sunday morning.

column1: Note: This write-up is about my cycle ride to Nandi hills strictly from a beginner's point of view. During the week before the ride
column2: I could not find a single entry which would tell a novice like me as to how difficult or easy would it be. Hopefully
column3: this blog could help a first-timer.

column1: The plan was this: We would start around 5:45 AM from our houses so that we meet around 6:30 AM at Hebbal (about 17 km from my house). We'll then ride to the foothills of Nandi hills
column2: with a break for breakfast in between. After that
column3: we'll try climbing as much

column1: That's me.. almost at the top
as possible. Our wives and kids would join us in cars around 11 AM at Nandi hills
column2: and we'll hitch a ride back. Our cars were fitted with brand new cycle racks for this purpose.
I got almost no sleep the night before as I was too excited about the trip
column3: and also worried that I wouldn't wake in time. After a lot of tossing and turning
column4: I slept only at 3 AM to catch about 2 hours of disturbed sleep before getting up. A strong cup of strong freshly brewed black coffee and a cold shower meant I was feeling absolutely fresh - though I knew that the lack of sleep would take its toll at some point. Anyway - I was off by around 6:05 AM - 20 minutes behind schedule. A note on what I packed with me: A change of clothes
column5: a lightweight cycle pump
column6: about 1.5 l of water (half of it with Gatorade powder) and a couple of energy bars. Of course I had my cycling shorts (the bum-pads are God-sent !!)
column7: gloves and helmet on.

column1: The first section of the ride (17 km
column2: to Hebbal) was a

column1: On the top... Conquered Nandi Betta
breeze. It was nice and cool - empty roads & ideal riding conditions. I made it to Hebbal by 6:45 AM. There I met Tatha
column2: and after around 5 minutes of hamstring and calf muscle stretches
column3: we set off. Riding along NH7 (we did not take the elevated highway) was super-smooth - though some cars & trucks coming on the wrong side was a major irritant. We kept up a good pace of around 28-30 kmph on the flat sections. We planned to have breakfast at the McDonalds just before BIAL
column4: but found it closed when we reached there around 7:40 AM. Damn !! Anyway - we rode on
column5: and just before turning of NH7 towards Nandi Hills
column6: we found a new 'parantha joint'. Being pretty hungry by that time
column7: we devoured a couple of large stuffed paranthas along with a nice cup of steaming hot tea. Well - that was a mistake - as we soon found out. A 'kinda-obvious-on-hindsight' tip to anyone trying this for the first time: Getting enough calories is necessary for a trip like this
column8: however
column9: getting them from oil-soaked aloo paranthas is a BAD idea !!

column1: It took us around 30 minutes to
finish breakfast - we got started and soon took the left turn on Nandi hills road. We had about 15 kms to go till the foothills
column2: and the road was lovely (with gentle up and down slopes). This is when we started realizing our folly - it was REALLY difficult to cycle hard with oily food stuffed in our tummies. The 15 kilos of extra weight that I always carry on my self didn't help matters either!! Yet - we were still high on enthusiasm
column3: and reached the foothills just before 9:30 AM - on time with our original schedule. Less than 3.5 hours for 60 km
column4: including a couple of small breaks and 1 longish breakfast stop. Not bad
column5: we thought. We realised at the same time that the real test lay ahead. I had already cycled the maximum I had ever done in my life in a single day.

column2: we got started for the uphill ride. For a novice like me
column3: and with tired legs
column4: it was tough. Period. I somehow got through the first 1 km - thinking all the time 'how soon till I give up'. Tatha
column5: despite a

column2: kept up the pace ahead of me
column3: and at times stopped to let me catch up. After about 2-3 km
column4: I started feeling a bit more confident (still hating all the aloo paranthas though). When we took a break around the 3.5 km mark
column5: the thought was - 'we are almost halfway - ab to pahunch ke hi rahenge' !! But the toughest section was yet to come. We had to stop once more at the 4.5 km mark
column6: and then again at around 6 km. We walked for a few hundred meters pushing our cycles along to regain our breath - the hairpin bends were tough even though we were down to our lowest gears.

column1: We stopped for a couple of photos - sadly
column2: our first photos of the whole ride. Then with new-found energy (maybe it was adrenalin
column3: or gatorade
column4: or maybe even the much accused aloo paranthas
column5: which kept us going....) we cycled up the last couple of km. ""Phew.... !!"" - was the thought at the gates of Nandi hills.

column1: My wife Payal reached about the same time - thrilled at having her first drive up Nandi hills with our
new Duster AWD. Sadly - 2-wheelers are not allowed on top of Nandi hills
column2: and that includes cycles !!! On second thoughts - maybe I will put a couple of training wheels next time
column3: convert the cycle into a 4 wheeler
column4: and whizz past the security guard !! Stupid rules !!

column1: We parked our cycles - went up to the top in the car. We spent some time on the top though it was pretty hot by then (we reached around 11:10 AM - 5 hours after I started from home). And then was time for the best part of this journey - the CRAZY ride downhill !!😊.. WHIZZZZZZ.. is how we went. I touched a maximum speed of 56kmph
column2: and it was unadulterated fun !!. Some photos were clicked by Aditi (Tatha's wife) this time. In less than 20 minutes
column3: we were at the foothills again.We loaded our cycles on the cars
column4: had a quick picnic of paranthas (home made this time) and chicken curry under the trees
column5: and drove back home. This would be the time to say THANK YOU to Aditi
column6: Payal and Tinai (my sister) for driving up all the way with the kids
column7: bringing

column1: The glee is visible on our faces :)

column2: and driving us back. The trip wouldn't have been half as enjoyable without you guys. Back home.. we downed a couple of chilled beers (yep.. we EARNED them). The evening went in a blur - the thrill
column3: tired muscles
column4: lack of sleep and the couple (ok
column5: more than just 2) of beers making for a heady mixture 😊

column1: Tips for the first timer cyclist to Nandi Hills:
1) Give yourself at least 5 hours (if going on an MTB / Hybrid) including breaks.
2) Start early - maybe around 4:30 / 5:00 AM. The uphill climb would be much better.
3) Do NOT eat oily paranthas / anything heavy just before the climb. Light yet high calorie food is the way to go.
4) Include as many breaks as you have to during the climb - remember
column2: you are not racing. It is the journey that matters. Enjoy - you WILL get there.

column1: 5) Get a ride back home - cycling back 60 more kms
column2: if you are not used to doing ~100 km rides
column3: would be really tough.

column1: 6) if you wondering whether to do it... I'd say.. JUST DO IT.. it is ABSOLUTELY worth the effort. and yes.. I am definitely going back 😊
BTW - this is my first ever blog. If you reach the end
column2: do drop me a note 😊 Constructive criticism welcome !!
note the hoarding
busy and bustling. Actually
column3: make that huge and hectic. We transited through Bangalore last year without seeing anything except one massive traffic jam that lasted two hours
column4: so this time we thought we’d devote a day to seeing the limited sites it has to offer.

column1: But first we have to get here. Google maps had suggested it would take six hours from our peaceful haven in Wayanad
column2: but we know it will be more. The hotel staff suggest it will take 7-8 hours
column3: so we accede to Mr Hussain’s suggestion that we should leave at 7am. We manage this despite a delay caused by the fact that the mobile phone signal is too weak to allow us to pay our bill by credit card and we have to scrabble around to see if we have enough to pay by cash instead. Mercifully
column4: we do – just. The first part of the journey is slow but scenic
column5: as we head out of the Kerala hills. Then we cross the dusty plains of Karnataka. This should be quicker but a 30 mile stretch of road is being rebuilt so the driving is both slow and bumpy. After five hours

column1: we reach Mysore and the road improves. After eight hours we are on the outskirts of Bangalore. ‘Bangalore very big city
column2: very confusing’ mutters Mr Hussain who
column3: to be fair
column4: must be exhausted after so much driving. It takes another hour to reach our hotel. We are all exhausted. Mr Hussain tells us we must find a guide for the next day
column5: as he does not think he can find his way around. He has a point.

column1: We collapse exhausted into our room
column2: have a very early meal and fall asleep. Next morning
column3: the hotel has not succeeded in finding us a guide. We encounter Mr H as we set out before breakfast to find an ATM to replenish our cash
column4: and suggest to him that we hire an auto rickshaw driver to show us the way. When we reappear after breakfast
column5: he has found us a ‘guide’ who will show us around for 500 rupees. Mr Hussain’s good humour is restored and we set off gratefully.

column1: With a local to guide us
column2: the traffic is not as bad as we feared. Our guide knows the one way system
column3: and which roads are closed while the new metro

column2: bejewelled

column1: system is built – a much needed but highly disruptive piece of civil engineering. First stop is Tipu Sultan’s summer palace. This is a much smaller
column2: less ornate version of the one outside Mysore
column3: much of it having been demolished
column4: but interesting nonetheless. A Nandi bull temple follows and then we head to Bangalore Palace. The original building was started by one Reverend Garrett (who was the principal of a local school) in 1862 and bought by the Maharajah of Mysore in 1884 to be their palace in Bangalore (one palace in Mysore was clearly not enough). The Wodeyars were the hereditary rulers of the state of Mysore
column5: within its fluctuating boundaries
column6: from the 14th century. They were periodically deposed by the Deccan sultans
column7: or the Vijayanagar empire
column8: but most famously they lost Mysore to Hyder Ali and his son Tipu Sultan in the 18th century. Those two enlightened rulers were sworn enemies of the East India Company and scored some notable victories over Our Chaps in alliance with the Frenchies. However after Tipu Sultan was defeated and killed by the British at Sriringapatam in 1799
column9: the grateful Wodeyars were reinstated as the ruling Maharajas by the British. They were

column2: complete with Windsor turrets

column1: faithful allies and supporters of the British (or should we say
column2: puppets) until Independence in 1947. The Maharajah recently died childless and a cousin who is also without any heirs is currently holding that position
column3: but this may be the end of the Wodeyar line.

column1: The palace is allegedly modelled on Windsor Castle. It has some turrets and you can sort of see what they mean
column2: but it is stretching the point a bit. It’s interesting enough
column3: but Tripadvisor reviews were right when they say it is a overpriced
column4: but it is rather a sorry Maharaja's palace compared to many in India. We decide not to pay £7 (!!) to take a camera in
column5: and conclude this was a good decision. The design of the palace is a weird mix of styles – Gothic
column6: Tudor
column7: Palladian
column8: Spanish art deco.... you name it! The rooms are mostly devoid of furniture and the whole place could do with some maintenance and TLC
column9: though in has been recently renovated so it must have been in a really dire state. For example
column10: the stuffed elephant head over the entrance door is covered in pigeon droppings
column11: and sections of the ceiling seem to be cracking open. The audio tour tells us the Maharajah was a great art collector
column12: but most of his collection seems to comprise execrable knock-offs of classic art and paintings of big boobied and naked white women
column13: or just lousy paintings. Not the best collection ever.....the whole place looks like it is going to fall apart and short of money.

column1: We seem now to have ‘done’ the main sites of Bangalore. Back at the hotel
column2: Sara has the inspired idea of popping to the McDonalds next door for lunch. We virtually never eat McDonalds at home
column3: but sometimes when travelling it fills a craving you didn’t even realise you had. There was a lot of controversy when they first opened in India
column4: as beef is almost universally not acceptable
column5: so the only options are chicken or veggie. The chicken burger and chips are wonderful.

column1: Asia » India » Karnataka » Bandipur National Park

column2: friends
column3: and others who may be reading this...

column1: Not that it's really a surprise
column2: but I hope you'll all be pleased to know this. Anyway
column3: let me start with a quick overview of what's going on here:

column2: in search of a form of 'right livelihood'
column3: I started studying Regional Development & Innovation (RDI) back in 2012. There I heard about and got interested in permaculture
column4: which lead to my doing a 10-week internship at Quail Springs in California in 2013
column5: as part of my RDI studies. At Quail Springs I met Malvikaa Solanti and Levi Mataga
column6: who have been working on a permaculture project called SwaYYam in South India. After almost a year and a half of 'regular' studying in Wageningen
column7: I contacted Malvikaa to ask if I could do my 20-week internship at Swayyam. As you probably guessed
column8: she said yes
column9: since I'm typing this in the house she's renting near her land in India...

column1: So far I've been here about 4 days. When I say here
column2: I mean India. I stayed at Malvikaa's daughter's place for 2 days and then we drove south through Mysore and Gundlupet to the Bandipur National Forest & Wildlife Reserve
column3: which also includes several small villages. The closest to where I'm at is called Yelachatti
column4: for those of you who wish to google earth it 😉 It's seriously tiny and reminds me of the villages in Hungary my class went to in 2013
column5: with about 20-30 houses per village.

column1: Here's where I wanted to post some impressions of Bangalore
column2: but unfortunately that's not possible right now due to an unstable internet connection
column3: so this thing is going to be picture-less for the time being. Oh well... time to use your imagination (or google images)!

column1: We only really walked around once to buy some things we needed
column2: so there's an immense part of the city completely unknown to me. Basically it's a concrete jungle
column3: complete with palm trees and other exotic foliage! Although the airport was super-neat
column4: the streets are quite littered with trash and during the day there are people everywhere. Also quite a few stray dogs. The traffic is pretty crazy
column5: but I found it easy to get used to. Just be aware of your surroundings (which y'all should be wherever you are anyway). It surprised me more that they drove on the left
column6: although knowing India's history of British occupation
column7: it shouldn't have surprised me at all I guess.

column2: as long as you smile and are friendly to them. I've gotten some stares
column3: though mostly due to my lip piercing. Malvikaa explained that it's common for men to get earrings (somehow it's good for their health) and for women it's mandatory. Women also get their noses pierced and this usually symbolizes that they're engaged or married. So piercings aren't strange
column4: just the placement
column5: which I guess is the same in most places.

column2: I get along great with Malvikaa. And then there's the tiny girl Gheeta who compensates her lack in stature by having the largest smile I've ever seen! Supersweet girl and she's very lucky to get a lot of appropriate support from Malvikaa. Both are also incredible cooks! I have been eating really well (and vegetarian) here and I plan to come back with some great recipes and the knowledge of what to do with them!

yesterday morning we left the house at about 5.50 AM and drove and drove to Bandipur. After we arrived we had lunch and then went to the land. There I met 6 people from Auroville (all but one are Europeans) who have been working for a week on building a wooden house on granite beams that have been dug into the ground. It's quite amazing and will look beautiful I'm sure. Today I got to know them a bit better but also 'met' some Indian guys and helped them in the process of getting a 5000 liter water tank up on a stone construction. I took pictures of all of it.

column1: What else can I write... hmm
column2: I feel very comfortable here and have been considering the reasons. Of course the weather is one (although I'm already sunburnt) though I think it might also feel a bit like 'home'
column3: since so many things remind me of life in Gabon. The friendliness of the people is also very welcoming. Seriously... Europeans have a lot to learn when it comes to just being nice.

column2: that's it for now... oh
column3: fyi
column4: I have no idea how to write a blog
column5: so please gimme tips if you want to hear more about this or that.

column1: Asia » India » Karnataka » Bandipur National Park

column2: and today is as frustrating as yesterday was wonderful. We have been sharing a jeep with a lone Danish traveller called Jakob and a family of three Indians who are regular visitors to the lodge. The son is in his late twenties
column3: touting a pro model Nikon D4
column4: a second Nikon
column5: and a range of massive lenses. It has already become clear that all he wants to see is big cats
column6: pretty much to the exclusion of anything else. We want to see them too
column7: but we also want to be able to stop and watch other animals when we get the chance of a good shot. This morning
column8: he overrules the ranger’s advice on where to go. We see almost no game of any sort and our patience breaks when we spend about ten minutes with him trying to photograph an eagle that is so far away the rest of us cannot see it. We are even less pleased when we get back and find that everyone else saw a tiger.

column2: we and Jakob
column3: our Danish friend
column4: ask to go out with somebody different in the afternoon. The request does not

column1: seem to surprise anyone and we’re allocated to a different jeep. Our guide from the morning comes over and apologises – he was clearly as frustrated as us. In the afternoon we are with a quiet couple who are much better company. We still don’t see any tigers or leopards
column2: although we hear warning calls and pass the largely dismembered corpse of a deer killed two to three days previously. We smell it long before we see it – a horrible rotting stench that takes us by surprise as try to work out where it could be coming from. Only the birds are left eating it now
column3: and we see two different sorts of vulture perched in the trees above
column4: and crows attacking the remains of the head down on the ground.

column1: We are enchanted by a family of langurs. The little ones play boisterously together
column2: and the smallest baby – maybe two weeks old
column3: and black all over
column4: unlike his pale grey parents
column5: practices walking along a branch. He moves a metre away from his mother and then back again
column6: repeatedly. Sometimes he falls off but scrambles back up
column7: and then has a quick cuddle before setting off

column1: Next morning we haul ourselves out of bed for our last game drive. We and Jacob join two others in our jeep and hope that once again there will be just five of us. But at the last minute
column2: another ‘look how big my lens is’ fellow arrives sporting a 600mm lenses
column3: with his son of about 7. A heated conversation ensues with the ranger who then turns to us and asks if we would mind moving to the back of the jeep as the new guy ‘wants both our seats to take photographs’. ‘Er
column4: so do we
column5: and why should we move?’ More heated debate. “blah blah foreigners blah blah” we hear in the Kannada language. 'Are we sure you won't move?' 'Up yours mate’. We begin to think we will never leave but eventually
column6: with much ill grace
column7: he sits in the back (where the view is no worse). Our hopes are raised early on in the drive
column8: when the range spots fresh leopard scat (or shit
column9: as the non naturalist would say). After five minutes
column10: the ranger excitedly shouts ‘leopard’. We crane forward excitedly. ‘Where
column11: where?’ He points to a distant spot in the grass.

column1: We make out an indistinct shape moving through the grass and have to take his word that it was a leopard. We don’t even have time to take any photos. Our hopes remain high for a better viewing
column2: but they come to naught.

column1: We return to the lodge where the occupants of one very full jeep
column2: whom we had pitied for being stuck three abreast
column3: were excitedly telling everyone they had seen three tigers
column4: three leopards and three jackals. Surely they must be having us on? But no
column5: they really did see a tiger with cubs
column6: a leopard with cubs and three jackals. We feel cheated and self-pitying. As we muse on this
column7: we reflect that going on safari requires the three Ps – patience
column8: persistence and phlegmatism. By far the hardest of these is phlegmatism – the ability to accept seeing nothing graciously and without resentment. Even when other people have had truly stunning luck and you have not!! David likens it to being an Everton supporter. You keep paying your money to attend and turning up in the hope that one day you will win
column9: but it rarely happens.

column2: we

column1: leave the lodge and set off for the hills in Wayanad
column2: Kerala. As we leave the game park
column3: Mr Hussain points out an elephant – the best sighting of the morning. And then
column4: just as we get back into the car
column5: he shouts ‘snake’ and we see a huge snake slithering with surprising speed across the road. Once out of the forest
column6: we enter a verdant landscape of bright green trees
column7: bushes and paddy fields
column8: in sharp contrast to the dusty brown/grey of the last three days. The towns here are markedly more prosperous than in Karnataka which one must ascribe to the richness of the agriculture as this is not the Kerala of beaches where most tourists we head (we are not tourists
column9: of course
column10: but independent travellers). The roads are properly made up
column11: with a central white line
column12: and the towns often have unbroken pavements. There are many brightly coloured
column13: substantial villas with fine wooden doors and windows that would not look out of place on the Mediterranean. Our next three nights are at a place described as a boutique hotel
column14: in the hills in the heart of a tea plantation. It is hard to describe where it

column1: is but we eventually find our way there. We wind through ever narrower and worse quality roads as we pass one tea estate after another. Our hotel is perched on a hillside overlooking rolling slopes of tea in all directions
column2: with a view to mist covered peaks beyond. The hotel is newly built and we have a spacious room with floor to ceiling glass on two walls
column3: giving a wonderful view. It is a beautiful and peaceful place to enjoy some downtime.

column2: Displayed: 11

column1: Asia » India » Karnataka » Bandipur National Park
I love morning game drives. Out at dawn
column2: in time to watch the sun come up over the forest. It’s cool but not cold
column3: in the breeze created as you drive in an open jeep. The air is fresh
column4: and smells slightly of smoke
column5: either woodsmoke from the villagers' fires
column6: or from the controlled but now dead fires set along the paths in the forest to improve the chance of seeing animals. So the first ten to twenty feet from the road is dark grey
column7: with a scattering of ash and some lines of white where logs have slowly smouldered out of existence. Beyond that there is sometimes forest and sometimes scrub. The forest consists of mostly spindly trees
column8: well spaced out
column9: with skinny silver trunks
column10: interspersed with some bigger trees with dark bark that looks like it will drop off in clumps. The scrub is grass and thorny bushes
column11: which look impenetrable from a distance but are in fact threaded with numerous narrow pathways created by animals. It’s the dry season
column12: and everything is brown or a dusty green. The teak trees have shed most of their huge leaves
column13: which cover the forest floor
column14: and only the tops of the

column1: bushes have any green left on them.

The first section of this morning’s drive is along the main road that runs through the park. It’s a new experience to share a game drive with lads on motorbikes and the A1 Banana van. Within five minutes we see an elephant right by the roadside
column2: the first wild one we’ve seen in India. After looking both ways (it clearly knows the green cross code) it lumbers across the road and off into the forest. Five minutes later
column3: we hear some alarm calls and stop. Shortly after stopping the ranger shrieks ‘tiger’ and we reverse up to the road in time to watch a large male tiger walk very slowly across the road before vanishing into the undergrowth on the other side. Four cameras click on motordrive. The fastest by far belongs to the Indian guy sitting up front with a pro Nikon and one of the biggest lenses ever seen (complete with camouflage markings in his lens to match the camouflage fatigues he is wearing – what a prat)
column4: who is on autoshoot and will have an even bigger job editing his photos than we face. The tiger is majestic
column5: and

column2: as tigers always are (unless they are maneaters!).

column1: We turn off onto the red dust roads that criss cross the small section of the park open to tourists
column2: and loop round in the hope of spotting the tiger again. But despite a lot of sitting and waiting patiently
column3: he does not appear again. There’s a lot of sitting waiting involved in game drives and it’s always hard to know how long to wait and when to move on. But that is not our choice
column4: by and large – the ranger decides. If you close your eyes as you sit
column5: you can feel the peace of the surroundings
column6: and start to make out a whole range of different bird calls.

column1: We don’t see so much on the rest of the drive – spotted deer (chital - just like you get in Richmond Park)
column2: some sambur
column3: a family of wild boar and a variety of birds. But the pleasure of the drive is partly in the anticipation
column4: and partly in the small things – a myriad tiny cobwebs
column5: white with the dew
column6: on the ground stretched over tiny holes (do the spiders live under ground?)
column7: a

column1: solitary langur monkey sitting at the base of a tree and looking contemplative
column2: the strange site of a termite mound that has been built all the way round a small tree
column3: looking for all the world like a geometric sandcastle that has solidified.

column1: We return to the lodge for breakfast and start the mega-task of downloading and editing the photos before heading out again at 3.45. This time we are on a boat
column2: on the lake formed when the Kabini River was dammed. The lake is now a key part of the park
column3: providing fresh grass which grows in the cracked mud surface left behind when the lake recedes in the dry. In late March (ie just a couple of weeks after we are here) hundreds of elephants will congregate at the lake’s edge to drink and feed on the shrinking grassland available. We don’t see hundreds
column4: but we do have a great view of a group of four elephants who drink from the water’s edge
column5: then slowly walk into the water
column6: spraying themselves all over and wade or swim to the other side before climbing out. There is something very special about elephants
column7: and we could watch them

column2: the boat trip is about seeing birds. We spot an osprey sitting on a dead tree stump eating a freshly caught fish
column3: and an eagle flying past clutching a small bird in its talons. We manage to get photos of a brilliant blue Indian kingfisher
column4: a beautiful small bird that is elusive and hard to capture on film. And we enjoy the breeze and the peace of the water.

column2: we enjoy our first gin and tonic of the holiday. We’re upset to hear we missed a leopard sighting
column3: but that’s the luck of the draw!

column2: Displayed: 8

column1: Asia » India » Karnataka » Bandipur National Park
We set off from Coonoor at 7am
column2: bidding farewell to the oasis that is the Taj hotel. Needless to say
column3: as this is the day we are leaving there is not a cloud or patch of mist to be seen and we enjoy distant views across the Nilgiris. We have to stop after about an hour at a charming spot next to a stinking bus station for the driver to buy yet another permit. While he does so we eat our packed breakfast box given to us by the hotel. Finishing this up David
column4: being British
column5: espies a bin and sets off to put the box into the bin. He finds he has to step his way carefully in his open toed sandals to avoid the cow
column6: dog and human turds along the roadside. Getting to the bin he finds it is overflowing
column7: with two dogs with their heads in excavating the contents and there is no space for the box
column8: so he offers the remains of our breakfast to the dogs. Might as well just have thrown the box out of the car window as the roadside is already covered with litter.....

column1: We sit for a few more minutes

column2: 2 weeks old or so

column1: enjoying the stink of diesel fumes from the belching buses
column2: and survey the groups of huddled people waiting on the corners for the gangmasters to arrive looking for day rate workers. Eventually we set off through the beautiful rolling Tamil Nadu national forest (or something like that). The scent of pine and citronella wafts periodically through the window as we wind down to the valley.

column1: Sara is having some bowel problems. This is every Westerner's dread on an Indian road journey. She manages to render three roadside toilets (one in a petrol station and two in a hotel
column2: which was really antisocial) unusable
column3: but what is a girl to do? There is no running water so you just have to do what you have to do and run away. The fourth toilet defeats her though as many previous users' shit is already piled up to the level of the seat
column4: so after the sight and smell of that her body appears to tell her that she can hold on for now. Nothing other than a bluebottle would want to enter that stall.

column1: The temperature is rising and the journey passes hour after hour. We pass through dusty little
towns. In one town we have to stop to buy the Karnataka permit. A legless beggar sees us waiting in the car and drags himself over on his knuckles to scratch pathetically at the car door
column2: while a wretched looking crone with a baby bangs on Sara's window. We resist the temptation to give out cash. Working Indians greatly disapprove of beggars and get really cross if you give them money. Mr Hussain returns to the car and shoos the crone away. I hope he saw the legless creature and didn’t run over him....I hope the squeal was just our tyres burning on the tarmac and not the cries of a squashed beggar.

column1: Eventually we find the turning off the road to Mysore that we need to find. However now the journey gets a bit tricky as all road signs are now in Kannada not Tamil or Malayalam
column2: and Mr Hussain neither reads nor speaks Kannada
column3: so stopping to check our direction of travel becomes a bit trickier. Eventually we find ourselves driving through Mudumalai Tiger Reserve followed by Bandipur Tiger Reserve (this on the main highway to Mysore!). We scan the forest but see only a couple of

column1: elephants in the distance. At one point a couple of thuggish types flag us down and ask if we would like to take a jeep safari into Bandipur. It seems unlikely they are kosher as they are not in uniform and it is midday when no one goes offroad in the park
column2: and we decline their kind offer.

column1: After six hours we roll into our lodge in Kabini
column2: which was formerly the Maharajah of Mysore's private hunting lodge. It sounds very grand but unfortunately these days it is run as government of Karnataka enterprise. The result is that it is overpriced
column3: the food is bland and unvarying
column4: and the service is what you would expect of a state enterprise. But it is the place you need to stay to be sure of getting on safari. The number of visitors per day is limited so you don’t want to find you are staying in a nice lodge but cannot get into the park! We have a nice cottage fronting the lake; this place could be so much better with private management. Such a shame.

column1: We have arrived though in time for our first game drive that afternoon.

column2: a short rest and then we are kitted up and ready to go out in the jeep. We see a tiger
column3: but it is a long way off in a clearing and our view is somewhat obscured by a tree. Still
column4: it feels like a good omen.

column1: One of the UNESCO world heritage sites
column2: HAMPI is a small village in the northern part ofKarnatakaStateinIndia.

column1: We left for Hampi from Chitradurga afternoon on the last week of December. It took three hours to reach the place.
Hampi is situated on the banks of theTungabhadraRiver. Like Mahabalipuram in Tamilnadu this place also represents the sculptural arts of earlier centuries of the southern parts of the country.
The site remains as the ruins of Vijayanagara Empire. It was part of the capital of this empire in the 14th century.
The major attractions here inter alia include the centuries oldVirupakshaTemple
column2: AchutharayaTemple
column3: HazaraRamaTemple
column4: KrishnaTemple
column5: VittalaTemple
column6: the sacred Tank nearKrishnaTemple
column7: Ganesha Mandapa
column8: UndergroundSivaTemple
column9: AnjaneyaTemple
column10: Elephant Stables
column11: Lotus Mahal
column12: Monolithic Nandi Bull
column13: Tall carved pillars
column14: canals
column15: Aqueducts
column16: Two storied gateway & Tungabhadra river.

column1: In the evening we covered theSivaTemplearea
column2: Royal Enclosure
column3: Fortified walls
column4: WatchTower
column5: the stepped Tank near the underground temple
column6: Elephant stables
column7: etc.

column1: As the trip was shortly planned we were unable to book accommodation in the few hotels available at Hampi or near by town Hospet. Hence we had to cross Tungabhadra to reach Gangavathi
column2: another township around 40 kms from Hampi

column1: where we could book Hotel Sarvesh thru makemytrip. In the night we reached there
column2: had dinner and next day morning returned to Hampi. On the way between the two towns
column3: we could see on both sides of the road various vegetable cultivations
column4: farms
column5: and beautiful meadows.

column1: Next day we moved around the Bazaar area
column2: Hemakunta Hill
column3: Ganesha Mandapa
column4: Kodanda rama &VittalaTemples
column5: Two storied gateway
column6: VirupakshaTemple
column7: etc. Due to shortage of time we had to give up the plan to visit theBearParkin the near by area and by evening we left forBangalore.

column1: The following are some tips which may be useful for a prospective traveler who would like to explore this heritage site:

1.It may take two-three days to cover all the monuments and places in detail as the ruins are vast and spread over large area. Hence either you may plan accordingly or prefer selected items/views after studying the location map.2.Try to fetch accommodation in Hampi itself well advance
column2: which will save a lot of time.3.Carry with you adequate drinking water as no shops are available in most of the parts.4.Eateries are there in the Bazaar area
column3: Mango Tree Restaurant is one

column1: among them. However avoid peak ours for lunch as these small restaurants would be crowded too much and you have to wait outside for long time.5.For those who plan to connect withBangalore
column2: plan carefully as it would take seven hours journey. En route you can visit Chitradurga fort
column3: another heritage site.

column2: Displayed: 11
the ancient capital of the Vijayanagara empire is in ruins in North Karnataka. My cousin
column3: her daughter and I decided it is a must see and jumped into the train headed north from Bangalore.

column1: I had booked air-conditioned railway seats but whole night I was wondering if I did indeed because it never worked. I observed my cousin wrapped up in blanket. It was all in anticipation of coming cool air 😊
We arrived at Hampi in early hours. A co passenger kindly offered us a lift to the main town centre. We booked into a budget hotel
column2: freshened up and ventured to see the ruins. It was very hot. We drank water like fish but it was not enough. Apparently all government approved guides were taken. We looked around into the carvings
column3: temples and other ruins like aliens not making a head or tail. Finally
column4: we took an auto rickshaw driver as guide and he took us around and explained the main monuments of attraction.

column1: The city was once magnificent and prosperous ruled by the Deva Raya kings. It had glorious rock cut Hindu and Jain temples
column2: royal baths
column3: elephant stable
column4: market places and gorgeous gates

column1: among others. The Vitthal temple with musical pillars made of rock is simply unique. The carvings in the temple were exquisite showing daily life of the people
column2: trading of horses with white Europeans
column3: mythological animals and stories from Ramayana and Mahabharat. This place is apparently the birthplace of monkey god
column4: Hanuman and was formally called Kishkinda. The market place with miles forgotten shops which sold gold-silver jewellery in return of horses must have been splendid. Vijayanagar empire was rich and envy of its neighbouring kingdoms who finally destroyed it.

column1: It was Basanti Panchami or day of Saraswati (goddess of learning) pooja (worship). As per Bengali custom
column2: from this day onwards we start eating crunchy jujube berries! Indeed
column3: we bought some and munched our way to Tungabhadra dam. The vast expanse of water in the reservoir appealed like an ocean for a quick swim. The catchment area had been built into agricultural fields and recreation area for children. An ideal picnic spot.

column1: Since our return train tickets did not get confirmed
column2: we bought local bus tickets which hopped and jumped very badly. I guess
column3: it ensured that bus drivers do not sleep at the expense of poor passengers!

column1: These historical places had attained unimaginable heights in different points of history that we were left awestruck. Even the elephants stables were magnificent. If elephants had such a great life
column2: I am sure humans had an awesome time too.
Displayed: 9
Belgavi
column3: Kolhapur
column4: Pune
column5: Mahabaleswar
column6: Ratnagari
column7: Margoa
column8: Yellapur
column9: and back Home.

column2: there's a chance you may never be found. I am lost. And the journey has begun to search self..

column1: It all happened in 48 hours that I planned my first road trip. Googled many options and finally the route was ride to Pune
column2: Mumbai
column3: Goa and back to Bangalore. Got the much needed permissions from my family and friends. Took my bike to the mechanic and told him to check the bike as I am going on long ride. The misunderstanding between us came as tension to me in middle of nowhere.

column1: My first and solo trip did not let me sleep and concentrate on anything. So finally the day arrived - 25th December. Took the blessings from God and Parents and left my home at 3:30 am. Took a shortcut and reached the Nelamangala flyover. I just covered a distance of 10 kms and there it was! the bike showed a warning of low engine oil. I was shocked
column2: standing on the flyover and cursing the mechanic. I calmed myself down and went to the fuel station in Nelamangala.

column1: The ride in the chilling morning was getting awesome
column2: I had my first

column1: tea break in Tumkur. Plan was to reach Kolhapur till 7 pm for stay. Again started my journey on one of the best roads in India the Bangalore-Pune Highway (NH 4). Reached Davangere at around 9 am and went inside the city to have the famous Benne Dose. My next stop was in Hubli for lunch. Took many breaks in between and reached Hubli at 1 pm. Phew! I was already running two hours late. Went to meet our family friend and had my lunch there. Left Hubli at 4pm and reached the broad and beautiful - NH4. I was 200 kms far from my accommodation. So decided to up the speed but the heavy lunch did not allow me to do so. Reached Belgaum around 7pm and decided to halt there.

On 26th Left Belgaum at 8:30 am to cover a distance of 100 kms. By the previous day’s experience I thought I will cover it in 90 mins but after crossing the border suddenly everything changed except the butter smooth road. At 9:30 am stopped for breakfast and felt the hatred from waiter. Was very much concerned by his behavior as I had to spend my next
