five days in Maharashtra. The oncoming traffic took a lot of time to reach Kolhapur. It took 2 hours for me to enter the temple as there was huge crowd. Had my lunch in Kolhapur and after some shopping left for Pune. Saw the warning light of low fuel and was very happy that I covered a distance of 754 kms with 15 liters of fuel. As I reached Satara it became even worse - the mad traffic and the road
column2: and finally reached Pune at 8 pm. It was so nice to see my favorite Mama and Mami.

column1: Went for local Pune ride the next day and found myself like AK in PK. No one was following traffic rules
column2: no helmets
column3: no rules nothing. Saw people staring at me for following regulations. While coming back from MG road a guy in Merc was shouting at me for waiting for traffic light to turn green. Educated illiterate eh!? Spent the next two days in Pune and got much needed rest and most needed sleep.

column2: energy and most importantly money I decided to skip Mumbai and head to Goa.

column1: Panchagani and Mahabaleswar. Visited Ganapati Temple in Wai and started climbing the hill. Reached the next destination by 11 am. Spent some time in city and at various places and left for Ratnagari. Joined Mumbai - Goa highway and reached the city of mangoes by 6 pm and stayed there for the night.

Next day went to Ratnagiri Fort and Ganapatipule temple and beach. Had my breakfast and checked out for the Party Capital around 12 noon. The amazing road and scenic route took a lot of time for me to reach Goa. As expected there was a lot of traffic and the small roads took time for me to reach my uncle’s place.

On 31st went for local sightseeing. Started from a temple called Shantadurga and Mangeshi. And then the churches in Old Goa. Had my lunch in Panaji. In the evening went to Baga and Vagator beach to join the huge crowd for New Year Celebration.
The first day of the new year - 1st Jan 2015
column2: went to Vasco-da-gama and then went to Calangute beach to meet my friend. It was time to head back to Bangalore. Left Margoa at 5 pm and rode

column1: till 9pm and found a room on the highway to spend sleepless nights yet again.

column2: checked out at around 7 am continuing on another superb road from Yellapur to Bankapur. The road goes in thick forest and was very empty. I hardly found anyone using that road. But the 70 kms stretch was superb to ride. Reached the Highway and was waiting to reach home eagerly. On the way back home saw many fellow riders. I had only one traffic signal to deal with. Reached home by 4pm and was very relieved that I made it a safe journey.

column1: It was now time for bike service and got into an argument with mechanic. He thought the long ride will be around 200 kms
column2: but little did he know that I rode 2637 kms in 9 days on my Bajaj Pulsar 220f. Poor him! I was very happy in the end with the bike which gave an average mileage of around 45
column3: whoa! more than what I expected.

column2: I have already started planning for my next Bike trip hopefully with some of my friends.
Displayed: 12

column1: We left Mudumalai National Park at 10.30am and continued our northward journey
column2: this time heading for Mysore. India is often termed the “land of the farmer”
column3: and we could easily see why as we drove through vast expanses of agricultural land of cotton
column4: palm trees
column5: bananas
column6: sugar cane and rice. Every so often we’d drive through a tiny village
column7: but most of the time the rural landscape stretched to the horizon.

column2: trucks and farm animals were sharing very narrow roads with speeding buses
column3: motorbikes and cars – which equated to very dangerous driving conditions. We came across an accident between a bus and a car
column4: but it didn’t appear that anyone was injured.

column1: We dropped into the Chamundi Hill Temple on our way into Mysore. We wandered through the popular and crowded temple
column2: and on the way out I made a donation to the temple and picked up an orange rope bracelet and a red/orange cotton bracelet (which I wore for the rest of our India travels). We jumped back in the minibus and headed towards Mysore
column3: eventually arriving at 2.30pm.

column1: We checked into Hotel KVC International and ordered dahl tadka (cooked lentils
topped with tempered spices) and vegetable shahajahani (vegetable curry) for lunch in Spicy Dine
column2: the hotel’s restaurant. The menu description for vegetable shahajahani was ‘vegetables cooked in semi Indian gravy’. I wasn’t entirely sure what semi Indian gravy was
column3: but it tasted great.

column1: We had a masala chai (spiced sweet milky tea) to freshen up before heading out to Mysore Palace at 4.30pm. We wandered around the impressive but crumbling palace for about an hour
column2: and I was amazed at the skill of the painters who’d managed to paint a cow in one of the frescos whose eyes and face literally followed you as you walked past it. I walked back and forwards past this cow at least three times
column3: and the illusion was extraordinary. Unfortunately we were being led through the palace by a local guide with a bit too much attitude and an enormous chip on his shoulder
column4: and it tainted my experience somewhat. On our way back to the hotel we briefly stopped in at St Philomena’s Church and the Eco-Friendly Incense Sticks Factory.

column1: We had a few drinks in the hotel’s roof top bar before heading out to dinner at the Park Lane Hotel
Restaurant at 7.30pm. We shared an aloo gobi (potato and cauliflower curry) with butter naans (leavened bread cooked in a wood fired oven) and parathas (naans stuffed with potato)
column2: and it was excellent. The combination of potato and cauliflower in a hot curry sauce is just so good. Four of us crammed into an auto rickshaw (motorised tricycle with a passenger cabin) on the way back to the hotel
column3: where we kicked back in the rooftop bar before heading down to the hotel lobby at midnight to access the free wifi. It had been a long travel day
column4: and we were exhausted.

column1: We headed out for a morning walk at 8.30am and unknowingly found ourselves in the midst of Pongal celebrations
column2: a four day festival where families get together to honour the year’s harvest. We realised the day was a little different to most when we met a yellow cow in the street. Cows are honoured for their contribution to the harvest
column3: and this involves colouring the cows yellow. We also passed a number of women creating rangoli (colourful chalk drawings) on the streets outside their houses. We withdrew some rupees from a guarded ATM
column4: stopped at a tiny

column1: cafe (Preethi Sagar) for a chai (tea) and met a few more yellow cows on our way back to the hotel.
We jumped into a minibus at 9.30am and headed to the Keshava Temple in Somanathapur
column2: an hour’s drive from Mysore. We wandered around the temple in the intense morning sun
column3: got a little distracted by a full-on wedding photo shoot
column4: cooled down with a fresh coconut juice and then headed back to Mysore at midday.

column1: On the drive back to Mysore
column2: the tranquillity of rural India slowly gave way to the mayhem of urban India
column3: and this transition continued to amaze me. We headed straight to the Red Pepper Restaurant
column4: cooled down with a fresh lime soda (fresh lime juice
column5: sugar syrup
column6: salt and soda water) and ordered a ‘veg thali’ – with rice
column7: paratha (naan stuffed with potato)
column8: vegetable soup
column9: rasam (spicy tamarind broth)
column10: gobi manchurian (spicy cauliflower stir-fry)
column11: paneer butter masala (Indian cottage cheese curry)
column12: dahl curry (lentil curry)
column13: beetroot poriyal (beetroot fried with coconut and spices)
column14: pickle
column15: curd
column16: and a pappadam.

column1: We finished lunch at 2pm and made our way to Mysore’s fascinating Devaraja Market. We wandered around the market stalls which were

column2: fruits and vegetables before walking back through the city streets to our hotel. We were leaving Mysore at 8.30pm on an 11 hour overnight train to the eastern coast of India
column3: so we settled in the hotel lobby with the free wifi and caught up on our travel notes.

column1: We jumped into a minibus at 6pm and headed out to dinner in the house of a local Mysorean family. They’d prepared vegetable biryani (a spiced rice dish cooked with vegetables)
column2: brinjal curry (eggplant/aubergine curry)
column3: mixed vegetable curry
column4: chicken tandoori (roast chicken marinated with a special spice paste and yoghurt)
column5: and cucumber raita (yoghurt based sauce); followed by custard and gulab jamun (fried doughnut-like milk-based balls
column6: soaked in spiced sugar syrup). It was fantastic
column7: and a fascinating insight into local customs. After thanking our hosts
column8: we clambered into the minibus and headed to the train station.

column2: Mysore Palace was on the way
column3: and its many thousands of light bulbs had been switched on for the Pongal Festival. The Palace was glowing
column4: so we jumped out and joined the throngs of locals who were enjoying the spectacle. I felt like a moth being unwittingly drawn

column1: to a bright light – it was an incredible experience.
We arrived at the train station at 8pm
column2: picked up some snacks and boarded our overnight sleeper carriage for the 11 hour trip to Chennai. I was amazed that we were the only non-locals on the train. Families had settled in with home-cooked meals and children were excited about the journey ahead. It was a warm and friendly atmosphere.

column1: The train left at 8.30pm on the dot. We sat and talked with two young students who were sharing our berth before settling into our bunks at around 10.30pm. The gentle rocking of the train had me asleep in no time.

It was a wrench to leave the peaceful Jungle Retreat in Mudumalai National Park for the four hour minibus ride to Mysore. The jungle landscape soon gave way to Karnataka’s plains and open farmland. We passed fields of banana trees
column2: cotton trees and coconut trees.

column1: The drive was mostly uneventful and I slept for about 90% of it. We were dreadfully behind on writing our blog notes and I had hoped to catch up on the bus trip
column2: but a few late

column1: nights in a row were starting to catch up with us. We stopped at the chain Cafe Coffee Day for hot drinks
column2: but it was the clean toilet that was the main reason for the stop.

column1: Mysore is the second largest city in Karnataka and used to be the royal capital (Bangalore is the State capital now). This was to be our only stop in this State. The main languages spoken in Mysore are Kannada and Hindi.

column2: our minibus wound its way up Chamundi Hill on the edge of town. There were convoys of buses carrying pilgrims up the same hill
column3: and it was a little disconcerting that the buses were full beyond capacity and being driven by complete maniacs.

column1: At the top of the hill we explored Sri Chamundeswari Temple
column2: dedicated to the Goddess Durga. Leaving our shoes in the open air ‘cloak room’ across the street
column3: we had just enough time to enter the temple before it closed. As we squeezed past the gate I realised the ground we were walking on was full of things I wouldn’t like to step in barefoot
column4: but I had to put that out of

column1: It was the first day of the Pongal Harvest Festival and we got a little lost in the hustling
column2: bustling crowd streaming in with their offerings. Crowds like this at first appear overwhelming in India (especially as they are so loud)
column3: but the people were very friendly and just parted to let us through. Inside the temple we made a swift circuit
column4: and I did my best to dodge the priests dishing out blessings for a small ‘donation’. However
column5: Karni organised blessings for all of us which were given with a tilak (red powder marking) on our foreheads.

column1: Outside as we mixed in with the woman
column2: men and children
column3: I was very aware that it was so crowded that I couldn’t see the ground – and when there are cows
column4: dogs and goats around
column5: it pays to always see where you are putting your feet. Andrew and Lee stopped to buy bracelets for us - I picked a black one with red beads
column6: while Andrew picked an orange one for himself.

column2: the view of Mysore was quite beautiful and far greener than I’d imagined an Indian city to look

column1: like. We descended the hill a little way to a nearby statue of a large black monolithic bull (Nandi). The Goddess Durga is an incarnation of Parvati
column2: wife of Shiva
column3: and apparently wherever there’s a connection to Shiva
column4: there’s a bull.

column1: The southern Indian states celebrate the Hindu festival Pongal – a four day harvest thanksgiving celebration in mid-January – to honour the weather gods
column2: the land’s abundance and their cattle. Pongal seems to be associated with many legends
column3: but I like the legend which involves Lord Shiva and his bull Nandi the most. In the legend
column4: on the third day of Pongal
column5: Lord Shiva sent Nandi to tell the people to have an oil bath daily and eat once a month. However
column6: Nandi got confused (as a bull probably would) and told people to eat daily and bathe once a month. This angered Shiva
column7: so he banished Nandi to earth to help the people to toil the ground and produce more food.

column1: On the first day of Pongal (which was our first day in Mysore)
column2: people usually buy new goods and clothes to celebrate the start of a new cycle. The second day is when the sun

column1: god Lord Surya is offered special prayers. People wear their new clothes and decorate their houses with rangoli (floor designs using rice flour and coloured clay - they are called kolam in Tamil Nadu). On the third day the cattle are honoured for their part in farming life – they are washed
column2: rubbed down with a turmeric paste
column3: have their horns painted and are sometimes decorated with flowers. The fourth day is reserved for gathering and celebrating with families and friends.

column1: The main food of the festival is sakkarai pongal – a dish of the season’s first rice
column2: fresh milk
column3: jaggery (a solid product produced from reducing sugar cane juice or palm sap)
column4: coconut
column5: raisins
column6: cashews and cardamom
column7: all of which are boiled to almost a paste. When the milk and rice are boiled in a claypot
column8: if the pot boils evenly on all sides
column9: it’s a sign of prosperity and abundance for the year to come. Given that rice is grown throughout southern India
column10: it’s not surprising that there are so many rice dishes – especially festive rice dishes.

column1: We arrived in Mysore and checked into our hotel – KVC International Hotel. The street was very green

column2: the hotel had huge clean rooms with hot water that worked
column3: but annoyingly
column4: the wifi only worked in the lobby. The biggest let down at this hotel was that the hotel staff were inefficient
column5: slow and uninterested.

column1: We decided to have a quick lunch in the hotel restaurant
column2: but it was anything but quick. We ordered dahl tadka (cooked lentils topped with tempered spices) and vegetable shahajahani (vegetable curry) and rice. A guy with a really bad toupee took ten minutes to take our order
column3: with much repeating
column4: clarifying and more repeating. I was beginning to think we were in a sketch comedy. The food was surprisingly good
column5: but then the bill saga began. It took Andrew 20 minutes to get (and pay) the bill. We later realised that money could only be handled in one area of the hotel
column6: so when the staff ask for the bill
column7: the bill was first generated by a cashier
column8: then walked up or down to the floor we were on
column9: then walked back to the cashier
column10: then walked back to us with our change. How could a business as large as this hotel operate so inefficiently??

column1: disorganised hour that it took us to have lunch and put some laundry in
column2: we headed to the Mysore Palace. Mysore Palace is a product of the Wodeyar Dynasty heritage and is set in huge grounds of courtyards and gardens planted with palm trees. We had to surrender our cameras and leave our shoes in a locker before we gained entry. We were accompanied by a local guide who immediately annoyed most of us with his smartarse sayings and forced
column3: tragic
column4: dad-type jokes. He had clearly memorised his spiel and was put off if anyone interrupted to ask questions.

column1: The palace is supposed to be one of the most ornate palaces in India – its interior was an in-your-face kaleidoscope of coloured glass and mirrors. It was built by the Maharaja of Mysore at the end of the 19th Century and it is a mixture of many styles of architecture and decor. The palace contained a heart wrenching amount of ivory
column2: and more than expected amounts of blingy silver and gold. The most over-the-top items for me were the bejewelled throne and the heavy gold howdah (a seat placed on the back of an elephant with a railing and

column1: canopy)... because apparently the well fed Maharaja wasn’t already heavy enough on the poor elephant’s back. There was a sense that this palace was furnished on the basis that ‘more is better’. If anyone needs a good example of man's inhumanity to taste – we found it! 😊
Even though most aspects of the decor weren’t to my taste
column2: there were some features that were quite stunning. I loved the floor tiles and extensive stained glass in peacock motifs in the Marriage Pavilion. The soaring ornate ceilings and sculpted pillars in the Durbar Hall were eye catching
column3: but I did question the colour choices! And the intricately carved wooden doors throughout the palace were beautiful.

column1: My favourite part of the palace involved the paintings that had been painted with a 3D effect
column2: where the eyes of some of the humans and the heads of the animals followed you from one side of the room to the other – our guide liked calling them ‘the Indian Mona Lisas’. It was impressive enough that a few of us kept walking backwards and forwards to test the theory.
we walked to the large forecourt / parade

column1: ground area for a front-on look at the palace. We arrived at the same time as a large posse of small school girls in matching uniforms
column2: and their teacher decided to send them over to practise their English. So in a very cute chorus
column3: we got roared at... ‘hello!whereyoufromwhatsyourname?’. I disentangled myself out of the scrum of little people
column4: but Kim and a few others were more accommodating of their high pitched squeals.

column1: Mysore was the first place in India to get extensive electricity in the late 1920s
column2: as the then Maharaja had built a hydroelectric power station. To this day
column3: on some special festivals the whole palace is lit up in lights and everyone is welcome to come into the grounds to see it. We were lucky to see this on our last night
column4: as it was lit up for Pongal. It was quite stunning to see all the buildings outlined in thousands of lights. It was packed and we were warned to keep together. I love seeing local people enjoying their own city
column5: especially when tourist attractions in India are beyond the means of most locals (even though they pay much lower entrance fees than foreigners).

column1: On our way back to the hotel we dropped into St Philomena’s Church. I quite liked this church
column2: but there were quite a few people praying and I didn’t wish to intrude
column3: so I didn’t look around as much as I wanted to. As with most churches we've seen in India so far
column4: it was very apparent that it could have done with some general repairs - and it was good to see that there was a fundraising board outside for this cause.

column1: Mysore is known for its incense
column2: so we expressed an interest in visiting an incense factory. To say it left a bad taste in our mouths was an understatement... we walked into a small
column3: cramped space off a little laneway and there were two people sitting on the floor rolling incense sticks at an alarmingly fast rate. One was an older woman of about 70
column4: and the other a girl of about 20 or less. There was something very wrong about the guy running the place
column5: and we all felt it. He sourced his workers from orphanages and other welfare organisations
column6: and he claimed the workers were paid regardless of the number of incense sticks they

column2: but I could tell by the young girl’s face that this wasn’t true. We might be wrong and he might have been a nice guy
column3: but it speaks volumes that almost all twelve people in a group were creeped out by him. I was glad that no one bought anything from his business.

column1: The usual suspects gathered for pre-dinner drinks at our hotel’s bar before our minibus drove us to Park Lane Restaurant for dinner. The rooftop restaurant setting was quite lovely and we had an enjoyable meal of aloo gobi (potato and cauliflower curry) with butter naans (leavened bread cooked in a wood fired oven) and parathas (naans stuffed with potato). We caught auto rickshaws (motorised tricycles with a passenger cabin) back to the hotel
column2: had one last drink in the hotel bar before calling it a night.

Andrew and I went for a walk around the hotel to find an ATM. We asked the bank guard for a chai (tea) stall recommendation and he pointed us in the direction of a small street just off the main road. The smaller streets were yet to awake and it was a nice quiet

column1: walk. It was the second day of Pongal
column2: and of the few people out and about
column3: women were drawing rangoli designs on the footpaths in front of their houses while men were congregating at the chai shops.

column1: Preethi Sagar Cafe was a busy little hive of a place with a constant stream of breakfast customers
column2: but we weren’t hungry so we sat with our glasses of chai and people-watched. As was the case in all the smaller shops and cafes we went to
column3: I was the only female present.

column1: Later that morning we drove out into the countryside an hour from Mysore
column2: to the Keshava Temple in Somanathapur. On the way we passed more farmland
column3: mostly just-harvested rice fields that cattle were now being grazed on.

column1: Keshava Temple is a beautiful example of Hoysala temple architecture from the 13th Century. It is enclosed within a high wall
column2: and we entered the rectangular complex through a room with tall pillars. The temple is made of soapstone that has aged to a warm grey. While it is no longer active
column3: the temple was once dedicated to Vishnu. There are three shrines which contained a statue each – two of

column2: but the third was ‘taken by invaders’. Our guide was quite good and seemed to enjoy his job. It was a public holiday for Pongal
column3: so the guide’s wife and three children joined us for the tour
column4: and they were dressed in beautifully colourful festive clothes.

column1: The Hindu faith is a way of life for most Indians
column2: and our guide seemed determined that we grasped the basics of the religion – a religion characterised by millions of gods/goddesses and reincarnation leading to a better life. We learned about Brahma
column3: Vishnu and Shiva
column4: along with their wives and children.

column1: The three shrines have a striking star shaped design with highly decorative towers above them. The outside walls are covered in panels with decorative bands of friezes and carved reliefs. The panels have sculpted swans
column2: yalis (part lion part horse mythical beasts)
column3: horsemen and a procession of elephants at the bottom. The other walls depicted detailed epics and stories from Hindu texts which were intricately and beautifully carved. The main hall
column4: the three shrines and their associated rooms were all as decorative as the outside walls.

column1: I liked these carvings more than many I’ve seen

column2: as they weren’t painted in garish colours. There was a symmetry and balance to the overall design that I loved
column3: and there was also a very lovely ambience to this place. I think I would rate this as one of my favourite Hindu temples to date! 😊

column1: On the way back to Mysore we stopped at the Red Pepper Restaurant for lunch. We all ordered the ‘veg thali’
column2: which came with rice
column3: paratha (naan stuffed with potato)
column4: vegetable soup
column5: rasam (spicy tamarind broth)
column6: gobi Manchurian (spicy cauliflower stir-fry)
column7: paneer butter masala (Indian cottage cheese curry)
column8: dahl curry (lentil curry)
column9: beetroot poriyal (beetroot fried with coconut and spices)
column10: pickle
column11: curd and a pappadam.

column2: we visited the central Devaraja Market that specialised in fruit
column3: vegetables and flowers. It was a riot of colour! My camera couldn’t keep up with the pace at which the market moved. The flower market was like nothing I’ve ever seen. There were whole rows of stalls that were dedicated to selling one or two specific flowers
column4: and the negotiations between the merchants were loud and swift. The walkways were narrow and manic with men hurrying past with multiple

column1: sacks on their backs or garlands of marigolds stacked high on hand carts. Andrew’s tall frame isn’t easily missed in an Asian market
column2: but I frequently lost sight of him in the hustle and bustle. I’m not sure if the market is always that busy or if it was more hectic because of the Pongal festival.

column1: We were catching an overnight train that evening
column2: so our group was using two day rooms until we left. We got back to the hotel
column3: showered and organised ourselves for the onward journey.

column1: We had been invited to an early dinner at a local family home. The table for the thirteen of us took up the entire living space in their house. The couple’s two grown daughters had come over to help cook for us. Pressure cookers hissed and whistled in the kitchen
column2: a sound I associated with my parent’s kitchen in my childhood. The meal was simple but delicious – an incredible vegetable biryani (a spiced rice dish cooked with vegetables)
column3: brinjal curry (eggplant/aubergine curry)
column4: chicken tandoori (roast chicken marinated with a special spice paste and yoghurt) and cucumber raita (yoghurt based sauce). If truth be told
column5: I’m not a fan

column1: of biryani... I find it dry and a bit ‘meh’
column2: and the only time I really enjoyed it was in Malaysia
column3: where they ‘flood’ the biryani with curry sauces. However
column4: this version of biryani was quite moist and tasty. For dessert we were served a very sweet custard and gulab jamun (fried doughnut-like milk-based balls soaked in spiced sugar syrup). I haven’t talked about Indian desserts yet – they have coma-inducing amounts of sugar in them
column5: so I’ve only been having a small serving – which is a first in all my travels!

column1: On the way to the station we dropped in to see the lights of the palace before continuing on to catch the first of our two overnight trains in India. We got to the station and joined the masses of people rushing to get night trains to different destinations all over the country. I was pleasantly surprised that the Indian railway system was nowhere near as decrepit or disorganised as I had read it was.
Our packs fitted neatly underneath our seats. I’d heard of thefts on the trains
column2: so if our packs had been too big to shove under the seats
column3: I would have

column1: shared my bed with my bag rather than leave it sitting in the walkway – one of the advantages of having short legs. 😊
The overnight train from Mysore to Chennai was supposed to take 11 hours. It was our sixth overnight train in Asia
column2: but it was a first for some members of our travelling group. We were in second class 3AC
column3: which was an air-conditioned carriage with berths containing three bunks on either side of the wall and two bunks opposite in the walkway. This is the first time we’ve had triple bunks
column4: and I’m not sure which bunk I prefer. However
column5: the top bunk is the most private
column6: and you can lie down whenever you want to as it’s a standalone bunk. During the day the middle bunk is folded up and the bottom bunk acts as a seat for all three occupants. So depending on who you’re sitting with
column7: you could be relegated to lying in your bunk very early in the journey rather than sitting comfortably until you’re ready to sleep. The ‘ladder’ for the upper bunks consisted of two very small rungs that jutted into the walkway
column8: and in 3AC the top bunk

column1: was pretty high... I’m surprised no one had an accident on descent. Andrew and I got the two bunks in the walkway
column2: so the politics of the three bunk system didn’t apply.

column1: Having learnt my lesson from overnight trains in Vietnam
column2: I packed a few layers of clothing and a warm jacket for when the aircon was cranked to ‘arctic’. However
column3: this train kept fairly warm all night. Sheets
column4: pillows and blankets were provided and looked clean enough
column5: but I’d packed my own tiny silk sleep-sheet which was very comfortable. I did a bit of writing in my upper bunk
column6: but I drifted off to sleep as the train picked up speed and started swaying a bit. I woke up once during the night when the train stopped to pick up passengers
column7: and the next time I woke was at 5am when we were nearing Chennai.

column1: I was a little concerned about the stories I’d heard about ‘train mice’
column2: and I can confirm that they do exist. I only saw one
column3: and I had no other option but to ignore it and hope it didn’t pop into my upper bunk during the night! We’d already been warned about

column1: not carrying any food in our packs or leaving any food on the floor.
Having had many conversations with friends and family about train toilets
column2: I’d like to report that the toilets weren’t nearly as horrible as I’d imagined. They were ok-ish to begin with
column3: but Andrew reliably informed me that they were a bit ‘messy’ as the trip wore on. As per my usual way of coping with train toilets
column4: I tried not to drink too much
column5: but I get headaches from being dehydrated
column6: so I just had to get over it. As with most things
column7: the reality is never as bad as the perception
column8: and they really weren’t that bad when I used them at 5am. However
column9: I think I went through a week’s supply of wet wipes and hand sanitizer in that one trip to the toilet.

column1: If you want some ‘toilet tips for moving trains' – shoes are always better than thongs (flip flops) for obvious reasons; tight fitting leggings or trousers are better than floppy/baggy ones; and the squat toilets are far cleaner than the western-styled toilets. But let’s face it – neither option is going to be a very pleasant experience. But
I lived. And I didn’t get Ebola. 😊
Our next stop is Chennai (Madras) on our way to the seaside village of Mamallapuram on the east coast of Tamil Nadu.

column2: although I have traveled alot but never thought of sharing my thoughts. I don’t know what drove me to write but I decided let’s start sharing my thoughts. So we 5 friends took self-drive car from Zoom cars and on 27thDec2014 midnight we left from Bangalore. We took the following route to reach Kemmanagundi

column1: After Tumkur one needs to take a deviation from NH-4 and join NH-206.The traffic on this highway was relatively less compared to others. There is a stretch of 130km which is single lane and very beautiful. Around 4am we stopped in between on the highway and all of us shared all our experiences about life and one of our friend is singer who sang beautiful songs. Then we started again at 5am and then at Kadur we had tea. We then proceeded towards Birur
column2: where one has to take a deviation towards left which leads to Lingadahalli. The road condition starts to deteriorate once the deviation is taken at Lingadahalli.This is the point where one can start getting the glimpses of the Kemmanagundi. One can see cloud covered hills and valleys creating a very beautiful view. The pollution free
the chilling

cool breeze added the excitement. After Lingadahalli one needs to take left turn on Sh-57 and follow the Karnataka tourism boards. We had already booked a home stay “Kanthi niwas” for us. The owner James was a very courteous man. We had our breakfast and then headed towards Kalhatti falls.

column1: Kalhatti falls are situated in village named as Kalhattipura. The water here comes from height of 100+ meters in front of Veerabhadreshwara temple. One can see three elephants carved on the rocks right in front of the temple
column2: over which the water falls. We then went to the top of the falls through the stone steps placed next to the falls to get view of the falls. There was very less water however we even enjoyed there and then returned back to our home stay to have our lunch and then we got ready to head towards Kemmanagundi hills.

column1: We headed towards Kemmanagundi hills which were around 15kms from our home-stay. The road leading to Z point was really steep and had bad patches in between. We reached there in 45 minutes to enjoy the beautiful sunset
column2: watching

column1: the changing color of sky from orange to red to dark. The serene beauty and beautiful sky took our heart away. There is a Government guesthouse at that point. We then went back to our home-stay which took around 40 minutes to reach. James had arranged bonfire for us
column2: we sang
column3: danced had our dinner and then slept.

column1: Next day morning we had our breakfast and we enjoyed cycling for some 4 to 5kms and played badminton and then headed back towards Bangalore.

column2: Displayed: 5

column1: Where should we stay in Bangalore? We had 2 options: a B&B which sounded quite promising bang in the middle of the town or a very promising B&B in Whitefield that was much cheaper and
column2: to top it
column3: one of the 30 most charming B&B in India (according to Conde Nast Traveller). We took the one that offered us a bed first with a lovely email: the Villa Camelotin Whitefield. And yes
column4: living far out of the town was a disadvantage. But we were so lucky to have stayed in Villa Camelot - the advantages outweighed the disadvantages. Well
column5: I will start from the beginning....

column1: To reach Bangalore from Mysore is easy. Just go to the Central Bus Station in Mysore. There are buses departing nearly every 5 minutes. Within 2 hours we reached Bangalore and immediately got a first taste of what this city is about: constant traffic jam! It took us another hour to reach the centrally located bus terminal. We got of our bus and asked around for local buses in the direction of Whitefield. We had no idea where exactly our B&B was located. Whitefield is the IT area of Bangalore with lots of high tech industry
as well as some excellent malls
column2: restaurants etc.. It is quite a leafy area
column3: but round about 16-20 ks away from downtown. We just knew this and had the address. So we wanted to reduce the rickshaw costs by simply covering most of the way by public transport. It was not a major problem. We found a Whitefield bound bus. The bus driver told us to get off at a certain point. And we were trying to get a rickshaw. That was difficult as all drivers obviously wanted to ripp us off. But with some patience we found a nice driver who even called our hosts and brought us there safely and by using the meter! A lucky punch. We were welcomed by the hosts Yamini and Raghu with a big hug
column4: huge smiles and a steaming cup of hot chai. It was the warmest welcome we have ever had by arriving in an accomodation! And what an accomodation it was! Really nice decorated
column5: all perfectly clean and our room was just amazing: huge
column6: a great bathroom and an amazing shower. We did not get a key
column7: as the room was simply part of the family house where we had

column1: a room with a bathroom. By stepping outside the room we were standing in the family living room and the kitchen. We were so happy to have chosen this place. For the rest of the afternoon we just relaxed by talking with our hosts. Amazing
column2: how similar minded we were. Sometimes one has to travel half way around the globe to find some soulmates :-). The day went by
column3: we made so amazing new friends and we still had no idea what to do and see in Bangalore. But we did not care. We all had dinner together. And had a perfect sleep in the comfy bed without any stains or bedbugs. Also next morning we took it slowly. After a great breakfast
column4: Raghu drove us the 2 ks to the next bus stop. It was sunday
column5: so it took us only 1 hour to reach town. We got off the bus close to the Garuda Mall. After so many spiritual place where we have been in the last days
column6: we really enjoyed some extensive shopping experience. We walked around the MG Road area
column7: a really beautiful part of Bangalore: new shopping malls for the middle class
column8: tree lined streets

column1: with our hosts Yamini and Raghu @ Villa Camelot in Whitefield
and clean streets! There were lots of fantastic restaurants and bars. Wow
column2: this was a totally different part of India which we had not seen so far. This is modern India where even the girls walk around in short trousers. We also enjoyed the atmosphere of the city. It is ruled by business
column3: but somehow people are relaxed
column4: well educated and friendly. For lunch we managed to get a table in the famous and delicious Queen's Restaurant in Church Street. We had some typical south indian treats with veggy curries
column5: dhal and fluffy and hot chapathi. YUMMY!

column1: After lunch we walked around the Vittal Mallya Road area (Grant Road). Wow! Now we believe what we have heared so often: in India
column2: there are living the poorest people as well as the richest people in the world. Well
column3: we were walking among the richest part of Bangalore for sure. We visited the richest mall where we have ever been before (the Trump Center in New York is nothing against that). In our backpacker clothes we truly felt like being at the wrong place. But it was amazing for people watching. And the toilets were wonderful (I never believed I would

column1: ever say this about a toilet in India ;-)). Later we walked through the leafy Cubbon Park and passed the State Central Library
column2: the Attara Kacheri (High Court) and the Vidhana Soudha (the government of Karnataka). All these were fantastic colonial buildings. Slowly we made our way back to MG Road and caught a bus back to Whitefield.
Monday
column3: we naively thought to be back in town by bus in 1 hour. Well
column4: it took us 2 hours! By midday we got of the bus in the Chickpet area. This is the wholesale area of Bangalore with old houses
column5: narrow streets full of little lorries and rickshaws. It is busy
column6: busy
column7: busy. In the beginning we did not know how to take it all in. It was too much for our senses. But after a while it was great fun. We walked along the streets
column8: visited some of the little shops til we finally reached Krishnarajendra Market
column9: the oldest and busiest market in Bangalore. It was really old
column10: but so wonderful. No need to mention that it was packed with people.... We continued with a visit to the old Fort of Bangalore and the Tipu Sultan's

column2: it was already quite late
column3: so the beautiful Venkataraman Temple (a Vishnu Temple) close to the Sultan's Palace was already closed. We took a rickshaw back to MG Road - and it took us 1 hour to cover the 6 ks. The traffic is unbelievable in this city. The streets are simply full with all means of transport. We had a quick bite to eat before we took a bus in the direction of Whitefield again. But this time we got off at the Kempfort Shiva Temple (which is about half way). This is a very special and beautiful Shiva Temple right behind a huge mall. We spend one hour in the temple. And then it was time to meet a friend. We met Shilpa in Madikeri for the first time at the Abbi Falls and later that day again in a temple in town. We became Facebook friends. When we wrote her that we are in Bangalore where she lives
column4: we quickly found time to meet again. Together with a good friend of her
column5: Niharika
column6: we 4 went for dinner in a restaurant. Later we were invited to Shilpa's home to meet her mum and her brother.

column1: modern indian ladies on MG Road
It was a great evening and the 2 ladies took great care of us. They even drove us around carefully on their scooters! Herewith we want to thank them again for the lovely evening!
On our last day in Bangalore we went again back to town by bus. OK
column2: again it took us nearly 2 hours to reach the town. This time we went to the Commercial Street
column3: a fantastic shopping street with small shops galore! Unfortunately
column4: it was already too late to visit the Bangalore Palace. We skipped this one. instead we took a rickshaw and went to the Iskcon Bangalore. We both enjoyed the Iskcon temple in Mumbai a lot. The Bangalore temple is much bigger. And it is extremely beautiful. The walls and the ceilings are made of pure gold - and they are not covered with gold
column5: it is solid gold! The murthis (statues of the deities) are also amazing! Wow
column6: we were speechless. We spend some time there for meditation and an aarti. Then it was time to get a rickshaw to the central bus terminal and the bus to Whitefield. To reach our home it took us 3 hours! By that

column1: time we were really fed up with the traffic. We love Bangalore. Although there are not many touristic spots to visit
column2: there are a lot of different things to see. We love these kind of cities where there is not much to do from a touristic point of things. But when you follow the suggestion of the locals it is a fantastic city. We had a fantastic homestay
column3: met so many wonderful people. But the traffic is so horrible!

column1: Bangalore has showed us a different kind of India
column2: a modern face. In between our travels we were shocked so many times about the way even young people still think positively about the arranged marriage
column3: about a lot old society rules and a lot of society pressure. These surely may exist in Bangalore as well. But there are a lot of well educated
column4: very open minded young people that create the future of India in a very positive way. One can feel that they want to break out (and they do break out) of this pressure. And what is wonderful to observe
column5: they are very proud to be part of a modern
column6: forward looking India.

column1: lot to see in Bangalore and we will come back for sure one day. Especially
column2: to visit our new friends again who made our stay great (despite the traffic)! For sure
column3: staying in the middle of town would have saved us a lot of hours on the bus
column4: but we would not have met so amazing people! Thank you so much guys!

column1: Become a fan on Facebook: http://on.fb.me/oRswdi

column2: Displayed: 28
an old car and a cow combined with lots of people around

column1: We thought it was a great idea to go to Chamundi Hill on New Year's Day. Well
column2: we were not really the only ones having this idea. To put it shortly
column3: Chamundi Hill was packed with people! We decided to take the foot trail up the hill. 1000-plus steps were awaiting us..... and lots of other pilgrims. Most pilgrims blessed each step with some kumkum (red and yellow powder). We just tried to make our way up quietly which was difficult with lots of people wishing us a happy new year and wanting to shake our hands. We did not want to be rude and started to play the game with them. But after I do not know how many people and pictures we gave up. We really felt extremely bad but there was no chance to arrive on top of the hill in 1 day with being friendly to all the people. After 2/3 of the way we arrived at the huge statue of Nandi
column4: Shiva's bull. It is a really impressing statue being carved out of a solid rock in 1659.

column1: The platform on top of Chamundi Hill was full with people
column2: sellers
column3: cows and cars.

column1: As we have been here a year before we were not too shocked and made our way to a swami who was giving some blessings. We received our blessing and then decided to buy an express ticket to enter the temple. Without an express ticket we would have had to wait for 3 hours in a squeezed queue. Still it took us about 40 minutes to enter the temple. Once in the temple
column2: it was a fight to receive the darshan of the devi with all the people pushing and squeezing each other. But we were lucky and even got some space to stand still in front of the deity. Again outside
column3: we relaxed with a fresh coconut in the shade before making our way to 2 other temples on the hill. These ones were beautiful but small and both of them really packed with people. In one temple I was squeezed in between a door and people; I could hardly breeze any more and I gave up. This is crazy! Finally we had enough of the crowd and took a public bus down the hill and back to downtown Mysore. We had a relaxing lunch on a rooftop terrace

column1: overlooking Gandhi Square. Fresh fruit juices
column2: kofta
column3: curries
column4: kulchas and dal - what a start of the new year. In the afternoon we just walked around the little streets in Mysore and took in the wonderful atmosphere of this amazing city. As we had already been to the palace a year ago we really took it easy this time. A visit to the Philomena's Cathedral and a walk over the Devaraja Market was enough tourist activity for us. For the rest of the day we went shopping. In the evening we had dinner at the famous RRR Hotel. The Thali is really good and cheap - but it is extremely spicy! So if you decide to check it out
column5: be prepared!

column1: The next day we were longing for getting out of the busy city again. We needed some country quietness again. We took a bus from the public bus stand to Jakkanahalli from where we took a rickshaw up to the pilgrimage village of Melkote. Melkote is a devout Vishnu pilgrimage village. It is home to the 12th-century Cheluvanarayana Temple with its rose-coloured gopuram (gateway tower). It is a really peaceful town and we loved it instantly
Nina doing some pranayamas on the hill in Melkote - a perfect place

when we arrived. Each house is decorated with the symbols of vishnu and nearly all people walk around having the vishnu tilak on their forehead. We bought some offerings for a pooja at a stand from a friendly lady outside the Cheluvanarayana Temple. She put some flowers in my hair - she was so cute and lovely! Then we went into the temple. It was nearly empty! A wonderful temple with lots of great carvings and pillars. The deities were extremely beautiful. We made our pooja
column2: received prasad (blessed food) and could quietly meditated. Finally we sat down on the floor as 2 ladies were singing some bhajans. It was very atmospheric and we enjoyed it very much. After the temple visit we walked around the village which is really small. As the other temple up on the hill was closed around lunch till 5pm we had a lot of time. And it was obvious that there is not much to see and to do in the village. So we first tried to find a place for having lunch. That was quite difficult. We discovered 2 restaurants and some small
column3: dirty street food stalls. As one restaurant was empty and

column1: start of the stairs up to Chamundi Hill

column2: we went to the New Sampathkumar Restaurant. Some families were having lunch there - a good sign. It was a simple
column3: dark but clean place. There was just one dish: a veg thali. Perfect! No spoons
column4: no fork - it was time to eat with our fingers. And the thali was delicious. And a lot! For less than 2$ we were really full and happy! After lunch we relaxed a bit at the Kalyani. A crew was filming a bollywood movie there and we just watched all the people watching the filming. It was good fun. Finally we walked up the hill to the old Yoganarashima Temple. We still had 1 hour left till the temple opened again. So we sat down
column5: enjoyed the views over Melkote and the surrounding hills
column6: meditated and slept a little bit. Also this temple was beautiful with only few people around. It is a very old temple and really difficult to maintain. All offerings
column7: water and so on has to be carried each day up the steps! I was really worth visiting this village which is far away of the beaten track and it even happened to us that

column1: people blessed each step on their way up to Chamundi Hill
people wanted to touch our skin as they had never seen white people before. ;-)
The bus ride back to Mysore took us again 1
column2: 5 hours. We had a last dinner before we packed our backpacks again. It was time to move on. Our next destination: Bangalore!

column1: Visit our website: http://www.holamundo.ch/ Become a fan on Facebook: http://on.fb.me/oRswdi Follow us on Twitter: http://twitter.com/NinaundMarkus

column2: Displayed: 26

column1: the resting place of the legendary Tipu Sultan
column2: his father and his wife

column1: Leaving Hassan after our great day in Shravanabelagola our next destination was Mysore
column2: a city where we have been before (here is our last blog of Mysore). We had an Ok place to stay last time in Mysore but this time we wanted to be a bit closer to town. That is why we ended up in the famous MB International Hotel. It was indeed close to town
column3: just a 10 minutes walk away from the Central bus stand. We were welcomed very friendly - our room was small but looked clean and ok. We were relieved as we had booked 4 nights here. We went for a quick walk around town and a bite to eat for dinner. As we had planned a special trip for the next day
column4: we went to bed early - well
column5: we tried to! When we entered into our room and switched on the lights we saw some small bugs running around in the bed. The very first time on our trips: bedbugs!!!!! We quickly killed the 5 bugs we saw and went down to the reception. They immediately offered us a new room
column6: were very friendly and even helped us to move our unpacked stuff. You can immagine - in the

column1: next room we carefully checked the matrasse and the sheets
column2: but everything looked fine. We were just very lucky that we discovered the bedbugs before going to bed! The rest of the night was quiet and bugfree ;-).

column1: The following day we got up early
column2: had a quick breakfast and went down again to the bus stand to catch a bus to Srirangapattana which is about 16 km away from Mysore. You can get on all the Bangalore bound buses which depart like every 5 minutes. So that was easy. After 40 minutes we arrived in Srirangapattana. Our reason for visiting this historical fort town was not its bloody history but the Sri Ranganathaswamy Temple. For the deity of Sri Ranganathna
column3: a manifestation of Mahavishnu (it is the lying form of Narayana) there are only five sacred sites of worship in India. They are together called Pancharanga Kshetram. One of theses places is this temple.

column1: We entered the historical part of town by foot through the fort walls. First we came across the beautiful Jamia Masjid
column2: a cream-coloured mosque with 2 minarets. There
column3: you can walk upstairs and enjoy a nice view over the

column1: area. Unfortunately the weather was quite cloudy. We kept walking and passed Tipu's place of death (the place where famous Tipu Sultan was found after he had died). It is a peaceful little garden. Close by were the old police headquarters and the Water Gate. We continued our walk to Colonel Bailey dungeon where we sat down at the river observing the locals: kids were playing in the water
column2: women doing some washing
column3: some guys were cleaning themselves and others were washing dishes... From here it was a quick walk to the temple. We bought some offerings for the pooja and went in. Luckily
column4: it was not very crowded. We had to wait in a queue for 20 minutes but without much hassle and much pushing. The temple is really beautiful with a huge statue of Sri Ranganathna. Actually the statue is a manifestation and not made by men! Really impressive! A swami made the pooja for us and we could feel a lot of power and energy this time. We even found some space to quietly sit down and meditate. It was really a wonderful experience. Inside
column5: there was also a temple for Mahalakshmi
column6: the goodess of inner and

column1: outer wealth and health. We could also do a pooja for her which was amazing. With many blessings and a really great experience we relaxed a little bit in the temple garden. We walked around the temple clockwise 1 time - this burns karma! And it is always good to loose some ;-)...... This was really the first temple
column2: where we quietly could spend our time. Amazing!

column1: After leaving the temple it was time for lunch. As everything is really spread out in Srirangapattana
column2: we took a rickshaw to the Mayura River View Hotel. That was an excellent choice for having lunch. They have a nice terrasse overlooking the holy river Cauvery. The atmosphere was tranquil and peaceful
column3: food was decent and later we could sit along the river and enjoy the sound of frogs. But
column4: as there is more to see
column5: we took the chance to visit some more places. First
column6: Tipu's Summer Palace. It is a nice palace in a beautiful garden. But from the outside it is far less impressive than the Mysore Palace. Anyway
column7: the interior which is made of 90% painted wood
column8: is really amazing. Our last stop of the day was

column1: entrance to the fort town of Srirangapattana

column2: where Tipu Sultan is resting together with his father and his wife. The building is amazing and also the nearby mosque Masjid-E-Aska is worth a visit. As we walked to most of the sights we were really tired. We went back to the bus stand by rickshaw and quickly got a bus back to Mysore.

column1: And it was new year's eve! So we had a quick shower and went down to town. There was nothing happening in town for new year's eve. Just some big hotels were having crazy parties where one could spent a lot of money. So we decided to have dinner in the tourist spot: the Parklane Hotel. Food is a bit expensive here
column2: but the atmosphere is nice
column3: the guests were totally mixed (some locals
column4: some tourists) and we met a german lady. We talked
column5: exchanged some travelling stories.... - till finally it was midnight. We welcomed the new year with some ginger tea! Wow
column6: how healthy do we live in the meantime ;-)! The funny thing was that 10 minutes after midnight
column7: the restaurant was closing already. So we even had an early night
column8: as the streets were quiet and

column1: selling fish in the plain heat without cooling
we are happy to be vegetarians...
really nothing was going on. New Year's celebration in Mysore is not a big deal - even the palace was not lightened.

column2: it was a great day to end the year 2014 and a nice and quiet start into 2015. Let's see what the new year has in store for us.... More about our time in Mysore soon...

column1: feet of the Gomateshwara statue in Shravanabelagola
After our ""shithole experience"" in Halebid (read in our last blog entry)
column2: we did not feel like staying overnight in another pilgrimage town. Furthermore
column3: the sleeping options in Shravanabelagola sounded
column4: well let's say
column5: limited. Most of the guesthouses are for pilgrims and are rented by the local jain organisation for as little as 210 rupees for a double. So we made the trip to Shravanabelagola from Hassan in 1 day - and it was a perfect decision. But as this place was an extraordinary place for us
column6: we feel like giving it some space in an extra blog.

column1: Why did we chose to go to Shravanabelagola? On this trip we wanted to visit some smaller
column2: remoter places around Mysore as this area is considered to be kind of a holy area with lot of sacred places and a special energy. Shravanabelagola was supposed to be one of these places. It is famous for the huge
column3: 17.5m-high statue of the Jain deity Gomateshvara. The statue is said to be the tallest monolithic one in the world and it is carved out of a single piece of granite.

column1: To get there was quite easy. Well
column2: very
column3: very few western tourists come here
column4: but lots of indian

column1: Markus and some random indians taking pictures of us

column2: the bus connections are perfect. From the Hassan bus terminal we took a local bus to Channarayapatna. It was a quick ride of about 40 minutes on the main Mysore-Bangalore highway. In Channarayapatna all signs were only written in Kannada (the local language). Bad luck for us. Also
column3: people do not really speak english here. But somehow we managed to find a local bus to Shravanabelagola. It was another 30 minutes on the bus through beautiful
column4: rural landscape. The whole trip set us back about 1 US$ per person one way - that looked like another really cheap day!

column1: By arriving in Shravanabelagola one can see the huge statue already from far away. The little town is nestled in between two holy hills (Vindhyagiri und Chandragiri)
column2: lots of big boulders and some small beautiful lakes. We were much surprised how beautiful it was! We decided first to climb up Vindhyagiri hill where the big statue of Gomateshwara is. Entrance was free (!) but you have to pay a small amount to leave you shoes at the foot of the temple (you must climb the mountain barefoot). The barefoot walk uphill was pleasant beside hordes of school children

column1: and families constantly asking us for pictures. Next time we will come prepared - we are seriously thinking of wearing a T-shirt saying ""picture - 10 rupee
column2: video - 20 rupee
column3: touching skin - 100 rupee
column4: screaming right into my ear for a picture - 1000 rupee"" ;-)..... Anyway - if you walk up the hill in the warm season at midday
column5: consider wearing some socks as the rock really gets hot. You quickly get an amazing view over town. On the way up
column6: there are some small temples and viewpoints. The statue cannot be seen while walking up. Only by entering the main temple you suddenly stand right in front of the amazing statue of the naked Gomateshvara. Oh yes
column7: although we are in India
column8: the jain deity is completely naked - and yes
column9: you can see everything! No wonder
column10: you can hear a lot of giggeling of school classes
column11: especially with girls only.... whereas most married couples just overlook the detail a bit ashamed. It was very funny to watch the reaction of the people
column12: we have to admit. Anyway
column13: the place has a nice atmosphere and some strong energy around. The statue is amazing. Every 12 years

column1: Markus with Shravanabelagola and Chandragiri hill in the background
there is a Mastakabishekam and millions of people come there. That means that the statue is dowsed in holy waters
column2: yoghurt
column3: kumkum powder etc.. What we have seen on youtube
column4: they need tons and tons of milk and other things. Well
column5: the next ceremony will be in 2018. We enjoyed the place and tried to sit in a more or less quiet corner - but that was nearly impossible. But this is India....

column1: We walked down again and quickly left the stalls and the hassle of the sellers around the entrance behind us. For lunch we tried the Raghu Hotel. This hotel is the only decent sleeping option here. Well
column2: let's say
column3: this time we were glad we had chosen to stay in Hassan! But lunch was more than amazing! They have only jain food
column4: that means
column5: no animal products are used in the food. It is purely vegan. Great for us
column6: as we are strict vegetarians (althouh not vegans). We ordered a thali which was a huge
column7: really tasty and so cheap. The owner was very friendly and chatted with us - well
column8: not a lot of westeners do come here. So he was extremely pleased to

column1: we loved the first aid kits on the buses ;-)
In the afternoon we climbed Chandragiri hill. This hill is nearly deserted. We met 5 people there in the afternoon - not more. It was stunning. We had amazing views of the statue on the other hill
column2: of the town and all the surrounding area. It was so peaceful and quiet!!!! On top is the Chandragupta Basti
column3: a lot of very old jain temples. Actually
column4: these are some of the oldest jain temples in India. The atmosphere was amazing as were the temples. Some of them had a very good energy. Entrance again was free and we visited 11 temples in total and one cave. It was just fantastic and we spend all afternoon there. In the evening we went back to town and took a bus back to Channarayapatna and then to Hassan.

column1: What a cheap an fulfilled day it was! We can highly recommend spending a day in Shravanabelagola. In the evening we had another fantastaic dinner at the Mayura International Hotel in Hassan. Then it was time to pack our backpacks again. Our next destination is a place where we have been already 1 year ago and which we loved: Mysore!

column1: View from hill top at sharavanbelagola
This blog is dedicated to the Ancient Hoysala Empire - its capital Halebidu and Belur.
28th Dec 2014 sunday morning and a destination 260 kms away from Bengaluru city was picked up as a weekend getaway by us.

We covered total 3 places in a day's tour to belur - Halebidu. Our trip started at 6 am from bengaluru. Our first stop was Sharavanbelagola(140 kms from Bangalore)- a very old jain temple. As soon as we got out of our car we figured out reaching to the temple will not be an easy task
column2: as there were 150 stairs waiting for us. Somehow we managed with 4-5 breaks in between. After reaching the cliff our tiredness was taken away by the temple's design and architecture. After covering the entire courtyard and the temple we quickly rushed down as we were running on a tight schedule.

column1: We then drove another 120 km to reach to the First Hoysala Empire capital - Belur.

Belur: Home to the Hoysala temple complex. The Chennakeshava temple here was completed in 1116 by Hoysala Vishnuvardhana. The temple is 37 meters tall and is standing on a platform which has exquisite art
Courtyard at Belur - capital of hoyasala
work on its outer walls and bracket figures of dancing girls in various poses in perfect proportion. The temple here is a classic example of Hoysala art
column2: and Belur was one of the Hoysala Capitals. After spending nearly 1.5 hours we still were not able to capture the mind-blowing architecture and sculptures.

column1: Our third and last stop was Halebidu - the later capital of Hoysala.

Halebidu was the regal capital of the Hoysala Empire in the 12th century. It is home to some of the best examples of Hoysala architecture. Most notable are the ornate Hoysaleswara and Kedareswara temples. The city which was originally called Dorasamudra got the name ""Halebidu"" because it was ransacked two times during the invasion of Malik Kafur.

The entire trip got us pretty close to the Hoysala empire and their art forms. while we headed back to Bengaluru city - we had so much to talk about the sculptures and architecture of these places. A must visit place in south India - all 3 destinations can be comfortably covered in a day's time.

column1: paper dosa for breakfast - we loved it.
What a perfect start of the day......

column2: the headline is quite provocative. We do have some indian friends who are spiritual. So please
column3: we do not want to offend anyone. We are just talking about the mass of people and what we observed on our travels. But later some thought on this.

column1: From Madikeri we took one of the many buses down to Hassan. If you want to travel this route: just be warned! The road is really bad and during these 4 hours we were shaken quite a bit. But again we had been lucky
column2: having seats in the front of the bus with great views. We arrived at the bus station in Hassan and were really surprised how clean and well organized this bus station is. As it was early afternoon
column3: we quickly decided to make our way to Halebid. Our plan was to visit the Hoysala temples in Halebid and Belur the following day and we were afraid that we would not make it in one day. So we decided to move on to Halebid to save some time instead of stay in Hassan for the night. Well
column4: to be honest
column5: that was one of the worst decisions we made on

column1: it is orange season - as you can see on the market in Hassan
this trip. The bus ride to Hassan was only 1 hour on a full and dusty bus. We arrived in Halebid and quickly found the only decent hotel in this grab little town
column2: the Mayura Shantala Hotel. Unfortunately
column3: it was fully booked. Really bad luck for us
column4: as there was only one alternative: the Shree Lodge a few meters away. Already from the outside we knew it - that was about to be a horrible experience. But we had no alternative. They had a free room (well
column5: no one is staying there voluntarily) for only 400 Rupees. At least
column6: it was cheap (even though for the shithole we got
column7: we should have paid not more than 100 Rupees). The lodge is about 10 years old
column8: we guessed. When it was new
column9: they put on some bedsheets and never changed them again. The bathroom looked about the same (like being cleaned for the last time about 10 years ago). We just left our stuff there and decided not to spend more time than really necessary in this shithole.

column1: For sunset we went to visit the famous Hoysaleswara Temple. The temple was full of people especially school classes. But
construction work in a bus terminal near Hassan

it is really impressive and beautiful. The construction of the temple began around 1121 and went on for 190 years. It was never really completed. But still today the temple is a masterpiece of Hoysala architecture. The outside walls of the temple are richly sculpted and are covered with Hindu deities
column2: sages
column3: stylised animals and Hoysala rulers. There are also 2 statues of Nandis (Shiva's bull) facing the inner sanctum of the temple. The whole temple is in the middle of a nice and well kept garden. It would have been wonderful and we could feel a very good energy in the temple. The only problem were the hordes of school classes and families. The closer we went to the inner sanctum of the temple
column4: the louder they became. For us
column5: a temple is a place for meditation
column6: a place of peace. For 99% of the visitors the visit to the temple was a big event. They spoke loudly
column7: took pictures and always asked us for pictures. One moment
column8: I was kneeing down in front of the main deity for praying
column9: some guys were standing beside me asking me for a picture. It opened our eyes to the fact
column10: that

column1: he is sitting behind the blue curtain
India is indeed a holy country. But there are not more spiritual people in India than in the rest of the world. They are born Hindus
column2: they obey to the religious rules and ceremonies
column3: but they are definitely not more or less spiritual than other people. We were kind of shocked. In fact it was really annoying as we could not find a place to quietly sit for a while and taking it all in. We tried to loudly recitate some mantras - but people were ignorant to that. They kept asking us for pictures
column4: pushing us
column5: shouting at us all the time. In a far corner of the garden they finally left us in peace. We sat there and thought about the indians
column6: their religion and their lifes.

column1: Some of our thoughts to India and religion: as we had experienced especially in Kerala
column2: a very conservative part of India
column3: people try everything to fullfill the social norm. They do not show any kind of emotions. Still
column4: 90% of the marriages are arranged and especially younger people are extremely unhappy with that. But the fear of being an outsider of society and the fear of not fulfilling

column1: traffic jam - view from the bus
the karma is to big to change the situation. Oh yes
column2: they think
column3: obeying their parents and getting married to a random woman/man is their karma. But this is only society pressure. And this again is caused by the way religion is lived today. Spirituality goes beyond this. In spirituality one follows the heart. Because the heart is never wrong. It maybe wrong in concern of the society rules but not for oneself. Of course
column4: this is the more difficult way as one has to face his own problems and his own decisions. Anyway
column5: this is a thinking most of the people do not understand (or they do not want to hear that). We met some people on our trip who already have realised this problem of the society and who have solved it for themselves. They opened their hearts
column6: made their own decisions and are highly spiritual people (and we are not talking about some saints or gurus
column7: just ""normal"" people). Some of them nearly never go to temples as it is always to loud
column8: to crowded and full of people not caring for others. They agreed to our thoughts. One wonderful lady even said: ""It is crazy. In

column2: we live in a holy country. And all the people want to go to the gym
column3: train in Zumba
column4: drink and party. And all the westeners come here and bring us back the spirituality. They look for peace of mind
column5: they visit temples in a way
column6: they do yoga and eat real ayurvedic food."" The world is indeed crazy. Just some thoughts......

column1: Back to our trip. As the sun was setting down
column2: we left the temple and went for a walk around Halebid town. Well
column3: this was done in 10 minutes as it is mainly just one dusty main street. There is another
column4: very colourful temple
column5: the Kedareswara Temple
column6: which was quite peaceful and nice to visit. That's it. So Markus decided to take the time for a haircut in one of the streetside shacks. For 60 Rupees he got a perfect cut and the time was coming closer when the only restaurant in the big hotel opened. We had dinner (it was quite ok) and then went back to our awful room. We put our sarongs on the bed and did not even get undressed. It was one of these moments when you try not

column1: details of the Hoysaleswara Temple in Halebid
to touch anything. The flush of the toilet was not working anymore. But luckily we did not need it too much anyway. ;-) The night nevertheless was ok
column2: we slept well. We got up the next morning very early as we wanted to escape out of our room quickly. At that time we even did not have any running water at all. We just put the few things we unpacked together and left at 6 am. From the bus terminal we took the first bus to Belur. It was about 40 minutes. There we went to Mayura Velapuri Hotel for having a nice breakfast. It was delicious and we could even wash ourselves in the bathroom. Luckily
column3: we could leave our luggage there while visiting the temple. We were happy again.

column1: And off we went to the Channakeshava Temple. On our way we realised that Belur is much bigger and much more pleasant than Halebid. We should have stayed here. Well
column2: sometimes you make stupid decisions.... The temple was simply stunning and even worth spending the night in a shithole for it. In fact
column3: there are different smaller temples around the main temple. It was also very

column1: details of the Hoysaleswara Temple in Halebid
crowded. But most of the people and school classes just visited the main temple. Like this
column2: the other temples were peaceful and quiet. We spend a lot of time in the temples and could even meditate without being disturbed. Again
column3: the architecture was stunning. The carvings and scultpures on the walls left us speachless. In some smaller temples ceremonies were going on and visitors even got blessings. Wonderful.

column2: we took our backpacks from the hotel and went to the bus station again. It was 1 hour by bus till we reached Hassan. From there we took a rikhshaw that brought us to the Mayura International Hotel . We had read good reviews about it on tripadvisor. As the prize was reasonable we just gave it a try. It was like entering into paradies for us. They had a huge and cheap room available. As it was quite cold a night we did not need an AC room
column3: so it was even cheaper. Everything was well kept and extremely clean. The towels were not stained
column4: the bedsheets nicely white (!) and the bathroom had a wonderful hot shower. It was the first ""normal"" (that means no bucket shower) hot

column2: 5 weeks! Wow!!!!! After the previous night we felt like kings. We showered
column3: washed all our stuff and went down to the restaurant for lunch. Another surprise. This restaurant was excellent! Never before did we have such a great variety of freshly cooked
column4: vegeterian indian food. And sooooo tasty! Later
column5: we discovered that a lot of well-off families from Hassan come here for eating as well. Well
column6: accomodation is sometimes a lottery while travelling. This time
column7: we got the jackpot. We went for a walk around Hassan. There is nothing to see in Hassan but it is ok for some cheap shopping. Later
column8: we had more wonderful food for dinner before we simply relaxed in our room.

column1: To some it up: the temples in Halebid and Belur are worth a visit. But base yourself in Hassan and make a daytrip. Both temples can easily be visited in 1 day.
The next day we made a day trip to the pilgrimage town of Sravanabelagola. More about this in another blog....

column1: Leaving Kannur in the direction of Madikeri
column2: I (Nina) had to face a special challenge. After having changed my ayurvedic medicine the evening before (as prescribed by the doctors)
column3: I had quite a strong diarrhea. As I felt healthy and ok
column4: I did not pay much attention to it
column5: but a 6 hour bus journey was not really what I was looking for. Anyway
column6: we were lucky. Being the first ones on the bus
column7: we were sitting in prime position in the front row with a perfect view. After 1 hour of travelling
column8: we realised that theses seats were essential for a good journey. The driver was driving like crazy and the road was really curvy. The result: we were nearly the only one not feeling sick and not in need of some sickness bags. Instead we were enjoying the drive up the Western Ghats. As the bus had no windows anyway and the engine was very noisy
column9: we did not even hear or smell that the co-passengers were all doing really miserable. Even my colon was quiet. Luck was on our side this time.

column1: After nearly 6 hours we arrived in the dusty town of Madikeri which

is nestled in between beautiful rolling hills. The landscape looked amazing. We went out to look for a rickshaw and easily got one to a fair prize to get to our final destination: the Rainforest Retreat
column2: an ecolodge tucked away in the forest. The ride on the rickshaw was nearly 1 hour and really bumpy (which woke up my colon and I had to train some specific muscles ;-)). But it was worth it. We arrived at the remote lodge. Our small and rustic cottage was a 15 minute walk away from the dining area and the middle of nowhere. We had our own fireplace in the room
column3: an outdoor bathroom (the first thing I saw in the cottage). We got hot water for the shower by heating a huge bowl of water on the open fire (there is a solar panel solution
column4: but we did not have enough sun those days) - and then it was a bucket shower. GREAT - and a real adventure. All the food is grown biologically on the farm - and one can taste this. Everything was so delicious. But still - there was one problem: my diarrhea. After dinner it got really bad

column1: and because of all my surgeries some years ago
column2: I got quickly dehitrated. As we were really remote in the forest
column3: I decided to be safe and go to the hospital as I did not know why I had this problem. I driver of the lodge took us there. Well
column4: it was a private hospital and the first thing I thought was: ""oh my good
column5: I do not want to see a public hospital then...."". I had to lay down on a bed which
column6: well
column7: more than stained. The doctor came in quickly wearing a battle dress. No angel in white - this guy was ready for a fight! It made me laugh. But he was friendly
column8: checked me and said: you must stay here for the night. Well
column9: I first wanted to know what my problem was. His quick answer was: food poisoning. OK
column10: finally we agreed that I could take some medicine especially for the dehidration and we went back to the lodge. I really did not feel sick enough to stay in this place. After returning and taking the medicine
column11: I quickly felt better and had a good sleep. Some days later I discovered that the cause

column1: of my problems was not food poisoning at all. My poor stomach simply did not like a specific ayurvedic tablet - that was all. So
column2: all problems solved and after a tough start in the Coorg we finally could enjoy this wonderful place.

column1: The first day we took it really easy. A nice breakfast with homemade bread
column2: curries
column3: idly
column4: fresh fruits and self-crown tea was followed by some hammock time. After a wonderful lunch (I was feeling much better at that time) we went for a walk around the hills of the lodge before we enjoyed a nice bonfire. At night it was getting freezing cold (around 0-10 degrees). We had not been really prepared for this
column5: but the open fire helped a lot. The other guests were a great mixture of indians and westeners and we were all talking and exchanging our stories. These evenings were really like what travelling is all about. Wonderful! This was christmas eve. We slept to the sound of frogs
column6: crickets

column3: we could also go and visit other places with our own driver as well - so

The temples were so beautiful! It took us quite some time to leave the place again. On our way back we stopped at the Abbi Falls
column5: a nice but not really spectacular waterfall near Madikeri

hidden temple in the sacred forest. This temple a a really powerful energy and the surroundings were so peaceful. Overmore

Just the cold and the humidity at night was really getting to us and we had no spare clothes left. So after 4 nights we left paradies for a warmer climate.
Laurie
