column1: Mysore is a mesmerising ancient city of palaces in South India. I started off the journey on 12Th of Nov at around 8 in the night by bus along with a bunch of energetic and enthusiastic chumps. On Thursday morning
column2: we checked in at Ashirwadh Hotel and straight away went to explore the Zoological Garden which was interestingly set up in around 8-10 acres within an exquisite bandstand. The zoo authorities do not allow one to carry plastics and food items as part of their new project scheme
column3: which means that
column4: we had a tiring time covering the entire zoo being thirsty.But the zoo invited us to a fascinating planet altogether.This planet not only contained varied varieties of animals
column5: but also beautiful walk throughs surrounded by natural vegetation
column6: wide range of flora and fauna
column7: and many rare species .Devika and I
column8: even though two nature buffs
column9: we found it a mammoth task to reach the exit point. We sauntered quiet too fast while the rest from my gang was indulged in clicking the wildlife. We then set out to visit the magnificent and the most opulent Mysore palace known as Amba Vilas Palace. The beauty of palace is

column1: beyond my words can possibly encompass. It's corridors
column2: antiques made of gold
column3: silver
column4: and ivory
column5: the majestic domes
column6: chandeliers
column7: the whole architectural elements were all very much awe- inspiring. One can never take their eyes off from it's colourful and intricate paintings the covers both the walls and ceilings of the palace with its rich detail about the myths
column8: tales of war and love with its essence of Hindu-Islam Rajput fusion . We girls got highly jealous of the wodeyar rulers for their lavishness and luxury
column9: but the sad part was that we were not allowed cameras inside the palace so as to capture the royal moments. After a small siesta
column10: we wriggled our way up to the Chamundi Hills.This place apart from being the area of the oldest temple
column11: it the prime view point where one can see the whole of Mysore City. The night view
column12: when the entire city is illuminated is something never to be missed. We girls got on top of a narrow parapet beside the road to get hypnotised in the bright and mind blogging scene in the panorama. Some of the us were too crazy to stand over the narrow parapet and to click the risky and dangerous selfies so as to outdo others in Facebook. After a chilly frozen venturing to the hilltop gulping down pani puris and hot teas
column13: we returned and crashed onto our beds as quickly so as to wake up for yet another adventurous royal visits to Tippu palace and monastery. The Tippu Sulthan's Summer palace is comparatively less luxurious
column14: situated within large area and is simple with its wooden architecture and faded paintings in its inside which is worth visiting. We then travelled another couple of hours to Coorg to experience the exciting White water Rafting . We jumped into to the rafts with few experts for a secured adventure paddling. The most memorable part of the rafting was whirling the raft and jumping into the river out of sheer excitement. After getting fully soaked we decided to go for musical night party amidst coconut farm and trees to recharge our batteries. We bunch of girls were banging our heads and tapping our foot with the rhythm of disco lights and DJ music giving a final touch to our adventurous trip.

column2: Mumbai

column1: Well we got togged up and enjoyed a very nice drink in the rather plush Harbour Bar at the lavishly beautiful Taj Mahal Palace Hotel in Mumbai. If only we'd checked Booking.com earlier as much to our surprise the room rate was pretty reasonable so we could have treated ourselves to a night's stay. Hey ho we will do next time as we certainly intend to visit India again as we're loving it so much.
We spent 3 full and rather crazy days in Mumbai over the Diwali Festival. It was extremely busy
column2: wonderfully colourful as many of the properties were decorated in fairy lights and so very noisy with fireworks being let off all the time. The sheer volume of people was a little overwhelming at times - the population of Mumbai is 18.4 million and there were thousands of visitors in town for the festival.

column1: We dd manage to see the following attractions though:-

column2: Mumbai's biggest and best museum which opened in 1923 and displays a great mix of exhibits from all over India.
a huge

column1: As seen on TV. Our place was one road back
column2: but a world away!

column1: basalt arch facing out to Mumbai Harbour. It was actually built to commemorate the 1911 royal visit of King George V but was not completed until 1924. Nowadays it's a favourite gathering spot for locals and a top spot for people watching.

column2: a charming building begun in 1672 and finished in 1718. It's the oldest English building in Mumbai - a marriage of Byzantine and colonial-era architecture.
an elegant 1848 neo-Gothic building the design of which was inspired by a German castle. Sadly for us it was closed over the Diwali Festival as we'd have loved to have seen inside too.

Mumbai's most extravagant Gothic building (added to Unesco World Heritage list in 2004) and the beating heart of its railway network. It was completed in 1887 and today is Asia's busiest train station.
another Unesco Heritage site and an hour's boat ride away from Mumbai Harbour
column3: home to a labyrinth of cave-temples carved into the island's basalt rock that contain some of India's most impressive temple carving. The temples are thought to date from AD 450 to AD 750. The island

column1: was originally known as Gharapuri (Place of Caves) but the Portuguese called it Elephanta because of a large stone elephant near the shore.
We flew from Mumbai to Goa on 26 October - just a short 1 hr 5 min flight away but felt like we'd landed on a paradise island! Wow what a fab part of India. Beautiful scenery
column2: so lush and green
column3: fabulous golden sandy beaches and the warm Arabian sea - a real tonic for the soul. We chose to stay way down South in Palolem and very pleased we did as it was a lovely quiet resort with a wonderful bay. We enjoyed 3 days of rest & relaxation there. It was very hard to leave but our time in India is running out fast.

column1: From Goa we flew to Bangalore (short 1hr 10min trip) and then took a cab onto Mysore which we'd expected to take 4 hours but had omitted to take into account the rush hour in Bangalore so ended up being nearly 6 hours. We'd only planned to stay in Mysore for a night or 2 but ended up staying there 4

column2: Mumbai

column1: Not bad for a train station

nights as we liked it so much. It's said that if you haven't been to Mysore then you just haven't seen South India. It's one of the most flamboyant places in India and is known for its glittering royal heritage
column2: bustling markets
column3: magnificent monuments
column4: cosmopolitan culture and friendly people. Whilst here we visited:-

column2: a jaw-droppingly stunning richly decorated palace. It was the former seat of the Wodeyar Maharajas. The old palace was gutted by fire in 1897
column3: the one you can see now was completed in 1912 by English architect Henry Irwin. Highlights for us were the Private and Public Durbar Halls'
column4: the Marriage Pavilion (a lavish hall used for royal weddings) and the numerous fabulous oil paintings. It's a feast for the eyes as everywhere you look you see the most ornately carved teak and rosewood doors and ceilings and amazing stained and painted glass ceilings. Unfortunately cameras are not allowed inside. Luckily for us we also got to see the palace lit up which happens for one hour every Sunday and on public holidays.

column2: which was brilliant and we're sure has much higher standards then we suspect most zoos do
Mumbai

column1: in India. It's set in pretty gardens that date from 1892 and highlights included the big cats (especially the white tigers)
column2: rhinos
column3: Indian & African elephants and giraffes.

column2: on its summit of 1
column3: 062m stand the Sri Chamundeswari Temple which is dominated by a towering 40m high entrance gateway. We queued with thousands of locals to get into the temple to be blessed. There are also fabulous views up here over the city.

column1: - Jayachamar Art Gallery which is housed in the Jaganmohan Palace that was built in 1861 as the royal auditorium. The gallery contains a collection of kitsch objects and royal memorabilia of the Mysore Royal family.

column2: open-air with main exhibit being the Mysore Maharani's saloon (a wood-panelled beauty dating from 1899). There are 6 steam engines you can climb aboard and pretend to be the driver - great for kids of all ages. Worryingly we noticed one of the engines was 2 years younger than us!

column1: - St Philomena's Cathedral built between 1933 and 1941 in neo-Gothic style with beautiful stained glass windows.
While we were in Mysore there were some parades going on which we later
discovered were to celebrate its name changing to Mysuru.
We're now making our way down to Kerala where we plan to spend our last week in India.

column1: We intended to reach our stay point (near Kutta) by nightfall

column3: which we later found out that the forest department

column2: their prey isn't here!

column1: won’t allow any vehicles into the forest after 6pm. We had to race to reach the gates of the Nagarhole forest and rather cinematically we were there by 5:58 pm. After a little convincing
column2: we entered the forest. It was already getting dark
column3: and our Innova seemed to be the only vehicle in the forest. We were warned by the officials. ""Don’t get out of the car
column4: don't sound horns and don't project lights etc."" Apparently
column5: elephants might get mad and we could die in the stampede. Where is fun if we don't defy authorities; we stepped out of the car
column6: took more than a few pics.

column1: There were some alarming animal calls as the night progressed
column2: and we followed the sounds
column3: only to find large masses of deer
column4: Bison and baboons. Dusk broke down into deep darkness and chilling breezes; the distant sounds of birds
column5: animals and crickets dominated our engine sound. That was when we saw a loner elephant at the side of the road
column6: which thrilled us (fear might be a better word ;-)) There was no signal in our phone
column7: no sight of man and no light nearby. It was something

column2: Heaven
column3: Eden
column4: Nirvana..you name it!

my batchmate from college paid the Bangalore gang a visit. The plan was to go for a road trip around Bangalore. She really wanted to go to Coorg
column3: but since I was just back from Coorg I insisted we go somewhere else. I did feel bad
column4: later on
column5: about making her change her plans because of me. So the four of us and Rahul (Tipu) decided to head out for Gokarna. But we misplanned the trip and started only late in the evening. We werent able to appreciate the beautiful route to the beach town. But that was made up by the interesting conversations we had on our way.

column1: We passed through curvy steep western ghats with dense forests. It would have been great if the journey had been in daytime. We reached Gokarna early in the morning.

The beach was just optimally crowded. There were several beaches separated by small hills. We could trek over the hills and go from one beach to the other. On the last beach in the row we hired a boat which took us to the beaches not easily accessible. We managed to spot some dolphins too in the ocean.

The coast line at Gokarna was uniquely beautiful. We could see big mountains directly merging into the ocean. The beaches were surrounded by mountains on three sides and had ocean on the fourth. We ate and drank at a shack and sometime around 4 headed back for Bangalore.

Once again we ended up traveling in the dark and missed the beautiful part of the journey. It was raining heavily on the way back and our driver was drowsy too. We were happy to be back safe in Bangalore the next morning.

column2: Displayed: 8

column1: Januaray 2007. This was my first trip after moving to Bangalore. Varun and Pawan
column2: my colleagues had just bought their bikes and had been looking to go on a long pleasure ride. So on one fine Friday night we along with Imon decided to set out for Coorg the next morning. We memorized the route to Coorg via Mysore through google maps. Smartphones with 3G connections were not quite there then.

column1: Hitting the highway next morning was quite a good feeling. It was a trip where I was kind of leading the pack of four boys on bikes and thus got a feeling of having finally entered adulthood from the protected years of college life.

We headed south-west of Bangalore on Mysore Road which happened to be one of the best highways at that time. We could easily touch 100+kmph on that road at least upto Mysore. It was a bright and pleasant day. The landscape on both sides of the road comprised endless uniform green fields with stony hills and coconut trees as the only aberrations. The stony hills of Karnataka are quite unique. They are like a spilled stack of large hard rocks
column2: the mud covering them

column1: having been washed off over the ages.

column2: we took a right turn towards Coorg. On the way to Coorg were Khushalnagar Buddhist monastery
column3: but we kept that for our return trip. Somewhere on our way
column4: I and Varun managed to get far ahead of Pawan and Imon and hence decided to take a detour onto a road which looked like going nowhere. We ended up on a muddy road which lead us to a lake which was completely inconspicuous from the highway because of the bamboo jungle all around it. That place was like a whole different world. No human settlement around. Vast stretch of untouched nature. A lake followed by a hillock and a lot of greenery. For a while we were feeling like Vasco-da-gama.

column1: It was time to get back to the highway after spending few minutes there. Coorg is a hill station and we were expecting steep climb somewhere
column2: but that does not quite come untill the very end. The road does start sloping upwards but hardly becomes steep. It passes through some really unique villages of Karnataka giving a view into a world so contrasting with what we have in

column1: Stone art near the lake we discovered
Bangalore. The life is conspicuously slower there making us question the need of daily grind back in Bangalore.

Closer to our destination we get into the region of large trees which looked much different from the ones which we are used to seeing. Or probably they looked unique because we noticed them properly after long. Our road took us through famous Coorg coffee plantations too.
Just before sunset we were at Madikeri
column2: a hill station town in Coorg. Managed to find a cheap room for four of us. Had dinner at this antique looking restaurant named 'the west end' (if I remember right).

column1: We woke up early the next morning to see sun rise at 'Raja seat'. We hired at auto rickshaw driver who became our tour guide as well and took as around some temples and important places of the Madikeri town. Abbey falls was our next stop. That probably was my first time at a waterfall. we went in the water near the falls though was not possible to get directly below the falls.

column2: we hit the road back to Bangalore. On our way back we visited the majestic Harangi Dam which

column1: was a slight detour from the main highway. We took another detour to Khushalnagar Buddhist monastery. The road to monastery had a Tibetan settlement which was quite a surprise for us. It was like a mini Tibet far too south in India. The monastery was a beautiful place. Peaceful
column2: artistically made and tranquil. We got a chance to see a session of prayer from the Buddhist monks.

column1: By the time we reached Mysore
column2: it began to get dark. We still had 150kms to cover to reach Bangalore. We had to slow down because of dark. We took a stop over at a CCD on Mysore highway (70kms from Bangalore). CCD was still a charm back in those days and specially at unique place like that.

column1: We hit Bangalore somewhere around 9:30 and congratulated ourselves on successfully completing a great road trip!

column2: Displayed: 15

column1: I completed 7 years in Bangalore on August 1
column3: a fairly long time in one place. That made me start thinking what all I have done in the last seven years. I felt that I could summarize all these years just by all the people I have come across and all the places I have been to in these years. The promotions and hikes in my job dont quite make it to the essence of the last 7 years. So I thought of consolidating all of these memories of the people and the trips with them at one place and there comes this blog.

column1: I had moved to Bangalore in July 2007 right after graduating from college. Many of my friends from college too had moved here at the same time. Among the many were Neelesh
column2: Rahul and Vivek who I would be going on a lot of trips with in the years to come and hence deserve a mention here.
Puneet moved to Bangalore in July
column3: 2009. I would get to know Chopra and Meenu through him who would be part of many of my trips in 2009-10. Puneet moved from Bangalore to Bombay in December 2010 almost marking an end of an era full of travel within these 7 years.

column1: My Techfest gang (including their WAGs) too deserves a mention here as I would at least one trip a year with it.

column2: I would be joined by Sonam in most of my travels.

column1: I hope to continue updating this blog with all my past of future travel descriptions chronologically.
Likes to hang out outside the studio and serenade us with gobbles.
Currently I am sitting at the airport waiting for a flight to Goa... I got here extremely early so I thought it was time for an update.

There hasn't been much adventuring for me over the past few weeks so I thought I might make a list of things I have learned that may be of use to someone wanting to travel to Bangalore. Please understand I must only say Bangalore because people from other places tell me they are totally different to here and different things apply but I guess some general things will be consistent.

So must begin by saying that one month is as long as it takes to feel adjusted. I have found myself a routine and some coping mechanisms for spending a lot of time on my own - a healthy addiction to Sons of Anarchy and Paulo Coelho novels. I feel more confident being out in my own area in the evenings now
column2: I know the streets and some shops where I have become a regular customer give me a sense of safety. Two of my students have been educating me about the local food and introduced to some people who work at
Plus various chutneys and Subzi
which was a huge help.

column14: a spicy lentil based stew
column15: very thin and Rasam

Something all people must know is the rickshaw and taxi guys see foreigners as an easy pass to getting free stuff. I was casually walking down Brigade road

column5: explaining that if I went with him to some places he would

column3: seriously

column5: where will I wear one? And
column6: no I can not buy wooden artefacts that will be taken off me by customs

column1: The best treat I got in the last two weeks
column2: apart from a full Sunday of cleansing rain
column3: was a double dose of full body Ayurvedic massage and steam boxing. I suggest you get someone to recommend you a place
column4: because there are good massage places and ones that give you a pretend treatment for the money because you are a foreigner. There are many different types of Ayurvedic treatments
column5: that treat all ranges of body and mind issues. I went in specifically to unwind my muscles from work and to de-stress so I can sleep better. Women massage women and men massage men
column6: and ladies if you are not comfortable with someone you don't know touching your breasts I do not recommend this. I was happy that when they say full body they meant it! You have to wear this paper g-string and lay on a wooden table that has a slight upward curve in it. You get covered in medicated oil and I mean coated
column7: completely
column8: my body was sliding on the table at some points due to the amount of oil used. They're movements are rhythmic
column9: repeated and increase in pressure. On first treatment expect them to take it easy on you
column10: this is a precaution due to foreign bodies not being used to the herbs and oils used
column11: but you can tell them to be firmer. After the massage I was placed in a steam box. This was pretty funny because it is not a sauna room
column12: it is literally a box with a hole in it to keep your head out. I was happy about this because I hate saunas because I get to hot and light headed. The masseuse said the head must remain out of the heat to avoid the giddiness. After the massage you are recommended to rest
column13: I got the best sleep I've had the entire time I've been in India that night and after the second massage
column14: it was like all of my sadness and stress had been wiped away. I think that from now on when I travel
column15: no matter where I am I will get a massage in the first week
column16: just to release the tension and anxiety that can be associated with travelling.

column1: Lastly I will mention a bit about how the dancing has been going. I have started teaching the Company as well as the training course
column2: so all of my time on the weekdays is taken up with sharing my knowledge with these wonderful people. I had a really magical moment this past week
column3: when I realised how beautiful it was to watch someone embodying my movement and how powerful this is to witness. I do not claim originality to any class exercise I create
column4: It follows the structures and conventions I have learnt
column5: but is my interpretation of them manifesting into sequences of movements. The feedback gained from watching different bodies grapple with my material helps me see my habits and the places I skip because they are difficult for me
column6: forcing me to change my approach and expand my practice. I have also been surprised every day with how much I have retained and learnt
column7: with the added challenge of answering questions of what the exercises are for
column8: why the class is structured in such a way and so forth. I have started creating a piece for the Diploma students graduation
column9: that was described to me as a jigsaw puzzle
column10: with unexpected relationships and serious of random
column11: although somehow related events. Everyone getting a moment to shine and with 26 students
column12: I feel this is very important. I get woken up at night with steps
column13: counts
column14: ideas flooding my consciousness
column15: I love it. This experience has really allowed me the time I've needed to explore myself as a teacher and an artist
column16: plus learning a bit about business along the way.

column1: 1. Only eat at recommended places or 5 star hotels.
2. Be ready to bargain. Start by buying things at government approved stores until you get used to the prices
column2: this includes local supermarkets for your fresh fruits and veg.

column1: 3. Never travel in a cab or rickshaw without the metre.

column2: you will adjust.

column1: 5. Get a massage and find ways to relax.

column2: share and create.

column4: I was not in the car but breakfast was going to be. Breakfast of Idli wala and some chutneys

column6: on to the highway. Stopping at toll booth
column7: men are trying to sell stuff
column8: coming up to inspect me one by one
column9: very intimidating but it's ok

column1: View on the way to Jain Temple
the window was shut and doors locked. We reach our first destination
column2: a boys orphanage where a guru of 110 years lives and oversees the care of these orphans
column3: feeding up to 10
column4: 000 people per day
column5: incredible place
column6: there was an energy there I can't quite describe. We went up to see the temple and a young boy said a prayer for me
column7: giving me some powder that is said to be auspicious and I should keep for as long as possible
column8: unfortunately I may be meeting customs on that but that's yet to be seen. I got so see the guru to
column9: a very tall man dressed in orange
column10: sitting giving people blessings. My friend told me that he over heard some of the boys saying comments that they were proud that a white woman came to see their place
column11: how lovely! From here we continue to the ladies town
column12: Tiptur
column13: it rained a bit on the way
column14: so soothing and refreshing in the heat. I check in to a hotel
column15: a more comfortable sleeping/shower option and then we head to her parents place to meet them. Such genuine and happy people greet me and feed me the traditional

column1: sweet pancake with fruit salad then rice and sambal. Yum. Then off to meet the cousins
column2: so many people were there
column3: many with no understanding of english except for the work bye. They were so keen to talk to me they would just address me directly like I understood and me to them
column4: obviously there was a translation happening through my friend but still it was nice to be addressed directly. So yep another late night.

column1: 7am In the morning I'm back to her parents for traditional breakfast (will have to get back to you with the name) and coffee. Then we set off on our adventure
column2: first travelling a mere 20 min to the village were her aunties and uncles farm Coconut
column3: Tiptur is famous for coconut and boy were they delicious
column4: I got to drink 2 fresh ones from the tree
column5: eat 2 fresh mangoes and some jackfruit
column6: I'd never had jackfruit
column7: it's so sweet tastes like a lolly! The family were so proud to be getting me all these fresh treats
column8: it was super special for me. The air was so fresh
column9: the farm so peaceful. Again different family member were talking to me like I

column2: such a happy bunch
column3: joking with each other. I was hoping to see a peacock but 2 puppies and plenty of Buffalo was what I got and I was happy with that. Then we drove on to a Jain Temple in Shravanabelagola
column4: home to the biggest single stone statue (a naked man
column5: I could go in to more history but that would take forever). You have to climb around 500 stairs barefoot to see it and there are some very old preserved carvings in the rock. The view was spectacular
column6: surrounded by coconut farms and bodies of water. Many women asked to have their picture taken with me
column7: I found this very amusing and felt like some weird celebrity! It was a beautiful sunny day also so this was a wonderful experience especially the stones burning the underside of my feet making me literally want to run up and down the hill. We then continued to Hassan for lunch and afterwards drove to Belur to see another temple with ancient stone carvings
column8: oh my was this stunning! Such intricate details of hand carved stone dating back to the 1700's. All of the gods
column9: Bharatnatym positions

column1: animals and Karma sutra positions carved around the outside of a gorgeous temple
column2: I had no energy for a tour but was happy observing the workmanship
column3: so delicate and precise
column4: no 2 pieces the same
column5: such craftsmanship you will probably never see in this day. A must see! After a quick stop outside Belur at a water catchment to get some fresh air
column6: we then journeyed to Halebidu to see another temple crafted in the same way. This temple seemed to have preserved better and the grounds were really well maintained with greenery and a garden surrounding it. The temple in Belur was stone as far as the eye could see
column7: so I enjoyed the feel of Halebidu more. They had some rather big statues of the cow god and plenty of carvings of other gods
column8: the mind boggles with all the stories that were encapsulated around these buildings
column9: represented by these figures of worship.

column1: Then on to the road and my what a road this was. There were so many holes
column2: so many different surfaces
column3: for kilometres and kilometres
column4: it felt like we were driving to the end of the world! So many lorry vans and truck

column1: rolled by with so many people packed on to them
column2: it was so strange to see! I'm told the roads are being fixed in India now
column3: under the new government and my god they would want to be
column4: I thought we would never be able to get over some of the terrain but we merrily bumped our way along
column5: cracking jokes about it because there was no way around this road. They had freshly made one part and used big rocks to block people from riding over it instead of those orange bollard things
column6: very environmentally friendly. Some parts had the bitumen spread at different levels so there were some bizarre speed bumps. It was truly an experience like no other
column7: especially seeing the amount of people travelling on the road. We were joking that they were fitting entire villages into rickshaws
column8: only in India! When we finally got off that road and on to the good highway I felt sad a little
column9: the rough road was way more fun
column10: albeit slow. When we finally arrived back in Tiptur
column11: it was the cousins turn to feed me. I tried a bit of a ragi ball
column12: this weird purplish flour thing

column1: you are not meant to chew

column4: no one was offended
column5: quite contrary
column6: impressed I had a taste. So I happily ate the best Chippatis I have had with some Mutton curry and fried chicken
column7: so tasty
column8: I was really spoiled this weekend

column11: giving me 2 Bananas
column12: some leaf and Betal nuts. This ceremony only happens for the women

column1: I learnt something very valuable this weekend; It does not matter what culture you are from or what type of upbringing you have had
column2: if you remove all preconceived ideas about what a person will be like due to the others of their culture/religion/country you have met you will see the true person
column3: the soul and on a very uniquely primitive
column4: human level you will connect
column5: regardless of language barriers. People can really surprise you if you let them. Also
column6: listening is the key to learning about a person
column7: and willingness to let go a bit of yourself will allow you to experience them and what they believe
column8: this is very important to building an understanding of each other.

column2: the Rain and dancing. Oh and my fever/cold only lasted 2 days. It is advisable to get a good rest each night so you don't wear yourself out and become susceptible to foreign bugs. Now I really am finding my feet and loving the experience of this crazy place.

column1: This was to be one of the hardest weeks of my life - I just didn't know it yet! It is not until I leave the airport that the gravity of my decision hits me
column2: It's 1am Sunday Morning
column3: my escort leads me straight on to the road where we are walking amongst the taxi traffic
column4: which is hectic by the way
column5: there is absolutely no system on the roads here
column6: people just do whatever they want
column7: horns honking. After finally getting ushered to the cab rank and getting in the cab we are off in to the extremeness of the traffic. It truly has to be seen for one to even grasp how crazy it is on the road (there is 'no traffic' right now either because it's so early
column8: oh my!)
column9: I thought I was not going to make it or that we would crash for sure
column10: but some how in all the chaos the people seem to manage
column11: like it's second nature. After one hour we reach our destination
column12: A wonderfully big apartment I get to have to myself for the next two months a blessing after a long stint on couches
column13: sublets and my old room at my folks place
column14: compliments of Attakallari Centre for Movements Arts where I am due to start work monday and what a day monday was
column15: but I'll get to that shortly. I'm left with not much information except for a dinosaur nokia mobile with no internet
column16: great! I go to have a shower to find there is no hot water
column17: well I know there is now because a friend showed me how the systems work here
column18: but I have no idea
column19: so I'll been having cold showers for an entire week
column20: this is ok in fact because it is so warm and lovely a big jump from the bitterness of the Australian winter. After coming to terms with this I sleep.

column1: I have a good friend in Bangalore who picked me up after I awoke and took me on a tour of the city. I'm thinking this was wonderful
column2: I'm feeling like I can cope with this forgetting that I am cushioned from the real environment of the city in his luxury car and his knowledge of were to go (he took me to a palace for lunch
column3: very lovely grounds so lush and green!). I only came to realise how intense the city was the next day (monday) early morning as I was trawling the streets with no idea in hell where I am going. I was given vague directions from my land lady
column4: who I had to ask what the address for my house was because no one told me that either
column5: asking many many people as they went by to point me in the right direction going around and around in circles for an hour looking for a place I'm told should have taken less than ten minutes. The stink of garbage and god knows what else made this experience even more difficult
column6: getting stared at
column7: honked at as I need to take the road because the foot path is non existent
column8: laughed at
column9: disregarded.... Why no one showed me or came to pick me up I have no clue
column10: but by the time a rickshaw driver with decent english finally pointed me to the right road
column11: only to be greeted by a security man I had no hope in hell understanding or explaining that I was there to work
column12: my nerves were so frazzled and I could not keep the tears back. I'm sitting outside the place now being stared down by the cleaning ladies
column13: the security man telling me for half an hour about how it costs one lac to buy a suzuki and me sitting there thinking what in the world possessed me to do this! the lady I have been speaking to arrives and I finally get to talk sense with someone. I get taken inside after the yoga class and am introduced to the majority of my 28 students
column14: I am calming down now! I get to watch their next class
column15: Kalarippayattu
column16: Indian Martial Art. A highly physical discipline consisting of different series of deep squats and kicking. know I am going to learn a lot from observing the traditional movement disciplines but am so hungry so I do not stay to watch Bharatnataym (classical indian dance). On my way how I got head butted by a cow
column17: apparently I stepped to close to his head
column18: but I had no choice
column19: he was on the footpath! I am going home to eat because I am very weary of the local restaurants
column20: they look unhygenic and I would have no clue what to order anyway
column21: on the way I ask the internet shop man about getting a dongle
column22: and he just shakes his head and hand at me and continually says no. Far out nothing is going my way today! I get back and now it's time to take the role for my ballet class
column23: oh what a joke that was
column24: Half of the names I have no idea about
column25: I make a joke of this but I'm feeling rather vulnerable here! So thats over we get on with the class
column26: I am testing their skill level today for both ballet and contemporary and can see gaps in their knowledge immediately
column27: this gives me my confidence back. The universal language of the body and what it needs. There are a few knee and shoulder issues
column28: I think this is great not for the students obviously but now I know where to direct my training and what the students need for strength. Dance really can lift your spirits and give you freedom even when your nerves are completely shot out
column29: bringing a joy and forgetting about the crazy desire in my heart to run back to Australia. The day has ended now time to find food
column30: but first I am given the Wifi code and an internet dongle now
column31: sweet relief I can tell my loved ones I have not died in the flight! I go the the place recommended and once again I have no idea what to order and surprise surprise the workers don't speak english! So much for being told that Bangalore is a big city you will be fine many people speak english
column32: well today they didn't. I get something finally
column33: the people there are nice enough. Going home was a tad frightening
column34: I don't think I'm in a very safe area for a woman to walk alone at night
column35: yet another amazing bonus for the day! I get home and take a cold shower and hand wash my clothes (something I will be doing a lot from now on). Finally taking solace in the adult cartoon Archer

column1: Jetlag wakes me at 4am the next morning
column2: silence
column3: oh sweet silence where have you been? I'm grateful for being up so early
column4: by 5am a beautiful singing can be heard
column5: I find out later that it is from the church down the road calling people to pray. I find this very soothing. My friend picks me up and takes me for a walk in the park and breakfast
column6: iggly and Masala dosa
column7: delicious. The home to prepare a ballet lesson
column8: before heading in to watch the Bharatnataym class. How expressive and beautiful this dance is
column9: powerful in rhythmic grounding and light in characterisation of the face with fluidity of the upper body and clarity of mudras of the hands. very powerful! After break they come back
column10: we dance together
column11: the students seem to really enjoy my lessons
column12: they later tell me that they love my classes and are having fun
column13: that they always found ballet boring but not with me... The imagery I have been focusing on must work
column14: very good research for my studies into ideokinesis and obsession with ways to make the physicality easy even when the movement is tough
column15: correcting alignment with image and anatomical facts. They clap for me when I do even the simplest of steps
column16: I feel so fabulous
column17: it's a real pleasure to be admired and to feel that through a friendly less demanding nature I can see great improvement and deepen the awareness of their bodies with them. This really is a shared learning experience. I can see a very very distinct difference in culture by the way the students respect me and respond to me. They have very little care for being self conscious and self esteem seems high
column18: they are friendly and supportive to each other
column19: none seem to have a competitive bone in their body. One thing I find so hilarious is the customary head movement for ok
column20: I ask if it is understood and due to this sideways head wobble I have no idea if they mean yes or no. The rest of the week continues like this. Going to and from the studio not going to far from home
column21: I am brave enough one evening
column22: desperate for some meat to eat that I take the rickshaw to the main road. Holy moly
column24: a bit frightening at first but funny none the less
column25: I'm glad I've been told how much I should pay though because I can see myself being ripped off very easily. I also take one trip on the back of a students scooter to see a very dismal dance show in a pub
column27: I told him he was brave for riding a scooter there as I clung to him fearing for my life! I am getting very tired of being stared at by the end of the week
column28: I feel sensitive and am going in and out of homesickness
column30: absolute blinding moments of inspiration and joy
column31: very surreal almost. I see the dirt and rubbish in the street
column34: monkeys turkeys and can not understand how are why people must live this way
column35: how is this chaos possible? It is so far beyond my grasp!

column1: I met a lovely man in the plane on the way over
column2: who would by the end of the week end up being like my family. He told me not to fight India and I would have a good time
column3: but by friday I feel desperate to escape
column4: my stomach has started aching
column5: I have not been eating well as I still have no clue what to eat. He invites me over friday evening after I finish work. Friday was hard for me
column6: the students support and love really picked me up and we did a slow massage/stretch class as they were tired and to be honest I had little energy. I stayed back late having philosophical convocations with some students
column7: still after they leave I feel lonely and I am grateful for the invitation to stay the night with a friend. His company driver picks me up. Nice guy we had a lovely chat and he took me down what I can only describe as the most dangerous road I have ever been down. I arrive at his door and his wife greets me with a tray with contains a sweet smelling candle
column8: and powder
column9: she dots my head with the powder and feeds me an almond. This is truly one of the most special experiences I have ever had
column10: I want to cry with joy and relief. Her neighbour and daughter come by
column11: they are so excited to meet me and we stay up the entire night talking laughing and I feel like I have found long lost relatives. The next day I am thankful to be there
column12: my stomach has given up
column13: it's time for the inevitable travel bug to hit me
column14: full blown gastro
column15: my stomach feels like it is going to come violently out of my mouth. I sleep for more than fifteen hours
column16: cry and want to seriously run home. They care for me like I have never experienced
column17: with pure unconditional love. I am so thankful
column18: the universe really helped me when it sat me next to this man on the plane. After this
column19: the next day I feel better. I have been dreaming vividly and feel an undeniable guilt for wanting to leave my students
column20: I can not leave them
column22: I will feel better. They take me out and make sure I am stocked up with good quality food
column23: both are from farming regions so we speak the same language when it comes to quality produce. I'm feeling better now
column24: all I needed was a little help and a little love. So here ends my first week in India
column25: I can say that I have indeed been shocked and the advice I have for the solo traveller is find a friend
column26: you need them! Also no expectation is best.

column1: Bryn knew early on that some his undercover work was going to require him to blend in with the locals.
Firstly I am so sorry that it has been so long since my last blog post
column2: I appreciate that you have not all been sat round
column3: wringing your hands
column4: deep in worry for me
column5: but I still need to say sorry.

column2: so when I left off last time I was heading to Bangalore to meet with my old friend Bryn to work on his thesis for his masters degree in Primatology. I wasn’t quite sure what to expect but I knew Bryn
column3: so I knew it wouldn’t be dull….

column2: the truth is I can’t get in too many details about the process for reasons I will explain later but I can tell you about what this has morphed in to and the findings.

column1: What started out as looking at the ritual torture of wildlife has turned in to a weird study in to Black Magic.
So let me explain. Bryn always had some evidence that his chosen primate
column2: the Slender Loris
column3: was being used in Black Magic but this has developed in to a study about the use of both illegal
column4: and legal
column5: wildlife in Black Magic sacrifices.

column1: Oooooh and what a strange world it is. It ranges from the relatively harmless things such as marrying two frogs to bring the rains
column2: to blowing up a flap shelled turtle to release the treasure inside. I have so many example of these beliefs it goes on and on….

column1: If you keep a Red Sand Boa snake under your safe it will protect your fortune. The idea is that the Red Sand Boa appears to have two heads
column2: so it can see in both directions and will see folk coming to grab your fortune.

column1: Therefore traders will split the tail of the snake and pin fake eyes in the tail so it appears that the snake has two heads.
And then it gets stranger……….the heavier the snake the better protection it brings. So traders started to force-feed the snake ball bearings to increase the weight.
Buyers started to work this scam out so they started to feel for the ball bearings in the gut of the snake.
Traders got wise to this…..so now they force-feed the snake liquid mercury so that buyers cannot detect the artificial weight increase. It doesn’t really matter that the snake
Would you pick him out in a crowd?
will die within a few hours
column2: once the money has exchanged hands it is too late.

column1: Legend has it if you see a Jackal when you wake up it gives you good luck. So some folk will keep Jackal captive at home and when they wake up they will head straight to the cage (without seen anyone else) so the first thing they see in morning is the Jackal.

During the recent elections a pot containing the head of a Jackal was found outside the parliament building. This suggests (as do our interviews) that this sort of stuff is far more prevalent then you would have thought. It certainly is not just restricted to “uneducated” rural areas.

column2: these beliefs permeate the political and legal classes.

column1: Now I would love for you to think of me as some sort of Indiana Jones type
column2: but the truth is most my work as a research assistant is pretty dull
column3: typing up notes and referencing documents
column4: in a clean and safe apartment in Bangalore.

column1: It really is not that exciting. And for good reason. The truth is that if two white faces turn up to
We found a second hand bookshop in Bangalore
column2: it was like a journey through my childhood.

column1: interview a poacher or a practitioner their suspicion will double. These guys already realise they are on the wrong side of the law and are only talking because of the promise of money
column2: we can’t spook them even more.

column1: There is a serious aim to all this study. Every time a Jaca is captured or a Flap Shelled Turtle is blown up
column2: there is one less. When there are no more Hyenas or Flap Shelled Turtles left poachers and practitioners will start to use other similar species until they are decimated too. This study could be used to try and convince religious and spiritual leaders to turn their back on these practices. This will not be easy though
column3: there is a huge amount of money involved in this trade. Others have tried and failed. But it could help.

column1: I am going to support Bryn in this venture until around the 25th of June and then I am going to take off for a while. Still not sure exactly what I am going to do. I am going to stay in India until the 26th of July (when my Visa expires). I am thinking about heading over
The farm we were staying at had four lovely dogs. It was nice to have canine company again. One day I decided to give them a wash. One was a St Bernard. It took over an hour.

Everything is easy in Thailand……….unlike India….which is a struggle… Our favorite phrase at the moment is “wither the challenge”. You set off to achieve something on a day but within an hour you feel withered.

column2: all my biggest love to you for reading this
column3: I appreciate it more than you will ever know.

column1: PS Sorry for the miserly amount of pictures.

column2: Displayed: 24

column1: We set out for Hampi with a lot of expectations as we had heard so much about it and seen such wonderful pictures. The sheer vastness
column2: complexity and craftsmanship of the place left us awestruck and we were left wondering as to how something like this was built and sustained so many centuries ago. The pictures have been taken at various locations like Vittala
column3: Virupaksha and Krishna temple complexes....and we were not in the least bit disappointed.

column2: Displayed: 10
Hampi and on to Bangalore

column1: 3rd Class sleeper class train to Hampi
We were warned about children being above us on bunks and having little 'accidents' on us which had us on full alert!
We last minute decided to go to Hampi
column2: we weren't going to bother as its a pain to get to but we re routed ourselves and could get from Hampi to Bangalore and from here we could continue south to Kerala
column3: we also looked at lots of pictures on the internet and decided we had to go if we were near it.

column1: Hampi itself is a small village built as close as possible to the sights and literally there to cater for the tourists
column2: all the locals live up the road In Hospet near the train station. Hampu itself is a UNESCO heritage site as the ruins within it are from the Vijayanagara Empire. The historical sights can be dated back to 1343 - so VERY old. There are many Hindu temples
column3: military buildings (including an elephant garage!) and civil building to explore. We had given ourselves a couple of days to have a look around the place and some of the main sights.

column1: We travelled by train from Goa to Hampi in Air Con (AC) 3 tier which was more than Ok
column2: this means bunks of three beds with the bottom bunk being used to sit on during

column1: the day and at night they all fold down for beds. This is the last tier of ac compartments
column2: the next step down is non ac and non booking of seats so a free for all and we werent quite ready to try that with all our bags. There with lots and lots of locals around us which was great
column3: this tier of the train was very busy with people and luggage who have a little bit more money to upgrade to this class. One family kept coming down the train with boxes and suitcases and room was running very low
column4: we put a couple of suitcases under my bed and they were all around us
column5: then the family came down and there was around 15 of them all having different berths around the train but wanting to sit together which after some doing what they wanted to do and not backing down they won with other people changing seats to accomodate them. After around 30 minutes they started eating
column6: they had brought the biggest spread lve ever seen
column7: shopping bag full if cooked rice
column8: chappatis galore and lots of curry and finally cakes and cakes and cakes. We decided

column1: they must have come from a wedding and brought all the left overs. It did look delicious
column2: and the mum fed all the men first and waited for them to finish before sorting her own food out. What dedication. We kept looking over hoping for a plate full but to no avail
column3: we made do with the train food of a fried vegetable cutlet in bread and a masala tea. The train was so busy with people walking up and down and the tea and food sellers moving up and down the train. With this and the scenery ever changing from the green lush lands of south Goa turning into more baron landscape of the Karnataka area it was a good journey. The train took around 10 hours so we were in by dinner time to Hampi.

column1: We got probably a very overpriced tuk tuk to Hampi and looked around for somewhere to stay. Coming into Hampi felt like being transported to another world and reminded me so much of The Flintstones and Bedrock. India's landscape is so diverse l would never of though the terrain in Hampi would be possible! It was very dry with HUGE boulders thrown

column2: like marbles giants would play with. Then amongst these boulders were the number one attractions of the temples. We bargained down a decent room which had a roof terrace so we could watch the sunset over one of the main temples which was pretty much on our door step. Having had a delicuous nut curry we found a tuk tuk driver to take us around the sights the next day (the area is vast and walking is out of the question to do it all in a day or two)
column3: we agreed a pick up time and hit the hay getting an earlyish night ready for the next day.

column1: Our guy rocked up 30 minutes late which meant we were worried he wasnt coming and we were panicking about what to do as we were aiming to leave the next day meaning we would miss out on seeing the temples we wanted to as we would have to find another driver. Whoops all round when he arrived and we started the day. We saw tons of temples and after a few they started to merge into one
column2: same same but different. It was also BOILING!..we ate lots of

column1: Unless you have an elephant garage you havent made it
ice creams which lasted about 10 seconds before melting due to the heat
column2: and drank lots of water
column3: near the end we were just chilling in the tuk tuk with the driver as we were too hot and tired to move. Our driver was lovely and everything went well until he started telling us about his life and the guilt trip kicked in. He told us about how he was practically an orphan after his entire family had died from various illness's. We listened intently and was reminded of how different peoples lives can be
column4: as well as thinking and hoping that his story was true and not a scam for more money out of us.

column1: On the plus side he did help us out getting a package posted home so things werent too bad. Some word of warning - posting packages back to the Uk is a huge pain!...you have to find a box
column2: take it to a tailors and have it sewn up
column3: then take it to a post office to be sent away. As with India
column4: a simple thing takes forever and is never as easy as you think and the time yo think it will

column1: take will actually take 5x along. Our guy helped us with all of this and we probably paid more for the sewing up part than a local but still only cost a few quid.
One attraction l enjoyed was the elephant garage! it was huge
column2: you know you've made it when you need a garage to keep your elephants in. Another highlight was meeting and talking to a guy selling sugar cane water. He even let Craig make our juice which was fun and surprisingly hard work.

column1: Our last stop of the day was to climb a rather high hill to watch the sunset. This did not go to plan
column2: we followed what we thought was the path- there were arrows but we still managed to take the wrong arrow ending up in someones back garden!..we thought we were back on track but got scared as l read about mountain bears roaming around and also we saw a LOT of HUGE monkeys (rabies alert) up where we wanted to be..we were also the only tourists heading up there which l wasnt loving. so we made it half way
column3: decided we could get a good view of sunset from

column1: Freshly fresh lemonade to cool us down
there and thats where we sat.

The next day we attempted to leave Hampi...we had tried to book train tickets to Bangalore and were on the waiting list - we started at 10 and moved down to 2 during the course of the day we were meant to leave
column2: with a couple of hours to go before the train left we were at 1
column3: so we crossed our fingers and after a bit of a mad dash through the roads of Hampi fearing for the tuk tuk to roll over after a couple of hair raising bends we made it to the train station. We checked with the booking office and we weren't on the train - Plan B was to go in unreserved class. We had done this once but it was empty and was during the day
column4: we decided if we got on (after the stampeed of people) we would have to take it in shifts to sleep and not take any food or drink offered to us as it would most likely have some sort of sleeping drug in it so we would fall asleep and wake up very robbed. If we were lucky we may

column1: be able to buy our way onto the AC tiered sleeper. The train arrived and after looking through the windows of the un-reserveed class and lack of seating and any space
column2: followed by the hundred people trying to get on we abandoned Plan B and had a pep talk/team meeting on the platform to form Plan C.

column1: Plan C - As we left the train station still with no idea what to do
column2: a tuk tuk driver started to talk to us as we thought we had first arrived and needed a lift to Hampi. After explaining our situation the very well spoken Tuk tuk driver suggested we get a sleeper bus to Bangalore from here we could catch a bus down to Kerala
column3: so we headed to Hospet for a look and see if this was possible. Hospet as l said was more where the locals live and was all hustle and bustle
column4: real Indian restaurants
column5: homeless people and really more like India than Hampi. The bus for that night was full but our guy sorted us on the next nights one and was so kind and helpful to us. Next plan was to find somewhere to stay

column1: Sunset on the lookout for bears

Instead of heading back to Hampi we deceied to stay in Hospet and take in the authenticity of it all and thought the money we would save on going back and fourth to Hampi and difference in food cost would get us into the ONLY hotel in Hospet. This was the BEST decision we had made and our second EMERGENCY hotel for a night situation since arriving in India (in the whole trip so far we have only needed one other emergency night in a hotel and that was in Bolivia
column2: but i think twice in India isn't too bad..i mean this is India where things can go wrong and not to plan all the time). The hotel was clean
column3: the room cold
column4: the shower hot
column5: a computer where we could print things off and there was a television with english channels!..The staff werent as good and the tuk tuk driver was x10 nicer with much better english language but it was great and we relished it for the night!.. This hotel was a 24 hour hotel which worked very well for us
column6: so the time you check in the time you leave 24 hours exactly. After a lovely sleep

column1: Super comfortable double bed for sleep and cuddles en route to Bangalore

and nice breakfast we chilled in our room then headed our to see what Hospet had to offer. One great thing was eating in a real indian restaurant with prices to match. We ate a delicious Thali meal which cost around £1 and was very filling. We stayed in our room and watched some english tv before walking over to the bus station to catch our sleeper bus down to Bangalore.
The bus to bangalore was a unique and new experience for us
column2: this wasn't a regular coach in that you sat in a seat
column3: oh no
column4: you got a double bed to share!..WOW!!!. this actually was a great experience and facilitated a rather good kip and a cuddle which is unusual on a night bus! I didnt want to think about the health and safety aspect but we made it no problems whatsoever
column5: probably best we were able to sleep so couldnt hear all the horns and feel the swerving of the bus all night making our minds race!

column1: We arrived in Bangalore at 6am from the sleeper bus. The hotel we were checking into was a 24hour hotel which meant we would have to check out
24hours later with our next bus at 7pm that night. We asked to add some hours on and the reception man responded with somewhat a dr.Evil laugh followed by a firm 'NO'
column2: great!...As not to dwell we got to our box room and had some kip
column3: we were going to need it!...we got a few hours kip and headed out to see what Bangalore had to offer.

column1: First thing was not being able to get a tuk tuk
column2: then the one we found refused to even agree on a price anywhere near what we been advised to pay by the hotel...this wasn't looking good. Finally after asking about 5 taxi drivers and arguing over 50p and 1pounds (it's the principle) we got moving to the main shopping area for some air con action and 'stuff'. Stuff to us means anything western we can look at or even eat. Just as a change from what we had been having
column3: and the ability to buy toiletries. We decided Pizza Hut would be a nice treat -I have no idea why when I don't eat Pizza Hut at home -but it was there and it was western
column4: we had had local food

column1: for 6 weeks so we gave it a go. We ordered the royal pizza
column2: what a mistaka to maka!..YUK! we regretted it almost instantly
column3: our poor tummies were not used to processed rubbish in those pizza's. We felt sluggish
column4: full
column5: had cramps and generally came to wonder what they actually put in processed food! I think we have been eating lots of pure foods for a couple of months that our bodies could not handle the crap found in a Pizza Hut pizza...lesson learnt.

column1: We relaxed the rest of the day in preparation for the following long day to come. We got an early night and set our alarms for our 6am check out time.

At 6am we were up and ready and decided to have some breakfast then hang around the lobby for a couple of hours in the vain hope they would just give us a room...this was not going to happen so around 8am we headed to the botanical gardens and had a lazy wander looking at the pretty flowers and relaxed sanctuary away from the hustle and bustle of Bangalore. Another treat today was going to see the new spider man movie in 3D
which was showing at the local cinema...getting there
column2: walking around the mall
column3: having lunch and watching the film killed some more time and before we knew it it was time for the bus.

column1: This time the bus was a regular coach and it turned out to be a regular Indian journey
column2: by Indian standards. This meant
column3: lots of swerving whilst driving
column4: emergency breaking
column5: playing very loud music all night which meant we generally spent the time not very relaxed and feeling like we were being tortured as the music was so loud you couldn't sleep. I honestly think that 37 hour bus journey in Argentina killed my bum and sitting down for long time skills. After a couple of hours I couldn't do anything to get it not hurting-maybe if l eat some more pies/curry/masala dosa it will become more cushioned?

column2: Displayed: 32

column1: This is my first travel blog anywhere and would love to hear your feedback.
I will start with a brief introduction about Hampi.
Hampi is a village in northern Karnataka state
column2: India. It is located within the ruins of Vijayanagara
column3: the former capital of the Vijayanagara Empire. Predating the city of Vijayanagara
column4: it continues to be an important religious centre
column5: housing the Virupaksha Temple
column6: as well as several other monuments belonging to the old city. The ruins are a UNESCO World Heritage Site
column7: listed as the Group of Monuments at Hampi.

column1: My friend Giri n myself headed for a weekend trip to Hampi towards end of Feb 2014. We travelledd by bus from Bangalore and was an 8 hours journey. On Saturday morning
column2: we rented a motor bike and headed for seeing around Hampi. Ride from our hotel to Hampi was wonderful with an amazing view of paddy fields on one side of the road and sugar cane farms on the other side. We reached Hampi after an hour ride through the villages and farm lands
column3: surounded by mountains.

column1: We could see demolished and partly renovated Hindu temples in each and every corner of that old city. It is hard to

explain the architecture and stone art of those monuments. Each design looked better than the rest.Many of the monuments were destroyed by the Muslim invaders hundreds of years back and some are being renovated. Crowd was less as it was an off-peak season due to summer temperatures
column2: close to 40 C .

we had to limit our visit to a few of the temples on the first day and on the second way we headed for the bear sanctuary which was a two hours ride and watched feeding the bears. Then we headed to Tunga Badra Dam to view the sunset
column3: where we hiked a nearby hill to get a better view of the horizon. We were back at the hotel by 8 PM and it was almost the time to catch the return bus. We returned happily with minds full of memories about that beautiful city.

column1: I have attached a few photos from my trip here. I hope you enjoyed it and please do leave your comments. Thank you.

column2: Displayed: 15

column1: Commerce continues despite the roadworks in downtown Gulbarga
The night passed without incident....a pre-ordered breakfast of Indian stuff arrived 20 minutes late
column2: we part consumed
column3: then set off. Stopped to visit a couple of tombs on the outskirts of town then on to Gulbarga.

column1: In 1991 a man called Michael Kent wrote a detailed description of the Deccan sights
column2: an interesting book though one which will detain no-one unless they David's interest in these matters. He mentioned that in Gulbarga
column3: a foul and unpleaceable odour emanated from the fetid green moat. The moat has long since dried up but we can report that same odour now seems to engulf you wherever you go in the town.......more 14th century battlements
column4: mosques etc
column5: but we had to flee because of the stink.

column1: The day however gets better because unbeknownst to us or our driver
column2: Narendra Modi
column3: the national leader of the BJP
column4: the Hindu extremist-ish party
column5: was holding an election rally in Gulbarga this very day. We had to go down the road where seemingly several hundred thousand of his flag waving supporters were massing. Lots of older gentlemen in Nehru caps and dhotis
column6: lots of energetic youths
column7: all of whom peered into our car looking and pointing at the two whities. David decided to respond with the wave perfected by H.M.Queen. Just the hour in a traffic jam then.......eventually we hit the road to Bijapur
column8: across another 100 miles of featureless Deccani countryside. You have to earn your history and culture around these parts.

column1: Bijapur. A name that resonates through medieval India history
column2: but let's be honest
column3: it is another dusty dump of a town these days. We check in to the Shashinag Residence
column4: “the best hotel in town”. Oh dear God
column5: standards are plumbing new depths here. James
column6: we have now found a hotel lower than the Gaddafi era hotel we stayed in at Benghazi.........toilet window needing to be papered up
column7: light fitting to be replaced.....probably built in the 80s and has not been dusted since. .....what a sh*thole. The people running it clearly know not the first thing about hotel management
column8: though the resident biologist has cultured an interesting green algae not previously known to man in the “swimming” pool.....what a sh*thole. Some Indian youths were spotted disporting themselves in the pool this afternoon......a fleet of ambulances have just arrived at the hotel and a number of youths removed on stretchers....unrelated I am sure.

column1: To our amazement we stumble into two other Europeans
column2: who sadly turn out to be curt nodding and heel clicking East Germans
column3: probably a shot-putting couple
column4: who speak no English apparently other than “two beers” which they keep repeating frequently.

column1: Dinnertime. We stumble into the “food bazaar” in the basement – perhaps they meant food bizarre? Anyway for once we are pleasantly surprised that the food is edible and some 24 hours on the bowels remain closed
column2: so that is a positive. £3.20 for a lavish dinner including a litre of premium Kingfisher.

column1: Never again to see her sandals.....
Our last day in India was supposed to be a quiet day with nothing to do. Things don’t always turn out as planned.
Mr Ali advises us when we leave Mysore that our airport hotel in Bangalore is a 3 ½ hour drive away
column2: so we ask to stop off at one more temple on the way. It’s a small but imposing 13th century temple with just a French woman and a group of three Indians as the only other visitors. As ever
column3: we are told to leave our sandals at the entrance. We stack them neatly in a concrete compartment and look round the temple
column4: which takes under 20 minutes. When we come to leave
column5: Sara’s blue sandals have been replaced with a small black pair. Some mistake
column6: surely? Gradually the awful truth dawns that her sandals are no longer there. We ask the man who purported to be the shoe attendant. He tells us the other visitors took the sandals and laughs. Sara does not find this amusing. We accost
column7: in turn
column8: the security guard
column9: the ticket seller and a guide taking round three newly arrived Irish tourists. The gist of their replies is that none of

column1: Mrs Bond in the Temple of Doom

them is to blame and nothing can be done. We enlist the help of Mr Ali who conducts vigorous conversations/arguments. Still the shoe attendant smirks and says looking after shoes is not his job and anyway
column2: surely I have other footwear. David avoids the impulse to punch his face in
column3: with difficulty.

column1: Mindful of the need for a police report if we are to try to claim on the insurance
column2: we ask where the police station is. The Somnathpur Police Out Post (sic) is a mere 200 yards away. Further discussion ensues between them and Mr Ali. They come with us to the temple and carefully search all round it
column3: as if somebody might have just hidden the sandals as a joke. Nobody had. We ask for a police report and are told that has to be done by an inspector
column4: at a bigger police station. We drive there. More discussion
column5: with ever more people joining in in. Only one guy is in uniform but they all seem to be police officers. Eventually Sara is handed a blank piece of paper and asked to write out her ‘complaint’. She does so. Yet more discussion
column6: and they all head off

column1: to a separate room – to file the report
column2: we are told. They return and ask Sara to rewrite the complaint
column3: this time describing the sandals as missing rather than stolen. Presumably this is to ensure their crime statistics (carefully recorded by year and type of crime on a blackboard) are not tainted by an unsolved sandal robbery. Finally someone appears who speaks some English. After checking several times that all we want is a record that we have reported to the loss to the police (ie no form of investigation) he makes further phone calls to someone called “sir” and tells us he will type up a report. This
column4: he assures us
column5: will take just 10 minutes.

column1: As we sit waiting in the plastic chairs
column2: we are kindly offered tea or coffee. We ask for our fallback request of ‘black tea no sugar’ which causes much consternation. After 15 minutes
column3: two small cups of staggeringly strong white tea arrive
column4: each with a quarter lemon which is pointed out to us with much pride. We accept with effusive thanks and
column5: under the watchful eye of all concerned
column6: squeeze out our lemons into the tiny cups of tea
column7: which we

column1: Overloaded sugar cane tractor with extra passengers
column2: bus careering all over the road and typical motorbike scene with man wearing helmet and woman obliged to take her chances bare headed

column1: then drink with great shows of enthusiasm. Actually
column2: the lemon serves to dilute the otherwise undrinkable concentrate of tannin into something halfway tolerable. After a further wait
column3: the report is finally brought downstairs. All is not yet complete however. Sara has to sign one copy
column4: and the desk sergeant has to sign and stamp it. The sheet is the folded with a flourish and put into an envelope for us. The English speaking officer (well
column5: we assume he is an officer but as he’s not in uniform he could just be a helpful passer-by) informs us with a grin that we are the first foreigners they have ever had to deal with
column6: they were not sure of the correct procedure to deal with foreigners and hence the call to Police HQ. This is also the first ever reported loss of footwear! The latter is probably not surprising as everyone we see seems to wear a 10 rupee pair of flipflops.

column2: we pile back into the car and set off for Bangalore. The journey seems to be proceeding OK until we he hit the outskirts of the city and discover that the flyover/ring road has been closed as a result of the construction of an overhead metro line. This dooms us to the best part of 2 hours driving through the centre of Bangalore
column3: a sort of urban hell
column4: past the wholesale market and down narrow streets under the now closed flyover. Filth everywhere
column5: cows wandering
column6: cows and wretched humans alike sleeping in the filth on the central reservation. Traffic chaos and mayhem beyond description.

column1: Finally we reach our ‘airport hotel’ at 4.45pm. Mr Ali has offered to drive us to the airport in the morning
column2: as it is now too late for him to drive home today. We ask the unsmiling man at reception how long it will take to drive to the airport given we need to be there at 6am latest for an 8am flight. ‘One hour’ he replies. One hour
column3: for an airport hotel???

column2: the good news is that the hotel is clean and the room comfortable (though it is a shame that there is an external light pointing straight into our bedroom through the exceedingly thin curtains). And a big bottle of Kingfisher is only 160 rupees (£1.60) for 650ml. We sit and drink while waiting for dinner sitting somewhat incongruously in a large dining room laid out with enormous wicker furniture which looks like it should be in the garden
column3: and elaborate curtains with draped pelmets that should be in a country house. And bowtied waiters. Bizarre.

column1: Mysore overall is a very pleasant city – wide avenues
column2: fine municipal buildings
column3: though of course very much an Indian city. On our last full day here we went early to the Ranganathittu bird reserve near to Sriringapatna on the Cauvery river. We paid for a trip in a boat with other people
column4: declining a private boat for INR2000. Suddenly the price came down to INR1000 (£10) at which price we said yes. Surprisingly we were not offered a receipt
column5: I wonder if the two rangers declared our payment to their boss?

column1: The reserve comprises a number of small islands in the river. It is a beautiful serene place
column2: with very few people if you arrive early. But peaceful it is not – instead the air is full of the sounds of thousands of birds cooing
column3: cawing
column4: screeching and generally calling to each other. On the boat
column5: you get really close to them. Masses of photos taken with the long lenses
column6: and of course lots of photos deleted later in the day in the search for the quality images.

column1: On to Sriringapatna again as David wanted to explore where the East India Company army made their breach in the

outer wall of the fort and sent in the two “forlorn hopes” to be the first to scale the breach and enter the fort during the 1799 battle. We found the obelisk commemorating the British soldiers who fell
column2: and the breach was south of there. We reckon we found the section
column3: took the photos to prove it. It is fascinating to find a site like this
column4: as it was 215 years ago when our boys came over the breach and took the cold steel to the enemy. The Wodeyars (the Maharajas of Mysore since the British reinstated them after killing Tipu in 1799) were very well inclined to the British
column5: but the whole site is so sadly dilapidated. On the other hand it means you can see it in an unsanitised form.

column1: Back into Mysore. Sara is indulging David today
column2: we eventually find and visit the Mysore Railway Museum. Billed as the second biggest railway museum in India
column3: we were expecting something rather grand given the size and importance of Indian railways. In fact it is comical
column4: very amateurish
column5: but rather fun. You know a site is rarely (never?) visited by foreigners when there is no “foreigner” ticket price

column1: and the little man behind the counter looks stunned to see you.

We feel ridiculously proud of the fact that this morning we have had Mr Ali take us to three different sites he has never visited or taken tourists to before (and probably never will again!) He probably thinks we are completely mad. As he said
column2: ‘most people just go temple’.
we retire to the hotel and rest before setting out again with the faithful Mr Ali to try and visit the Devaraja market. We fail to find it
column3: visit some other market
column4: and decide we have had enough. Time for a beer back at the hotel
column5: where we have take full advantage of happy hour each evening.

column2: Displayed: 6

column1: Sunday morning. David is still recovering from Everton’s loss to Arsenal in the FA Cup. Continuing to meet our craving to eat something different
column2: we reverse yesterday’s move from Indian to European food
column3: and swap out the toast and omelette breakfast of the last ten days for an Indian breakfast of wada
column4: sambur
column5: yoghurt and lassi.

column2: reliable as ever
column3: collects us at 9am and we head to the Chamundi Hills which overlook Mysore. At the top is an old temple
column4: still in use and absolutely heaving with people as today is Sunday and hence a day off. Mr Ali informs us that people start arriving at 5am. We decide not to join the queue
column5: but instead wander back to the car through the numerous stalls selling trays of fruit and flowers for temple offerings and a range of cheap plastic toys and souvenirs. Next stop is yet another Nandi bull temple
column6: and then we go to the Lalitha Palace.

column2: and if you just read their website you’d be very tempted to stay there and enjoy the experience of staying in a palace. Sadly
column3: this one is run by the Indian government and

column1: not the Taj group. The money available for restoration was clearly inadequate and the place presents a picture of faded grandeur
column2: heavily scuffed around the edges. It boasts an ancient lift with an opulent sofa for important people and a grand dining room (once the ballroom). We wander upstairs and a cleaner offers to show us the Viceroy suite where
column3: he claims
column4: Prince Charles and Lady Diana once stayed. It costs £500/night now and definitely did not look worth it. Our 100 rupee entrance fee included a cup of coffee
column5: so we sat in the deserted coffee lounge and were served in solitary splendour. There was no sight of even a single guest.

column1: In the afternoon we headed for Mysore Palace
column2: built at the start of the 20th century after the previous palace burnt down. It’s a hugely imposing building from the outside
column3: but visiting proved a trial. We were elbowed aside brutally in the queue to buy a ticket
column4: and even our finely honed London bus stop skills failed to solve the problem. Once in
column5: we found it was necessary to remove our shoes and check them in. Next stop was the security gate
column6: where we were told
