column1: we could not take our cameras in. They were supposed to left by the main entrance thought there was nothing to tell us this was the case. By now we were barefoot and a fair distance from the main entrance. The security guard suggested that for 40 rupees (the fee for checking in the cameras
column2: he assured us) we could take them in if they were in a bag. We had no bag. After much discussion
column3: he vanished and reappeared with a small flimsy black plastic bag into which we gingerly placed our two large Canon cameras
column4: topped by a hat. The bag was clearly not going to bear the weight of the cameras for more than 20 seconds
column5: so Sara had to clutch it to her body
column6: holding it from the underside.

column2: we joined a long winding queue of visitors. The main attraction is the three large durbar halls
column3: decorated in a bizarre mix of English art deco (the architect was British) and ancient Hindi and Islamic designs. Most of the rooms had turquoise as their main colour theme
column4: and were impressive if not exactly tasteful. In the second hall
column5: we became aware of

column1: a security guard calling after us. Oh no
column2: we thought
column3: he’s realised we have cameras in the bag and is about to expel us or extort more money. We ignored him and marched on
column4: pointing with feigned interest at things – anything – in the opposite direction. All was in vain as he caught up with and grabbed David’s arm. ‘Have you seen the elephants over there?’ he asked? Bewildered
column5: we said no. 'Maharajah's personal elephants you want see I take you'. He had flagged us as foreigners with no guide
column6: and was seeking to offer his services as a guide no doubt for an outrageous fee. We escaped.

column2: we headed for our shoes
column3: only to find we were required to walk all the way round the outside of the palace – still barefoot
column4: on a very hot surface – in order to be funnelled past the elephant and camel ride options (treading carefully around the piles of camel and elephant poo
column5: both of which are found in significant sized deposits). Nice. Finally reunited with our footwear
column6: ignoring the abuse of the shoe man claiming money while standing in front of a sign 3ft high saying it was a free service
column7: we relocated Mr Ali and returned to the hotel to cool down and take advantage of happy hour.

column1: We went back to the palace this evening to see it lit up. What an amazing sight - thousands of lights strung all over the place all shining brightly. turning it into a version of Cinderella's castle.

column2: Displayed: 2

column1: David at Tipu Sultan's summer palace
We drive south through the rice paddies from Hassan. We ask Mr Ali to take us via Sharavanabelagola where there is a massive statue of a Jain saint on a hilltop. We arrive
column2: gaze up at the 660 steps which you must ascend barefoot
column3: and decide to give it a miss. The guide book suggests it’s a 2 hour round trip
column4: barefoot up the rock which heats up. We return to the car
column5: surrounded by aggressive hawkers and beggars clawing at us. We leave this unpleasant place.

column1: Sringapatnam. There are many ways to spell this town
column2: but it was the site of the famous battle in 1799 when Tipu Sultan (he who owned the famous mechanical tiger now in the V&A Museum in London) was killed by the forces of the East India Company. The story was told in one of Bernard Cornwell's “Sharpe” books and David was keen to try and identify the key sights from the book. Sadly
column3: the British demolished most of the fort subsequent to the battle before handing the rule of Mysore state to their puppet maharajah. All that is left are some sad ruins gates and pieces of wall
column4: overgrown and often covered with

column1: rubbish. David did though discover the Water Gate where Sharpe supposedly killed Tipu. Mr Ali was completely puzzled by our behaviour
column2: clearly not too many of his guests behave in this strange way. We also found the dungeon where Colonel Baillie and other British prisoners were held
column3: some for up to fifteen years between 1784 and 1799.

column1: There are also the remains of Tipu's summer palace
column2: beautifully decorated inside but in need of some serious renovation
column3: and the mausoleum that Tipu built for his father Haider Ali
column4: where he is now buried alongside him.

column1: Now it is time to move on the last few miles to our hotel in Mysore. After reading generally poor Tripadvisor reviews on the hotel we were booked into in Mysore
column2: we swapped to a 4 star place in town that costs a mere £30/night. So far it is looking like a good choice – a clean room
column3: internet in the room and a good restaurant. We’ve been away 25 days and had one European meal in the whole of that time. Today felt like the day to extend that to two
column4: and we thoroughly enjoyed our late lunch of a club sandwich with

column2: another photo call

column1: David has spent the last half hour trying to find an online fed of the Everton v Arsenal match
column2: only for Sara to scroll through the multitude of channels on the satellite box and locate a channel showing the match live. His nerves are jangling
column3: Sara is happily enjoying the chance to check the internet.

column2: Displayed: 4

column1: Our fan club at Halebid temple

column2: probably just as well as we were both exhausted after two days of route marching in the midday sun around Hampi. A 9am start proved to be just as well after it took 45 minutes for breakfast to arrive. Who’d think scrambled egg and toast was such a complicated order?

column1: Belur and Halebid are about an hour’s drive away (no hotels recommended anywhere nearer). Both have 11th and 12th century temples
column2: amongst the greatest in India
column3: built by the Hoysala kings
column4: with an extraordinary quantity of exquisite sculpture. Bangles on a dancer’s wrist that move
column5: despite all being carved out of a single piece of stone
column6: 64 elephants marching in a ground level frieze
column7: every one different to the next
column8: dancing girls
column9: gods
column10: demons
column11: mythical beasts
column12: pillars covered with carvings – the list goes on. Both temples were truly beautiful
column13: but we were feeling the effect of the heat and our previous exertions. The guide seemed determined to describe every single sculpture to us
column14: in considerably more detail than we really wanted or needed. The pace and the script were set by the guide showing round a French couple just ahead of us. It rapidly became

column1: clear that every description and every poor joke was identical
column2: while off-the-cuff questions did not get much of an answer. David was so entranced by the carvings that he kept asking subsidiary questions and took 180 photos of them
column3: while Sara sat on a step nursing the remains of a migraine. Heavier than usual photo editing required this evening!

column2: the world’s largest school party was on tour. Round about 100 small children in their neat little uniforms aged probably no more than 6 or 7 were being shown around at breakneck pace
column3: in a long winding crocodile. We made the mistake of saying hello to one of their number who felt brave enough to accost us. Instantly they stopped their march and we were mobbed
column4: with every remaining child wanting to greet us and shake our hands. The noise level rose to deafening proportions
column5: while helpless teachers looked on unable to restore control. Even our guide seemed rather bemused patting one or two of them on the head. Eventually
column6: duty done
column7: we continued on our blow by blow tour of the temple
column8: which features 2 huge statues of the bull Nandi on whom the god Shiva rides

column1: through all eternity. By this time
column2: as David continued his quest for the shooting the perfect image
column3: Sara had reverted to her repeated “er ehr” and “mm
column4: yes” responses when we were told “this is a masterpiece of our temple madam” about yet another sculpture
column5: while her idiot husband compounded the delay by taking yet another photo.......

column2: even Mr Ali declared it hot today.
Displayed: 4

column1: If you are thinking of driving from Hampi to Hassan
column2: be aware that the roads are pretty awful in places. One can see why this is a less well trodden route
column3: most people jacking out of Karnataka at Hampi and taking the train to Goa. Not us though
column4: we were off to see the great temples at Belur and Halebid
column5: which necessitates this drive south. On the way we stopped at Chitradurga
column6: to see the fort situated atop seven adjacent boulder strewn hills. The hill has seemingly been fortified for millennia and fell to Hyder Ali of Mysore in 1780 who lopped off the defeated king's head and stole all his treasure in time honoured Indian fashion. He was then succeeded by his son Tipu Sultan who further fortified the place and was in turn killed by the British at the battle of Seringapatam in 1799
column7: of which more on a later day.

column1: Clearly not many foreigners come here
column2: as we had to wait five minutes as the ticket man rummaged around in his drawers to find the foreigner tickets wrapped in a dusty plastic bag. The fort walls are built of massive stone blocks pieced

column1: together without mortar and for some reason it reminded me of the walls of Mycenae. We were trailed round continually by locals and were stopped more than once for the “please one photo” routine. All very friendly though
column2: handshakes all round with me (not with Sara though
column3: women don’t shake hands in India it seems). We got as high as we could in the heat as of course it was midday and sweltering
column4: then admitted defeat and descended
column5: trailed for a white by nasty mangy little macaque monkeys who seemed to specialise in stealing water bottles.

column2: four hours bouncing over roads that were not so much pot-holed as cratered
column3: and here we are in Hassan. Rarely has a three star hotel felt so luxurious.

column1: It is difficult to convey the scale of Hampi. A city of 500
column2: 000 people
column3: one of the great trading centres of the world in the 15 and 16th centuries
column4: visited by merchants from England
column5: Europe
column6: the middle East and China. Devastated
column7: pillaged and destroyed by vengeful Muslims from the Deccani sultanates after Talikota in 1565 (as the guide kept telling us ad nauseam)
column8: and then abandoned and overgrown by the jungle until discovered by an intrepid Englishman on his horse in the 19th century. And now a World Heritage Site
column9: little known outside India.

column1: Massively long and wide colonnaded market avenues lead up to temple complexes of the 14th to 16th centuries. The temples were also social centres
column2: so you find a dining and dormitory building
column3: a consultation hall
column4: a music and dancing hall and an inner sanctum where the deity would be worshipped in most of the temples. The level of carving varies in quality
column5: as does the level of iconoclasm indulged in by those vengeful Muslims.

column1: The light is rather dead as the day is overcast so the whole impression is one of a rather grey coloured city
column2: the building and massive boulders all around blending one
but with the vivid greens of the paddies and the palm groves counterpointing the grey
column3: the river meandering through adding another dimension. The whole thing feels immense
column4: a lost civilisation recovered from the jungle.

column1: The temperature is passing 30C and rising and our guide suggests a drift down the river in a coracle powered by a nut brown and gnarled boatman to another temple complex. A relief from a half hour walk
column2: we take the coracle as people have done for thousands of years
column3: past reed beds and riverside shrines
column4: the massive boulders all around.

column1: The magnificent Vitthala temple is one of the grandest and home of the iconic stone chariot that features on all promotional pictures of Hampi. A magnificent vehicle
column2: frozen now but capable of movement if it is was let free. Quite unique.

column1: It is now over 35C and time to visit the Royal Quarter
column2: the palaces of the kings and queens
column3: unfortunately all gone apart from their ornate stone plinths as they were all built of fragrant sandalwood and so all burnt in the sack of the city. We see the elephant stables where the royal nellies were kept
column4: and

column1: the queen's palace where she was attended by her vast coterie of ladies and guarded by her faithful eunuchs. Only the intrepid Brits are out in the midday sun
column2: all ridiculously attired in one way or another and exchanging a polite “good morning” in some sort of show of solidarity in the face of adversity (etiquette has to be maintained you know).

column1: One last photographic vista and it is back to the hippie cafe for lunch. Some quick ruthless bartering by Sara for some earrings
column2: no pestering today by the “photo sadhus” who recognise a lost cause when they see one
column3: an invitation from a fierce looking transvestite to enter her shop which is politely declined
column4: assorted beggars and that man who is trying for the second day to sell us a flute on which he plays the first few bars of Titanic.

column1: Mr Ali then takes us to his home for a cup of the strongest tea we have ever drunk
column2: introducing us to his wife and daughter. Sara asks the teenage daughter her age
column3: occasioning a fit of giggles and causing her to hide. The only common ground she could find with Mr Ali’s wife was

column1: to note that her ewing machine was very similar to the 1952 Singer sewing machine Sara inherited from her mother. This went down very well. A small crowd gathers at the door to stare and giggle at the two overheated Englanders. We bid farewell amongst much waving and further giggles
column2: and return to the hotel.

column1: An amazing place seen by a route march in blazing heat that our forebears would have been proud of.

column2: Displayed: 5

column1: The drive from Badami to Hampi is only about two hours. Early excitement as we track two guys on a motorbike carrying a pane of glass at right angles to the direction of travel so it acts as a great big windbreak. They nearly come off as they swerve over a speed bump
column2: but we get bored as they seem to have the hang of it and are not going to fall off
column3: so we tell Mr Ali to speed up. The land is fertile and the trees a mix of deciduous trees and palm trees
column4: coconut and banana groves abound
column5: as do fields of sugar cane and rice paddies. Gone are the fields of wheat and cotton. The temperate climbs again
column6: as does the cloud cover. “Cool today” says Mr Ali. “Only 30
column7: when warm 45”.

column1: Hampi. 29sq km of abandoned 16th century city
column2: the ancient capital of the Vijayanagar empire that was defeated in 1565 at the Battle of Talikota by a confederacy of sultanates from the Deccan to the north
column3: after which the city was sacked for six months and then abandoned. The buildings are scattered amongst massive granite outcrops where you can still see the lava

column1: flows sitting where they hardened in place. Trees are lacking and in the midday heat (when inevitably we are out and about)
column2: it presents a surreal landscape
column3: not to mention a physical challenge as we slip and slide over smooth rock slopes with our hitherto loose fitting clothes plastered to us in the heat. Sweat is salty and it’s impossible to drink enough. But it’s worth it to see the sheer magnificence of this once proud city.

column1: It’s the first place we have encountered any Western tourists in numbers
column2: but Hampi has clearly made it onto the hippy/gap year backpacker trail. Mr Ali deposits us at a backpacker cafe and tells us to meet him at the car park in an hour. Mr Ali knows best so we agree to do so
column3: while probably he pops home as he lives in the next village
column4: which is fair enough. The cafe is run by Nepalis and serves tasty food of the sort that saved our lives in Tibet where the local food was unspeakable. The young things who were hanging out in the cafe were lounging on comfortable cushions and mats on the floor
column5: but the old people were shown

column1: Haven't you got jobs to go to
by the waiter to a table and chairs
column2: he correctly surmising we would not have been very comfortable on the floor. We were at least 35 years older than anyone else in there. We think that the place is a bit out of the 70s but there is no smell of weed drifting around
column3: even the hippy types seem cleaner living these days. After splurging £3 on lunch we fill in the rest of the time by drifting round the shops selling clothing for backpackers and leather goods that will stink the place out when you get them home and realise they have not been properly cured. Fake sadhus wander around offering to have their photo taken for money. We decline.

column1: Once reunited with Mr Ali and the blissfully air conditioned people carrier
column2: we set off to visit sites that we will not go to with the guide tomorrow. Mr Ali’s local knowledge comes in very handy
column3: and most of the sites we visit are deserted. Along the way we see Western tourists toiling up hills on bicycles or risking life and limb on hired motorbikes. All have bare arms and legs and no hats or head protection. Many sport alarming displays of sunburn. There will be a few cases of heatstroke tonight in the backpacker hostels.

column1: The Vijayshree Resort.......a slightly odd place
column2: bungalows set about 100 yards from the main building. The bungalow is in my mind what a Colonial administrator would have stayed in during the Raj while touring his area of responsibility
column3: all a bit faded but basically OK.

column2: no alcohol here so it is lime soda tonight. Sara recoils with horror when she sees the outside dining area with low tables and people sitting on the floor flapping away the mosquitoes
column3: but relief when we are lead to the European's dining room. Indian TV burbles on in the background
column4: David may have to switch it off soon. Meanwhile
column5: outside we hear the beat of drums. The hotel is
column6: in fact
column7: not a mere resort but a heritage village
column8: offering a range of faux rural Indian pastimes for the Bangalore city dwellers – camel rides
column9: dancing and goodness knows what else. They don’t have camels in Karnataka
column10: but let's not quibble.

column1: Strange things happen.... as we sit in the lobby/dining room of our hotel (only place with wi-fi) under the cooling breeze of a fan
column2: a small white rabbit has just ambled past. And left
column3: presumably not wishing to be spotted by the cooks.

column1: Badami is famous for its rock temples
column2: hewn and carved out of massive sandstone cliffs. For once
column3: we don’t need the sensible hats that cause so much derision
column4: as the temples are in shade first thing in the morning. Today we have a guide
column5: recommended to us by our guide at Hyderabad and charging a modest £9 for three hours. There’s no doubt you see and appreciate a lot more with guide
column6: even though yesterday we were so hot we just wanted to keep going and would not have paid attention to explanations of the nine incarnations of Vishnu etc . This guide was good
column7: explaining the place without going into five minute lectures on Indian gods every time he showed us a different carving. The views as we gradually ascended the cliff were impressive
column8: looking across to more cliffs and giant boulders
column9: and down to the man made lake (tank) built in the sixth century to

column1: provide a water supply but now sadly too polluted to be drunk. Instead
column2: a man was washing his ox
column3: and some women were scrubbing rugs
column4: laid out to dry on the steps.

column1: We stopped off in the market to buy some more oranges (emergency lunch supply of fruit and biscuits is always a good idea in case there is nowhere obvious for lunch). From time to time the sheer overwhelming combination of noise
column2: smells
column3: bustle and apparent chaos can be slightly overwhelming. You realise you cannot hear anything other than a background deafening roar
column4: and in a place like this where there are far more Europeans you do not get noticed so much
column5: so you can sort of drift through in a slightly disembodied way. Overlapping images of piles of vegetables
column6: fruit
column7: spices
column8: plastic tat
column9: food stalls
column10: rubbish
column11: rummaging black pigs
column12: and the occasional monkey trying to steal things and being chased off by a stick wielding store holder fill your vision. And all the time that din and the heat beating down on you as the clothes stick to your back and you seek out the shade.

column1: Finally we climb up to one last temple
column2: past a

column1: group of children seemingly mixing cement for some unknown use. The gardener followed us up and opened the temple for us. It’s still in use and he told us he goes every morning to make his puja. He asked anxiously what we thought of the gardens
column2: and beamed when we admired them.

column1: Back to the hotel for a much needed shower and lunch
column2: followed by a relaxing afternoon reading and sorting photos. We're staying at the Krishna Heritage hotel and it is a wonderful oasis of calm
column3: with great service. The mystery of the white rabbit resolved itself when the manager appeared clutching two tiny brown rabbits by the scruff of their necks and proceeded to feed them milk. He explained that they are wild orphans which he is bringing up
column4: but the white rabbit is one he has boiled ..... no
column5: we misheard
column6: one he has bought as a pet and not for the pot.

column2: Displayed: 6

column1: The day breaks in dusty disgusting Bijapur. I awake and contemplate the brown smears on the bedroom wall.....just what is that substance? Best not to think
column2: get up shower
column3: and give thanks that the bowels have held up after last night's delicious dinner – 1.5l of beer
column4: 8 biscuits (cost 10p per packet) and six bananas. We could not face the food bizarre downstairs. We had tried room service; a man appeared with a grease stained menu card. “Is not our menu is someone else's
column5: food not same prices not same but maybe similar”. Excellent salesmanship you will agree. We gave up at that point and took comfort in beer.

column1: By 8am we are packed and ready to flee but Mr Ali the driver does not start till 830am. But at 825am we espy him and run to the car
column2: flinging our cases in. The management do not even bother to check us out
column3: and fortunately for them they did not ask us if we had enjoyed a pleasant stay or we would have unburdened ourselves.

column1: Off we roll across more miles of God's ironing board
column2: the Deccan plateau. The road is a good four lane highway and we

column1: make excellent time. We practise that well known Indian custom of driving the wrong way down the dual carriageway when Mr Ali needs some fuel on the other side of the road. Add that one to the CV.

column2: ” sorry to disappoint) is a cluster of temples built from the 5th to the 8th centuries. Crumbling sandstone
column3: but very evocative and with some beautiful carvings. In one place the temples are actually in a village
column4: with houses and temples cheek by jowl. Pattadakal
column5: a few miles on
column6: is more sanitised as it is a World Heritage site
column7: so better maintained. The villagers there were relocated. By the time we arrive the temperature has soared to well over 30C
column8: and of course we are out in the midday sun as we are British
column9: and that is what we do. We are grateful for the chance periodically to shelter inside the temples. For some reason
column10: David's stylish hat occasions great mirth amongst a group of young Indian ladies. No idea why........our last stop is a Hindu temple complex out of town
column11: clearly a Nandi shrine
column12: as stone bulls are everywhere. The smell of incense hangs heavy

column1: Playing in the 6th century water tank
in the air. There is an ancient water tank
column2: full of dozens of boys and youths messing about and shouting. We get a lot of stares here
column3: as if we have stumbled into a world where we do not belong.

column1: At last we reach out next hotel
column2: a calm oasis in the countryside that is clean
column3: spacious and welcoming. We settle gratefully onto our balcony
column4: whilst keeping an eye open for the monkeys we are told will enter our rooms unbidden if given the chance
column5: and just steal whatever they can lay their hands on......makes a change though doesn't it?

column1: We lingered in the comfort and luxury of the Falaknuma for as long as we could this morning
column2: but eventually it was time to say goodbye and set off on the second half of our journey. Our new driver was waiting for us
column3: in an identical Toyota Innova people carrier to the last one. After a slight hiccup when he took the wrong road
column4: we were soon on the highway for a mere 3 hour drive to Bidar. We have just one night here
column5: partly because it would have been a very long journey to our next destination if we’d driven direct from Hyderabad
column6: and partly to see the fort.

column1: Luckily the driver knew his way round the fort. You enter through the 14th century city walls
column2: which are about 10km long and encircle a large area. We drove along the main road
column3: which would once have been the main shopping street
column4: and stopped first at a huge mosque that had been mostly destroyed by an explosion in 1672. The local children were just leaving their madrassa and getting onto their various buses
column5: so we spent a lot of time saying hello and answering the same old questions: ‘What

column2: ‘Where are you from?’

column1: Next up was the fort itself which is huge and impressive. Our guide in Hyderabad said he had spoken to someone who would unlock the various buildings. Whether or not it was the same person
column2: an old fellow with a key appeared out of nowhere. We looked round another mosque with an Indian family for company. They left
column3: and our guide led us into two separate palaces. Restoration work seems to be taking place slowly and patchily
column4: and we were grateful to have a guide to lead us through the labyrinth of corridors and stairs (including one in pitch darkness that David found especially unamusing). We wandered round some more distant ruins
column5: overheating steadily even though it was 4.30 by now. Back at the entrance
column6: we thought we’d seen everything
column7: but our driver summoned another key holder who took us round yet another palace
column8: this one with bright tiling and amazing carved wood all dating back to the 1400s. It’s extraordinary it could have survived so long given the monsoons. There were very few visitors and
column9: needless to say
column10: no other foreigners. Once again we were much in demand for photos.

column2: it was time to find our hotel. To say Bidar is a dump would be kind. We drove up and down the main street
column3: which outdoes most other Indian streets in looking dirty and unfinished
column4: and eventually found a small grimy sign for the Sapna Continental hotel
column5: handily located above a clothing store and a shop selling TVs. Much discussion ensued at the front desk who claimed we had no reservation despite our pre paid voucher. Mercifully the driver conducted the discussion in Telugu
column6: the local language
column7: and called the travel agent for us. Eventually all was sorted and we were led to our room. Or
column8: more precisely
column9: our suite
column10: complete with a large seating area
column11: two sofas and a mock marble table and chairs for six. Execrable taste but it was clean – such a relief! Though the lack of any hot water till 6am next morning was less pleasing. The manager offered to bring hot water upstairs by the bucket load but somehow that didn’t seem like much of a solution...

column2: but dinner can be ordered in and served on the marble table. £3 for the two of us

column1: produced a tray with 4 foil bags (potato curry
column2: pea and paneer curry
column3: rice and nan) 2 bags purporting to contain lime juice and 2 bottles of soda water. Since lime juice should be clear we didn’t have the lime sodas as
column4: once mixed
column5: a strange orange scum rose to the surface. The food tasted fine but nagging doubts about hygiene remain – fingers crossed and sphincter muscles tightened........

column1: It’s 9.00pm. The TV options comprise Bollywood serials
column2: old sport of various sorts or – most bizarrely – WWF wrestling. I feel an early night beckoning.......... but wait
column3: there’s a National Geographic programme on Komodo dragons
column4: not to mention the last 15 minutes of last week’s Everton match at Chelsea which David watched glumly.

column1: Last view of Varkala beach. It was a bit old hippie. But they were harmless and I liked them.

column2: a bit of a preamble: I actually wrote the bulk of this about two weeks ago
column3: and had thought about rewriting it
column4: but decided to leave it the same but add some postscript so this text and the pictures might be a bit disjointed.

column2: as always I hope you are all well.

column1: A fairly short entry this time round
column2: not to say that stuff hasn’t happened
column3: because it has
column4: but it is just not quite as much stuff as on previous posts.

column2: let me flip that a bit. I have been suspecting for sometime that things that would have filled me with novelty on the previous trip are now pretty much matter of course and so I don’t report on them. I remember on my last trip I would report on things such as frogs in toilets
column3: cows on the streets
column4: the laughable driving
column5: regular power cuts. Things that would intrigue and entertain me have slowly become…..normal.

column1: I must try and reverse this as many of the readers of this current blog were not readers before
column2: so I must make more of an effort to capture these things that define a

column1: Train travel in India can be a hot and tiresome business.
good old fashioned developing country. But please don’t think that I am taking anything for granted I am not
column2: I am deeply appreciative of my current lifestyle.

column1: Does that make sense? I hope so.
But. To complicate things a bit further
column2: I also suspect that I have not really been off the beaten track that much since coming to India. The funny thing about the beaten track is that when you are off it you wish you were on it
column3: and
column4: many times
column5: when you are off it you wish you are on it again. Like all things in life it is all about balance.

column1: Anywoo. So. Last time I left you in Varkala. I liked that town. Which I why I stayed for two weeks. But I did finally leave to head to Cochin to meet a friend called Zane. I met Zane on the Turkey to Iran train (you always meet the best people on trains
column2: especially in remote areas). It turned out Zane was going to be in the North of India
column3: I was going to be in the South
column4: so we decided to meet up half way.

column1: Every house or shop has a little shrine area.

column2: he is interested in stuff
column3: I am interested in stuff
column4: so we had much stuff in common. I have a natural fear and suspicion of technology
column5: he on the other hand embraced technology as an aid that can enhance life. I spent much time warning him that the satellites could fall from the sky and the Internet could breakdown whilst happily following his GPS I Phone and using his various apps to help me identify various onward travel options.

column1: He had to carry on down South to meet up with a tech company developing a gravity light (Google it) and I had to make up South to Goa
column2: Via Mangalore
column3: to meet with another traveling partner.

column1: I met a lass called Neriman when working on the farm in Turkey and I got an E mail about a month ago to say she was heading to India so we decided to meet up in Goa.
Not quite sure where we will go but that is fine. India is that sort of place
column2: just play it by ear. She has some friends who live up in the North of Goa so I think we will head there

column1: A popular Ice Cream make here is Uncle John. I have two Uncle Johns. And as I write this I am reminded that I am also an Uncle John. To those who know all three of us
column2: which Uncle John does this chap look like most? Answers on a postcard.

column1: at some point. Not sure how long we will travel together
column2: it is very hard to know these things.
but I am conscious I am yet to see the “real” India. I have had to deal with a few beggars
column3: seen a small amount of public street defecation but I continue to be reminded that Kerala and Goa are not really the real India. Fear not peeps
column4: I will…….I will.

column2: I also meant to say that the great thing about India is that you can get off the beaten track just by catching a bus twenty minutes in any direction. You don’t need to go to the disputed territory of Kashmir or the lawless bandit country of Mizoram to get away from Westerners
column3: just catch a bus to a town that is not mentioned in the Lonely Planet. Oh don’t get me started on the Lonely Planet…..maybe that is a rant for another time….

column2: so now for the postscript..
met with Neriman and had lots of fun in Goa but I have decided I can’t spend any more time on the

column1: Mother Teresa holding a poor infant. They seems to have stuck her in a disco. The lights rotated. These Indians
column2: they be crazy.
six weeks is just about my limit. I cannot believe I am saying this but….I am bored of beaches.

column1: I can now walk in any beach restaurant in Kerala
column2: Goa or Karnataka and recite the menu without even looking. If I hear another Bongo drum I am going to cry. If someone tries to sell me another trinket they may end up in Hospital. After so many weeks in Beach Huts I am getting desperate for a change of scenery.

column1: Neriman however is just at the start of her trip so these places hold the same appeal as they did for me when I arrived (remember the “life is a beach” comments
column2: the endless photos of palm trees?). India holds so much interesting places I am at a point where I want to and explore a bit more.

column1: I loves a good beach I do
column2: but like all things in life you need a balance. We plan to meet up again later in the adventure because she is a jolly good lass and a fun traveling partner.
I decided to catch the 15 hour over night train (vomit) from Gokarna
another Church. You cannot escape religion in these countries. Where are you from? Are you married? What is your religion? In that order.

column1: to Mysore as an attempt to break away from the coast. Blimey India is big. Google map Gokarna
column2: then Google map Mysore. Ask yourself how it takes 15 hours. It looks like a quick jaunt up the road
column3: but it isn’t.

column1: I am also at the point where I need a break from the heat so I am going to try and find some hills soon. I want to stop sweating.
Those pesky North East States still seem to be calling me….But what folk don’t understand is that at the moment the North of India is very cold. And I mean very cold
column2: so maybe these will have to wait until later on. But
column3: I have a decent Interweb connection in my new place so I can spend some much needed time looking at the logistics of a trip up there.

column2: there we are
column3: a wee update. I really hope that the terrible weather you Brits are being subjected too isn’t getting you down. I have just seen the news for the first time in ages and it looks mighty bad.

column1: I know that this has almost become a standard issue statement but I am
These are the famous Chinese fishing nets of Kochin. They don't seem to be catching very much fish. Maybe the fish ate the rubbish and all died.
sorry if I haven’t replied to any messages
column2: with this superfast Internet connection I hope to make amends.
Displayed: 26

column1: Oh all we ever seem to do is catch a train. I am sure by now you guys are all trained out. I really like train travel and its all so comfortable and well organized. We met a couple in our compartment the husband lectures in tool and dye cutting and she is a professor of engineering/ they had recently been to South Africa so we had lots to talk about. Every youngster we speak to is studying engineering of some sort there is a glut of engineers here and so they in the end take on crappy jobs just to get a job often not even in their own field. And we have the problem in South Africa that we only have one place in Durban where they teach Tool and Dye cutting and that is a huge problem for us as we have to import all the tools we need and no one able to repair them. Very short sighted of our government to close those colleges.
Our meet and great rickshaw was waiting for us that is the first time I have ever had that service in India. We didn’t have to deal with the touts what

a pleasure Thanks Padma Guest house. First we had to try and confirm our onward journey as we were wait listed. We had moved up the ranks and were told we were now number 5 and 6 on the list but don’t worry we will definitely be on. Better had otherwise it might mean we would have to suffer a 10 hour bus drive and Terry would not like that at all and me too trains are so civilised.You can never go hungry or thirsty on a train journey. all the time you hear a food wallah coming up and down the corridor singing what they sell Chaaaaaai or lassi lassi
column2: cooldrinks.
column3: pani water then food calls biriyani
column4: bajias of some kind or another.

column1: We drove past a few villages up some hillocks and down into little vallies. Then a few ruined temples and then more and more until at last over the last hill and we had arrived at Hampi. It had a big dusty bus station – by this I mean an area where busses stopped nothing formal
column2: with the cutest cart shops selling chai and fried snacks (always lots of fried stuff) like chillies in

column1: a bhaji batter that are quite nice once in awhile
column2: and then a couple of rows of carts selling tourist stuff. Hampi is a very special place for locals to come on pilgrimage so its always busy.. On the opposite side there was a post office
column3: school and a few guest houses where’s ours was. It was very nice basic but clean. We had breakfast muesli of a crude but tasty home made kind with big chunks of roasted coconut pieces
column4: curd yoghurt
column5: honey and fruit (tourism city) then it was out to explore the town and we made arrangements for rickshaw driver for the afternoon to do some temple visits. The main section of the town was down the road closer to the river. The streets were mostly dusty and unpaved old houses all now converted into restaurants
column6: guest houses
column7: money changers
column8: shops selling everything from clothes to leather goods and jewelry and of course bakeries selling western style munchies.A good money making venture by 3 older guys is to dress up in traditional clothes say you are a magic man and get photos taken for a hundred rupees. Good wicket guys!!! the only other thing that disturbs the peace

column1: Bob Marley alive and well and played in every roof top restaurant
is an occasional steal of bananas by a cow might start a rumpus with the banana wallah.

We only did the free temples in the afternoon set over many miles its almost like Bagan with the multitude of buildings though very different style and of course religion. In many ways Anchor Wat is closer in religious terms. It was hot and dusty and thankfully we had our trusty rickshaw waiting for us after each temple visit. For sunset we were taken to a lovely spot on the hill where priests were chanting the Ramayana 24/7 there is never a break they never stop there are always 2 priests taking it in turns oh and using a microphone so its loud even if no one is there. Besides monkeys and dogs there were some beautiful wild vivid green parrots flying around and our guide said this is the only temple where they hang out and for sure they were the only ones we saw during our stay. The whole area is full of balancing rocks. Its like there was one huge explosion which I am sure there was and huge boulders of rocks were thrown into the atmosphere and then

came and landed here some of them balancing in the most precarious way. In fact some of the temples too are balancing in a very precious manner too. The sunset did not disappoint either except for the few too many other people who came as well. Well not hectically but one always wants mostly solitude at these moments.

We knew exactly where we wanted to go for dinner as the word had it they sold special Lassi’s and the word was not wrong. Walking around the village after dinner was incredibly special. There is a special peacefulness amongst the mingling of cows
column2: dogs
column3: monkeys and people all in a very unhurried manner that is far away from the big cities. Tourism sure has changed this valley forever but not in a bad way at all. There is no alcohol so that for sure is a big factor. During the day there are many many local tourists who come to make puja. I was up before sunrise the chai shops were already crancking up so of course I had one to start the morning. Then I followed a bus load of pilgrims down to the river to watch

column1: them bath and do their morning rituals. After bathing its off to the Temple.
All the women were wearing fresh flowers in their hair and everyone with fresh bhindi’s on their foreheads. As it was Republic Day the school children were all dressed up in clean uniforms
column2: flag stickers pasted to their cheeks a few had flags. The school was being bedecked with banana fronds the main flag waiting to be unfurled. We could hear them from our guesthouse later singing and saying what I suspect were poems or stories. Everything is always done with microphones and on loud. That is the Indian way.

column1: Terry had hung his bananas in a packet from the burglar bars in our room. The next thing we noticed they had gone. It must have been a monkey who came past and smelt them
column2: broke the fly screen and stole them – would so have loved to have seen him in action the bugger so smart and as Terry says something he will never do again. The pay for Temples were more special of course and one building t that I really liked was a stable for the Kings elephants which I think

column1: was one of the most beautiful. The roof was domed with about 9 domes and 3 different patterns of domes. The insides were decorated in stucco.The elephants had a view out of big doors ways that are now open. they could have been closed originally with wooden doors now long gone. Small openings for people to get through. The walls around this building were amazing all put together without mortice and reminded me so much of my travels to Cusco with Toni. How did they do it without the sophisticated tools we have today?
You stand amongst the ruins of passageways where shops once were
column2: where a whole community lived
column3: ate and prayed and one can only try and imagine the splendor which is nothing now compared to what it was.Yet so splendid in what remains.

column1: We packed early and went for a last dinner and walk about this lovely town it would be a very early call the next morning 5 am departure as I am nervous and we needed to confirm we were on the train. So it was good bye Hampi and I am so glad we came - I loved this place

column2: Displayed: 13

column1: girls selling chili at the Devaraja Market
.....this is what lonely planet says about Mysore. Well
column2: we are not really LP-fans - but this is certainly true. Mysore has everything South India is made of: tempels
column3: pujas
column4: lovely food
column5: hot weather
column6: friendly people
column7: colonial buildings
column8: honking
column9: crazy markets
column10: yoga
column11: all kinds of smells and colours and
column12: a highlight for us (after a long time without): nice cold local beer. This city is a feast for all sins. But come prepared and be ready to dive into this world - otherwise it will makes you crazy.

column1: We were thinking a lot about going to Mysore. The last travelblogs about this city were not really enthusiastic. But in Wayanad
column2: we spoke to so many people who simply loved their time in Mysore that we finally decided to check it out. And did we regret coming there? Of course not - we loved it and could have stayed much longer. It is crazy
column3: it is stressful
column4: colourful
column5: mindblowing - I have no more english words to describe this city. But may be it is not my limited knowledge of english. You must experience this city
column6: there are no words to describe it
column7: no matter in which language. Well
column8: at least

column1: I will try to write a bit about what we did.
First of all we were very lucky with where we stayed. As it was weekend
column2: all the popular places had already been booked. Beena
column3: our angel from Wayanad
column4: found a cheap homestay for us a bit out of town: the Rooftop Retreat. We did not get this fantastatic rooftop apartment which is really a great deal for only 2.000 rupia. We had a very small but superclean room downstairs for only 1.000 rupia including free water and indian breakfast.The owners were very nice and helpful and with the ricksaw it is just a short ride to town. First of all we just walked around the center and got the real Mysore feeling by slowly walking through the Devaraja Market. What a wonderfully bustling bazaar full of traders selling traditional items such as flower garlands
column5: spices and conical piles of kumkum. Of course there is also the typical tourist stuff - but you have to bargain hard. On our first visit we did not buy anything but took it just all in. Outside the market we found a music store and decided to buy some traditional music. We were

column1: just standing inside listening to a CD when a cow walked passed and put her head into the store looking at us. This was so surreal for us (for the locals it must have been normal) - it was a good combination of the modern world and the tradition Mysore is made of. We had lunch at the travellers' famous Parklane Hotel which was nice
column2: especially the cold beer. Since New Year we had not had anything else than water and tea (just because beer was not available)
column3: what a nice taste of the first sip! The next morning after a delicious homecooked breakfast at our homestay we went up to Chamundi Hill. This is one of the 8 most sacred hills in South India and there were some celebrations going on that day. So it was packed with people and
column4: of course
column5: cows. We made our way to the main entrance. Before entering the palace
column6: we got a blessing and then could quickly walk through the tempel receiving a Darshan and another blessing inside. It was amazing to see how all this people were quickly led through the tempel
column7: all receiving their darshans and blessings. An amazing experience and

column1: we were really happy that we already know the meanings and rules of how to behave and what to do on such an occasion. Afterwards we descided to walk down the 1000 steps back to town. After halfway
column2: you can see a big statue of Nandi
column3: Shiva's vehicle. Back in town it was time for a late lunch before we did some big shopping which was good fun and we made some really good deals concerning clothes. Walking through the streets suddenly someone called our names. We turned around in surprise - well
column4: the street was packed with locals
column5: who is knowing us here anyway? A french couple we met in Wayanad was standing behind us. Funny. We would not have found us if we had tried to. But these guys were not the only ones we met....

column2: sunday
column3: we were ready for the Mysore highlight: a visit to the Palace. From outside
column4: this palace really is spectacular. Around town there are more wonderful
column5: colonial buildings giving the city a certain grandeur. But this palace really left us speechless (which is so difficult
column6: as we both love talking ;-)). We entered the gardens and first visited

column1: Can you spot the elefant we saw on our way from Wayanad to Mysore?

an old Vishnu Tempel which was also very beautiful and overall peaceful. As there are no photographys allowed inside the palace we first walked around the gardens taking some pics. In one shady corner of the park we saw some elefants. As Markus loves those animals
column2: we went there. We got some elefant blessings (the elefant put his trunk on our heads and gave us a big blow with some awfully warm air). Finally
column3: we could also sit on the elefant. We gave the guys a few rupia for this. Later we discovered that this was a real bargain for us. Even local tourists pay nearly the double price to sit on the elefant. How lucky we had been!

column2: we also visited the palace. It was again packed with people and many school classes. But it was really beautiful with some amazing architectural details. We loved the detailed wood carvings with marble. And suddenly
column3: just in front of us
column4: were our friends from Belgium - the family we had met in Kannur a couple of days earlier. Spontanously
column5: we had lunch together and spent the rest of the afternoon walking around town to some sandalwood shops and

column1: also trying all the famous sweets in coffee shops. That was good fun and it was great to see you guys again - have a safe ongoing trip!

We ended our time in Mysore with one more highlight - a visit to the palace in the dark when it was illuminated by around 100.000 light bulbs. It was stunning! We felt like in Disneyland. The whole atmosphere was breathtaking. There
column2: again
column3: were many people
column4: but all were happy and peaceful and we simply had a great time taking this all in. What a better way than ending a perfect day with a nice dinner on a roof top terrace at Gandhi Square.

column1: Much too fast our time in Mysore was over. We had not expected to enjoy an indian city that much. Still there are a lot more things to see and do. But we decided to move on anyway. Our time is limited and some more interesting destinations are waiting for us. A bus was taking us up into the mountains again - over 2.000 meters into the heart of the Nilgiris.
Our next stop: the chilly and strange hill station of Ooty.
they collect the garbage in some areas of Mysore....
Become a fan on Facebook: http://on.fb.me/oRswdi

column2: Displayed: 26
3 hours southeast of Bangalore
column3: on our way to the government silk factory
column4: when 3 cows across the street caught my attention. After 3 months in India
column5: I usually don't notice cows anymore. We've seen cows in the city
column6: cows standing on a thin grassy median surrounded by relentless Indian traffic
column7: cows on the beach
column8: cows on the train station platform
column9: cows in restaurants
column10: cows in temples. Big cows
column11: little cows
column12: camel cows
column13: cows with painted horns adorned like an Indian bus
column14: sleeping cows
column15: walking cows
column16: stampeding cows
column17: frisky cows
column18: even self-pleasuring cows (seriously). I usually don't give them a second glance.

column1: I don't know why they're yellow
column2: or how they're yellow. All the white spots on the cows we saw in Mysore were dyed yellow.

column1: There was a tree blooming with yellow flowers
column2: and we thought that might have been used to dye the cows' white hair. But we're not really sure.

column1: We were in Mysore during the last week of January. There there were no festivals we knew of going on that week. But in India
column2: there are always festivals and holidays of various religions and cultures that we often know nothing about.

column1: Why were all the cows yellow?
The road down the mountain towards Mysore was rough and rugged but travelled through National reserves so we were entertained with flocks of pretty spotted deer
column2: a baby elephant being washed in a stream and a group of very cute black faced monkeys who had decided to come down to the road to watch the humans and play a game of chicken on the road. They observed us as much as we observed them. The road became much better once we hit the flats and we motored quickly to Mysore
column3: pausing once to admire the pelican elegantly fishing in a lake and a group of pelicans nesting up in the trees. Once we arrived in Mysore we headed directly to the palace. The place was teeming with tourists and we learned from Antony that it was the 'number one' palace in India
column4: and second most popular tourist attraction after the Taj Mahal. We were not allowed to take photographs and in fact could not even take a camera inside. The bag screening indicated that Sue had a camera and security were insisting that she take it to security until a guard called Roy over and said that it was okay and she could keep her camera but not take photographs for a tip. Roy handed over the hundred rupees explaining to the guard that this was a bribe/ not a tip - the guard was happy whatever the language
column5: Sue was happy that she kept her camera
column6: so we popped off our shoes and headed in. Firstly we got herded into a line by a very officious elderly gent with a stick which he banged on the floor
column7: banged in the pole and waved at us yelling and gesturing to us in Indian. It was quite strange to be treated like cattle but also very funny. We were basically herded through the entire place in a long snake of tourists which was okay except if you needed to go through a door and these became very claustrophobic as everyone tried to jump the queue. The palace was spectacular and is the official residence of the Wodeyars
column8: the royal family of Mysore who ruled for over seven centuries. I have put in a link as we had very little information about it and became quite interested. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mysore_PalaceAnother 5 star dinner- to bed.

column1: Anusha's family have agreed to rent us a room they own at only 1200 rupees per month (about AUD$24). This is a fantastic achievement given that the rent in the village is usually over 2000 rupees per month.
For two months we will occupy a smaller room on the top floor of their house
column2: until the current tenant of the larger room moves out. The larger room is a separate dwelling on their property
column3: with an attached bathroom.

column1: We are all thrilled about this.

column2: we have one great candidate named Apoorva. She is about to start her Masters in Science
column3: and has a fantastic grasp on English. Her father is also very supportive
column4: we just hope she will be able to fit Pod into her busy schedule!

column1: I'm loving all your comments and feedback
column2: so please keep them coming!

column1: We are still swanning around in luxury; lovely Thai dinner last night
column2: pedicures
column3: swimming in the pool
column4: sitting enjoying a drink at the al fresco bar and delicious complimentary breakfast. The staff are just lovely and did I mention the beds? Goose down pillows and duvets
column5: crisp clean sheets and thick luxury towels- oh so mmmmmmmm.... We did however tear ourselves away to go sightseeing this morning and then some last minute shopping. Bangalore is ( according to the guide) the largest city in India with a population of close to 2 million. It is much cleaner and much more modern than other cities we have visited. We visited the Hindu Shiv Temple and had a quite different experience from what we expected. Firstly we dropped 108 silver coins on a snakelike walk through 108 bronze urns then we tied off our red thread to leave all our problems behind. We then started on a 'symbolic pilgrimage' through narrow tunnels that housed copies of holy shrines from other parts of India. We burned incense
column6: threw a coin into the water ( wishing well) floated a candle and poured a milky substance over a stone. These all had significant meaning and we

column1: Pouring milk over the holy stone at the Shiv Temple

were given a pamphlet about it as we left. The towering four armed elephant idol and huge Shiv idol were impressive though the polystyrene Himalayas background was a bit odd. From here we headed to the Bangalore Palace
column2: which was built after the Tudor style and looked amazingly English from the outside. Inside we donned audio guides and started our tour
column3: walking up the rosewood staircase
column4: passing under the huge trophy elephants head shot by the present maharajah's father. There were fascinating insights into royal life and the palace held a real charm as well as architectural interest. The internal gardens and womens quarters were lovely. There were many photographs of grizzly hunts of magnificent tigers
column5: elephants and other game animals. Underneath the photographs were grizzly elephant feet stools and one stool where the four legs were of some poor beast- a bit gruesome really. Apparently he saw the light in the early 1900s and now all these animals are protected.

column1: Shopping was great and it was back to the lap of luxury!!!!

column2: Displayed: 5

column1: We got up to head to our final Indian destination- Bangalore. On the way we visited a summer palace. It was gorgeous
column2: still original
column3: fading and pitted in parts but still lovely. It was much smaller and housed a lot of history; finely worked aquatints from the 18 the century
column4: a number of portraits of the ruling family by Thomas Hickey. These were very simple but expressive and sympathetic to the individuals. Weaponry
column5: fresco paintings and explanations gave the history of the battles against the British. We arrived in Bangalore at our hotel. It was grotty!! That was it
column6: we decided we would like a decent hotel before we left India so we talked to a local who recommended the Oberoi. We packed our bags back into the van ( much to the consternation of the hotel owner) and arrived at the Five star Oberoi-Bangalore. Oh luxury! It is divine. We spent the rest of the day here. The credit cards are getting loaded but we decided we needed a treat.

column1: Alarm went off at about 0600 for all in the room. This was probably a bit of a relief as the bed was hard and we were fully rested. We joined a guide
column2: 2 others and Anne from the group on a bird watching tour. We walked around the 17 acre property and saw:

column1: · A pair of malibar horn bills
· Evidence of a slothbear breaking down a termite nest

We also saw painted cattle for the first time. Back to the retreat for a hearty breakfast. We settled our bills and the various tips and got back into the minibus headed toward Mysore. We followed the same rounds as we dead for the safari the previous bight
column2: narrow with steep drop away edges. We passed through 3 national parks and spotted langurs
column3: wild boar
column4: macaques
column5: spotted deer and unfortunately no elephants. The parks were quite clean and clearly actively managed. A buffer zone of at least 50m was created between

column1: the road and the low vegetation around. We saw a family of langurs literally hanging around the tress
column2: watching the passing parade of cars. One group of tourists were cycling through the park! The plains became more fertile as we approached Mysore. One the outskirts we drove up a mountain to see the Chamundeshwari temple right on the top. Dry landscape dotted with gum tress. Pilgrims dressed in black swarmed over the temple site. Catherine and I were each shooting off.

column1: Down towards Mysore on the other side of the mountain we had a good overview of historical Mysore. We stopped to see a huge bull statue – the vehicle of Shiva. Young boys were dressed as characters from the great Hindu books. There was the monkey king
column2: with a painted face and large lips. Local fruit stalls are plentiful
column3: it’s a pity we cat enjoy them.

column1: Towards the bottom of the hill we went past cattle that had been dyed yellow with turmeric
column2: as part of a festival. These subsequently appear all over Mysore. Mysore seemed clean and quite regal
column3: perhaps a university town. We drive past the palace and some upmarket department stores. We got to

column2: so Catherine and I grabbed what we could for lunch. We ended up sharing a thick dip like puree of spinach and lentils
column3: topped with melted cheese.

column2: through facebook
column3: that she was looking for an apartment in Udaipur for the girls to share. Anne (who teaches at a Steiner school)
column4: wanted to buy cheap saris for all 15 girls in her class. Catherine
column5: Kathleen
column6: Vicki
column7: Roger and I joined her. It was at a government store
column8: so the price was fixed. But none the less there were hundreds of options to sort through. 15 beautiful saris were purchased for the girls
column9: as well as one for Anne to make a dress for her son’s wedding in Mexico next year. When we finished it was after dark. There was some difficulty in connecting with the other half of the group who had been to the markets. Several loops of Mysore CBD
column10: and frantic phone calls before we connected again.

column1: Well and truly dark by this time
column2: so we were able to visit the palace which was lit up spectacularly as part of the festival. We wandered through and captured what we

column1: could using our fantastic Leica. The group then went to a beer garden restaurant with many tourists and a standard indian ensemble playing. I was struck the incredible diversity of western styles on show
column2: with a couple of punks sitting just near us.

column1: I was feeling a bit tentative about food
column2: so I had a mushroom machali. I also tried another form of bread called kalcha
column3: which was completely dry. I discussed with DJ the differences between chapartis
column4: roti
column5: naen and kalcha. This amount of curry and bread worked well. Catherine had a mocktail of mango
column6: as well as her first butter chicken of the trip. The group was completely exhausted by 2130
column7: so we headed home. DJ
column8: our guide
column9: told me about his experiences as a guide and how on occasion
column10: tour companies black ban difficult clients.

column1: I fronted for an ordinary breakfast of bread
column2: jam and pawpaw. We were to visit a temple outside Mysore during the morning: Kesheva temple at Somnathapur. There was a local guide in our minibus by the time we all gathered.

column1: The temple was about 50 minutes out of town through wonderfully lush farm land. We saw

column2: vegetables sugar cane. The cattle are decorated with different colours here
column3: with streamers and glitter coming off their horns In the Mysore paper that morning
column4: I saw photographs of cattle and people jumping through fire – all coloured with turmeric. This was all part of the festival. The temple itself had features like AngorWat. It was a monument to Vishnu. The guide was excellent telling us about the interpretations of the images and icons.

column1: The guide showed us some of the features that are mnemonic. Three showing faces of Brahma plus a beard
column2: Havati has a book and an instrument
column3: gods can have as many as 36 arms: mortals only 2. Some exquisite carvings of daily life and the great battles of the religious texts. Many of the small statues have been distributed around the world. Beautiful tress in the actively renovated garden. I particularly noticed the rain tree (Albizia).

column1: We then went back to Mysore and directly to the palace. We embarked on a palace tour with a guide
column2: who really put on a pantomime. There was a

column1: spectacular hall for royal weddings. Paintings dating to the early 1900’s
column2: where eyes seamed to follow you no matter where you stood. The palace was packed with Indians
column3: around this festival day. Spectacular statues of jaguars guarded the palace. The whole thing was paid for by taxes from peasants and rajas. The tiles came from England
column4: stained glass from Glasgow. After the tour I was able to return to the plaza area we had photographed the night before. Lunch was again at a small public eatery
column5: where 35 RPS (about 75c)
column6: bought roti and several masalas. I got back to the hotel on the back of a small motor bike with the palace guide. Held on tight! I blogged in the room until we left for dinner at the house of a Muslim family near the station. A simple 3 room attached house. The table for 13 swapped it. The father was a friendly ‘Tevier’ type of character. Long suffering wife was definitely happy to have both daughters married and 3 grand children. One of the daughters had moved home: the custom is for the daughter to move from her husband’s family home back to her parents 3 months before

column1: the birth of a child and stays for 3 months after the birth. House had simple décor and heated floor – perhaps not intentional.
They served a lovely bhiriani of chicken and nuts. Wonderful for delicate stomachs
column2: not too much ghee.Also an eggplant sambal and cucumber raita. Talk was free and our host was very engaging. Desert was golabjaman and custard. Entertainment was a copy of the wedding album. Bride and groom not smiling.High gloss paper.Only 450 guests. One grandchild ‘helped’ Andrea read through the book several times. The other daughter’s wedding had 4
column3: 500 guests as the husband was a ‘big’ business man. We then left for the station.

column1: DJ told us that he is always stressed when getting onto night trains. Criminals target tourists who are dealing with all the chaos
column2: and obviously tour groups get caught up in it. We gathered just beside our tour bus and covered each other’s backs. The train we were after was on the first platform and the carriage not too far away. Of course the carriages were dirty and not very inviting. Nonetheless the insides are clear enough. We were sharing our compartment with four of the other travellers. We got

column1: Catherine onto the top bunk and she immediately went to sleep. Gradually the other five found their respective bunks. Big backpacks were secured under the bottom bunk and there was not much extra space. The train started on time and lights-out was at about 2230.
