column1: Bella is doing well at the Voice of Stray Dogs. He is anaemic
column2: but is responding to treatment.
if you want to follow his progress yourself
column3: you can go to http://www.strays.in/ and type in my email sheree.venter@outlook.com

column1: I will keep you all posted though on his progress. Think about liking their Facebook page for updates on their other rescues and research at https://www.facebook.com/strays.in?fref=ts

column2: Displayed: 1

column1: India is filled with stray dogs. I was prepared for that. But then I met Bella.
Bella was lying by the main road in our village
column2: helpless and sick. He was severely malnourished
column3: barely able to walk
column4: and totally unloved. You could see his ribs ripple under his skin every time he breathed.

column1: And nobody seemed to care. Everyone here would walk straight over him.
I have been trying to feed him milk and soft biscuits this past week
column2: but he remained extremely weak and unresponsive. He made my heart break.

column1: So last night I got in contact with Rakesh
column2: the founder of Voice of Stray Dogs (http://www.strays.in/). Check out their website! They are a not-for-profit organisation that rescues and gives medical treatment to stray dogs
column3: and helps rehabilitate them. They have animal ambulances
column4: and qualified vets on staff. Rakesh confirmed that they could treat Bella. I now had a plan...

column2: lying by the road as usual (see the photo)
column3: and carefully lifted him into a box with a towel as a bed. I was so worried I would hurt him
column4: he was so fragile.

column1: a bus and a rickshaw into Bangalore city
column2: where the Voice of Stray Dogs has its office and shelter.
the founder came to meet me and Bella
column3: and assured me that they would look after him! The vet said that Bella had a fever and an extremely low blood count
column4: but they could help him!!!

column1: I must admit I cried. I know that I cannot fix India's problems in a month
column2: or even a village's problems. But you know what? I could solve this poor dogs problems. And thanks to Voice of Stray Dogs
column3: I believe I did.

column1: If you would like to follow Bella's progress
column2: pop onto their website
column3: and type in my email: sheree.venter@outlook.com

column2: if anyone is wondering
column3: I named him Bella
column4: because it means beautiful. When you look through the fleas and emancipation
column5: you can see how beautiful he is.

column2: Displayed: 9

column1: One of our catch-phrases here is ""TII"" to stand for ""This is India.""
We just had a TII moment...
We were in Bangalore city for the weekend
column2: and had to head home this evening. We found a lovely auto-rickshaw driver who would give us the meter fare
column3: and was even willing to drive us ALL the way home! Usually this trip requires you to change rickshaw's twice
column4: to put this into perspective. He was even willing to wait for us to finish dinner before driving us the final leg home. Top Bloke.

column1: Rural India. Rough roads. Speed bumps. Darkness.
Thankfully I had my teeny tiny torch on me (It's smaller than my pinky and puts out about 10 lumes). So for most of the trip home
column2: I was half hanging out of the rickshaw
column3: pointing this tiny flashlight at the road!

column1: I am loving my time at the 40K plus pod here in Maralakunte. As many of you know
column2: I have had trouble interacting with children in the past. I am loving it here though. The kids are lovely
column3: enthusiastic and well behaved.

column1: Pod time consists of the welcome song
column2: and 2 sessions of 15 minutes on the tablets. These are broken up with ""Brain Breaks"" where we play games
column3: such as Bullrush
column4: Stuck in the Mud
column5: Bang and Simon Says. Finally there is a 15 minute session of spoken English
column6: where we generally break up into smaller groups to help the kids with conversational English.

column1: 40K is in the process of upgrading its curriculum and delivery method
column2: changing it into a fully interactive app
column3: which is very exciting!

column2: please consider donating to 40K
column3: to help these pods keep running until a totally financially sustainable business model can be implemented. The new interactive app is going to be amazing
column4: but it is also a huge capital expenditure. Even five bucks makes a difference here!

column2: feel free to comment on these posts. I'd love to hear your thoughts and impressions. Any requests for a blog about

column1: a particular aspect of life here is also welcome!

column2: Displayed: 7
is a very beautiful place which I had been waiting to explore since quite sometime now which finally we (me and my husband) managed to plan it in December 2013 from 21st to 25th.

column1: To start with what hampi is all about
column2: Hampi is the former capital of Vijaynagar Empire where you can see beautiful Virupaksja temple
column3: Vitthala temple
column4: Lakshmi Narasimha and many more. The ruins of Hampi are a UNESCO world heritage site. Along with the beautiful Hampi ruins
column5: you will find boulders all around which makes climbing on them an amazing experience.

column1: We started off from Pune via VRL bus on 20th Dec. around 10:30PM and reached Hospet at 8:30 AM. It takes abt 9 hours to reach Hospet. Hampi is abt 30 minutes from Hospet... You can reach Hampi from Hospet via the state run buses or you can drive in a rickshaw. We being tired
column2: hired a rick which charged us around 180Rs to drop us till Virupaksha temple.

column1: We stayed on the other side of the river and abt 4 KMs after crossing the river. I had booked Gowri resort and was a perfect decision as the rooms were really clean and

column2: had a nice swing on the front where I could sit hours together just gazing at the skies and the boulders.. They also had rice fields which added to the beauty... Also very close is Sanapur lake which is unexplored by tourists as its far from the main river but its really too beautiful.. The food was good too so we didnt bother to go out to eat ever.

column1: You will also see a lot of foreigners staying on the other side of the river
column2: mainly as Hampi is a holy place
column3: you will not get non-veg food and Alcohol which is both available on the other side of the river.

column1: We hired a bike for all the 4 days and thoroughly enjoyed our stay... Hiring a bike gave us the flexibility of reaching a place at our pace and not being bothered.. Bike is charged abt 200Rs per day and 100 Rs/liter petrol. We visited it at the right time so the temperature wasn't too high though by the end of the trip
column2: i was all tanned. (which I still am recovering from ) Hampi is pretty hot during the day so ensure that you use

column1: The highlight of the trip was Vitthala temple
column2: Virupaksha temple
column3: Ganesh temple
column4: Matanga hills
column5: Krishna temple and Monkey hill.. You shall visit Matanga hills if you stay in Virupaksha side of the temple and visit Monkey hill if on the other side of the river
column6: for sunset.. You get a beautiful view of the entire Hampi from both the hills... we truly enjoyed seeing the view and wish could be on the hills every evening to see the sunset..

column1: We had hired a guide for few hours to show us around Vitthala temple
column2: Virupaksha temple
column3: Matanga hills
column4: Achutraya temple and all the important other ruins. It was nice to know the history behind these places. We went to Lakshmi Narsimha
column5: Krishna temple
column6: Shivlinga all by ourselves as it was all walking distance. Also we ensured that we travelled on bicycles one day (cycles are one of the ways to explore around Hampi) after we had seen all the important ruins and just be all by ourselves... we thoroughly enjoyed our bicycling experience... Coconut water helped us refresh ourselves whenever we were tired with cycling.

column1: This has been one of the best
trips till date.. Do try to visit this place when in India and I am sure you will be happy you visited Hampi...

column2: Displayed: 12
where we will be staying for the next month!

column1: I have seen a massive juxtaposition between the wealthy and the poor here. We have walked through a village past a dog dying of starvation (I wanted to cry)
column2: and soon after passed a house with solar heating on the roof and a car out the front. In the city you occasionally pass the luxury car in your auto-rickshaw
column3: for which you are paying 20cents per 1km!

column1: The village is larger than I expected
column2: and has a brand new temple
column3: which only opened recently. This means that they have celebrations every night for the following month
column4: with blaring prayer music
column5: gong-banging and incense burning! Lots of fun
column6: unless you want to go to bed early
column7: what with the temple across the road from our apartment!

column1: Today we attended our first +Pod session. The kids were amazingly keen
column2: and excited!

column1: The program runs for one hour
column2: were the kids work in groups of three for 15 minutes at a time on a tablet
column3: with ""Brain Breaks"" in the middle. We played Simon says in these

column2: I folded it/ put it on myself!

column1: breaks- they seem to know their body parts!!
As part of my stay here with 40K
column2: we are working to set up a new Pod in a village called Chikajala about 15km from where we are staying.

column1: We approached the local government school today
column2: and had a mixed reaction. The English teacher seemed very keen on the idea of 40K Plus Pod
column3: but apprehensive about the admission fee. We believe however that parents with recognise the value of the program focusing on improving their kid's English foundation.

column1: It is so important to get these pods being financially sustainable and accessible to the poorest families
column2: but achieving these dual aims is still hard. At the moment fundraising is making up the difference. Please think about donating to help us work towards a sustainable model. At the moment
column3: the 200 kids in the program would not be here without your support! Visit http://makingadifference.gofundraise.com.au/page/VenterS to donate!

column1: Tomorrow we will go back and talk to the other government school and another English teacher who is interested in facilitating the Pod classes.

column2: Displayed: 10
a stopover in Frankfurt and much fitful non-sleeping
column3: I have arrived in India!

column1: We landed at the ungodly hour of 2:30am
column2: so truth be told
column3: I'm a little bit like a walking zombie today!

column1: I have made my first foray into the city to purchase some much needed coffee (a surprisingly acceptable latte) and Indian styled clothing.
I now have a beautiful sari (whose blouse is being tailored today
column2: so I can't show you it just yet) and a traditional ""salwar kameez"" (the long tunic
column3: trousers and scarf). I somehow feel like I paid more than I should have for these... but what the hell
column4: being ripped off once or twice is part of the fun isn't it?

column2: when I have some pics to post.

column1: Also- please leave comments on these posts (even if it's just your name) since I'd love to know who is actually reading these! Cheers
Our last breakfast together as Pete and Jane were going home today. No radio active marmalade for a change
column2: the colour of it has generally been bright to say the least. Very sad to say goodbye to them as they have been great travelling companions and also say goodbye to Bala
column3: he had been great to have as our driver.... Sal got emotional again with all the goodbyes and as we were all hugging and saying goodbye a tuk tuk driver came and joined in! Sal and Col had a bit of time so took a short ride in a tuk tuk just because we like a ride in them and the driver was lovely
column4: his name was Babu. He took us to see a huge tree
column5: he said it was a rain tree that had been decorated for Christmas and found 2 kids playing cricket and Col had been longing for a game all holiday
column6: at last he had his chance
column7: the kids thought he was mad! Sal had a chat with their grandad who was so pleased we were British and said how the place wasn't the same since the British left India and rubbish/litter was

column1: his main gripe. Next to where they were playing cricket on a rough bit of ground was the tuk tuk driver training and exam area
column2: that figured! The tuk tuk driver spoke great English
column3: between him and the man in the laundry we understood more than we did from the guide! The tuk tuk driver called his vehicle his open air 3 wheeled Ferrari!

column1: As Jane and Pete headed to the airport
column2: Col and Sal met their new driver David and smaller vehicle. We were heading north to a small village near to Palakkad. Apart from Bala we have decided all Indian drivers are mad and David was no exception
column3: once out of the city
column4: the road was one lane each way and not in great condition but they drove the same.... For instance
column5: the car In front of us was overtaking a truck and we overtook both but at the same time the same was going on on the other side of the road so a 2 lane road had 6 cars abreast
column6: we clenched our buttocks and closed our eyes! You have to give credit to the Motorcyclists and tuk tuk drivers who get pushed out of

column1: the way and really have to have their wits about them constantly. Not that we would consider doing a self drive holiday here but if we did
column2: Col's vehicle of choice would be a steam roller!

column1: We stayed in a home stay again
column2: an old family home that had been in the family for 5 generations. It was a beautiful old house with lots of dark rich wood and seemed to be built around what would have been 2 small bathing pools. Shoes left at doorstep. Our host had a long name
column3: he said to call him Bugs and he had a dog called Dodger who was a pug and real character
column4: he actually had 2 more dogs in kennels in the garden and 3 puppies of Dodgers too. We ate with Bugs in the evening
column5: he had a woman housekeeper who cooked and served the most delicious food
column6: it really was very good. He was slightly odd being mine host as he had dinner and breakfast with us as he said he did with all guests but never asked us anything
column7: we did our best to keep a conversation going asking him various questions but he asked us

column2: seemed odd. We went for a walk in the local village and were warmly welcomed by everyone we saw
column3: but we were doing battle with Mosquitos which carried on for our entire stay
column4: so inside seemed a better bet.

column2: we set off for Coonoor which is a 4 hour journey mostly vertical. We have no idea how high up we drove but we passed some clouds. The journey wasn't the most comfortable as it was hairpin bend after hairpin bend and lots of overtaking going on
column3: there are numerous signs saying dangerous bends
column4: no overtaking......... Nobody read them. A couple of times we would have to stop as they had got in a tangle ahead of us and someone had to get out of a vehicle to make others move back to allow the traffic to move. Bus drivers are mad men +++
column5: they go tearing along and take the downward bends on the wrong side of the road aaaggghhh! Our hotel is another homestay and we are in the deluxe suite
column6: it makes us laugh how they like to big things up with names
column7: it was hardly deluxe but

column1: has lots of room and everything we need. David took us down to the town for an hour
column2: it was pretty manic so an hour was probably enough. The market was lively as they all are
column3: fruit
column4: veg
column5: flower garlands
column6: clothes
column7: shoes
column8: bags and everything else you might ever need. Full of people and noise but fairly clean which was good to see. Our driver like most of them sleeps in the car which we feel quite uncomfortable about and can't imagine he gets that much sleep when he has so much driving to do
column9: anyway we bought him some chocolate and nuts as a New Years Eve present.

column1: Our hotel was offering a 'gala' dinner for New Years Eve
column2: there was about 20 people and it was out in the garden. They had a roaring fire going as it was very cold being so high up and they did well
column3: a good selection of food and a great guy making the breads
column4: he would have given a pizza maker a run for his money with his style
column5: we have to admit to sliding away at 11pm and tucked up in bed to see the New Year in plus

column1: the hotel was dry so waiting another hour in the cold to raise a glass of water .... Hmmmmm. Our driver was parked up just a few feet away and he wouldn't have been offered anything by the hotel and no doubt there was loads left over...... Strange old world
column2: which we didn't feel comfortable about at all.

column1: Service at breakfast was non existent
column2: after 3 requests and half an hour plus wait
column3: we got some coffee
column4: we gave up on the eggs! David drove us down to the railway station where we were going to catch the toy train to Ooty. It is a regular passenger service but travels through beautiful countryside so is popular with tourists. There were lots of signs on the station which made us laugh
column5: the retiring room
column6: 1st class waiting room though the upper class waiting room was locked (what's the difference between upper and 1st class!) on one station there was a dormitory room.

column2: a large Indian family were in the same carriage as us and they made very pleasant company to talk to
column3: their older son age 13 had quite good English

column1: and was keen to practice and their younger son had climbed up into the luggage rack and gone to sleep. David was there to meet us and start the descent
column2: it was a longer but a much prettier route than the previous day and far less cars though we turned one corner to find a car on its roof though everyone seemed to have got out ok. We travelled through a wildlife park where there are suppose to be tigers but no luck this time and though we didn't see any
column3: David said you could often see elephants here
column4: we did see lots of deer.

column2: another busy
column3: vibrant
column4: noisy town
column5: cows and dogs everywhere
column6: we went to Mysore Palace which was pretty spectacular though the Maharajah has just died
column7: and it was a public holiday so overloaded with people
column8: all having to remove shoes so there were piles of them
column9: everywhere
column10: we chose the free shoe storage desk which we thought gave us a better chance of finding them again
column11: however
column12: it might have been free but had the attendant demanding a tip to give us back our shoes!

column1: with a lovely colonial feel. Big news
column2: we were going shopping! Not much of that on this holiday! Sal had spotted a place earlier and had to try and get David back there! David was disappointed that Europeans don't barter
column3: so
column4: he came with us and after we had looked at the obligatory tourist shop went to a local place and he stood back whilst Col bartered and he was dead impressed! High fives! Later Sal had a hawker selling ankle bells which was not on the shopping list but it's all a game
column5: he wanted 1200 rupees we got him down to 100 for 2 and we are sure he still made a profit! Anybody want any ankle bells?!

column1: David was very keen to get us back to the palace for the sound and light show and we weren't disappointed
column2: we really enjoyed it
column3: followed by a great meal at our hotel.

column1: Very strange at breakfast this morning
column2: having struggled to get a seat for dinner last night
column3: there was nobody there
column4: it was 8am which has been busy at every other hotel.

column1: David had suggested a visit to Keshava Temple which way
just north of Mysore on our way to Bangalore
column2: we are so glad he did as it was a stunning 13th century temple
column3: the architecture was beautiful and the detailed carving was stunning
column4: from here we went to Dariya Daulat Bagh
column5: the summer palace of Tipu Sultan.... He was ringing bells from the V & A. This was 18th century and was intricately painted inside with flowers and peacocks plus some murals as well
column6: in its day it would have been an amazing place but much has got damaged and weathered but they have started to restore so would be fabulous to see in a few years time.

column1: The journey to Bangalore was through lots of very fertile countryside
column2: loads of paddy fields
column3: carrots
column4: jasmine
column5: cauliflower
column6: sugar cane
column7: banana and David had now got the hang of us that we wanted to stop and photograph everything that seemed everyday and normal to him and the opposite to us. We went into the paddy fields where they were cutting it and another where they were collecting it
column8: shame on us we didn't even know what rice looked like when it was growing. We had 2 varieties of banana
column9: quite different

column2: we didn't always get the best photos but it is amazing how friendly people are and willing to let you
column3: in fact pleased to let you photograph them working. We saw loads of oxen pulling carts loaded up
column4: must be hard work but the animals have very gentle eyes. There were herds of goats and sheep and we saw lots of donkeys as well
column5: some of them just roaming. We loved it. We never cease to be amazed at the ladies deportment
column6: carrying huge bundle of sticks or big pots of water on their head. Calfs and goats laying across the passenger's lap on motor bikes
column7: too much to see!

column2: unfortunately on the outskirts an accident had not long happened and the person was dead
column3: the drivers all slowed to have a look and then Immediately restarted whacky races
column4: the person had been killed by a bus and the newspaper also said that a bus had crashed the previous day killing all on board.........

column2: this was David's home town
column3: he said there was 100
column4: 000 tuk tuks on the road here and we didn't disbelieve him.

column1: We saw a truck loaded up with motor bikes which were being taken away for illegal parking
column2: can't say we had ever noticed 'parking' everyone seemed to leave their vehicle where they felt like it! This particular truck had a man running after it waving a fistful of rupees!

column1: We went to the parliament building and palace and then a bit of time to walk around the old market area
column2: we love this
column3: get in amongst it! Shopping is a big deal in India and here the smart shops mixed with the more traditional shops
column4: we added a bit more to the Indian economy of course.

column1: Unfortunately the next stop was the airport to start the journey home
column2: as always a lovely chap was at the airport from Indian Panorama to assist us. Nearly every stop we have been met by somebody from Indian Panorama to assist with anything we may need though everything has been so well organised we have never needed help
column3: we can't praise them enough.

column1: We had a flight (with piped music of the Christmas variety all the way!) to Mumbai with an overnight stop in the first hotel we stayed in more

column2: before onwards to London the following day.

column1: What a fabulous trip we have had
column2: Jane and Pete were great travelling companions. Every day has brought a new experience
column3: new sights
column4: sounds and smells. India is an amazing place
column5: sometimes it is a amazingly wonderful and sometimes amazingly sad and awful but never anything less than fascinating.

column1: I will miss being called Shally or ma'am
column2: we will miss the incredibly welcoming people and the lovely weather
column3: the fantastic food and the fact that Delhi Belly didn't pay us a visit is a big plus. I am sorry I didn't get an opportunity to weave Sheila Dikshit into the blog
column4: she is an Indian politician we read about and that name deserves a mention! What a fabulous holiday but we are looking forward to a cup of tea and our own bed.

column2: Displayed: 31

column1: So there I was heartbroken and just shy of my birthday. The question was where do I arrive and depart from here?
Forty-five minutes later I was rooting for the auto driver as he dodged traffic to get to the bus stand and then before I took stock of things I was on the bus en route to Gokarna with S.
It is funny how our weakest moment can set us free to live more bravely and truthfully. I hope Gokarna will take my mind off things but I take my mind along. A rookie mistake.
I don’t remember much of the bus journey except for the amourous exchanges between the couple in the berth across mine.
We get off the bus in Gokarna. We trudge along lost and all we know is we have to head to Gokarna International. One look at it and then at each other’s faces
column2: we are back on the street. An auto driver agrees to take us to Om Beach
column3: named so as the beach seems to spell out Om the way it is written in Sanskrit. Soon we are on the hills zigzagging; these are the Ghats.

column1: Higher and higher and I get my first glimpse of the sea. It is green and brown and green and then there’s shimmering blue gazing up at me. That turn where I first catch sight of it – I forget everything and know I did the right thing coming here to this town named after the cows that are everywhere.
We arrive at the Namaste Café and get a cottage. We sit in the café for a while sea gazing. There are guests sunning themselves or smoking on the porches. But otherwise
column2: it is quiet and deserted. We slather on Nutella on the toast. That was mostly what we ate during our stay.

column1: The town is sweltering. But the shops beckon. There are adorable bandannas
column2: dresses
column3: stoles
column4: harem pants and other hippie-ish clothes that soon help us blend in with the crowd. A young boy sells books in many languages
column5: left behind by tourists and he speaks many languages too – Italian
column6: French
column7: Russian…and they are more than a smattering. Yet another invites us into his shop filled with drums
column8: xylophones and more. He shows us how to hold the African drum pressed between our thighs and

column1: how to slap its goat-skin surface with our palms to build a rhythm. He plays and plays until sweat drips down his hair and he is completely lost in the beats.

column2: we take a break to cool off. The heat is unbearable. A woman
column3: a blonde and older version of Zeenat Aman crooning Dum Maro Dum
column4: sits across the table. A big tikka on her forehead
column5: huge sunglasses
column6: a saffron kurta. She is met by a bald and tattoo-ed man and he asks us where we are from. She is heading to Bangalore
column7: taking a train from there. He says we Indian women are beautiful and the woman swats his arm and laughs. I want to ask them where they are from
column8: where is the train taking them to next
column9: what did Gokarna bring to them…but I don’t.

column1: We stop for a beer at a shack on Kudle beach and the decision is unanimous. We are trading Om Beach for Kudle. We also find the other Gokarna International. We trudge up a hill
column2: the bendy soft grasses brushing our legs and at High Point the views stops us.

we pack our bags and make our move to Kudle. The descent is steep. We exchange hellos with other tourists. It is friendly and non-intrusive. It feels like we are looking at them and with our hellos we are really agreeing ‘isn’t this wonderful? Aren’t we glad to be here?’ These steep climbs turn into mini waterfalls during the monsoons we are told. The shacks are closed down
column3: not the best time to visit Gokarna. But it is November and just the right time to be here and the clouds have long since cleared.

column1: A man is practicing meditation. Barefoot
column2: he is paying attention to every step he takes
column3: feeling his feet press down into the stones and red earth. We don’t exist as he communes with the earth and his soul.

column1: We wake up to the sea. A few boats are bobbing on the waves. There are mostly families with children early in the morning. Children with pails playing in the pools between rocks the sea forgot to take back. The rocks have black crabs crawling on them. A woman in a neon bikini claims the rocks have changed positions
column2: the sea goddess has moved them
column3: she says.

column1: Shells peek out of the sand
column2: some broken and some whole. There are ridges drawn by the sea waves by swirling and pulling at the sand. We trace a circle around a dead starfish
column3: the circle of life. There are sand mounds
column4: castles decked with shells. A bunch of red flowers float by. A pentacle is enclosed in a circle. 369 it says.

column1: Later an older crowd starts coming out. Some spread out the blankets and lay down to tan. Others occasionally run into the water to cool off. A couple exchanges a long kiss
column2: the waves dancing around them. A man with dreadlocks collects shells to put in his hair. At night
column3: it is pitch black and one can’t take a step forward without a long range torch. Only the shacks are alive.

column1: We sit at the shack. More nutella and toast
column2: interrupted by falafel and hummus (lots of Israelis around) and bonafie pie. And Somerset Maugham’s Of Human Bondage while not gazing at the sea.
crowds of people sit out on the beach. Cows wander in. There are men selling beaded necklaces. Frisbees in the air. A woman with tassled sticks does her thing. Some just lie back with a book. Slowly
column3: as if by an unspoken agreement
column4: the sea is clear of swimmers and everyone is out on the beach. The cows disappear. The chatter dies down. The clamor of a dog is brought to a halt as an old bearded man with chillum
column5: roars out ‘Shanka!’ We watch the show. Now
column6: there is only the sound of the sea.

column1: A lone lithe woman with wispy blonde hair looks like a sylph thrown out of water. The evening was so heavy with magic
column2: I would not have been surprised if her legs
column3: as they teased the waves with light kicks
column4: had turned into a shimmery green mermaid’s tail and the wave had whisked her away. She seemed to be doing a tango with the sea
column5: taking a step forward as the wave receded and stepping back as it approached. Her boyfriend walked in
column6: a wooden staff in hand
column7: twirling it deftly.

column1: Watching the long drawn out sunset with no promise of an encore
column2: the sky splashed in neon pink
column3: orange like a dragon’s breath and purple
column4: the sun – a great orange ball – sliding down into the sea
column5: I was restored and I made peace with the world. And then all was dark.

column1: Mysore is a bustling city which main tourist attraction is the Maharaja's Palace. Tom really wanting to see it so I waiting for him to arrive to go inside. Tom was due to arrive on Sunday but missed his flight in London so didn't make it to Mysore until Monday. So I went around the place on my own for a day. I even tried street food and survived.
Chamundi Hill: to get there I took the bus 201 from City bus station. It is about half an hour away
column2: up a hill. The place was crowded with Indian tourist. I did not bother to queue to see inside the temple or to get a free darshan (the lines were too long). So I just stayed around the temple
column3: watching people doing some rituals before going in. It was interesting even if I have no idea what was going on.

column1: Rail museum: I went there because the Lonely Planet wrote 'this one is a real gem' and 'half a day of fun'. Well I don't know if they have ever been there or not but this was a big disappointment. There is not much to see and I went around in
half hour. If I were them I would rather write something along those lines 'if you have some time to kill while waiting for your train in Mysore
column2: you can have a quick look at the rail museum (it's only 10 rupies)'.

column1: Maharaja's Palace: the Palace is illuminated on week-end days from 7 to 8pm. It looks very impressive
column2: and they even have a marching band. The Palace is rather recent. The building was finished in 1912
column3: 15 years after the previous one burned down. Learning form experience they built the new palace in stones and not in wood. When you are a foreigner you pay your entrance fee about ten times higher than Indians (it seems to be the same all over India). However you get an audio guide ‘for free' and this was very much appreciated. It's full of interesting facts and not too long.

column1: Devaraja market: very lively bazaar. Highly recommended. It's full of colours
column2: with the paints
column3: the flowers... We were shown how to make incenses and drawn on our hands. I really enjoyed walking around
column4: overwhelmed by the colours and scents.

column1: Mysore est une ville grouillante dont la principale attraction touristique est le Palace des Maharajas. Tom voulait

le visiter donc j'ai attendu son arrivée avant d'y rentrer. Il était censé arrivér Dimanche mais comme il a raté son avion à Londres il n'est arrivé que Lundi. J'ai donc visité la ville toute seule pendant une journée. J'ai même été assez courageuse pour manger dans la rue et je n'ai même pas été malade. Mon estomac tient bien le coup.

column2: j'ai pris le bus 201. Depuis la station de bus prés du palais on est en haut de la montagne en une petite demi-heure. Une fois là haut
column3: je me suis retrouvée au milieu d'une foule de touristes indiens. La file d'attente pour rentrer dans le temple était très longue et ne semblait pas bouger bien vite. Du coup
column4: je me suis juste baladée autour du temple en regardant les gens faire les rituels avant d'y rentrer. Je n'y comprends rien mais c'est intéressant.

column1: Musée du rail : j'y suis allée parce que la Lonely Planet a écrit ‘une perle' et ‘une demi-journée de fun assuré'. Je ne sais pas si je suis allée au mauvais endroit ou si eux n'y sont jamais allés mais j'en ai fait le tour en une
demi-heure et ce n'était vraiment pas intéressant. Si je devais écrire un commentaire je dirais ‘si vous avez une longue attente en gare de Mysore
column2: vous pouvez aller faire un tour au musée du rail
column3: c'est seulement 10 roupies l'entrée'.

column1: Palais des Maharaja : le palais est illuminé les soirs du week end de 19h à 20h. Ça rend vraiment bien et ils ont même une fanfare qui fait le spectacle. C'est un palais récent
column2: sa construction s'est achevée en 1912. C'est à dire 15 ans après que le précédent ait brulé. Du coup
column3: celui-ci est en pierre et non en bois. En tant qu'étranger
column4: on paye la visite 10 fois plus cher mais on a droit à un audio guide. On a bien fait de le prendre car il est bien fait et rend la visite bien plus intéressante.

column1: Le marché Devaraja : c'est le souk. Les couleurs; les bruits et les odeurs se mélangent dans ce lieux fermé et entassé. On a pu voir comment fabriquer des encens. On s'est baladé au milieu de sacs de fleurs et de tas de poudres colorées. On nous a même fait un dessin sur la main. On s'est régalé.

column2: Displayed: 15

column1: <strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">Coorg Travel-log (21/10/13 to 24/10/13)<strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;""> by Aravind
It’s after more than 12 years that I am at writing a travel-log again. Not that
column2: in 12 years we haven’t travelled
column3: but for one reason or other
column4: it simply didn’t happen. I dedicate this to the dearest family!

column1: When I make a comparison between ‘the then’ and ‘now’
column2: I realise that slowly I have distanced myself from making detailed planning and preparation for the trip. As for everything else
column3: this approach has its positives and negatives. Many of them revealed themselves during the trip. We hope to learn from these experiences and get better for next trip
column4: which of course will be next year. We have forced ourselves to be in the business of travelling each year by becoming member of Club Mahindra for 10 years. So
column5: here we go with our first trip to ‘Coorg’
column6: courtesy Club Mahindra Coorg Valley!

column1: <strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">Day 1 – 21/10/13 – The journey and introduction to Mahindra Resorts

column2: I checked about the distance
column3: time and condition of road to Coorg with some experts. Distance is about 80 to 90 KMs
column4: none was sure about the road condition and time it would take is about 3 hrs. I wasn’t convinced with the ‘time’ as it seemed 30 KM/hr is too slow for any condition of road. Trusting the words of the experts
column5: we started at 11 AM as check-in @ resort would be at 2 PM. I was almost sure that we will complete lunch on the way. My conviction got further strengthened as we could maintain an average speed of 60+ for first half an hour or so (close to Sullya). Then came the most dreaded part of this journey
column6: as there was any road for next 30 KMs (upto Sampaje)
column7: forget about the condition of the road. It took almost 90 mins to cover this 30 KM distance. ‘TATA’ jindabad
column8: our Indigo XL survived! As we entered Coorg and the ghat section
column9: the road was amazingly
column10: in excellent condition. Yet another realisation about different ways in which ‘unity in diversity’ is demonstrated in our great country
column11: India!

column1: Our plans of having lunch before checking-in
column2: had gone for a toss. With butterflies in our stomach
column3: we went through the rituals of check-in. By the time we were on lunch table
column4: it was 3:15 PM
column5: and restaurant was about to close in 15 mins. We rushed through the orders and lunch. At the end
column6: I am not sure if had enough to fill our stomach
column7: but certainly bill was fat. We realised we need to be ‘kanjoos’ when it comes to availing services within the resort
column8: and we indeed did so! The microwave owen and fridge in the room helped us in the process.

column1: Rest of the evening was spent in park (children’s play area)
column2: and fun zone. Anagha did painting and Amogh had a bike ride before ‘evening activity’ of that day.

column1: Each evening the ‘holiday activity’ department organises entertainment programs. This evening was ‘magic show’ and ‘dj’. It was refreshing to see a magic show
column2: and we thoroughly enjoyed it along with Anagha. For some reason
column3: it didn’t seem to invoke any curiosity in Amogh. However the last part
column4: removing Salman Khan’s top
column5: and Aishwarya’s hair (from their photos) had both kids rolling in laughter. Anagha
column6: Amogh and I (though I am ‘pappu’ when it comes to dance) danced to the DJ and Grishma watched us. The experience had us looking forward to the activity in coming evenings.

column1: Being very cautious of the charges
column2: we booked ‘jeep safari’ for next morning and ended our day with dinner in the room. The leftovers were stored in refrigerator. We had fairly good idea about what to do next day i.e. a ‘jeep safari’ in the morning
column3: ‘swimming pool’ in the after-noon
column4: and ‘fun activities’ in the evening.

column1: <strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">‘Jeep safari’ was to start @ 9:30 AM
column2: and we managed to reach on time. We started fairly on time compared to usual stretches that happen with IST (Indian Stretchable Time). Ours was the first jeep among the 2 and we had a couple accompanying us. Naturally we occupied the 2 back seats (parallel to road). This seating was first time for Anagha and Amogh
column3: they seemed to be excited about it. Our jeep was leading the way through the rocky mountain roads (if they can be called roads)
column4: and we suddenly found ourselves on the tip of a mountain. We were to drive them from that tip at an angle more than 45 degrees
column5: and so we did with ‘woos’ and ‘aaas’. The real risks involved in this ride were visible only when we got down from our jeep and saw the second jeep take the same path. There came Grishma ‘If I knew that this is what we were up to
column6: I wouldn’t have taken this ride’. Then we trekked around on the mountains. We went to a place where last scene of supposed to be hit Kannada movie ‘Galipata’ was shot. I haven’t been really watching or following Kannada movies
column7: but even Grishma hasn’t been doing it for long
column8: so we couldn’t really relate. Grishma seemed unusually energised by the surroundings and did all trekking (though with some grumping). It was difficult to believe that she was almost stuck to bed for 50+ hrs 3 days ago.

column2: we got down near a bridge where river Kaveri flowed across and played in the water. We were back at the resort at about 1:30 PM as 1 piece each after the first adventure.

column1: Kids had the urge to immediately get into the swimming pool after lunch
column2: but I had exercised veto and we had a nap. We went to the swimming pool at about 4 PM and there was little drizzle and water was freezing cold. Our urge
column3: determination and ‘paisa vasool’ mentality got better of us. We spent about an hour in the pool. After lot of force
column4: Anagha swam in the 4 FT pool and I tried my ‘once in a year’ kind of swimming attempt. Amogh was in the kid’s pool
column5: and Grishma was enjoying our ‘suffertainment’ (a combination of suffering and entertainment).

column2: the evening activity was limited to ‘indoors’ and there was a ‘visual quiz’. Residents of the resort were split into 2 teams and mostly ‘bollywood’ based quiz was conducted. From each team volunteers were called up to answer questions. Our team won
column3: thanks to our contribution of ‘not attempting to answer the questions’
column4: surely we would have lost as we hardly knew any answer.

column1: We planned the next day after dinner. We had to leave our kids in the room to go to the ‘wi fi’ zone. Our plan was to go to ‘Buddhist monastery’ in Kushal Nagar early morning
column2: then to ‘Dhubare elephant safari’
column3: and some other places nearby. Curtains
column4: day 2!

column2: we had decided to go around <strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">on our own on day 3 & 4. Even though our plan was to start at 7 AM
column3: we started at around 8 AM. Experience had forced us to have breakfast outside the resort
column4: and so we did. Not that the experience was great outside (except for economy). When we inquired about cold idli
column5: wada and sambhar
column6: the prompt reply was that it’s common in hilly areas
column7: by the time the eatables reach the table
column8: it becomes cold (I remembered Rajnikanth).

column1: Finally we bought Duracell batteries for our camera on the way to ‘Buddhist monastery’. Even these batteries run out quite fast and we had to change them often (date gets reset every such time and photos show 1/1/2002). We reached monastery at 9:30 and were there till 11 AM. It’s a peaceful place where one will be absorbed into spirituality. The writings were inspiring especially because I consider myself spiritually inclined. It was more than worth the travel!

We reached our next destination ‘dhubare elephant safari’ @ 11:30 AM. For the first time in our life we had ‘jolly ride’ on the elephant and also a ‘horse ride’. While height was only risk factor in the elephant ride
column2: horse ride had combination of height and speed. My overconfidence took a beating when the horse took off. I was left at the mercy of the horse and so was the horse. I enjoyed this ride though! The kids too enjoyed the rides. The boat ride and little play in the water were icing on the cake. There was white water rafting as well
column3: but we have postponed it for future (possibly somewhere else).

column1: I had ‘Rajiv Gandhi National park (a.k.a. Nagarahole)’ in the mind all the while. As we hadn’t planned anything in particular
column2: we inquired about Nagarahole. We got mixed feedback on safari
column3: some said it’s ON
column4: and for some others it wasn’t. However people referred to nearby ‘Irupu falls’. It was about 60 KMs
column5: and we decided to GO FOR IT
column6: after having a quick lunch.

column1: The drive was scenic and quite long among the hills of Coorg. Roads however weren’t in great condition though better than between Sullya and Sampaje. Impact of the lunch was visible on the kids as they went to sound sleep on the back seat. Grishma had several doubts
column2: ‘is it worth? Will it be safe (naxalite area)? When do we come back? Etc’. I kept on giving some or the other answer which obviously weren’t convincing to her (as always). We passed through Ponnampet and Gonikoppal which evoked some childhood memories of Grishma. We reached an isolated and crowd-starved ‘Irupu falls’ @ 2:30 PM. To know that it’s 0.75 KM walk (trek) to the falls one-way
column3: only increased existing doubts (on its worth) multi-fold. ‘Let’s have look at the falls anyway’ we thought (paisa tho vasool karna padega).

column1: <strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">The scary trek: As we started on
column2: several signboards appeared about ‘wild animals’
column3: ‘poisonous snakes’
column4: ‘tigers’ etc.
column5: but there was no sign of any other human soul. Anagha and Amogh quickly found some security by holding my hands tightly
column6: and brave Grishma was left alone behind. The memories of cheetahs attacking Tirupathi pilgrims only made matters worse. Soon all the mentioned animals (and much more) were running around in our stomach. Somehow
column7: we reached the falls
column8: and it was ‘AWESOME’. I remembered quote ‘there is no short cut to any place worth going’. How true literally it was
column9: and I wished it applied to all our lives on a daily basis. Why are we always in a hurry?

column1: There were few people near the falls and it seemed they were spending their day there. We stuck around for 30 mins or so. The return trek was easier than the forward as we were walking down the known path
column2: experience teaches
column3: and indeed counts! Just when we were near the exit
column4: Anagha <strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">screamed loud!!! She mistook ‘<strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">Aumbbhhaaaa’ of a cow for roar of a tiger J

column2: we started to ‘Nagarahole’ from there which was only about 8 KMs or so. As anticipated there was no safari
column3: but we decided to pass through the forest to Hoonsoor and back to Madikeri. We could spot lot of deers
column4: few peacocks
column5: and a lot of signboards warning us about wild animals. When Anagha asked about ‘what’s a safari?’
column6: Our answer was that ‘it is opposite of the zoo’. The logic being ‘In zoo
column7: animals are inside a cage and we enjoy looking at them
column8: and in safari
column9: we are inside cage (car etc.) and they enjoy looking at us’!

column2: but ok for an evening long drive through a thick forest. Now we had to rush back to the resort before the start of evening activity. We reached just at the right time.

column1: <strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">The family games: The participating residents were divided into 2 teams and made to play/involve in different games/activities. One such activity was picking a pair kids sandals
column2: and Anagha made our team win. In another activity
column3: maximum number of upper clothings (vest
column4: shirt
column5: coat etc.) was to be collected. As Grishma removed Amogh’s clothing
column6: he was furious and started to cry. I enjoyed the moment though
column7: and more so
column8: others even more
column9: when we were made to dance to the tunes of gangnam style
column10: lungi dance etc. The last was a ‘couple musical chair’ which we quit mid-way. Our team won handsomely in the end!

column1: Day 3 ended with plans of visiting ‘Talakaveri’
column2: ‘Abbey falls’ and back to Puttur on day 4. I must say we were totally drained out that day
column3: and the big portion of this travel-log dedicated to this day goes to validate that. It was immensely satisfying day!

column1: <strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">Day 4 – 24/10/13 - On the way back
column2: Talakaveri and Abbey Falls

column1: Day 4 started with check-out from the resort
column2: and we started at about 9 AM. We thought of going to abbey falls first
column3: but due to my mistake we ended up on the road to talakaveri. I refused to turn back even after realising the mistake
column4: but this wasn’t to Grishma’s liking. As expected
column5: the drive to talakaveri was silence personified! By the time we reached talakaveri after having breakfast on the way
column6: it was 11 AM. The place was filled with clouds and visibility was near to zero. It was a very hard drive in the curving hills. We took about 30 mins at the temple with a ‘kumkum archana’ pooja. With some shopping on the way back
column7: we went to abbey falls.

column1: Abbey falls didn’t take much of our time as it didn’t have a long trek and we were very hungry. We spent just about 15 to 20 mins
column2: but it was a treat to watch as well.

column1: We started to Puttur after lunch at about 3 PM and called up Amma to convey that we will reach by 6 PM. The return drive though was much faster than the onward journey though. We reached Puttur by 5:15 PM. Memorable 4 days of time was spent on the journey of life
column2: and this had left us hungry for more in the coming years!

column1: This journey starts in Amritapuri and ends in Mysores 27h later. This is my first long distance travel in India and I am on my own.

column2: I had to wave goodbye to Chloé. It is thank to her if I feel fine starting this journey
column3: I had a great introduction to India. I jumped into a taxi. I got a good price because he had just dropped someone here and didn't want to go back empty.

column1: At the bus station the taxi driver told me ''It's that bus''. So I climb in the designated bus and checked with a passenger ''Is this bus going to Ernakulam?''. Wobble of the head and slight movement of the shoulders and a movement of hand that to me seemed like he was pointing at a seat for me to seat. I was not convinced so I asked the critical question ''Ernakulam stop?''. Few seconds. Movement of head and shoulders and the man goes ‘'Ernakulam bypass''. OK so this is not my bus! I get off and go back to the station looking for a station warden. They are easy to spot
column2: they wear beige uniforms. ‘'Bus to Ernakulam?'' ‘'That side'' said the man pointing at a wall. So I go around that wall
column3: few people are waiting. I ask a woman ‘'Bus to Ernakulam?''. The answer was a wobble of the head and a sign of the hand that seemed to say ‘'stay here''. So I stood by her and looked at the buses coming in and out of the station. Signs are all in Malayalam (local language) so there is no chance I could understand a word. And suddenly
column4: a slap on my harm
column5: a quick head wobble and the women run toward a bus. Ok so that is the bus to Ernakulam
column6: let's go. A man must have seen the scene and asked ‘'where to?'' ‘'Ernakulam''. Wobble of the head. That is definitely the right bus. I'm in! There is lots of empty seats and the back of the bus but I squish my bump next to a women in the second row. Few reasons for this behaviour: front seats are for women because some men don't like seating next to women (so mainly if not only accompanied women go at the back) and the bus have no suspension so at the back it's very bumpy. It is about 4h to Ernakulam. I spent 1h with a women half seating on my lap because the bus was crowded. I like looking outside but I hate looking at the road. They drive like the only commandment is ‘you must not leave an empty space'. It's epic!

column1: From Ernakulam I easily made my way to Fort Kochi to pick up my big backpack that I had left at my previous hotel.

The next challenge was to reach Ernakulam Town train station. I took a bus at Fort Kochi that was supposed to drop me very near. We don't have the same definition of very near. I had to take another bus and then walk about 10min. And that part of town is not very nice
column2: it was very dark. I finally made it to the station after asking my way 2 or 3 times. I was early. So I got some snacks for the ride and found the Ladies-only waiting room to seat and wait.

column1: The train was about 30min late so I had plenty of time to find out where my carriage was. It was at the very front and trains are long long long. Inside
column2: it was easy to find my sleeper and
column3: as most people were already asleep
column4: I just made myself comfortable and ready for bed. I had to take my jumper out of my bag because the AC was on. Good night.

column1: I actually slept rather well. We arrived at Yesvantpur (Bangalore) earlier than scheduled (to my surprise). A rickshaw took me to the other train station. I was there at 10am already hungry so I had a Massala dossa. Spicy food for breakfast was not such a good idea. I think my stomach would have preferred something sweet. I had to wait on platform 7 for about 1h and after another 2h30 in the train I was in Mysore. The journey went smoothly except for the girl who kept wanting to feed me out of date crisp and chocolate. I noticed because the taste was a bit off... My hotel and a well-deserved shower were only a short rickshaw ride away from the train station. I have done it! I guess I can go anywhere now.
Mon périple commence à Amritupiri et se termine à Mysore quelques 27h plus tard. C'est mon premier trajet longue distance en Inde et je suis toute seule. Allez je vous raconte !

Tout d'abord il a fallu dire au revoir à Chloé. C'est grâce à elle que je me sens prête pour entreprendre ce grand trajet toute seule. Elle m'a fait une très bonne introduction de l'Inde. J'ai pris un taxi pour aller jusqu'à la station de bus car il venait de déposer des gens là où j'étais du coup il m'a fait un bon prix. En me posant
column2: le chauffeur m'a dit « c'est ce bus ». Du coup
column3: je monte dans le bus qu'il m'a montré et là je procède à la vérification de rigueur avec un passager. « Est-ce que ce train va à Ernakulam ? ». Mouvement de la tête et petit mouvement d'épaule
column4: accompagnés d'un signe de la main qui semble dire ‘assieds-toi là'. Bon je ne suis quand même pas trop sûre alors je re-vérifie « Arrêt Ernakulam ? ». Après quelques secondes l'homme me regarde
column5: secoue la tête et les épaules et lâche « Contourne ». Bon donc ce n'est pas mon bus ! Je descends et me rend dans la gare routière à la recherche d'un employé. Ils sont en général assez facile à repérer tout habillé en beige. J'en repère un et lui demande « bus pour Ernakulam? ». Mouvement de tête
column6: il pointe un mur et dit « De ce côté ». Donc je contourne le mur dans la direction indiqué et me retrouve avec un petit groupe de personnes. Je demande à deux femmes « bus pour Ernakulam? ». Pour toute réponse j'ai eu droit à un mouvement de tête et un signe de la main qui cette fois veut dire d'attendre ici. Cette fois j'en suis presque sûre donc je ne bouge pas et j'attends. Je regarde le va et vient incessant des bus avec leur affichage en Malayalam (zéro chance que je comprenne quoi que ce soit). J'étais là
column7: perdue dans mes pensées quand tout d'un coup…une tape sur le bras
column8: un mouvement de tête et les femmes s'élancent vers un bus. Bon ça doit être aussi le mien. Un homme qui se dirige aussi vers ce bus me demande « Vers où vous allez ? » « Ernakulam ». Mouvement de tête. Ok c'est le bon bus. J'embarque. Je me trouve une place à l'avant en me serrant contre une dame et ce malgré le fait qu'il y ait plein de places vides à l'arrière. En fait les banquettes avant sont plus ou moins réservées aux femmes alors mieux vaut se mettre là. Et puis il n'y a pas vraiment de suspensions dans les bus ouvert donc à l'arrière ça secoue méchant. Le bus se remplit et je me retrouve avec une femme à moitié assise sur mes genoux pendant près d'1h. Pour les 3h restantes j'ai de la place. J'aime bien regarder le paysage défiler. Par contre j'aime moins regarder devant. Ils conduisent comme si le seul commandement était « sur la route
column9: tu ne dois pas laisser d'espace vide ». Du coup c'est épique !

column1: Une fois à Ernakulam je n'ai pas du tout galéré pour aller récupérer mon gros sac que j'avais laissé à l'hôtel d'avant.

column2: rejoindre la station de train Ernakulam town fut plus compliqué. J'ai pris un premier bus qui devait soit disant me déposer tout près. Bon on ne doit pas avoir la même notion de tout près… Il a en fait fallu que je prenne un autre bus
column3: et donc que je demande mon chemin et que je décrypte maints hochements de tête ! Après ce deuxième bus
column4: j'ai dû marcher environ 10min. J'étais bien contente d'arriver à la station car le coin était plutôt sombre et pas super rassurant. Une fois que j'ai eu demandé quel était mon wagon et ma couchette
column5: je me suis acheté des bricoles pour manger dans le train et j'ai patienté dans la salle réservée aux femmes.

column1: Le train avait 30min de retard. Une fois à l'intérieur il y avait déjà des gens qui dormaient donc je me suis installée pour passer la nuit. Evidemment la clim est à fond donc j'ai sorti mon sac à viande et mon sweat. Bonne nuit.

J'ai plutôt bien dormi même si je me suis faite réveiller à 7h du mat' par les autres passagers qui voulaient s'asseoir (j'ai la banquette du bas). On est arrivé à Yesvantpur (Bangalore) en avance. De là j'ai pris un rickshaw jusqu'à l'autre station de train. J'ai mangé une Dossa Masala pour le petit dej' mais je crois que mon estomac aurait préféré quelque chose de moins épicé. J'ai dû attendre 1h sur la plateforme 7 que mon train arrive et 2h30 plus tard j'étais enfin à Mysore. Il m'a fallu prendre un dernier rickshaw enfin d'arriver à mon hôtel. Après une bonne douche (à l'eau froide)
column2: j'étais requinquée. En tous cas je me suis plutôt bien débrouillée
column3: je pense que maintenant je dois pouvoir me rendre à peu près partout !

column1: My first mission in Mysore was to buy a saree. I asked at my hotel where to get one and for what kind of price. A guy told me I would find the best deals at the Government Silk factory. It is also what the Lonely Planet says. So I went there. I gave them my budget and the women didn't try to convince me to get a more expensive one. And what I really liked was that the prices were written on each piece of fabric
column2: which mean they don't make up a price for foreigners.

column1: You get a seat and then the show begins. The women unfolded many sarees on the table in from of me. Everything that had a little bit of pink or purple was eliminated. From the start I liked one that was burgundy and gold with peacock motifs. The good thing is that you can wear them over your shoulder to see if the colour will suit you. I tried few different colours and patterns until the choice was down to two. The above mentioned one and a turquoise blue one with a leaf pattern. After a wee while I settled for the burgundy
how to put a saree on
and gold with peacocks. As they say
column2: first choice is always the best!

column1: Once you have the piece of fabric
column2: they call the tailor
column3: he takes your measurement to make the blouse and the skirt that goes underneath. I also asked them to show me how to put it on. It is not too difficult but it will require some practicing. They also gave me a 'manual' to use as a reminder.

column1: I think I got all that for a rather good price
column2: 2 420 rupees which is about £25. Not bad for a 6m long piece of silk and tailored top.

column1: The tailor brought everything to my hotel and I tried it on. He just said 'You look very different'. No kidding! Look forward to the pictures guys!

Ma mission principale à Mysore est d'acheter un saree. Donc une fois installée à l'hôtel je me renseigne pour savoir où je peux trouver un saree au meilleur prix. L'homme me dit d'aller à la boutique de la fabrique de soie du gouvernement. C'est aussi ce que recommande le Lonely Planet donc j'y vais. En arrivant je leur donne mon budget et la dame ne se met pas en tête de me faire dépenser plus. Et ce que j'ai trouvé vraiment bien c'est que les prix sont écrits sur chaque pièce de soie. Donc ils ne peuvent pas faire un prix différent en fonction du client.

Tu t'assieds et là le show commence. La vendeuse sort une pile de saree et commence à les ouvrir. Tous ceux qui (de près ou de loin) avaient du rose ont été éliminés rapidement. J'ai tout de suite bien aimé un bordeaux et or avec des motifs de paons. Ce qui est bien c'est que tu peux les mettre sur tes épaules pour voir comment ça fait. J'en ai essayé pas mal avant de réduire mon choix à deux. Celui mentionné plus haut et un bleu turquoise et or avec un motif de feuille. Après un long moment d'hésitation j'ai opté pour l'option bordeaux
column2: or et paons. La première idée est toujours la meilleure !

column1: Une fois la pièce de soie choisie
column2: le tailleur vient prendre tes mesures pour faire le haut et la jupe de dessous. J'ai aussi demandé que l'on me montre comment le mettre. Ce n'est pas trop compliqué mais ça va demander un peu d'entraînement. Ils m'ont même donné une feuille avec les explications. Je pense que je me suis bien débrouillée et que je n'ai pas payé trop cher. C'était juste 2 420 roupies ce qui fait un peu moins de 30€. Ce n'est pas si mal pour une pièce de 6m de soie et un haut sur mesure.

column1: Le tailleur m'a tout amené à mon hôtel le soir même. Du coup j'ai essayé l'ensemble et il a dit « Ça vous change » Non
column2: sans blague ! Vous verrez les photos.

column1: Road Conditions: Very Good/some patch of village road (Mostly Toll Roads)
Days needed to see : average 3 full days.

column2: is one of the most important tourist destination on the Indian as well as international map. Located in the state of Karnataka
column3: the town is popular for its intricately carved temples and stone sculptures. Some of the most popular temple structures here include Shri Virupaksha Temple
column4: Balakrishna Temple
column5: Shri Vijaya Vitthala Temple and Sasivekalu Ganesh Temple. Few must see are : the Stone Chariot at Vitthala Temple and Ugra Narsimha statue at Lakshmi Narasimha Temple.

column1: For history lovers and for pilgrimage alike
column2: this place offers a lot. Much more about this place can easily be found from various blogs available over internet.

column1: My trip summary and recommendations for Hampi:
In general Hampi can be divided into two sets of places depending on the taste of the traveller.
Pilgrims : Hampi relates it to the ancient theology of Ramayana. It is considered to be the land of Monkey (Vanara) King Bali and his brother Sugriva
column2: who ruled the kingdom called Kishkinda. This kingdom is identified to be the regions around the Tungabhadra river. The best way to have a peek of this region is to visit “Anjaneya Parvat”
column3: said to be birthplace of Lord Hanuman. This peak offers very nice panoramic view of the Tungabhadra region. Places which can be spotted from there are: Matanga hills
column4: Vitthala temple
column5: Rishimukha Parvat etc. For pilgrims the places that can be covered are: Anjana Mata Temple
column6: Lakshmi Temple
column7: Durga Temple
column8: Anjaneya Temple and Ranganatha Temple. If you are staying in Hampi
column9: the best way to cover all of these is to cross the river from the Hampi Bazaar’s side. There is a frequent boat/coracle service which charges 10/50 rupees per trip respectively. Then you can take moped or negotiate for an auto rickshaw to show you all of these places. If you have stamina left then you can choose to cross river from the Anegundi village’s side and cover few more spots on the way back to Hampi at your stay.

column1: 2. For History and Architecture lovers: Hampi and nearby places offer most of what Hampi is known for. You can start your day after taking a bath in the nearby ghat and then head towards “Virupaksha Temple”. Then you can plan you morning covering Hemakuta Hills
column2: Kadalekalu Ganesha Temple
column3: Sri Krishna Temple
column4: Badavilinga Temple
column5: Narasimha Temple
column6: Veerabhadra Temple
column7: Sister Stones
column8: and the Main Royal enclosure of Hampi which has plenty of places exhibiting amazing sculpture work on stones
column9: done mostly during the Vijayanagar kingdom. My recommendation would be “Hazara Rama Temple” to witness mostly preserved art work depicting the stories of Lord Rama from Ramayana. You can head back to Hampi bazaar for lunch and have some rest as it gets too hot during afternoon.

column1: Evening: get ready for a walk of around 3+ hours taking you to divine history. Start towards Hampi main bazaar street and feel the glory of most blossomed Vijayanagar empire having a street market which is known to be selling precious gems and other commodities. Take left to the royal walk way towards river. You will get to see a soothing Tungbhadra. You can get a coracle ride across the river to see

column2: one of them is the “Sahasra lingaam”. On the way ahead you can see few other temples and finally the most hyped “Vitthala Temple”. This temple is indeed of much interest and worth taking a guide who charges 150 rupees. This temple houses the most spectacular structure called “The Stone Chariot”. If you have enough time you can covers the nearby places which do passes amazing beauty of tranquillity else you can head straight towards main road. You can take a ride on the electrically operated vehicle which drops you at the gate side and charges 10 rupees each passenger. Take an auto back to you stay.

column1: Next day you can plan for Matanga hills. People generally to go up to see sunset rather than sun rise for a better view. Depending on your plan you can over few more places of your interest at the foot hill of Matanga hills like; Veerabhadra Temple and Achutaraya Temple. Sun generally goes down at 6:30 PM and it gets dark very fast then after
column2: so avoid staying at the peak for too late.

column1: My travel itinerary says minimum 3 days for Hampi but you can make

it in 2 days if willing to skip few places and have lots of stamina to walk and climb. You can opt to stay in main Hampi Bazaar or stay across the river where you can find better options for food as well as for lodging.
If you get little more adventurous then probably you can follow my trip itinerary which covers few other place
column2: obviously it will cost you few more days J : https://maps.google.com/maps/ms?msid=215053520020715622475.0004e2565d6c1b32465b3&msa=0

column1: A trip to the south Indian temple town of Kumbakonam is indeed a very informative and exhilarating experience.The trip invariably leads one to the various temples of the Chola dynasty replete with religious fervour and architectural finesse.I commenced my journey from Bangalore and travelled by an overnight train.It covered the journey of about 600 Kms in 11 hrs.This small temple town draws crowds who come mainly to pay obeisance to the presiding deities of the navagraha temples.Some of these temples are indeed marvels of architecture built by the Cholas.It definitely helps if one has a personal transport since the temples are situated in different directions and to make it to all these places in a brief span of time can be strenuous and tiresome.There are a number of hotels for the budget conscious traveller.

One could also include Thanjavur in the itinerary which is known as the granary of South India due to its extensive paddy growing fields which are a feast for the eyes'As regards accomodation at Kumbakonam one can pick and choose an accomodation suited to one's budget.Typical Indian or specifically South Indian cuisine is available in most of the hotels.It is better to have one's own transport

column1: I was hoping for a monsoon ride in 2013 but it did not happen due to some reasons
column2: so thought of recompensing it with a drive. It was almost end of monsoon and one of my friend and my colleague (then) Kunche Swamy was okay with the plan as he was not very fond of long rides. None of us had a car
column3: so hired one
column4: and it came on time to pick me up around 10.30 pm. We had one more person with us to fill the seat
column5: Venkat – Swamy’s friend.

column2: we reached Tumkur highway by 12.30
column3: and then stretched to Chcikmagalur by stopping once or twice for tea. While going
column4: Swamy could not hold the very desire to drive a car on a highway
column5: but the driver refused it with a smile.

column1: Chickmagaluru : We reached Chikmagalur town early in the morning
column2: its around 260km from Bangalore. I do not remember whether we took rest in a hotel room or straightaway left to Mullayangiri Peak. I remember reading some broachers available there regarding Chikmagalur and places nearby. Chickmagalur literally means ""The town of the younger daughter"" in the native Kannada language. The town

column1: is said to have been given as a dowry to the younger daughter of Rukmangada
column2: the great chief of Sakrepatna and hence the name . This is the story I hv read somewhere online. Chikmagalur was one of the place where coffee was cultivated early in ‘India’ soil. Rivers like Tunga - Bhadra have their sources in the mountains here which are parts of the Western Ghats. Chickmagalur district also contains Mullayanagiri
column3: the highest peak in Karnataka.

column1: The city is placed within a scenic landscape in a fertile valley; it is surrounded by lush green coffee plantation hills. The distance from Bangalore makes this place a perfect weekend getaway
column2: and if that happens to be in monsoon through the Western Ghats
column3: man you wouldn’t have to think twice.

column1: Mullayanagiri : This is the highest peak in Karnataka
column2: located within the range of the Western Ghats of Chikmagalur Taluk
column3: and one of the best trekking place in south India as well.

column2: when the scene became bit bright
column3: we got down from the cab for an early morning photo-shoot near some estate gate. We reached peak after a tough drive
column4: it was foggy and rainy too

column2: we got down from the cab as we could not see anything in the front. We used mobile phone indicator application to give driver some clues. Unless you are an expert in driving seat
column3: stay away driving till the peak. The road to Mullayanagiri is very narrow with views from steep cliffs. Driving to the peak is almost impossible and includes a trek up the hill from the half-way point. From the topmost point on the hill
column4: the Arabian Sea might be visible on clear days. However
column5: ours was not a day of such weather.

column2: the better the sight
column3: else it may start raining
column4: but we couldn’t make it early. With the light rain we climbed the stairs to the top. The rainy winds were so powerful; we were feeling we might be thrown down the hill at any point of time. Nevertheless
column5: it was a life time experience to cherish. I feel chilled while writing about it. We lost our way while coming back
column6: the driver had looked for a short cut to Kemmanagundi.

column1: Kemmangundi : I do not remember whether we ate something until we reached Kemmanngundi.
Fairy-tale Land : Mesmerizing Place on the way to Kemmanagundi
Oh yes we has some snacks and tea at Mullayangiri . The one thing I can’t comprehend (in Karnataka) was the smallest glasses (plastic) used for serving tea at many places. I wish I had carried a cup.
The route through Kemmanagundi Hills were terrible
column2: so much of
column3: super muddy potholes
column4: (scene might have changed now.) we were anticipating soon we have to come out of the cab and push it from behind
column5: or we would be getting a flat tire
column6: but nothing happened. We often stopped and captured the fairy tale scenic views on the way. Then reached top of a hill called Rajendra Hill
column7: which we heard is extremely rich in iron ore. Rajendra Hill is one of the highest peaks in Karnataka encompassed by coffee plantations. We then got into same Krishnarajendra Hill Station Park.

column1: We spent some time and had some late lunch there in a motel. We then moved to Habbi/Hebbe falls to give the day a dashing end. It was raining at times. On the way we saw mesmerizing hills in different moods and shapes and was about to set the sun off.
Habbi/Hebbe Falls : Hebbe Falls are located few
km away from Kemmangundi hill station . By the time we reached there
column2: it was late in the evening. These sprightly falls are inside a coffee estate and can be reached either by walk or four-wheeler
column3: Surrounded by dense forests and coffee plantations. Don’t miss a refreshing dip in this herb-infused water. If you want to come here
column4: Let the monsoon come first
column5: then a trip through the Western Ghats .

column2: we had to take a small diversion to get on the “road” to Hebbe Falls. When it’s pouring in monsoon
column3: it becomes a slushy mess that can be navigated only by cars with good ground clearance. As we neared the place beyond which cars can’t go
column4: we got down from the car
column5: as soon as we started walking
column6: leeches attacked us from all directions. Man
column7: the only way to escape was to go back or run faster and faster. I was not wearing a shoe then
column8: but a sandal with a strap
column9: so leaches could easily stick and suck my blood. The surroundings were dripping wet
column10: fresh and aromatic due to rain.

column1: After a short 20 minute run and crossing three streams
column2: we heard the thunder

column1: of the waterfall. As with the thunder
column2: my heartbeat also increased. What we saw next was a sight to behold!

column1: Tremendous amounts of water were cascading down two levels of the waterfall. We could not capture the other level due to misty weather in the late evening. The water spray was too much to handle. We couldn’t even keep our eyes open. There was no much people around except the few of us
column2: and I think Venkat has not come till the end. We could not spent a long time near the waterfall and getting wet and dark. We could not take much pics due to slight rain and fog in the air. We should ‘ve reached bit early.

column1: The fun was to get rid off leaches while we were back to cab
column2: none of us had any spare dress
column3: except a towel and a boxer kept for shower in the falls
column4: we removed everything and each one helped other for finding leaches from the body
column5: and Swamy sat in the cab only in towel
column6: me in boxer
column7: somehow dried our t-shirts and banyans to make a run to the hotel room when we reached in Chikmagalur town.

column1: Swamy teaching the lady how to use smartphone
kudremukh : The next day early morning
column2: after shower we checked-out from the hotel and had breakfast outside. The plan was to go to kudremukh for a trek. 95 kms southwest of Chikmagalur is the secluded hill station of Kudremukh. Situated 1894 m above sea level
column3: the Kudremukh hills overlook the Arabian Sea and are chained to one another with deep valleys and steep cliffs. There is rich flora and fauna here
column4: waiting to be discovered. There was a lot to be explored. A lovely places to camp. No trekker would be able to resist Kudremukh

column1: We were going through the tea estates and we stopped for some clicks perhaps a freshly made tea from the same tea estate. A young lady from the small shop made tea for us from her house just behind the shop
column2: it had a unique taste. We were chatting with her while having tea. Her subservience and some sort of rural innocence were very aesthetic and feminine. Swamy had tough time in explaining some old ladies who work in the tea estate on how to operate a smart-phone
column3: but even after his lecture they were unable to take his pics. He posed

column1: again when I took my cam in hand. Another fun happened when we left the place and all of a sudden remembered I had forgot my pullover in the shop. When we reached the shop again
column2: the pullover was not there. We looked everywhere. Again we got into the cab and later realized I was wearing the same pullover. I wondered how come even others were not find it on me!

column1: Finally we were at the starting place of Kudremukh trek
column2: but we were so disappointed to hear from the localities that the trek tem with the guide had left an hour before we reached. It wouldn’t be prudent to go without a guide for first timers. So we finally thought to have an early lunch from a small hotel and the meals were delicious. The lady who supplied the food felt so happy by seeing the way I was having it. The disappointment of the trek miss throgh amazing kudremukh hills faded a bit after the food.

column1: So we thought we will have a drive through the hills in other direction and perhaps do some chilling in another falls nearby Kudremukh hills. So finally we reached
though we lost our way in between. Someone had shifted the sign board to a wrong direction

HanumanaGundi Falls : This Falls is situated in Kudremukh National Park between Kudremukh Road and Lakya Dam. The site featuring this beautiful waterfall is a popular climbing spot. The 100 ft waterfall can be accessed from 400 steps that are climbed down from the main road to reach the site. Hanumana Gundi Falls is managed and maintained by forest department of the state government. Along with the fall
column2: tourists can also visit Bhagavathi Nature Camp. I had this dejavu feeling when I reached here and while stepping down close to falls. Yes few years back when I visited mangalore with my colleagues to attend a friend’s marriage at Uduppi
column3: we had visited here while coming back. Since we alredy had too much experience in water and rain and fog previous day
column4: we laft the falls after an hour or so. We had evening tea. Then while coming back visited one more place called Lakya Dam.

column1: The Lakya dam was not like a dam as we expected. As per the information shared
column2: it is a check dam built across the river

a tributary of the Bhadra river. The dam was constructed by Kudremukh Iron Ore Company. This dam was built with the objective to collect silt and other waste materials from the mining industries situated beyond Kudremukh. The dam also acts as a source for the irrigation of agricultural lands in Kudremukh.

column1: The dam gives an awesome views for photo enthusiasts and peace of mind for nomads . We spent some quality time there and when the sun was almost ready to set completely
column2: they were ready to close the gates.

column1: We then did not made any further plan other than coming back!

column1: Here are some photos taken during a trip to Bangalore. Just fascinated by all the British names you see in this Hitech city.
