column1: Stepping off yet another overnight sleeper train with the standard array of snorers
column2: starers and people that think it’s acceptable to hock the nastiest sounding loogies from way up in their sinuses and flob them out the window
column3: we arrived in Hospet.

column2: we would need to take a 30 minute or so Tuk tuk to Hampi for which we were already dreading the obligatory haggling with the local drivers. ‘Fortunately’ for us
column3: there was a guy on our train who had a tuk tuk parked outside (how this was possible
column4: I don’t know) who followed us down the platform asking if we needed a ride into town. Having had this kind of hassle many times before
column5: we decided to sit on the platform with a cup of unbelievably sweet tea and wait him out. Not realising this was probably the only driver we had come across in Asia with a tiny bit of patience
column6: he played us at our own game
column7: dug in his heels and called our bluff. After about 20 minutes of this
column8: he appeared to finally cave
column9: and came over quoting us a good price…we were

column1: shocked. Looks like this actually worked? We would be testing this theory again for sure.

column2: half an hour passed and we were whizzing around the skinny dirt streets of Hampi Bazaar dodging everything from people
column3: bikes
column4: other Tuk tuks
column5: cows and of course cowpat before arriving safely outside our hotel of choice
column6: Rocky’s.

column2: we knew this was more our scene. Chilled and relaxed
column3: plenty of fellow travellers around (it had been sometime since we had seen other ‘travellers’) and more Ali Baba pants than you can shake a monkey stick at…. Finally a place we felt we could get on board with.

column1: After registering our arrival with the police (everyone has to do this
column2: we are not known criminals or anything) we took a walk around Hampi.

column1: This place has been described as beautiful
column2: magical
column3: and even otherworldly
column4: and on first glimpses of the terrain and landscape here
column5: we could easily see why. Hampi hosts some of the most incredible ruins either of us have ever seen
column6: all of which are surrounded and sometimes embedded in a mass of giant boulders and rocks that stretch as far as the eye can see.

column1: It really is one of them places that needs to be seen to be believed
column2: and also one that is on a huge scale.

column1: The first set of ruins we went to visit seemed to go on for miles
column2: with amazing architecture everywhere you looked. Not wanting to see too much of the area to quickly
column3: we stopped after a good few hours to ‘save’ some temples for another day. After coming back to the bazaar however
column4: we were shocked to find that we had only covered a tiny piece of what this place had to offer
column5: and if you wanted to
column6: you could probably spend weeks here exploring.

column1: We quickly decided that this was a place we would like to hang out in for a few more days
column2: and spent plenty of that time flitting between temples and walks among the landscape
column3: with relaxing and reading on the floor cushions of the local restaurants and cafes.

column1: The closest temple to the bazaar has a resident elephant
column2: Lakshmi who will ‘bless’ you for 1 rupee. This consists of putting a coin in Lakshmi’s trunk who then passes the coin to the handler. She then blesses you by

column1: raising her trunk and patting you on the head with it…. Quite amazing I must admit. Not usually one for gimmicks like this
column2: I couldn’t resist a blessing from an elephant guru and decided to part with my rupee. I was shocked when Lakshmi refused the coin and my blessing was snubbed. Knowing that I was a tourist
column3: she wanted 10 rupees from me! Obviously this was either from an invisible signal from the handler
column4: or this elephant really was a guru or something
column5: but either way
column6: I was strangely impressed and so parted with 10 rupees (about 10p). Again realising I was a tourist
column7: Lakshmi’s trunk was resting on my head for longer than the locals so we could get the photo….amazing stuff!

column2: we were able to see Lakshmi get her daily wash down by the river
column3: and having watched this and seeing her thoroughly enjoying it
column4: we were reassured that she was being treated well which pleased us both.

column1: Hampi really was exactly what we were looking for after such a rollercoaster ride in India so far
column2: and sitting here writing this on our roof terrace as the day draws to a
we will both be sad to leave this little slice of heaven. However
column3: it’s time to motivate
column4: and we are now off to Goa. Being the rainiest month to visit Goa (July)
column5: we are certainly not expecting much in the way of sun
column6: however we hope to enjoy the little capital of Panaji for a few days.

column2: we were just going to play this by ear.

column3: we should have realised there and then

column1: After finally escaping from the church

column1: Our next day was probably the best one we had in Mysore

column2: and growing in confidence with walking around the streets

column4: invites to tours and what not

column1: on earth were we thinking? Just when we thought we were getting better at batting off people and staying incognito
column2: we decided to do this……

column1: Upon reaching the outskirts of the market
column2: we were mooching around and taking in the sights and the smells of this bustling area
column3: and then we made our way into the market itself. Being the only tourists around
column4: we were of course immediately jumped on by every market seller in the place.

column1: It was uncomfortable to say the least for me

column6: fuming at the guy who had ruined our visit
column7: and really quite horrified at some of the people walking around here. I understand some people may take this with a pinch

column1: of salt and say it’s to be expected

column4: anywhere.

column1: For the rest of the day
column2: we stewed on this incident

column4: the constant badgering
column5: the trash everywhere and now this. It just all seemed to hit us at that moment
column6: and we both just felt like throwing the towel in there and then…it was just one of those moments I guess.

column1: Deciding perhaps booking some Yoga would brighten our time here

column2: after time to cool off

column1: had begun jumping on the trains and taking photos it happened…….

moving on from that picture I have no doubt sadly ingrained in your head now

column1: The LONGEST day of my life
Who knew it was possible to experience one day for more than twenty-four hours???

column2: but it can be done and I have lived it! I lived 30 hours of July 20
column3: 2013. It started out in Bangalore
column4: India and ended in Chicago
column5: Illinois
column6: USA.

column1: Leaving was bittersweet. I enjoyed my time in India
column2: but I missed the United States and the people I love back there. It was a nice experience to undergo and I am very glad I participated. I am very glad I went to the Taj Mahal and was able to successfully tour Delhi by myself and not get sold into the slave trade (I was so nervous for that…).
so hospitable.
doesn't mean the adventure did. When we left for the airport
column3: it was almost midnight. The bus couldn't make it into the parking lot so we had to walk out to the busy street and load. This was also where we said goodbye to our WorldStrides chaperone – Cheten. We all got comfortable in our seats and I remember thinking to myself how dry my eyes were and so thankful I had taken out my contacts. I remember listening to others reflect about the experience. I thought I would just shut my eyes for a few moments (to lubricate them)
column4: but ended up falling asleep. I guess everyone pretty much crashed on the ride to the airport. Suddenly we were all awaken when the bus almost got hit by a water tanker on the expressway. By this time we were very near the airport
column5: so I stayed awake the rest of the way. The other thing I remember thinking on the bus was how bright the lights were from the oncoming traffic in the other lane.

column1: When we got to the airport
column2: our luggage was unloaded and we said goodbye to our driver
column3: Edward – phenomenal doesn't even begin to describe his driving skills
column4: especially in the chaos we were exposed to!!! We also said goodbye to our navigator.

column1: Before we could enter the airport
column2: we had to show some sort of proof that we had a flight
column3: so I showed them my printed receipt/ticket confirmation. I was one of the first who was waved through. And the security put me into a different line than my counterparts
column4: who were waved to other lines. I got through before them and looked around and figured I would wait for them near the airline. But
column5: someone from the airline saw me and must’ve figured I was loitering
column6: so they brought me to the check in area for my airline. I got in the line for economy
column7: but
column8: then was asked to move to first class for my check in…I told the lady I was with a group
column9: but she said
column10: they’d be on their way and that I should check my bag. So
column11: I did what she asked. I figured after I checked my bags
column12: I would wait before going on to security and again
column13: I ushered to the escalator for security. Enough was enough and I figured I would just have to catch up with the group at the gate. So
column14: I went through customs and security quite smoothly. No waits or anything
column15: just flew through them. When I go to the gate area
column16: I looked around and there were still a bunch of people there waiting for the flight that was before ours
column17: so I went back to the duty free area to wait for the gang. They were worried I got lost
column18: so I sent the Program Manager a text that I was through and fine. It took some time

column1: My last few purchases were the India Barbie and a tuk-tuk – best part – they let me pay in $USD$!!! Did some reading and reorganizing. By the time it was time to board (around 2:30 am)

column1: Landing in Germany was a great feeling – while it was not home

column1: Our last day of the residency of getting packed prior to our departure for the morning. Our last two visits consisted of GE and Micro-labs But before we could get to either

column1: The part of GE we visited was GE Aviation as two of the students work there in the USA. At GE they are big on digital solutions for aviation and being able to effectively use data. column2: aviation 700
column3: P&E
column4: transportation
column5: health care

column1: The main competitor is Rolls Royce. And the motto is “bring them home safely”
GE typically doesn't make profits on engines
column2: the profits are made on services. GE India started as a joint venture first few years
column3: which were a test relationship and were a validation stage. It proved to be successful and is now its own entity.

column1: Top down prioritization occurs a lot
column2: but it

column3: if GE will lose people they will go to Honeywell

column5: or other automotive companies.

column1: Flex working schedule certain hrs. need to work and can work any other hrs. as desired

column1: An interesting phenomena we learned about was how India invented the missed call. In India
column2: a person can never be charged for an incoming phone call. This made it very easy for working class people to purchase a phone. Whenever they need to get in touch with their boss
column3: they would call the number
column4: let it ring once and hang up. The boss would see the missed call and call the employee back. The employee was never charged for the call.

column1: Infosys is not a product company – they are a problem solving company for clients. Everything is highly regarding toward the customer relationship. Innovation to address a specific need. Some times with competitors in the environment

column1: The US is the largest spender on IT outsourced and 80% of those employees are based in India. There is often a balancing act of going global and remaining relevant locally. column1: The day of the residency brought more company visits and more experiences. We had breakfast as usual and boarded the bus. Pradeep

column1: The first company we went to visit was Selco-India. Selco is a solar panel distribution and service company that helps to bring light to the rural poor. Lots of people in the rural areas of India are without power. And those with power in the rural areas may not have the electricity from the grip. The goal is to provide energy to the rural poor. Selco offers an abundant of aftermarket services and they often will provide service to competitor’s panels as well
column2: as often the after sales service is something that goes forgotten.
the products they sell have a 25 year warranty on them and they are expensive. Most of the people live on less than 3
column3: 000 Rupees ($50) a month and each product costs about 420 Rupees – often a bigger expense than people can afford in one go. Couple that with the difficult banking structure in India and

column1: it poses a real threat to getting light to the rural poor. A service that Selco offer is financial counseling. They assist people with taking about a loan and filling out the paperwork – essentially Selco helps to establish a poor person’s relationship with a bank and a credit history
column2: which is crucial for future investments and purchases. The way Selco is able to do this is by recruiting retired loan officers to donate their time and knowledge of the industry. In this regard
column3: Selco is not the creditor or backer of the loan
column4: but the networking piece of the puzzle to bring the two factions together. Something important to note
column5: is that the default rate on loans to the poorest of the poor is virtually nonexistent.

column1: After sales support is a big revenue generator for Selco. It also helps to establish trust with the customer
column2: and when the trust builds
column3: the confidence in utilizing solar energy also increases.

column1: The mission of Selco is to remain focused on the rural poor. About 80% of their product line of solar energy is for light and the other 20% is for heating. In the past they have tried to develop

column2: but it never proved to be very reliable
column3: so that is something they try to stay away from. As far as their market make up
column4: 75% of the market is the rural poor or the handicraft makers and the other 25% are some rural institutions (think NGOs). Selco prefers NOT to serve the institutions
column5: but understands
column6: in some regions this is the best way to enter into a rural area that have virtually been left untapped before. When a cash paying customer comes to Selco
column7: they will in turn service them
column8: but that customer is not given priority in the business model’s current state. Another reason to remain focused on the rural poor is to help these people who are completely left out of the economy
column9: enter into the economy with a positive credit history – it goes beyond just providing light for Selco.

column1: When it comes to Marketing and Sales
column2: there is a small budget and the majority of the marketing is done informally. Occasionally
column3: there will be news coverage of what Selco is doing and they try to capitalize on that as best they can.

column2: Post its
column3: Scotch Tape
column4: etc. Investment into R&D is HUGE at 3M. Another thing that is big with 3M is mix and matching technologies to create new uses. Take something learned from Posits
column5: alter it slightly with Scotch Tape and now there is a completely new product and new opportunity to exploit. Something to

column2: is this location only works on R&D for the Indian market only – products seen there might not be seen in the US or elsewhere in the world. One such product was the 3M Car Care shops that help to service the vehicles on the road. The was something very different
column3: but at the same time
column4: I totally think it could work in other markets.

column1: The vision of 3M is in alignment with its foundation and there is a thriving environment of cultural innovation. There are also some things called Customer Technical Centers which have over 60K products that customers can give direct feedback to 3M on. At 3M
column2: the individual initiative is crucial to the success of the employee
column3: and the company. Personal ability to be independent and the ability to thrive in ambiguity are two characteristics 3M looks for in hiring.

column1: Research is the transformation of money into knowledge and innovation is the transformation of knowledge into money. Within 3M there is a mantra of the 3-touch rule. If an employee comes to a problem
column2: they should be able to find a solution after contacting three people in the ENTIRE Company. To

this is an unspoken way of saying communication is key to 3M’s success. An often time in the corporate world people like withhold information and not communicate living by the mantra of knowledge is power and he with the knowledge has the power. My inference from the visit at the 3M-India is that is defiantly NOT the case.

column1: Another part of the core of the 3M is crossfuncitonal teams. The business will prioritize projects based upon resources and money
column2: and it is up to the teams to manage the expectations of the business and the customer. Another part of this is also managing people. People often work on a more than one project at any given time
column3: so prioritizing their work and their projects based upon a balance of customer demand and business priorities. According to 3M this is a fine line to walk and balance
column4: and people can get sensitive if their projects are further developed. Often time’s project will reach a certain point and get killed for one reason or another.

I had to wake up at 4 am to finish packing and take a shower and checkout. This time
column3: since I was just flying to Bangalore to meet the group

It was still dark out and the drive was quite peaceful. There were no other cars on the road. An occasional truck here and there
column5: but nothing else on the road - very different to see. The driver made good time to the airport. Upon arrival

column1: The flight was pretty empty. I was seated in the emergency exit row which was nice

because I was able to stretch out more. A man from a few rows back moved up and sat on the aisle seat – leaving the middle seat open. We talked and I found out that he was an architect. He is the lead architect who works for Bacardi – designed all the Bacardi lounges located in international airports. The breakfast on the flight was one of the best I had on this trip to date. After breakfast
column2: I took a nap and when I woke up I was in Bangalore.

column1: My first impression of Bangalore was that the airport was one of the nicest I have ever been in. The baggage was sent to the claim right away. I walked out the door and found my driver right away. I had two people – a driver and a navigator. The first thing I noticed was my driver had an extra thumb; I did my best not to stare. Both of the guys were fairly young
column2: early 20’s
column3: but they were very helpful and talkative. The car had some jasmine in it and it is absolutely fragrant. Lots of jasmine garlands and what hot. I noticed a lot of

column1: Catholic influences. And it turned out the owner of their company was Catholic.
As we were driving into the city they were telling me all about it. About how Bangalore used to be so lovely with lots of gardens
column2: but urban sprawl has set in. Another thing we discussed were weddings
column3: given mine is just around the corner. The navigator’s sister recently got married and because of their class and caste it was a four day event with around 1200 people. They also talked about the jasmine can be found everywhere. Jasmine is very fragrant flower and Indians will twine it into garland. At the beginning of a marriage
column4: a husband will often bring jasmine for his wife to wear in her hair. Some other things they showed me were where the gardens used to be and some of the good places to shop – not that I would get there
column5: but it was nice of them. Finally
column6: we arrived at the hotel. The traffic was heavy and congested by American standards
column7: but was fairly light compared to New Delhi.

column1: When I arrived at the hotel
column2: I had to go through security
column3: and checked in. The

column1: service was really impressive – they didn’t let me lift a finger. My room was 305 and I was rooming with the other female in the program. In order to get to our room
column2: we had to put our room key in the reader on the lift - which would only let me go to the third floor. My roommate had arrived with the rest of the group around 2 am in in the morning
column3: so she was already in the room. We were all getting ready to meet our driver and guide and to explore the city. We had our lunch at the hotel before we left.

column1: When it was time to go

column5: linguistic knowledge
column6: religious knowledge
column7: etc. Our first stop was the Botanical Gardens
column8: which were originally set up by the British. It was nice having the guide because then all the beggars left us alone. The

column2: and drove to another part of the city. There we walked through a little marketplace with lots of colors from the fruit stands and the flower stands. Everything was very bright and colorful.

Our next stop was at the remains of a palace that stood in the city. We did some more sightseeing from the bus – definitely could see all the massive amounts of humanity 😉 ! After a few hours we were headed back to our hotel. Our dinner was just down the road from our hotel. It was a traditional style Indian restaurant. LOTS of good food and good

column1: wine. It was a nice kick start to our residency. After dinner
column2: we walked back to the hotel and got ready for the week. It was nice to have a shower.

coorg

column1: My first ever trip to Bangalore and to South India was in the year 2006 for an induction programme with the multinational organisation i had joined. I do recall the HAL airport and that it was small and not being able to cope with the pressure of Bangalore having emerged as the Silicon valley of India. We left for the training facility and it was part of a sprawling over 100 acre property where the corporate office used to be. I remember the weather to be cold and raining
column2: this was in November and I had dinner and called it a day. I was sharing my room with another manager and she arrived in the middle of the night and scared me out of my wits. The next day our induction began and I think we may have been there for a few days
column3: 3 nights at the most. One of the evenings with my new found friend and a few others we caught auto rickshaws and left for MG Road
column4: a long winding ride through narrow heavily clogged roads with traffic and construction to reach after almost an hour or so. We dined on burgers from a fast food joint

column1: and met up with my brother's friend there. We caught auto rickshaws back and this time it was a bit better. Later I got to know that we were staying at Brookefield near Whitefield and it was a different part of the town from MG Road. One of the evenings we dined at an Andhra joint nearby
column2: all of us sharing the meal. We explored the lobby of the erstwhile corporate office and besides being grand and resembling a lobby of a palace it had this gigantic Hussain painting strapped to the wall. The last day group photographs were taken and it was time to come back.

column1: The next trip was with our own division and we were driving down to Coorg for a conference cum outbound. I still remember the flight from Mumbai being very scary
column2: our entire team was on it and we met winds of crazy speeds while trying to land at the airport. Unfortunately we were not able to land and the winds pushed us off the runway and we had to come around for another landing. Needless to say everyone on board was scared but the second time round we managed to land. I was at this point of time based out of the guest house in Mumbai and hence was on the flight originating in Mumbai. We arrived in Bangalore and I remember meeting up with the rest of the team at a dinner somewhere from where we left for our guest house in Indiranagar. It was a lovely guest house and I had one of the terrace rooms with a lovely open terrace with it.

column1: The next day early morning we left for Coorg stopping at Kamats for breakfast. There is a quaint store in Kamats from where I picked up wooden bangles and we left for Coorg. On the way we worked on our presentations and after a round of nerve wracking presentations and head bashing sales analysis we decided to get some sightseeing done. We were staying at the Orange County and had a lovely villa all to ourselves with a pool at the back. In the evening we explored the grounds a bit and watched the Kodavu tribal dance. The buffet lunches and dinners were lavish and extensive. The next day we left for the Dubare elephant camp and saw elephants being bathed by the Cauvery river. We also went to Bylakuppe where there is a Tibetan settlement. I bought a mobile accessory for myself and my colleague in the Kolkata office and then it was time to drive back to Bangalore.

I was staying back for one more day before which I would leave for Mumbai with rest of the team. One of my assignments was to connect with a leading fashion person in the city and I did so before leaving for Mumbai. At Coorg I also picked up a leather pouch from the store at Orange County.
The next time we were in Bangalore we had an event to organise and it's a different story that the event went out of hand
column2: tempers flared
column3: last moment damage control had to be exercised and somehow we salvaged the situation and the many egos involved. One of the days I dated someone and we dined at Little Italy at Indiranagar and on another day met the same friend and had dinner at 100 Ft road
column4: a Boutique restaurant. After the event at the poolside of the Park
column5: we met up at this exotic restaurant in Indiranagar for a fashion show and it was heartbreaking for me to see the same celebrity organise a far more eclectic event. From here we left for Chennai for the second leg of the journey where unfortunately tempers flared again and all in all I have such mixed feelings of this event.

column1: My last trip to Bangalore would be sometime in the middle of 2007
column2: this time with another event. We had a tough time organising the event at Garuda Mall and altercations with the management occurred before we could proceed again. Luckily for me this time it wasn't my fault at all. It was my boss'. We had a team lunch at a restaurant at Garuda Mall
column3: I shopped a bit at the Home Stop and at Garuda Mall and we stayed over at my colleague's place at Richmond Road. The next morning i left for Kolkata
column4: I had managed to convince my bosses to let me go back to Kolkata again and develop the market there. Still remember the shot glasses and Dunhill deo I picked up for my brothers. The store at Homestop was amazing
column5: it was massive and had this classy and elegant collection of home items. After moving to Bangalore it was here that I would spend so many happy hours. Every time I entered the Garuda Mall it would remind me of the day the mall management fought with us and disconnected our electric connection. Over the years that memory too has dimmed and paled. I also visited the Nallis shop
column6: then on MG Road with the area manager from South and chose this lovely green South Indian saree for my mum. The company owned salon was on Richmond Road and that would be our base. We would walk down once for lunch at a Chinese restaurant and I would be amazed at the cosmopolitan nature of the city and some lovely salons
column7: very high end. In those days we didn't have the new airport and neither did we have the UB City all of which have added to the style quotient of the city. My boss wanted to shop at Forum Mall and I remember going there once and finding it very crowded. After moving here all these places would be my haunt and how happy I would be being the mall rat that I am.

column1: So I pestered and pestered my hubby for a quick break before my medicals begin again. Yes I am in the middle of some medical complications but enough of that. Hubby has booked a deluxe room at the Taj Madikeri
column2: Coorg and am so excited. Watch this space for more!!

column1: What to have for dinner is a question which always leaves you in trouble. And dealing with such questions is quiet difficult. And in such situations agreeing of everyone is important!!
And weekend it was; my parents
column2: my brother
column3: my sister and I were sitting together and playing cards. We all were having a great time as the game was becoming interesting
column4: when out of nowhere I just recommended that we can go to Chokhi Dhani today. With least interest in what I said everybody said “Okay” because everybody’s attention seeker at that point of time was that card game. But our Chokhi Dhani plan was executed also.

column1: So we all went to Chokhi Dhani. It was quiet far from our house but drive was fun indeed. We finally reached the place – and the food turned out to be awesome. The food of Chokhi Dhani which we always use to talk about which is very famous in Jaipur maintained the same standard and taste in Bangalore also.
Now you must be thinking that how costly could this Chokhi Dhani could be? Not at all costly guys
column2: they have very nominal charges in which you get not only food but get to see really nice dances and activities.

column1: A very early start for me being around 7am to give me time to get showered and to the station in Chennai to head onwards to Bangalore. The trip took around 6 hours and it’s safe to say that the second class seating is not comfortable at all. It certainly isn’t as good as a virgin voyager service back home.

I arrived mid afternoon and got into a taxi and headed out to my guesthouse. Obviously being the way here the taxi driver took me saying he knew where it was when he didn’t. After a phone call to the guesthouse I waited for a couple of minutes with the taxi driver and a bloke on a motorbike turned up to take me to the right place.
After waiting 10 minutes for someone to attend the reception
column2: if you can call it that I got my room. In the evening I headed into town and towards the cricket ground
column3: around 4km from the guesthouse. Luckily Bangalore is nowhere near as hot as Chennai was yesterday so it’s far more manageable. After stopping in a local place

column1: for some food I got to the ground to be told there was no ticket office open and it was sold out. I walked around for 30 minutes or so asking all sorts of people about tickets. When I thought I wasn’t going to get in I was approached by a man with a ticket selling for face value. I felt this was a bit sketchy so I agreed to pay on being let in which I did. The game was great
column2: produced a super over to end it and was well worth the 1200 rupees I paid.

column1: I had a strange experience on the way home. I was maybe ¾ of the way back when a scooter pulled along side of me
column2: this now being 12:30am and stopped. The guy started talking to me asking where I was from
column3: why I was here and where I was staying
column4: I answered the first 2 but definitely not the last one. Then I was asked if I wanted his company for the night. After laughing and telling him to do one I carried on my way back to my guesthouse. I’ve plenty of girls offered to me in various cities

column2: Philippines and Thailand etc but I’ve never had a man offer his services. I think the fact I started laughing showed I was not interested and he left pretty sharpish.
Thursday and Friday followed pretty much the same routine. Every morning I headed into town to the cricket ground. First day the tickets were not on sale
column3: the second day they were but were very pricey so I left it and thought I could buy online instead. The third day I realised I couldn’t buy online and had to purchase from the ticket office
column4: paying 3300
column5: way more than I’d planned or wanted to pay but at the end of the day I am in India for the IPL so I accepted it and paid it.

column1: The afternoons of these days I pretty much wandered the streets
column2: with no plan in mind to hopefully find something to do or things to see. There is not much to do
column3: that would take up time but there are plenty of impressive buildings in the city. The main things online to do are a water park and snow centre which don’t interest me at all. I spent my

column1: evenings eating in the local curry houses and watching the IPL on the tv in my room. Without a tv in my room I may have been a little lost as Bangalore hasn’t a nightlife.

I did get to the stage where I was struggling with the bathroom situation. There was no toilet roll in Bangalore it seemed. As I was running very very short and was out walking one day a great idea crossed my mind. I walked past a pharmacy and saw nappies so figured they’d sell baby wipes. Luckily they did. I did however look a bit of a plank walking through the city centre where I was getting stared at any ways
column2: but this time with a large pink bag of baby wipes. I imagine they all knew exactly what it was for.

column1: Whilst I was in Bangalore on I think the Wednesday there was a terrorist bomb planted which exploded and injured some 16 people. This happened a couple kilometres from my accommodation and you could sort of tell the city was a little bit cautious after that. Luckily they didn’t postpone the cricket on the Saturday night which they were considering.

On Saturday I got all my stuff packed and ready to go then headed into town for food followed by the cricket. I needn’t have bothered with the food as I was in a corporate stand and food was served between innings. I gave it a swerve as I was still stuffed and instead had my 2 free Kingfisher’s instead
column2: the first time I’d seen alcohol in India
column3: 5 days in!! It never takes this long in a country. There were no dodgy encounters on my way home this evening so that made the walk home far more straightforward.

column1: This morning I headed back to Chennai
column2: I wasn’t looking forward to the trip as I didn’t enjoy the 6 hours on the way here
column3: but it turned out not to be to bad. I had the usual fun and games when I arrived in Chennai around 2pm. Flocks of taxi and auto-rickshaw drivers asking me where I wanted to go etc. I got one sorted
column4: showed him the address on my ipod and we proceeded to not be able to find it as

column1: commonly practised here. It turns out my hotel was on a little side street of a 23km long road so lucky to find it.

The rickshaw driver decided to help himself to 50 rupees more than we’d agreed. Ok it’s only like 60 pence sterling but he wouldn’t give me the arranged price as we had to drive around the block 3 times. I tried to tell him that at the station he said he knew where it was. He was having none of it. He even came into the hotel and told the owner that he couldn’t find it. I always manage to pick absolute planks to drive me about. If I had small bills I’d have paid what we agreed but I didn’t so he short changed me. I accepted that I wasn’t getting my correct change and headed in. Dropped all my gear of and walked to the stadium to buy tickets for the 2 games while I am in town this time. 750 rupees which is great compared to Bangalore. In the evening whilst sat in the lobby met a lad called Leo who was also going to the cricket so agreed we’d head there
together and hang our during the day.
On Monday and Tuesday I pretty much hanged out with Leo
column2: a lad from the Isle of Wight who’s been in India since early January
column3: on my first impressions that’s far longer than I would like to stay here. We spent most of the 2 days just chilling in either the huge mall just around the corner or relaxing in our hotel rooms watching tv. On Monday night we went to the game. It turned out to be an absolute cracker and one of the best T20 games of the season. Not bad considering it was Leo’s first ever game of any sport. Leo left late on Tuesday so the rest of my time would be spent back on my own.

column1: On Wednesday I decided to do some major walking around town. It was about 36 degrees and very humid but I managed a good 3 hours walking around town before I felt knackered. I wandered to Fort George which is just an army base and not impressive. Also down to the sea front where there is a lot nicer area. I think it was called Anna Square. It’s obviously one
of the nicer spots in town as its full of people
column2: still no other tourists though. I’ve hardly seen any white folk in my 2 weeks or so here
column3: it’s a bit off putting as locals just stare permanently at me. It seems a lot easier place to be when you have company. It doesn’t seem to bother me as much when the stares are aimed at 2 people as opposed to 1. I thought India would be a bit more used to white people than it seems. I got less stares in China.

column1: Thursday I just enjoyed that I had probably the nicest room I’ve had in a while and lay in bed until early afternoon when I went to the cinema to watch Oblivion
column2: Tom Cruise’s new film. After being pretty much completely baffled by the storyline I headed out to watch my final match in Chennai. Another home win and top class performance topped of a good few days in Chennai
column3: I feel like I am enjoying India a bit more than I was although I’m still not hugely keen on it
column4: there just doesn’t seem a lot to do here which is a shame considering

column1: So....I made it to India in one piece. Erica and I spent the last night in Amsterdam with our two friends and got on the plane at 5 am the next day. We met up with Robyn
column2: another girl in our program
column3: in Paris
column4: where we met at the gate for our flight to Bangalore. Everything went fine until Paris
column5: where we were stuck on the tarmack for three hours because of technical difficulties with the plane. Not an encouraging thing to happen just before a 9 hour flight. However
column6: we landed in Bangalore safely
column7: and spent the night at a family owned hotel near the airport.

column2: this is where the networking began. We talked with the wife of the hotel owner in the morning and she had connections in the city which is an hour from the airport area. She arranged for her friend George who was a friend of a friend who knew somebody who had a membership at the catholic club which was basically like a YMCA with a pool and cheap food. Very safe. Perfect. So
column3: we shacked up there for 4 nights and the next day slept in til 1 pm!!!

column1: Talk about jet lag. We then spent the afternoon finishing our final papers and hanging out near the pool. Hard life I know. Then we bought traditional Indian dresses called salwar kameez and wore them to dinner to celebrate the end of another semester.
The heat here is insanely hot. I just came from - 1 degrees celsius in Amsterdam and it is literally 40 degrees in Bangalore with the humidity. My poor Scottish
column2: Danish ancestry has given me the weakest capacity to deal with heat of this kind.

column1: The next day we hired a taxi driver to take us to Mysore
column2: my old stomping grounds
column3: where I lived at the age of thirteen and my whole journey towards working in Global Health began. We visited the palace
column4: the Chamundi hills
column5: ate masala dosa and butter chicken at my old time favorite restaurant
column6: which has since been renovated
column7: but which still exists!! We then visited a few temples and shrines dedicated to dead sultans
column8: and made our way back to Bangalore
column9: stopping only for coconuts and chikoo (small brown fruit that tastes like a mix between a prune and a pear) along the side of the road. We

column2: dusty
column3: loud traffic for about 2 hours longer than we should have been. After a long day
column4: we passed out almost immediately when we got back.

column1: From Bangalore we headed to Kerala by plane
column2: to a place called Cochi
column3: which is a little fishing village on the outskirts of brackish water canals that loop in and out of floating villages. They call it the Venice of India: I would argue that it is even more beautiful than Venice
column4: having been there myself a few years ago. I came to Kerala with my mom when I was thirteen
column5: and I have to say
column6: although there is much more development than there used to be
column7: I felt very nostalgic as I walked along the fishing shore and saw the very familiar chinese fishing nets
column8: and the fisherman selling all types of fish and seafood. The three of us bought fish and prawns
column9: and a local restaurant cooked it for us in garlic and butter. Cheap as chips
column10: as they say. And delicious it was!!

column2: we got sarees made (another traditional Indian dress) made of Keralan silk
column3: and we ventured over to a cultural center where we saw traditional Kathakali dancing
column4: which is basically theater dance with large
column5: heavy intricate costumes
column6: and detailed eye movements which convey emotion
column7: rather than actual acting. It is a very cool thing to see

column1: Next we made our way to an elephant sanctuary where we made friends with a baby elephant and watched elephants bathing in the water. Very cool. The rest of our time was spent on the backwaters exploring small villages and taking in the view from the water of the women on shore making string out of coconut husks
column2: which
column3: unlike the way it used to be when I was here ten years ago
column4: is supplemented by the government
column5: which gives these women machines which helps to increase the production of string.

column1: Kerala was probably the hottest place we went to. After about a week in Karnataka state and then Kerala
column2: we ventured to Goa
column3: where we ended up staying for five days. Palolem beach is my favorite beach in India
column4: aside from a place called Gokarna. I was afraid that it would have been ruined by tourism in the last ten years
column5: and although again
column6: there was much more development that before
column7: it is off-season for tourists
column8: so the beach was not busy
column9: and it was JUST as I remembered it. I was home again in some small way
column10: which may sounds weird
column11: but makes perfect sense to me. I think my mom and brother would understand what I mean...

column1: After two weeks of traveling for pleasure
column2: balancing headphone parties and fire dancing/poy on the beach with trying to find internet occasionally to let people know we were alive or finish final papers and assignments
column3: we arrived in Manipal. We are staying in an all girls residence which is very clean and safe
column4: although we have a curfew
column5: and I feel like I am 5 years old again. I guess the university used to have problems with alcohol
column6: drugs
column7: and public displays of affection
column8: so they have really cracked down and made things a lot more conservative around here. I will be here for two weeks working with students from all over the world
column9: and I will start fieldwork at an ART center (anti-retroviral treatment) at the state hospital in Udupi district. I will work with HIV positive patients and health workers to investigate issues associated with the side effects of taking anti-retroviral drugs. I am so excited to have this practical experience
column10: and I cant wait to report on how it goes. I will report back when I can. I can’t believe I only have two weeks left before I am back in Canada! Talk to you soon

column1: Our second placement weekend was spent in the beautiful city of Mysore
column2: (mistakenly pronounced by Ali as ‘Mee-sore’ much to the amusement of our Indian housemates) a three hour bus ride away from Ashwini. We stayed in a hotel 3km outside the centre claimed by the Lonely Planet as ‘the nicest hostel in all of India’. Not convinced by this statement but if nothing else it definitely has a shot at being the most hilarious. We were staying in the women’s dorm which contained about 20 bunk-beds and at least another 20 mattresses strewn on any available floor surface. The other guests were exclusively Indian
column3: my particular bunk-mate made her irritation at our presence very clearly known-after enquiring of me suspiciously several times ‘why are you here?’
column4: she tried to oust Ali and I to the other side of the room and then insisted Ali move her rucksack as it was in
column5: I quote
column6: ‘the place for my soap’. I also got a very stern yelling for rolling over in the night. The bathrooms are also an adventure as queuing is not a concept which India has adopted. In fact the exact opposite. The shower etiquette goes as follows: barge in when you can and if someone dares to take more than 5 minutes
column7: attempt to knock the door down. Is an interesting approach. The sign stating check-in is from ‘10am to 10am’ (just below the sign that bans ‘all gambling and playing cards’) is clearly not a strict rule as a literal bus-load of women rolled into the room at 6am and
column8: mid full-blast singing
column9: threw a bag onto Cat’s head thinking her bed was empty. One way to start the day!

column1: We found an excellent local restaurant which we quickly made our regular lunch venue-highlight was a HUGE thali for the grand price of 80p including curry
column2: poppadum
column3: family sized portion of rice
column4: various non-descript but fantastic sauces and poori
column5: a kind of puffed up bread which is delicious. The food situation only got better as we decided to splash out for our Saturday dinner and go to a beautiful hotel for an afternoon and evening of fruit platters
column6: masala peanuts
column7: cocktails and (for me) pasta in their courtyard
column8: candle-lit restaurant. I visited the toilets approximately 55 times to make full use of the toilet roll. Speaking of toilets we also found a mall in the middle of Mysore which is half built (health and safety not on the radar) but very much open and contained
column9: much to our delight
column10: air-conditioning
column11: the most impressive selection of ice-cream flavours I have ever seen
column12: escalators and
column13: the crowning glory
column14: a set of loos with not only toilet roll but soap dispensers and an actual hand drier. You have never seen 6 people so excited. So much so that we visited again on the Sunday. In my haste I managed to fall over the doorway and slice my toe at which point the very lovely security man leapt at the opportunity to christen his first aid kit and doused my wound with not one
column15: not two
column16: not three
column17: but FOUR types of antiseptic. It is still the cleanest wound in the history of time.

column1: The palace is one of the most impressive buildings I have ever seen from stunning green-pillared wedding room (dad-get saving I have found my future marriage venue) to very British-style stained glass windowed courtyards. We returned in the evening for the promised light spectacular display of the 42000 bulbs lining the palace. After a few tepid flashes we gave up and went to drink some beer instead. Equally cultural. On the Sunday morning we got a bus to Chamundi Hill to visit the temple which at first read I am sure sounds incredibly serene. Think again. The temple itself is a beautiful white building perched on top of a hill with an incredible view of Mysore. However the rest of India decided they also wanted to witness its beauty on the same day. There was a queue (which actually seemed to function as a queue) looping round the entire building. We naturally had to pay the 3x increased foreigner price which did mean that we got fast tracked through the throngs straight into the temple
column2: past the ‘coconut breaking place’
column3: into the Goddess chamber where you are instructed to stick your hand in fire and drink holy water which looked so dubious we threw it on our heads instead. And then 30 seconds later we were out! And into the market next to the temple which includes the most bizarre selection of toys you could possibly imagine. Am still baffled by the thought process that went into making some of these things:

column2: I have an idea. For our next big seller how about a plastic man with a cone shaped head pushing a plastic cart full of tiny white balls’
let’s make 500 in 10 different colours
column3: but I was thinking more along the lines of a plastic baby in basket called “Titoo”’.

column1: ‘Brilliant boss. But I have an even better idea. Take the same plastic baby
column2: surround it by neon pink fluff and make it into a rucksack.’

column1: We spent what we thought would be our final few Mysore hours in a rooftop café overlooking the palace as a parade drummed away below us punctuated with the occasional cannon boom. No-one seemed too alarmed by this though we did see several birds literally drop out of the tree opposite us. Afterwards we headed to the bus station in plenty of time for our 17:30 bus home. I resist the urge to use the ‘physically challenged toilet’. 17:30 came and went. Turned out our bus had crashed on the way and was cancelled. Ah. After a fun half hour of shoving in the refund ‘queue’ we found out there is another bus at 11.30pm that we were about to book when we realised it wouldn’t arrive until 7am. Ah. Why? Turns out that the forest roads close overnight as this is when the elephants presumably get their rage on so the bus simply stops for a few hours. In the middle of the forest. We quickly vetoed this option and found a hotel near the bus station which for the grand price of £10 a night (we decided it was justified as we had spent £1.20 at the hostel of dreams). We were rewarded by a rooftop pool; lady kit containing essentials such as toothpaste
column2: bindis and tongue scrubber; fan AND air conditioning AND TV
column3: all of which I turned on immediately
column4: just because I could-Harry Potter in Hindi is a fascinating experience; mirror which helpfully asks ‘am I smart’; and the best shower head I have seen in a month. It. Is. Heaven. We reluctantly left the next morning and our 7am bus mercifully appeared. After an hour-long tyre change we are finally on our way. Clearly the little boy in front of us was caught short as his mother dangled him out the window to do his business. Unfortunately we had all the windows open and Ali and Alex received a lovely face-full of toddler pee to finish off our very eventful weekend! As Han (wrongly but very accurately) read from the guide book: ‘If you haven’t been to Mysore
column5: you just haven’t been’.

column1: I touched down in Bangalore just before midnight on Monday
column2: and was greeted at arrivals by Veena and her friend
column3: Indu. We took the hour's drive back to V's place and after a short catch-up on the balcony
column4: my tiredness got the better of me and I turned in. For some reason
column5: I'd stayed wide awake for the full four and a half hour flight
column6: which is very unlike me. I usually can't sit still for five minutes without drifting off. I somehow managed to zonk out whilst riding in a Cambodian tuk-tuk for goodness' sake! And those of you that have ridden in Cambodian tuk-tuks will understand how difficult a task that should be.

column2: we just chilled before heading out late afternoon. We went to Frazer Town and had a coffee at French Loaf
column3: where I was eaten alive by mosquitos and - for the first (and hopefully last) time during my travels - was attacked by a spider. Now
column4: most people know about my paralysing fear of creatures of the arachnid variety
column5: and those who don't
column6: usually experience a mix of amusement and utter shock at my reaction to seeing one. Anyway
column7: I was just

column2: minding my own business
column3: when something dropped on my arm. I mindlessly flicked it away
column4: and in doing so
column5: noticed that it was a spider. Unfortunately
column6: my flick had not been strong enough for the eight-legged terrorist
column7: and so strong was its conviction in terrifying the life out of me
column8: that it landed on my leg. I closed my eyes
column9: flapped my hands in the air and incoherently whimpered at Veena
column10: begging her to help me. Bless her cotton socks - she jumped out of her chair and in seconds
column11: had removed the assailant from my person. Once I had calmed my breathing
column12: and recovered from my traumatic experience
column13: she began gently teasing me about how small the spider was. I was in no position to argue with the woman that just saved my life
column14: so I graciously accepted the mockery.

column1: Still reeling from the recent dramatic event
column2: we went in search of food
column3: stopping at a small street stall serving panipuri
column4: which is a common snack in the north of India. It's basically a crispy
column5: hollow pastry ball with a large hole in it
column6: which is then filled with potato
column7: onion
column8: chilli and some seasonings
column9: followed

column2: people!

column1: by 'pani' (Hindi for water). This is then served on a banana leaf 'saucer'. Anyway
column2: the idea is to just shove the whole thing in your mouth
column3: lest you dribble the liquid down your chin. No prizes for guessing who made a mess of herself.

column2: we popped across to a sweet shop
column3: selling an array traditional Indian sweets
column4: such as gulab jamoon (small sausage-looking deep-fried dough rolls soaked in sugar water) and raspuri (small
column5: yellow balls
column6: of Bengali origin). I got a little too excited
column7: and proceeded to order half the shop
column8: not even deterred by the power-cut half-way through.

column1: My first observation of Indian roads was that drivers use their horns more than any other function on their cars/autos/mopeds. During peak hours
column2: it's hard to hear yourself think over the constant honking and bibbing
column3: and the sheer number of vehicles on the roads sends my mind into utter confusion. I didn't know which way to look
column4: let alone where to cross. It has to be said
column5: however
column6: that drivers are quite skilled when it comes to dodging crossing pedestrians and Sunday-strolling cattle.

column1: And that brings me to observation number two: cows. Throughout the day
column2: I

column1: They looked at me rather aggressively
column2: so I ran like the wind after taking this photo!

column1: saw numerous cows just wandering the streets
column2: some down the middle of the roads (causing vehicles to divert around them)
column3: some taking the civilised pavement route
column4: and some just chilling by the road-side. The bizarre thing is
column5: they are just as oblivious to the honking horns and bustling traffic as the drivers are to the sight of cattle strolling in their paths. One cow was even chewing away on a crash helmet that had been left on a moped outside a shop! You see
column6: cows are seen as sacred in Hindu society
column7: and one of the reasons for this is that the god of revenge
column8: Shiva
column9: rode one through Heaven. Likewise
column10: monkeys are not killed due to their association with the god Hanuman.

column2: Veena's housemate Vidya and their friend Ashish picked us up and we briefly swung by a poetry reading at Urban Solace
column3: before satisfying our hungers at Queen's - a Punjabi restaurant on Church Street. We ordered a variety of dishes
column4: including palak paneer (spinach and cottage cheese)
column5: mushroom masala (self-explanatory) and malai kofta (veggie balls). Wow! The meal was amazing
column6: so much so that the lack of meat didn't even register in my mind. With food like that
column7: I could easily be vegetarian.

column1: At some point during our walk to Frazer Town
column2: Veena asked me how I feel about the attention I get in public. No
column3: not the sort of looks that Julia Roberts got when she donned the red dress and strutted through the hotel lobby in Pretty Woman; the ""oh look
column4: a foreigner!"" look. Until she mentioned it
column5: I hadn't even realised I was drawing attention
column6: to be honest. I grew so accustomed to being stared at in Korea
column7: I'm oblivious to it now. Perhaps this can be considered in a positive light
column8: in that I feel no form of self-consciousness
column9: but in terms of 'keeping my wits about me'? Not so much.

column1: Wednesday and today were basically chill days
column2: interspersed by periods of eating and my own private showing of the movie Veena directed
column3: 'Reminiscence of Ether'. I was blown away. Such a lovely story line. I listened in awe as Veena told me 'behind the scenes' anecdotes and the production build-up. I'm also proud to say that I have met everyone involved in the making of this movie. Keep your eyes peeled for these guys
column4: people.

column1: And for the food update: Wednesday's lunch consisted of puri
column2: sagu
column3: dhosa and coconut chutney
column4: and dinner was biryani
column5: egg chilli
column6: masala papad and a couple of brandy and cokes at a restaurant called Rewind.

column2: I finally pulled my finger out of my arse and ventured out alone - following very precise instructions from Veena. The aim was to pick up an SD card reader for my iPad from the Apple shop on MG (Mahatma Ghandi) Road since the non-Apple one I bought in Singapore only served to slow down the device's performance. Well
column3: the Apple store doesn't stock them
column4: so I proceeded to Hard Rock Cafe on St Mark's Road
column5: had a couple of iced lattes
column6: then hopped back in an auto to Veena's place in Benson Town.

column1: Veena and I have just been discussing Hindu gods and the stories behind them. I didn't provide such entertaining responsive banter as Pete did back in Cadiz
column2: but i found it just as interesting. Did you know that the Hindu god Ganesh had an elephant head because his father
column3: Shiva
column4: chopped off his original one
column5: not knowing that the man he was decapitating was his own son? Upon discovery of this fact
column6: Shiva duly replaced said head with that of an elephant.

column2: I'll bid you goodnight.

column1: The shiva statue is located in the old airport road of Bangalore. If you are going from MG Road side
column2: you have go on the old airport road for about 4kms till you find a shopping complex called “Total Mall” (earlier called Kids Kemp). The Statue is located behind this building
column3: slightly visible to outside. There is an entry at the side of the building
column4: mentioned as “Pahadi Siva dhama Yatra”. You have to mark it from close or you may miss it.

column1: The interesting fact of the temple is that it is open in 365 days a year and 24 hours a day. This is something rare for any other temple in India.
Although people feel that the place has been commercialized by selling various types of tickets
column2: you can also go free and have darshan without spending a single rupee. All the tickets are for extraneous activities and not necessary for any common devotee.

column1: There are various types of entries
column2: free entry and special entry. Free entry may have a long queue (as below) and may take about an hour depending on the crowd. Special entry costs 50 rupees to bypass the queue. However
column3: I mostly prefer free entry as it gives me more time to think about God and spend that money on buying other pooja tickets like milk abhishek etc.

column1: While standing on a long queue you will come across about hundred shops on both of your side. Shops selling idols of God and other pooja/ religious items. The place may be slightly costlier than other places where they are available cheaper
column2: but you will get a good variety of items here in this place.

column1: After the queue you will find the ticket counter. This ticket counter is not for fast entry as you have already free entered through the queue. This counter sells ticket for various attractions like:
- Om namah shivaya wish coin Rs 20/-
Thus total Rs160/- if you buy individual tickets. Alternatively you can buy a special ticket for Rs 100 which includes all the above in a package.

Besides you have to buy camera tickets for Rs 25 and video camera tickets for Rs 100. Earlier till 2008 (?) photography was strictly not allowed. Some people were taking pictures very secretly through mobile cameras. Although I had great wishes to take pictures I never liked taking stealth pictures. But suddenly when I went after a gap that I found that cameras are allowed for a price. I also took a lot of pictures and videos of the beautiful place.

After buying special pooja tickets (if you wish so) and camera tickets (again if you need) you are entering to the main compound. Here you can keep your shoes in the shoe stand for Rs 2/- and proceed inside.
Now you can see a giant statue of Ganesh and a giant statue of Shiva
column2: both very beautiful and very attractive. You will soon forget the pain of coming so far to see the place. You will feel eager to go close to the statue and see the statue from different angles.

column1: Most people first visit Ganesh statue then proceed to Shiva statue. You have to climb a few steps (about 30) to reach Ganesh statue and then climb down the same on the other side.
Pahadi shiva dhama yatra is a special place having Himalayan Shiva statues. As I mentioned earlier
column2: if you have bought special tickets you can enter into this place. Apart from various Shiva Lingas you will find Amarnath
column3: which is made of ice. You can touch the ice Linga and feel it in your hands.

column1: If you have bought tickets for this
column2: you will be given 108 coins. There will be 108 pots. You will chant om namah sivaya and put a coin in each of these pots. This is quite interesting and keeps you busy for atleast 5 minues.

column1: If you have bought tickets for Om namah Shivaya wish coin
column2: you can wish something at this spot and drop the coin in the water. People believe that their wishes will be fulfilled.

column1: You may buy tickets for getting a candle from this counter and float the candle on the water in front of the statue.

This is a ticketed activity. You will be given a piece of wood and a small bowl of ghee for havan. You will go to the havan kunda (behind me in the picture below) and put the wood and ghee inside. There will always be fire inside the havan kunda to burn your offerings.

There is a navagraha temple inside the compound as ususal in any other temple in south India. You can have free darshan of Navagraha. But if you have bought a ticket then you will be given a deepa (candle) to pray the lords.

Coming out of the temple is fairly simple. As the whole place is an open compound there is nothing much to confuse. You take the exit any time after having darshan. The entry and exit are two different routes. You will find a lot of shops on the exit route too. If you have failed to buy anything while entering
column2: you can buy from here.

column1: The place is very peaceful. You can sit here for long time. Especially in the evening it is very peaceful to sit here in the courtyard in front of the statue and stare at the statue. People staying close to this area come here regularly for a prayer to the Lord. As I stay far (about 15 kms) which takes one to two hours drive depending on traffic
column2: I come about once in a year.

column1: Shivaratri is a festival day and you have to stand on long queues. Avoid on Shivaratri if you are not a serious devotee. Once in Shivaratri (2006) I stood on the queue in the evening and had darshan of the lord at 2 O’clock after standing for about 8 hours. Reaching home was almost morning.
I have seen some other big Shiva statues
column2: one in Haridwar
column3: one in Gajnur (Karnataka)
column4: one in Murudeshwar (Karnataka). I guess Murudeshwar statue is the largest of all. Bangalore statue is probably more homely 😊 (because I stay in Bangalore!).

column1: (View this article and other travel articles in travelindia.tk )
Steam - the good old days - to Ooty
So next stop after The Andamans are parts of South India
column2: before heading north for a few weeks
column3: and then going to Japan at the end of this month. These are
column4: in fact
column5: “filler” weeks as we were going to do Darjeeling & Sikkim till we discovered that it might be too cold to visit this time of year
column6: and we didn’t wish to carry our warm gear with us as well through the places we have visited since the girls left.

column1: We get a Jet Airways flight from Port Blair to Chennai after a slight hic cup when we realise we don’t have the copy of the e-ticket for C. Thankfully there is a Jet counter at the entrance to the airport & we get a copy free (as she is sooooo nice) - they decide not to charge her the Rs 100 usual fee for dorks who forget such things.

The flight is uneventful other than the surprise lunch on board and the nerdy kid in front of us who couldn’t just talk to his parents but had to shout at an annoying pitch every five seconds - M could quite easily have strangled him. Ipods to
the rescue and the squirt lived to see another day.

We arrive at the new Chennai airport ½ hour (2.35pm) early which is great and then luckily we bump into a Czech guy (Michael from Prague) who’s also looking to take a pre-paid cab to Mamallapuram. So we share the cost (Rs 1280) and the cab gets us there in an hour and a half. We therefore
column2: avoid the hassle of getting a Metro to the centre
column3: finding the Bus station and then taking a 2 hour bus ride to get there. We also avoid the need to stay in Chennai which isn’t our bag. We were here 5 years ago and it didn’t do it for us then. However
column4: from the air Chennai looks great with the houses all brightly coloured in yellows
column5: pinks
column6: purples
column7: blues etc amid palm tree lined streets.

column1: We’ll be back to catch the train to Ooty in a few days.
Mamallapuram – The World Heritage Site for the Pallava Dynasty carvings & Temple.
The ride to Mamallapuram is slow going for a while then the freeway opens up and we travel along the sea shore for miles. There
C & friend - too early for an ice cream - Mysore
are a host of tourist places here now and large backwater lakes
column2: a few filled with Indian Pink Flamingos – smaller and less pink than the ones in Africa.

column1: We get to the town in bright daylight. We had rung ahead and booked a room at a Hotel (we thought was a family Guest House) called Le Vie en Rose. Odd name for a place here – but then so are most of the places in what the LP guide rightly refers to as “Backpackistan”! The hotel is fine – only Rs 600 per night – wow. It’s also near the Bus stop and at the center of the action here.

One thing we discover early on is that M’s Hindi isn't going to be much help – most locals only speak Tamil and some English. So English it is - as his Tamil is pretty non-existent despite the fact he spent 3 years in University at Chennai.One point of note in this part of the world/India is that names of people seem to go on forever - see the signs we have taken pictures of.
The place really is a backpacker’s delight and pretty chilled. The

main drag off the town’s High Street (called East Raja Street) is Othadavai Street where most of the eateries and shops are. It leads to the sea where life seems largely the same as it was for the local fishing community many years ago bar the arrivals of the tourists and everything that brings. The fishermen are busy getting on with life
column2: fixing nets
column3: preparing nets for fishing at sunset
column4: fixing boats
column5: playing cards till fishing time etc. All the while many cows
column6: some dogs and quite a few foreigners walk around them.

column1: The sea front cafes and restaurants are all painted in bright colours as are the fishing boats all along the shore front. The sea looks clean but is more for surfers than swimmers. At the shore
column2: resplendent at sea level is one of the famous temples – called quite originally – Shore Temple!! There’s a movie or TV crew working nearby.

column1: Looking around we can only imagine that this is akin to Hampi
column2: which many travellers have said is really lovely and laid back with the usual blend of Indian mysticism
column3: history and picturesque landscape. We do regret the fact that we missed the chance

column1: to go there when we were in Goa (we didn't realise we were so close to it; about 180 kms). However
column2: we can always add this into our next trip to India
column3: together with Dharamsala & Manali which we discounted in favour of Leh
column4: Srinagar & Sikkim when we get back in June.

column1: We find a really small book shop and discover that they are selling the new LP India Guide – second hand for Rs 500 – bargain and we are back in business.
After all the seafood in the Andamans we are ready for some good south Indian food – Dosa’s
column2: Idli
column3: Uttappam etc. But amazingly most places are labelled North Indian or tourist joints – we have to search out the two places that do what we want - Anand Bhavan & Mamalla Bhavan. Mamalla is the better of the two and we eat there quite often – awesome breakfasts and dinners and very cheap. It’s a bit of a local institution with staff that seem to have been there since the day it opened – the guy who serves us is really sweet and attentive. We also take Michael (the Czech version!) there one

column1: breakfast - as he’s a keen foodie with an ambition to open his own eatery back in Prague - so he can experience Pongal (a sort of rice
column2: lentil and spice mix that’s yummier than it sounds!) and all the other delights and their excellent Madras coffee.

column1: We do try seafood one night at Ponn Water Face – Kalamari & seafood noodles – ok
column2: but not as good as the Andamans. We only went there really for the “cheap” beer (at Rs 180 it isn’t cheap at all but there’s no bottle shop nearby so needs must!).

column1: Internet here is great value at Rs 30 per hour and really fast so we catch up with family & friends and spend a happy two hours uploading our last three blogs.
We have come here to see the temples and rock carvings from the 7th Century
column2: during the Pallava Dynasty
column3: which now have UNESCO World Heritage status. The 2 separate sites have to be paid for – The Five Rathas and the Shore Temple. In all honesty
column4: unless you want to get close to the carvings to see them in detail
column5: it’s not worth paying. You can see the

column1: Five Rathas quite easily from the road and the Shore Temple from the beach. M is definitely not convinced that the sites warrant World Heritage status and in terms of value for money for the RS 250 fee – it only warrants about Rs 50 compared to other World Heritage sites we have seen in India.

At one of the Temples in town (Talasayana Perumal) there is a story that the Shore Temple was built on the spot where Vishnu appeared to a saint who was trying to bail out the sea (!) to present a gift to Vishnu. The Five Rathas (5 temples and a life sized elephant and lion) are apparently carved out of one huge piece of stone and may or may not be dedicated to the five Pandavas and their wife – the heroes of Mahabharata – depending on whether you believe LP or the Archaeological Survey of India respectively!
The rest of the sites are free
column2: and to our eyes
column3: more impressive. Especially the bas relief carvings of Arjuna’s Penance and Trimurthi’s Cave. These are all found in one long stretch of grounds along the edge of town which makes a popular local

column1: picnic site (judging by the litter left around!). A local favourite is called Ganesh’s Butter Ball (haven’t a clue why?)
column2: a large boulder that sits on a slope precariously which is good for photo’s. We do most of the sites early in the morning and late afternoon when it’s more comfortable as it’s incredibly hot and humid here; we think only Palenque in Mexico was more sweat inducing.

column1: The stone carving craft is still a major feature of the town
column2: with sculpture workshops everywhere and either the gentle noise of stone chiselling or the whirring din of stone cutting machines. There are some pretty impressive pieces which we suspect are bound for businesses as they’d be too large for a home.

column1: Weekends see a lot of local day-trippers on buses
column2: coaches and in their own cars and all the sites are packed with folk (generally all dressed up and the women with garlands in their hair) and the restaurants are full.

column1: We meet up with Michael again one evening for a beer (he’s not sure whether to go to Hampi & other parts of India or go back to The Andamans which he loves). We hope to
meet up with him when we head to Prague in future. The next day we take the local Express bus to Chennai
column2: where we are to catch our overnight train to Metupalaiyam and (hopefully) the early morning connection with the Mountain Railway steam train up to Ooty. We book our bags into storage at Chennai station for convenience (Rs 45 for 3 bags for one day) but we aren’t inspired to go out and about. M lived here for 3 years as a student and we visited in our last trip and really it’s just a big smelly city. So instead we find a chair in the waiting room upstairs (which is quite big and airy) near a power point and play games and catch up on planning and the blog.

column1: Supper is some awesome kebab rolls from Tibby Frankies in the station – chicken tikka and paneer with mint sauce are best. Then all aboard for overnight the trip to Ooty.
There are only 3 direct buses from Mamallapuram to Central Chennai a day. Rs 39. Then get a local bus from the bus station to Central Railway station Rs 7.
So from the sweltering heat of Mamallapuram
column2: we are sitting in our room in Ooty writing this wrapped in blankets!! It’s cool here.

column1: The overnight journey went well and in fact we arrive into Metupalaiyam 30 mins early; great as it means time for a couple of good hot coffees and lots of photos of the Nilgiri Mountain Railway narrow gauge steam train and steam engines before we set off. Aditya has managed to get us 1st class tickets
column2: one on each side of the carriage so we get the best photo opps of the views all the way up. (Thanks Aditya). The journey takes 5 hours with plenty of stops along the way for refreshments etc. We see quite fresh elephant poo by the tracks but no signs of the real thing. There are also plenty of birds and butterflies and the vegetation changes from palm trees to tea plantations to eucalyptus trees as we go higher.

column1: On some of the steeper sections
column2: the steam train engine really struggles and shudders and on arrival at Coonor after 3 hours
column3: the steam engine is replaced with a diesel engine for the final 2 hour

column1: leg to Ooty. More smooth but less atmospheric. (Unfortunately we also change travelling companions at Coonor; some eejit Brits and their guide join us and we soooo want to tell them where to get off for being completely obnoxious & ignorant twits!! The Indian guide wasn’t much better
column2: giving incorrect information. M has to bite his lips
column3: a lot; we guess they deserve each other.)

column2: the train journey is a great experience and at only R’s 350 for both of us
column3: an absolute bargain.

column1: We have planned to stay for one night in Ooty
column2: with the option for more if we like it. As we pull in we decide we are not too sure. However
column3: the weather changes and it starts to rain and gets really cooler. This gets us to decide that 1 night will definitely be enough (a view that is confirmed later when we wander into town for some lunch) as it seems a very non-descript place despite the colourful houses. An impression not helped by the heavily over cast sky.

column1: We are staying at Hotel Sweekar
column2: overlooking the town and racecourse which is right slap bang in the middle of the town.

column1: It’s an English style bungalow and ok for the money (R’s 550) but a bit basic. Thankfully the owner is a nice chap who happily gives us extra blankets as we are feeling the cold.

We head back into town for a mooch and some lunch but despite the recommendations in LP it’s really hard to find anywhere that looks interesting and we have to walk for ages. It’s also raining – cold rain! Waterproof jackets required. In the end we head for a bar for a couple of beers then a local halal restaurant for some chicken kebabs. Not bad.

On the way back we call into the bus station and pre book our coach seats for the trip to Mysore in the morning. We are able to choose our seats which is great – first time this trip we are doing a long (5 hours) bus journey in India. More surprising is that M gets a discount for being of mature age!!
We dine at Kebab Corner after a few cheap beers at a local bar. The food and service are really good and reasonably priced.
We are up early and have a lovely

light breakfast at the Guest House and get to the bus stop to get to Mysore. Today the sun is shining and Ooty looks very different and more interesting. We reflect on this and realise perhaps we were perhaps being influenced by the weather and judging Ooty by our experiences elsewhere rather than accepting what it has to offer us as visitors. Ooty has a lot of amenities and areas of interest close by. Nature trails and trekking are big draws aswell as the local national parks.

It’s spread over a vast area. The pockets of housing are colourful and have a charm all of their own. The Nilgiri Tea plantations give a lovely colour and texture to the landscape; the land is fertile and green with fruit and vegetables growing. Other than Tea
column2: the big draw here is chocolate – including chocolate tea (yuck says M). The chocolates (including a Jain version) are home made with a variety of fillings – nuts
column3: raisins
column4: dates etc – and sold in just about all general shops along the streets.

column2: all the signs are in Telegu
column3: as are the posters for films recently released and as

column1: Comfort break & stop for refuelling - Ooty
it’s election time – wall to wall posters of politicians trying to grab your vote!

As we drive from away from Ooty we feel perhaps another day or so may have given us a totally different perspective of the place & its people. The drive is a challenge by anyone’s standards and more so when your driver is in a hurry. The bus has to negotiate 36 hairpin bends and most of the passengers (not us thankfully) end up throwing up into sick bags provided by the bus company. They even run out of them by the time we hit the plains. It does make us wonder why these folks who have paid quite a lot for this bus trip couldn’t take a motion sickness tablet (cost about Rs 5) that would stop their discomfort.
