The drive takes us right through the heart of the Mudumalai National Reserve where we spot 4 wild elephants and many deer. Next we are into the Bandipur Tiger Reserve – but no tigers I’m afraid despite a thorough search around.
Eventually we hit Karnataka – the next state and eventually (after a 20 mins pit stop for a comfort break and
some lunch) we arrive ahead of schedule in Mysore.
Mysore – The Garden City (we are not so sure!)
We arrive at the Mysore Central Bus station ½ hour ahead of schedule. It’s an impressive bus station
column2: modern and bustling. It’s also clean and has good information counters
column3: a few eateries (veg & non-veg)
column4: plenty of snack stands and all the facilities you would expect.

column1: We are persuaded by a “tout” to try the Aishwaraya Residency nearby rather than go to our chosen hotel as it offers free wi-fi and various other amenities unlike the one we were going to for the same price. So we check it out and it’s ok – as much as we dislike dealing with touts
column2: the free wi-fi clinches it for us as we need this for sorting out many things for our trips to Japan & The Philippines and to skype Sarah on her Big Birthday!!

column1: It’s pretty hot in Mysore and our first impressions of the city is that it is well planned with wide streets
column2: pretty clean
column3: with buildings reflecting its history under Mughal rule
column4: The Royal heritage
column5: the British and now Indian independence. Most places in

column1: the central area are walkable. In theory it’s a place we should enjoy. But….What is interesting for us is the absence of good eating places in & around the centre. There are hundreds of Hotels that have small eating places (veg or non-veg) but very few decent restaurants. And so it doesn’t quite do it for us as a place of interest.
We read about a day trip of Mysore and Sirangapatna (the abode of the once King Tippu Sultan) run via the Karanataka Tourism Office which we decide to go for. At Rs 210 each
column2: it starts at 8.30 am and finishes at about 8.30 pm.

column1: We are the only foreigners on the small mini bus for the trip. The rest are folks from various parts of India visiting Mysore. The guide thankfully speaks in English
column2: Hindi and Kannada (the local state language). The tour covers the following sites:

column1: This is the old residence of one of the rulers of Mysore which is now an “Art Gallery” come Museum. Entry is Rs 130 for foreigners and we weren’t sure about going in but didn’t have a lot of option as we had to
pay the guide up front for all the entry tickets – this included. We were pleasantly surprised though. The building has architectural merit. Inside it has a host of regal memorabilia
column2: many rare musical instruments
column3: some great paintings – notably one called The Glow of Hope which has a room to itself and is impressive as is a pencil drawing of Tagore. There were amazingly carved Tusks and a black stone elephant. The Rosewood hand carved furniture was awesome as was the marble small replica of the Mysore palace. Upstairs
column4: there’s an amazing Ivory Palanquin that once carried the rulers here. The inside of the building looks tired but the size of it all gives a sense of what royalty had in days gone by.

column1: The big cheese in Mysore without doubt. Entry is Rs 250 to the main palace and they want another Rs 280 from foreigners to see the residential bit of the palace. This is optional & we opt out. The Palace though is still a working palace for ceremonial events in Mysore. The big festival is Dussehra in Oct when the King and gentry go on an elaborate parade &

column2: horses etc.

column1: We are not allowed to take cameras in so no photographs unfortunately. The place is well maintained as it’s still private. The most striking areas are The Main Durbar
column2: The Marriage room (which has the most amazing glass ceiling made of iron and stained glass manufactured in Glasgow. The scope of colours makes it breath-taking – a truly grand design for its day!) And finally the King’s private audience room – again the ceiling is a beautifully coloured stained glass marvel of craftsmanship. It brings the place alive – even today. The door to and from the room are amazingly carved with ivory insets. One is carved in Silver. All very regal and grand as befitting a king! Well worth the entry fee.

column1: The surrounding garden and area is also well maintained and there are a variety of Temples at corners of the outer perimeter and very grand gateways on each side. The elephants are kept in an enclosure not far away. The palace glows with a hundred thousand light bulbs every Sunday between 7 and 8 pm & for big national events.
St Philomena’s Church (AKA St Joseph’s Cathedral):
Vishnu Bhavan - great breakfast & coffee - Mysore
It’s a catholic cathedral which has a Gothic look to it but neither the outside or inside are particularly spectacular. It’s a 10 min whistle stop trip.
It’s part of the trip & not somewhere we were looking forward to having had our fill of zoos (no disrespect to Pi & Pondicherry!!) However
column2: this for us was the surprise package of the lot. Entry Rs 40 – foreigners and Indians (parity for once - yeah). It’s really clean
column3: well laid out and the directions and signs lead you to all the sites. It looks well-kept and managed; there is significant investment in new areas being prepared for the animals. They have a great selection of birds including white peacocks which we’ve never seen before. Some of the other highlights for us were the really healthy Bengal Tigers
column4: the awesome leopards
column5: the cheetahs
column6: the white rhino and the only Gorilla in India.

column1: On top of Chamundi hill is a temple – nothing special to look at as Indian Temples go but is apparently one of the most sacred. A quick flit through (Rs 30 entry +
Rs 2 for the shoes stand – a new Indian stealth tax or enterprise by all temples and mosques!! In addition to the ridiculously high entry fees for foreigners.)

column2: there’s a 10 minute stop to see a huge Bull called Nandi (representing Shiva) carved from one very large stone – quite impressive really.

column1: After a few photos we were ready for lunch.The break for lunch is at a Hotel complex in the city which looks in part like a building site. The options are a South Indian Thali & a North Indian Thali at a set price and not particularly a good advert for Mysore or Indian cuisine – enough said. The prices of the cold drinks were extortionate too.

Was the seat of Tippu Sultan and his father Hyder Ali. They ruled for 36 years. Tippu Sultan had his fort and palace here and was defeated by the British and killed after a bloody encounter having been betrayed by his uncle. The place Tippu was killed is marked by a stone. The fort is in ruin and was actually blown up by the Bristish within 6 hours of the
Five Rathas - backside view as they say
battle in 1799. The fort was strategically built on the confluence of 2 rivers. While there we stop for a visit to a very uninspiring Ranganatha Swamy Temple. Unfortunately
column2: the guide misjudged his timings so we didn’t make it to Tippu’s summer palace which is supposed to be beautiful.
for Indians particularly
column3: are the Brindavan gardens – most of the middle aged and older generation who were fed on Bollywood movies (as there was no TV at the time) will recall many happy Indian songs being filmed here with hero and heroine prancing around each other coyly (with heavy suggestions of sexual attraction – Indian style of course). The gardens are at the bottom of a 3 km dam wall built by the kings of Mysore. The gardens are laid out reasonably well and separated in the middle by a lake. On one side is a nightly colourful fountain display to India music which most of the day trippers come for. It’s not quite worth the journey in our view – but Indians love gardens
column4: sunsets and musical fountains so for them it is heaven!!

column2: Mam

column1: and get dropped off near the bus stop so we can dive into the Bar for a cold beer or 2. Unfortunately
column2: the guy serving us that night clearly didn’t like our presence in the place so ignored us for ages till his boss had to tell him off. A complete shit head compared to the guy who had served us really well the previous 2 nights.

column1: The best eating experiences for us were at Hotel New Shilpashri Bar & Restaurant & The RRR Hotel
column2: both in Gandhi Square. The latter is an institution and gets packed out. Their speciality is a vegetarian thali served on Banana leaves – a dying art in India. They also do a few non – veg dishes. Be prepared to queue a bit
column3: but it’s worth it and the turnaround is really quick.

column1: One place worth a visit is the area known as the Devaraja Market. It’s colourful and has a host of interesting stalls selling most things you are ever likely to need to live and eat. Drinks you have to get from a Bottle shop!!
It’s difficult to say a lot about the place as it’s
been labelled the High Tech city & happening place in India etc. However
column2: we are only here for about 3 hours and our experience in that time is pretty poor on a number of fronts – so we are aware that our comments may not reflect the real B.

column1: The train journey from Mysore to B goes off without a hitch. It takes 3 hours on the Chaumandi Express which only runs from Mysore to B. The station at B is pretty big and clean and they have a left luggage counter which we use so that we might explore the city a bit. However
column2: once out of the station – the main Bus station (Majestic) is reached via an underpass. The rest of the road is blocked off and the area looks like a building site. We try to catch a rickshaw to the City Market area (as we don’t have much time) and for 1km the guy asks for Rs 200. The others aren’t interested as we suspect that the fare is pretty low. As we have had no breakfast and left the Hotel in Mysore at 5.45 am we try a local eatery at the station.

column1: Crap coffee. Toilet flooded. The public “pay as you use” Toilets which seem to be all over the South charge C Rs 3 and M only 2? Given the heat we decide it might be better at the airport rather than hang around as we hear that it’s a brand spanking new place.

So au revoir Bengaluru – we seem sure we had the worst of what the city has to offer. The 40km journey to the airport is on the Vayu Vajra A/C Bus – a special airport shuttle which costs Rs 195 each compared to the Rs 770 quoted by the Prepaid Taxi stand at the railway station. It takes 1 hour and they depart on the ½ hour from the main city bus station known as Majestic. The journey takes us through much of the northern half of B with all its flyovers and many new housing developments. It reminds us of Pune in a way – which we liked a lot
column2: though a lot bigger and more expensive (given the advertised prices for 2 & 3 bed flats here Rs 29 Lakh to 1.5 Crore).

column1: Bengaluru airport is relatively new (parts of it still
look like its being completed) and has a lot of amenities and is a delight for travellers.

column2: this whistle stop tour of some of the South
column3: a last minute substitute for the hills and mountains of Darjeeling and Sikkim
column4: has been a bit of a mixed experience but worth it if only for the train journey to Ooty
column5: Mysore Palace & the carvings at Mamallapuram.

column2: Displayed: 40
agua em abundancia por entre blocos redondos de granito avermelhado. Bananais
column3: coqueirais
column4: caminhos de terra
column5: muitas ruinas de um enorme imperio hindu dizimado pelos muculmanos e templos bonitos
column6: alguns ainda vivios. Gente a lavar-se
column7: a lavar roupa
column8: beber
column9: brincar no rio pela manha.

column1: Se fecharmos os olhos a certas coisas (muito turistico)
Tour das ruinas em bicicleta com um grupo porreiro
column2: sob calor torrido a horas improprias.
Laxmi
column3: que trabalha no templo. Grande paquiderme
column4: pele aspera e enrugadinha e pelos como arame
column5: a tromba brincalhona e rosada na ponta bufa feliz enquanto a esfregavamos. Grandes patas
column6: solidos troncos
column7: como ossos! E um lindo olhar molhado me olhava da grande cabeca.

column1: Toquei pela primeira vez nos bagos leitosos (ainda nao polinizados
column2: um agricultor explicou-me como 'funcionava'...) da planta do arroz
column3: que tantas vezes tive no prato.

column2: Displayed: 5

column1: Trimurty temple is around 30 kms from Bangalore on Kanakapura road. If you are going from Banashankari temple
column2: you have to go around 20 kms on National highway 209. However
column3: you have to be vigilant to notice the temple at your left.

column1: The temple is a combination of three temples
column2: Ganesh
column3: Hanuman and Srikrishna. There are huge statues of Ganesh
column4: Hanuman and Srikrishna on easy of these temples. You can easily notice the three huge statues while going on Kanakapura road (NH 209). It is better that you go by your own vehicle
column5: otherwise you have to try your luck on any Bangalore-Kanakapura bus.

column1: Apart from the huge attractive statues on the temples
column2: the next beautiful attraction of the temple is the garden. The garden has beautiful grass lawn and excellent collection of various plants.

column1: There are various activities in the temple like annadana (free food). Besides there are festivals on various auspicious days
column2: which are written in the notice boards in side the temple.
there are also other temples like Shiva temple etc. The environment is very cool and peaceful and you will definitely enjoy to sit for some time inside the temples.

column1: Although the temple is recently built it has the peace and piousness of old temples. It is colorful
column2: attractive and surrounded by beautiful lawns and trees. It is worth visiting by everybody going on Bangalore-Kanakapura road.

column1: (This article was first posted in JournalSite.tk )
St. Mary’s Basilica is the oldest church in Bangalore. It is located in the Shivaji nagar
column2: next to Shivaji nagar bus stop. The institution was raised to the status of a Basilicaon the order of Pope John Paul VI in the year 1973. Mary’s Feast is celebrated with grand processions in this church every year.

column1: As the church is centrally located
column2: you can approach the church from Queen’s road side
column3: from MG road
column4: from Commercial Street
column5: from Ulsoor lake side etc. However the place being in the heart of the city is overcrowded all the time.

column1: The Mary’s feast is celebrated in the month of September. The Arch Bishop of Bangalore hoists flag in St. Mary’s Basilica to begin the festival. The festival continues for 9 days and ends on the 10<sup style=""margin: 0px; padding: 0px;"">th day with a car festival with grand procession.
Other activities are also organized such as thanks giving to elderly couples completing 50 years of marriage

column2: you can find several idols of Mother Mary near the church with beautiful decorations. Usually the celebration continues for 10 days. The last day is celebrated with the car festival with huge crowd.

column1: The above is a Mary’s statue decorated outside the church. These are temporary statues made specifically for this occasion. Similarly below is another temporary decoration on the roadside near the Basilica.
Thousands of people visit the church on this day. People have to stand on a long queue (picture below). Although the crowd is there for the whole day
column2: the length of the queue increases as the time become closer to car festival.
the idol of mother Mary is finely decorated. Many priests take care of various aspects of the festival on the day. The idol of Jesus is also decorated and worshiped in a grand way.

column1: The last day of the 10-day long Mary’s feast is celebrated with a car festival. People start gathering in the mid day. The security forces create cordons around the church and don’t allow the crowd to go inside. Ave Maria music and prayers are chanted through loud speakers. Priests from various places come and gather here.
A chariot is decorated with beautiful flowers
column2: lights etc. The idol of mother Mary is placed on it. Some highly ranked priests/ bishops sit on the chariot. Band parties play their music and drums. The place becomes fully crowded.

column1: The Chariot is beautifully decorated. Especially the lights are arranged in a beautiful way. As they give different colors of light
column2: each picture of the chariot will look different. Thousands of people go along with the Chariot. Although people here are generally disciplined
column3: the law and order is maintained by a large number of police.

column1: The festival is celebrated not only by the Christians but people of other religions too. As the Shivaji nagar area is more populated by the Muslims
column2: having shops and businesses
column3: they also get involved in the festival in various ways. The car festival is attended by thousands of people from across different religions.

column1: Parking vehicles in the car festival will be a great problem
column2: as such there is hardly any parking place in Shivaji Nagar. Besides on the day of Mary’s feast the traffic police will not allow any vehicle to enter from a km. If you are taking your vehicle then be ready to park it somewhere at 2 kms distance. Alternatively go by public transport till MG road or Queens road or some place nearby and then take a walk to the church.

column1: St. Mary’s basilica is a 300 years old Church and organizing daily prayers. People of different religions visit it. You can visit it on any day
column2: even if not in Mary’s feast.

column1: Photography is allowed inside the church
column2: you can take beautiful pictures of mother Mary and other views around.

column1: There is possibility of having mild rainfall during September. Twice I got completely wet while watching car festival. Be prepared for that too.
(This article was first posted in Journalsite.tk )

You have to go on Bangalore - Hyderabad National Highway 7. On this road do not take a deviation to the airport. But still proceed until you reach a circle for Devanahalli township marked towards right. You have to go half km further and take a right turn from the highway.
Actually the fort is about 100 mtrs from the highway and visible from the road. But because the fort looks old and not attractive
column2: you are very likely not to notice it from the road. I had never noticed the fort although I had gone more than 50 times on that highway. But this time after coming from the fort I realized that it is in fact visible from the highway.

column1: There is a fort in Devanahalli was built by Mallabairegowda in 1501 A.D. Which was latter taken over by Tippu Sultan in 17th Century A.D. The present fort in Devanahalli is rebuilt by Hyder Ali and Tippu Sultan during 17th Century. The fort was then taken over by the British after Tippu lost the battle in Mysore war.
This fort is very different from what I was expecting it to be. I was expecting a ticket counter
column2: a parking place
column3: some guards and stuff. But actually the fort is just an entrance and nothing after that (for the tourists). Talking from a different angle the fort area is used as a regular habitation.

column1: There is no ticket or entrance fee for the fort. The entrance of the fort is rather a regular road to pass through. You can drive in through the fort entrance and go to the habitation area. The entrance to the fort is bit narrow
column2: just enough for a big car to go.

column1: The fort is spread over an area of 20 acres. This is a living fort where many families are living inside. There are many temples inside the fort area
column2: such as Venugopalswamy temple
column3: Siddheswar swamy temple
column4: Raghabendraswamy Math
column5: Chandramouleswar Temple etc.

column1: After we drove in through the fort entrance we first saw two temples
column2: Venugopalswamy temple and Siddheswar Swamy temple. The Venugopalswamy temple is just behind the entrance of the fort
column3: sharing the same common wall.

column1: This is front side (above) of Venugopalaswamy temple. This temple is believed to be the oldest among other temples. The sculptures of this temple are very attractive. We saw a beautiful Vimana (below) which is used to carry the idol during festivals.
There are two black colored statues guarding both the sides of the main entrance of the Venugopalswamy temple (below).
While coming out of Venugopalswamy temple
column2: we could see Siddheswar swamy temple and two other temples in the front within yards.

column1: Siddheswar temple (below) is just in front of Venugopalswamy temple
column2: on the other side of the road
column3: say at 10 meters distance. There is a newly built Siva statue with mirrors which gives multiple reflection of the lord. In order to protect the mirrors from birds and animals the temple is fully covered by metal grill.

column1: The temple has a traditional look with beautiful sculpture. Painting with beautiful colors has made it even more attractive.

The main deity of the temple is lord Siddheswar (behind me above). The deity is old and worshiped since several centuries. A new temple is built in the campus (behind me below) fitted with mirrors at all sides to give infinite reflections of lord Shiva and Parvati.

There are few more temples inside the fort area which we could not visit because of limited time. It was going to be envening and we thought to visit Tipu’s birth place before it gets dark. So we came out of the fort and went further on the same road for 200 meters. We saw a small memorial marked as Tipu’s sultan’s birth place.

column2: it has just some archeological importance
column3: but there is nothing much to see. It is just an arch of about 20 feet surrounded by a wall.

column1: There is nothing much to see in the fort. So don’t go with much expectation
column2: which might lead to frustration. Similar in case of Tipu’s birth place. If you like old monuments and archeological places
column3: then you would like this place.

column2: if you are in Bangalore
column3: it is worth driving a few kilometers to visit this place. Particularly if you like temples
column4: you will get some beautiful temples within a kilometer radius.

column1: There is no timing of the fort (as it is always open)
column2: no tickets (as the fort entry road is used as the public road). So you can go at any time of your convenience.

column1: There are two Beautiful Nakoda Jain temples on both sides of the highway. They are beautiful and worth visiting.

Nandi hills is also on the same direction. You have to go 2 kms further on the National Highway and then take a left turn for Nandi hills. It will be a good idea to combine Devanahalli fort in your Nandi hills trip and first visit the fort while going to Nandi hills.
(Note: This article was first published in JournalSite )
If you are going from Bangalore you have to first go to Kanakapura and then take the road going to Sangama/ Mekedatu. Although there are many busses to Kanakapura
column2: there will be fewer busses to Mekedatu. It may be convenient to go by own vehicle.

column1: After going to Kanakapura you have to leave the highway at Kanakapura and take a left turn for Mekedatu. The road here looks like a narrow lane (although widened afterwards) and is not easily recognized. It is better to ask people there for confirmation. Once you get the road
column2: you have to move straight without any confusion.
Kanakapura to Sangama 30+ Kms
column3: Sangama to Mekedatu 4 kms
column4: total around 100 Kms (one side).

column1: Sangama is the confluence of two rivers – Arkavathi and Kaveri (Cauvery). In Summer season there will be less water and you can easily walk inside the river. In rainy season there will be more water with heavy flow. Both the seasons are enjoyable although differently.

Near Sangam you will find some signboards warning you about the crocodiles and dangers in water. You should be careful about your safety. You can park you vehicle there near the road side and pay a parking fee.
We had gone to Sangam in April 2011. It was summer season and there was less water in the river as you can see in the picture below. The water was about 2 to 3 feet in the river. However
column2: this was an advantage as we could walk into the river without any fear.

column1: It was a Sunday and there were around 500 people in Sangam. As there was a good crowd
column2: we did not fear about the crocodiles.

column1: As there was less water we could fearlessly get into the water. However
column2: in rainy season the river will be full of water. The place becomes suitable for river rafting and other water sports activities.

column1: We saw many people were bathing in the water; we also had a cool bath. It is also believed to be auspicious to have bath in Sangam. The water was flowing very slowly. It was an interesting experience to float in the moving water.
After enjoying the water in Sangam we proceeded towards Mekedatu. We crossed the river and took the bus to Mekedatu on the other side of the river.
Mekedatu is just 4 kms from Sangam. You must cross the river at sangam in order to visit mekedatu. If it is summer
column2: there will be less water (as in the picture above) and you can walk through the river. In other seasons you have to cross the river by boats. As Sangam and Mekedatu are close to each other
column3: both the places have to be combined in one single visit. 'Mekedatu' means 'goat's leap' in Kannada language.

column2: you have two options to go to mekedatu. You can take the old noisy bus or take a walk to mekedatu depending on your physical strength
column3: money and time. Walking will be more enjoyable though
column4: bus will be faster. The bus will take 50 rupees per head. The same bus is shuttling between Sangam and Mekedatu. The frequency depends on the availability of people.

column1: The picture below is the point at Mekedatu where people sell water
column2: lemon drinks and butter milks. The sign board warns you to be careful as this is a “dangerous place”.
you have to climb down few hundred steps through the rocks to reach the actual spot. You have to get down first and then climb up a little to see the river Cauvery.
the river has become narrow and at a point as narrow as only about 20 feet between the two banks. As both the sides are made of strong granite
column3: the water cannot expand further
column4: it has to flow within this short rocky passage.

column2: the width of the river is so less that a goat would jump across
column3: hence the place is named as Mekedatu. (Meke = goat
column4: datu = cross in Kannada). The river runs through a deep narrow gorge.

column1: It is interesting to see that the same river which is more than 150 meters at the confluence (at Sangam) flows within 10 meters width in Mekedatu. The river runs ferociously at this point within the rocky banks.
If you are going from Bangalore
column2: you can visit Trimurthy temple on the way on Bangalore Kanakapura highway.

column1: You can visit Chunchi falls which is on the same route on a diversion 10 kms before sangama.
If you are planning for Chunchi falls then you may ignore TK falls which also come on the same Bangalore-Kanakapura highway. Chunchi falls will have more water and thrills than TK falls.

column2: just 4 kms by walk or bus from Sangam. Mekedatu and Sangama are twin locations and must be combined in the visit.
Bheemeshwari and Cauvery fishing camp are also close to Sangam. You can take a try there too.

column1: Drive slow as there are sharp unexpected turnings near Sangam which may cause accidents.
Leave home early and keep enough time in hand to enjoy the twin places.
The place is unbelievably beautiful and much more than my expectation. It can be compared to any national level tourist spot. The place is really worth visiting even in any season.
(Note: This article was first published in JournalSite )

Chunchi falls is about 90 kms from Bangalore city. From Bangalore you have to go to Kanakapura. From Kanakapura you have to go on Sangama/ Mekedatu road. Before about 10 kms from Sangama you will find a signboard for chunchi falls to go towards left. After going for about 6 kms on rural road you will find chunchi falls.

Chunchi fall is located on river Arkavati. The waterfall is nestled among the amazing ranges of rocks. You can park your vehicle in the open field there and walk inside the rocky area. The area is definitely risky and you will find some warning sign boards at the entrance.
Initially you will find a straight cut way to walk down for about 300 meters. Then you will find a canal bridge. As you will be eager to see water
column2: you will immediately be excited to see that canal water and bridge in the jungle. But have patience to walk further there is much more to see ahead.

column1: Then gradually there will be no demarcated route to walk. You will land up in a rocky zone
column2: where you can either go nowhere (if you are scared) or you can go anywhere (if you can jump on the rocks). Now you are in the difficult part of trekking.

column1: As there is no visible road
column2: you will have some disadvantages. You may move this side to that side and get exhausted much before you reach the fall. If it is summer and mid day
column3: then the place will be extremely hot (because of stones). You should better carry some drinking water with you. The other problem is if you are on a dry day or odd time and there is nobody
column4: then you may feel scared and return back from half way.

column1: There are two solutions; one is to go on a holiday where you can expect some more visitors on the spot. This will help you to trace the route on the rocks. Alternatively take a local from there who will guide you short cut route for a small price (say Rs 20 to 30).
We were lucky to have a local guide who took us straight into the water fall through all kinds of funny zig-zag path. We saw two waterfalls
column2: one smaller while going inside and another bigger at the end. However
column3: the water was less because of summer season. In rainy season
column4: the water is ferocious as people say.

column1: I got down to the water and took bath in the fall. It was extremely risky and thrilling at the same time. Cold water in hot summer was quite enjoyable. But I was afraid of the slippery stones and the depth on the other side.

Overall the experience was exciting in Chunchi falls. The water you see in picture was in extreme summer. There will be much more water in rainy season. The place surrounded by green forests look scary and adventurous. It was a great adventure trip for me and will be for anybody. (Note: This article was first posted in JournalSite )
Veerabhadreshwara temple is on a small hill located on the road side 12 kms from Ramanagaram on Kanakapura road. If you are going from Ramanagaram
column2: you will first see Sabbakere from where a road goes to right side towards Siddheshwara beta. You can leave that road and go straight on Kanakapura road. You will find this temple within one km at the left side of the road. The vehicles can go to the foot of the hill and small vehicles can go up to the hill.

column1: While coming from Ramagaram to Kanakapura you will find a beautiful arch on the left side of the road (right side while coming from Kanakpura to Ramanagaram). You can go through the arch and reach the hill temple within half km.
There are two ways to the hill
column2: one driveway for the vehicles and another steps for the walkers. However
column3: the driveway is not very wide for cars but wide enough for bikes.

column1: Veerabhadra swamy temple is built with beautiful architecture. There is a statue of nandi in front of the temple. You have to climb a few steps for the temple and have darshan of the lord.
The beauty of the temple is that it is built on huge granite stones. Some of the boulders are more than 50 feet high. They look very terrific and magical.
You can see Siddheshwara beta from the Veerabhadra Temple hill top
column2: which looks very tiny from about 4 kms distance. But if you have a zoom binocular or video camera you can see the hill clear with 30x –40x zoom.

column1: If you are going on Ramanagaram - Kanakapura road
column2: don’t forget to give a halt at this place. Even if you are going on Bangalore-Mysore road it is worth driving 15 kms inside to visit this temple.

column1: (This article was first published in journalsite.tk)
If you are going from Bangalore
column2: you can go straight on Mysore highway till Ramanagara. Then go further for 5 Kms more
column3: you will see Janapadaloka at your right. If you are coming from Mysore then you will cross Channapatna and go further till you find it at your left before you reach Ramanagara. If you are going by bus
column4: you can go upto Ramanagara by bus
column5: and then take some local conveyance till Janapadaloka. The signboard of Janapadaloka is quite huge and prominently visible from distance.

column1: There is a ticket counter near the entrance gate. There is plenty of parking place on the highway side. We parked the car there and got the entrance tickets. The tickets were like:

column2: Kids – Rs 5

column1: Camera fees: Rs 100 (if you want to take pictures inside museums)
Video show – Rs 5 (there are specific timings of the show)

column2: Tuesday holiday

column1: The entrance gate is one of the attractions of Janapadaloka. A majestic door adorned with Harige and Trumpets and tall brass Nandidwajas on either side of the pathway enhance the grandeur of the entrance. We were there during July 2011 and there was a workshop for drum beating (Charma Vadya Sibira) was going on during that time.
Lokamatha Mandira is a museum displaying articles of daily use of folk people like cooking vessels
column2: equipments used for farming and animal husbandry and other such rural activities.

column1: Chithra Kuteera"" which reflects different stages of the founder's literary achievements and struggle during the building of Janapada Loka and also houses photographs of different folk art forms of Karnataka.
Loka Mahal"" is a two-storied building where more than 5000 folk artifacts are aesthetically displayed. The artifacts include agricultural
column2: hunting and fishing implements
column3: weapons
column4: ingenious household gadgets
column5: masks
column6: dolls and shadow puppets etc.

column1: A community house called “Doddamane"" built in the traditional rural style. It serve as a place for workshops and seminars. During that period there was a workshop on drum beating and we had an opportunity to see the fantastic drum beating show.
When you go inside you find gardens and a lake (known as Loka Sarobara). Some people say that there was boating facility in the lake
column2: but we did not see any boat there. We saw an attractive logo board of Janapadaloka made in the lawn.
there are some interesting cottages. They are just empty and don’t seem to be used for any purpose. However
column3: they look pretty attractive like tribal cottages.

column1: There are various other things to see in the campus
column2: such as
column3: art gallery
column4: amphitheatre
column5: playground for children
column6: gardens and statues etc. There was also a canteen inside the campus. We enjoyed some tea and snacks in the canteen
column7: although the items were highly overpriced than outside.

column1: The most attractive item for us was drum-beating event. A group of 20 participants were demonstrating their drum beating with various styles and dances. We took a full video of their drum beating and enjoyed for long time.
Drinking water and toilets are available inside Janapadaloka. I did not see certain things which I was expecting
column2: but I saw many more things which I had never expected. It is a must go for people traveling frequently between Bangalore and Mysore.

column1: We visited this place after visiting Ramadevara beta and Siddheswhar beta as all these are close to Ramanagara. If you are combining more than one place in your tour you should start early to give enough time to each of the place. (Read this article on JournalSite at http://journalsite.tk/journalsite/articles/viewarticle.asp?articleid=216)

Sri Revana Siddeshwara Betta is about 65 km from Bangalore. You have to go straight on Mysore road till Ramanagaram. From Ramanagaram take left turn towards Kanakpura. Siddheswar Beta is 13 km from Ramanagaram situated near Avverahalli along Ramanagara-Kanakapura Road. The road is motorable and good.

Route of Bangalore to Sri Revana Siddeshwara Betta: Bangalore–(take Mysore Road)–12 km–>Kengeri–18 km–>Bidadi–20 km–>Ramanagaram–take left turn towards kanakapura ->13 km–>Sri Revana Siddeshwara Betta

Rebena Siddheshwar beta is famous for Siddheshwar temple. It is also popular among the trekkers and rock climbers. It is better to visit this place in winter as you may feel very tiring to climb hills in summer. We went there during August 2011.
There are totally 3 temples in the hill complex– at the top is Revanna Siddeshwara temple
column2: midway is Bheemeshwari (named after the pandava Bheema) and Renukamba temple at the base. We first went to Renukamba temple which is at the foot of the hill.

column1: After visiting Renukamba temple one has to go up to the hill. The hill is made of huge granite stones
column2: very attractive to look. If you have a vehicle you can ride up
column3: otherwise you can take the steps.

column1: Behind me (above) is the huge stone hill. The left side road is for vehicles
column2: the right side steps are for pedestrians. While going on this road we saw the temple chariot.

column1: This temple is famous in Karnataka and visited by devotees from all over Karnataka
column2: The hill is more than 3000 feet above the sea level. The main Idol is in the cave temple on the hill. The place has rich history linked with the Gangas
column3: Kempegowda and Tipu Sultan.

column1: This is the Siddheswhar temple on the top of the hill. The outside views from this hill are very attractive. It is worth visiting the place.
Ramgad or Ramadevara Beta is also near Ramanagara. If you start early you can plan to combine visiting Siddheshwar beta with Ramadevara beta.
Ramanagara is famous for its silk market
column2: one of the biggest silk market in India
column3: known as Silk town.

column1: Kengal hanumantharaaya temple is nearest visiting place in ramanagara City. One may have food in Lokaruchi (Kamat group) and visit Janapada loka just next to Kamat Lokaruchi.
We checked into the Chandra Palace Hotel (not as fancy as it sounds) around 8:00 a.m. on the 8th. Although the room was pretty big and fairly nice
column2: we were informed that whoever had told us the price per night was misinformed
column3: and the already overpriced room was actually more expensive than we'd been told. The staff there was also rather cranky
column4: so we decided to stay one night then move to a much cheaper
column5: though slightly smaller and grungier
column6: place the next day. Unfortunately we realized that Mysore isn't the best place for tourist lodging
column7: in that most hotels are filthy
column8: overpriced
column9: loud
column10: and smell like smoke. We managed fine
column11: though.

column2: we spent our first afternoon in the city touring Mysore's trademark Maharaja's Palace
column3: once home to the 24th Wadiyar raja. The palace was very beautiful with brightly painted ceilings and columns
column4: as well as amazing hand carved wooden doors. However
column5: its upkeep and preservation appeared to be lacking
column6: which was unfortunate considering its intricate craftmanship. We were required to take our shoes off to enter the palace
column7: and
column8: since the floor had obviously not been cleaned in quite awhile (if ever)
column9: this was

column2: similar to when we visited the museum in Mumbai
column3: all of the Indian tourists were pushing and shoving to get ahead of one another
column4: making the pathway through the palace rather cramped. One interesting thing we noticed (and have continued to notice since) is the way security is handled in India. There were security guards at the palace ""checking"" people's bags - basically by simply glancing inside them with little to no rummaging around - and there were metal detectors that everyone chose to walk through despite the fact that the guards supposedly operating them were off in the corner smoking cigarettes. The metal detector beeped every five seconds
column5: hopefully from people's jewelry
column6: belts
column7: etc.
column8: but the guards paid no mind. You could easily smuggle something inside and no one would even know. On the contrary
column9: when we visited a fancy bookstore in the city
column10: we had to leave our bags at the door
column11: get searched and go through a metal detector that actually had a guard on duty. Apparently shoplifting is a bigger concern in Mysore than someone blowing up the palace. But who am I to judge?

column1: Our second day began with lunch at
a great little place we found in KR Circle
column2: one of the main eating/shopping areas in town. A nice British couple sat down at our table (it's pretty common for strangers to share tables in India when a place is busy
column3: and so far it's been a great way for us to meet and talk to people!) so we spent a good hour or so talking to them before going our separate ways. Afterward
column4: we bought some famous Mysore pak from the well known Guru Sweet Shop across the street. This delicious melt-in-your-mouth treat has a similar consistency to sugar cookie dough
column5: and I'm pretty sure its main ingredients are pure butter and sugar... a few bites and you're good to go
column6: but Scott and I overindulged a few times. Then we stopped by the market and bought the tiniest and best bananas I've ever had in my life. Yum!

column1: Our next destination was the government operated Cauvery's Arts and Crafts Emporium. These emporiums are scattered throughout India and sell a variety of the region's handicrafts at a (supposedly) reasonable price. We browsed through the silk products
column2: jewelry
column3: paintings
column4: incense and sandalwood carvings. We wanted to buy a sandalwood

column2: but they were way too expensive
column3: so we bought two paintings which had been painted on leaves - very cool - some incense and some sandalwood soap. While we were there
column4: we ran into an American man whose daughter graduated from Clemson and talked to him for a bit. Then we went to the bus station and took a public bus to Chamundi Hill
column5: which was probably the scariest bus ride of my life. Apparently it's perfectly fine to speed around blind curves while going up a mountain past other buses that are coming down. Oh
column6: and you can pass cars on curves. In a giant bus. On a mountain. We almost died. Anyways...when we got there
column7: alive
column8: thankfully
column9: we toured the 12th century temple
column10: which was impressive on the outside
column11: but a bit underwhelming overall. There was a shrine inside containing a solid gold statue of a god
column12: but we weren't allowed to get close enough to get a good view of it. The most interesting thing we saw were several extremely fat
column13: presumably pregnant monkeys hanging around the temple. Since it was a hazy day and the view wasn't wonderful
column14: we began our descent via the 1

column1: something steps down. (There was no way we were taking another bus!) At the bottom
column2: we looked around for a rickshaw to take back to our hotel. Unsure of how much to pay for one
column3: we approached a police officer who was sitting in his car nearby. He was very friendly and helpful
column4: asked us a lot of questions about ourselves
column5: and ultimately got us what we think was a really good deal for a rickshaw without us having to haggle.

column2: neither of us were feeling very well and we'd already seen most of the sights
column3: so we decided to have a lazy day relaxing. This consisted of Scott napping while I did all of our laundry in a bucket in the bathroom then hung it to dry on the huge spider web of a clothesline I constructed in our room with some rope we'd brought. Very relaxing. The following day we were off on the night train to Kochi
column4: located south of Mysore in the state of Kerala.

column1: Interesting fact: apparently (and quite unfortunately) we barely missed a harvest festival in Mysore where they paint all the cows yellow and their horns various colors
then make them jump over fire. I was wondering why it looked like someone had taken a highlighter to all the cows...

column2: Displayed: 18

column1: Bijapur est une ville plus grande
column2: approx. 200 000 habitants
column3: en majorité musulmans. On a eu une belle surprise en découvrant une ville assez calme (sauf la Station Road évidement)
column4: avec des habitants très accueillants
column5: ouverts
column6: sociables et souriants. On est arrives dimanche alors on s'est précipites aller voir le marche. Quelle fête! Des femmes d'une ethnie très spéciale
column7: qui habitent un village a 15 km de Bijapur
column8: viennent vendre leur produits au marche. On n'osait pas les prendre en photos mais elles sont très gentilles et se laissent prendre en photo sans problème. D'ailleurs la majorité des gens au marche nous demandaient de prendre des photos d'eux. La joie quoi! On a profite au max et on se sentait comme des enfants fou. On a fait plein de photos.

column1: Les autres jours nous avons visite les attraits historico-artistiques: des mausolées des sultans musulmans du XVI- XVII s
column2: des vieilles mosquées. On s'est même balade en tonga
column3: petite charrette sur 2 roues tirée par un cheval. Nous avons passe 3 jours paisibles dans une grande chambre d'un hôtel très sympathique avec jardin au palmiers ou il faisait bon prendre son souper (resto végétarien sans alcool)Nous avons eu d'ailleurs assez souvent des

column2: avec sofa
column3: TV écran plat (qu'on utilise pas) et salles de bain énormes. Des fois nous avons eu 3 lits
column4: mais la plupart du temps il y a un lit double et on nous met un matelas pour la 3e personne. Nous avons eu toute sorte de douches
column5: le summum étant une douche ""jacuzzi"" car l'eau jaillissait de partout les tuyaux étant perforés a plusieurs places! Nous n'avons pas tout le temps d'eau chaude mais ça ne nous dérange pas car elle est tiède et avec la chaleur nous n'avons pas besoin de plus.Nous quittons aujourd'hui l'état de Karnataka. Il nous a semble plus propre que Tamil Nadu
column6: avec plus de ville aux trottoirs et moins de dépotoirs. La poussière est aussi présente que dans d'autre état
column7: en dépit du fait qu'il y a beaucoup de verdure
column8: car les routes sont très poussiéreuses. En Tamil Nadu le portrait de la première ministre était omniprésent (au point de la nausée) mais au Karnataka nous n'avons jamais vu de portrait politique et nous ne connaissons pas du tout le visage du premier ministre. J'ai lu dans un journal que cet état est très discret et je peux dire que

column1: Though it saddens me to begin this post on a negative note
column2: I must say that the process of getting from Gokarna to Hampi was nothing less than a nightmare. After about a 45 minute ride
column3: we arrived at the bus stop in Ankola around 8:00 p.m. via a public bus from Gokarna. Just to be on the safe side
column4: we’d gotten there quite early (3 hours early
column5: to be exact)
column6: so we had some time to kill. We read our books and eventually got some dinner
column7: but as 11:00 p.m. rolled around
column8: our bus was nowhere to be found. The staff working at the bus stop withheld whatever information they had about our bus’s whereabouts
column9: but occasionally we overheard talk about either an accident or a breakdown… In any case
column10: we waited for a total of 6 hours before a bus – which wasn’t even the bus we paid for – showed up at 2:00 a.m. Since everything else was full when we booked our tickets
column11: we’d paid 2
column12: 000 rupees for an A/C sleeper
column13: but we ended up having to cram into a seater bus with several other disgruntled travelers
column14: one of whom snored loudly and had frequent night terrors.

column1: We assumed we would get our money back
column2: but when we contacted the company they said the most we could get back was 200 rupees
column3: since supposedly the bus that was sent for us cost 900 rupees apiece (the fact that this was not the bus we paid for or that it was 3 hours late didn’t seem to factor into this wonderful customer service…). In the end
column4: we decided to cut our losses
column5: move on
column6: and enjoy our time in Hampi.

column1: We pulled into the ancient town around 8:00 a.m. and were immediately greeted by at least a dozen rickshaw drivers who were so eager to take us one place or another that they literally blocked the door to the bus
column2: preventing us from exiting without being squished like sardines. When we finally broke down and told them where we were staying
column3: we got one strangely low offer after another – one guy even said he would drive us for free. This is when we realized we were within about a two minute’s walking distance from our guesthouse
column4: and these guys were just trying to get in our good graces so we would allow one of them to

column1: act as our tour guide and drive us around all day for a pretty penny. After we wised up
column2: we began walking and were astonished (and annoyed) to find the rickshaw drivers had not yet given up and were driving alongside us
column3: still shouting out offers. It was rather stifling and overwhelming
column4: especially after barely getting any sleep
column5: but they eventually left us alone and we were able to find our guesthouse
column6: where we immediately passed out for 3 hours.

column2: we decided to explore some of Hampi’s ruins near our guesthouse to get a feel for the ancient city. A bit of info about Hampi: imagine a surreal landscape of giant boulders balanced delicately but sturdily atop one another for miles in every direction. This wondrous natural landscape was once home to Vijayanagar
column3: the ancient “City of Victory” whose ruins surround the winding River Tungabhadra. This popular tourist destination for Indians and Westerners alike used to be a thriving Hindu kingdom
column4: but was attacked and ultimately defeated by Muslim invaders in 1565
column5: leaving only what are now the ruins of Hampi
column6: which
column7: due to weather and a lack of proper preservation
column8: are in danger of

column1: continuous erosion and destruction. For now
column2: however
column3: the ruins are a marvelous spectacle – definitely worth even the most horrible of bus rides to see.

column1: Being in Hampi feels like being in another era or world. One can view ruins of impressive buildings and temples
column2: as well as giant sculptures of Hindu gods
column3: and there is even evidence of an ancient
column4: sophisticated irrigation system
column5: which is still used today to feed the city’s banana farms. On our second day there
column6: we rented an old automatic motorcycle (whose condition was questionable) so that we could cover more ground. We began at the Archaeological Museum – not terribly interesting
column7: but it did have a good model of all the ruins
column8: helping to put our surroundings into perspective. We then continued to the remnants of the Royal Enclosure
column9: where we wandered around for a long time. There
column10: we were surrounded by school children on field trips who were fascinated by us
column11: wanting to know our names
column12: where we were from and if we’d take pictures of/with them. I’m pretty sure they were more interested in our digital camera than they were in us…but they were seriously adorable.

column1: we passed a teenage boy selling postcards. As we got closer
column2: I noticed that he had cerebral palsy or a similar condition
column3: but I also noticed his wide
column4: happy smile
column5: bright eyes and mop of shaggy hair. I couldn’t help but go over and talk to him. As I browsed his merchandise
column6: he answered our questions about Hampi
column7: and we talked for a bit. He was happy to talk with us
column8: asking us about America and giving us directions to the various ruins we wanted to see. I gave him 20 rupees
column9: as well as (to his surprise and delight) our last
column10: crumpled American dollar
column11: and left with a postcard and a lasting impression caused by a kindhearted boy with a big
column12: beautiful smile.

column1: Our next stop was Vitthala Temple
column2: where we ran into
column3: by chance
column4: our German cabin mate from our train ride to Arambol. That night
column5: we went back to our guesthouse to shower and get ready for bed
column6: but as soon as Scott went into the bathroom
column7: he saw a rat on the windowsill! It seemed even more surprised to see us as we were to see it
column8: and
column9: in its attempt to run away
column10: it

column1: fell into the toilet and began flailing about. For a rat
column2: it was actually quite cute (I think it was a baby)
column3: and I felt bad for the poor thing – I knew when we asked the owner to come remove it
column4: it would end up as dinner for some lucky stray cat outside…which is precisely what happened. Sadness.

column1: Our last day was spent checking out the nearby and impressive (and still in use) Virupaksha Temple
column2: where we got to watch the temple elephant
column3: Lakshmi
column4: get “made up” for the day with colorful
column5: chalky powder applied in religious Hindu designs. We were also surrounded by lots of loud
column6: rambunctious monkeys
column7: which was our cue to leave. Afterwards
column8: we walked to some nearby ruins
column9: got some lunch
column10: and sat in a café reading until it was time to catch a local bus to Hospet where our sleeper bus would (hopefully) pick us up. We made it
column11: bought some snacks
column12: and hopped on our bus at 8:30 p.m. Aside from some brief motion sickness
column13: a lack of bathroom stops (I had the lovely opportunity to relieve myself on the side of the road at 2:45 a.m. …)
column14: and my i-pod dying

column1: the ride was smooth and comfortable
column2: and we arrived safely to Mysore
column3: our next destination.

column1: (I wrote this weeks ago and have been meaning to edit it before posting it. However
column2: I have giving in to the fact that I probably won't find the time to do this. So hear it is in the raw...)

column1: This weekend we went to Mysor
column2: about 5 hours drive from Shanti Bhavan. Much more open than other India cities and towns
column3: the atmosphere felt a bit slowing and more relaxing. Though cars still packed the streets
column4: the wideness of the main streets made the traffic less daunting. A weekend away in a lovely city
column5: with lovely people
column6: eating delicious food and seeing interesting sites: It was a good weekend.

column2: the home of the Maharaja built during British rule. Architecturally the palace was stunning and interesting. Mixing Hindu and Gothic styles it is a building unlike any I have seen. Despite the beauty
column3: I was revisited by this now familiar feeling of discomfort I experience whenever I see such extravagance. When our tour guide told us how many pounds of gold was used to make the Maharaja’s throne
column4: or when he pointed out the ivory inlaid doors
column5: I think he

column1: meant to impress. I just felt sick.

I was interested to learn that most of the palace came from elsewhere. Stained glass from Scotland. Tiles from England. Chandelier from Belgium. Stone from somewhere. Brass from somewhere else. I don’t know why this surprises me. Foreign treasures are a sign of wealth
column2: after all.

column1: Much more I enjoyed going to Devaraja Market
column2: a riot of colors and an scream of smells. Bright powdered pigment. Fruits and vegetables. Spices. Fragrant oils. Persistent shopkeepers asking me where I was from in order to coax me into a purchase. Though I am not good at haggling nor do I ever care to become practiced in the art
column3: I am glad to have found myself in the middle of such a vibrant and bustling and beautiful mess.

column1: That evening we had intended to visit some gardens
column2: apparently beautiful at night. Unfortunately
column3: due to a water dispute
column4: the gardens were closed for the weekend. Instead
column5: we went to temple on top of Chamundi Hill. It was beautiful. Overlooking
column6: the city at sunset I felt I could breathe. The sky was soft
column7: a swirl of purples and pinks. I was visited by another now

column2: thought this one more pleasant. A feeling of that the world is simultaneously incomprehensibly small and unfathomably huge. When I look at the sky
column3: I feel at home. I am reminded that we all share the blue above us and the earth below. Although I am far from home
column4: it is still the same air and same rock. But big. So
column5: so big. So many steps. So much of this rock I have not
column6: and will not
column7: see. So much air between my lungs and yours.

column1: The morning we went to a nature park. More lovely open air to breath. More beautiful things to see. We took a paddle boat ride in a lovely pond
column2: that I afterwards learned is home to crocodiles. I saw peacocks and other birds of which I still do not know the name.

we left Mysor for a small Tibetan village that somehow found itself in Southwest India. The monastery was peaceful. Winding paths through open space. The temples had vaulting ceilings in which the sound of chimes clung to the air. While I appreciated the tranquility of the place I am still baffled and a bit disturbed by

column1: the need for building-tall golden statues.
In my wanderings around the compound
column2: I say many of the young monks. How strange it would be to grow up in a monastery. I suppose not much different than living in Shanti Bhavan. Away from family
column3: living in dormitories
column4: little time unscheduled or alone.

column2: we had gobi Manchurian at every lunch and dinner this weekend
column3: and I am still not tired of it)

column1: all weekend. I don’t want that feeling to go away.
The drive back was longer than our trip to Mysor
column2: as the Tibetan village was an hour outside of the city in the opposite direction from the school. We pasted the time playing games and chatting
column3: but eventually our conversation would give way to silence as we watched the nightscape zoom past. As the hour grew later
column4: traffic increased. For the first time since being in India
column5: I saw accidents. It was horrible. A man on the side of the road surrounded by a cluster of helping hands. Later
column6: we saw another crowd of people. A bloody man leaning against a knelling figure waiting as another called for help. And then later
column7: a man prostrate on the road a friend or stranger talking to him a motorcycle yards away. I am grateful that every accident we saw was met with by a crowd of good Samaritans. But I ache to think of how long it probably took for medical help to arrive. As I tried to push thoughts of the men’s families from my head
column8: I thought of my own. The distance between us felt larger than it ever

column1: has. Met by the sudden shock and sadness of an accident
column2: all I wanted was to be home. My desire to keep moving was replaced by a longing to be still and to be with the people I love.

column1: Such a hard thing to balance
column2: the desire for new and exciting
column3: and the need for the familiar and beloved. I wrote in a poem
column4: “Sometimes it feels like wings used to be there or will be there. Sometimes it feels like my feet extend into the ground
column5: roots weaving their way deep
column6: to the source of something. Is the answer above or below. Above of below? Below of above?”

Our journey from Arambol to Gokarna
column2: a sacred seaside town in the state of Karnataka
column3: directly below Goa on India’s west coast
column4: began with a train ride from Pernhem station to Margao. When we arrived in Margao a few hours later
column5: we bought tickets for the “express” train to Gokarna. This train would supposedly arrive sooner and get us to Gokarna faster than the normal train
column6: but
column7: as it turned out
column8: the slower train was on time and left on time
column9: while our train was an hour and a half late! Once we were finally on the train
column10: we had to search for empty seats
column11: as it was rather crowded
column12: and we ended up sitting in one of the last cars alongside a group of beggar children and an elderly man who appeared to be with them. One of the children was a toddler and was sitting barefoot and naked on the floor
column13: occasionally picking up trash and putting it in his mouth with no supervision. Each of the older children asked us and the other passengers for money multiple times
column14: but they made such a ruckus by yelling loudly and running back and forth from car to car
column15: climbing all

column1: The walk from town to the beach
over the seats (and sometimes over people)
column2: that we eventually became irritated by them.
while I did sympathize with these children
column3: I instinctively
column4: perhaps without good reason
column5: felt the need to keep a close eye on my things for fear that they might try to swipe something. I could probably attribute this fear to books I’ve read and movies I’ve seen that portray street children in a negative light
column6: but
column7: unfortunately
column8: I’ve learned that in India it can be a reasonable concern. Ultimately
column9: everything was fine
column10: and
column11: as we stepped off the train at the Gokarna station
column12: the children leaned out the windows waving and yelling goodbye to us.

column1: We took a rickshaw into town around 4:30 p.m. and were dropped off at our guesthouse
column2: the Haripriya Residency. Our host came out to greet us immediately
column3: showing us to our incredibly spacious and clean room and then serving us masala chai in her living room. The couple who own the guesthouse built it as their own and later added several rooms. We sat and talked with her awhile about her family and the town
column4: and she happily gave us advice for sightseeing as well

column1: This lizard loved to pose for the camera!
as recommendations for dinner. Then we set out to explore a bit.
We were happy to find that Gokarna is far less touristy than Arambol. Though its main street is dotted with souvenir shops
column2: it actually felt like an Indian town where not everyone is in the tourist business. Gokarna is considered a very sacred site
column3: attracting pilgrims from all over India who want to dip their feet into the sea’s holy water. We quickly discovered
column4: however
column5: that the holy beach is not really a good place to hang out or swim because it is littered with trash and cow pies. This seemed quite strange to us
column6: since the other beaches in the town are very clean and beautiful. We’ve come to realize during our time in India that littering is widely practiced and accepted – it’s simply part of the culture. Unlike Americans who are raised on the notion that littering is unacceptable and bad for the earth
column7: Indians as a whole devote little time
column8: money or energy toward protecting the environment
column9: perhaps because that’s how they were raised and how it’s always been
column10: or perhaps because they have more immediate issues to concern themselves with. Either way

column1: Our first glimpse of the beach
though I find it difficult not to cringe when I see someone throw a plastic bottle on the ground when there’s a trash can right next to them
column2: I have to remind myself that this culture I have chosen to immerse myself in is beautiful in as many ways as it differs from my own.

column1: Another cultural difference between India and America is it’s view and treatment of cows as holy creatures. They are not killed or eaten
column2: but are left alone to roam freely throughout the towns
column3: or even on the beaches if they like. You definitely have to watch where you step
column4: no matter where you happen to be walking! It’s a bit sad
column5: however
column6: because
column7: since the cows are sacred and believed to be cared for and protected by the gods
column8: no one feeds or takes care of them; therefore
column9: there are a good many very thin
column10: unhealthy cows roaming about eating trash or whatever they can find. While in Gokarna
column11: we actually witnessed a cow fight
column12: which I had never seen before. Interestingly
column13: to break up the fight between these sacred animals
column14: the townspeople began beating them with sticks. I suppose their intentions were in

column2: but it was somewhat difficult to watch.

we spent one full day exploring nearby Kudlee Beach and Om Beach. We followed the trail from the town and reached the first beach in about half an hour. We then walked along the water until we reached the trail that led to Om Beach (which is actually shaped like an Om symbol). It was nice to find this beach to be far less crowded and touristy than Arambol. Additionally
column3: there was a similar number of Indian visitors as westerners

column5: we did see the occasional westerner sporting a thong

column8: but I can assure you that this practice of men strolling about in their skivvies is
column9: well
column10: simply not okay.
