column1: There is not really much to say about the 1st and 2nd of February except that we are all really sad to have come to the end of this fantastic experience. We have been back in Mangalore
column2: definitely my favourite place in India. We flew to Mumbai to get our flight to Heathrow and have noticed the biggest slum I have ever seen directly beside the runway in Mumbai
column3: covering three sides of the airport perimeter. We didn’t see anything like this in Karnataka. We can see kids playing cricket
column4: houses stacked on top of each other
column5: yet most of them have satellite dishes
column6: and I’m wondering how they ever have any privacy or ever protect their belongings? As our flight is delayed by two hours
column7: due to a technical fault
column8: and we are more than likely to miss our connecting flight to Manchester
column9: now that we have take full advantage of the British Airways hospitality
column10: I suppose it would be a good time to sum up my month in Karnataka…..

column1: I have been making notes throughout the month about the things that have surprised or intrigued me the most about India. I say India loosely as I am now well aware that South India is so different to North India. We have only discovered one very small part of India and maybe one day I can visit the North to find out the differences in culture. So
column2: in no particular order
column3: these are my thoughts:

column1: Even before I arrived in India
column2: I had read about IST. It’s know as Indian Standard Time (Like GMT) but widely known as Indian Stretchable Time. The Indian’s themselves will admit that they have no real concept of time and if they say they will be there at 8am it will be 9am before they arrive. It gives the country a relaxed feel but it’s hard for us British to adapt. At home
column3: I’m very punctual and always like to be early for appointments. By the end of the trip I have adapted and when somebody says ‘be ready for breakfast at 8am’
column4: I take at least an extra 20 minutes to wash and dry my hair and put some make up on. Even then
column5: in some homes I have time for a tour and a look at the photo albums before breakfast is served!

column1: I have mentioned the traffic and driving skills a few times in the blog already and Emily has also added a whole post dedicated to the transport here. I don’t know what else to say except it has to be seen to be believed! I tried to take a few videos but even they don’t capture the bedlam of the road system. I can’t see any logic except ‘only the strong and brave survive’! At home we wait to get onto a roundabout. Here
column2: we all pile onto the roundabout and then toot at each other to get off the roundabout. Our driver Nagaraj is great and the only time we have felt a bit worried was when we say other vehicles heading straight towards us on a bend. Although they drive on the same side of the road as us
column3: I challenge any British person to drive here. Good luck! It will take a very brave person!

column2: I’m quite ashamed to admit that I was not really familiar with the various religions which I would come across. Between us
column3: we stayed with Hindu
column4: Muslim and Christian families during our month in Karnataka. We also visited various churches and Hindu and Jain temples. We could regularly hear the prayers and chanting coming from Muslim mosques. We commented on the final day that we couldn’t capture this sound to let others experience it. Anybody who has been to Turkey will to doubt be familiar with it. Having spent a month here
column5: asking endless questions and watching the various different styles of worship
column6: I can admit that although I have learned a lot
column7: I will never fully understand these religions. They are complex and fascinating and having 30
column8: 000 Hindu idols is something I can’t get my head around. I don’t know how the Indian people get their head around this. What I did like was their passion and dedication. Their beliefs are admirable and I am almost feel that I am missing out by not having such beliefs. Personally
column9: I am not religious. I have never been christened and I never plan to get married in a Church. The majority of my friends are the same. It’s very hard for Indian people to understand this. One woman actually told me that I had lost my faith and I need to learn to believe again. At the time I was quite upset by this. It is a surprise for people here to learn that the majority of people in the UK don’t go to Church every Sunday. One nice aspect of the religion here was that we all got involved in the Hindu style of worship. All of the Hindu families I stayed with had a pooja room
column10: or at least a visible shine which they worship every day. In one home
column11: the wife hit a very large symbol in the early morning and late at night while the husband carried out the candle lighting and praying rituals. When they asked me to join in
column12: they were surprised that I knew what to do with the holy water and the candle. However
column13: as I was almost at the end of the trip
column14: it would have been impossible for me not to know what to do when they asked me to get involved ion their prayers.

column1: I don’t think I will ever get used to seeing men being so affectionate to each other. During my time here
column2: I have not seen any two Indian women holding hands or even being truly affectionate to each other (although I regularly hug the women). At least three times I day I have seen Indian men
column3: from young boys to middle aged men holding hands as they walk down the beach
column4: chat at a Rotary meeting or walk down a busy street. It is completely normal here and is by no means a sign of their sexuality. I picked up a copy of a weekly magazine here and read a sex survey which was quite revealing and openly states that homosexuality is still completely frowned upon in India. Yet
column5: if we saw this kind of hand holding at home we would automatically assume that these people were gay. There is nothing at all wrong with this practice
column6: yet it does seem so unfamiliar to us. Only in Ibiza have I seen anything similar! I asked one of my hosts about how common it was for young heterosexual couples to hold hands or show each other affection (I had seen it at the mall and was shocked) and he said that although youngsters were doing it
column7: it was not readily accepted in India.

column1: I had never expected that when I came to India that I would be classed as a minority. I think that I expected to be going to areas where they receive a lot of international tourists and are used to seeing white faces. However
column2: on more than one occasion we were stared at
column3: laughed at and asked for photos. To start with
column4: we obliged
column5: particularly for the under tens. However
column6: when it was day 20 and grown adults were pointing at us and making us stand for photo after photo
column7: it got to a point where we were fed up. Even in a temple
column8: we were approached about five times to have photos taken. It made our visits less enjoyable but more than anything it made us realise that this is perhaps how minorities feel in our own country. In the UK we are becoming much more tolerant. However
column9: in the North
column10: particularly Cumbria
column11: it is rare to see a face which is not White British. Although most people are accepting of another colour or race
column12: a minority of uneducated people are still very racist.

column1: <strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">Superficial things versus family values
Most of the hosts we have lived with had lovely homes
column2: beautiful silks and a nice lifestyle. However
column3: superficial things in India don’t seem to be so important. At home
column4: people take credit to furnish their homes with beautiful furniture and go on nice holidays. Something we learned from the families here is that money should be saved for the future
column5: even if it’s just a little each month. The most important things in life are health
column6: education
column7: family and happiness. I think all Westerners could learn a lesson from this.

column1: One of the first things that we were told when we arrived in Indi is that the ‘Guest is God’ and Indian people look after their guests well. I can’t dispute this fact and I can honestly say that I have never received such hospitality before. We were looked after
column2: cared for
column3: and more importantly
column4: welcomed into the family and made to feel like an old friend. I only hope that the hosts in the UK can live up to this when they welcome the Indian GSE team. It wasn’t just in the home though as every person we came across welcomed us and showed a real interest in finding out about us. They happily answered our questions about culture
column5: family and foo. They even made their food a little less spicy to help us along!

column1: Parents and students alike place a lot of emphasis on the importance of education. In many cases
column2: they are paying for private education as the Government run schools are not up to scratch. In every school or university we visited
column3: the students seemed genuinely happy to be there
column4: to be learning and to have opportunities opened up to them. We only stayed with middle class families but from what I could see
column5: this was consistent across the classes. Even the children of the lower classes are now educated ad they have aspirations much higher than their parents. Sadly
column6: I don’t think that education is rated so highly in the UK. Perhaps people take school education for granted as it is free here?

column2: I have to mention manners and the frequency of spitting
column3: burping and going to the toilet in the street. I have lost count of the number of men I have seen going to the toilet in the street. Sadly
column4: I have to say that I also saw a small child squatting in the street in one town. Yes
column5: we see this at home on occasion. But here
column6: it’s as regular as saying hello! Weeing in the street is a huge problem here. In some places the authorities have started to paint idols on the pavements and walls to prevent people going to the toilet there. The real problem is a lack of public facilities. Even those which are available are unhygienic or you have to pay to use them. To us
column7: it’s a small price. To an Indian working on the roadside selling tender coconut
column8: it’s not always possible to pay to go the toilet. When it comes to manners……. At the airport
column9: in shops
column10: at the temple
column11: in restaurants
column12: people are burping
column13: sniffing
column14: snorting. Even when they see us looking at them with shock
column15: they ignore it. People are constantly spitting
column16: including women
column17: yet nobody bats an eyelid!

column1: Can anybody in the UK remember what life was like when they bought their first mobile phone? You had a loud ringtone and you were so pleased to have a phone that you answered it in very public places just so that people knew you had one. That was maybe 15 years ago. That is what life is like in India. At every Rotary meeting we have been at
column2: people keep their phone turned on
column3: it rings loudly
column4: at least once an hour
column5: and they answer it
column6: no matter what they are doing. Many a time we have been presenting and people have sat in the audience
column7: taking loudly on their phone. If their phone isn’t ringing
column8: they are talking to whoever is sitting next to them
column9: again loudly. To us sensible and polite Brits this is complete and utter rudeness. To Indian people this everyday life. Nobody is offended. In fact
column10: nobody cares!

column1: A lot of people said that we had not seen ‘real India’ because we were in a relatively wealthy part of the country. However
column2: as with every place
column3: there are rich people and there are poor people. It was quite shocking at times to see some of the poorer people
column4: particularly the young girls begging near tourist attractions. At times it seemed like the Indian people are quite oblivious to the poverty in their area. However
column5: I imagine that other parts of India see much worse poverty and we would have to travel further afield to see genuine poverty. When we landed in Mumbai on the way home
column6: we thought we had seen poverty when we saw the slum which was right beside the perimeter fence. Then you see that almost every house has a satellite dish!

column2: we have all said that our biggest struggle is not having any control over time
column3: food and schedule. All of us are independent people with full time jobs
column4: mortgages and in some cases family. While we have really enjoyed this trip
column5: it has been hard to answer to other people all of the time. They dictate our activities
column6: they tell us when to take rest
column7: when to each
column8: how much to eat
column9: what activities we will do. The downside of this is that I can’t seem to make my own decisions anymore. On the last day we had a menu put in front of us and I asked Devdas to order my food. I even accidently locked myself in my room and didn’t think I could make it out without help. Not sure how I’m going to cope living alone again!

column1: Explaining our personal circumstances in India has been difficult. None of us
column2: from the four team members
column3: to the team leader
column4: have a traditional set up with a husband and children. All of us are aged over 26 so to the Indians
column5: this is strange. Ideally
column6: we would all be married and have a child
column7: or at least be planning a family. On more than one occasion people have tried to find me a husband
column8: from their son to their cousin to their nephew who lives in London. They also can’t understand that I live alone. Ideally
column9: I should live with my parents (who are divorced)
column10: my unmarried brother and also my married brother and his wife and two children. We would need a very big house! One of my hosts actually told me that under no circumstances would he ever ever let his unmarried daughter live alone
column11: let alone 30 miles from the family home. I have to accept his opinion. Maybe one day he can come to the UK and see that I can manage fine alone
column12: working full time
column13: managing a house
column14: bills and life alone.

column1: <strong style=""mso-bidi-font-weight: normal;"">Maids and help in the home

Many of families I lived with had a full time live in maid or at least one or two staff who visited daily to clean for them. One woman was amazed to learn that my brother and his wife both work full time
column2: have two children and no maid! ‘How do they cope?’ ‘How do they look after their children?’ ‘How do they find the time to cook and clean?’ I was actually quite shocked by this. At home
column3: couples know what they are taking on when they have a family. They know it will be expensive and they know they have to work. They are grateful for support from their extended family. We couldn’t contemplate having staff
column4: not least because we couldn’t afford it! In India
column5: they can’t imagine life without staff. Yes
column6: the women here work hard looking after their family and preparing meals from scratch. But I challenge them to work full time and then come home to cook and clean and pay bills (And that isn’t even taking into account looking after the children!).

column1: One thing which I found quite hard to witness was the treatment of some women. In India
column2: it is completely normal for wives to run around after their husbands
column3: eat their meals after the rest of the family
column4: and serve food to everybody
column5: even if they are quite capable of helping themselves. In the factories
column6: many en supervised groups of women who were doing hard annual labour. One person actually told us that women were not capable of being supervisors! At home
column7: women are taught to be quite independent
column8: and more and more men now help around the home too
column9: cooking
column10: cleaning
column11: parental responsibilities. Both systems have their pros and cons I’m sure
column12: but I personally prefer ours!

column2: we have been very lucky to have been chosen to be part of this GSE team. People would give anything to have the opportunity and see the things that we have seen. Devdas said that we have seen more in one month than he has seen in his lifetime. It is an experience we will remember forever.
Rekah
column3: Ramkrishna and Nagaraj all waved us away from Managlore airport and both me and Nicola later admitted that we were crying. Nicola because she would miss her hosts Devdas and Rekah and me because I really want to stay. Devdas did say that he would turn a blind eye if I didn’t want to get on the plane. He also said I was more than welcome to stay at his house but I’m sure he would live to regret that!

column1: You can probably tell from the tone of the final blog that I really don’t want to leave. Although I have missed everybody at home
column2: I could easily stay another month or two. Although
column3: I’d like to maybe use some of my vocational skills out here and work with organisations to help them deliver their communications or Corporate Social Responsibility projects. The GSE trip has been a great experience but it’s time to start doing some work before I forget how to!

column1: Rajendra and Janhavi have already phoned me and Nicola to ask us to come back to Belur or to visit their apartment in Bangalore
column2: a place we haven’t been. Other fiends we have made have also asked us to comeback and it’s clear that they are 100%!g(MISSING)enuine and can’t wait to see us all again. The nice thing is that all four of us have had a very individual experience because we lived with different families. We will never run out of things to talk about and we will all stay in touch too. So if I’m not e-mailing or texting the girls
column3: I will be e-mailing
column4: whatsapping or hopefully visiting my friends in India.

column1: Although I was nervous before I came
column2: for many different reasons
column3: I can say that I have had the best time ever and I am so grateful for this experience. If we had visited Karnataka and stayed in hotels it would have been a nice holiday but living with Rotarians and their families has made this experience extra special for every one of us. Yes
column4: it was challenging but it has been worth it
column5: both personally and professionally.

column1: You can expect to see me in India again very very soon! (Maybe not in the monsoon!)

column1: Early morning over the rice paddies.

There's nothing intimate about Indian cities. Surely it's here that that well worn cliche ""assault on the senses"" was spawned. Urban India is where the concept of a billion people in one nation resonates.

The gamy odours of raw filth that overlay the spicy aromas of street cuisine. The incessant rhythmic honking of car horns. Mosque wake up calls (there may only be a 10% Muslim population here but that's still 100 million). Mainlining vegetarian curries. Cows knee deep in street rubbish somehow eking out an alternate food source to grass. It's dank
column2: it's full throttle and maybe it's not the Indian romance of imaginations or from the pages of Rudyard Kipling
column3: but the lurching excitement of Mysore
column4: Bangalore and Hyderabad has left a thousand still-life images entrenched in the memory banks.

column1: No more so than the mayhem of their markets. The atmosphere is pure earth but the colours
column2: noise and smells are brutally left field from Woolworths
column3: Carrefour or Walmart. (Ok
column4: maybe not Walmart).

column1: Far from there being a stampede of tourists
column2: ourselves and the few westerners we stumbled across in these markets would stroll around bug-eyed and rattle off a few frames while the locals gawk

column1: back and wonder what this tourist fuss is all about. We wallow in the good
column2: the bad and the ugly of this otherworldly environment but from a native perspective this is simply their day in day out rota and a struggle to disinfect themselves from a breadline existence. The implication of some of their looks was;
how about we swap"".

column1: You don't need to do too much soul searching to understand their frustration at the inequities. The roles we had fallen into we're primarily an accident of birth.
The most ambitious guy was the bloke with the table full of second hand dentures. I didn't know who to feel most sorry for;
- the vendor himself trying to find customers in the narrow market of used teeth.
- the people who had been forced to sell him their choppers
column2: or

column1: - those who might be actually tempted to purchase a set of fangs that had already spent a deal of time inside someone else's mouth. I assume this group would also need to try quite a few sets before finally settling on the ones with juuuuust the right fit.
As character building as those cities were
column2: only a martyr would visit all three consecutively without trying to shoehorn some recovery time in the midst.
tucked into the middle of Karnataka
column3: has been long esconsed on the hippy tourist trail in India and looked a worthy stop for a few days. We should have made it longer.

column1: Verdant rice paddies are lined by a landscape of hanging boulders that balance like a set of fiddle sticks that cling on through sheer self belief. A creek meanders amongst and the entire region is peppered with Hindu places of worship.
The backpacker demographic holds court here
column2: as if a force field exists to keep large hotel chains and anything else remotely upmarket at arms length from this world heritage area.

with such a majority of shoestring clientele there's no shortage of westerners who have converted to overnight gurus. The guy with the stick-on dreadlock business must be doing pretty well for himself in Hampi.
days could easily turn into weeks in this little oasis about as far removed from the Indian maelstrom as can be

column1: The live version in cages could see these guys 2 metres away.
Anybody out there with an aversion to gutter rhetoric
column2: please tune out now. As for the rest of you ......

column1: It was one of those lower depth days when you search for some self justification for this travelling gig. Caught off guard
column2: India launched a jack-in-the-box attack and went for the jugular.

column1: It's only 150 klms from Wayanad to Mysore but 3 tuk tuks
column2: 2 buses
column3: 5 hours and 20 lineal klms down
column4: the 130 to go may as well have been to the moon given our chances of getting there.

column1: That ubiquitous say it all yet say nothing Indian head wobble had lost all its exotic gloss in the hours of mis-communication;
Bus coming sir. Bus not coming sir. Bus being late sir. Bus being full sir. Please go to other bus station sir"".
The prospect of ""bus not bloody existing sir"" weighed heavily.
Penny wandered off to the public ladies for a touch of aromatic ""eau de India"" whilst I sat on a crumpled iron bench at the bus stop of this dusty frontier town and no escape plan. I needed a

column2: up sauntered a monkey. Totally at ease with his position in the primate pecking order
column3: he sat down 3 metres in front
column4: stared directly into my eyes with a look of teenage disdain and began masturbating
column5: as if he recognised a human hangdog expression and was up for rubbing some salt into wounds.This wasn't the message from above I had anticipated.

column1: (a) Walk over and spoil the guy's romance by swinging my number 11 foot in his general direction
column2: or

column1: (b) Go and buy him a cigarette to help him enjoy his moment of post self-gratification.

column2: it's now official. I don't like monkeys.
you won that round.

column1: After leaving Kerala we travelled to Mysore
column2: Bangalore
column3: Hampi and finally to Hyderabad to conclude our Indian experience ( this time... does that mean we might be back)?

column1: really have enjoyed India this time round despite us both getting sick here on our last few days. I think we jinxed ourselves as I had only just finished bragging to a German couple that; ""we had not been sick all year"". But having fallen ill
column2: Hampi was probably a good place to just watch the world go by for a few days and let the bug do its thing.

column1: So I sat in my hammock
column2: trying not to let it swing in case it made me nauseous and watched and pondered on the new breed of white collar hippies we had encountered along the way to actually see the final transformation in Hampi.

column1: First they arrive sporting their corporate hair cuts
column2: neatly shaven
column3: wearing their designer label clothing and looking every bit the tourist. Within a few days a dreadlock is woven into the short strands of hair
column4: their designer clothes are gradually being swapped for haram pants
column5: Indian shirts and the odd headband. By this stage they have a healthy collection of string wristbands and anklets
column6: and occasionally sporting a red dot in the middle of their forehead. Not long after this
column7: the shoes disappear and

column1: they can handle the rugged dirty garbage ridden streets and lane-ways barefoot. All that is required now is some body piercing to complete the picture.
By the time they reach Hampi
column2: many more dreadlocks have been added
column3: no doubt from the trade-in of their western sandals. They look thinner and more gaunt
column4: ahh but they haven't been sick they claim
column5: they have thrown away knives and forks
column6: they can eat with there hands and eat rice and curry once a day and survive on bananas every other meal.

column2: a place that has a great history
column3: UNESCO sites
column4: the most beautiful rice paddies amongst elephant size boulders. A small stream dividing the very hippie from the up and coming hippie town. The temple elephant comes to the stream each day to be washed by the tourists and to bless them for their efforts. At sunset you can climb any number of boulders to a temple and sit overlooking the town below. This is where the white collar hippies turn pro. In this tranquil setting
column5: ( apart from 50+ westerners) young kids come selling chai
column6: the ""seasoned hippies"" offer tattoo services
column7: and the white colllar

column1: Anengundi. Sleeping baby in a sling.
hippies compare notes on their resent additions
column2: be it makeup
column3: more dreads etc etc.

column1: So where to from here? How long after leaving India
column2: do the dreadlocks get cut off
column3: their feet get scrubbed and the Indian clothes get tossed? I guess I'll check it out at the airport tomorrow.

column2: it’s nearly the end of our fantastic journey around Karnataka. I think I can safely say for most of us that there’s still so much more to see here
column3: we’d like to stay a little longer; some would stay a lot longer.

column2: and are staying a hotel called Blue waters. The hotel is fantastic
column3: very clean
column4: and very beautiful. After we were checked in and shown around we were given a couple of hours to settle in and use the pool etc
column5: needless to say we jumped on the wifi!

column2: myself and Emily decided to go for a walk along the river and found a small boat yard where some men were making boats by stitching them together
column3: sounds strange
column4: and I couldn’t tell what they used to cover any holes but it was pretty impressive. We saw some of the boats on the river later and they were rather good.

column1: Around 4:30pm we were taken on a boat to a small island in the river. We all had a little giggle that the boat man had to bail a bit of water out when we disembarked. I know
there’s been lots of good food here but I didn’t realise we’d put that much weight on! On the other side of the island we could see where the river meets the ocean
column2: and there was lots of little water wildlife to keep me happy
column3: from birds to miniature crabs and flip flop trees!

column1: As the boat left the island for the hotel docking point
column2: we were happily gliding along the river
column3: like a gondola
column4: all sat with our life jackets on
column5: and me
column6: Tracy and Emily wondered how the fishermen reached their boats moored halfway out into the river...then we spotted a man walking near a boat and realise the water didn’t even reach his waist. Felt a bit daft sat there with our life jackets on but better safe than sorry!

column1: In the evening we ate by the pool with Abhi
column2: the hotel owner
column3: and his wife and 2 children. We were served lots of tasty food and they were such good company even though the little one had a cold.

column1: Today Abhi took us to see his Floriculture farm
column2: they grow Orchids
column3: Antheriums
column4: Heliconia
column5: Rubber trees
column6: Areca nuts and have a few lodges in

column2: which would be brilliant for people who love nature
column3: drawing
column4: photography etc... They have made the lodges very rustic and have kept the landscape as natural as possible. The orchids were gorgeous and they gave us each a stem to take
column5: shame it won’t make it home. The rubber trees were quite young and not ready to harvest for another 3 years. There were 2 men painting each tree with lime
column6: this apparently helps keep the tree free of some diseases. I think we know the Heliconia called the bird of paradise plant mostly
column7: but I didn’t realise there are actually over 100 varieties! A lot of their flowers are used in displays in hotels
column8: but mainly they are sent to Goa
column9: as they are in big demand there for festivals
column10: weddings
column11: gifts
column12: offerings
column13: etc.

column1: When we left the Green woods
column2: we visited a Nagar temple
column3: which is a temple that is for the serpent. They feed about 4000 people every month at a festival held there. We learnt that people with skin problems come to the temple and roll on the floor around the idol and believe this will help to cure them.

column1: Must be something connected to the shedding of the snake skin (good theory Emily!)

Back to hotel for lunch and then some of us may hide from the hottest part of the day. We have our final presentation tonight which is the marker for the end of our experience really. As much as I’m looking forward to boring everyone at home with all my stories about the things I have done
column2: the places I’ve seen(I have a LOT of photos!)
column3: the amazing food that I’ve eaten
column4: and the most welcoming
column5: fantastic people I’ve met with every host I’ve been lucky to have
column6: and the people who have taken us everywhere and looked after us every day
column7: I would love to stay longer
column8: but I’ll just have to start saving now so I can come back!

column1: I couldn't be in India for a month and not write a big about the Indian road network!!! The best way to summarise is “expect the unexpected” and we've certainly seen our share of that during the past 4 weeks. From overloaded lorries to scooters with family of four on board we really have seen everything India has to offer. We've seen buses so overloaded with people standing in the aisle it's leaning heavily to one side
column2: rickshaws with fridges hanging out of the back
column3: scooters with water barrels on and many many more crazy sights!

column1: 2 wheelers are much more prevalent here in India and provide many people with affordable transport between towns and villages. Scooters are very popular for women to drive and motorbikes are parked outside most houses. Rickshaws are very common sight across the whole of India
column2: operating as taxis
column3: light goods vehicles and school transport.

column1: Motorways under construction can take years to finish due to disputes over land ownership
column2: which results in many ""diversions"" from the main highway on most routes between towns. A lot of people ignore these signs and stick to the unfinished part of the road anyway and then some people

column1: just drive down the wrong side of the main highway because the route is shorter! Our bus driver Nagaraj has looked after us tremendously well and doesn't take any chances when trying to overtake. He is always paying attention to the road ahead and despite the constant tooting from other drivers
column2: refuses to overtake until the road is completely clear.

column1: Millet thrashing on the main road is another strange practice we have observed on rural roads
column2: where farmers put out in large piles and as the cars drive over the seeds are removed from their shells and the farmers collect these after a few hours. This practice is not recommended by the Government as it can cause damage to vehicles and pollute the crops with diesel.

column1: Lorries here in India are very interesting and painted with very bright colours and interesting warning signs on the bumper! They carry everything from rocks to coffee and lots more! A lot of them are Ashok Leyland brand which have a UK subsidiary company called Optare which has recently shut down it's factory in Blackburn
column2: Lancashire.

column1: Here you will find a few photos collected on our travels and hope you enjoy!!!
Tractor with gigantic load of hay!!!

column2: Displayed: 9

column1: I’m keeping this one short and sweet too as we are on the last leg of the trip and taking a little bit of time to relax and reflect on our time in India.
We have arrived in Kundapur and we are staying in a hotel
column2: Blue Waters
column3: owned by Abhinandan Shetty. Abhi has recognised that we are exhausted so we have a more relaxing itinerary for the next two days. This also gives us a chance to enjoy this beautiful resort
column4: right next to the place where five rivers meet the Arabian Sea
column5: and to catch up on some sleep.

column1: Abhi has taken us on a boat trip to an island where we can see various wildlife
column2: and also to his floriculture farm
column3: his family temple and to his other resort
column4: Green Woods
column5: a secluded hideaway favoured by artists and creative types looking for some tranquillity in noisy and busy India. We were also able to share a nice meal with Abhi and his beautiful wife Neeta
column6: as well as their two children. We got to know Neeta and daughter Ahana better when they took us to the beach too.

column1: Kundapur is also our last presentation to a Rotary club. Staying in this beautiful resort almost makes you forget that you are in India. Then you go to a meeting in a rotary hall with a power cut and you have to present to a noisy audience by candlelight.

Blue Waters is certainly a hidden gem in Kundapur. I have asked Abhi how he markets his resorts and he is working solely on word of mouth. Locals and international guests are flocking here and it’s easy to see why. It really is quite different to anywhere we have stayed in India. I would recommend this place to anybody visiting Karnataka who wants a bit of luxury after staying in traditional £3 a night hotels and lodgings. Ashok
column2: our resident cocktail waiter
column3: the Tom Cruise of India
column4: will make sure you are well looked after
column5: and it’s just £50 a night! You wouldn’t get this at home!

column1: How can we say goodbye to Karnataka? It feels like home!

column2: Displayed: 6

column1: Harish showing us round the farming training centre at Mysore
Providing training to farmers is often referred to as “extension services” and is often done through the same measures such as workshops
column2: seminars and on-farm demonstrations. This is often carried out in India with public funds directly through Government staff
column3: where the project I currently manage

column1: Many people have asked me if there is a need to educate farmers in the UK when we have much higher rate of literacy and general increased level of awareness. Both UK and India need to communicate ideas and new technologies to farmers and it’s not always easy .
After talking with many different agriculturalists here in India I have found many similarities
column2: despite the very different climate and geography. In the UK our average farm size is approx. 50ha which is much larger than India’s 2ha. Even with these differences in scale
column3: I have learnt the farmers are actually similar. I have visited many farms in Karnataka
column4: growing tropical crops we cannot grow in the UK
column5: but the challenges are the same. Farms need to adapt an integrated system to provide a diverse income stream to allow for crops failing
column6: drought or low market prices. This is something Indian farms are much

column1: Members from the Shimogga office who kindly spent nearly 2 hours answering lots of my questions!!!
better at. In the UK all our markets are private and prices change daily
column2: but India certain crops are controlled by Marketing Boards where prices are set for the whole year.

column1: I have learnt a lot about the workings of the Karnataka Milk Federation (KMF)
column2: both in Mangalore and Shimogga and made some very useful contacts who I will definitely keep in touch with. UK farmers are not terribly good at working in cooperation
column3: but I strongly agree with Mhatma Ghandi’s vision “I firmly believe that we shall not derive the full benefits of agriculture until we take to cooperative farming”. Wise words indeed from 1947!!! Farmers can definitely create better market prices by working together
column4: but it will take time.

column1: On another vocational visit in Mangalore I visited the Karnataka State Government Department of Agriculture and I feel the policy structure here in India works much better than the UK. The subsidy programmes for farmers run for 12 months and uses information gained from the Taluks (villages)
column2: which feeds into the regional and state policy. This bottom-up process is much more effective and able to deliver positive results
column3: unlike in the UK where our policy comes down

column2: firstly from the European Union and then national UK Government. This approach makes it hard for UK farmers to understand and accept messages and is one reason why the training and extension services provided through our project – Rural Skills Cumbria - is so important and why I enjoy my job.

column1: In Mysore I visited another Karnakata State Government office
column2: this time an Agricultural Training Centre and learnt how staff work very hard to promote courses to farms
column3: using native language and many posters
column4: so even illiterate people can learn. In the UK farmers are very busy people and leaving the farm for 2 or 3 days is very difficult. Karnataka State Government pays for accommodation
column5: travel and expenses to help encourage attendance and perhaps we can learn from this in the UK.

column1: My last vocational visit took place in Shimogga I visited the University of Agricultural Science
column2: which I found really interesting and made some very useful contacts that I hope we can work on collaborative projects in the future. The meeting consisted of the Dean of Education
column3: Head of Research
column4: Extension Services
column5: Organic Department and Soil Scientists. Some PhD and Masters students were also present and I asked them the question “Will you find agricultural jobs when you graduate?” None of the students plan to use their qualifications for rural jobs
column6: but instead work in IT or Commerce. This was very disappointing for me and I think India and the UK need to encourage youth to stay in rural areas and provide job opportunities which benefit the whole community.

column1: Our official Vocational visits are now over but we are constantly learning from the various Rotarians we meet. A lot of people in India come from agricultural families of some description and have a good knowledge of farming practices. The opportunity to meet so many people connected to my industry has been amazing and I am truly grateful to Rotary for this wonderful opportunity.

column2: Mangalore comference was definitely an experience
column3: in many ways. We were told that over 3000people had registered at the conference when we arrived on friday! Yikes!

column1: As soon as we got off the bus on friday
column2: we were greeted by our old friend Devdas who has bern in touch with us throughout our trip. We arranged to meet at the conference hall that evening then went to unpack
column3: what by now
column4: are rather humongous suitcases!

column1: It was great to see so many faces we recognised.(hello again to Dr.Hari A Shetty and family from Kushalnagar!) It was amazing how many people we recognised. After a lovely catch up and evening of cultural entertainment
column2: we went back to the club for an early night and final preparations!

column1: By saturday I was nervous about the presentation
column2: lot of people watching
column3: tv screens etc... while waiting to go on we were put on the big screen
column4: just as Tracy was taking a nap!lol it rested my nerves so thanks Tracky!

column1: Shouldnt have been worried. Presentation was good
column2: quite enjoyed it. People clapped at my speech
column3: which was lovely (thank you Rekha) I have been fascinated by the bond that families have here
column4: and that they share such fantastic meals and I think we should bring this back in the UK!

column1: After presentation we went for a deserved Lychee bacardi breezer and a bash on the karaoke!
Needless to say it was a late night Saturday and later morning Sunday. We made up for it with breakfast and brunch and an afternoon shopping!
Diane receiving rose at Rotary School funded by Shimogga East Club

column2: especially Wednesday
column3: when we visited seven different places. The morning began with an elephant ride. Our hosts had heard that we hadn't been able to ride an elephant at the Dubare Camp
column4: so kindly added an extra trip to make up for it. Elephants seem very tall from the ground
column5: but once you climb the ladder and are placed on the howdah
column6: it doesn't seem so bad and the animals move so gently
column7: it's almost as if they want to look after you and give you a comfortable ride.

column1: The summer palace was another interesting place to visit
column2: with beautiful carved stone pieces
column3: brought from many places
column4: which were really attractive works of art. Then there was the tiger and lion safari. Again
column5: we had failed to see tigers earlier on our tour
column6: so it was a plus to be able to photograph some now.

column2: though
column3: the best parts of the day were visiting four examples of the kind of projects Rotary clubs in Karnataka have been involved in. First there was a low cost housing initiative
column4: where we saw four houses built with Rotary funding
column5: in order to give rural workers a better

column1: Affordable housing project funded by Rotary

home to live in. We worked out that each one had cost the equivalent of £750 to build. The owners were keen to show us around and to follow us round the village and be photographed with us. It was interesting to see a rural set up.
The next project was a blood bank
column2: which was a new thing for me to see. I learnt a lot there
column3: and now feel much more aware of how blood banks operate. Then there was a Rotary funded school
column4: where we were asked to address a hall full of students
column5: neither for the first nor the last time during our trip. Nicola was cursing me for dropping her into speaking off the cuff to the audience
column6: but I was confident that she could do it well
column7: and she did! Tracy was the one who was speaking when the awkward question came up about how sex education was imparted in Britain. In her usual form
column8: she handled it perfectly. It's a very good team we have here for being able to speak to any audience on any subject which is thrown at them.

column1: The fourth project was a residential school for the severest of mentally challenged people. Apparently these children are so difficult for poor rural parents to handle
column2: that they tie them up all day
column3: while they go to work. The state they are in when the parents return at the end of the day is appalling. The school manages to seek these children out and educate them in the most basic of things
column4: such as cleanliness and toileting. It was a sobering visit for us all
column5: but very good to see how much local Rotary clubs are managing to achieve.

column1: After Shimogga we returned to Mangalore through beautiful countryside. This was the weekend of the District Conference
column2: which had some interesting highlights. K. R. Ravindran from Sri Lanka proved a moving speaker
column3: as he spoke about the importance of having passion in what we do. He talked of pity killing with kindness
column4: whereas passion gives action and hope to people. He also said
column5: quite rightly
column6: that each Rotary district must look at the sort of things that they can focus on and concentrate on that. This has been made very clear to me
column7: as we have travelled around Karnataka. Indian clubs need to focus on very different things to our clubs in Britain. Finally he talked of a sustainable initiative by Danone
column8: the French milk products company. Apparently they have set up a very successful social
column9: philanthropic business in Bangladesh
column10: which now employs 1
column11: 600 people. I need to look further at this.

column1: In the evening there was a choice of karaoke or a presentation of a wide variety of Indian classical dancing. I'll leave our readers to guess who chose which activity
column2: but suffice it to say that we all enjoyed ourselves very much.

column1: It is now time to move on to our final leg of the exchange
column2: which has so far been so eventful.

column1: I’m falling behind with the blog as we are so busy! Other team members have updated our activities from the last few days so I will try to keep this brief.....
We have spent Monday and Tuesday in Karkala where the Rotarians were delighted to meet us all. They had a packed itinerary for us including visiting a church
column2: an artisan centre where we saw some fantastic carving from the students and a museum of old artefacts from the area. My favourite part of the day was the visit to the Rotary hospital where Dr. Asha Hedge works. Although Di has visited a lot of hospitals here
column3: this was my first and it was really interesting to visit a place which specialises in care for women and children. The hospital looked very clean and tidy. I had commented that I had not seen any pregnant women in India
column4: and I got my chance here. Women in India seem to hide their pregnancy well with their sari so it’s hard to tell if somebody is pregnant.

column1: There were many babies in the hospital
column2: sharing a bed with the mother to help them

column1: bond. We also heard a couple of very sad stories of the patients. I was also interested to learn that expectant parents are not allowed to find out the sex of their baby here. This is quite a new system in India and was introduced by the Government to protect female babies
column2: less desired in India as they cost families more through marriage.

column1: Our trip to Karkala also took us to a beautiful waterfall for a picnic
column2: a Jain temple at the top of 200 steps and a traditional festival where communities meet and can have their social problems solved by village witch doctors. It was explained to us that people who have an unfaithful husband or a husband who drinks too much could bring their problems here to have them solved. We did a lot of people watching at the festival and we didn’t see any two ladies with the same sari. The variety and colours of the women’s outfits are amazing!

column1: On our second evening we attended a meeting and a house warming. It was like no house warming you have seen before
column2: with hundreds of people coming along to see the house
column3: share dinner in

column1: a outside canteen and watch the various blessings take place.

column2: I stayed with two different hosts. Ananthakrishna and his wife Raja had a beautiful home
column3: built by their son in 2005. They were very proud of their house
column4: car and four granddaughters. They had to leave to attend a wedding in Banaglore so I spent my second night bunked up with Nicola. Thank you to Dr.Asha and her husband Prakash for taking me in unexpectedly! And for feeding me up on dosas and fruit!

column2: Displayed: 4

column1: As other team members have already mentioned
column2: we had a big audience for our presentation at the District Conference in Mangalore last weekend. Thanks go to Val and Terry Leivers from Nottingham for the picture of us up on stage not looking at all nervous. We have done so many formal and informal (unexpected) presentations now that nothing seems to faze us!

column1: After the long build-up to our conference presentation
column2: it was great to spend an evening winding down
column3: even if it did mean I had to sing in the karaoke bar
column4: which you would never see me doing at home!

column1: We knew we would have the opportunity at the conference to catch up with many of the Rotarians we have spent time with throughout our trip but this time we were saying goodbye for much longer. Having bid so many farewells
column2: it felt quite strange to hop on our bus again and set off to our final two host families. However
column3: we were warmly welcomed in Karkala and immediately started another programme of visits.

column1: Our first visit was to the Rotary hospital
column2: whose main services are for women and children. There is also an ophthalmology department. The

column1: hospital teaches students and is associated with a medical college under Manipal University.

We then visited a Catholic church where preparations were being made for the annual Attur Shrine Festival. Thousands of people travel far and wide on a holy pilgrimage. Non-believers and people of other religions also attend.

Also on our programme for the first day in Karkala was a visit to a theme park. We thought this was a bit strange until we were told that it was actually a museum! The Kotti Chennaya Theme Park depicts the lives of two heroes (Koti and Chennaya) through several pictures and there are 10-feet high statues of them. There are also many interesting features of the local culture displayed.

column2: we saw the skilled work of students at an artisan training centre that is sponsored by Canara Bank. Great talent was evident in their stone and wood carvings
column3: metal work
column4: and terracotta items. Had we not already been struggling with the restrictions on our luggage allowance
column5: I think a few of us may have been tempted to buy a few items!

column2: we were taken to a spiritual festival known as

column1: Karkala - Hanumangundi Falls Kudremukh National Park
bootha kola. We saw the ritual dancers preparing to impersonate a spirit. When viewed in full costume and make-up and seeing them run towards you bearing swords
column2: it is a little unnerving!
we thought we were going on a trek in the kundremukh national park. It turned out to be a relatively short
column3: gentle
column4: walk to the hanumangundi falls
column5: though there were almost 400 steps involved. It was very peaceful and relaxing sitting in the sunshine at the base of the falls
column6: chatting and eating papaya. We almost had to be dragged away from the scenic beauty of the falls and the national park.

column1: As if one climb that day was not enough
column2: we climbed another 200 steps up to a slightly smaller gommateshwara statue late in the afternoon. At 42 feet high
column3: it is the second tallest in Karnataka (the tallest being the one we saw in Shravanbelagola).

column1: An informal Rotary meeting followed and we delivered a short presentation about ourselves and our experiences so far. We were then whisked off to one of the Rotarian’s relative’s housewarming in Moodabidri. It was a bit like an open house where people were welcomed into the home and were able to wander round at their own pace. I am not sure that I could welcome complete strangers into my home! As is customary here
column2: food is always offered. We therefore sat down to a wonderful selection of foods
column3: eating off a banana leaf.

column1: The hospitality everywhere we go is overwhelming and we are always sad to say goodbye to our hosts but we are looking forward to the next
column2: and last
column3: stop of the tour of Karnataka now
column4: which we believe will be somewhat more relaxed (we’ll soon find out if this is the case!).

column2: we will ....rock you!

column1: It’s fair to say that we have been ‘Indianised’. When we first arrived in Mangalore everything was a shock to us. The food
column2: the traffic
column3: the noise and the litter. Now
column4: we are back in the city and everything just feels like home. We don’t notice the noise or the litter anymore
column5: the traffic feels calmer and we can’t wait to eat the Mangalore food and see some of our old friends!

column1: We are back in Mangalore for the district conference. Although we got to relax and meet friends at the venue on Friday night
column2: today was time for serious work as we had to present our experiences to over 3000 people. First though
column3: we were able to listen to the rest of the guests and keynote speakers. Our own presentation went well and we covered what Rotary does in the UK
column4: what we learned on our vocational days as well as our own personal highlights from the trip.

column1: Also at the conference were a couple from Nottingham. They are Rotarians who have spent 10 weeks per year in India for the last six years. They have worked on projects totalling

column2: 000. It was really interesting to share our thoughts on India with them. And great to hear a British accent again! In the evening
column3: after a long day
column4: it was time for a cultural exchange
column5: so while Angie went to watch some dancing
column6: the rest of us showed the Indians some British Culture..........by singing on the karaoke and dancing to Gangnam Style!

column1: Sunday was a chance to relax and perhaps overindulge. So we started the day with two breakfasts
column2: just so that I had a chance to have my favourite food again
column3: banana buns! After an afternoon of shopping for silks
column4: wall hangings and other gifts
column5: my Mangalore host Rupal picked me up to take me to a famous ice cream parlour called Bappas. The Chocolate Dad ice cream I had was fab! I also got a chance to see Dev and Rahul again and they both beat me at board games before we had a KFC. KFC is not like the KFC in the UK
column6: it’s certainly Indianised!

column2: the bakery owner friend of Nicola's has invited Nicola and Emily for dinner and me
column3: Rupal and Punit also go along. Prakash has what I would

column2: Prakash and Punit

column1: call a ‘party room’ in his home with a fantastic bar area which we can enjoy along with Prakash
column2: his wife Keerthi and Devdas and his wife Rekha. We also had some fantastic Indian wine. I might be a convert! The other girls also wanted to try out KFC in India so I made my second trip of the day there. I think it’s time for a serious detox when I get home. The food here has been so amazing that I’m going to find my old diet at home very bland and boring. Luckily I have been given lots of recipes and ideas and I also picked up another cookbook in the mall. So if anybody wants to come round
column3: its hands only
column4: no cutlery!

column2: Displayed: 7

column1: We have said goodbye to our sixth set of hosts today. Jangannadh and Vidya have looked after me very well in Shimoga and Yashas sends us off with a high five. We have a five hour bus journey to Mangalore
column2: along some of the best (or worst?!) roads we have seen. I still can’t believe that people drive on roads like this. There are craters
column3: not potholes
column4: and drivers overtaking on corners. This road has hairpin bends as we go down the side of a huge mountain. It’s all worth it for the views though! We are back in Mangalore for the district conference where we will be presenting to over 3000 people. Good job we have had lots of practice on this trip. And we don’t want to rub it in
column5: but it is 35 degrees here in Mangalore. Enjoy the snow!

column2: Displayed: 2

column1: I think we have all learned to expect the unexpected on this trip but my vocational visit to a government-run hospital and medical college in Shimoga certainly put me to the test. I thought that catching sight of students working on a cadaver in Mangalore was enough but here I got to see much more than I had ever thought (hoped) I would see in my entire life! I was taken on a tour of the anatomy department of the medical college where there were lots of different body parts on display
column2: including embryos. However
column3: I was then taken into another room where there were brains on slabs waiting to be dissected. I was then told to go through to a small back room and to get close to a tank. Well
column4: there was not just one but three bodies in it! I also saw chopped up body parts in another basin. This tour was not long after breakfast so I’m very pleased I did not have any adverse reactions to what I saw!

column2: I was taken round the paediatric ward and gave the children a small toy to play with. I was informed that families are educated about the importance of nutrition and that meals are tailored to the needs of the children. The mothers of babies that require hospital treatment are able to stay in a separate ward so that they can continue to breast feed. I also visited the intensive care unit where I was surprised to see so many twins.

column1: I then had the opportunity to speak to a member of staff about some of the issues that healthcare services in England face and I was told that there are some similarities. The hospital does not conduct any form of quality of care assessment but does have a very open complaints and suggestions policy. Patients can contact relevant hospital staff directly by telephone 24/7 and any issues are looked into straight away.

This was my last vocational visit of the trip and I have had the opportunity to see things that I would not be able to see back home. I haven’t quite managed to get the full picture of healthcare services so I may have to come back!
Vidya let me into her kitchen today to show me how she makes some of the South Indian cuisine I have been enjoying here
column2: including idly
column3: roti and coconut chutney. I hope I can find the ingredients at home so that I can share them. I also got a chance to play with Yashas and the young neighbour from upstairs. It is quite common here for neighbours and family to walk in and out of each other’s homes. The door always seems to be open
column4: especially in these smaller communities. I was really interested to see that Yashas toy kitchen has all of the traditional Indian utensils. I’m sure the kids at home would be a bit confused by this!

column1: Today is my fifth and final vocational day and I’m visiting KUVEMPU University
column2: along with Angie and four Rotarians. I was delighted when I walked in and spotted a sign for the Public Relations office. I have already visited Manipal University and Mysore University and both said that they didn’t have a PR or communications department so they showed me their journalism faculty instead. KUVEMPU is ranked 92nd out of 4000 universities. However
column3: when I

column2: it seems that the results are all based on what the university says about itself and there is no form of student satisfaction or performance measurement.

column1: First stop is the Vice Chancellors office where we meet Dr. Bari. The chancellor of the university here is the state governor. The university is 25 years old and it caters for a rural and tribal population. To support this
column2: there are 81 affiliated colleges across the state and the university has 55
column3: 000 students in total. There are five faculties; Social Sciences
column4: Humanities
column5: Science and Technology
column6: Law and Education. There are 4
column7: 000 postgraduate students and 70% of all students are female. This university is more like the university where I work
column8: the University of Cumbria
column9: than any of the others I have visited here. Dr. Bari tells us that the university is highly subsidised by the government and a social sciences student for example would only pay around 3000 rupees per year (about £30 if my calculations are right!).

column1: The students here are well motivated as the country has had a big focus on education for the last ten or 15 years. The economy has opened up and people

are attracted by the employment opportunities available within private companies. Course options fluctuate though as most parents want their children to be engineers or doctors. It means that basic sciences and social sciences are falling out of fashion. The dropout rate is low
column2: just 1%
column3: but of those who do leave
column4: the boys go to seek paid employment opportunities and the girls often have to leave to get married if their parents are offered a good match before they finish their education.

column1: When I ask them what their biggest challenges are
column2: I’m told that the university always struggles with money
column3: despite being funded by the government. They also say that students have much higher expectations when it comes to facilities and lots of welfare measures have recently been introduced for students and staff. They also bring up the topical international visa issue which has been rumbling in UK universities. They want to know what we do about it and if we need more international students in our universities. The staff here
column4: and most of the people we talk to day to day
column5: can’t believe that all of our schools are government funded. Here
column6: only the poor children go to

column1: government schools. We also have a very interesting discussion about how Indian people look down upon people in certain professions. Yet
column2: in the UK
column3: we respect skilled people who work hard.

column1: Despite asking again to visit the PR office
column2: we are taken to the management institute where we meet around 100 students. It’s strange to see them in a uniform as I can’t imagine UK students sticking to a uniform rule. We are getting used to giving impromptu presentations and after telling them about my job
column3: the staff and students ask me some questions which cover the things to consider in public relations
column4: the importance of business ethics and Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) and the qualities of a good manager when it comes to communication and CSR. The management institute encourages entrepreneurship and they work with the local Chamber of Commerce and private businesses to offer placements and experience. The government has its own programme for business start up and sustainability but it doesn’t associate with any university when delivering this.

column1: I ask again to visit the PR office and I am taken to meet a man who has responsibility for PR
column2: however he is a full time

column1: academic and there are actually three staff in another office that do the day to day PR activity. The frustrating thing with the vocational days is that we are not always getting to talk to the right people
column2: the ones who could tell me about how the PR office works here and discussions around the differences in the UK. He does tell me that the three staff also do all of the marketing activity and one writes
column3: one types up the writing and the other distributes the information to the media or other stakeholders. They do not have any sort of expert datatbase
column4: they don’t use social media
column5: they have a press meeting with the VC once a month and they publish an internal magazine but it seems to be more about research papers than anything else.

column1: While this may be working for them now
column2: newspapers and media are growing across India and I can imagine that in around 20 years time
column3: the university will have to invest more resources in public relations and communications.

column2: Displayed: 6
I went for a short walk with my host in a nearby park. It is quite new and named after Mahatma Ghandi. Apparently
column3: taking a morning walk is a new concept. Local people pay 50 rupees per month to use the park
column4: or 5 rupees per visit
column5: which goes towards the park maintenance.

column1: There were quite a few people out walking and jogging. There was also a group therapy class going on – a laughter club. I was curious about a gentlemen who was sitting on a bench clapping and my host told me that this was another form of therapy.

column2: there is an aquarium
column3: a train ride
column4: and all the usual things you would see in a playground ride back home.

column1: Whilst I was wearing tracksuit bottoms and a T-shirt
column2: the majority were wrapped up as if it was really cold
column3: so I did get a few odd looks (although it could just have been because I was the only white person there!). It was a lovely park to walk in and I wish I had somewhere like this to walk round every day.

column1: On my first night in Shimoga
column2: my host took me to a centre that cares for people who are not able to look after themselves and who have no-one else to care for them. The centre was established in 2007 by a gentleman whose aim in life is to serve others. The majority of the people who are cared for at the centre are people with physical disabilities
column3: though there are also people with mental ill health. 280 people have received care from the centre since it opened.

column1: As soon as I walked into the centre
column2: I saw that there were three occupied beds surrounding the office desk and the television was blaring. The main room off this had at least eight beds but also two people sleeping on the floor. The third room
column3: which was quite small
column4: had three beds. Both males and females slept in each of the rooms. The whole centre lacked any form of ventilation so you can imagine the odour emanating as a result of the heat and the lack of hygiene and cleanliness. I was told that the centre can accommodate up to 30 people at a time
column5: which I found difficult to visualise
column6: as the three rooms were already packed full of beds.

column1: Ten staff provide personal care services. The owner will do anything and everything for the people he welcomes into the centre. No specialist training is provided though the appropriately qualified staff are brought in as required. Doctors voluntarily visit the centre to check on the residents who are all fully dependent on other people. I was told that all they want is to be touched (as if they are a child) and to see other people. People from local social / sports clubs visit the residents but there are no other activities for the residents to engage in.

column2: the owner would transport the individual to hospital. I did not see any walking aids or wheelchairs though. Donations are given to the centre and the owner believes any challenges can be overcome. Somehow
column3: the centre finds sufficient funds to provide care to people who may otherwise have nothing. I was pleased to hear that a new site has been found for the centre
column4: which will be next to a new hospital that is being built.

column1: The owner’s dedication to help others is humbling and I hope that local communities continue to support his work.

column2: all of us at some point have had to face challenges
column3: cope with difficult situations and become very adaptable to a very different way of life. I think we are all coping remarkably well and we will be sad to leave here in ten days time.

column1: Today started with a ride on an elephant. I also had my first experience of an elephant dribbling down my back and hitting me over the head with its ear at Sakraibail camp. One of the young elephants was showing off and it almost looked like it was dancing for us! This was followed by a Lion and Tiger safari. Although these ones were not completely wild at Bandipur
column2: it was great to see such beautiful animals up close and personal. We also get a chance to visit Shivappanayaka Palace where there are some beautiful wood carvings. I would like to take one of these pieces home for my fireplace!

column1: Back to the more serious stuff
column2: we visited a number of projects supported by the seven Rotary clubs in the Shimoga area. First was some low cost housing in Lakshmipura village on the

column1: outskirts of the city. The houses were built to support families working in agriculture. I’m pretty sure that the whole village turned out to see us here and they all walk in and out of each other’s homes. This seems to happen a lot in the smaller towns and cities in a way that I don’t think it would in the UK. The houses are small but ideal for the needs of the families and cost just £750 to build.

We also visit a local school supported by Rotary. The kids here also have a Rotaract club which they tell us about. Although they are not quite as confident as the children in the private school we visited earlier this week
column2: Rotaract is helping them to progress. We all present to them and explain our jobs and a bit about life in the UK. Opening the floor for questions was interesting when they asked me about sex education. This isn’t something they will have come across here and I have already had an interesting chat with my host family about a very similar subject.

column1: At the blood and eye clinic we learn about how Rotary are supporting blood
collection and distribution in the area. The Government are keen to support blood donation here. Finally
column2: we head to Asha Kirana
column3: a school for children with severe learning disabilities. This school has 48 pupils who board here and it is quite different from the other special schools we have visited in India
column4: much noisier and uncontrolled. We are told that the children are particularly distressed as most were tied up all day when they were living at home. Their parents had to go out to work so the children were left outside
column5: soiled and hungry. The school has taken them in and they live here for 11 months of the year. The parents visit for two weeks and are taught how to care for the children and given targets to meet while they take their child home for the twelfth month of the year. If the child meets those targets
column6: they can return the following year.

column1: We meet a 32 year old woman who was a resident here and now helps the younger children. When the school opened 26 years ago
column2: she was a six year old girl
column3: dumped by her parents who gave a false address and could

column1: not be traced. She was supported by the school and the Rotarians and she has even managed to overcome some of her medical conditions. The school aims to get all of these children back into mainstream education to prevent the stigma placed upon them and their parents.

column2: Vidya tells me all about the meals she prepares
column3: the ingredients and preparation. Many of my hosts have been homemakers so they spend a lot of time and effort cooking. And they have staff to help with the cleaning too. Our hosts live by the mantra that ‘the guest is God’ and are keen to feed you lots of food. They can’t understand that we don’t eat so much at home
column4: particularly at breakfast time. Although I was a bit worried that Indian food would be too spicy for me
column5: it has been really nice to try out lots of different things
column6: with and without spice and pepper. South Indian food has so much taste and variety and I will come away with lots of ideas. I have already bought one cook book and been given another as a gift. Just hope I can find a shop

column1: at home that sells some of the things I need!

column2: it’s been a very thoughtful day. We are seeing things here that we would probably never get the chance to see in the UK and it makes you realise and appreciate what you have.
Displayed: 8

column1: Angie and Emily stayed on Chetana Halli Estate

column2: we have been staying in the beautiful coffee region of Belur. We were all fortunate enough to be hosted by coffee planters on their plantations. Emily and I stayed with a wonderful old man
column3: Ganghia
column4: and his wife
column5: Vashanta. He is evidently highly respected by everyone in the region
column6: deservedly so
column7: it seems to us. His son is the owner of India's largest coffee shop chain
column8: Cafe Coffee Day and apparently one of India's richest people. He is also
column9: we are told
column10: an unassuming man like his father.

column1: The house where we stayed was built about 150 years ago by a coffee planter from Wales. Ganghia's family bought it in the 1940's and have built it up to its 11
column2: 000 acres of today. He took us on a tour
column3: showing us the difference between arabica and robusta plants
column4: how they grow in the shade of tall trees such as silver oak and teak
column5: and are interspersed with pepper and cardamom. He then showed us how the beans are washed and dried for seven days in the sun.

column2: one of which involved climbing 716 steps. There are said to be a
which has to be done by hand.

but I counted far fewer. It was very good to be out in the lovely weather. Our host for the day told us only after he had negotiated all those steps that he had a heart problem! Jain and Hindu temples visited later had the most intricate carvings of animals and gods. In one I was given such a very special holy garland that I could barely carry the weight around my neck.

column1: The giving of garlands and individual flowers
column2: generally roses
column3: is a common custom to honour guests. We have been given so many. Apparently after use it is customary to leave them under a jack fruit tree to wither away.

column1: While in the Belur region we also visited some friendly Rotary clubs
column2: an Interact club and a college named after Ganghia
column3: where village students over 16 are taught English and trained in various subjects in preparation for working for Cafe Coffee Day. They are given six months training with free board
column4: food
column5: uniform and education. They are then required to work for the company for two years
column6: after which they are free to choose whether to stay with the company or

column1: All beans are washed and then skinned to extract the two beans in each pod. The outer husk is separated and dried for use in fertilisers and manures.
get a different job. The college is in immaculate condition.
We were also shown Ganghia's son's very smart resort hotel
column2: where for a mere £330 a night one can rent an opulent suite
column3: complete with its own pool. The inclusion of a helipad may suggest the wealth of their clientele!

column1: Now we move on to Shimoga for further new experiences.

column2: photos by Emily)
Displayed: 7

column1: Diane administering life saving polio vaccines

column2: I welcomed the opportunity to stay in the middle of a coffee plantation
column3: sit out on the veranda basking in the sun
column4: and wake to the sound of birds singing each morning. Our journeys to
column5: from
column6: and surrounding the areas of Hassan and Belur may have been quite long but it was so good to see some countryside again. The highlight for me had to be the visit to Shravanabelagola where we climbed barefoot up the vindhyagiri hill to a Jain temple. As well as enjoying getting my first bout of exercise on this trip
column7: I took in fantastic views of the city and the gommateshvara statue. We visited two other temples during our time in the Hassan district – the Hindu Hoysaleswara temple at Halebeedu and the Chennakeshava temple complex at Belur. Both of these are amazing architectural feats. A special puja ritual was performed for us and Angie was adorned with a rather grand flower garland – a great honour.

column1: The next excitement was visiting three polio immunisation booths. I had the opportunity to give polio drops to two children – it was not as easy as you think! It was good to see a group of children attending one of the booths and the commitment and hard work of the Rotarians and healthcare workers manning these booths was greatly appreciated by the families.

We also saw rotary in action when we visited a school’s Interact club. The young ladies all spoke with great enthusiasm and confidence about the activities they are able to engage in through rotary. It was really good to hear young people talk this way; they clearly valued the experience and I’m sure they all have bright futures ahead of them.

column2: I started reading the best book about yoga I have ever come across and was inspired by his views on yoga and meditation. All in all
column3: even with all the extra visits that were slotted into our visit to the Hassan district
column4: I felt it was a place where I could spend some quiet time reflecting on what we have experienced so far on our journey. Reading the yoga book will make my journey home slightly more bearable but I don’t want to think about that just yet
column5: as there is so much more to see and do here!

column1: For my vocational day in Mysore
column2: three very different visits had been arranged for me. The first of these was to a 90-bed private hospital that is part of an international chain of hospitals providing world-class healthcare. It opened in 2009 and recently achieved accreditation with international standards. A community ethos is an integral value for the hospital; free / concessional clinics are offered every month. Although I have not visited a private hospital in England
column3: the facilities
column4: services
column5: and operational procedures I observed and was informed about were in line with what I would expect and hope to see in any hospital.

column1: I was slightly surprised that the hospital had only one ambulance (with access to a back-up). The emergency department was only set up with three beds
column2: though it could accommodate six and could also use the entrance hall / waiting area in the event of a disaster (room for an additional 6 beds). If the hospital is unable to provide treatment immediately
column3: it sends patients to its sister hospitals nearby
column4: providing any necessary first aid before transfer.

column2: corporate
column3: hospital
column4: it does not experience the same issues as government-run hospitals. For example
column5: it is able to offer higher salaries and attract the best surgeons. It also has an effective workforce planning system to ensure that patient care does not suffer. The most impressive aspect for me was the company’s commitment to supporting its staff; time is set aside every day for staff training.
