next four nights and I’m keen to get to know the family. They tell me that they married 16 years ago. It was an arranged marriage and they met one year before the wedding. Rupal moved from Bombay to be with Punit and his parents
column2: who live in a separate apartment in the same block. The children go to a nice co-ed school and take part in lots of extracurricular activities. They also love cricket! I get them on side by mentioning that I know that India beat Pakistan last night. (Mitra and Mr Shetty made a lot of noise during the game!)

column1: Punit and Rupal take me to see a nearby Church which is more than 300 years old. There is a wedding taking place and Punit explains that his brother married a Christian girl from India and they had a wedding which celebrated both of their faiths. The day started with a Hindu wedding like we have seen this week
column2: and ended with a Christian service in this very Church.

column1: We go on to see the old port and I ask them to show me the local fire station too. This is partly because I am
interested in these things and partly to impress my dad
column2: a former fire-fighter at home. There are about five machines here to cover the Managlore district of 600
column3: 000 people. At any time
column4: there are 15 men working in the station and each machine needs a team of seven. They work twelve hour shifts here for 15 days at a time. They let us come inside the new and very modern building and explain that when somebody dials 101
column5: it comes directly to the station. They ring a bell on the wall only once (They show me how this works!) and the fire-fighters can be in the machines and on the road in 50 seconds. I am surprised that they have to dress in their full uniform
column6: minus the boots
column7: as soon as their shift starts and ready to respond at any minute. Surely this must be hot and heavy? But it all makes sense when I see their uniform....a brown shirt and brown trousers. Not exactly safety gear! There are very few fires in Managlore and sometimes they sit and wait days before a call out. On the way home
column8: we stop off for some coconut milk. Once the coconut

column2: it is split open and the inside is offered to me. I willingly eat it when Rupal explains that it is good for your complexion!
Displayed: 9

column1: We are quickly learning that plans seem to change as quickly as they are made. Today
column2: we thought we were going to visit some temples. Instead we landed at a Rotary Club meeting about 15km from Udupi in Brahmavar where we received yet more beautiful flowers and were asked to talk about ourselves. The English here is different and it is quite difficult to understand what people are saying. I do understand when they take us downstairs to the cake shop and ask us to pick anything. Unfortunately it’s a case of ‘can’t eat
column3: won’t eat’. Nicola can’t eat cakes
column4: and I was advised to avoid anything from street caterers. It takes all my willpower to say no!! We are taken to a research farm
column5: part of Bangalore University. The presentation and tour are great but my highlight is the cocoa beans. Our Brahmavar hosts choose to call me Chocolate Girl after this! The temples
column6: one Jain
column7: one Buddhist
column8: are very interesting. It would be good to know a little more about the background though. Most of the signs are not in English.

column1: While on the bus with our hosts
column2: they are asking us about our

column1: personal circumstances and are amazed to hear that I don’t live my parents and I am unmarried. I explain my family situation and they say that we should all be living together
column2: including my mum
column3: dad
column4: brother and other brother with his wife and two children! They continue to question me about it and find the situation hilarious! They even ask if perhaps my Dad will find me a husband? I hope not! This does start to worry me when they take us to our second wedding of the trip and I’m a bit concerned that it’s actually going to be my wedding. Tomorrow I’m wearing a ring!

column1: At the wedding I come across my first Indian style toilet. I think I have done well to avoid even seeing one properly for four days! Although it’s clean
column2: I decided to wait. Emily took the initiative to check the other toilets and we find two western ones beside the four Indian style loos!

column1: We have some free time with our hosts and Mr Shetty takes me and Mithra out. I should have been staying with Mr Shetty and his family but due to a death in the family
column2: my

column1: host was changed to Mithra. We go on a rustic boat ride down the river which is fantastic. Very peaceful and serene. We then head to Udupi beach where families have gathered to watch the sunset. It’s like no beach I have been on before. Most beaches are either crowded with tourists or deserted. This is simply hundreds of locals from inland who come to fly kites and splash in the waves. There are camel rides
column2: tight rope walkers
column3: Muslim women in veils and also Indian men holding hands
column4: a sight which is becoming more common to me!

column1: It has been a fantastic final day here and I really love Manipal and Udupi
column2: the people
column3: the cuisine
column4: the sights and the university town atmosphere. I have become very close to Mithra already and she has told me lots about her family
column5: her life here in India
column6: her arranged marriage and her interests. She has been an excellent host and I have loved sharing her beautiful home. I’m going to be really sad to leave tomorrow.

column2: Displayed: 8

column1: So many things happen each day that it is hard to keep track of them all and write them in the blog
column2: especially when we don’t have wifi to keep updating it! If anybody wants a real and honest account they will have to ask to read my personal diary when I get home!

column1: Today has mainly consisted of food and learning.
The Indian people are so friendly and hospitable that they insist on feeding us
column2: a lot of food
column3: all of the time. Much more than we are used to
column4: including breads and potatoes for breakfast! We have all agreed that although the food is lovely
column5: unless we start to say no
column6: we will all come back much heavier than when we arrived.

column1: I was lucky enough to visit the Manipal Institute of Communication today where I learned about the courses
column2: the students and how they are recruited
column3: how journalism and communication works in India
column4: recent changes and a social uprising being started by the youth via social media. I am told that this is especially common now that people are talking about the recent gang rape in Delhi. The younger generation of

column2: more so than ever. I also learn about how the university interacts with the community and discover that staff here have the same communication issues as we do at our UK universities. I meet a 91 year old professor who still comes to work every day! I hope I’m not working at 91. He is somewhat of a celebrity in Southern India as he has been a reporter and editor for some of the biggest newspapers. I also find that some people disagree with page 3 of Indian newspapers. I curiously ask what page 3 is and I am told that it is gossip and celebrity news
column3: with some women wearing revealing clothes. If only they could see our version of page 3!

column1: The printing press in Manipal is very impress and gets work from across the world
column2: including Penguin and Pearson. JK Rowling’s book
column3: Casual Vacancy
column4: was recently printed here and the Hindu version of ‘The Secret’ is currently on the press. There are also school book
column5: calendars
column6: leaflets and the most recent copies of Indian Vogue and GQ. The factory is run well and I am very impressed. Although
column7: I doubt that

column1: I would be allowed to do this in the UK without ear plugs and a hard hat!

In the afternoon we all met up to visit the Manipal University’s main campus and watch the virtual tour. It is impressive but starts to feel a little bit like propaganda. The university is one of the top five in India and they are keen to instil pride in the students. We also meet the Pro Chancellor who gives us all a rose. I have had more flowers this week than ever before. We then travelled up to End Point
column2: a beautiful hill overlooking the city of Udupi. It was nice just to get some sunshine
column3: the first we have been able to enjoy outside! We seem to be spending a lot of time indoors and travelling.

column1: The Astare Centre is a home for people with disabilities and it is an eye opener. The people here are treated very well and the centre is clean and tidy. Everybody welcomes us with more artificial flowers which are made by the residents to help them develop their life skills. The centre is funded by the university and Rotary.
Tonight we also delivered our first presentation to two rotary clubs. It went well and was received well. We were given lots of gifts and we are all wondering how we will get everything home!
Angie signing the register at Asare School
Just to prove we haven't hidden Angie in a cupboard somewhere here are a few photos of her taken today at the Asare School. We have all been looking after each other
column2: but we won't let Angie be in charge of the presentation clicker again!!! 😊

column1: Asare School is for mentally challenged people and is sponsored heavily by the Rotary Club in Manipal and was set up as a joint initiative with Manipal University.

Children and young adults live here permanently and have lessons and recreation time together. They also make synthetic roses and plates to sell and raise money for the school. The vocational training offered allows some people to go on and lead independant lives and find a job.

It was originally set up by Jai Vittal - Estate Manager at Manipal University and named after his daughter who attends the school. He showed us round today and we met his wife who is a teacher at the school and his youngest son who is in the final year of his degree in Computer Science.

column2: Displayed: 2

column1: As ever here in India there has been LOTs of food and I managed to have 5 meals today!!! My stomach is ready to burst!!! I had a very large breakfast this morning which consisted of:
Normally I don't have time for any breakfast back in the UK so this is a lot of food for me and could last me all day!

Today we started our vocational visits and Rtn. Shetty picked me up at 8.15am (early rise for me on a Saturday!!!) and took me to visit Kajane Agricultural Farm. I met Natraj Hegde who is a very forward thinking 2nd generation farmer/businessman who grows coconuts
column2: cashew nuts
column3: rubber
column4: mangosteen
column5: rambutan and peppers. He is experimenting with multiple cropping systems to get maximum yield from his crops and efficient use of water and land. Although we can't grow such exotic crops here in the UK the concept is something many UK farmers could adapt.

column1: After walking round the plantations (which even at 9am this morning were approaching
Areca nut tree on Kajane Farm

35 degrees!!!) we sat in the shade and I drank fresh coconut water straight from the shell with a straw. It was very refreshing and afterwards they cut open the shell and I ate the soft creamy inside flesh -delicious!!! Natraj also has a successful online business called Vanilla Mart
column2: based in Tumbridge Wells
column3: Kent selling vanilla products to UK and European markets.

column1: Lots of photos were taken on the farm of me with my hosts and this was just the beginning of the photograpgy!!!

Rtn. Shetty then took me to a local tile factory that is run by a close family friend as unfortunately the visit to the AMPC weekly market and office was unable to happen today. I met the mother of the family in their house and even though her English was non-existant she was very kind and welcoming to me
column2: with lots of hugs and hand holding. It was here my 2nd meal of the day appeared in the form of more dosas with a sweet filling known as Chana Dal witha side order of freshly roasted cashnew nuts and chilli tikki banana chips. The very kind lady then gave me a packet of

column1: Don't think we can buy these in the UK - very exotic fruits.
the dosas and banana chips to take away with me!
Next we were supposed to go straight back to the hotel in Manipal to meet everyone for lunch
column2: but Rtn. Shetty wanted to show me his house and let my try some of his special fried fish (meal 3). It was absolutely delicious and just the right ammount of spice
column3: but did make us cough a lot in the kitchen as he was cooking it! Apparently his wife makes fun of him and says he only likes people who like fish! I guess I am in the good books then!!! I ate 2 pieces and tried desperately not to think of lunch a mere 10 minutes away!!! Rtn. Shetty is a retired banker in his 60's who teaches English part time at a school in his home town that educates poorer children. He also goes swimming every morning VERY early is a member of a Laughter Club - I really like the sounds of this concept and think we could use some of these clubs back in the UK!!!

column1: Lunch (meal 4) at the hotel with all the GSE team and their hosts was again delicious
column2: but I

column1: think we were all strugging with the sheer volume of food. We did of course manage mains
column2: seconds and even pudding with some ""gentle"" persuasion from our hosts! Afterwards we headed on a tour of Manipal University which was VERY impressive - a very different place to any of our UK univerisities and I got the impression that students were more committed to their studies and appeciated the opportunities available to them following graduation.

column1: A very busy man called Jai Vittal showed us rounf the campus and he was always trying to make us hurry up and move on
column2: but we were all taking lots of photos!!! He even introduced us to the Pro Chancellor - Dr Ballal - who is second in command under Dr Ramdas Pai who is the son of the original university founder Dr PMA Pai and had a significant influence of the development of Udupi and Manipal in general.

column1: We didn't have long to get changed before heading out to our first Rotary Club meeting in India which was a joint event between Udupi and Manipal clubs. We were all very nervous about delivering our presentation for the first time to an audience of nearly 100 people. The difference for us was the outdoor venue with bright stage lights and l lots of mosquitos!!! We got all the technology working (Eventually!!!) and delivered without any hitches. We got presented with several roses from the hosting clubs and we also exchanged banners. Lots more photos were taken including group photos for each club with all members on the stage. We then ate dinner in the same place and was a wonderful buffet which again went down only using the right hand to eat. Meal number 5 of the day done and definitely no more room today!!!!
Onwards now to bed for me I am afraid as it's not after midnight and I must be at breakfast tomorrow for 8.30am.

Rajyotsava Day is celebrated in the Karnataka State on 1st November every year. It is usually celebrated the full month. The state emblem is Ganda Berunda and the flag comes in red and yellow. The deity on the bullock drawn chariot is Bhuvaneshwari is decorated with flower garlands and the persons leading the procession
column2: played Nadaswaram. They wore the same colors attire. The big drums are called ""dolu"" with other musical instruments to compliment the parade. Cultural programmes
column3: congregations of artists and poets are part of the festival. At some places
column4: feeding of the poor is also organized.

column1: While I was making my way to the Travel Agency
column2: I saw some men clad in traditional costumes
column3: yellow turbans
column4: holding musical instruments and walking the same path as I am. Soon after my driver turned to the right I could not see them in sight anymore but my heart was racing because I do not want to miss this opportunity to photograph them and put into my album. I love to see cultures of many
column5: particularly the Indian cultures and traditional festivals. It would be ashamed if I miss this festival moreover this is my very

column2: I do not want to live in disappointments. Being there on the second day in Bangalore
column3: I am kind of lucky to have stumbled something like this but I had to walk about two kilometers down the road
column4: checking with by passers where about is this people that clad in traditional costumes with musical instruments. “Down the road where Lord Subramaniam Temple is situated "" said by some who can reply in English. I finally reached A. Nanjappa Circle where the whole troupe was waiting for me. Thank God! They have not started the festival. They must have been waiting for me. I thought with a happy smile.

column1: Many Bullock carts to head the parade
column2: devotees on top of the chariot arranging what was necessary to beautify the chariot and the musicians clad in colorful costumes with colorful turbans. Bhuvaneshwari is the deity. While the swamijis in prayers and offerings
column3: the artists who were busily tending their make-ups
column4: some dressed in striking patterns cat costumes with black underwear on the outside
column5: clowns on stilts (if you don’t look up
column6: you might think they are flag poles)
column7: men in drags – they are beautiful
column8: with heavy

column2: beautiful headdress
column3: glittering costume jewelries
column4: Hindu symbolic patterns on their foreheads
column5: and the visible patch of unshaven moustache against the red full lips makes them very special.

column1: Yellow turban drummers posed with their “dolu” drums
column2: which I found them very friendly and corporative to my request. I am enthralled by the size of the drums and I also wondered “Do they rolled and played the drum as they parade?” It is a long road to reckon with
column3: all because for the love of their culture
column4: festival and faith traditionally believe in
column5: that was carried out joyously every year
column6: a tradition since their forefathers.

column1: Rajyotsava Day is celebrated in the Karnataka State on 1st November every year. It is usually celebrated the full month. A colorful event one must not miss when you are in Karnataka state. It may be a small troupe but the celebration is great
column2: knowledgeable
column3: an insight to festival not known to my world.

column1: I am happy and glad to have “caught” on them in time to enable me to add in to my album of Beautiful India.
My Dream to travel and see the whole of India before I strike Gold.

column2: Displayed: 16

column1: So much has happened today that it’s hard to know where to start! I was woken up by a mixture if dogs barking
column2: train going over the bridge and chanting or praying from a nearby home. We experienced Indian time when the plans and timings changed
column3: something which is common here but makes everything feel laid back and relaxed.

column1: We have a bus to use for the duration of the trip and our driver Nagaraj is to take us into the city of Mangalore. As we are driving in
column2: we are able to see lots of things we missed yesterday. It is amazing that there is so much wealth and poverty living side by side. I have seen wealth before and I have seen poverty before
column3: but never both so close together without anybody batting an eyelid. One minute we have cows and goats grazing by the roadside
column4: small fires and people looking through rubbish
column5: then we have expensive advertising
column6: shopping malls and people immaculately dressed n bright and expensive clothes. Everything is very loud and the main noise is car horns tooting and the whistles of road police and parking attendants.

column1: the venue for our first Indian wedding! The father of the bride is a Rotarian and his 24 year old daughter is marrying a 27 year old man. Although arranged marriages still happen
column2: they are less common and Rathi and Rajesh met through work and they are marrying for love. Both have university qualifications and will work once they are married. Rotarian Sathish and his wife Sapna talk us through the ceremony and answer our questions. It was interesting to learn that the groom changes the name of the bride to match the same letter as his first name. In todays case
column3: both names began with ‘R’ but Sapna was called Tara before she married Sathish. They also have children
column4: a son of 20 and a married daughter of 26 with the same initial. Sathish and Sapna had an arranged marriage
column5: with suitable partners picked by their horoscopes.

column1: The wedding ceremonies here last for days
column2: with lots of celebrations and rituals include burning
column3: henna
column4: (more common in North India) washing feet
column5: giving beads and hundreds of thousands of flowers
column6: used as venue decoration but also as a garland for the couple and in the brides hair. We learn that

column1: best man must be younger than the groom and we are told that if there are two boys or two girls in a family
column2: the younger cannot marry until the older has. Similarly
column3: the sons must wait until the daughters are married before they can marry
column4: unless there is an age difference of more than five years. They also tell me that there are far fewer women in India and for every 200 men
column5: there are just over 130 women
column6: meaning that many young men can’t find a wife. The maternal uncles deliver the bride to her groom and she is paraded to the guests
column7: and lifted towards him before a blanket is removed to reveal her. I feel very emotional watching this and the loud music and smells sweep you away.

column1: Everybody must have a full stomach to wish the couple well and we are shocked to see just how many people are being fed. There are around 1000 guests and while some quickly eat at the buffet outside
column2: many are sitting down in a canteen. Here
column3: we are given a banana leaf to use as a plate
column4: as well as around ten small meals
column5: eaten with our

column1: hands. We are also given a box of Cadbury sweets
column2: some I have never seen before
column3: with a sticker noting the name and date f the wedding. (Apparently the bride’s father is a distributor for Cadbury!)

column1: All of the guests who are invited will turn up for just part of the ceremony as it lasts so long and takes place on various days of the week. Many people go to around 30 weddings per year but they are asked not to bring any gifts as their presence is enough. Also
column2: if the couple are given gifts
column3: they must note what they were given and then in the future return something worth more. This could end up a bit pricy I think! What has hit me most is the fact that people in India are celebrating their marriage with so many people
column4: making family and friends the most important part of their day. At home
column5: this isn’t always the case and more and more people put on a show but forget the real meaning of their marriage.

column2: Devdas Kamath
column3: invites us to his home and tells us that he and his wife had an arranged marriage and married two months after they met. His mother and father have been married for 52 years. They met on the day of their wedding! Devdas and his wife show us their wedding album from 19 years ago which is similar to the wedding we seen today.

column1: We then travelled about an hour north to Manipal and Udupi where we met our first hosts. We were all greeted by female Rotarians
column2: mine a 73 year old lady called Mithra Bhandarkar. Mithra has two children
column3: her son living in California and her daughter living in Mumbai
column4: and four grandchildren. Mithra has lived alone since she was widowed seven years ago. Her husband was ten years older than her and she tells me that when she had her arranged marriage
column5: this was normal. Now women have a partner just four or five years older. Mithra’s house is beautiful and sits back from a main road through secure gates. The home was her husband’s dream home as he grew up in a house with just two rooms. The house features an indoor fountain as well as indoor and outdoor balconies. Mithra now just uses the ground floor so I have the top floor to myself! She also has staff
column6: a young woman aged 27 who lives in quarters below the main house with her husband
column7: a construction worker
column8: and four year old son. He is delighted to see a foreigner! Mithras helper only works in the mornings to clean and wash. Her own mother worked for Mithra for more than 20 years and Mithra greets the little boy like he is one of her grandchildren which was very nice to see. She also tells me that she had a driver for 22 years but she sacked him two years ago because he was stealing from her.

column1: Mithra takes me to her ladies club
column2: Manipal Mahila Samaj. She spends a lot of time between here and the rotary club and the hall where the meeting is held was named after her late husband. She also tells me that she is a donor to the rotary foundation and so far she has donated more than $60
column3: 000. During the meeting
column4: Mithra unexpectedly grabs my hand and takes me up to the stage where I have to explain to all of the guests who I am and why I’m here! After introducing her friend Nandita
column6: they take me in the car. Although Mithra has said we might go some places
column7: plans change quickly and they speak to each other in their own language so much of the time I am at their mercy
column8: jumping in the car and wondering where we will arrive next!

column1: They take me to see a car festival
column2: which are basically floats or a parade. We are in Carstreet
column3: ironically a street with no cars but eight small community temples and one large temple. Although I’m finding it hard to keep up with all of the religions and community names
column4: I gather that each of the eight compete to take over the larger temple for two years. This celebration today happens twice a year and everybody crams inside to watch the rituals and catch a glimpse of the idol through a grate in the wall. He is decked in diamonds and there are candles everywhere. The bell ringing
column5: chanting and praying is quite overwhelming and although I understand hardly any of what they tell me
column6: it feels like a very spiritual place. After leaving the temple and visiting some shops selling many idols
column7: I get a chance to see my first elephant. It dances for the people before blessing them!

column1: We also bang into some friends of Nandita and Mithra and the children are fascinated by me. One of the children
column2: Greetha
column4: is very intelligent and asks me what I think about the protests being made in Delhi and if I feel safe. I am shocked that she seems to know so much but she goes on to tell me how she feel about this and being a young female in India. Greetha is intrigued by my life in the UK and asks a lot of questions. She is sad to leave when we head back to Mithras. I have also spoken to a lady about family life in India and we discuss adoption and why it is not so common here. I have learned so much already!

column1: Dr Gowri in her office at Sonia Clinic
It's so hard to believe that just over 48 hours ago we hadn't left UK soil and hadn't met any Indian Rotarians!
Everyone we have met is SO friendly and it would be impossible to name them all. People are so genuine and friendly out here and go out of their way to make us welcome.

Today we experienced our first Indian wedding and if I had to describe it in one word it would be - colourful!!!! More photos to follow in other blogs as I very unhelpfully left my camera at Devdas Kamath's house in Mangalore!
We were taken in our personal minibus this afternoon to the district of Upupi where we are staying for 2 nights and met our first set of hosts - who are all female Rotarians
column2: many of them doctors. This is the first night we've not been staying as a group and although we were all aprehensive at initialy parting it only took a few moment to be in the host home to feel welcome and part of the family.

column1: My host is Dr Gowri who is a very respected padeatrician in Manipal and Nicola is staying with her sister (also a doctor
column2: but specialising in gynaecology) Dr Girija. We were both taken round the hospital which their father founded - Sonia Clinic - and saw their offices and consulting rooms. We also met their 86 year old father who still lectures at the medical college and lives right next door to the hospital.

column1: Both our hosts are members of a local Ladies Club which meets once a fortnight and we were lucky enough to be invited to their first meeting of 2013 and greeted once again with open arms and many ""Happy New Years"". We were fed (again!!!) and watched the new committee being sworn in for duty.
Once I had arrived again and spent a day alone in the office
column2: It began to sink in how much has happen the past 4 years...

column1: Peace Child was my first step into the world alone
column2: my first adventure
column3: the time when I first realised what was possible.

column1: I think sometimes in England we lose what is possible and just do what is expected.
I'm not sure if by escaping every January
column2: I am running away
column3: recharging my battery’s or discovering something new
column4: I guess its a mixture of all three.

column1: Sometimes I wonder what it all means
column2: deep I know but with the Ego and the voice inside our heads it so difficult to just be
column3: be present be in the moment
column4: I think sometimes when I’m lost in my thoughts
column5: tight chested and anxious “Breath
column6: let go and remind yourself that this moment you are living right now is the only one you know you have for sure” Sometimes it releases a little pressure
column7: sometimes it make me smile
column8: but honestly
column9: I can remember the only time I’ve even completely been in the moment
column10: it was here in India on the 11th of February 2010
column11: I

column2: the southern tip off India
column3: the meeting of three seas
column4: the home Hindu's say of Devti the female spirit of Hinduism. I was sitting on a wall on the coast looking out to sea
column5: unimportantly Matt was beside me... The wind was blowing on my face
column6: its strength
column7: wild and free... suddenly
column8: somehow my mind complexity cleared all I could feel was my breath
column9: then I began to cry
column10: no emotion had cause the tears it was I think a trastion to letting go. That moment was by far the calmest most peaceful moment of my life.

column1: Sometimes I think maybe I’m hedonist
column2: constantly searching for a perfect; life
column3: moment
column4: partner
column5: feeling
column6: job
column7: home
column8: state of mind.

column1: So after that first day of just being on Friday the ….. I returned to the boys home
column2: the interns at the moment had organised a Christmas meal for them all
column3: all together they our 70 boys in the home at the moment
column4: I wasn’t sure if returning was a massively good idea
column5: I mean my last experience had been a whirlwind of emotions
column6: the treatment of the boys had been something I had really

column1: struggled with but for some reason I hoped my boys were still there... for me maybe? I feel its because I was worried if they weren’t there where would they be... the boy I was hoping for the most was J avid
column2: a shy undeveloped 13year old we had shared moments and story’s without words. As we approached the building a strange feeling overwhelmed me
column3: fear I think.

column2: paper garlands
column3: then at 1 o'clock the food arrived. The boys were made to stand in line as we organised the massive pots of chicken curry
column4: rice
column5: dal
column6: chapit and sweets. Usually they would only eat dal so the chicken was a real treat for them.

column1: After handing out the final plate I entered the room in which they were eating. Sat in lines they all wait until the last boy had sat down
column2: then they chanted
column3: maybe like a pray of thanks
column4: it was such a beautiful moment
column5: and sound. We sat and shared a plate of the food.

column1: Straight after lunch we left and headed to Bern’s the director of peace child
column2: it was a surreal experience a

column1: difficult one to comprehend straight away
column2: none of my boys were still they
column3: a partly there is a new law that they need to be sent home or somewhere else before 3 months is up.

column1: The end of 2012... It had been such a difficult year in some ways
column2: but so amazing also! I love new years and the start of a fresh calendar. Well
column3: I dislike the last minute party plans and people making a huge deal out of NYE but I think it is important to take a moment to reflect on the past year and what you have accomplished. I remember a piece of paper I wrote with my goals that stared at me every day. If you don't make any goals
column4: you certainly won't reach them. I set absurdly ridiculously huge goals...and guess what? If I had that little piece of paper with me right now
column5: I could draw a line through everything I wrote down. That being said
column6: ok
column7: yes I wanted to travel for a year. Here I am
column8: siting beside rice paddies hear a monkey pounce on the roof while I'm drinking terrible instant coffee in the middle of India. Be cautious of what you wish for because what you get will most likely exceed your own expectations 😊

column1: Enough of my self introspective... Once again
column2: I've waited too long to write a blog. Picking up where I left off
column3: I arrived in Agra where the Taj Mahal is. Wow oh wow! What an incredible building. Made of solid
column4: white marble and all of the inlay designs are from other stones. And guess what...when you step inside
column5: it smells like roses. I woke up for sunrise to take some pictures and to see it. I didn't really have much of a choice because I had to leave that afternoon so sunrise seemed the best option. There is just something so special to watch the light change and the day begin...and it is just a bonus I get to do that while looking at some of the most beautiful buildings/sites in the world. After such a peaceful morning
column6: I was all ready to travel down south for Christmas. Good thing I was rested because the 28 hours of travel was some kind of stressful adventure!

column1: So I go to leave and apparently
column2: the rickshaw drivers are on ""strike""...come on! Basically just a way to ask 5x the price and get it. So I'm in this rickshaw and he pulls over and gets a little guy missing one of his eyeballs on a bike to get me the rest of the way to the train station. Ahh at this point
column3: I knew it was going to be an interesting trip...

column1: I arrive and my train is delayed 7 hours. Normally
column2: I wouldn't care
column3: it's India...delays and things going not according to plan are expected. Trouble with this particular train being delayed is that it was connecting me to another train which was taking me all the way to Mumbai. My 2nd train had been booked solid for weeks (I booked it first day in India) and at one moment the wait list was over 800 people. So
column4: crap
column5: I can't miss it. I asked about my delayed train and the response I received was ""just jump on a train passing through and keep walking from car to car to avoid the ticket collector"". I am up for that challenge but not that day. So I race outside the train station and got a taxi to get me to the connecting station. And here is something fun
column6: when you tell a driver in India to go as fast as possible...they most certainly do! I think the guy had his horn and gas peddle pressed all the way down for 1 hour of the 1.5 it took to arrive. I get out of the car at 5:13...my train was supposed to leave at 5:15. I was running through the station
column7: which is not that easy because people are laying on the ground etc. hah ok so needless to say
column8: I found the platform and no joke
column9: as soon as I walked up huffing and puffing
column10: the train pulls up. I heave my bag on
column11: jump on the nearest car and zoom
column12: the train is gone. This particular train was not late (shocking) and it paused for 60 seconds at the station (which is also rare because normally they sit for a long time in each town). At this moment
column13: all i could do was laugh with relief and pray I was on the right train.

column1: It only got more interesting because I was in a car with 49 men and myself. As luck would have it
column2: all the seats face forward but at the very end of the car they are opposite so you are sitting facing everyone...guess where my seat was? So not only do I have to squish between two strange men
column3: I provided some sort of entertainment for all the men to look at for the next 17 hours. Sorry to elaborate on this story
column4: maybe it is not that interesting but it is an experience I will never forget.

column1: I arrived in mumbai and had contemplated going site seeing for a couple hours. But let me tell you
column2: the 1 hour I was out on the street and getting to the airport...I think that city does not need to be on my list of places to explore. I will watch it in slumdog millionaire and be content.

column1: Within 10 minutes of landing in Goa
column2: it felt like all the stress of the past 3 weeks just melted away. The beaches are beautiful
column3: no pollution
column4: and only the occasional honking of horns. So relaxing! It was the first Christmas I spent away from family
column5: snow and festivities. I can honestly say
column6: I didn't miss it TOO much. I feel horrible saying that
column7: because obviously I miss my family and friends but Christmas time has become so focused on gifts
column8: food and it is so built up that it was such a beautiful feeling just sitting on the sand with nothing
column9: and simply being grateful. It also helped being in such a cool place. I went out on a boat and saw dolphins. How awesome is that??!!

column1: The south of India is much more relaxed and easier! That is a relief because I was so close to booking a ticket out of India. So close! But I am really thankful I didn't. I met a group of travelers and have been moving from town to town with them. This town I'm in (Hampi) is one of the top destinations in India and I now know why. It has a mix of natural beauty and ancient beautiful temples. Thousands of years ago
column2: a volcano erupted spraying massive boulders over the valley. So you can just stroll through banana plantations and come across rocks the size of two storey buildings. It is a really chill place and no alcohol is allowed
column3: which really tones down the crazy backpacker scene. The group of us went for a walk yesterday and jumped in the river and floated back into town. I wish I could paint the picture but there was not a soul around
column4: just palm trees
column5: rocks and the water (which I accidentally swallowed some...oops). I can understand now why people fall in love with India (after a very rocky beginning 😊

column1: India is an amazing experience for the first time visitor - colourful and busy are the two words that immediately spring to mind. Along with all the beeping and cars on the wrong side of the road and stray cows we made it safely to the Mangalore Club where we are staying tonight. Air conditioned balcony rooms with fantastics views are a welcome sights after a 9 hour overnight flight!!!
We have lots of exciting experiences ahead of us over the next few days and hopefuly after a good nights sleep we will all be raring to go. We are all doing remarkably well on severe lack of sleep
column2: but need to get our body clocks back to some normality soon!

column1: Tomorrow we have been invited to attend a Hindu wedding in the city and witness the main part of the ceremony. There will be about 900 guests present
column2: which is small for this part of the world. Normally weddings have over 1000 guests
column3: which a far cry from the traditional church wedding in the UK. This is a surprise addition to our agenda

column1: and we're really excited to experience this part of Indian cullture. The wife of one of the Rotarians we met today will shaparone us at the wedding and explain/translate the ceremony for us which will be extremely useful.
Let's just hope we don't melt in the 32 degree forecasted temperature!!!
The food is a LOT spicer than any of us were expecting
column2: but all of it is delicious and cooked from fresh. We are all learning to scoop up the food with our right hand (left hand for cleaning only!) which is a challenge for me as a lefty
column3: using the chapati or naan bread. I think we will all increase our spice tolerance over the coming weeks and looking forward to trying the difference regional variations in dishes.

column2: the end of our first day here. I'm full of lovely food
column3: what a fantastic way to start!

column1: I've been given a new suitcase
column2: Thank you very much again! I've also managed to break into Di's to rescue her computer.

column1: If I can ignore the huge black spider that just ran in front of me
column2: I might be able to get to my room to sleep!

column1: After a very early start at Manchester
column2: a short trip to Heathrow and five hours in Bangalore
column3: we have arrived in Mangalore!

column1: We were waved off this morning by District Governor David Simpson and his wife Janet
column2: who both came to wave us goodbye. Despite some heavy suitcases and too much hand luggage
column3: we all made it here in one piece. My nerves were nowhere near as bad as I thought they would be and I managed to say goodbye to everybody without any tears!

column1: The first things that have stuck me are the amount of adverts in Bangalore airport for green and environmental initiatives. It seems naive but I didn’t consider that this would be a priority for people in India. Being in Bangalore still felt like being in an airport at home
column2: except for the beautiful Indian jewellery in the duty free! I was also very surprised to see copies of Fifty Shades on sale within the airport
column3: obviously Twitter has spread the word over here too.

column1: We have all withdrawn some rupees
column2: witnessed some sunshine (something we don’t see much of!) and also had our first experience of an Indian toilet. Nicola was first to

column1: The rail and road bridges to and from Mangalore

go and was shocked to open the toilet door at Bangalore airport to be faced by a small drain in the ground and a hose attached to the wall. Once she pushed the door further she did see the western toilet right beside the drain! I’m sure we will see worse during the next month! After crossing my fingers through a flight on a propeller plane
column2: we have just been met at Mangalore airport by a large group of our hosts. They decorated us with a bindi each and a garland of fresh flowers.

column1: We travelled to Mangalore Club hotel for a relaxing evening before the work starts. The hotel was occupied by the English and the names of the honorary secretaries since 1876 reflect this; Brown
column2: Black
column3: Morgan
column4: Davies
column5: Jackson........ We were all welcomed to the club with coconut juice fresh from the coconut but the lunch we enjoyed with the hosts from D.3180 was very spicy
column6: and I had to keep remembering to use my right hand. It is certainly different!

column1: The view from my room on the top floor is fantastic
column2: not sure about the beehive though! We are going to spend tonight relaxing and catching up on sleep. We are all a bit excited as we have been invited to a traditional Indian wedding tomorrow. Around 1000 guests will attend a ceremony which will last throughout the day. I am looking forward to seeing Indian culture up close and personal and sharing in the couple’s special day.

column1: The kind moustasted man with the newspaper sign with my name splet wrong probably made it a little easier last time
column2: after 18hrs of travel
column3: no sleep and an emerging sore thoat i was once again where i had stood almost 4 years ago
column4: bewildered and praying not to be ripped off i threw on my pack and walked into the crowd of taxi men
column5: my ill spoken Hindi and his inability to read made the location difficlut to get across and as the journey progressed i tried desperately to recognise something of the town i'd spent over a month in...

column1: When i arrived at the peace child office i was once again greeted by Viji
column2: a famalir face
column3: she is the interns house mother she cooks
column4: cleans and looks after you.

column1: It was now 5am and without sleep and a qucik glace at Tamzin i flopped down on to the same wooden bed and prayed for sleep...
I woke at 12 to the sound of voices in the kitchen
column2: Juile another intern and Sammy who works full time for Peace Child were having there lunch inbetween teaching at two local primary schools.

column1: Tamzin and the other intern Emily were at the boys home and wouldn't be back until 6.30pm.
Half asleep i tired to strick up conversation but as i began to realise how much things had changed
column2: my thought wandered and i kept myself to myself...

column1: While i waited locked into the office i lay in bed listening to the sounds
column2: breathing in the smells and feeling the heat
column3: it was only a few weeks before that i was stood in a marque in Emmbankment Gardens on the South Bank planning a party for 1700
column4: full face of make up and a smart black suit
column5: yet here i was laying on a plank of wood in baggy green silk throues and a purple salwa.

column1: Asia » India » Karnataka » Bangalore » Ganga Nagar
People have asked me over and over again ""Why are you doing this documentary Loretta?"" After all
column2: you already have a non profit that does this work and you're about to start your masters degree
column3: you're coaching clients and have a little startup. Is it really worth it?! How is this documentary really going to impact in the world?

column1: After being here in India I can tell you exactly why we are doing this and why it's so important.

If you haven't seen it yet (in the past couple posts from this trip) we are uncovering some beautiful gems who are going to be the fortune we need for a brighter future. They are girls and young women who are strong and making a change in the world. They are young women who are ready to make change. They are girls who are ready to shine and ready to dust off the debrie of systemic pressures and old belief systems that result in child marriage
column2: sexual violations
column3: misconceptions and views that females are a curse not a blessing. They are ready to fight for their freedom. They are ready to share their voice with the world.

column1: been watching the news you might have seen that we've been in India at a time where girls and women's rights are being rallied for after a young woman was raped on a moving bus and thrown out the doors in New Delhi. There have been rallies across India to press the govenment for change. Unfortunately that 23 yr old girl died today. This has to stop.
In the last 12 days here in Bangalore
column2: we've worked with 20 girls
column3: ages 11-18. Girls who's safety challenges are no different than that young woman on that bus. In their slum alone women are trafficked and assaulted daily. At least one woman a month dies or is killed. Almost all go unreported because they are female. The girl child is the most vulnerable.

column1: We've feel privileged to have provided these girls with leadership training skills and asked them questions that have challenged some norms. We've talked about safety
column2: body development
column3: communication
column4: and carrying themselves with confidence. We've learnt about their dreams and their values. We've danced with them
column5: we've made art with them
column6: we've sang with them
column7: eaten with them
column8: laughed with them
column9: and today shared some sad good byes.

column1: We've been invited in homes. We've interviews girls
column2: boys
column3: women and men about their lives
column4: their views
column5: and their opinions about equality. We've heard some extremely sad stories and some very powerful ones. We've cried while filming. We've tried really hard not to laugh while filming (apparently I'm not a great sound technician cause I can't keep quiet).

column2: as a team
column3: have had some really interesting and intense conversations. We've been able to provide 25 girls with a Pads4Girls kit (so they dont need to stay home a week a month)
column4: over 12 hours of Passion Project leadership development training
column5: and we've collected some inspiring stories that we believe will have a larger impact on those who will watch our film. We've also taken our mascot Passion (the sock monkey) on her first global trip
column6: and used her to engage girls with laughter and create a diverse sense of community. (see pictures on our Facebook page )

column1: I can't even put into words the impact this will have and has had not only on us but also on the girls.
Thank you to all our amazing supporters
column2: without you
column3: this would not be possible.

column1: journey has just started and we need your continued support and energy. PLEASE help us make our Global Giving campaign a success. If we reach our goal we get to expand our outreach and become a vested program with Global Giving in the USA.
Only 24 hours left to help make it happen! CLICK HERE

column2: Displayed: 16

column1: We've now been in Bangalore for 6 days and already I know I'm leaving a piece of my heart here with the girls in Vivek Nagar slum that are connected with Global Concerns Leadership India .
Alot of international workers will say ""Once you've seen one slum
column2: you seen them all."" I've heard that many times since starting international humanitarian work in 2008. I bet though they have not been here or met Brinda Adige. Here in Vivek Nagar slum
column3: imparticular the area where Brinda created the Global Concerns India office (a small 10x20 sqft room with a metal garbage pull down door)
column4: the energy and the people are a little different.

column1: Groups of women meet each month and share their concerns about their community
column2: their health
column3: their wellness
column4: and that of their children
column5: especially their daughters. On a regular basis their daughters
column6: their neices
column7: and neighbour's daughters go missing.

column1: On a weekly bases a woman dies or goes missing. Abuse and violence is ramped. These women though
column2: do their best to find and hold jobs
column3: they tend to their children
column4: they tend to their often abusive or drunk husbands
column5: they care about their neighbours
column6: and come together to talk regularly

column2: poverty
column3: and spousal abuse. They want change and they want to be involved in the process. Brinda the founder of Global Concerns makes sure they know their rights. She fights for their freedoms. Brinda and her staff go out and find the missing children and ensure their school fees are paid for. They have created an effective leadership program like I have never seen before. Tia
column4: Robyn
column5: Reem
column6: and I have been blown away at the devastation these girls and women face yet are in awe of the powerful community that Brinda has created.

column1: In order for the girls to be able to be part of our program
column2: the mothers needed to agree and they needed to sign our film/photo release forms. Brinda called all the women together. The mothers were quite concerned about the material we were going to cover because they wouldnt know how to answer any of their daughter's questions. We held a discussion
column3: asked alot of questions of them
column4: and they of us. It was such a moving circle. The women all agreed and actually insisted that Brinda also learn the Elements Of Sucess coaching program
column5: so she could also

column1: teach them. Brinda thanked me for creating more work for her. Before I leave I will be giving Maria and Zeena (Brinda's staff) a crash course on Passion Projects to add to their already amazing programs. I feel pretty honoured.

With the support of Maria and Zeena translating to the girls (most understand a basic English level) we have taught over 8 hours of Passion Project leadership training. We needed to break for Christmas holidays but will complete our training with an awesome art project that Tia created that ties into Passion Project leadership training (we'll post another blog before we leave). We will also provide the girls with a Pads4Girls kit and talk with them about honouring our bodies
column2: our female energy
column3: and hygiene. For maybe of you ""honouring our female energy"" might sound strange or airy fairy but the fact is that many girls here
column4: when we asked them
column5: would rather have been born a boy because it would have caused their families less troubles.

column1: After all the interviews we have done
column2: all the workshops
column3: all the questions
column4: all the observations I feel I could write another book (and perhaps I will after this documentary is completed).

column1: Tia and Loretta with some of our training group
Until then we'll keep at it
column2: with your support and energy.

column1: Speaking of which we have 10 days left on our campaign for Vietnam and the Philippines . If we make our goal of $5000 and 40 unique donors we become a vested program that can grow and gain charitable support in the US.
There are a good number of you who read this blog and offer your support to us in many ways
column2: today
column3: we need your support to make this happen. For as little as the cost of a movie ticket you can make a difference.

column1: So after travelling up the Western Ghatts through the mountains we took a 9 hour bus journey to Bangalore
column2: which is one of the craziest cities I've been to in India
column3: and then a 13 hour train journey to one of our target destinations Hampi. It was definatly NOT what we expected! after travelling around the cities and towns of India Hampi was a welcome break from dusty roads and extremely busy city and town centres.

column1: Hampi is famous for its temples and the amazing rock formations that surround the area. We stayed across the river from the main town and after a 9 hour bus journay and a 13 hour train journey we were gladly met by the first person who offered us accomodation across the river. We stayed in mud huts for 3 pound a night and they had a restaurant attached that over looked the river with temples in view.
Hampi has got the feeling of Goa
column2: is really laid back and you can easliy lose a day just doing nothing! there is a local resevoir that everyone goes to for swimming and we rented scooters for the day to have a look about. On our

column1: last day we took a Tuk Tuk tour of some of the temples
column2: which are pretty amazing to say the least (Check the photos below 😊 ) and packed our bags ready for our last stop in India for Christmas . . . we are heading back to Goa 😊
Displayed: 9

column1: Sometimes best communications happens when you're on separate bikes.
I Still remember that drizzling cold midnight
column2: it was in the end of year 2012
column3: winter probably. I had a shower that late night and then got my bull ready
column4: warmed up the engine
column5: held the helmet in the hand and slowly started riding bullet in a zig-zag way on the empty outer ring road of Bangalore humming an old hindi track

column1: Bas ek nigaaah ho pyaaar ki
I was on my way to my friends' room to join them for a whole new chapter of ‘Motorcycle Diaries’ on my Royal Bull. The worst thing happened as I reached friend's room
column2: could not wake my friends up from their dead sleep as they hear neither my voice nor my mobile call.

column1: Since they stay at third floor
column2: they should have at least kept the ground floor gate open
column3: which locks anyone in entering inside the apartment
column4: they forgot that as well. So
column5: now I can’t even knock their door on the third floor of the apartment. I lost all my cool and dropped the food I bought for them.

column2: almost a hundred times (exaggerated round-off)
column3: I did even throw stones to their window
column4: no use! Can you imagine this scene around 1.30am? I was on my way back to room
column5: and my blood became as hot as engine crank.

column2: around 4.00 in the morning
column3: My cell phone started ringing! I picked the call
column4: No response from either side.

column2: then small spark of lightning
column3: and then the thunder explosion...
column4: I exploded like anything over the phone!Finally cooled down after a while
column5: after all what’s friends for all?

column1: Thadiyandamol is the highest peak in Coorg. Its windy peak offers unhindered views of impressive mountain ranges and valleys of Coorg and beyond. Neatly stacked layers of hills align one behind the other
column2: extending to the horizon and gently merging into the blue sky. Sensuous curves of the ridges lead down the peak and further up to the next one and the next
column3: eventually disappearing into the mist somewhere faraway
column4: inviting the beholder to walk along them and lose themselves in the mystery that the depth of the hills seem to convey.

column1: Beholding the tremendous natural beauty of the scapes by all my senses
column2: I praised The Lord of all the worlds.

column1: Almost without exception the initial exposure elicits a profound feeling of wonderment and awe
column2: mixed with a certain amount of repulsion and bewilderment. That first encounter with any of the possible ports of entry is an assault on the senses: the myriad colours of the disparate mass of milling humanity; the cacophony of sound; the jostling
column3: jousting multitude of vehicles; roaming beasts; heady aromas of incense
column4: cut flowers
column5: spices and sandalwood battling the astringent stench of urine and stagnant effluent; and
column6: unless arriving in a Delhi winter
column7: all bathed in a stifling
column8: oppressive heat. Juxtaposed
column9: like nowhere else on earth
column10: are tarmac and dirt
column11: wealth and poverty
column12: the mouth-watering and the repugnant
column13: the hi-tech and the medieval
column14: suited businessmen and loin clothed or naked sadhus
column15: ladies in stunning sari/choli combinations and filthy rag-wrapped old crones
column16: munificent kindness and indignant rudeness
column17: trendy iphone-sporting youths and desperate broken and twisted beggars
column18: the obese and the starving. India: our first love; the one country – to date – that we can never imagine tiring of. For the western traveller it defines culture-shock. That said
column19: like all gut-churning
column20: head-spinning infatuations the passion – the frissance - is inevitably tempered by familiarity. This

column2: felt more like being reacquainted with a dear but unpredictable old friend
column3: one who you can never quite define – and therein lies the magic of the relationship.

column1: We flew from Colombo to Chennai
column2: lucky to be chasing the tail of the cyclone and having avoided its brunt. Previously one of our least favourite Indian cities
column3: Chennai immediately welcomed: simple rail-links to the city centre
column4: good cheap accommodation and excellent food. Chai stands are once again everywhere (although seemingly always referred to as tea stalls these days) and real masala tea (ginger and cardamom-infused) is well worth the few extra rupees. The amalgam of boiling milk and steeped tea is still – magically - mixed by the elaborate repeated pouring from one elevated
column5: head-high vessel into another at waist height.

column3: more than a quarter of a billion (250

column6: following rain

column1: Inside Arunachaleswar temple at Tiruvannamalai there was the sad spectacle of a performing elephant. It was surreal to witness an elephant inside a building
column2: but also distressing to see it pacing-time
column3: head swaying back and forth

column5: hurling the crowd aside and crashing blindly through the maze of pillars. Actually
column6: there have been a large number of deaths recently at the hands of wild elephants drawn close to towns by shrinking water holes

column1: Maybe after two months in Sri Lanka – where they are also staunch proponents – we are becoming immune to the ubiquitous Indian head waggle. I’m sure we go days without witnessing/receiving it; saying that
column2: Ali reckons that I’m a bigger user than most locals. As I am totally unaware of having adopted it – let alone what I mean by it – I now feel it is unfair to expect the Indian’s usage to convey any set message.

column1: From headshakes to handshakes; and this note really should have featured in the Sri Lanka blog as that is where Ali first experienced it. Rarely

column5: to be pressed into her palm. She feels it has some unpleasant sexual connotation (and I’m sure she’s right

column7: withering

column1: to Mysore in Karnataka. These days the ticket classes have been re-jigged. Seven years ago there were first class sleepers and first class chairs (luxurious
column2: possibly even with AC – we were never to take one)
column3: second class sleepers with two or three tiers of bunks; second class seats and finally (and most certainly a last resort) wooden-benched third class seats. All grades could be reserved in advance with the exception of third class and some second class seats. Our target
column4: for a journey of any real length
column5: was always the two upper
column6: facing bunks in three-tier second class. During the day the middle tier is dropped so that all passengers can sit on the bottom bunk. The top bunk always remains in place
column7: giving the occupier the choice of lying down at any point during the journey – it is also closest (indeed beware if you have long hair) to the ceiling fans. Today there are air-conditioned compartments comprising just two bunks (1AC)
column8: four bunks in two tiers (2AC) or six bunks in three (3AC). Non-A.C. is limited to an open carriage of sleeper class and the new lowest grade
column9: second class seats; apparently there is nolonger a third

column9: sure enough
