column1: Western tourists are obviously a rarity in Bidar and the usual questions of “What country?”
column2: “What’s your name?” and “How many children?” were typically replaced with – in the nicest possible way - “Why you come here?”.

from here we will head to Nagpur where we hope (subject to ticket availability) to attend several days of the last Test match – we’ll be wearing the Burmese hats (keep your eyes peeled for us on the television).
five weeks into India and (I am touching wood at this point) not a single stomach bug – how times have changed.
I can’t resist a quick mini resume of the last twelve months: Hong Kong
column3: China (very superficially – back there next year)
column4: Laos
column5: Cambodia
column6: Thailand (just passing through)
column7: Malaysia
column8: Indonesia (seven islands)
column9: Myanmar
column10: Sri Lanka and India (on-going).

column1: It has to be said that this doesn’t seem like a lot of countries for a year and
column2: for that matter
column3: it is only four new countries for us. Still
column4: it has been a fantastic year and one we’re very

column2: Bidar
now that I have a list of countries in front of me I see that few wouldn’t merit special mention; however
column3: for us the Cambodian’s
column4: Sumatrans
column5: Myanmar and Sri Lankans were very
column6: very special indeed. Hell
column7: the Laos were delightful; whilst the Chinese are far friendlier now than we remembered them. On a negative note
column8: many touristic areas of Bali and Lombok in Indonesia should be ashamed of themselves; whilst the Thai’s seem plain jaded.

column1: b) Sights: China (and so much more to see); certain Indonesian islands (Sumatra: almost everything we were privileged to experience
column2: Lombok’s Mt. Rinjaniand Suluweisi
column3: not to mention the sunsets
column4: orangs
column5: dragons and snorkeling); and Myanmar’s Bagan.

column1: c) Food: Every country has provided something exceptional (save Hong Kong where we know they have it
column2: but price prohibited enjoying it – they do have great Maccy Ds though). Laos for banana flower and rattan salads and Tai Dam food (Papaya restaurant was magnificent); Cambodia for their special – and at no extra cost – pizzas; Melakain Malaysia for sublime noodles; goes without saying anything cooked by Mark;
Tiruvannamalai

column1: Indonesia for the gorengan and Warung Bambu’s pelecing kangkung and bakso; Myanmar for its Shan and Mon cuisines; Sri Lanka’s veggie curries – yes
column2: I am thinking of Mrs.Bawa’s; and India is just simply food heaven.

column1: d) Alcohol: It has to be said that China can out budget anyone in South East Asia in terms of beer (lager)
column2: although both Laos and Cambodia (and Malaysia’s duty-free LangKawi) have notably cheap brews; Indonesia and Sri Lanka for their variations on palm and rice wines – the latter in particular for the ambiance of the drinking experience.

column1: e) All round backpacker price-friendliness: current thinking would beLaos but we’re still saying India
column2: although it is no way as clear cut as it once was. The big surprises were that Myanmar and Sri Lanka really can be experienced on a small budget (both cheaper than Laos for us
column3: plus Laos didn’t have to absorb any flights). Indeed South East Asia is still backpacker heaven pricewise (just don’t rely on Lonely-sell-out-Planet for any bargains) - even with 16 flight tickets and 16 visas we are still averaging a fraction under $40/day ($39.96 as

column1: I type) between us and we weren’t expecting that.

column2: Displayed: 38
and my Travel Blog countdown is nearly to the single digits.

column1: I will likely put up a couple more blogs before my India Adventure concludes (We still have a Christmas celebration to document!)
column2: but I wanted to take a moment to reflect on my time here
column3: and on what December brings for me and the students.

column1: I know that I've mainly written positive things for my blog entries
column2: and I know that many of you are probably asking
column3: ""Is it really that great over there?"" And the answer is that I guess I've been a little dishonest in my writing. It hasn't all be great. There are days (especially recently) when I want to run to my room screaming
column4: ""BUT I'M NOT EVEN PAID FOR THIS JOB!"" I am often confronted with ""surprises
column5: like a fundraising concert where the choir had to brush-up/learn seven songs in eleven days (more on the concert in a moment)
column6: or when the 12th graders are suddenly thrown into a block schedule of studying and testing that not only conflicts with half of my time with the 11th graders
column7: but makes it so I am working virtually the whole

column1: This little dude is quite the cutie. He is a second grader
column2: but he's much smaller than his other classmates
column3: and his energy is just adorable.

column1: school day (and before and after for prep
column2: choir
column3: voice lessons
column4: and PT). I don't do well with scheduling surprises. I need 24 hours to process
column5: and that has often not been given to me (or my supervisor
column6: for that matter).

column2: here's the thing: Even after a truly dreadful day
column3: like this past Monday
column4: where the 12th graders are sleepy and I'm so stressed I can't make decisions
column5: something beautiful happens. On Monday
column6: this came in the form of Creative Writing with the 8th graders. I was just given this class the week previous
column7: to fill a gap created by a departed volunteer. I was not looking forward to ending my Monday with them
column8: as my first class with them the previous week had been hellish: I had been so excited to talk about archetypes with them by sharing one of my favorite concept albums (Light Chasers by Cloud Cult...so beautiful) and having them write a story inspired by the archeypal events the music follows
column9: but they did not understand and continued interrupting me before I could explain. And then
column10: when I came to pick up the first part of their stories on Friday
column11: not a single one

column1: of them had done the homework because they were ""too busy studying for exams."" When they told me this
column2: I had to walk out of the room before I said something I'd regret. Instead
column3: I vented to Lizzy
column4: and I know she and several other staff members reprimanded them
column5: so I was also wary of how the 8th graders would react to the project (the album was only about half-completed) now that they'd gotten in trouble over it. But when I came in this Monday
column6: the students were apologetic and then
column7: after we listened to a few more songs
column8: legitimately involved in the project. Of course
column9: I also made some adjustments to clarify things
column10: but they met me halfway
column11: and by the end some were singing along. Some stayed after class to listen to the final song. Where I (and perhaps they) had least expected it
column12: we ended up having a wonderful time.

column1: I think this is one of the reasons I like teaching. You can take it on a day-to-day basis and
column2: although something may go horribly
column3: you are forced to either face the issue or determine it is negligable the next day and move forward. Either way

column1: This picture reveals so much about my students. Sujatha
column2: the one behind her hands
column3: is a mischievous 11th Grader. Nickhil
column4: in the red
column5: is always very chill. Shrimathi
column6: smiling
column7: loves attention. And Vijay
column8: in the stripes
column9: often looks a little tired (especially in class) :-D

column1: I have learned that humans of any age have ample capacities for forgiveness. If only it could be exercised more outside of the classroom.

column2: this past week has also felt insane because we have been preparing for a fundraising concert. A group of 34 choir members has been rehearsing with me an hour every night
column3: losing some of their precious studying time for exams (starting December 3). I am so proud of the work they have done
column4: but rehearsals haven't been without their struggles. The performance space doesn't have any piano
column5: so we had to record the accompanist
column6: and I don't think the students understand just how much their accompanists have been adjusting to their fluctuating speeds--I cannot tell you how many complaints I've received about the speed of the recordings. They also are not used to actively watching a conductor
column7: which is more necessary than ever now that we don't have live accompaniment. But
column8: except for ""Memories
column9: which the students found either too fast or too slow
column10: depending on who was talking
column11: we brought everything together nicely for the performance.

column1: We all packed onto a bus and rode for 1.5 hours to Rainbow Drive
a gated community outside of Bangalore. Apparently
column2: SB students don't travel very much
column3: and are prone to terrible motion sickness. In light of this
column4: each student was given a ""vomit cover"" (cover being the word used for bag) and some chewing gum. I was lucky to be sitting with some folks who were decidedly not carsick. Lizzy brough her speakers and ipod
column5: so we listened to music and danced and played a (slightly unfair) game of ""Never Have I Ever."" When we arrived
column6: we set up and then were given delicious food. We didn't have enough time to rehearse anything on the stage
column7: which was unfortunate
column8: and the audience didn't really finish arriving until 30 minutes after we were supposed to start
column9: which was also unfortunate. The kids were antsy
column10: as we had already seated them in front of the audience
column11: and so they were put under scrutiny for an extended period of time.

column1: When the concert finally did begin
column2: we had several problems with sound
column3: and at first I could not hear the music from my conducting spot. I changed location
column4: which improved my hearing significantly
column5: and although the choir was clearly nervous and unused to singing in large echoey spaces
column6: they were extremely attentive
column7: and we managed to pull through. After the concert
column8: we were given cake and juice boxes
column9: which are very special treats for the kids.

column2: here I am
column3: sitting in a hotel room in Bangalore on Sunday morning
column4: taking what I've deemed a ""Me-Weekend."" I only have twelve more days left in India
column5: so this will likely be my last chance to explore outside of SB. It's strange
column6: to roam a city alone after spending most of your days at a secluded school. When I return to SB
column7: it will be time for exams and more choir rehearsals for the ""German Party"" next weekend--another event in Bangalore that SB students go to each year because the attendees are some of our biggest sponsors. But for now
column8: I'm just going to relax
column9: meet a friend of a friend for lunch
column10: and take some time to reflect.

column1: I made a promise in my last entry that I would dedicate this entry to ruins and the movie Up
column2: and I have no intention of disappointing (I know you all must be sitting at the edge of your seats
column3: dying to hear about both). First
column4: some ruins
column5: and then I'll move on to this Upbusiness when I get to that part of the story.

column1: Our ruins exploration took several different forms over a couple of days: One day
column2: we walked to one end of the Bazaar and wandered around
column3: and the next we went to the other end of the Bazaar
column4: where the Virupaksha Temple is
column5: and Peter and I took a bike tour from there (Ally doesn't bike so well
column6: so Bitsy agreed to walk around with her instead of touring with us).

column2: I want to give a little disclaimer: I was inundated with a lot of interesting information over this week
column3: but I wouldn't be surprised if I wrote something down incorrectly. If
column4: by any means
column5: I misspeak about a tradition or concept
column6: I would like to apologize in advance
column7: and invite you to bring light to the mistake. the last

column1: One of hundreds of pictographs at the Rama Temple
column2: all telling the story of the Ramanyana.

column1: thing I want to do is provide everyone with a ton of misinformation.)
A little bit of background regarding the ruins
column2: and why they are where they are
column3: surrounding the little town of Hampi: The ruins are from the 7th c.-16 c.
column4: and display the growth of an empire that at one time covered half of India. Hampi was the hub of this empire
column5: and the Hampi Bazaar was once filled with vendors selling precious jewels. Hampi's golden age was from around 1520-1560
column6: but ended when it was invaded and subsequently occupied for a grand total of 6 months. After that time
column7: the invaders moved on
column8: but took Hampi's wealth and any chance of rebuilding the empire with them.

column1: When you walk to the end opposite the Virupaksha Temple
column2: you are greeted by this fantastic monolithic bull. In Hinduism
column3: bull-statues are called nandi
column4: and they are a symbol of Shiva. The monolithic bull is impressive
column5: but can no longer be considered holy because it is broken. Hampi is actually home to a one-of-a-kind nandi (a very small one
column6: but memorable all the same) with three heads
column7: which is believed to symbolize the unity of the three main gods:

column2: the Generator; Vishnu
column3: the Operator; and Shiva
column4: the Destroyer. Get it? Generator Operator Destroyer. GOD. My tour guide's
column5: Hanuman's (yes
column6: just like the monkey-god)
column7: face lit up when he told us that trick to remember the key Hindu gods.

column1: But I'm getting ahead of myself. Back to our un-guided ruin-wandering.
After you passed the monolithic nandi
column2: you descended into a large temple
column3: complete with deteriorating columns and doorways. Bitsy and I sat and admired the architecture for quite some time
column4: enjoying the quiet
column5: the rest (this was the same day as the Hanuman Temple climb)
column6: and the shade.

column2: all of a sudden
column3: I heard it.

column2: I didn't believe my ears
column3: but then it happened again
column4: and I told Bitsy
column5: and she listened for it too. It happened a third time
column6: and there was no denying it.

column2: so that was enough drama for a not-so-dramatic moment
column3: but I will be perfectly honest that this made my day. For those of you who are not familiar with the movie Up
column4: or for those who need a refresher
column5: Kevin is the large fictional bird (called a ""snipe"") that

column2: colorful dodo. She has a very distinct call--one that cannot be mistaken--and we definitely heard her many times somewhere in the rocky distance. I did some research
column3: and found out that she was designed to resemble the male himilayan monal pheasant
column4: but when I listened to the call of said pheasant
column5: I was disappointed to find it completely different from Kevin's. So
column6: in short
column7: I have no idea what type of bird I heard
column8: but I like to imagine there is a giant chocolate-loving snipe roaming among the boulders of Hampi.

column1: And while I'm on the subject of boulders: One of the things that baffled me when I first started walking around Hampi is that there are many boulders with a thin line of square holes across its face. It turns out that this is evidence of harvested rock. Quarriers would make little nodules in which they would squeeze squares of wood. When the wood got wet
column2: it would expand
column3: and break the rock.

column2: when we went into Virupaksha Temple (before the bike tour)
column3: we were told to go to the river to see Lakshmi the Elephant get her bath. She later

column1: The site from which we heard Kevin.
blessed Peter and Ally (put her trunk over their heads). Peter was then approached by a couple of tour guides
column2: both with whom he had agreed to go on tours. They were from the same company
column3: but what Peter didn't realize was that they worked independently during the same hours
column4: so they decided to ask him to choose which one he wanted to be our guide. He chose Hanuman (to whom he had spoken earlier than the other)
column5: and we certainly were not disappointed.

column1: Hanuman took us to a bike rental place and outfitted us with some really nice 1-speed bikes (no
column2: really
column3: they were well-kept). He led us to about eight or so stops
column4: mostly temples of various sorts. We learned that Virupaksha Temple was considered a very holy place because Vishnu's symbol
column5: the lingam (which is a cylindrical
column6: basically unmarked slab of rock)
column7: was naturally found there without human alteration. We visited a couple of Ganesha temples with broken monoliths (""Peanut Ganesha
column8: named after the shape of the dent in his belly; and ""Mustard Ganesha
column9: named so because the man who built it made all of his money as a mustard seed vendor). Across from Mustard Ganesha

column1: Somewhere in the direction of Kevin.

column2: with what looks like a beautiful pool. Turns out that it was actually a tank used for holy water
column3: and was blessed at least once a year by a procession walking around it clockwise (you always do this at Hindu temples).

column1: We also visited the Hazara Rama Temple which
column2: if I remember correctly
column3: is supposed to be on the site of Rama and Sita's wedding. In any case
column4: the temple is covered with a series of pictograms that tell the Ramanyana
column5: and after Hanuman (the guide) was finished giving us a brief description and showed us the very beginning of the story
column6: Peter found the pictograph of Hanuman (the god) showing Rama's ring to Sita (see part 2 if you have no idea what I'm talking about). That made us feel like quite the accomplished students.

column2: that's all for ruins and Kevin...but WAIT! There's more action-packed adventure to come! Filled with bicycle accidents and train-chases and McDonalds!
for now
column3: much love from India!

column2: friends. Now for the second installment of my holiday adventures (or
column3: should I say
column4: ""Now to our featured presentation!""):

column2: we decided to go to the Hanuman Temple on Anjaneya Hill. This temple is still-functioning
column3: and is one of about four places that claims to be the birthplace of Hanuman
column4: a very important monkey god.

column1: Some background on Hanuman: He plays a huge role in the Ramanyana
column2: the epic tale of Rama's (one of Vishnu's incarnations) battles against the 10-headed demon king of Sri Lanka. The tale begins with the demon king's abduction of Sita (Rama's wife). Hanuman becomes one of Rama's followers and
column3: when Rama is unable to cross a large body of water to get to Sri Lanka
column4: Hanuman leaps (or ""flies like Superman"" according to a tour guide) across with Rama's ring to show Sita that he is a friend. Of course
column5: there is a lot more to tell
column6: but that gives you an idea of Hanuman's devotion.

column2: we had to take a rickshaw to the river
column3: then cross the river by boat because there is no functioning bridge in the area. The boat was

column1: The reason why we needed to take a boat to get to Hanuman Temple

column2: but it was a short ride and the morning air was lovely. We then had to take another rickshaw by lush fields and through small towns to the base of Anjaneya Hill.
the temple is up about 570 steps
column3: and even in the morning sun
column4: it was a difficult climb. But once we reached the top
column5: we were welcomed by a beautiful view
column6: prayer-chanting in a small shrine
column7: and monkeys. For a long time
column8: we kneeled in the dark shrine and listened to the chanters
column9: who were doing a call-and-response. Then I went back out to enjoy the scenery
column10: while the others stayed inside.

column2: they each had bindis on their foreheads
column3: and they directed me to another small room where I could be blessed by Hanuman. As soon as I entered the shrine
column4: I wished I had seen someone else perform the blessing ceremony first. There were several local women and a boy kneeling in the room
column5: and a small table spread with various dishes and items
column6: and I had no idea where to start. The women looked at me expectantly for a moment
column7: then
column8: realizing my panic

column1: made a gesture to the boy. He took a small spoon and put holy water into my cupped hands
column2: which the women then gestured for me to drink. I tried
column3: but it basically just touched my lips because I hesitated too long and the water was already falling from between my fingers. Then the boy gave me a handful of sugar
column4: and I was told to eat that
column5: which I did readily. After that
column6: there was a long awkward pause
column7: in which I figured I was supposed to put the bindi on my forehead
column8: but I could not figure out in the dim light which bowl held the powder. The boy seemed hesitant
column9: too (maybe he was not allowed to help me with that part?)
column10: and eventually one of the women stood and put the bindi on my forehead. I thanked her and the others as best I could
column11: but I have to admit that I came out feeling like a fool. Hopefully Hanuman understands that I had the best intentions.

column2: I noticed Peter disappearing over a big boulder behind the shrine. When I looked closer
column3: I realized that there were man-made steps at the base

column1: and so I decided to do some climbing
column2: too. It turns out that there is a path laid out to a small man-made pond and a single tree among the rocks
column3: straight from your favorite kung-fu movie. The view from was amazing
column4: and the openness at the very top of the hill made you want to stay up there forever.

column1: I'm going to save my ruins exploits from this day and the next for my next entry
column2: but I also wanted to point out that we discovered another fabulous restuarant in Hampi called the Bamboo Tree. It is a roof-top place
column3: with low tables and cushions and pretty darn good naan. It would be a great place to sit back and read a book
column4: though I never got the opportunity to do so.

column2: temples
column3: and how I found a little bit of ""Up"" in India.

column2: Displayed: 7
we took an overnight bus from Bangalore to Hospet
column3: which is next to Hampi. On Wednesday we took an overnight train to Hyderabad. On Friday we took another overnight train back to Bangalore.

column2: this week has certainly been quite the adventure. There is quite a bit that I'd love to tell you all
column3: but I'm getting the feeling that it may take a while for me to sprinkle all of my impressions into my various entries. I certainly can't put it all in one
column4: because it would look a bit like a novella in length. So
column5: I've decided to break certain ideas/observations into specific topic-entries. But I thought it'd be nice to give a general overview of my travels here and in a few subsequent entries.

column2: with a fine mediterranean meal on the roof of a nice
column3: clean mall. It was the most lavish meal I've had in India to date
column4: but I am finding more and more that I don't really crave fancy food here. I'm far more interested in trying the local dishes. In any case
column5: we arrived at the bus station full and happy.

column1: Allow me to give some background: ""We"" refers to the five intrepid travellers who set off for Hampi. There was my roommate
column2: Ally
column3: my On-Site Administrator
column4: Lizzy
column5: and two other coworkers
column6: Bitsy and Peter. Lizzy left our group on

column1: We look more comfortable than we are.

column2: and Bitsy went back on Wednesday night
column3: leaving Ally
column4: Peter
column5: and me to the mercy of Hyderabad (more on that later :-) ). The intended itinerary was to arrive at Hampi on Sunday morning
column6: and to leave for Hyderabad on Wednesday night (arriving Thursday morning). Hampi (pronounced ""Hum-pee""--the kids told us to think of humming while peeing) is known for its ruins and rocky vistas. Hyderabad is a large city known for its pearls
column7: but also with some recommended museums/areas.

column2: the night bus to Hampi was dreadful. When it comes to public transportation
column3: I am pretty relaxed
column4: but this bus made me realize just how uncomfortable transportation can be. All night buses without beds are pretty bad
column5: but remember how I said that honking was the only mode of vehicle communication in India? Well
column6: that doesn't change when the sun goes down. Even in the country
column7: you'd just start to nod off and the bus horn would stab you through one ear and out the other. And I was lucky enough to be next to a vertical pole
column8: so when I jerked my head up in surprise
column9: I'd wham it against the pole. The

column1: Shown off by the lovely Lizzy and Bitsy.
frequent sudden braking caused similar discomfort.
And then there was the bathroom incident. The bus stopped about four times total for an 8-hour drive
column2: and the first one was nearly 1/2 an hour long. Bitsy
column3: Lizzy
column4: and I thought that the second stop would be about as long
column5: so we got off to use the toilet. It was my first pit toilet experience
column6: but I got through it well
column7: and came out of the bathroom very proud of myself. Bitsy was there waiting for me
column8: and we walked out together. But when we got out
column9: the bus was already moving. Lizzy was nowhere in sight
column10: but we ran and one of the bus drivers was out there calling to us. Luckily
column11: Lizzy got on the bus before us to point out that we were still in the bathroom. We laughed it off
column12: but I can't help but be grateful that we were not left at a toilet in the middle of nowhere at night. That would be a whole different adventure entirely!

column2: we arrived at the Hospet station (30 minutes from Hampi) intact
column3: and after evading some very pushy rickshaw drivers
column4: managed to catch the

column1: The site of the Ganesha Immersion procession.
first bus into Hampi. I made the mistake of letting my guard down at this point--I imagined that we would get off the bus
column2: get breakfast
column3: and stroll around to find a nice hotel. But
column4: as soon as we pulled into the Hampi Bazaar
column5: a mob of business owners surrounded us
column6: pushing maps and business cards into our hands (and taking them back away when we did not agree to follow them). They followed us for about fifteen minutes
column7: bombarding us with recommendations every time we stopped to discuss a possible plan of action. Eventually
column8: they began to trickle away
column9: but two or three stuck around for much longer
column10: most notably the owner of the Gopi Hotel and Restaurant (which looked like a good enough establishment
column11: but in which I swore I would never step foot because of the owner's overbearing pushiness). There were guest houses everywhere in the little city proper and it was the off-season
column12: so we had our pick. The problem was
column13: the hotel that we arbitrarily picked from the guidebook in the frenzy of being followed turned out to be recently demolished. Tired
column14: unbathed
column15: and hungry
column16: we finally allowed ourselves to be guided to the Moon

column1: This girl was among the children running around during the festivities at the Ganesha Immersion procession. She was rather surprised that I asked to take her photo
column2: but obliged.

column1: I have come to understand that it doesn't matter where in the world a small town is; the small-town web of connections exists in Hampi as much as it does in Morris. The restaurant owner picked up on our dilemma pretty quickly
column2: and kindly recommended his cousin's guest house. His daughter even made some calls to make sure there were two rooms available. Grateful for the guidance
column3: we checked it out (Manju Guest House--I highly recommend it)
column4: and were pleased to find it clean and spacious.

column1: And so--though the prologue to our trip was rather stressful--began the amazing visit to Hampi.
By the time we were all settled in our hotel
column2: it was only about 10 a.m.
column3: so we had a whole day to look forward to. We started wandering the streets and looking in the little shops. The streets in the town proper are small
column4: with colorful buildings and wash hanging on the lines. There is no doubt that Hampi is a tourist town
column5: as there was a travel agent
column6: cyber cafe
column7: bike rental
column8: and guest house on every block. But
column9: as it was the off-season
column10: it was not too crowded (even

column1: The Ganesha statue that was eventually immersed into the river
with the dozens of cows roaming the narrow roads)
column2: and although the shop owners were very vocal in asking us to look at their wares
column3: we were no longer harassed or followed. The typical Hampi response to ""No
column4: thank you
column5: was a smile and
column6: ""Maybe tomorrow"" as if there would be enough tomorrows to satisfy every request.

column1: I stumbled upon my favorite little shop toward the end of the afternoon. It was basically unmarked
column2: but had walls coverred with figurines and postcards and secondhand books. I found a pile of ""singing bowls"" on a bottom shelf
column3: and asked the store owner about the purpose of the different tones. Before I knew it
column4: I was sitting on the floor with the shopkeeper
column5: trying to play various sizes and shapes of bowl. When water is put into an unblemished hand-made bowl
column6: it will begin to sparkle and leap when the bowl is played. The shop keeper was very good at it
column7: and patient when I had trouble figuring out how to hold the bowl and stick. Eventually
column8: Peter joined in
column9: and we were all playing an atonal symphony. Absolutely beautiful!

column2: we determined that we wanted to go to
on a banana leaf.
which came highly recommended by everybody we talked to. We had some trouble finding it
column3: though
column4: and ended up on the Hampi Bazaar. Good thing
column5: too
column6: because nobody would have been at the restaurant. Turns out that it was the fifth day of celebrating Ganesha's birthday
column7: and we were in for a treat.

column1: Some background on Ganesha: He is the elephant-headed god of good fortune
column2: and the son of Parvati
column3: wife of Shiva. While Shiva was out
column4: Parvati bore a baby god to protect her while she bathed. The new god did
column5: but was thought an intruder and beheaded by Shiva upon Shiva's return. Parvati was distraught and insisted that Shiva find a new head for her child
column6: and he brought back an elephant's head. In remembrance of this story
column7: stautes of Ganesha are immersed in local bodies of water on an ordained day (which varies depending on who you're talking to).

column2: we stumbled upon the Immersion procession on Hampi Bazaar
column3: and were almost immmediately greeted by a crowd of locals and a sprinkling of foreign visitors like us. The Ganesha statue was in a trailer on the back of a tractor (again
column4: some small town things are strikingly familiar)
column5: and people were passing by
column6: giving their respects to the deity. Soon
column7: there was drumming
column8: and dancing
column9: and kids started running around to slap red or yellow chalk on people's faces. At first
column10: I was wary of joining in the dancing
column11: because it seemed to be mostly local men and children
column12: but then male tourists and eventually female tourists joined in
column13: and by sunset
column14: the procession was underway. A small local girl asked me to put her on my shoulders
column15: and we had a blast bopping around. Ally was carrying the girl's friend
column16: so they would grab hands and dance together on our shoulders.

column1: The procession took a total of about 1 1/2 hours to get to the riverside (1-2 kms.)
column2: because we'd take a few steps
column3: and then the drums would start up again and people would get swept up in the dancing again. Eventually
column4: the road became a rocky path and Ganesha had to be carried by several men. As we moved down to the river
column5: the drumming stopped and the chanting began. We walked by haunting ruins in the rock-face
column6: and through a small cavern to the bank of the river. Once there
column7: we sat and watched by flashlight as Ganesha was immersed in the water. Beautiful.

column1: We capped off the night with the long-awaited visit to the Mango Tree
column2: which served us delicious food on banana leaves. It was a perfect ending to an eventful
column3: wonderful day.

column1: Stay tuned for more on ruins
column2: monkeys
column3: and trains
column4: coming soon to a computer near you!

column1: Bangalore has a slight traffic problem. The city has turned into an Indian powerhouse
column2: and is the hub of the IT and telcoms explosion that is driving unprecedented growth in southern India. However
column3: I'm sure the founding fathers never imagined their native town would become a major city on the subcontinent. As such
column4: the streets of Bangalore weren't designed on a grid
column5: and the city centre is a mishmash of one way streets that wend their way around town like a sinuous snake. The traffic is the worst I've experienced in India
column6: and the inevitable result of the chaos makes for some prodigious traffic jams. So what does an Indian do when their car or bike has their progress impeded
column7: yes you guessed it
column8: it's time to lean on the horn. Bangalore is a cacophony of noise and traffic
column9: but the centre of the city based around Cubbin park is pleasantly clean and modern.

column2: constant reader
column3: to bring you up to speed. We left off in Goa
column4: with your humble correspondent feeling sick as a dog in a Goa resort town. It's not an ideal situation
column5: to be sure
column6: but it is the situation nevertheless.

column1: I farewelled the staff and travellers from the guest house
column2: and jumped a taxi for the hour long drive back to Dabolim airport. From there I hopped on a Go Air jet for the one hour flight to Bangalore
column3: and then jumped a further taxi for the long drive into town. I booked into the recommended Sumanjay homestay in the heart of the city
column4: and had a few days to explore this excellent city. There's a long term guest from Switzerland staying at the homestay
column5: and the friendly Indian owners made me feel very welcome. I'm still feeling quite fragile
column6: but am well enough to get out and about to explore the sights.

column1: It's amazing how illness dents one's confidence
column2: and my first morning in Bangalore I was nervous as a racehorse before heading out. However
column3: it's simply a matter of getting back on the bike
column4: and as soon as I left the guesthouse to negotiate with auto (tuk tuk) drivers it all started to come together. I spent the first day exploring Cubbin park
column5: and the famous monuments in the vicinity. It's likely you will become hopelessly lost in this city of one way streets
column6: but once I

column1: gave in to the situation and just asked the locals for directions at crucial intersections I was able to find my way eventually. The parliament and high court buildings are impressive
column2: and Cubbin park itself is great for walking around.

column1: There's one daily ritual I seem to go through on the subcontinent
column2: where I say something slowly and clearly to an English speaker. They reply with something weird
column3: sometimes not even related to the topic as far as I can discern. I look confused
column4: then repeat myself and get the answer I was seeking first time around. But the important thing is that Indians are an engaging and friendly nation of people
column5: who will do what they can to help travellers get by in this complex country. I spent a pleasant first evening over dinner with the Swiss guy from the homestay
column6: where we traded stories about India over a beer and an excellent meal. It was great to get out to a quality restaurant in the heart of the entertainment district.

column1: I set out next morning to explore Lalbagh botanical gardens
column2: which is around five kilometres further out from the city centre. The park is
featuring a vast variety of species set in luscious grounds. The gardens are so big I spent over two hours exploring the park
column3: and bumped into several friendly Indian people who were happy to stop and chat. It's hard to believe you are in a bustling Indian city when strolling within the grounds of Lalbagh
column4: and the park is highly recommended as a tourist destination. At the end of the day my auto driver was driving me back to the guesthouse when we got stuck in a traffic jam ... again! Anyways
column5: a tout was selling genuine rayban sunglasses
column6: and I beat him down to 200 rupees. That's incredible
column7: I thought
column8: only four dollars for the genuine article when they cost a fortune in Australia. My driver scolded me after the transaction
column9: and said I should only have paid 100 rupees. Come on
column10: I thought
column11: two dollars for genuine raybans surely cannot be possible? So I handed over my old pair to placate him
column12: and he sported them with pride while driving me home
column13: often taking the time to style it up in the mirror.

column1: During my final evening in India I packed up
column2: farewelled the owners

column1: and jumped a taxi back to the airport. I had a flight booked to Colombo
column2: and the only way to get there is to fly north to Mumbai
column3: and link up with an international flight. I arrived at Mumbai domestic terminal around midnight with the plane thirty minutes late
column4: feeling pressed for time
column5: tired and sick. It was left to our friend's from Mumbai's unregistered taxi industry to administer a final kick up the arse before leaving the country
column6: and they didn't miss! I was surprised there was noone around to help
column7: and the sharks starting circling within an instant. I tried to fend them off
column8: stating this wasn't a licensed taxi
column9: where is the meter
column10: why are there two of you in the car
column11: how much etc but they were just too good for me. I was worried about my connecting flight
column12: and they kept pressing the issue with rapid fire talking. Before I knew it I was in the car
column13: they drove me a little
column14: then stopped and produced some ridiculous brochure with prices on it. I was up for the equivalent of $65 to get to the international terminal
column15: and had no idea how far it was.

column1: The only 'facts' I knew were the non stop lies spewing from their mouths. I had less than $40 cash in total
column2: which they relieved me of in a flash
column3: then fobbed me off to some poor sap who had the unpleasant task of driving me the 15 minutes to the airport. The sharks told me the international airport was 45 minutes away
column4: and even a fare for that distance costs less than $10 dollars in India. On arrival we queued with tuk tuks
column5: which the shysters swore were not allowed at the international terminal. I was furious
column6: and told my driver in no uncertain terms how displeased I was with the unethical
column7: exploitative and immoral behaviour of his associates. I think the guy was genuinely uncomfortable with the situation
column8: as he's just a pawn in this well organised criminal racket!

column2: I maintained my rage all the way to Colombo
column3: but eventually cooled off for the final day staying at Marine Tourist Guest House on Negombo beach. I was pleased to greet the friendly staff again
column4: and gratefully climbed into a bed for several hours to have a kip. I took the opportunity to go for a long

column1: walk along the beach in the afternoon
column2: and dive in the water for a final swim before my flight home tonight. My trip to the Indian subcontinent has been unforgettable
column3: including it's fair share of trials and tribulations. But what else can one expect visiting this unique region in the world
column4: basically all of you should be here now!

column1: We owe a lot to the Indians
column2: who taught us how to count
column3: without which no worthwhile scientific discovery could have been made."" Albert Einstein

column2: so until next time I'm signing off for now

Hampi

column1: Disclaimer: no Abreva or latex was used in the making of this blog.
Ariel teased me that I would write a few entries in my blog and then neglect it for the rest of my trip... He was partly right. But I am back! So put down the pitchforks and torches.
I'm going to recount my two trips I've had so far within India: Mysore (sometime in July) and Hampi (this past weekend). Let me start by saying not all trips are created equal. Mysore is first up.
Last minute another expat here for only a few weeks invited me to go to Mysore
column2: about a three and a half hour drive from Bangalore. As there was low Malaria risk
column3: little cost involved
column4: and I had been spending all my time in Bangalore
column5: I signed up. Since it was quite a few weeks back
column6: and I am struggling to care enough about this trip to recount it
column7: I'll just sum it up below:

column1: Mysore is only 88 mi away from Bangalore. In NY/NJ
column2: you can cover 88 miles in just over an hour. In India
column3: it takes three times

column1: as long. And there is a lot of fucking horn honking. Even when there are no other cars around.
There is a palace at Mysore. It is actually rather beautiful and breathtaking. However
column2: you can't wear shoes inside and the floor is about as clean as a Rodeo. And there are a lot of tourists bumping into you. And you can't take pictures. Why? I was told they don't want the secret beauty of the palace advertised. Uhhhhh.

column1: We went to the Olive Garden for lunch. Funny thing: I checked the corporate website
column2: and the Olive Garden doesn't have a location in Mysore
column3: India. Go figure.

column2: when translated directly to English
column3: means ""lackluster"".

column1: Our driver's ring tone on his cell was Justin Bieber's ""Baby""

column2: now that Mysore is out of the way
column3: Hampi time! Hampi was absolutely fantastic. This trip was also planned last minute
column4: however
column5: whereas Mysore was just three of us poor souls
column6: Hampi was thirteen! Nine expats and four locals from work. To give you an idea of the adventure: the trip started out with thirteen people with luggage piling into a twelve person van. Luckily
column7: we are all rather agreeable individuals and decided that it would be OK to take turns sitting on the floor. The driver had laid down an astro turf matt that ran the length of the van and
column8: when padded with jackets and towels
column9: wasn't all that bad. It was actually preferrable to some of the seats. I
column10: being the lucky bastard that I am
column11: was blessed enough to pick a broken seat. Before I go any further
column12: let me disclaim that most everything so far
column13: if not broken
column14: has had a funny way of working. My seat in particular had a nice reclining function; except
column15: the mechanism wasn't functioning properly
column16: and everytime we hit a pot hole (which was approximately everything 3.5 minutes)
column17: my seat would go from a 135 degree recline
column18: to 180 degrees and straight up to 90 degrees. This made sleeping a challenge on the 8.5 hour overnight trip.

column2: now to the juicy stuff (and when I say juicy
column3: it was literally juicy. Ready?). About 2.5 hours into the trip
column4: the driver stopped for a potty break and some coffee. No
column5: silly
column6: we did not stop at a rest stop; those do not exist on the particular highway we took (and I doubt they actually exist on any highway in India). Instead
column7: we stopped at a roadside stand
column8: made of twigs and palm branches
column9: and inhabited by other weary travellers and local animals (like
column10: cows and dogs) alike. A bit sleepy and disoriented (it was now ~1:30 am and the driver had just made us watch Apocalypto) we all piled out of the van
column11: looking for a place to relieve our bladders. The ladies scurried behind a hut
column12: and the gentelmen searched for their own trees. Several guys were ahead of me and I struggled to find my way to the ""men's room"" as it was rather dark and I didn't have my glasses on. After finding my way over some rocky terrain (a product of dried mud and tractor wheels) I reached my friends. And
column13: just as fate would have it
column14: during my struggle to squint to see what was ahead of me
column15: I violated the first rule of mobility in India: always watch the ground below your feet; you never know A. when there will cease to be ground there or B. what that ground is made of... And
column16: so
column17: as these things go
column18: wearing my Cole Haan slip-ons
column19: my right foot descended into what I can only imagine (hope) was a puddle of grabage mud
column20: of a smell that
column23: it was disgusting; and not the regular kind of digusting
column24: it was the most disgusting type of disgusting you can imagine. To this day
column25: I still refer to that puddle of deplorable rubbish (I think it actually was rotting garbage mixed with mud and other ""things"")
column27: while my colleagues maintain that it was a mix of... well... I think it's time I move on.

column2: everyone hopped back onto the bus and ""passed out"" for the remainder of the trip (again
column3: do not question my use of quotes. They are very deliberate). We arrived in Hampi at approximately 7:00 am and checked into our rooms. The ""resort"" we stayed at had absolutely magnificant grounds. The rooms were just alright
column4: though they smelled like sweaty socks and farts a bit; nothing we could not bare after an 8+ hour drive. We all napped for two hours
column5: caught our complimentary breakfast of North Indian cuisine (fluffy rice pancakes that kind of looked like uncrustables
column6: chickpea stew
column7: and COFFEE)
column8: showered and got dressed for a day of guided tours. Our tour guide
column9: Raj
column10: was extremely knowledgable and did a great job of dealing with 13 sleep deprived types-As. He brought us through the ruins of what was the Vijayanagara Empire's ancient capitals and gave us all a little bit of much needed history. We saw temples
column11: road in boats
column12: took plenty of pictures (check Facebook) and had an overall great time. And
column13: surprisingly
column14: no one got on anyone's nerves; somehow thirteen personalities seemed to mix just fine. Maybe we were all too tired to care
column15: or maybe we were all so starved for something other than Bangalore that the sustinance that Hampi provided was enough to keep us all in good spirits. Either way
column16: the long drive there and back
column17: ruining my favorite shoes
column18: and the sweaty sock-fart smell of our rooms were totally worth it. Hampi was just was the doctor ordered for all of us.

column1: We stop by Bangalore on our way to Hampi (only briefly - it is not a nice place - it's a big dusty noisy and unappealing city
column2: we arrived at night and left immediately the next day!!)

column1: The bus journey from Trichy to Bangalore is 8 hours. We took a private company KPN. The rickshaw bring us to a recommended place (by him).Some rickshaw drivers can be trusted but you have to get lucky. Most will recommend a hotel who will give them a commission for bringing customer and you will see the price of your room increase! Bangalore is just a short stop for our next destination: Hampi.
We embarked on Hampi Island (Viripur Gadi) to settle down at Shanti Guesthouse for few days before moving to Shiva Guesthouse (recommended by friends).
Shiva is owned by Olgan and family. There we lived in a very basic way but which shows to us that you don't need much to be happy in life.
The volcanic landscape is a bit mad around here. Some talk about a magical and spiritual forces
column2: others about aliens and some with a

column1: geographical explanation. (Indians believe the Monkey god Hanuman placed the stones in Hampi) Either way whether by nature or a Hindi god - the scenery is otherwordly....

column2: Hampi is very green surrounded with the rice fields on one side and desertic landscape and Ruins on the other.

column1: It is a good start to try to understand the Hindu religion and history about the country itself. We took the service of a Rickshaw-guide to visit the Ruins who explain the Hindu religion and the history of the place. We did learn that the Arabs conquered Hampi during 1635 and destroyed some sites and temple to build their own legacy: Queen's palace - Lotus Palace - Elephant Stables.
A lot of places can be visited on your own as to be honest the Hindu religion is a bit complex (more than 3 millions names - reincarnation
column2: avatars and divinations to remember).
we visited the Hanuman temple monkey on the top of the mountain accessible by a 570 steps climb.

column1: There is a nice contrast of colors between the green of rice field and coconut and banana plantation and the
reddishness from the arid landscape(lava stone).

The current situation in Hampi is difficult as they are destroying people's home built near or using part of the Heritage walls. The State want to restore the site as a World heritage monument. To enable them to do so and to have more visitors and more profit we expect
column2: they move people away
column3: give them a land (3km away from Hampi) and 130.000 Rupees. Of course for people who had a business
column4: this may not be a compensation for the loss of profit but one can understand that some houses were at risk and it will have been not safe for any one to stay under some very old stones...

column1: Hampi is definitively an interesting place to be
column2: full of history and mysteries. We were looking for something original and authentic... this is it! Incredible India...

column1: Years back in 2003 I saw this wall poster of a white Lord Shiva statue in one of the Kodak Shop in Puchong
column2: Kuala Lumpur. It was an amazing picture I ever saw and I asked the owner of the shop where about is this place. She said India. I don't even know this God at all or his name so it was kind of difficult for me to search him in the internet those days. I shelved the whole idea until in 2005 I decided to visit Batu Caves
column3: Kuala Lumpur only then I recalled and asked the Indians around who actually he is. I have constantly wanted to know him
column4: doing researches on him
column5: Indian friends of old and new like to tell me stories of him. The more stories I hear the more I want to see this statue in India. And so it happens in 2011 just before my birthday.

column1: On my first day in Bangalore I visited this beautiful statue of Lord Shiva. Shiv Mandir is the name. My driver swerved into a car park. I asked where we are going. He said “To Shiv Mandir
column2: the Lord Shiva Temple”. “Do we have to walk

column1: far?” I asked. “No” he replied. It was just a few feet away into an exit and there stood the same statue I last saw in 2003. Exactly the same. I didn’t realize the Total Mall and Shiv Mandir shared the same car park. Any foreigner would have missed this place if not for the help of the locals. Remember it is on Old Airport Road.

The temple reached its completion in year 1995 was set on an auspicious day Maha Shivaratri as the inauguration day. The Lord Shiva statue is 65 feet high with River Ganga flowing out from his matted hair. In 1997
column2: the Mount Kailash was added as backdrop behind the statue making the whole scenario more magnificent. The first Linga was founded in Mount Kailash(Tibet). It contained a natural Linga. On the whole of India
column3: there are six natural Lingas discovered in six different states that marked these temples sacred by the Hindus.

column2: I saw statue of Lord Ganesha
column3: the Elephant God as The God of Wisdom
column4: a gallery of the seven Lingas
column5: a long narrow path with probably about 3 feet wide
column6: dark
column7: wet and cold
column8: contained its history

column1: and some words of wisdom for those believe in Lord Shiva. I like one particular word of wisdom
column2: hope and encouragement he quoted. “Faith has Magic - When doctors gave up hope
column3: you should not. If you have health problem
column4: have faith in God
column5: He can solve it.”. I was thinking of people suffering from Cancer
column6: HIV and AIDS the moment I read this. I believe everyone has their own beliefs and miracles do happen.

column1: I am glad I made this trip to see this Shiv Mandir. In reality it was better than the poster. The feeling is so nice and calm
column2: thinking of the founder who had a dream to build this temple was not easy for him. He has no money to buy a piece of land and to build this dream place. But it was God’s blessings all that came to place
column3: one after another; part by part with new statues
column4: the gallery and the artificial Mount Kailash that took so many years was finally paid off. During the Maha Shivaratri
column5: thousands of devotees throng to this place for this auspicious prayer and celebration. Thousands came to visit this Shiv Mandir throughout the year. Thanks to

column1: people who wrote and post about this beautiful place.

column2: they should celebrate for having a place like this.

column1: Aha...I'm a bit delayed in writing these next couple of posts. As the program progresses I'm getting less and less motivation
column2: as it often goes with experiencing new things. At first it's really exciting and everything you do is new! and wonderful! and you want to use exclamation points to end all your sentences! But eventually you start to get used to things and don't try to learn as much. I think part of it
column3: too
column4: is that I haven't been able to get much exercise here so I'm losing my eternal endorphine high. NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!

column2: back to actually reporting on the fun stuff. On Sunday we got the day off from hours and hours of lectures and got to go visit some sweet temples in Belur and Halebidu
column3: Karnataka. Just as in our trip to Mysore
column4: the bus rid was gruelingly long--a whopping 5 hours to get from our hotel to Belur. What changed
column5: however was the space. Since a lot of people heard of the length of the bus ride and remembered the underwhelming trip that was Mysore (too much shuffling
column6: not enough sights) a lot of them skipped out rather than get onto a bus at 4:30am. What this translated to was the entire back row of one of the buses--all 5 seats--reserved just for yours truly. So
column7: of course
column8: I went ahead and flopped my pillow down
column9: plugged into my ipod and got ready for a few more hours of REM. Such a better ride than that to Mysore.

column1: Not only was it a better ride because it was more comfortable
column2: but the countryside was gorgeous. I slept for a couple hours then woke up to peer out the bus window. That part of India is mostly rolling hills
column3: with coconut palm trees everywhere. I think most of the world's coconut product must come from there
column4: because there were obscene amounts of palm trees. Sometimes off in the distance I'd see a rise of rock that could be considered an aspiring mountain
column5: but mostly you could see to the horizon (over the palm trees
column6: of course). I liked seeing this part of India much more than the cities
column7: probably because I'm more of a country girl than a city girl. The towns were smaller
column8: much more farms right up next to the road
column9: and the occassional roadside food- or drink-stand. I really liked some of the houses we saw on the trip; the roof is usable as a patio and they have plaster outside that's been brightly painted so it looks wonderfully cheerful and nicely put together. Looked like a great place to come home to. Occasionally we'd pass through larger towns
column10: that might be considered really small cities
column11: but for a lot of the ride we were basically out in the country. I loved it
column12: and really wanted to just get off the bus and go trekking (what they call backpacking) through the woods.

column1: The main attraction in Belur was the Chennakesava temple. Because it is a hindu temple
column2: you must take off your shoes before entering. Some leave them at the door
column3: but rather than risk ours getting stolen we left them on the bus and walked barefoot from the bus to the temple. (Some of the other kids not used to walking barefoot had some trouble.) To be fully polite
column4: you should also cover your knees and shoulders when entering the temple
column5: but they seem to be a little more lax about letting foreigners in with shorts or tanks. The layout of the temple was similar to the one I saw at the Mysore palace
column6: but on a much grander scale. Once you pass through the main tower-gate-thing you are confronted with an obelisk and a small statue that rest about 100 feet in front of you. I'm not sure what it signifies
column7: but it must mean something because it's placed directly in your way in what otherwise would be a gigantic courtyard floored in stone blocks. In fact
column8: pretty much everything except the doors are made of stone. That's what has made these temples so famous and attractive to tourists
column9: is their stone carvings. And
column10: honestly
column11: I think they deserve the fame.

column2: let me try and draw a map of this temple for you. The whole area it covers is roughly rectangular
column3: surrounded by a stone wall about 10 feet high
column4: sometimes higher in places. Let's say that the main gate is in the southern side of the wall. Then the obelisk and small statue are about 100 feet north of the gate. In the southeast corner there sits a ""tank
column5: a 100ft-by-40ft green pool of water sunk about 40 feet down into the ground
column6: with fish occasionally breaking the surface to grab a bug. Not sure what it was for
column7: either
column8: since the text on the sign had worn off to indecipherability. But there was a short wall around it and the entrance had a locked door so I figured I wasn't supposed to go closer. In the southwest corner there was an overhang that covered what looking like the makings of a parade in storage
column9: wooden horses on wheeled platforms and suchlike
column10: all painted gold
column11: probably for some festival or another.

column1: If you continue north past the obelisk you get to the main temple
column2: a star-shaped stone-carved building that is elevated onto a star-shaped platform about 4-5 feet off the ground. As you climb the stairs to the temple you are supposed to touch them
column3: to petition the gods to allow you to enter the sacred domain. The outside of the temple is covered
column4: I mean literally covered
column5: in stone carvings of the gods. There are thousands of hindu gods
column6: if I remember correctly
column7: and each one has bunches of incarnations as well. Some I remember
column8: like Ganesh with the elephant head
column9: and Shiva and Vishnu
column10: but it would take a lifetime to remember them all. Our tourguide was very knowledgable
column11: using a small hand-mirror to reflect the sunlight at a particular carving he was focusing on as he told us of the god-story that led to the carving. ""And here you see an incarnation of Shiva destroying a demon with just the fingernails of one hand
column12: see how the carver made her fingertips pass through the demon's body and back out
column13: or ""and here you see Ganesh lifting an entire mountain over his head
column14: and you can see the hunter on the mountain and the farmer
column15: and so on. An entire anthology of lore is contained on those wall
column16: and it would be easy to miss without a guide.

column1: There are three doors to the main temple building
column2: two on the east and west sides (as I have designated
column3: not sure of the true directions) and the main one on the south. The hallways from the doors converge on a round dais that is raised about 4"" off the ground. In the ceiling above the dais is a circular carved dome with more ornate carvings of the gods
column4: and to the north of the dais is a small room where the priests keep care of the deities. People can leave offerings and take blessings there. The door was guarded by two incredible god statues that were carved from single pieces of stone
column5: but carved so that the sprays of stone above her head almost look like lace
column6: and it's raised up enough from the back wall that you can slip your hand beneath the stone and see your fingers through the many delicate holes. It's pretty nuts
column7: the level of detail present in these temples.

column1: I didn't stick with the guide for much of the Belur temple
column2: because I hadn't found much use for our guide at Mysore and I wanted to try and interact with the local people at the temple and I figured that wouldn't happen surrounded by a group of foreigners. So
column3: I wandered off and snapped photos of cool statues that I liked. My idea turned out to be successful
column4: a couple times people (mostly children) would say ""hello"" to me and giggle when I smiled and said ""hello"" back. A duo of girls came up again after going through the hello-giggle performance and shook my hand
column5: asking me something that I eventually construed to be asking my name
column6: then where I was from
column7: then my mother and father's name. After deciphering their accented english and answering their questions
column8: they then asked for 100 Rupees
column9: which set me laughing as I told them no. The way they asked it was really funny
column10: because it felt like they'd been told stories about how foreigners were free with their money and wanted to see if it was true. They didn't badger at all like some beggars or vendors may do. They just asked
column11: and then left when I laughed and said no. Another lady asked me where I was from
column12: then wished me a good stay. And once you start taking pictures with people
column13: man
column14: there is no stopping. I saw a couple of boys trying to take surreptitious photos of Fae and I from around a corner
column15: so I leaned over and mimicked a camera and asked if they wanted a photo. Of course they said yes
column16: but what I didn't realize was that there were about eight more of them around the other side of the corner
column17: so then I had about four rounds of pictures with two or three boys on each side. It's wicked fun
column18: to have a lot of people asking for their picture with you. ;D

column1: The other notable thing we saw at Belur was an engagement party! In the northwest corner of the temple there was a sort of elevated patio that was crowded with men and women
column2: just sitting. I avoided it myself
column3: not wanting to intrude on whatever was happening over there. Eventually I met up with Naveet
column4: Sumedha
column5: and Fae
column6: and the two Indian girls explained that it was a wedding (we later learned it was just an engagement) and Fae wanted to go and see. Apparently it was okay
column7: so we wandered up the steps and crowded near the back of people. The bride and groom were sitting on the floor in an open space
column8: next to each other and both facing the crowd. They both had red dots on their forehead and there was some sort of ceremony going on as a women holding a plate with cups and a candle on it was passing in front of them
column9: but I couldn't see what she did. Fae wanted to give her blessings to the bride and groom
column10: so she got some advice from Naveet and permission from someone from the wedding party and went up to the front of the crowd. I stayed in the back
column11: not wanting to draw more attention away from the bride and groom then I already had. Apparently
column12: to give blessings at an engagement you sprinkle rice on the head of the bride and the groom
column13: dip a finger in tumeric and press it to the center of their foreheads
column14: then dip your finger in red and mark the same spots on their foreheads. I heard people laugh while Fae was up there
column15: apparently she dipped her thumb in the red and pressed firmly to the groom's head
column16: who leaned back in surprise
column17: making it look like she had poked him very hard. I asked Naveet afterwards
column18: and the proper way to do it seems to be to stick out your ring finger
column19: using your thumb to keep your other fingers back
column20: and dip the finger into the dye lightly and mark lightly. So if I ever make it to an Indian engagement

column1: After the temple at Belur we hopped back on the bus and traveled a short distance to the Halebid temple. The temple was different from the Mysore and Chennakesava temple in that it was not surrounded by a gigantic wall
column2: and there were grassy areas surrounding the temple that made it seem very peaceful. The carvings there were just as impressive as those at Chennakesava
column3: if not more so. This time I stuck closer to the tour guide and got to hear more stories about the carvings of the gods. But
column4: there's not much more to say that I didn't say above
column5: so I can't embellish any more...

column1: After seeing that temple we went to lunch at a local resort
column2: where we got to have a tasty buffet lunch. I got to have my favorite dessert of all time
column3: gulab jamoon. I can't remember if I've written about it before
column4: but it is so glorious that it deserves some more words. Perhaps a poem. An ode. A sonnet. A thorough and solid declaration of my love for the deliciousness that is gulab jamoon (with ice cream) and for the man who first made it. Gulab jamoon is some sort of dough that has been rolled into a ball and then cooked in a sugar syrup until it has reached a level of tastiness that places it upon deity-status. It is usually served with ice cream
column5: and if you are blind and get two scoop of ice cream with two gulab jamoon and a little extra syrup sprinkled on top you will see once again. If you are lame
column6: you will walk. If you are deaf you will hear. It is that freaking good. They also had fruit trifle and stuff
column7: but I don't really care about that. After that
column8: we piled back into the bus to come back to Bangalore
column9: with a stop for snacks and tea along the way. So
column10: would I recommend Belur and Halebidu to others visiting India? In a heartbeat!

column1: Yesterday we got a day off from lectures and instead we got to go sightseeing! We woke up early and piled on the bus at 5am to take the ~200km trip to Mysore. In a car or on a motorcycle it probably wouldn't have taken too long
column2: but on a huge trundling bus the trip there took around 3 hours. NOT my favorite way to spend the morning
column3: but I'm pretty flexible about where I can sleep. And
column4: in fact
column5: I would have slept quite well on the bus since I smuggled a hotel pillow out and planned to prop myself up in a corner and snooze and drool until we reached our destination. (Okay
column6: ""smuggling"" is a bit strong. I kinda just walked out with it...) But
column7: there was something that I did not account for. The roads here have a lot of speed bumps
column8: and they are BIG speedbumps. Add that to the fact that I was sitting in the back of the bus and you get quite a rough ride. The driver was relatively good at slowing down
column9: so on most of the bumps you just felt your stomach and brain lift up but nothing big. One bump
column10: though
column11: left all of us in the back at least a couple inches off of our seats. Better than coffee for waking up
column12: that.

column1: Our first stop was in Mysore
column2: outside of pit stops
column3: was at the royal palace. I learned a lot of history of India on this trip
column4: and much of it from someone other than our tour guide. I spent some time talking to Professor Sriram
column5: who grew up in India
column6: did his undergrad in Thailand
column7: and is now professing in New York. He was a walking fount of knowledge
column8: I tell you. But I digress! In the early days (before Indian independence) India consisted of a collection of states: Karnataka
column9: Kerala
column10: etc. The British didn't rule so much
column11: as just trade with the maharajas and sultans. (Both maharajas and sultans are kings of a certain area
column12: but I think one is muslim and one is hindi. I can't remember exactly. Google it if you're curious. :D ) The British provided the rulers with soldiers to enforce their authority
column13: and in return the maharajas et al over-taxed the people and gave a large portion of that to the British. I'm not sure why
column14: but India was rolling in dough back then
column15: something about the country got them a lot of money. That's also why a lot of Indian artifacts are chillin' over in Britain right now.

column2: you may ask
column3: where does Mysore come into all of this? There is a palace there
column4: a huge wonderful palace where the son of the last maharaja of Karnataka now lives. At some point they restructured the government to remove the political power of the maharajas
column5: and so when the last maharaja died in 74 his son did not become the next maharaja
column6: but remained a prince. And since the prince is in his late 50s and has no children it's not looking promising for the royal line. I don't think this prince is complaining
column7: though. The last maharaja agreed to let the public tour a small portion of the palace in exchange for 20%!o(MISSING)f the fees acquired. That's a crap-ton of money
column8: because that placed is jammed with tourists. Apparently the government is refusing to pay his son
column9: though
column10: and there's a case in court to figure out if the prince gets royalties from the tourism. (Ha
column11: royalties
column12: get it? 'Cause he a prince
column13: and all.)

column2: bigger than the Palacio Real in Madrid but a bit more worn-down. You can't wear your shoes in
column3: so you get to put them into a bucket and prance around barefoot. Well
column4: I pranced. But that's me. The floors were mostly tiled
column5: apparently with tiles from England
column6: with stairs of concrete near the entrance. The ceilings were plastered with colorful designs
column7: and there was some beautiful stained glass from Glasgow. In fact
column8: a lot of the palace features were imported from other countries. It was that fact that prompted me to ask Professor Sriram how these maharajas could afford such glamour
column9: and that was when he started telling me the history of India. My favortie feature of the palace was a courtyard
column10: about 25 yards wide and 35 yards long
column11: near the center of the palace. There was nothing really interesting in the courtyard
column12: no fountains or statues in the center
column13: and we weren't even allowed to go in it as all the entrances were blocked by nets. But I really liked the feel of it. There was a small stair set at one edge of the courtyard
column14: about 6 stairs or so
column15: with statues of snarling leapords on each side facing inwards
column16: and a spiral staircase on another wall up to the second floor. A breeze would occassionally come from the open sky above and ruffle the nets
column17: or my hair as I leaned out the windows that lined the edges and it was really easy to imagine the maharaja standing on the stairs
column18: surrounded by attendants and holding court between those two leapord statues. Also it looked like a great place for a bollywood dance scene. :D

column1: The palace grounds also featured a hindu temple which I got to wander around in. There's a sort of entranceway into the temple where you leave your shoes--you're also supposed to cover your knees and shoulders in deference to the gods. The main temple sat in the center
column2: a building made out of granite pillars with ridiculously ornate carvings at the top. The wooden doors to that temple were shut and locked
column3: so I'm not sure what deity/cod/goddess resided there. There was another building with a pooja room near the back corner
column4: and this one was open and accepting supplicants. You can walk into the small room
column5: stand on a table covered in rangoli-like artwork and the preists (or whatever they're called) will wave some incence in front of the statue and offer you some sacred water to splash on your mouth and head. I did not partake of the ceremony
column6: but we were with Professor Sriram and got to watch what he did. The priests offered a silver platter with a burning lamp on it
column7: he put down some rupees (not sure how much)
column8: then they offered him the bowl of sacred water.

column1: Part of the fun of Mysore was what happened outside the palace grounds. I mentioned above that Mysore is a huge tourist attraction. Well
column2: there is nothing foreigners are better at than paying to much for useless junk. So there are all sorts of peddlars right outside Mysore
column3: and they are aggressive. I wasn't interested in buying anything
column4: and I knew the rules: stare straight ahead
column5: ignore them even if they're in your way or your face
column6: and give them no reason to think that you are interested. Don't justify why you aren't going to buy their things. Don't stop
column7: just keep walking. I found their flutterings hilarious and soon enough they left me alone. Some of the other kids
column8: though
column9: showed a bit of interest and were BOMBARDED. Reggie asked a fan-seller how much one cost when going in
column10: and the man even followed him when we were coming out. To get to the bus we had to get through a narrow walk of stalls
column11: and we temporarily lost a lot of kids as we were inundated. After I got on the bus the first time we realized one of the kids from China was missing
column12: and I'd seen him interacting with the sellers before and knew he wouldn't be good at just walking through them and saying no. And if I knew
column13: then the peddlers knew. It's like blood in the water
column14: and you know they'll buy something from you just to get you away. So I left the bus to go escort him back
column15: trying to use my body to get in between him and the peddlars. It was super-fun
column16: like being a body-guard. And even once we were on the bus they didn't stop! They stood outside our windows and waggled their products at us. Sam thought it was ridiculous so she started making faces out the window
column17: much to their amusement. I thought it looked like fun so I joined in
column18: too. Some fan-seller in Mysore has a picture on their phone of Sam with her cheeks puffed out and me cross-eyed.

column1: We ate lunch in the basement club of some fancy hotel
column2: and it was wicked. The entrance to the club looks like a barrel
column3: then you walk into this short tunnel with lit crystal in the floor
column4: and then you get to the club-turned-restaurant. They set up buffet tables on the slightly elevated dance floor
column5: and there were tables and cars around the outside for eating. That's right
column6: they had two cars set up with tables in the club. It was super-fun. The decor was chic-western
column7: with black walls and blue LEDs to simulate the night sky. The food was super-tasty--six types of desserts! Pulab jamoon (I think
column8: I can't remember the exact name) with ice cream
column9: ""bread pudding
column10: a fruit-casserole thing
column11: some sort of fruit-pancake-pastry thing
column12: and some tasty cookie-things whose name I can't remember. I didn't keep very good track of what I was eating--I was too busy snarfing it down and wishing I had a faster metabolism. I'm pretty sure I've gained at least 5 pounds on this trip already. Too much eating
column13: not enough unicycling! But I'm not worrying about it since I'm only getting this chance for a limited amount of time. I'm also getting really good at eating with my hand properly--I've realized the trick is to scoop the food up with my four fingers
column14: then slide my thumb from my palm towards my fingertips to flip the food into my mouth. I'm an Indian-food-eating pro
column15: man.

column1: After lunch we moseyed over to sultan Tipu's summer house
column2: also in the Mysore area. The story behind that was interesting; Tipu did not like British sovereignty so he opposed them and fought. It didn't turn out so well for him
column3: though. After winning one bought with the British they came back en force and razed the huge fort that used to be near the palace and killed Tipu. There are some impressive wall paintings in the summer house that depict the battles with the British (before Tipu was killed
column4: I think) and other famous people that I really didn't pay much attention to. After that we hung out on the grounds for awhile
column5: and that was quite peaceful. I met two new Indian guys
column6: Surya and Sasi (whose name means sun and moon
column7: respectively. they should be friends for life.)
column8: and chilled with them on the lawn. I think they weren't quite sure what to do with me; even though I ate lunch with them and Kiri and they smiled whenever I wandered around it looked more like one of the nervous smiles I see when people don't know what to expect of you here. I was nice
column9: though
column10: and didn't chatter or anything. Just sat and enjoyed the breeze and the wonderful weather they have in this part of India. Our last stop of the day was a collection of stores on the outskirts of town that were arranged almost like a city square. The complex was absolutely deserted
column11: though
column12: so it was obvious that our tour program had some sort of deal with the owners that they would bring in batches of tourists on a bus. I was a bit bummed; I had hoped for something like the insanity outside of Mysore. Ah
column13: well. Can't win 'em all! After that
column14: we piled back on the bus and made our slow way back to Bangalore. Fun day
column15: in general
column16: but I would have loved to tool around by myself for several days. Maybe I'll tour India on a motorcycle one day. :D

column1: I can tell we're all getting tired of this break-neck pace
column2: here in India. It's getting harder to convince myself to blog every day
column3: which is why I've gone and missed one yesterday. Sorry everyone! But not really much happened yesterday
column4: so there's not a whol lot to report. I convinced Bala to order me a ""cheese burst"" pizza from Domino's
column5: non-veg. It was delivered to my room in less than 30 minutes just like they promised (I was really surprised) and was pretty tasty. The sauce is more BBQ than tomato
