column6: and the toppings are similar to a supreme pizza. The difference is the ""cheese burst"" part--they put a bunch of melty cheese between layers of crust on the bottom. It's pretty darn tasty
column7: though ridiculously rich. I should not have eaten as much of my medium pizza that I did
column8: but I finished the rest the next morning anyway.

column1: Tonight we had a girls' night in my room
column2: which meant snacks and Bollywood! Naveet has a super-nice hp computer with ridiculously good sound
column3: so we set it up on a table in front of my bed
column4: plopped into comfy positions and started watching! The movie in question is called ""Jab We Met
column5: a romantic comedy from 2007. The story centers around an energetic
column6: bubbly girl who meets a heartbroken guy on the train. She then gets all up in his business and
column7: of course
column8: hilarity ensues. We only got through the first half
column9: but already the romantic sparks are starting to fly. (You see
column10: it took that long because she has a boyfriend she plans to elope with. We haven't gotten that part resolved yet.) The male actor is good at brooding and occassionally flashing glimpses of teeth in a small smile while sneaking glances at Geet. One of the kids from China in my program
column11: Chen
column12: looks a bit like the actor
column13: so it was a lot of fun comparing the mannerisms of the two. I'm eager to finish
column14: though it will be a couple days.

column1: Onto my second topic: women in India. Honsetly
column2: I don't fully understand the complex dynamics that occur here. On one hand there is the traditionalist side of things. The large majority of women wear traditional clothing
column3: like saris or (more commonly) kurtis with loose pants
column4: leggings
column5: scarves
column6: etc. I've been warned not to wander the streets alone
column7: though I'm moderarely sure I'd be okay before 11am. Women and men are not friends; I do not think I have seen a women and man walking the street together unless they were married. In Jab We Met
column8: Geet gets stranded at a bus station and almost immediately starts getting harrassed by a group of men. The buses have trouble with men sexually harassing women. I read in the paper about a case in Mangalore (a city in the same state as Karnataka but pretty distant) where groups of young men considering themselves moral keepers gang up on people who are partying in the city
column9: and probably harass women for wearing non-traditional clothing as well. The state's getting slammed because the officials in Mangalore are traditionalist-minded as well
column10: and therefore are not as diligent about catching the ""goons"" as they could be. When I told Prakash that I drove myself to school he was surprised; even something that we consider as meaningless as driving could be an unusual privelage here. I don't fully get the picture of women in India
column11: I need to ast Naveet and Sumedha for some of their experiences. And probably some of the Indian guys
column12: too
column13: since they see the other side of it. As a foreign woman I am in a unique position
column14: since I can interact with both groups freely.

column1: Whew! I'm tired. I think I've been fighting some sort of sickness for the last two days or so. Perhaps that sore throat that's been going around has caught up to me. I was doing really well up till recently but I think this lack of sleep these last couple days is what tipped me over the edge from 100% to 90%. I'm still fighting it and hope to get to bed soon so I can sleep and recover
column2: but I had to write blog posts for the last three days since I've been so busy. I was supposed to do work for my advisor today
column3: as well
column4: but it took me this long to get the posts written that now I am just going to go to bed after this. Whoops.

column2: no adventures
column3: just an evening jaunt to a close restaurant named Al-Bek that I wanted to write about. I went with Tim
column4: Sumedha
column5: Naveet
column6: Jeyandran
column7: Prakash
column8: Ganesh
column9: and Hussain. The place was packed
column10: but we got lucky and a table opened up about 5 minutes after we got there. Tim says it's been packed every time he's been there
column11: and he's been there several times for dinner on varying nights. Like a lot of the fast-food restaurants on our street there are two floors
column12: which is necessitated by the lack of real estate in the city. Things are much more spread-out in the states
column13: there is space and areas and parking lots between buildings. Not here. And since they can't build out
column14: they build up. So the second floor is basically a wide balcony with several tables that overlooks the standing area below.

column1: We ordered several curry dishes and a couple noodle dishes
column2: not to mention some roti (flatbread). I practiced eating like a proper South Indian
column3: with my right hand only and no utinsel. I spooned some chicken fried rice onto the plate
column4: topped it with some masala (sauce) from one of the dishes
column5: mixed the whole thing up with my fingers and went to town. I'm still pretty bad at successfully getting the rice from the plate into my mouth without getting extra rice on my face or dropping it into my lap
column6: but I think I did okay overall. I had a slice to drink
column7: which was a good choice because some of the dishes were a bit spicy and Slice is the best thing to cut spiciness
column8: outside of curds
column9: which I didn't think they offered. After dinner I washed my hands and face in one of the washbasins they offer in South Indian restaurants
column10: copying Sumedha by only rubbing my right hand by itself
column11: not with my left
column12: and copying Naveet by cupping water to wash and rinse out my mouth. I'm torn on how I feel about eating in a South Indian style. On one hand I love the idea of eating my food with my hands. On the other
column13: I'm not sure if I like getting my hands messy. Then again
column14: if you round off the meal with roti and then a napkin your hands come away surprisingly clean. And the washbasins are provided in almost all restaurants
column15: even if a washroom is not.

column2: ""Why Jenni
column3: how could you possibly have seen lions and tigers and bears at the ANCRiSST workshop you were supposed to attend today?"" Well
column4: my dear readers
column5: there are two likely possibilities. The first is that the workshop hosts decided to bring a menagerie at lunch to entertain us guests--not an unlikely scenario considering the immense hospitality I've seen here--and the second is that I skipped out on the conference. As you may have already guessed
column6: I did indeed play hooky today! After talking late into the night with Bala
column7: Hussain
column8: et al. I heard their plans to skip out on the conference and go see some tigers at Bannerghatta National Park. Naturally I was thrilled at the opportunity to a) get some extra sleep
column9: b) have another adventure in India
column10: c) hang out with my new friends from various countries
column11: and d) see some wicked-cool animals.

column1: My plan was to sleep until 9:30 or so
column2: since we were up until 2
column3: but that didn't pan out. Unfortunately the front desk called around 8:30 to tell me the bus was ready and that they wanted everyone to get on it. Ooh
column4: side-track here. Another example of how India is different from the U.S.: on the first day Dr. Ramaswamy
column5: one of the main organizers
column6: told us not to be late and not to miss the bus. The problem is that they count the number of people on the bus and they won't leave until there are either 50 students on the bus or they've called every single room. This means that
column7: now that people have figured out that they can skip lectures and not really miss anything
column8: we often end up waiting for at around 30 minutes on the bus. Just another example of what I am beginning to affectionately refer to as ""India time.""

column2: I didn't get my precious beauty sleep because of the hotel call and I was not really able to get back to sleep after that. So there was nothing left but to stagger up
column3: take a shower and go grab some breakfast upstairs. I then hung around for awhile
column4: watched some TV
column5: and waited for word from Bala and Tim about when we were going to go see some giant cats.

column1: We ended up leaving the hotel around 11:30am: Yuuki (nickname: Shimapu)
column2: Bala
column3: Hussain
column4: Tim
column5: Rodrigo
column6: and myself. Our method to get there was bus to the central transportation area
column7: then switch buses to get to Bannerghatta
column8: which I would never in a thousand years have tried without Bala. You see
column9: Bala grew up near Bangalore (in Mysore
column10: I think) so he speaks Kannada
column11: the native language here. This makes him invaluable because even though the national language is Hindi
column12: not everyone speaks Hindi. And Bala also speaks Hindi
column13: just in case
column14: so we had an excellent companion to chauffer us around.

column1: The buses were a fascinating experience. Apparently there are three classes of buses: the cheap
column2: the slightly-less-cheap
column3: and the not-really-cheap. I think we took the middle-class bus for both legs of the journey on the way there
column4: but honestly I'm not really sure. We just all gave Bala 100 Rs at the beginning and let him do all the talking. When we got onto the first bus I stood with the guys near the door
column5: but before long the conductor tapped me on the shoulder and indicated a seat near the front of the bus. That's right
column6: the buses are gender-segregated here. I'm not exactly sure how much of it is out of respect and how much of it is to prevent harrassment. I had read on wikitravel before coming that if a woman sits on a bench or a bus seat where a man is sitting
column7: the man may get up to give you the whole seat
column8: and that in that case the man is being respectful and not rude. But then Tim told me that he had read in the paper that there was a huge problem with men harrassing women on the buses here. I think it's also a problem for women walking at night
column9: because when I talked about walking about a block to the hotel by myself the Indian guys I was with told me to wait and they'd walk with me. I'm honestly not sure if I'd get harrassed walking alone on the streets at 8pm
column10: since I'm not Indian
column11: but even if it was a possibility I wasn't really concerned. I mean
column12: what could they do? If they tried to verbally harrass me I wouldn't understand since I don't speak Kannada or Hindi. If they tried to physically harrass me I'd knock them ass over teakettle since I am usually at least 4 inches taller and 30 pounds heavier. I waited
column13: though
column14: for they guys' peace of mind.

column2: back to the buses. I sat up front with the girls
column3: occassionally accompanied by Shimapu who had to give up his seat anytime ladies came onto the bus. When people get on the bus they stand around until eventually the conductor makes his way to you
column4: asks where you are going
column5: then takes your money and gives you a ticket. You don't bargain for bus tickets
column6: just like you don't bargain for food. In India
column7: there aren't little bell pulls on buses to indicate you want to get off the bus. If you're a lady I suspect you make your way to the front door and tell the driver or conductor that you want to get off. If you're a man you whistle to tell the bus to stop. It's the same whistle Indian men need to develop if they want to stop an auto. Apparently foreigners can make do with waving their arm
column8: but Indian guys need to whistle to get an auto to stop. I had heard that whistling is rude
column9: and Bala had told me a couple days ago that they did it to call taxis or tease girls. So as I was sitting on this bus
column10: facing backwards because that's how my seat was
column11: I heard a lot of insistent whistiling and thought ""great
column12: someone's harassing the blond chick on the bus."" I didn't want to encourage the person
column13: so I insistently stared out the window. At one point I tried to sneak a glance around the bus to see if I could find out who was whisting at me and accidentally made eye contact with a man standing about halfway back. Of course I went back to staring out the window and of course I heard the whistling again after that. So then I did not bother sneaking glances inside the bus
column14: I just stoically stared out. I even thought I heard someone giving the whistler a set-down in some non-English language because I didn't hear any whistles after that. But when I asked Bala--who'd been sitting in the back of the bus
column15: facing backwards as well--at Bannerghatta if someone had been whistling at me on the bus he laughed and told me no. The whole time it was people whistling to stop the bus. Aaaaaaaaaand since I'd stared out the window I couldn't have known that. Whoops.

column1: The trip to Bannerghatta took about 2 hours total because our second bus stopped at basically every stop. We started getting excited when could look out the window and see what looked like a forest. The park was definitely a tourist trap: there were food stands
column2: kids selling bubbles
column3: and a ferris wheel
column4: just to name a few. We purchased tickets for the bus safari--about twenty people squished onto a bus that drives through the enclosures of different animals--for 210 Rs per person
column5: which is a pretty decent price (about $4). We then walked over to the waiting area
column6: which was a square area surrounded by a waist-high wall with a granite-topped bench to sit and a roof with clay tiles. After waiting for around 5 minutes we were ushered onto a green bus lined with two-person seats on each sides
column7: with holes for cameras on the grates that covered the window. Somehow in the maneuvering it ended up that Bala
column8: Tim
column9: Rodrigo
column10: and myself were in the front
column11: and after awhile we got Shimapu and Hussain in the front as well.

column2: this was no accident. Anytime we stopped to see animals
column3: from the spotted deer in the beginning to the lions near the end
column4: the ""guide"" (in quotes because he didn't do anything but accompany the driver) and driver would take our cameras from our hands and lean out the windows to take pictures for us. I ended up just laying back a lot
column5: or looking at the animals with my own eyes rather than on my camera screen. It seems that this happens all the time
column6: they seat the foreigners up front and take their cameras to take pictures
column7: knowing that a lot of Westerners will feel guilt-tripped into giving a tip at the end of the safari. It's how Fae lost a bunch of money at the Mumbai airport: guys kept taking her bags and carrying them places without her asking
column8: then indicating that she needed to give a tip. And Fae
column9: being nice Fae
column10: gave all of them 50 Rs tips
column11: even if it was one guy carrying her bag and accompanied by three others. So it seems this is a common scheme: do something nice for the foreigners to make them think they are obligated to pay you. Obviously it's a good scheme and it works. That being said
column12: I did not tip the driver or the ""guide"" at the end of the safari. Rodrigo did
column13: though.

column1: The safari started off with the more tame animals
column2: like spotted deer
column3: alligators
column4: and some other hooved creatures
column5: and progressed to more and more exotic. The first animals are all in one really large enclosure
column6: since the alligators probably get fed and are unlikely to want to eat the deer. The bus then passed through a double-gate into the bear enclosure. The bears in this enclosure were sloth bears
column7: and they looked kind of like shaggy black bears with dog-like paws and goofy muzzles. As soon as we got into the enclosure there was a bear right next to the bus
column8: and a bit later one of them put his paws up on the side of the bus to sniff. I would guess that sometimes people feed the bears out of the bus and this one was hoping to get a snack.

column1: After the bear enclosure can the lions
column2: which were my favorite animal of the safari. I'm not sure I've seen a lion up close like this
column3: and these guys are beautiful. Their heads are gigantic--as big as my unicycle wheel--and their golden eyes are rimmed in dark so that when they turn their heads to look at you it seems like they can see straight into your soul. One of them was pacing next to a gate that either held food or a lionness
column4: and watching him pace back and forth was amazing. He was so quick
column5: so powerful
column6: it was exhilirating and I was glad the guide had taken my camera because it meant I could just watch him move. After that we saw Bengal tigers
column7: then Siberian tigers
column8: but to me they just couldn't compare to the lions. They're definitely pretty
column9: and I definitely decided that anyone who hunted tigers should be slapped in the face with a fish
column10: but I still liked the lions better. Though I did not get to see a pair of lions mate
column11: as I did with the tigers
column12: since I think they keep the lionesses in a separate enclosure from the lions until they choose to breed them. Nor did I get to see a lion take a bath
column13: as one of the siberian tigers did when we were near.

column1: Once the safari was over we wandered around to scrounge up some lunch. Bala bought two ears of corn from a vendor-lady
column2: one had been boiled and one had been cooked over an open fire. Both were very good; the boiled corn was basically the same as in the states except for the tasty spice on it
column3: and the fired corn had harder kernels
column4: almost like unpopped popcorn but not quite. Tim and Rodrigo did not partake
column5: fearing the possible digestive repercussions that could come of eating street food
column6: especially with a 2-hour bus ride back to Bangalore. We ate lunch at a restaurant in the park
column7: but I didn't check its name nor would I have likely remembered it anyway. I ordered chicken noodles
column8: since it was something I'd never had before
column9: and was a bit dissapointed when I got something similar to what I might get as chow mein in a Panda Express. Turns out the noodle dishes here are approximations of Chinese food
column10: just like we have back home. So I know now to not eat the noodle dishes if I want something exotic. I did get a Fanta
column11: though
column12: which is popular there. In fact
column13: the most popular sodas that you see offered everywhere are the main labels you'd see in America
column14: like 7up
column15: Pepsi
column16: Sprite
column17: Coke
column18: but also Fanta and the delicious non-carbonated mango drink Slice. I think the carbonation is lower here
column19: which I really like
column20: and the drinks are in glass bottles that look beat up and are fun to drink from.

column1: The bus ride back to the central transportation hub was much shorter because we picked a nicer bus that didn't make as many stops. Another nice thing about it was that it was not gender-segregated
column2: so I got to sit with Bala and the other in the back. Once we got to the hub we took an auto the rest of the way
column3: because it was peak traffic hours and a bus would a) take FOREVER and b) be ridiculously crowded. And that was just the first half of the day.

column1: That night we went out with a couple of professors to The Tavern
column2: a pretty nice bar inside the Inn at Museum Road. I think it was made for foreigners because it felt almost exactly like any nicer bar back in the states and also played American music like stuff from The Fray and Pearl Jam. I had a chocotini for the ridiculous (at least in India) price of 330 Rs post-tax and got to hang with everyone. Sumedha had us play a game
column3: basically charades where you chose what you want to act
column4: and it was a lot of fun playing with kids from all over the world. We even got a little nerdy
column5: too: I pantomimed a mode shape with my hand which someone guessed correctly
column6: and someone else tore up a napkin to show the finite element method and someone got that
column7: too. It was really fun! And since most of the bars in India close around 11pm
column8: I still got back in time to get most of a good night's sleep. :D

column1: It only took two shopping trips
column2: a trip to a back-alley tailor
column3: and a couple hours of chaos but we finally got to wear our saris! It took the three of us (Sam
column4: Fae and myself) a long time to get ready because we didn't know how to put on saris at all
column5: of course
column6: and Sumedha did not have much practice at getting them to look just right. I got to put on my sari first
column7: and even though it took awhile we were able to get my sari fully assembled with just Sumedha's and Naveet's help. When we tried to get Fae and Sam set up
column8: though
column9: they couldn't quite get the whole thing arranged. Their saris were two-toned
column10: which made it a bit harder to get it to look right
column11: and the girls are shorter than I am so they had to tuck a lot of fabric into the petticoat. Faced with such complications
column12: what did we do? Call up one of the ladies who worked down in reception! Since they wear saris every day we hoped that they could finish up Sam and Fae properly and
column13: sure enough
column14: in no time at all they had been transformed into Indian princesses!

column2: a bit of description on the whole sari outfit. There are three parts to a sari: the petticoat
column3: the blouse
column4: and the sari itself. The petticoat is just a simple underskirt that has a string to tie near the waist and falls all the way to the ground. It is suposed to match the color of the sari exactly
column5: but mine was a bit darker than my sari and seemed to work just fine. The sari usually has some sort of border on the edge
column6: say a thick ribbon
column7: to edge it off. When you buy a sari it will often come with a strip of fabric to make a blouse
column8: which you then take to a tailor. The sleeves of the blouse have the same edging as the sari
column9: which makes the whole outfit look really shmancy. The style of the blouse is basically a t-shirt that ends a couple inches below your breasts
column10: and features either hooks in front or a zipper under the arm
column11: and loops in the shoulders that snap around your bra strap to keep it properly in the blouse.

column1: The sari assemblage starts with putting on the petticoat and the blouse. Then one edge of the sari is tucked into the petticoat over the right hip and wraps around the waist (towards the left hip first) to get one layer of the sari as a skirt. Then a length of the sari is accordion-folded to give a bustle of fabric that sits in the front. All of these bits are tucked into the petticoat
column2: which is how the whole thing stays together. We also used a safety pin to keep the folds together. Once the bustle is tucked into the front of the sari
column3: the length of fabric that is left over is taken up and over the left shoulder. You can chose whether to pin the whole bit of fabric up on your shoulder
column4: leaving your shoulder bare and exposing a bit of midriff on your side
column5: or you can just pin one edge on the shoulder and leave the rest of the fabric to drap over your arm and shoulder. Some women take the extra length and wrap it so it tucks back into the sari
column6: which seems a practical way to wear it because then you won't have the extra fabric flowing around and getting in the way when you try to sit.

column2: learning to move in a sari took a bit of work. Walking was relatively easy to pick up
column3: since the skirts fall just above your toes. I did have a bit of trouble when walking uphill since your chances of stepping on the hem are greatly increased. And
column4: of course
column5: stepping on the hem basically guaranteed that you'd pull the sari out of the petticoat and would have to go to the washroom to rearranged yourself. Walking up steps or getting on the bus was excessively nerve-wracking because you need to grab your skirts and lift them to get up the step
column6: and you can't lift your skirts too high or you look indelicate. Not only that
column7: you have to be sure to grab ALL of the bustle and the petticoat
column8: or you'll step on the sari and pull it out. I did pretty well in general
column9: never stepping on the hem really badly. At one point in the evening I noticed my sari was falling out and I had to go fix it
column10: but that seemed to be from normal motions of standing
column11: sitting
column12: walking
column13: etc.

column1: We were quite the sensation. I am used to standing out
column2: I mean
column3: you don't see many 6' tall blond girls dressed in guy shorts and tanks very much in India
column4: so I got used to people looking at me. This was nothing like that. As soon as the three of us reached the lobby of the hotel everyone looked at us
column5: and I could feel it was a different look. When you're foreign
column6: people might look at you and see your foreign clothes
column7: but it's not an excessively interested look. These were interested looks. There are a group of Indian guys staying in our hotel for some medical conference and we had the attention of every single one. Our auto driver complemented me (through Naveet) saying that many foreigners dressed in jeans and t-shirts and it was nice to see one in traditional Indian clothing. He then looked at me in the rearview mirror
column8: smiled and said ""very nice."" In fact
column9: we got that reaction from a lot of the Indian men in service positions
column10: like waiters and such like. Always a ""very nice"" and a smile. I smiled back and said thanks every time. Luckily for me I have no problem being the center of attention
column11: but Sam was really shy at the beginning and even hid from pictures! She got better
column12: though. :D

column2: the evening didn't end with the banquet. Some kids from the k-mob (Korea) brought some liquor from Korea
column3: called soju
column4: so after ditching the sari (which was not good for lounging) I hung out with them and kids from the i-co and j-crew in the hotel room next door. I can't really describe the taste of soju
column5: since I only had a little. Mostly I was drinking Kingfisher beer that we swiped from the minibar and will replace...eventually. That's one nice thing about the general disorganization of India--it's easy to do things like drink from the minibar and replace with stuff you buy at the market later. ;D Once the group in Yuki's room had winded down
column6: a core group of us relocated to a different room to continue hanging and chatting. I got to ask Hussain about Islam
column7: and he talked about the Koran and Ramazan and the comparisons between Christianity and Islam. They're about 1/3 of the way through Ramazan right now
column8: which means that Hussain can't eat or drink from sunrise to sunset
column9: which is still mind-boggling to me. My friend Sabreen had done Ramazan (though she called it by its arabic name Ramadan) back in undergrad and I was impressed then. We were up really late just talking and exchanging stories
column10: and I think that it's been one of my favorite experiences so far.

column1: I am very tired today; staying up so late blogging is not good for me! After lectures us girls and Gift (pronounced ""jift"") and Duan went to pick up our saris from the tailor and buy some accessories. I got earrings and bangles
column2: and will be wearing my dress sandals that I bought. Apparently it's going to take 2 hours for us to fully get ready so we're going to ditch the entire afternoon workshop session to have time to prepare. Don't tell on us
column3: 'kay?

column1: I'm going to go to bed now--it may only be 9:45 but I need my sleep and the bus leaves at 7am tomorrow morning (ugh). 'Night.
I'm posting this six days late
column2: but below is my experience registering with the Foreign Regional Registration Office:

column1: I am sitting in a cafe
column2: ""The French Loaf"" in Indiranagar as I write this. I've just ordered myself a coffee and a donut (quiet
column3: gays!). No one here seems to know what a black coffee is
column4: and no matter what you order
column5: it's a cappuccino. Le sigh.

column1: I arrived at the FRRO this morning at 8:35; twenty minutes late. My assistants (yes
column2: plural) from ISO were already waiting for me. They saved me a spot in line and had all of my documents completed. My only job
column3: as explained by Lohith
column4: was to stand in line and get my token. After that
column5: I was to promptly report back to him for further instruction. To my surprise
column6: the office opened five minutes early and the crowd of foreigners waiting with me piled into the FRRO in an orderly fashion. The day was off to a smooth start.

column2: making me token 17. After I retrieved my token
column3: Lohith told me that I was then to sit on the ground floor until they called me. At such time
column4: I was to report to the reception desk. So
column5: when they called token 1-7
column6: I dutifully reported to the reception desk. They checked my passport
column7: signed in a few places
column8: and sent me upstairs to the Scrutiny Desk. Once upstairs
column9: the masses were split by visa type: students
column10: researched
column11: etc. in one ""line""
column12: and those on an employment visa in another ""line"". Now
column13: before you get all excited and quietly accuse me of misusing quotes here
column14: let me assure you that they are 100%!w(MISSING)arranted; for
column15: once upstairs
column16: all semblance of process disappeared: the employees refused to speak to the helpless foreigners
column17: and all of us knew that we were now in the Wild Wild West. But
column18: I must admit
column19: to our credit
column20: we followed what we believed to be the law of the land; we compared tokens
column21: claimed a corner of the room
column22: and set ourselves up in order. Several numbers were missing in the middle (they were in the student visa line)
column23: but we managed to get ourselves in an orderly
column24: seated line. I have no idea how many people were in front of me
column25: but I know it was less than sixteen. Things weren't all that bad (yet).

column1: For no less than an hour
column2: I sat
column3: happily
column4: playing sudoku
column5: reading Rachel Maddow
column6: and playing solitaire. Once it was my turn
column7: a lady and a gentleman
column8: in succession
column9: shamelessly hopped in front of me and handed in their papers. I did not see tokens in their hands
column10: and so I looked to my clueless friends in line with me who
column11: in response to my bewildered look
column12: shrugged their shoulders. Those doing the scrutinizing behind their desks didn't think anything of the line cutters
column13: so I went back to my games. After the cutters were finished
column14: it was my turn. My scrutinizer didn't say a word to me
column15: which I assumed was a good thing. After fifteen minutes of watching him flip through my papers and sign things
column16: I was finished! Time to go home
column17: right?

column1: Nope! Time to go to the authenticator. So I queued up behind a line of one (score!) and was authenticated in about five minutes. Where to now? The signature line
column2: of course! I was directed by my pearl of an authenticator to the ""cabin""
column3: about ten yards to my left. Once in the cabin
column4: my documents were signed by the fourth person... but this time
column5: with a fancy blue pen. Certainly this was the last step! Four reviewers and a signature with a fancy blue pen. What else could there be?

column1: Some may call it judgement. Some may call it torture. I haven't quite found the word for it
column2: but let's just say I think I have a pretty good idea of how Jesus felt for those 40 days in the desert. It was time for Counter 4.

column1: What could I possibly be talking about? What could have been that bad? Well
column2: let me start by saying that the woman staffing Counter 4 would have been well suited for the Third Reich. She was hands down the most sadistic person I have encountered during my time here (even more so than that dumb fuck rickshaw rickshaw driver who dropped me in the middle of nowhere yesterday ). As I sat in the chair
column3: facing her
column4: I was ignored for twenty minutes; imagine facing your judge and they could not even bother to acknowledge that you were a fellow Homosapien. No one else existed in the world except for the two of us
column5: but it was her world. I sat there
column6: sweaty browed
column7: anxiously waiting for either a directive or the end of days. To my relief
column8: I received a directive. Granted
column9: it was in the form of a grunt that was in no discernible language and an outstretched hand that I assumed meant she was ready for my paperwork. Since she could not be bothered to lean forward over her bloated belly to accept my paperwork
column10: I had to maneuver through the 12""x12"" square in the glass to deliver my papers right to her hands (picture Princess Leia feeding Jabba). We repeated our dance once more as she petitioned
column11: again in her own cute way
column12: for my passport. Sadly
column13: after chatting with her friends in what I can only assume was Kannada and without even hinting at providing any sort of service
column14: she handed me back my passport and our adventure together thus ended. She gave me the ol' stamp of approval
column15: and I was released.... for 2.5 hours while they ""processed"" my documents (Again
column16: quotes warranted. I'm pretty sure this was another one of their Gestapo tactics). Which brings us back to the coffee shop
column17: where I sit
column18: eating this God-awful donut and typing on my Kindle Fire. In a perfect world
column19: I'd have been lost in this entry and 2.5 hours would have fit in the last fifteen I spent writing this. But
column20: alas
column21: this world is far from perfect.

column2: I will leave you with a closing thought: I would rather spend my next TEN birthdays at the DMV than ever have to step foot into an FRRO again. Yes
column3: it's that bad.

column1: Appending note: today wasn't all bad; my visit to the FRRO gave me license to dress casually and consequently show up to the office looking like Richard Engel. It doesn't even the score
column2: but it is a small victory
column3: and I will take what I can get.

column1: Eventually there will be a day when nothing really out of the ordinary happens and I'll have to resort to summarizing little things that I've noticed here and there but haven't really been able to fit into any other post.

The first half of the day was pretty normal. Exact same breakfast buffet as described earlier (except I tried watermelon juice). Lectures weren't excessively noteworthy except for the fact that our second lecturer ran 40 minutes over because he had gotten the wrong stopping time. I got to unicycle during lunch
column2: yay! My hand pump to inflate Tweaker broke while I was trying to inflate the tire--not surprising since I paid only $2 for it plus shipping--but Keshav's friend had an air compressor in his car so I was soon tooling around near the courtyard. I think I'll be able to work on some flatland there
column3: which is good since I can't do any flatland tricks (yet).

column2: however
column3: was that our last lecture of the day was cancelled. Not only did this mean that we were freed of a 90-minute lecture
column4: but that Fae
column5: Sam
column6: Naveet
column7: Sumedha and myself were able to go shopping for saris. So off we headed to Commercial Street
column8: via auto of course
column9: to see what fun stuff we could buy.

column1: We wandered into a jewlelry shop first
column2: allured by the sparkles and shinies. I tried on a cool pair of turquoise earrings that loop over the shell over your ear and dangle down the back
column3: and Fae tried on a jewled headpiece. I was surprised that we could just take the earrings off the wall of the shop and try them on and put them back
column4: since that would be considered unsanitary in the states and the stores wouldn't allow that. We then remembered that we needed the saris before we could accessorize
column5: so we wandered down the street until we found a shop that looked promising.

column1: The shop was full of women
column2: so you know that it is a popular place to buy clothes. There were bright red signs everywhere ""Buy 1 Get 1 Free"" and ""50% Off
column3: but also ones that blared ""Beware of pickpocketers."" I kept my purse on my hip
column4: where I could see it
column5: and laid a hand on top to be doubly-sure. I was carrying enough to money to buy a sari (about 5000 Rs) and the last thing I wanted was to lose that. Especially since I had borrowed 2000 of them from Sam since I didn't have enough cash on me.

column2: but nothing really caught Fae's or Sam's attention and I had no clue what I was doing
column3: since my head was in the clouds. Both literally and metaphorically. I am taller than all the women in India
column4: at least all that I've seen
column5: and a large majority of the men. But I guess that's true in America too. But I digress. Saris are long rectangles of cloth that you wrap around you in such a way that you feel like a princess or a goddess come down to grace the poor earthlings with your presence. They were folded and stacked on shelves behind a large counter. You walk up to the counter and skim
column6: looking for one you like
column7: then point and ask an employee to lay it out on the counter. You can then examine it and see if you like the pattern. In that first shop we went to they catered more to the everyday people
column8: so you didn't get to try on the sari. We wandered to the back of the shop to look at kurtis
column9: which are Indian tunics that can be worn over leggings or jeans. I found two that I liked for 324 Rs each (under $6) and bought those. I wanted to buy a pair of leggings there to go with
column10: but they didn't have a good color.

column1: Once we finally got out of that shop (we all kept looking at kurtis) we wandered down the street again until we saw another sari shop. This one obviously was not just for everyday saris as it was completely empty when we came up. In this place the saris were hung on hangars instead of folded on shelves. One sari immediately caught my eye
column2: a turquoise with silver dots and maroon trim. The shop owner told us we could only try on a sari if we were likely to buy it
column3: so after dithering for a bit I asked him to try it on. First he wrapped a loop around my waist and then pinned it to itself to keep it up. Then a large length of it is accordian-folded to make extra fabric in front that swishes and flicks while you walk and makes you feel glorious. Finally
column4: the length that is left is brought up over the left shoulder to round off the goddess look. I can't wait to wear mine for reals.

column1: The sari itself set me back 1690 Rs (~$30) but I still needed to buy an underskirt (called a petticoat) and a blouse. It turns out that the sari fabric came with extra fabric that they use to make a blouse
column2: assuming you find a tailor. At the time I figured it'd be easier to just buy a blouse ready-made
column3: so once I'd purchased my lovely new sari we continued down the road to find Sam and Fae something
column4: since they hadn't found anything yet. Fae was looking for something very similar to a sari she'd tried on the day before the program started
column5: but with a smaller pricetag
column6: and Sam just hadn't seen anything she liked.

column1: The next shop we wandered into because they sold petticoats
column2: which I needed for my sari. Since the sari is sheer the petticoat is supposed to match exactly
column3: but they didn't have a shade that matched so I just went for a sort of forest green that would work under the fabric (cost: 195 Rs = $3.50). They sold leggings
column4: too
column5: and I found a pair that would work with my kurtis but when they named a price of 350 Rs I laughed and walked out. I know nothing about shopping
column6: especialy in India
column7: and even I knew that was ridiculous!

column1: Our next shop ended up being out last sari shop. Called WoW!
column2: which stood for World of Women
column3: it sat on a neon-lit street packed with nicer shops. The saris were folded and on shelves
column4: like the first shop
column5: except that they were stored in plastic packets to keep them neat. The overall feeling of the shop was more high-end than that of the second
column6: and way more high-end than that of the first. After viewing several saris
column7: Sam decided to try on a golden yellow one that ended up looking GORGEOUS on her. Fae was still comparing everything to the one she had tried on a couple days ago
column8: but she pulled out a red one and a magenta one to try. I was interested to see that in this shop the lady helping Fae with her saris offered her opinion on the choice of fabric color
column9: and I was happy that my opinions coincided with hers in terms of color choice. Fae ended up buying the red one
column10: but both looked wonderful
column11: and hers and Sam's saris ended up both costing around 3000 Rs each (~$53). The shop had a tailor who worked nearby come over to arranged making the blouses out of the extra sari fabric
column12: so I ended up just adding my sari to their order
column13: which is how I'm getting a tailored blouse.

column1: After Naveet and Sumedha haggled with the tailor to get us a better deal
column2: the tailor led us to his shop about two blocks away that was tucked into a sketchy back alley that made us a bit nervous when he first led us down. The shop was about 10"" deep and 6"" wide
column3: with four men crammed in over sewing machines. The tailor and another man talked to us over the counter in the front
column4: took our measurements
column5: and asked whether we wanted hooks in the front or zippers under the arm. Sam and Fae chose the zippers
column6: but I thought that might get scratchy if your arm rubs it so I went for the hooks instead. They also offered to hem my sari properly for 75 Rs so I threw that into the bargain. Then we realized we wanted to wear these to the banquet tomorrow night so Naveet and Sumedha had to heckle to get him to finish them on time. When he finally acceeded I was surprised--wouldn't it cost extra to get a rush job? Sure enough
column7: when the bill came he had added extra charges and the two Indian girls had to heckle (again) to get him to drop the price a bit.

column1: With that business completed we decided to find some grub. We quickly stopped in a last shop to buy leggings for me
column2: and Sam tried on some wickedly ridiculous harem pants that looked like they were made for the circus. When we found an auto he told us he'd take us anywhere close for free
column3: as long as we'd go to a shop afterwards for only 5 minutes. Apparently the shop had a deal with the auto driver that if he got people to go to the shop for 5 minutes they'd give him a coupon for 100 Rs and a t-shirt. Well
column4: who's to turn down a free ride to dinner? Especially when he'll wait while we eat then drive us back to the hotel after we visit the shop.

column1: So we went to a super-tasty
column2: super-cheap restaurant in the Kamat Hotel (I think. I didn't write the name down
column3: which is a pity.). We ordered three curry dishes--paneer tikka masal
column4: abu gobi
column5: and malai kopta--for around 100 Rs each ($2)
column6: a plain rice dish for 20 Rs ($0.40)
column7: and roti (which is basically pita) for less than 100 Rs ($2). I ate first with a spoon
column8: then with roti
column9: and finally fingers. As it turns out
column10: you're allowed to mix your curry and rice together with your fingers and scoop it into your mouth with your hands. When I saw Sumedha eating like that I immediately wanted to try. It's like finger painting
column11: but with food! We also had sauf at the end of the meal
column12: which is a collection of seeds that you and eat as a breath freshener. Tasted a bit like licorice.

column1: Before we could head back we had to head to the auto driver's contract shop. Turns out it sold a variety of Indian goods
column2: like scarves
column3: sandalwood
column4: incense
column5: jewellry
column6: knickknacks and trinkets. I didn't buy anything
column7: since I was shopped out and also hadn't figured out what souveniers I wanted to get for what people
column8: but Fae bought a cool scarf and Naveet and Sumedha bought gems for themselves and their fiancees. Something really funny happened in the shop: I kept looking at a variety of trinkets as possible souveniers for people but with no intention to buy. One of the workers was shadowing me and anytime I expressed interest in something he'd rattle off words about how good it was
column9: etc. And then I'd ask for the price
column10: he'd tell me
column11: and I'd say ""thanks"" and walk away. When we were in the jewellry room he showed me a box of bracelets and said 300-400 Rs. Of course I wasn't interested
column12: but what was funny happened later. As we were just trying to leave the jewellry seller roped Fae into trying on a bracelet from the same box. His price to her for the bracelet? 600 Rs! So I guess it's worthwhile to not be interested in anything for a bit
column13: then take them by surprise. :D

column1: We had a scare on our auto ride home. Just after we had left the curio shop I thought our auto driver was acting strangely
column2: driving slowly and waiting for the other auto with Sumedha
column3: Fae
column4: and Sam to catch up
column5: then following slowly. A bit later both autos turn down a side street
column6: then down a steep ramp into the parking garage of some building
column7: where they parked and turned off their motors. I was a bit nervous because Naveet was a bit nervous and she was asking the driver to ""just take us to our hotel."" I ducked my head to see out the auto better and saw two men nearby standing next to an elevator. So that made four men
column8: vs. us five girls. I was figuring if I should get ready to bolt when one of the men went to the first auto
column9: handed a business card
column10: then came to our auto and gave me a business card. Turns out these guys just worked for a silk seller and their method of getting business was for shopping foreigners (and perhaps Indians as well) to make an unscheduled stop. After we vehemently expressed a lack of interest
column11: our auto drivers took us back to our hotel like good little boys.

column1: We tried on our clothes in Naveet and Sumedha's room; turns out one of the kurtis I bought was too small and one of Fae's was too big
column2: so we switched. My other was also too small
column3: but we're taking it to the tailor tomorrow when we get our saris back and I'm getting strips put in the side to make it a bit wider. I'm also going to have him make the armholes in the other kurti bigger. My biceps are just too buff
column4: you know? All that iron I pump all the time. ;D

column1: This post might be a bit shorter than the others as I am pretty tired and my A/C has decided to go on the fritz. I talked to the front desk and they sent someone up
column2: but unfortunately he and I couldn't communicate. It's terribly frustrating
column3: since I was talking to some of the guys from India on the bus perfectly fine
column4: yet I just couldn't grasp the what this man was trying to say. He did say something about it being cool for 5 minutes
column5: or something
column6: but i just could not understand what he wanted from me. And I think he was frustrated that I didn't understand him. So I have no idea if/when they'll fix my A/C. 😞

column1: The day started out a bit earlier than I expected: my 7:30am wake-up call came at 6:40am. Fae said this happened to her as well
column2: so we're not sure what went wrong. It's kind of a common theme here. Well
column3: not things going wrong
column4: exactly. It's a bit hard to explain. To me it feels like everything here is on the verge of falling into total chaos
column5: but things are barely held together by metaphysical tape and the chaos only shows through now and then. Like my bag being lost
column6: and eventually delivered
column7: but damaged. Or dealing with auto drivers (I asked the Indian guys
column8: and that's the way to refer to auto-rickshaws in short). Or getting things fixed
column9: like my A/C. It won't necessarily happen quickly
column10: and I suspect there's no way to know when it will be fixed. It's a different feeling from the states
column11: where everything is very regulated and controlled. You know when you get your food
column12: when the repair-man is coming
column13: when your wake-up call is coming
column14: etc.
column15: and if something goes wrong it's cause to complain vigorously. I suppose you could complain for the same things here
column16: too
column17: but it would get you nowhere. Lucky for me I'm pretty easygoing so this is all part of the fun.

column1: The buffet breakfast was the same as yesterday
column2: except that the dubious french toast was replaced with pancakes. Which actually looked like pancakes and tasted similar to pancakes. Oh! And there was fresh-made grape juice
column3: which I've never had before. IT IS DELICIOUS. I wanted to steal the whole pitcher.

column1: I had to bring my duffel back to IISc today because a friend of Keshav (an awesome guy who's been doing a lot of behind-the-scenes work with the program) said he could get my bag repaired. This meant that I had to lug both the bag and Tweaker onto the bus
column2: which was less than stellar. I tried to ride Tweaker during the lunch break
column3: but I didn't inflate the tire nearly enough and had a huge problem just riding straight. Hopefully I'll do better tomorrow with more air. I'm not sure if practicing on the street where I was will work
column4: since it's still driven on occassionally but I'm going to keep trying. Perhaps a bit of exploring will lead me to a spot that will work.

column1: My favorite part of the day was a cultural lecture we had in place of our fourth professor lecture. A lady gave a presentation on the art of Rangoli
column2: which I had no clue existed before she told us about it. Rangoli is artwork that household women do on the pavement between the gate and the house every morning. Mrs. Pradash (I don't think that is her name but I have to call her something...) said that it's one of the first things women do in the morning. After waking up and perhaps boiling mint
column3: she heads out to sweep the front yard
column4: then cleans it with water and cow dung (since cows are sacred this serves as cleansing and purification)
column5: then create the Rangoli design in some sort of powder on the ground. Mrs. Pradash also talked about making Rangoli designs on a completly full
column6: completely settled container of water
column7: but I think the design on the ground is the most common. The designs are done every day
column8: unless something terrible has befallen the family such as a death or serious illness. It's even a bit of competition among the different households
column9: who can have the prettiest Rangoli. Kind of like husbands and yards back home.

column1: The name Rangoli comes from the Sanskrit word ""Rangavalli"" which is a joinging of the words for color (ranga) and rows of color (avalli). The designs are often inspired by nature
column2: and they are meant to block the negative energy outside of the house and only let in the positive energy. For you nerds out there I think of it as a ""good-pass filter."" :D The story she told us about the history of Rangoli is that a high priest of a long-ago king lost a son
column3: and the king drew an image of the boy and asked Brahma
column4: the god of creation
column5: to bring life to the drawing. In addition to the front yard
column6: Rangolis can also be found in the pooja room (the room where the gods reside) in the house. There are also Rangolis for festivals
column7: different ones for each festival
column8: and the festival begins with Rangoli.

column1: Rangoli can be made with a variety of materials and a veriaty of patterns. The designs made of powder can be made of rice powder
column2: crushed colored chalk
column3: crushed limestone
column4: or even crushed brick for red. Mrs. Pradash showed us pictures of Rangolis made in flowers
column5: from the petals of flowers like crysanthemums and marigolds
column6: and she had several designs she had made out of things like beads
column7: plastics
column8: glass fragments
column9: or fabric. She'd even made a Rangoli pattern on a coaster with puff paints. When I asked to see it at the end of the talk
column10: she told me I could keep it. It's sitting next to my bed
column11: now
column12: to give me good dreams! My favorite style of Rangoli was not the really elaborate patterns
column13: like the peacocks and sunsets
column14: but the geometrical dot and line Rangoli. To see the difference between the elaborate and the geometrical
column15: trying google-imaging ""rangoli"" and then ""dot rangoli"" and you'll see what I mean. She even gave us pencil and paper and had us draw the most basic dot Rangoli. I couldn't get my proportions right but I had a lot of fun. 😞

column1: Rangoli is traditionally done by hand
column2: but Mrs. Pradash showed us several gadgets that are available to help women make their Rangoli faster since they may have more responsibilities now that just staying at home. One was a tin cylinder with holes punched in a pattern; you filled the cylinder with sand then rolled it over the ground
column3: leaving a line pattern. Another was a container with four holes that you filled with sand to help you draw parallel lines. She even showed us Rangoli stickers
column4: for the truly busy.

column1: After the lecture we hopped back on the bus and came back here to the hotel. I didn't eat my wrap from lunch
column2: so that is going to be my dinner. Not only does that mean I get to earn a bit of money off my per diem
column3: it means I get to just stay in my room and veg out tonight. I'm pretty excited. What's even better is that as I was writing this post I had a couple times where the electricity in my room went out. I think it was a black out--apparently they are common here
column4: along with brown outs and grey outs--since my internet bugged out at that time
column5: but the best thing is that my A/C is working now! Yay! And I see that my post is just as long as my previous ones
column6: so I guess I muscled through this one just fine. 😊 Until next time!

column1: I'm going to attempt to fit about a week's worth of adventure into one entry (Wednesday 7/11-Thursday 7/19). Since work has started I've been a bit burnt out... My schedule has been irregular because of a long Friday night and several early work mornings. Here's my attempt at relaying nine days worth of events:
Let me start with some advice I received from my boss before I left: to state the obvious
column2: being gay in India is not like being gay in NYC (duh). I was told
column3: essentially
column4: to leave out some key details of my personal life so as not to let the proverbial cat out of the bag. This advice was given from the heart; my boss wanted to ensure that my work would be judged on its merits and not by what my teammates perceived my character to be because of my sexual orientation. I took this advice very seriously; I want this exercise to be as smooth as possible.

column2: as you may or may not know
column3: for the first eighteen years of my life
column4: it was regular practice for me to leave out key details of my personal life to keep that rambunctious cat in that tiny
column5: shrinking and ever-less efficacious bag. But after being out for six years
column6: and building a life based on being out
column7: this advice was more easily received than executed. My first night out with my team (which kept me at a house party until 4:30 am) was filled with a ton of awkward advice from my colleagues... Apparently
column8: my hair
column9: glasses
column10: and socks all point to homo in the eyes of twenty-something Indians (and probably most twenty-somethings around the world). So
column11: after a few drinks
column12: a few were comfortable enough to spill the beans: for sure
column13: American style is different than Indian style; but for God's sake
column14: I'd better be more careful
column15: else folks might think I'm actually gay! But
column16: not to worry
column17: they can tell me how to avoid that. The key to success in this endeavor
column18: I was told
column19: was to never
column20: under any circumstances
column23: is the dead giveaway (insert traumatized emoticon here). So... what did I do in response you ask? I evaded their questions on girls
column25: and wore pink socks on Monday. Yee-haw!

column2: so that was Friday. I'm going to skip over Saturday and Sunday for the most part. Highlights: I slept until 6pm Saturday evening (which ruined my schedule) did a very NY lounge with other folks in my program
column3: Amy
column4: Hannah
column5: and Jennifer (these are not their real names; they asked for pseudonyms in the blog)
column6: and did brunch with the same group on Sunday.

column1: Do you feel rested after the weekend recap? I hope so
column2: for more
column3: yes more
column4: drama is on its way.

column1: Let me continue with my journey for passport photos
column2: and my SP rickshaw driver who went rogue on my ass. At the suggestion of a friend
column3: I went to a shop a few blocks away for photos I would need for FRRO registration (see: Papers Please). Getting a rickshaw there was relatively easy
column4: and the driver was a very pleasant man. An old lady even helped him with directions
column5: unsolicited! I tried to pay him to wait for me outside the shop
column6: but he was too busy (doing what
column7: not sure). So I tipped him for his troubles and we went out separate ways. Feeling confident from that interaction I pressed on to get my photos. I accomplished as much without a hitch (other than looking awkward in my photo). Ay
column8: but the hitch was yet to come. On my return trip
column9: feeling that the universe was on my side from the tip I gave my last driver
column10: I was confident that getting home would be as easy. Silly me.

column1: After fighting with my first two rickshaw drivers because they were trying to fleece me
column2: I settled on the third
column3: who was charging just as ridiculous a rate (30 rps ); if they were going to steal from me
column4: at least they were all stealing at the market rate. Most rickshaw drivers don't speak English
column5: have probably never passed a driving test
column6: and certainly don't know where they are going. This poses a bit of a logistical issue for someone not familiar with the city. Long story short
column7: the motherfucker dropped me off about three blocks away from my hotel and did it with attitude. If I were in any Western city
column8: navigating those three blocks may not have been a challenge... But getting around in a 12th Century city with 18th Century infrastructure and 20th Century automobiles and 10 people per square foot is a bit of a task. Thank God I had emailed myself a map cut out of a 10 block radius around my hotel. By the time I found a road sign and mapped myself a route
column9: what should have been a three minute walk turned into a twenty minute adventure. I wasn't so much scared while I was walking around
column10: half aimlessly
column11: half intentionally; I was more so frustrated. It's tough when you lose at a game that you still don't know the rules of.

column1: To wrap up: that same day my expat security briefing was scheduled with the head of security for Asia. His main points: taking rickshaws is dangerous and dumb (everyone ignores this advice; if only I had gotten it before Sarah Palin dropped me off on the wrong block)
column2: tens of thousands of people die every year on Bangalore's roads due to automobile related accidents
column3: and if I am not careful
column4: I will wind up getting hit by a car
column5: laughed at by locals
column6: washed into a storm drain by a monsoon
column7: and left to die. Apparently this man has even more of a flare for dramatics than yours truly
column8: but that is his job.

column1: If that last paragraph made you anxious
column2: rest easy; I practice all the safety precautions
column3: and the firm has a strong presence in the city. If anything goes wrong
column4: they'll have my airlifted
column5: or whatever. I'll be fine!

column1: Today was another solid day in my Bangalore trip. It started out quite early
column2: around 4:30am or so
column3: because my body still hasn't quite adjusted and decided that it had had enough sleep
column4: thank you very much. I actually wasn't tired because my brain had gotten into the habit of sinking straight into deep REM the instant I fell asleep (thanks to excessive sleep dep.) so even though I only slept for less than 5 hours I was awake. Around 4:40 or so the islamic prayer came over the outside loudspeakers--a man's voice in a wailing
column5: ululating cry that echoed a bit eerily around outside. Not that I really heard it over the howling dogs. Yes
column6: that's right. People who have been here for a couple days inform me that every morning around that time the prayer comes on and the dogs howl with the singing. Right now I find it hilarious. In a couple days
column7: I will probably hate it. In a couple weeks I may be able to sleep through it!

column1: Breakfast was served on the fourth-floor Kebab restaurant
column2: buffet-style. There was a large variety of food and
column3: of course
column4: I tried to eat as much of it as I could. I had a pinwheel-shaped baked good
column5: a slice of white bread studded with candied fruits
column6: some sort of cold noodles
column7: ""french toast"" (more like flatbread with a thin coating of egg)
column8: vada with sauce (savory fritter with chives shaped like a donut)
column9: idly (pronounced ""id-lie"" it's this kind of salty sponge-like cake-thing made of rice and lentils) with coconut chutney
column10: a brown-style omelette with no cheese and some chives and tomatos in the egg
column11: a boiled egg
column12: and
column13: last but not least
column14: I tried my first cup of tea. I'm not sure what kind it is specifically
column15: I asked our Indian friends and they just said it's tea
column16: but it's served with milk and adding two lumps of sugar made it delicious. It almost tastes like they added cocoa to it
column17: but I don't think they did.

column1: After breakfast we piled into the bus to travel to the Institute of Science's campus. Day 2 and I'm already getting used to the driving methods here. It's rather strange
column2: but the rules make a lot of sense to me. It reminds me of swarming ants and large flocks of birds. On the surface it looks like chaos
column3: but when you get down to it there's no collisions between people. It's just like cooperative control and rigid formations. Then again we were in a large bus and people had to navigate around us. Things were still sketchy when viewed from the back of an auto-rickshaw (details below).

column1: The schedule today dictates what almost every day is going to be like for us for the next week and a half: two lectures in the morning
column2: with a break for tea
column3: then lunch
column4: then two lectures in the afternoon
column5: with a break for tea
column6: then a bus back to the hotel where we scrounge our own dinner. The teas and lunch were served in a small courtyard right next to the lecture room. A small courtyard that was also inhabited by...monkeys. Patrick and I had had a conversation earlier in the trip about how we'd both heard we weren't supposed to touch dogs
column7: cats
column8: or monkeys since there is a large rabies epidemic here. We'd laughed at the last. I mean
column9: really
column10: what were the chances we'd be anywhere near monkeys? Turns out
column11: pretty high. These monkeys looked similar to Jack the monkey from Pirates of the Carribean
column12: except they were a bit bigger on average
column13: about the size of cats
column14: and were all grey. The alpha male was the biggest of all
column15: maybe about the size of a medium-small dog. All of them had tufts of hair that made them look like they were wearing toupees.

column1: The lectures today were really good
column2: all topics that I am familiar with and like. The first was an overview of structural dynamics
column3: then wireless sensing and digital signals processing
column4: then experimental modal analysis and finally system identification. I really wanted to pay attention in the last lecture
column5: as he was discussing the theory behind wavelets and some system ID techniques I didn't know
column6: but jet lag hit me hard and it was all I could do to keep from literally passing out. At one point I fell asleep and did a head-bob
column7: with my eyes wide open and staring at the screen. It did not help that my bag had been delivered and all I wanted to do was shower
column8: brush my teeth
column9: and change my clothes.

column2: my bag was delivered today! Some of the program guys have been really awesome in keeping in touch with the baggage people
column3: so they delivered the bag to me at the lecture hall and I got to sign for it and regain posession of my bag right then and there. Unfortunately the bag did not come through unscathed. There's a zippered panel on the bottom side that hides some backpack straps
column4: and somehow that zipper was torn completely off the bag. The plastic handle on the bottom side is also broken. But the program guys are so awesome
column5: they've told me to bring the bag tomorrow and they'll get the zipper fixed. I think the handle's out of commission
column6: though
column7: but I don't use that one so it's okay. But this is a good lesson for travelers to India: be prepared for damage to your baggage
column8: and possibly the contents within. Especially bags like mine
column9: which have several straps and buckles hanging off it.

column1: My best adventure for the day commenced after returning to the hotel
column2: showering
column3: and changing into some new clothes (FINALLY). The title? AUTO-RICKSHAW DINNER ADVENTURE! A group from the American contingent (Reggie
column4: Samantha (Sam)
column5: Fae
column6: Patrick
column7: Chungzhao
column8: myself
column9: and Jim) and Nick (the Swede attending a university in Japan) decided to go out to dinner to a restaurant called Oye! Amritsar based on Sam's Lonely Planet book. Of course
column10: to get there we would need to be driven
column11: and what better way to get around the streets of Bangalore than in the wonderfully comfortable
column12: uber-safe backseat of an auto-rickshaw? So we split up into smaller groups (I rode with Nick and Sam
column13: all the blonds in one rickshaw!) and all found ourselves some rickshaws. Jim
column14: Sam
column15: and Fae had all taken an auto-rickshaw around yesterday so they knew how to go about it properly. Here's what I've learned based on our experience:

column1: • They are wicked fun and exhilirating to ride in.
• Stop panicking. The driver knows what he's doing and you'll be fine. Probably. Even if he pulls a u-turn into and through a line of oncoming
column2: full-speed traffic. We kinda thought we were gonna die on that one.

column1: • Write down where you want to go
column2: show it to them
column3: and ask them if they can take you there. I'm not positive
column4: but it seems the drivers are honest enough to tell you if they don't know where it is or if they can't even get you close. If there's another driver near they may flag him down for you. Be aware that if they don't know exactly where it is they may just drop you near and you'll have to hoof it and possibly ask for directions along the way.

column1: • MAKE HIM TURN ON THE METER. Once you've ascertained that he can get you where/near where you want to go
column2: tell him to turn on the meter. If he hems and haws
column3: say ""meter or nothing."" If he still refuses to turn on the meter
column4: find a different driver. If you don't do this
column5: and don't agree on a price beforehand he will rob you blind. If you agree on a price beforehand he may just up the price midway because he can. This happened to Jim
column6: Fae and Sam
column7: and Jim threw a fit but they still paid. In my personal opinion
column8: if this happens to you
column9: just pretend to grumble but have the bills for the original agreed fare in your hands. Then when he drops you off
column10: hand over the bills and walk away. He tried to cheat you
column11: might as well cheat a bit back. But really
column12: best way is to just turn on the meter.

column1: • Enjoy the experience. There's nothing like it.
• Sometimes you can get away with paying a few Rs less than the agreed price
column2: but only if it's 2 Rs
column3: none of you have 2 Rs and another customer comes along and the driver needs to go. Then he'll curl his hand into a fist
column4: face down
column5: then sweep his fingers down and towards you and say ""take it and go"" like he's disgusted with you. But you keep your rupees!

column1: Our driver dropped us off on some corner and pointed in some direction and said something unintelligible. We wandered down the street in the direction he had pointed
column2: asked for some directions and eventually found the others in our group who had been dropped off closer to the restaurant. Unfortunately
column3: it had closed down between the publication of the book and tonight. So instead we dropped into a restaurant we had seen while walking down the street
column4: one who's name I had recognized as also being in the Lonely Planet book--the Coconut Grove.

column2: dark-wood and lamp ambiance with northern Indian-style food. When I ordered the ""chettinad button mushroom"" (chettinad is a region of india) the waiter graciously warned me that it was spicy. I then added a side of naan
column3: and at the waiter's and Fae's suggestion (Fae is Iranian and so has experience eating similar cuisine) added in a side of curd (basically yogurt) to tame the capsaicin. Everyone got a ""plate
column4: a 14"" metal circle with 2"" sides as the rim
column5: with some sort of large leaf inside. Our dishes were then brought to the side of the plate
column6: and you spooned stuff onto the plate and ate it from there.

column2: indeed
column3: spicy
column4: but not unbearably so. It was a very thick gravy
column5: laden with spices
column6: with hunks of mushrooms floating around to make you feel all happy inside. The naan helped a little (mostly it was just tasty)
column7: Sam gave me some of her rice which helped too and made it even tastier
column8: and the yogurt helped a lot. I'm very glad Fae and the waiter told me to get it or my stomach would have been extremely unhappy with me. The naan was a style I haven't seen yet--this time it was similar to a tortilla that has had lots of slits put it in it so it looks kind of like something a goth might wear
column9: except it wasn't black. I finished off my meal with a ""mango waltz""--mango and vanilla ice cream with pieces of mango.

column1: The ride back was relatively uneventful
column2: but I really liked our driver this time. He made no fuss about turning on the meter
column3: had mostly intelligible English
column4: and asked us about what we were doing in Bangalore
column5: how we liked it
column6: etc. I even forgave him for trying to wheedle extra money out of us when we got to the hotel. I then finished unpacking
column7: assembled Tweaker
column8: hung out with Fae and Sam for awhile
column9: then started blogging. It is now WAY past my bedtime
column10: so I'm signing off!

column1: The weather when we arrived in Bangalore was beautiful
column2: perfectly cool and perfectly humid. We had some drivers to chauffeur us from the airport to our hotel in Ganga Nagar. THANK GOODNESS. I'll explain why in a bit. The vehicle of choice was a van similar in style to a VW minibus
column3: but with a bit more headroom and squishy seats that could seat 10 people comfortably. We six participants piled in the back to peer out the curtained windows
column4: our guides hopped in the front and we were off on our road adventure.

column1: And what an adventure it was. Anyone who has traveled to India knows: the traffic there operates on completely different rules than it does in the states. The white lines mean basically nothing. You drive in a mostly-straight line
column2: use your horn often to let people know where you are
column3: and stay on the left side of the road
column4: but beyond that there are few rules to follow. Well
column5: don't hit other cars/motorcycles
column6: I guess. Oh
column7: and the cows. Don't hit the cows. Because since they are sacred they wander the roads.

column1: So for most of our 40-minute drive to Ganganagar I was staring as the variety of motorbikes
column2: cars (some colorful and outlandish
column3: some normal) that were often only literally inches from my nose. There were many buses
column4: almost always full to the brim. One bus had a boy who was hanging out an open door as it drove along; when we stopped temporarily he hopped out and jogged around before jumping back onto the moving bus. Some men pee when they need to go and can find a wall. Almost no one wore shorts or anything above the knee. Most women wore saris or tunic and pants
column5: but there were a few that wore jeans and t-shirts. Only once did I see a pair of shoulders
column6: and those on a young boy working construction. Stray dogs roam the streets
column7: and there are people everywhere. All the time. On the roads
column8: by the roads
column9: near the roads
column10: walking
column11: biking
column12: chatting
column13: laughing
column14: sitting
column15: anything
column16: but there are people and there are a lot.

column2: though it is not very luxurious by American standards. I can hear the prayers over the speakers outside
column3: which I like. I lucked out and got a room to myself on the second floor with some nice natural lighting and a comfy bed. To get the lights to work and the A/C to turn on
column4: you have to stick your room key in a slot by the door. I didn't know this and when I first got here I went downstairs and told them my lights didn't work. They were so gracious
column5: after asking me if I had put my key in the slot (duh) they actually sent someone up to show me how to do it. So now I know: some hotels have key-slots to activate the room's electricity. My largest snafu today came when my room phone rang (which is
column6: incidentally
column7: in the bathroom. Not sure why.) and I answered it to hear a man say
column8: ""housekeeping."" ""Okay."" I said
column9: then waited. Did they have a message for me? After a period of awkward silence it became apparent that they wanted something from me. Unfortunately I didn't know what they wanted. So we ended up having an awkward conversation where I almost hung up
column10: or was silent
column11: and so did he
column12: and then I did hang up and went outside my room to talk to them since they were right there. I told them I didn't understand what they had wanted. In my defense
column13: how could I? They hadn't actually asked me for anything. Well
column14: we ended up not really communicating and he and his buddy smiled that awkward smile Indian people give you when you're not communicating well or you've done something wrong and they feel uncomfortable. Turns out I think they were seing if I had anything to launder
column15: so next time I guess I should say ""I don't need anything
column16: thanks.""

column2: Patrick and I walked around our street a bit to get a bite. We visited a KFC and a Domino's
column3: and the boys chose Domino's (I wasn't eating). It was on the second story
column4: which meant I was able to watch the busy street
column5: and dogs and cows
column6: while we waited. Afterwards I made them visit an alleyway I had scoped out as a possible unicycling location. That's going to be difficult
column7: unicyclig here
column8: because there aren't parking lots like I'm used to. I need large
column9: relatively flat ground
column10: where I won't get run over by speeding autorickshaws
column11: and I might not get that here. Anyway
column12: turns out the alleyway led to a pretty cool graveyard back behind the houses. Maybe I won't practice there.

column1: Dinner is what has really made today fantastic. The dinner tonight was a reception with all of the Asia-Pacific School in Smart Structures students
column2: which includes people from universities in Japan
column3: China
column4: Korea
column5: U.S. and India. We started with a toast of Kingfisher beer
column6: then everyone had to introduce themselves individually during this time. Of course
column7: with 50 participants this took a large amount of time. This was happening on the top floor of our hotel
column8: on a terrace which had some 6' walls that were stone on bottom half
column9: glass up top
column10: that looked over the city
column11: and in particular down onto the roof terrace of the next building owner. I was leaned up against this wall
column12: my back to the building
column13: but at some point during the talktalk I turned around and was an Indian girl on the roof
column14: watching this large group of foreigners right next door. She was wearing the tunic and leggings that you see in place of saris on some women
column15: and a veil
column16: all brightly colored
column17: so I spotted her right off
column18: grinned
column19: and waved. She smiled and waved back and I turned back around to pay attention. Later on I peeked again to see if she was still there and saw that she had a friend with her now
column20: and when they saw me look at them they collapsed into giggles and lash-fluttering. And that's when it hit me.

column1: They were flirting with me. With my hair braided back
column2: my male-styled tank and my guy's button-up t-shirt on top
column3: they thought I was some blond foreigner flirting with them. I almost collapsed into giggles right then
column4: it was so ridiculous. I did turn back to the room and tried not to attract their attention anymore but the damage was done. I have flirted with Indian girls. What's worse
column5: I think they were only around 14 or so. I was definitely embarassed
column6: when I realized what was going on
column7: but the humor of the situation was not beyond me. When we broke from the terrace to sit down to eat I pulled Reggie and Patrick over to wave at them too
column8: just for fun.

column1: Dinner was one of the most amazing meals of my life. We sat and had plates in front of us
