column2: and waiters kepts coming around and offering bits of this
column3: bits of that
column4: whatever they had. Anytime they offered me something I just smiled and said ""yes
column5: please"" regardless of what it was. I had potatoes
column6: chicken
column7: prawns
column8: baby corn
column9: tofu
column10: fruit
column11: veggies
column12: and more
column13: all cooked in an Indian kebab-style. I was getting a little full from the delicious food when I listened to someone talking next to me and realized that these were only the appetizers. There was a buffet next door with even more delicious food. I had veggie rice
column14: egg-fried rice
column15: dal (a tasty mush made of lentils)
column16: some lamb -in-mystery-sauce
column17: some chicken-in-mystery-sauce. I piled the sauce-foods on the rice-foods on my plate and took it back to my seat. Then waiters brought around dosa and naan
column18: two types of flatbreads. Dosa has a consistency that reminds me of steamed buns and naan is like pita
column19: but not really.

column1: I'm happy of how I ate tonight because I think I ate this food in a proper indian manner. The left hand stayed strictly in my lap and did not come anywhere near my food. I used my right hand to tear of bits of the naan or dosa
column2: then laid those bits over the sauce-and-rice-and-meat and pinched the edges together to get a nice packet of flatbread-and-delicious. As I ate I conversed a lot with some Indian professors near me and I tried to learn more about Indian culture
column3: what to expect
column4: what to eat
column5: how to eat
column6: and much more.

column1: The meal was concluded with the waiters handing around two bits of leaves wrapped up like a packet on a toothpick. I
column2: unfortunately
column3: thought it was more food and popped one into my mouth before finishing my ice cream. This matters because it was paan
column4: an after-meal item meant to help digestion. The flavor is really strange. There's no way I can describe it
column5: though I can describe the consistency. It's like chewing a leaf. Well
column6: that's because it is a leaf. Kind of a thicker one
column7: though
column8: like a palm frond. What was really strange
column9: besides the taste
column10: was that I felt it doing something to my stomach. Kind of like when I eat mint and I can feel it in my stomach. The taste was so overpowering at first I found it a bit nauseating. The other kids that tried it definitely did not enjoy it either; it was hilarious to watch unwitting students pop one into their mouth and then make a really strange face. I tried to eat the first one fast so I could finish my ice cream
column11: but didn't really enjoy it. I tried the second one
column12: despite the first one being less-than-stellar
column13: more out of trying to outdo the people around me than anything else. That's when I realized it's not meant to be chewed and eaten
column14: paan is meant to be chewed and sucked on. It's not the leaves that are useful
column15: it's the juices. And sure enough
column16: the juices mae my stomach feel nice
column17: though not if I had too much at once. Fun learning experience of the day.

column1: After that we chatted with some of the students from other countries
column2: and then I headed off to my room to write these first two entries. I figured I better stay up and do this now--if I keep having so many new experiences every day I can't afford to fall behind on writing them down!

column1: Whew! So much has happened already on this trip to Bangalore (or Bengaluru if you prefer) that I've decided to write a blog about it. This way my mom can keep careful track of me
column2: my friends can see what hijinks I get up to
column3: and maybe other people can benefit from the experiences I had traveling from North Carolina
column4: USA to Bangalore
column5: Karnataka
column6: India.

column1: My flight schedule was: 2-hour flight from NC to JFK (Friay afternoon)
column2: 7-hour flight to BRU (arrive Saturday morning)
column3: 8-hour flight to Delhi (arrive Saturday night)
column4: then (next Sunday morning) a 2-hour flight to Bangalore. Since I did not book my own tickets--they are courtesy of my Smart Structures program--I didn't even notice that I was overnighting in Delhi for about 7 hours. Luckily I was traveling with two other participants all the way from JFK so we exchanged emails about how we would deal with that layover. Not that the layover went as planned
column5: but I'll get there. ;D

column2: as was the airport in Brussels. I was interested in comparing my flight to Brussels
column3: (operated by American) and my flight from Brussels (operated by Jet Airways). The second flight was definitely more comfortable
column4: but it also just felt more luxurious. The AA flight had two movies
column5: but the screens were in the center of the aisle so I
column6: being tall and sitting in the window seat
column7: could not see a lot of the screens. The food was okay
column8: but mostly it just felt cramped and I'm glad I slept for some of that flight to get it over with.

column2: my second flight was GLORIOUS. There were screens in the backs of the seats with Hollywood movies
column3: Bollywood movies
column4: games
column5: music
column6: the whole shebang. The quality of the food on both flights was about the same
column7: your usual airplane meal and snack
column8: but I was delighted to be fed. I haven't been fed on a plane since I was five or so. I watched most of the Bollywood movie Robot
column9: of which I had seen a few hilarious clips before this trip
column10: and would have finished it except I accidentally exited the movie and reentering started you from the beginning with no good fast-forward option. So instead I watched ""Always Kabhi Kabhi"" (""Always Sometimes"") which is similar to High School Musical in style.

column1: Things really took a turn for the adventurous in Delhi. There we were supposed to get off the plane
column2: pass through immigration
column3: get our bags
column4: pass through customs
column5: then check back in through a domestic transfer point to get back into the secured domestic area where we could get to our transit hotel
column6: an hourly hotel within the airport. Unfortunately
column7: we managed to get through immigration without a fuss
column8: passing under some cool statues of huge hands in Buddhist or Hindu signs
column9: but it was getting our bags that gave us trouble. Apparently the baggage handling system in Brussels broke down
column10: and our plane was forced to leave with a large number of bags missing. This translated to my first true glance into Indian culture.

column2: it seems that one does not queue up in India. One MOBS. When people realized bags were missing
column3: everyone flocked to the Baggage Enquiries desk
column4: manned by a couple truly unlucky people that day. People were angry
column5: voicing frustrated complaints in tones of voices that would probably have someone intervening in America with calming comments. The paperwork process to report our bags was roundabout and time-consuming: once you got a paper from the desk
column6: you filled it out
column7: gave it back to them while they filled out another form that they gave back to you to take down to a guy 50 feet to the left so he could stamp it and you could bring it back to the desk. This meant that this angry mob was stuck in front of that desk for hours. I hung out at the back. I wasn't going anywhere. Why get entangled? I was ridiculously amused
column8: though
column9: especially after they ran out of forms
column10: went to get more
column11: and were passing them out from the front of the mob. You've seen footage of the stock market
column12: a huge group of agitated people waving papers in the air? Yeah
column13: it was like that. I saw two guys wich a stack of papers almost go into a tug-of-war game and rip the whole stack. So
column14: so amusing. And so different from anything I'd see back home.

column1: After about two hours of hanging near the back of the mob and chatting with friendly Indian people who told me foods to eat
column2: where to visit
column3: Patrick and I (Yao did not check any bags so he had already gone to the hotel) decided we wouldn't bother to go to the hotel
column4: we'd just crash the terminal. So we ""went through"" customs--it was deserted and we had no bags to be checked anyway--and into a really nice terminal. I partook in a sponge-bath in one of the bathrooms because I felt pretty gross and needed to wake up. There were ladies cleaning in the bathroom
column5: and when I asked them if I could dunk my head they smiled and nodded. But when I tried to wipe down the sink after I was done they shooed me out and looked a bit put out. One of the Indian professors I spoke with tonight said that Indian people take hospitality very seriously
column6: and I think that me trying to clean up after myself might have been insulting their hospitality. Or taking their job. Either way
column7: I think they weren't super sad to see me go.

column1: In the terminal I bought a tikka sandwich (it's like chicken salad with curry and onions) that was packaged exactly the same as they sell tuna sandwiches from gas stations in the states
column2: and some water. Things are cheap here: the sandwich and water cost less than 200 Rs (rupees) which is around $3
column3: and I probably got really overcharged for both. A bit later Patrick and I relocated to our gate
column4: and I bought 2 samosas and a bottle of mango juice for around the same price. The mango juice was super-sweet
column5: just as I expected. It tasted like someone pureed some mangos
column6: then extricated all the water they possibly could. I think there were over 100g of sugar in that drink
column7: but it was de-ri-cious. The samosas were also tasty
column8: and the guy at the coffee shop even heated them up in the microave
column9: or as they say ""made it hot."" I tried to practice eating properly
column10: with only my right hand
column11: but I think my technique is still a bit foreign because I was biting chunks out of the samosas and I saw a guy tearing hunks off and dipping them in the provided ketchup. I'll have to try that next time.

column2: it was simply a matter of waiting before we boarded our last flight to Bangalore. Three other APSS participants were due to fly with us on that flight
column3: and they only barely made the connection due to baggage/customs/etc. I don't remember much of the flight--I hadn't slept much
column4: or well
column5: in the last 36 hours so I sank into REM awhile into the flight and only woke up when we touched down. And then I was in Bangalore.

column1: Mysore has always been one of the major tourist attractions in South India. My previous visit to Mysore was about 20 years ago
column2: when I was in college. I still keep a lot of great memories of that college trip to Mysore and we remember some of the words from the tourist guide in the palace.

column1: After we moved from USA to Bangalore
column2: we wanted to visit all of the major tourist attractions around Bangalore and Mysore was an obvious choice. Many people from Bangalore visit Mysore and return on the same day. However
column3: considering there are several places to see in Mysore
column4: it may not be a fun trip if you rush from place to place with a tight schedule in hand. Two days is ideal to see most attractions in Mysore.

column1: We wanted to make it a real fun trip and so we decided to spend 2 nights and 2 full days in Mysore.

column2: Mysore

column1: We started after lunch from Bangalore. The drive was very comfortable in the highway. We were estimating to reach Brindavan Garden by around 4:30 but got lost the way in Mysore town and so it was about 6'O clock when we entered the garden. It was very crowded and we could not enjoy the garden since it was already dark. We took a small boat trip within the garden
column2: watched the musical fountain and exited the place at about 7:30pm.

column1: We did not have a hotel reservation in Mysore. That is becoming a practice for us these days. Most of the weekend trip we made were without a hotel reservation. Sometimes we landed in to trouble but most of the times we were able to find good hotels at relatively low rates when we walk in and ask for room rates. We returned to Mysore town from Brindavan and I started driving around looking for hotel. I stopped in front of a 3-Star hotel but they did not have any room available. Once I got in to the car after enquiring availability in the hotel
column2: someone came in a scooter and knocked on the car. I drove away quickly since I didn't know his intentions. But he kept following us and started shouting and waving his hands. Finally I stopped the car in a crowded area and asked what he wants. Then he explained that he can help us get a hotel room at low rates in the available vacant rooms. After negotiating the rates
column3: he took us to a hotel called ""Adhi Manor"" where he arranged an A/c room for us at a rent about 40%!o(MISSING)f their published rates.

column1: Hotel Adhi Manor: The hotel was pathetic. Very poor quality rooms
column2: lot of bugs around and not even the reception looked good. The bed was very old. Based on our request
column3: they moved us to another room but that was no different. Next morning
column4: the first thing I did was to find another hotel for the rest of our stay in Mysore.

column1: Hotel Palace Plaza: After visiting couple of hotels
column2: I found Hotel Palace Plaza
column3: which turned out to be an excellent place for stay in Mysore. Rent was bit high compared to the low rates we got in the previous hotel but the stay was very comfortable. Due to the bad experience previous night
column4: we did not had much expectations
column5: but we all loved the new place. They have a restaurant called ""Dynasty""
column6: which served very tasty food for us
column7: looked very clean and have very friendly staff. I have written a bit more on the best restaurants in Mysore.

column1: Mysore Zoo - the best attraction in Mysore
After a tasty breakfast at Dynasty
column2: we visited Mysore Zoo. We spent about 3 hours in the zoo but the kids were very tired after walking all the way within the zoo. We somehow wanted to get out of the place
column3: but even though tired
column4: kids wanted to see all animals. The zoo was pretty crowded but since it is a huge area
column5: the crowd did not make it uncomfortable. After seeing hundreds of animals
column6: we exited the zoo and drove back to the hotel for a short break.

column1: Keeping the taste of breakfast in mind
column2: we returned the Dynasty restaurant in Hotel Mysore Palace for lunch and ordered some Chinese food. They served the hot food in the room. Not sure if it was because we were all hungry and tired
column3: but we felt it was one of the best food we had recently!

column2: we took a small nap and then came out of the room. We saw many horse safaris near the temple. We negotiated with couple of people and finally came down the rate from Rs 500 to Rs 250 for a 20 minute ride. (Later
column3: we met other people who offer the same ride for Rs 75). During the 20 minute ride
column4: they offered us to take to a great market place in Mysore were we can shop as long as we want and he will wait outside for us. And he said this was a courtesy to the visitors to Mysore
column5: but it was cheating. He took us to a textile showroom were we ended up spending lot of money (our fault) and later realized the horse safari people took us there to get commission for the items we purchased.

column2: we returned to the hotel
column3: took a shower
column4: changed the dress and then started looking around for places for dinner. Even though we loved the food at the restaurant in the hotel
column5: we decided to try something else for dinner. We had heard about the theme restaurant at Hotel Pai Vista
column6: which was walking distance from our hotel. The restaurant looked very interesting. It was made with the theme of a jungle/forest. The waiters were dressed like hunters and they had lot artificial animals or stuffed animals everywhere in the restaurant. Food was bit expensive but was tasty. Kids enjoyed watching the animals and messing with the hunters!

column1: Mysore Palace - the historical monument in Mysore
Mysore Palace is the giant palace of the Kings
column2: which attractions millions of domestic and foreign visitors every year. Photography is not allowed inside the palace but you can take pictures outside the buildings. It will take about 1 to 2 hours to see and enjoy the palace. You can rent automated voice guide system which will give detailed history of each important buildings and rooms in the palace.

column1: Mysore is a great place for shopping silk items and Sandal products. However
column2: be aware of lot of fraud referrals. Taxi driver
column3: auto rickshaw driver
column4: travel guides - almost anyone you meet would refer you to some of the ""best market"" that is offering some ""special deals"" ""only on that day""! We fell into that trap multiple times and ended up wasting lot of money in various shops. For example
column5: a tourist guide who offered to take us to many attractions like Sandalwood factory at a very nominal fee of Rs 40. We drove all the way with him just to see a small shop
column6: which claimed is the factory. We were expecting a huge factory where they cut big trees and make various things from Sandalwood
column7: but disappointed to see a small shop which wasn't worth the drive at all. Moreover
column8: the guide had said the factory is open only on Tuesdays for visitors but we learnt from the shop that it is open for all any day.

column2: going there
column3: etc

column1: I've made it here... in one piece. Thank the deity (also known more commonly as Ina).

I had a couple of ideas last night for names of my first entry. They all came to me on my cab ride from the airport to my apartment. The country (this area at least) feels similar to the Western Caribbean
column2: with blocky
column3: cement dominated architecture
column4: similar food and sporadic packs of wild dogs (they're not dangerous... from what I hear). There are many things here that are direct imports from the West: one block we drove down had a series of signs for a McDonald's placed every few steps... McDonald's
column5: 149 steps ahead! McDonald's
column6: 113 steps ahead! McDonald's 86 steps ahead! McDonald's
column7: on your right! But my favorite: a sign for Hot in Cleveland
column8: Betty White's new show (the inspiration for this post's title)
column9: which I've actually rarely seen advertised in the U.S. I guess in today's world
column10: no matter how far you travel on this rock
column11: you're never that far from home.

column1: Getting here took quite a toll: Qatar Airways figured out my plot to have my own row and bumped me to what they promised was a much

column2: I won't be eating the fruit

column1: better location on the plane. They sat me next to a father and daughter who were nice enough

column3: there was nowhere in front of me to stow my backpack that I filled with goodies for the trip

column5: Qatar (my layover)

column8: security in Doha was efficient (you get to keep your shoes on your feet!). I left on a Sunday night
column9: got here on a Tuesday morning at 3 am
column10: and slept until 6 pm
column11: which means I haven't seen the sun in a very long time (don't ask me to do that math).

column1: My apartment (pics posted) is as nice as expected; I've got a kitchenette
column2: a large living room
column3: a dining nook
column4: desk for work
column5: large bedroom with king-sized bed
column6: and a

column1: spa inspired bathroom all to myself!

column2: to say the least. Unfortunately
column3: leaving the hotel by foot is not recommended
column4: and there isn't much around the hotel other than furniture stores and crumbling bodegas (I'm sure they have a name for them here
column5: but I've yet to learn it)
column6: so I will be spending quite a bit of time in my apartment. For trips other than to and from work I will have to find myself a driver since renting a car is impractical and driving in the city is pretty dangerous: red lights mean nothing

column8: sidewalks don't exist
column9: and the car horn is a well developed but little understood language by foreigners. Thank god wages here are low and the exchange rate is favorable; a personal driver it is!

column1: Work starts tomorrow at 1pm local time. At this point
column2: I am content with my accommodations and am optimistic about this trip. I will have a better feel for how things will go the next six months in the coming days as I assess what work will entail and get a sense of what Bangalore has to

column1: View of the beautiful hills from Divine Euphoria
I just came back from a trip to Divine Euphoria
column2: one of the most attractive weekend destination near Bangalore. Whenever we travel to any vacation places or picnic spots around Bangalore
column3: I take down a lot of notes hoping to blog about it
column4: but I hardly get time time once I get back home. Even though we have visited most of the popular weekend destinations around Bangalore and have taken hundreds of photos

column1: Divine Euphoria is our favorite weekend destination and picnic location around Bangalore. Yesterday was our third visit to this amazing farmland picnic place
column2: after I purchased a small plot there to build our own farmhouse. Before I go too far
column3: let me give some background about this place and how we found this place.

column1: After spending a good part of our life abroad
column2: we decided to come back to our home country and spend the rest of our life here enjoying what we really love. Buying some farmland having lot of animals and lot of

column1: fun was one of the entertainment plans. I started searching for some kind of ""managed farmland"" where someone else will take care of all the work and we just need to spend our time with plants and pets. I posted the requirement in some forums and someone pointed us to Divine Euphoria. When we read more about them
column2: it was like our dream coming destination.

column4: offices etc)

farm houses already built by many people which include wooden cottage

column4: once you leave Kanakapura town

column4: boat house

column1: We met one lady from Punjab or Mumbai who was living there in a tent cottage. She seem to be a frequent visitor with her children and grand children. This time she was with her son and was planting lot of fruit trees in her farm plot. She owns a pretty big plot there and has planted a lot of trees and vegetables. I wonder if she would be able to pick the
Tent cottage at farmland near Bangalore

Here is a ready to use tent house in Divine Euphoria. This tent house was already occupied by a lady visitor from Mumbai. She purchased a farmhouse plot at Divine Euphoria after reading the reviews about the project. She is from Mumbai and comes all the way to this place for vacations. When I met her
column2: she said it was her 5th visit to the place.

column1: fruits/vegetables unless she visit often. When I asked her about it
column2: she simply smiled and said her intention is not to make money out of vegetables. That was very true. I don't think even we bought the plot there to plant vegetables and harvest. Instead
column3: people are there to have some quite and relaxing time with the nature and nurture the trees and plants.

column1: Like to have some time with the mother nature
column2: away from the crowd and pollution of cities like Bangalore? You will not see any better place than Divine Euphoria. Even though there are many other farmlands near Bangalore
column3: I don't see anything else even comparable to Divine. Whether you want to buy your own plot and build a farm house or buy an already built cottage or just rent a cottage for overnight stay or just have some day trip picnic
column4: you can confidentally choose this place.

column1: All good things come with some not so good experience as well. Here are some drawbacks I can think of about this place:
• No internet connection. If you are a busy worker and like to continue your online work while your family
This is another cottage which look very beautiful. This is ready to occupy and serves the weekend visitors from Bangalore to this farmland often.

column2: you do not have any choices here (unless you have your own mobile internet or data card)

column1: • No hospitals in the vicinity if you have an emegency. No doctor on call. Medical help may be too far.
• No restaurants nearby. You will have to either cook yourself or depend on their restaurant
column2: which is not yet completed.

column1: • Slow progress of the project. They launched the project more than a year ago
column2: but it is not even near completion. Day picnics and night stays are offered only for the potential customers and people who have contacts with them. Not yet open for public. Very less visitors currently.

column1: • Private properties are mixed with common amenities. You will have no idea which cottage is occupied by private parties and which are common properties which everybody can walk in to.
• Too large area sorrounded by hills. Small kids may get lost within the property because of similar looking plots and roads.
• No internal transportation. You may have to drive or walk pretty long distance from one amenity to other. They said they will provide battery operated carts like Golf cart
column2: but I don't see anything coming up yet.

column1: This mud house is under construction. I think this is a model cottage
column2: which visitors can rent for overnight stay at the farmland. I think visitors from Bangalore and other metro cities who live in concrete apartments would love to spend a few nights in a mud house.

column1: have given my feedbacks to the developers few times and they seem to be listening to all suggestions. None of my suggestions are implemented so far
column2: but they promised they will look in to all these. I have written more detailed review of Divine Euphoria Farmland project at IndiaTravelBlog.

column1: The farmland is located about 65 km from Bangalore city. If you are coming from Sarjapur Road or Martaalli area
column2: take the Hosur Rd and then take NICE road. Exit at Kanakapura Road. You will reach Kanakapura within an hour. After Kanakapura junction
column3: take the left turn towards Sangam road
column4: which leads to the Cauvery river and the famouse fishing camps. After about 11 km
column5: you will see a small sign board on the leftside to Divine Euphoria. The destination is about 1 km from the statehighway to Sangam.

column1: Avoid travelling in the night to the place since it will be hard to get guidance in case you get lost. There are not many houses around and you will hardly see any people after sunset.
Hab mich von Wwoofhost getrennt und ab in den Bus nach Mysore. Die Busfahrt ist ein Abenteuer.
Vor uns bleibt irgendwann ein LKW stehen und blokiert die Strasse. Nicht gross erwaehnenswert beim aussteigen faellt aber auf
column2: dass unser Bus viel einer neongelben Fluessigkeit verliert. Ich haette auf eine Art Hydraulikflussigkeit getippt. Jedenfalls scheint es keinen zu interessieren
column3: weiter geht die Fahrt. Irgendwann halten wir dann an und sie kippen Wasser nach. Warscheinlich war es doch nur Kuelfluessigkeit. Trozdem seltsame Farbe. Jedenfalls halten wir noch 2 oder 3 mal an. Einmal an einer Moschee
column4: wo irgendein alter Mann scheinbar gar nicht gluecklich ist
column5: dass sein gutes Moscheehahnenwasser jetzt als Buskuehlwasser missbraucht wird
column6: einmal an einem Bach bei dem ich mich frage wie sehr sich der Bus ueber die Truebstoffe freut. Auf dem Weg fahren wir durch mehrere Wildreservate. Die Tiger bleiben leider verborgen aber immerhin sehe ich einige vermutlich halbwilde Elephanten. Irgendwann ist der Bus dann wohl doch am Ende.

column1: Jedenfalls tauschen nach einer halben Stunde warten den Bus. Auf dem Pissoir der Busstation starrt ein Inder noch voellig dreist und ununterbrochen auf meinen Penis und macht am Ende noch anzuegliche Schmatzgeraeusche. Gluecklicherweise besetzen irgendwelche netten Studenten mir einen Sitzplatz im neuen Bus. Nach 8h statt 5h Fahrt kommen wir in Mysore an. Such mir Zimmer und erkunde noch ein wenig die Stadt. Anfangs sind meine Abwehrmechanismen noch auf Alarmstufe Rot. Aber hier in Mysore sind die Menschen netter. Sie schleppen einen zwar auch in ihre Laeden aber sie sind freundlich
column2: geben einem nuetzliche Tipps und sind nicht beleidigt wenn man dann doch nichts kauft. So komm ich auch in einer kleinen Raeucherkerzenmanufaktur vorbei und bekomme den nuetzlichen Tipp
column3: dass der teure Palast heute umsonst sei und Abends toll bleuchtet wird.

column1: Auf dem Weg dorthin spricht mich noch ein Inder an. Irgendwie ist mir sofort klar
column2: dass das kein Verkaufer ist
column3: dafuer hat er ein viel zu unverbrauchtes Gesicht. Ist er auch nicht. Nach kurzem Smalltalk kommt die Frage: ""Are you gay"". Nach hoeflich verneinen und kurzem weiteren Gespaech fragt er: ""You are a 100% not gay"" und ""You never like to try sex with a man"". Ich glaube irgendwann ist er dann ueberzeugt
column4: ich mach ein Foto vom Palast und verliere ihn ausversehen. Ich haette mich gern noch mit ihm unterhalten aber es kann gut sein
column5: dass er lieber weitere Europaer anquatschat als weitere Zeit mit mir zu vergeuden. In Indien gibt es offiziell keine Schwulen. Homosexualitaet erfaehrt in Indien absolut keine Toleranz. Dementsprechend trauen sich die Schwulen hier natuerlich nicht sich zu outen und muessen es bei toleranten Europaern versuchen bei denen ihr Geheimnis zumindest Gewahrt bleibt. Interesannterweise werden Transvestiten toleriert. In Mubai konnte man die abundzu sehen. Als ich Ajeet (Mumbai) nach ihnen gefragt habe sagte er:"" Ja klar
column6: das interessiert niemand. Die haben ja keine Rechte."" Aber Schwule? Das liegt ganz ausserhalb des Vorstellbaren.

column1: Vor dem schoen beleuchteten Palast sind wir Weisse wieder Fotoobjekt. Unter anderem wird mir fuer ein Foto ein kleiner Sohn in die Hand gedrueckt der mir vor lauter Angst dann ueber die Hand pinkelt. Ich treff hier auch noch Jeremy aus Australien. Angehmer Typ und wir trinken spaeter noch ein Bier.

Morgens ab auf so nen heiligen Huegel von Mysore. Chamundi Hill. Sehr langweilig. Ganz nett sind die Treppen die ich hier runterlaufen kann. Auf dem Weg bin ich wieder Fotoobjekt aber so treff ich eine nette indische Familie und weil ich gerade nichts besseres zu tun habe begleite ich sie spontan in den Zoo. Der Zoo ist vergleichbar zu deutschen Zoos
column2: nur dass wie vieles in Indien alles gerammelt voller Menschen ist und teilweise irgendwelche affigen Polizisten meinen sich aufspielen zu muessen und Menschen mit ihrer Pfeife weiter zu scheuchen. Ist aber ne nette Sache mit ner indischen Familie in den Zoo zu gehen. Ein riesiger Zufall will es auch so
column3: dass ich 2 Tage spaeter 3 Jungs von denen mitten auf der Strasse in Bangalore wiedersehe.

column1: Mittags bin ich mit Jeremy und einem Amipolen Tam unterwegs. Witziger Unterschied. Jeremy isst vor allem Strassenessen schlaeft auch mal auf ner Bank und versucht jede Rupie zu sparen. Tam benutzt nichtmal Sonnencreme
column2: ist Vegetarier und auch sonst sehr auf Sicherheit bedacht. Wir Essen in einem kleinen billigen Resraurant das sichtlich nicht zu Tams behagen ist. Spaeter schauen wir uns nen Bollywoodfilm an(natuerlich nicht Englisch). Ein Riesenspektakel mit Gangstern
column3: Himmel und Hoelle
column4: ausdrucksstarken Gesichtern und Gesten
column5: schoenen Frauen die einem anderen Schoenheitsbild entsprechen
column6: viel Liebe und mit immer wieder pfeifendem und jubelndem Publikum. Auf jeden Fall ein Muss wenn man nach Indien geht.

column1: Danach trinken Jeremy und ich noch Bier in der billigsten Kneipe die wir finden und freuen uns darueber.

Morgens mit dem Bus nach Bangalore. Ich goenn mir die Deluxe AC Version. Ungluecklicherweise kommen wir an nem anderen Busterminal an. Und weil ich nicht Rikshawfahrern in die Haende fallen will sprech ich nen Inder an. Der ist auch gleich hilfsbereit
column2: bezahlt sogar mein Busticket. Danach sucht er mit mir ein Hotelzimmer
column3: bezahlt sogar noch einen anderen Kerl der ihm dann hilft ein Zimmer fuer mich zu finden. Total abgefahren. Aber ab da wird es dann nervig. Er nennet sich uebrigens Happy der nette Kerl. Setzt sich erst mal in mein Hotelzimmer und raucht erst mal eine. Bestellt einen Kaffee und bietet mir Kekse an. Danach baut er doch tatsaechlich in meinem Zimmer ne Tuete und raucht sie. Ich lass es hin und her gerissen in Dankbarkeit und Ablehnung ueber mich ergehen. Abends will er sich noch zum Abendessen treffen. Eigentlich ungern aber wir tauschen mal Nummern aus. Er schreibt dann echt seltsame SMS mit Lebensweisheiten und Komplimenten und ich frage mich
column4: ob der Kerl eben nur ein kauziger kiffer ist oder ob er anderweitig Interesse haben koennte. Mir ist das nicht gehaeuer und ich Entschuldige mich fuers Abendessen. Auch das Zimmer ist echt eher bloed. Haett ich selber geschaut waer ich halt nach dem Lonely Planet gegangen und haett vielleicht auch noch andere Reisenede getroffen. So geh ich halt allein los und finde Bangalore nicht sehr spannend. Bangalore bietet zwar schon das ein oder andere
column5: und auch das Sciencemuseum ist echt ganz lustig. Aber ich treffe hier niemand fuer ne vernuenftige Unterhaltung. Ist halt eine Businessstadt und keine Tourisstadt.

column2: dass ich als einmal ne Rikshaw nehme und mich doch zu mehr als einer Fahrt ueberreden lass. (jaja selbst Schuld) Es klang wie ein gutes Angebot. Tatsaechlich faehrt er mich aber vor allem zu kleinen Sachen die gerade auf dem Weg liegen und auf seinen Fotos gut aussahen um mich dann zu ueberreden in seine Shops mitzukommen. Weil der Rikshawfahrer irgendwie nett ist und ehrlich ist lass ich mich mal drauf ein auch wenn ich weiss
column3: dass ich nichts kaufen werde. Jetzt hoert man ja immer
column4: dass sie einen in die Laeden von Freunden und Verwandten ziehen. Nein viel ausgefeilter. Die haben ein Couponsystem. Wenn ich 5-10 min im Laden bleibe und Intresse heuchle bekommt der Fahrer einen Benzingutschein und wenn ich etwas mehr kaufe bekommt er Schulbuecher fuer seine Kinder. Gut
column5: die Schulbuecher sind garantiert gelogen um die Mitleidsschiene noch zu fahren
column6: aber trotzdem haben die ein ausgekluegeltes System. Mit mir hat das halt ueberhaupt nicht funktioniert weil ich kein Kaufinteresse heucheln kann wenn es nicht da ist und ich verlasse die beiden Laeden nach 2 min wieder. Geht mein Rickshawfahrer halt lehr aus.

column1: Am 17.5 steig ich dann in den Zug nach Jaipur.

The Vaisakha Poornima (full moon day of the first Lunar month) is known as Buddha Poornima Goutama Buddha the founder of Buddhism had taken birth on this day. It is believed that Buddha also got enlightened on the same Vaishakha poornima and also passed away on the same day of Vaisakha Poornima.

column2: drive towards Kanakpura on National Highway 209. After a few kms you will cross NICE ring road. Then after about 18 kms you will find a sign board to take a left turn for Buddha Pyramid.

column1: I had given more details on the route and other info on pyramid valley in my previous article. Please refer the details of pyramid valley in the following links. http://freejournal.heliohost.org/freejournal/?/articles/2012/03/25/maitreya-buddha-pyramid-bangalore.html

Buddha Poornima is celebrated every year in Pyramid valley. Brahmarshi Patriji conducts his music meditation through his mesmerizing flute performance. This year (2012) the Buddha poornima was celebrated during 4th-6th May 2012.
The participation to the celebration was based on Registration. The registration charges were Rs 450/- per person for all three days
column2: which included daily 3 times food and shared accommodation inside the pyramid valley.

column1: We reached there in 4th May morning
column2: the first day of celebration. We got of participants’ badges from the reception. We saw a queue for the breakfast and got into the queue. That time there were about a thousand people
column3: but many more were just flowing in.

column1: Our accommodation was inside the Pyramid. Generally the pyramid is meant for meditation only. But only during Buddha poornima celebration
column2: a large number of participants are accommodated inside the pyramid
column3: because of shortage of general accommodation.

column1: Maitreya-Buddha Pyramid is world’s largest meditational pyramid. The size of the pyramid is 160ft. x 160ft. Height 102 ft (equivalent to 10 floor building). To know more about Buddha Pyramid
column2: please read my previous article in journalsite:

column1: During daytime there were some spiritual classes. Some experienced people shared their experiences on spiritual journey. Below is a picture of the classroom.

During lunch time I noticed a crowd was moving near lunch area. When I went near the crowd I saw the crowd was around Brahmarshi Patriji. People were shaking their hands with Patriji and conveying their wishes. I also had the privilege of shaking hands with Patriji (picture below).

The evening started with an inaugural function. That was the first of the three-day celebration. The celebration was conducted at the amphitheatre inside the pyramid valley. There was a huge gathering of about five thousand people.
There were three eminent guests who delivered their valuable speeches. Patriji was a perfect anchor on the stage
column2: coordinating the guests and participants
column3: sometimes interpreting English speeches into Telugu and sometimes stimulating the crowd with humorous comments. After the spiritual lectures
column4: music and cultural programs continued on the stage while people slowly moved for dinner at their convenience.

column1: The second day morning started with a music meditation at 5 AM. We were woken up at 4.30 to attend the meditation. Brahmarshi Partriji was playing flute with three others artists on other instruments. All the participants were sitting on meditation (picture below)
column2: some on chairs and some on the lawn.

column1: Meditating on the flute music was a beautiful experience. Besides Patriji’s performance on flute was also extraordinary. As getting up at 4.30 AM was difficult for many
column2: some participants were taking their nice sleep in the name of meditation. After music meditation Patriji spoke on Buddha poornima and spirituality. Overall it was a fantastic experience.

column1: We had to make queues for breakfast and bathrooms. Some preferred to go to toilet first and some preferred to have breakfast first. When I saw a big crowd near toilets I decided to have breakfast first fearing that the food might finish if I make late.
After breakfast I thought to explore the valley. When I walked behind about half km
column2: I discovered a beautiful Shani temple. There was a remarkably big anthill near the Shani temple (picture above). After visiting Shani temple I came back to the program.

column1: During daytime there were spiritual classes (picture above). Besides
column2: there was also a dance performance by Pyramid Spiritual Science Academy
column3: Bangalore. In the afternoon some of us we went to Tapasthali
column4: about half km on hillside inside the pyramid valley.

column1: There is a beautiful statue of lord Shiva in Tapasthali. Many people were doing meditation near the shiva statue. From Tapasthali we could see the Pyramid nicely. The views of the hills and the valley were beautiful. I could also see the shani temple from distance which I visited in the morning.

The evening program started at 5 PM in amphitheatre. There were two guests who delivered their speech. Patriji also mesmerized the audience with his beautiful songs and speeches. There was lot of music and cultural program afterwards while the dinner was going on simultaneously.
The 3rd day morning again we were woken up at 4.30 to attend the music meditation at 5 AM. Patriji was on flute with three other artists
column2: who were on tabla
column3: violin and mandolin (picture below). All the people were enjoying the flute and doing meditation at the same time

column1: The third day was the last day of the celebration as well as the full moon day or birthday of Lord Buddha. After the music meditation
column2: Patriji spoke on Buddha
column3: Meditation
column4: Pyramid Meditation
column5: Pyramid Masters and on other spiritual concepts. He spoke about the concept of “Maitri”
column6: “Karuna”
column7: “Mudita” and “Upeksha” the four methods of dealing with others.

column2: we had to stand on long queues for food. The food area was near the amphitheatre (the program area) which was about half a km away from the toilet area. Although it was very irritating to walk half a km for going to toilet
column3: soon I realized the benefits
column4: as it was a good compulsory exercise to digest the food and stay active.

column1: The lunch queue was longer than the previous days (probably there were more participants on the last day). There were about six food counters (three starting counters and three repeat counters)
column2: but there were endless queues near each food counter. Some wise foodies like me were taking the food plate and standing immediately in the queue near repeat counter
column3: finishing the food plate while standing in the queue.

column2: we saw Patriji walking near the Pyramid surrounded by a large number of followers (picture above). People were shaking hands with him. Some people were having quick interactions. Patriji was also wishing people in different styles.

column1: The evening program started as usual at 5 PM. Patriji gave his valuable speech to the audience. Patriji is not only a spiritual leader he is many in one. He was coordinating all the programs on the stage as the main anchor; he was interpreting speeches in between Hindi
column2: English and Telugu
column3: honoring the guests with shawls and gifts and doing many other activities on the stage. His songs (prayers) and speeches were very inspiring.

column1: The evening program continued with cultural programs
column2: songs
column3: music and dances by various artists. There was also a group meditation till late night. It was the night of the celebration
column4: the full moon day
column5: the auspicious birthday of Lord Buddha.

column1: My experience went fine with all the events of the three-day celebration. The participants were mostly from Andhra Pradesh
column2: followed by Bangalore
column3: followed by other places. I was quite impressed to see such a big crowd coming from different parts of the country. In my guess there were more than five thousand participants.

column1: Personally I liked Patriji’s flute performance and spiritual speeches. He says he is against all doctors and healers of any kind. He advises to live without fear of death and be ready to accept death happily at anytime. Some of his speeches are to be understood not just by words but in right context with appropriate spiritual maturity .
Sangama is about 95 kms from bangalore
column2: the place of confluence of two rivers – Arkavathi and Kaveri (Cauvery). Mekedatu is about 5 kms on the other side of the river. We had visited the place last year and liked much. Incidentally we visited the place again this year. However
column3: the visit was still interesting.

column1: From Bangalore you have to go to Kanakapura and then take the road going to Sangama/ Mekedatu. I had gone there last year and given the route details in my previous article. Please refer http://freejournal.heliohost.org/freejournal/?/articles/2012/03/27/sangam-and-mekedatu.html
Visiting Sangam again after a Year
Last year when we visited Sangam
column2: we visited Chunchi falls and could not get time for visiting Muthathi. This year we had no plans for Sangam again
column3: but the plan was for Muttathi and Bheemeswhari. But on the day of visit
column4: we thought why not to cover Sangam again. Driving 45 kms on highway is simpler than driving anywhere within Bangalore city. The decision was not bad. The road was very good. We soon reached there in Sangam.

column1: The road to Sangam is always fascinating with large number of mayflower trees on both sides of the way – as if ready to greet all the visitors.
Interestingly it was the same summer season as our last visit. Hence
column2: the scenery was not much different. As before
column3: there was not much of water in the river. As it was not a holiday
column4: there were less number of people. We soon got into the water for bathing.

column2: we marked that the water was dirty and there were various types of insects in the water. I was scared for a moment and was about to get out of water. But next moment I saw others bathing very happily and became fearless. Enjoyed water for a long time.

column1: Last year we had gone Sangam in April
column2: the water was about 2 to 3 feet in average. This time it was May
column3: hence the water was even less at many places. Crossing the river was much simpler.

column1: Bathing although was difficult with less water you could always walk to a place where there was slightly more water.
Last time it was a Sunday
column2: so there were about 500 visitors. This time it was a regular day
column3: the number of visitors were about 100.

column2: the bus to Mekedatu was waiting indefinitely to be filled up with passengers.

column1: Some more constructions near the entrance
column2: other things were almost the same.
we visited Sangameshwar Temple
column3: which is just near that place. It is a small temple
column4: but neat and clean. There are lot of monkeys around
column5: they took our bag
column6: opened up everything to see if there was any thing of their interest. Luckily left the bag there at a distance.

column2: whether in Sangama or in Muthathi or other places
column3: are considered to be risky. Many people loose their lives every year in Sangam and similar places. Besides there are Crocodiles in some seasons. One has to be careful about those too.

column1: While going to Sangam and Mekedatu
column2: you can combine visiting other places such as Chunchi falls
column3: TK falls
column4: Pyramid Valley
column5: Muthathi
column6: Bheemeshwari etc. However
column7: from my experience
column8: combining too many things does not give you adequate time to see the places. I would suggest not combining more than two places to visit in a day.

column1: You must read my previous article on Sangam in order to make this experience complete http://freejournal.heliohost.org/freejournal/?/articles/2012/03/27/sangam-and-mekedatu.html as I have deliberately not mentioned many things in order to avoid repetition.
So far I was pretty happy that my tour was going as per my plan. However I was rather confused to opt from the 4 spots which were not in my schedule. Irpu Falls
column2: Kabini WLS
column3: Nagarhole NP and Shivanasamudram waterfalls. I had previous appointments to attend in Kochi so I would be heading for Kerala
column4: this was the thought. I finally voted for Irpu Falls as the place was not known to the tourists. After saying ‘virtual’ good bye to rest of the three places I went to bed as I had to wake up early next day.

column1: I woke up at 6am and hit the road in next 15 minutes. I had to take care of my personal hygiene. I walked in to the bus stand in Mysore and from my research I knew that I had to take a bus to Gonnikopal. There are several routes to reach Irpu. One can follow the Hunsuru-Gonikoppal route to Kutta
column2: Mysore-Nagarhole route to Kutta and finally Mysore-Kabini route to Kutta. But as red from the magazines
column3: I decided to follow the Gonnikopal route because of maximum availability of public transports. I took a bus which was on the

column1: way to Virajpet and as said earlier and again
column2: buses in Karnataka are the best when it comes to schedule and accessibility. Within 5 minutes I was cursing down the Mysore-Madikeri road where I had my footsteps left on my previous tour to Bylakuppe (separate blog). This road wasn’t new to me but still it was pretty enjoyable early in the morning. The bus took more than an hour and half to reach Hunsuru and driving further 10km
column3: took a diversion to the left and hit the Mysore-Virajpet road. First a few miles it was through the villages of Karnataka and later it hit the forest area. This was early in May and chance of a shower was bleak
column4: so the lush green outfields were ‘green’ but not shining. Once the bus entered the forest area I picked myself up from the seat hoping if something could get caught in my eyes. As expected
column5: in next 15 minutes I noticed a wild elephant on the right and the locals not seemed to show any interest as they were quite ‘used to’ with this kind of wild animals. The bus quit the forest roads and started climbing up the hills. The

column1: road here was through the coffee and pepper estates. Most of the passengers were either working in one of those estates. I was really enjoying the scenic ‘pleasures’ and was thinking about my next journey from Gonnikopal to Kutta which was around 36 kms. Around 10:30 am I reached Gonnikopal. It seemed to me a small town with very basic facilities available. Then I didn’t know the challenges were in ahead of me.
I knew that I was in Coorg
column2: so the first thing I decided to have was a ‘cup of coffee’. I walked in to a small restaurant
column3: opposite to the bus stand and helped myself with a cup of coffee. It was as fresh as the beans were handpicked from the nearby estates. This part of Karnataka is enriched with coffee and pepper plantation and most of the homestays or resorts are either ‘an old estate’ or a part of it converted to a homely accommodation for tourists. I spent some time noticing the local crowd and their styles. The first thing I noticed was the typical style of wearing a ‘saree’ which eventually looked like a ‘nighty’ at the first shot. When asked

column2: he said that this was called ‘Kodava Sarees’
column3: with no difference than the regular sarees we see but the style of draping made the difference. After spending a few ‘gazing moments’ at the ‘Coorgi beauties’ (as people may not know
column4: the girls from Coorg are known for their unfathomed charm) I walked back in to the bus stand.

column1: Oh my god ! I may have sounded like ‘Janice from famous Tv series Friends’. Where the hell the busses were going to ? I asked a fellow about the buses towards Kutta and he ‘scanned’ me from my head to toe and said.

column2: it’s Kutta’
It should be Kutta not Kutta (means dog in hindi)
column3: though the spelling is the same. ‘Narrow escape’ was the first call to me however I moved towards ‘a point’ where the bus to Kutta was waiting for me. All I could see people from different ages
column4: sizes
column5: heights were present in that bus. Forget about getting my butt to rest
column6: I didn’t find a place to climb up. ‘Quit’ was the call from my heart and I followed

column1: that religiously. After 15 minutes another bus came and before I could even see the ‘face’ of it
column2: it was all filled up with all proportions.
what the hell’
column3: I whispered.

column1: I quit again and this ‘Quit Bus’ revolt concurred for another one hour or so. It was 2:00pm then and I knew that I had to travel another 36 kms
column2: had to find a place and then had to proceed towards Irpu Falls. I could see my ‘Plan of Titanic’ was sinking in front of me and like Edward John Smith
column3: I was giving blunt looks towards the sky for a ‘hope’. Noticing my struggle
column4: one generous fellow walked in and said something in Kannada. With my ‘great’ understanding
column5: this was it.

column2: the guy asked
I replied with the correct pronunciation.
he pointed the same which I just ‘quit’ some 10 minutes ago.
no place to stand even’

column2: there’s a festival in Kutta
column3: today and hence everyone is heading up

column2: he smiled and said.
I almost cried with my lost soul.

column1: ‘There would be a bus from Kerala
column2: which would be an express bus to Kutta
column3: try for that’

oh ! here it is’
