column1: I took the last part of the conversation and chased him as he was my ‘pace setter’. I saw one ‘very’ colorful bus just entered the stand and it seemed a lot of people were waiting to get un board from it. I used my pair of elbows to ‘win’ a seat and finally I managed. I was pretty happy with my success and it was a sigh of relief. The bus didn’t wait too long and surprisingly with ‘not much’ people
column2: it hit the road. I later came to know that being an ‘express’ bus and so the high price of the tickets (may be 10 bucks more than the standard ones)
column3: local folks

column2: I focused on the ‘road’.

column1: The drive from Gonnikoppal to Kutta was perhaps one of the ‘most scenic’ bus journeys I’ve ever had. Long winding roads though lush green coffee plantations that you can feel the freshness and aroma. Since I ‘prized’ myself with a window seat
column2: I could sense the ‘splash’ of cold breeze. So refreshing that in 5 minutes
column3: I forgot my ‘Quit Bus’ revolt and was really enjoying the scenes. The entire journey seemed to be the same through ‘estates’ and finally around 3:30pm the ‘Green Beauty’ (Eventually
column4: it was the name of the bus) dropped me in Kutta. It was a small ‘modern village’ with a very few shops
column5: That’s what I could describe Kutta at a first glance. I knew I had to search a place for the day. I rather decided to walk in to a nearby shop. I bought a pack of cigarette and stroke a ‘business conversation’. This is what I do mostly. In a new place
column6: I usually find the most ‘knowledgeable’ shop
column7: buy something and then ‘band up’ a ‘casual conversation’ to get the details about the place.

column2: any place to stay here’
column3: I started with my as usual ‘smile’.

column1: ‘Only one lodge here to the right. Try your luck’
column2: he replied.

column1: I was bit shocked that why to try my luck. ‘Were there a lot of tourists arrived before me?’
column2: Asking those questions to myself
column3: I ‘crawled’ towards the board which was ‘Kutta Lodge’. The place was empty
column4: not even a stray cat or dog was there to greet me.

column2: anybody here?’
column3: I knocked at the reception desk.

column1: And after a couple of more ‘hard knocks’
column2: one old lady showed up.

column1: ‘What you want?’ was the question from her
column2: in a rough ‘note’.
I asked
she shut both the doors up.

column1: I walked back to the same shop and asked for ‘reason’.

column2: today being the festival
column3: most of the guys was either ‘drunk high’ or went to the temple. You would hardly find any one’
column4: he replied with a smile. I didn’t know whether it was a ‘note of proud’ or a

column1: I stood there ‘all blacked out’ for another 15-20 minutes. Suddenly I saw one guy with a ‘three wheeler’ just crossed past me. I ran to him and asked for his advice to find me a place to stay tonight. That guy seemed was ‘in shape’ and fortunately could speak Tamil. I literally dragged myself in before he could reply ‘yes
column2: no or maybe’. He couldn’t give me any fruitful answer so I had to open my ‘Book of Notes’. Found a few and immediately started calling them. The cellphone network seemed pretty good here and after a few more tries
column3: I managed to get hold of ‘The Chilligeri Estate’. It was a lady.

column2: I came all the way from Chennai
column3: any place to stay in your estate?’
column4: I cried for help.

column2: was the question from the other end.
alone’
column3: was my quick reply.

column2: Rs. 1000 a day including all meals
column3: come’
column4: Was the deal offered to me.

column2: how far?’
column3: I asked

column2: drive through the
find our ‘sign’
column3: take left’
column4: She finished all these words in 10 seconds maybe.

column1: I had to stare at my ‘auto guy’
column2: he seemed to have heard of this place before
column3: but ‘what did she mean by taxi
column4: I didn’t see any taxi here’
column5: was the big question for me. The auto guy said that there was no taxi. All these ‘autos’ are referred as a taxis here. Incredible India ! he asked for Rs.50 to drop me to the estate. I agreed without any hesitation. We drove back through the same road I followed earlier and reached the estate within 15 minutes.

column1: Wow ! Just Wow ! What a place to stay. Located in a remote valley with amazing Bramhagiri hills at the backdrop
column2: amidst plenty of colorful flowers and coffee plantations
column3: I really fell in love at the first sight. I was offered to have lunch and I decided to skip as I was ‘too late’ for The Irpu Falls which was some 6kms away from this place. Meanwhile I clinched a small ‘friendship’ with the auto guy
column4: Pramod and without any minutes lost
column5: I asked him

column1: to drop me to the base of Irpu Falls. I knew that there wouldn’t be any public transport available to reach Irpu Falls which would eventually be located inside the Bramhagiri Wild Life Sanctuary. Pramod offered me a nice option that he would drop me to the falls and once I was done with my ‘photos’ I would give him a call to pick me up from there. I liked this offer and we started again. In next 15 minutes or so I was at the entry point of Bramhagiri Sanctuary.

It’s inside the Sanctuary so one has to walk about a mile from the entry point to reach Irpu falls. No vehicles are allowed rather there are no roads to reach the base of the falls. Pramod dropped me there and warned me repeatedly to wind up before 6pm
column2: as the presence of wild elephants was ‘high’ and that was for two reasons. One
column3: all the water bodies up in the hill had dried up and Two
column4: Elephants couldn’t resist themselves from tasting ‘Ripe Jackfruit’ so they prefer to come down to the estates. It was around 5pm and I knew I may run out of

column1: light to take photos. With his warnings framed on my mind
column2: I entered the Bramhagiri Wild Life Sanctuary. It was a walk through thick woods following a narrow stream which was the continuation of the water from Irpu Falls. I noticed a couple of ‘sign boards’ which had it mentioned that the ‘Largest Breed of King Cobra’ was actually spotted in this region. I don’t know why but I am not too friendly with this animal so I got ‘spine chilling’ sensation. After a mile’s walk
column3: I reached Irpu.

column1: If you have seen Hebbe in Chickmagalur
column2: Irpu is not that mighty roaring falls
column3: nor even gorging from ‘high heights’ like Hebbe. But the surroundings with mighty Bramhagiri and the wilderness gave this place a ‘heavenly felling’. I didn’t find a lot of people there except some guys from a nearby college. They were spending their time enjoying the streams of Irpu. I looked for a place where I could place myself for some ‘silky water’ shots. I missed my tripod again and felt like ‘kicking my butt’. The watch was moving as fast as it could
column4: and with the available ‘natural accessories’
column5: I managed to place myself

column1: on a ‘large stone’ and took a few photos. Though Irpu was a small waterfall compared to the ‘mightiest’ I have seen in India
column2: I was in love with this place. It was so serene one could expect ever. However
column3: with a huge ‘unwill’
column4: I decided to walk back to the ‘gate’
column5: meanwhile I called Pramod to be there in next 15 minutes. When I reached at the gate
column6: Pramod was there already and we returned to the estate around 6:30 pm.

column1: I saw that the owner ‘lady’ was trying to say something. So to bring them to the comfort level
column2: I asked if anything that I could have helped. She said that they had to attend the festival at the temple so would it be okay
column3: if I could stay here all alone in this estate till 9pm. Without any hesitation I asked them to go
column4: and once they left I was hovering around the estate. What a beautiful place it was and if you were there with your ‘sweetheart’
column5: I bet you couldn’t have expected more romantic place than this. Plenty of birds
column6: singing the ‘music of nature’. I was not completely alone
column7: I

column1: had company of a ‘little cute’ Lhasa Apso ‘Jimmy’. Being one of the greatest dog lovers on earth
column2: I was enjoying every bit of his company. I tried a few sunset shots and finally around 7:30 pm it was completely dark. I was feeling a bit of scary and thrilled as well. I was recalling the words of Pramod regarding the jackfruit and elephant story. As I could see some Jackfruit trees around ‘showcasing’ some mighty ones hang. The climate was so cozy as if ‘mother nature’ had her A/C’s on. There was a completion which may be the best part of this trip
column3: I had not seen so many stars and fire flies at the same place. Millions or Billions was the question unasked. After a few hours hovering at the estate
column4: around 9:45 pm
column5: they arrived. Then I realized the ‘burning stay of hunger’ in my stomach. I recalled that I didn’t have anything since morning except a couple of cups of coffee. The dinner was served within 15 minutes. Though I was asked about my options still I asked to make it as ‘Coorg’ as possible. It was one of the best I have ever had. Coorg Rotis made with Rice Flour
column6: with a series of veg: preparations with a glass of homemade wine. Marvelous ! Proper justification to the Coorgi hospitality. I was too exhausted after having such a wonderful diner and I was seeing everything ‘blank’. I didn’t know how much I slept but woke up early at 6:30 am. As instructed
column7: Pramod was there to pick me up. And expressing my heartfelt gratitude I said ‘good bye’ to Chilligeri estate for one last time. I knew that I would be back soon for my ‘sweetheart’. I definitely would like to get lost deep inside the forest with her. Missed you !

column1: When last I wrote we were waiting to get picked up by Sagar to head up north to his new wife's hometown to have another reception there.
We were sort of used to the way timelines work in India by this point
column2: so although we had been told we would be picked up at noon
column3: we had a feeling that might not be the case. We opted to have a drink in our favourite ""Aqua Bar"" to wait it out. Eventually Sagar showed up with his family in what can only be described as a party bus! It was like a comfy 15 passenger travel van/bus with sweet blue/green lighting and a great sound system. The van was to take us (myself
column4: Josh
column5: Jeff
column6: Vanessa
column7: and Brodie) and Sagar
column8: his parents
column9: his aunt
column10: and Deepa. It's a good think that it was a comfy ride
column11: because the journey was actually a lot longer than we expected. It must have been at least 400km north and it took many hours.

column2: Sagar showed me some of the pictures of the wedding photographer on his computer and explained some of the parts that were confusing to us during the actual ceremony. The rituals and symbolism was endless - I couldn't possibly rewrite it all. But many of the traditions were really sweet
column3: like the ritual of seven steps to show devotion to husband and vice versa. He also explained to me the five things that married women wear: a red forhead spot
column4: a nose peircing
column5: flowers in her hair
column6: a necklace
column7: and a toe ring. Apprantly the numbers 5 and 11 are considered lucky in India. You do things like burn five sticks of incense
column8: or give five or eleven types of fruit in a basket as a gift.

column2: we stopped for dinner in a small town. Sagar ordered us a giant spread of food
column3: but shortly afterwards Deepa informed him that her mother was making a bunch of food for us in Havari
column4: so we shouldn't eat a full dinner. Whoops! So we cancelled our order and switched to ""snacks
column5: but the snack was pretty much still a full meal for me. I was somewhat dreading getting to Havari because I forsaw a whole bunch of food being placed in front of a very full me. Sure enough
column6: that's what happened...

column1: Deepa's house was pretty amazing. It was about three floors high with an open concept design and a big winding staircase up through it. It also had a nice landscaped courtyard which actually had lawn. When we came back the next day we discovered it's multiple beautiful rooftop terraces and - our favourite element - an indoor swing!! There is a specific Indian festival that uses the swing
column2: but it can be played on at other times of the year.

column1: Shortly after we arrived we sat down for food. There were only 6 spots set at the table and there were tons of us
column2: so it was a bit awkward to figure out who was supposed to sit at the table. At the end I sat at the table while a few others sat on a nearby bench
column3: but I knew I would regret that decision because it would prevent me from escaping from food consumption. They constantly put more and more food on my plate and I felt so badly having to refuse
column4: but I just couldn't do it. Some people have stomachs which seem to be able to expand to accomodate whatever is necessary - I am not htat way. I just can't eat if I'm not hungry
column5: no matter how much pressure I feel. I hate it because food is so often a social thing and I frequently find myself feeling rude for having to decline food while others are just trying to be good hosts. This night was no different. The food was delicious
column6: but the quantity was so much! Once we finished the bus took us to the small nearby hotel we would be staying the night in. The rest stayed behind because Deepa's family is quite orthodox and normally the men eat first and then the women
column7: so half the group still had to eat. Whoops... should I not have eaten or not have sitten at the table? Sagar said it was fine. Ah well.

column1: Considering we were in such a small town the ""VIP Suites"" which we were housed in were actually pretty nice. I wasn't sure what kind of accomodation they would have for us. Certainly no internet there
column2: though! No toilet paper either
column3: but luckily I'm always prepared =) The best part of where we were staying was the rooftop courtyard. I thought it would have been nice to sleep out there under the stars
column4: but there were a whole number of guys who seemed to work for the hotel that slept out there
column5: instead! I thought maybe they just didn't have anywhere else to sleep
column6: but Sagar said they were there in case we needed anything in the middle of the night. Yikes! I am not used to the amount of ""attending to"" that we get in India. People are always serving food onto our plates instead of just leaving a serving dish on the table
column7: or bringing our bags around
column8: or just kind of hovering.

column1: We were told to meet Sagar's parents at the reception for breakfast at 9am
column2: but when we tried to find them they weren't there
column3: and we weren't sure where we should be going. This didn't really surprise us
column4: again
column5: due to loose timelines here
column6: so we just went back up to the rooftop and we all took some time to read in the shade. At one point
column7: some guys silently brought over some little dixie cups of something hot (tea? coffee? there is so much milk and sugar we couldn't tell)
column8: which was pretty good. Around an hour later a nice man came to get us and told us to come down to the basement for breakfast. It turns out that we WERE supposed to have gone down at 9am
column9: but we just didn't know what to do. So once we never turned up various phonecalls were made and this gentleman took us under his wing. Thanks goodness
column10: because would have been lost. We sat in a row along a long silver table and were served some pretty tasty curries on palm leaves. After that
column11: we were directed to the bus
column12: which took us back to Deepa's house. It seemed that people were a bit surprised to see us there
column13: but we were just following directions! This whole day was rather confusing.

column1: We hung out with Deepa and got to know her better. She showed us the rest of her house
column2: including the network of solar panels on the roof which are used to heat water for the house. She said that their set up was an older model
column3: but they didn't want to upgrade because the monkeys would destroy the pipes! Sure enough
column4: a metal tank up there was full of dents from them. I had no idea monkeys could do so much damage! We also enjoyed watching the wild pigs off the roof
column5: frolicking in the garbage. Deepa had to go change into her wedding clothes for the next
column6: and final
column7: reception
column8: so we amused ourselves on the indoor swing. The reception was supposed to start at noon but I think it was probably around 1pm when the bride and groom headed over in a cute red car decorated with flowers and signs.

column1: This reception seemed a bit less formal and the atmosphere seemed a bit more fun than the other events. There were probably around 200 people in attendance
column2: but Deepa seemed to know most of the people there and both she and Sagar appeared to have a good time. Vanessa and I weren't really dressed up when it started because we had just been shuttled around all morning without sense of what was happening when
column3: but after sitting amongst everyone in their faciest saris we eventually became self-conscious and went upstairs to change into nicer clothes (the reception was in the hotel where we were staying). I took the opportunity to get one last use out of my pink Indian outfit that the Dugani's had bought for me. I love it!

column1: These receptions have two parts: greeting the bride and groom on stage
column2: blessing them
column3: then getting a picture taken
column4: and EATING. After we had done our bit on stage we were ready to eat. The giant lunch was in the basement area where we had had breakfast. Man
column5: what a production!! The whole things was a finally organized
column6: if slightly chaotic appearing
column7: enterprise. Everyone was seated along rows of long tables. A long roll of paper tablecloth was laid out
column8: and then the procession of servers began. They would slap down palm leaves and bottles of water (then people would wash their palm leaves with the water
column9: we noted for our turn). Then various servers with buckets and ladles would whizz by dowling out curries and chutneys and breads and a bunch of things which were totally unknown to me. This would continue until no one could eat any more. Then the diners would stand up and leave
column10: the table cloth-paper would be rolled up with all the palm leaves
column11: the table would be wiped down
column12: and the process would start again for the next seating. It was pretty impressive! It was a bit hard to get a spot
column13: mind you
column14: but fortunately
column15: again
column16: a few people took us under their wing and secured us a seating. After we sat down there was a loooong wait before anything happened
column17: and we weren't really sure what was going on. Turns out they had ran out of paper roll
column18: so everything had to be held up until some new paper could be acquired. It was worth the waiting
column19: though. Mmmmm such good food! Probably my best meal in India. (Sagar told us later that the hotel guys were super happy that we enjoyed the meal).

column1: Oh! And I forgot about the roti bread man! There was a guy set up in the corner with a giant hot plate in front of him. He must have been dying from heat
column2: but he was great at what he does. Basically
column3: he would scoop up batter from a giant bat and pour it onto the grill in perfectly sized circle pancakes. Dip
column4: pour
column5: dip
column6: pour
column7: dip
column8: pour. He had real rhythm to it
column9: working with his right hand and keeping his left hand on his hip
column10: with kind of a pelvic thrust each time he poured. Then he would grab the spatula and flip flip flip! Some extra spices and greens of some kind were sprinkled on
column11: then they would all get flopped into a giant bowl
column12: ready to eat. Yum!

column1: We were supposed to be on the road back to Bangalore by 3pm (the day before we were told noon...) but we knew that wasn't going to happen so we just went up to the rooftop and read until someone came to get us. Around 5pm
column2: it was finally time to hit the road. We stopped off at Deepa's house to say final goodbyes. It was so touching to see the way the two families had bonded already. There was lots of love between them
column3: that much was obvious. Deepa was staying in Havari for a few more weeks because she has to write her final engineering exams
column4: then she will come to Bangalore to live with Sagar's family. From now on
column5: she ""belongs"" to Sagar's family (but only in the sense that she's like their daughter
column6: it's not a repressive thing). We were supposed to stop at a cousin's for tea
column7: but mercifully we skipped that as it was getting late and we had a long
column8: long drive back to Bangalore.

column1: I think it was around 1am when we reached our hotel. For a lot of that journey I was glad I was in the back and couldn't see out the front very well. Ignorance is bliss when it comes to road travel for me in most developing countries
column2: and this journey was certainly no exception. Rickshaw travel in the city is nuts
column3: but at least you don't travel very quickly. Highway speeds with rickshaw-style weaving is a whole other ballgame. We did get a reminder of the dangers of the road
column4: though. We passed an accident scene where a big SUV-type vehicle had hit and killed a bull. The bull was dead
column5: but the vehicle was in pretty bad shape
column6: too. I guess it's like hitting a moose back in Canada.

column1: I think I'll end this entry here
column2: and start another one for the post-wedding happenings.

column1: The day after the final reception
column2: everyone was ready for a little R&R. It had been a wild few days! Sagar really wanted to plan a special day for us
column3: especially since it was the last day for the boys in India
column4: so he took us to a resort just outside the city limits.

column1: It was Sagar himself who picked us up from our hotel
column2: and we managed to squeeze 6 of us in to his tiny compact surprisingly comfortably. I'm so impressed that Sagar can drive here - I think that's why he's such a calm guy in Toronto. If you can drive here
column3: surely nothing can phase you! He took us to his family home where we transfered into a much larger car which could accomodate all of us
column4: and which came with a driver. I realize now that an advantage of having a driver is not just the not-having-to-drive part
column5: but also that you don't have to find parking really. They can just drop you off and swing back around when you need them. As you can imagine
column6: parking is often at a premium in such a dense city.

column1: The resort was gorgeous. It was like a huge
column2: tropical
column3: gated community with a mix of privately owned vacation condos and hotel suites
column4: with resort amenities like a fitness club
column5: spa
column6: and big pool. We were especially taken by the pool because it has been so hot here and our hotel in Bangalore doesn't have one. After a buffet lunch (at which I pretty much couldn't eat anything
column7: my stomach had finally quit)
column8: we took a walk around the beautiful grounds. I have to admit I felt someone like an exploitive British colonialist here
column9: but I pushed the thoughts aside and just tried to soak in the serenity of the place. There were so many beautiful lush bushes
column10: flowers
column11: and birds - wonderful! Finally
column12: it was pool time! While Sagar napped (well deservedly) on the pool deck
column13: the rest of us changed into bathing suits and started playing. There was a big waterfall that you could sit under
column14: and some polo balls we found provided endless entertainment. All in all
column15: it was a really nice afternoon.

column2: I realize by this point you're probably thinking that I haven't exactly been slumming it during this trip
column3: and you are partially right. But what can you do when your hosts are this kind?

column1: After we had changed and dried off
column2: we loaded back in the car to head back into town. We were going to a tourist area called MG road (Mahatma Gandhi
column3: of course) to pick up some souvenirs. Also
column4: Vanessa really needed to get a SIM card for her cell phone because she is staying here for a while after we leave
column5: and we needed Sagar's help because we have had NO success in getting this thing. When she finally found a place that actually sold them
column6: they told her they needed a copy of her passport! So she and Sagar set off to do that
column7: while Josh
column8: Brodie
column9: Jeff
column10: and I poked in nearby shops. In one shop
column11: a really nice sales guy helped us out and I acutally bought quite a bit from him because he wasn't push at all. I mean
column12: he was encouraging the upsell
column13: for sure
column14: but he was reasonable and calm about it. Earlier I had gone into a textiles place and instantly people were literally yelling at me and shoving products in my face. I hate that. I just ran away. No sale for them! Eventually Vanessa and Sagar returned with photocopy and 15 passport photos in hand (don't ask)
column15: and she got her SIM card. She was told it would be activated by the next night
column16: but when she left me the next evening it still wasn't working... I hope it gets activated eventually.

column2: it was time for the great day and the group travel to come to an end. The car dropped me and Vanessa off at the hotel (she would be sleeping in my room that night) and the boys picked up their luggage. They were all going back to Sagar's house for about an hour
column3: then Sagar would drive them to the airport. Their trip is far from over - they were flying straight to Cambodia
column4: and they are still going to Japan after that! It was crazy to say goodbye and realize I would really only see them for a couple weeks around convocation
column5: then I will be moving to Calgary and we will be living apart for at least the next five years. For the past year I've been living in the same apartment building with them all
column6: and it's been great.

column1: When I got up to my room with Vanessa
column2: I took the opportunity to catch up on emails. Ooooh boy was there a lot of them. I had a bunch of high priority
column3: time sensitive Scout documents to review and a number of issues for school to deal with. It seemed that we still didn't have a speaker for convocation
column4: which was supposed to be my job and I was really stressed about it. It had been a long few days and I was literally falling asleep at my computer by the time I shut it down. V and I decided not to set alarms for the next morning...

column2: Tuesday
column3: it was just Vanessa and I on our own. Our group had gotten so small! We had planned to hire a car to go to Bandipur National Park to do a wildlife safari this day after failing to make it happen on Friday
column4: but during some late night browsing Vanessa had discovered the park was closed on Tuesday! Argggghhhh!! We had spent so much time figuring this out
column5: too. At least we made the discovery before we got all the way there. So we spent a good portion of the morning trying to figure out a plan B. Honestly
column6: getting around this city is really
column7: really difficult. Every time we come up with an idea we have to work out how close it is
column8: if we could possibly rickshaw there
column9: will traffic be OK. Then there is the problem of figuring out where things are. See
column10: we had wanted to check out a temple or two. There were a few good ones listed
column11: but when we tried to look up their location it wasn't clear at all. Google maps would list multple locations for all of them. Others were too far out of the city.

column2: we decided to go to the botanical gardens. It turned out to be a great choice! Sagar had said they had fallen into a bit of disrepair and I think that was true for a number of the areas
column3: but overall the area was a green oasis in the middle of the city. We really enjoyed walking around. I particularly enjoyed looking at the different birds living there
column4: which were similar to Canadian birds but not quite the same. A kind of bird Twighlight Zone. Like
column5: there were sort of cormorants
column6: but different. And harks
column7: finches
column8: and ravens that just weren't the same. There were some bird interpretive posters around but I couldn't match up any of the birds that I was seeing to those. There were lots of families in the gardens
column9: which was nice to see. We made the mistake of engaging (only briefly
column10: but that was enough) with some little hooligans over by a GIANT tree that we wanted to take a picture in. The followed us for like 15 minutes yelling for money. We hadn't experienced anything like that during our time here. We really didn't know how we were going to get rid of them because they clearly had nothing else to do then pester us (which they thought was hilarious)
column11: but we found an unlikely saviour in the form of a dog. There were dogs lying all over the gardens (including a very cute beagle!) but when we got to the edge of a lake
column12: this one dog just started snarling and barking and lunging at the kids
column13: who jumped behind benches for safety and forgot about us. I imagine they had not been good to that dog in the past
column14: because I didn't see them do anything to him then. We made our escape
column15: but kept one eye open for the little pack the rest of the time.

column2: we picked the hottest day of our whole trip for this outdoor excursion. Honestly
column3: it was difficult to breathe it was so hot and humid. We ended up only being in the gardens for an hour but it seemed waaay longer than that
column4: and we were completely wiped afterward. We had planned to walk around the area afterward and see what we could find
column5: but after less than 5 minutes of heat stroke
column6: crazy traffic
column7: and a sidewalk-free neighbourhood
column8: we gave up and flagged the first rickshaw we could find to take us to the sanctuary of an airconditioned mall. Hey
column9: it was really
column10: really hot
column11: OK? Don't judge! We were just so exhausted we couldn't imagine doing anything else
column12: so we went back to the movie theatre we had gone to earlier with Anjali. We considered watching a Bollywood movie
column13: but in the end we went for an English one
column14: that new Tim Burton one called Dark Shadows. The best part
column15: though? The seats!!! The entire theatre was filled with lazy-boy style airchairs that fully reclined. They were so plush and cozy. Vanessa and I were in heaven. It may not have been a very cultural experience
column16: but it was definitely the right choice for us at the time. The movie was better than I expected it to be
column17: too.

column1: When we exited the theatre we were hit with an unpleasant surprise: there was pretty much a monsoon happening outside. Like
column2: serious torrential downpour. The kind where you are instantly drenched just from stepping out from undercover. Everyone was hoarding around the mall foyer because no one wanted to go out in it. I had actually been carrying around either a raincoat or an umbrella for most of the trip
column3: but this particular day I had left them at the hotel. We waited around 20 minutes but there was no sign of it letting up
column4: so figured we had better face the fact that we were going to get wet. We ran out into the rain and pretty much got into the first rickshaw we saw. We paid more than we should have but we didn't care - it was worth it to get home.

column1: What followed was the most harrowing ride of the trip
column2: which is saying something. The roads were all flooded
column3: and our driver was young and wild. He also didn't have a windshield wiper (note to self: next time it's raining make sure you get in a rickshaw with a wiper). He kept taking one way roads the wrong way and driving through puddles and rivers that were so deep they would come up into the rickshaw. At one point we almost stalled out and I was SO worried we were going to get stuck but
column4: miraculously
column5: we made it. Phew. Now
column6: we were wet and freezing. Quite a change from our heat exhaustion of earlier in the day!

column1: Vanessa had another hurdle to pass at this point. She was supposed to go to an aunt's for supper and then go to her friend's apartment
column2: where she will be staying for the rest of time. As I have said many times
column3: though
column4: travel is hard for us here and now she would have her big suitcase with her. She also didn't think a rickshaw driver would know how to find her aunt's address. It's hard to phone a cab becasue we don't have cell numbers which they require
column5: and it is a constant struggle and negotiation with the hotel to make local calls here. EVENTUALLY she secured a cab to take her
column6: and after a half hour's wait it arrived. I hear it screwed her over in terms of price
column7: though
column8: and then it supposedly ""didn't have change
column9: either. Sigh. I'm not looking forward to getting to the airport tonight.

column2: as I was hit with a rather unpleasant bout of traveller's diarrhea shortly after. Not a great night. But it in terms of timing I couldn't have asked for anything better. I was planning to take it easy today anyway. I got some drugs from the pharmacy this afternoon so I should be in better shape for my 24 hours or travel back to Canada tonight (I hope!). I changed from a window to an aisle seat
column3: though
column4: just in case =)

column1: And that pretty much wraps up my India trip! I felt like this blog was a lot less fun and descriptive than my previous world tour ones. I think I was busier on this trip so it was harder to fit it in. Oh well. I think my pictures tell a better story of the journey. I'll put them up when I get home.
***Note: I wrote this days ago (Saturday morning) but haven't had internet access since
column2: so I couldn't upload it. Now it's Monday night and I haven't written anything else! I also don't have a fast enough connection to upload any pictures. Sorry! Hopefully tomorrow night I can summarize the past few days events. In the meantime
column3: here is a tome to finish off last week.***

column1: The internet seems to have cut out (good bye 100 rupees) so I’ll write this entry in Word and hopefully I can upload it later.
I think last night when I stopped writing I had finished the part about the engagement party. The next morning we all woke up
column2: ate the delicious hotel breakfast
column3: and then got dressed up for the wedding. Sagar’s family had bought us all amazing Indian clothing to wear for the occasion
column4: which was amazing of them to do. Quite frankly
column5: we looked awesome! The boys looked especially great in their outfits. By the way
column6: I’m travelling with some in-law whisperers here. You know those kind of guys that can work a family reunion and have all the relatives gushing over them? Yep
column7: that’s these boys. They are really great with everyone.

column1: I should mention that this was a south Indian wedding
column2: which is a bit different than the north Indian weddings which I think are a little bit more well known. I’m told north Indian weddings have the groom ride in on a horse and there is lots of dancing
column3: etc. This one had a lot of blessings and rituals
column4: but a bit less spectacle
column5: I would say. So when we arrived at the wedding Sagar and Deepa were both up a the front of a giant room under a lavishly decorated tent awning. We had already missed a few things
column6: like them playing a game where they fish in a vat of milk for their wedding rings. The tent was decorated with reams and reams of strands of fresh flowers. I’m not completely sure what was going on
column7: but they were kneeling down and being dressed up a bit. Sagar had on a decadent turban and an additional headdress of jewels was being tied on. Eventually the couple left and then just Sagar returned. He went through a long time of blessings with a priest (?) where he had to touch various things
column8: have various garlands put on
column9: have candles waved around him
column10: etc. We couldn’t see everything because often the camera people were in the way
column11: but we had a decent view. The atmosphere was pretty casual. We were free to talk and wander around as we pleased.

column1: Then Deepa came in and did the same thing. Next there was a big white sheet put up between the two and I think they were blessing each other (?). The sheet was dropped and much more blessing and rituals took place. Eventually the key part occurred: they exchanged golden necklaces and voila! They were married Then we all got to throw coloured rice at them. I liked that part. (I may not have the order of all of this quite correct). Next a big receiving line was formed and we all went up on stage without shoes to sprinkle rice on their heads and wish the couple good luck.

column2: it was time for lunch! (food has not been an issue on this trip!) Another big Indian buffet. After lunch we went back in to the wedding room for a bit because we were told the couple was going to do a fire ceremony of some kind
column3: which sounded neat. However time waned on and we weren’t sure when it was going to happen
column4: so we decided to make our exit. We were going to head to a mall to watch a Bollywood movie – the true Indian experience! First
column5: of course
column6: we did a photo shoot of us in our awesome clothing. I look like a giant in all the “girls only” pictures
column7: however
column8: because Anjali and Vanessa are both super small. In fact Vanessa is the shortest person in our entire class. When the boys are in
column9: things balance out.

column2: so
column3: we went back to our rooms to change out of our fancy Indian clothes and into western clothes to hit the mall. This time we weren’t going to mess around with cabs – we just walked up to the road and grabbed some rickshaws. Much easier! I’ll try to take a video of rickshawing later. It’s a bit of an adventure and not for the faint of heart
column4: but it’s actually my favourite way to travel here. You get a nice cool breeze and if anything seems like it’s not quite right
column5: you can just get out. Plus
column6: no one is able to go very fast in the bad traffic so I feel like if we got hit we wouldn’t get TOO hurt (my mom just had a heart attack when reading that).

column1: Once in the mall we went up to the top level (there were like five or six – it’s a huge mall!) and bought tickets for a showing. Anjali picked a good one out for us which had both action/adventure for the boys
column2: and choreographed dance numbers for me. Perfect! We had a bit of time before the movie started so we split up to explore the mall. Jeff
column3: Brodie and I happened upon “Play Salon” which had an unsecured wireless connection
column4: so we loitered outside of there for a while with our smartphones. I think this mall is fairly new
column5: and I got the impression that Bangalore doesn’t have a lot of buildings with escalators in them. At every escalator (and there are many with so many floors) there were at least two security guards stationed
column6: armed with whistles. You got whistled at for EVERYTHING. Not facing forward
column7: being too close to the person in front of you
column8: being under a certain age without a parent
column9: standing too close to the entrance or exit
column10: or even walking up/down the escalator. At first I thought it was a bit ridiculous
column11: but actually I can see why they need it. Having grown up with escalators I take them for granted
column12: but I can see how they would be tricky to navigate if you weren’t used to it. I saw many people have trouble stepping on the correct moving step when boarding
column13: and lots of time people would step off at the top and just stop right there. I even saw two kids fall
column14: seemingly from a steady standing position. Still
column15: though
column16: it was annoying for us Canadian “rebels” to constantly get whistled at because we were riding backwards to talk to each other or walking down the escalator to speed up the ride. Come on
column17: people
column18: we have advanced escalator skills!

column1: When it was time for the movie we met up outside the theatre entrance. There were separate entrances for guys and girls. There we were given the third degree and our bags were checked. There were bag checks and metal detectors going in to the mall
column2: too (although they were useless because they constantly beeped and no one cared) but these checks were not for security. They were looking for cameras. I think movie pirating is a big problem here. My camera snuck through undetected
column3: but Vanessa got caught. They made her take out her battery and check it
column4: plus fill out all kinds of paperwork. Finally
column5: once we were all in
column6: the others grabbed some snacks and we headed in to the theatre. They have assigned seating at these movies
column7: which would have been good since our group was so large
column8: but actually this movie wasn’t very full. Anj told us that usually when the theatre is really full there is a lot of cat calling and heckling at the screen
column9: but there wasn’t much of that during our movie. It was a much more relaxed atmosphere though with much giggling and whispering than would be acceptable at home. This was a good thing because the movie was in Hindi
column10: so Anjali
column11: poor thing
column12: spent the whole film whispering translation to us. Granted
column13: the plot wasn’t that elaborate so we could follow along fairly well on our own
column14: but it was nice to have a guide. It was surprisingly violent! Also there were some make out scenes and a sex scene. Apparently ten years ago there wasn’t even kissing allowed in Bollywood movies
column15: but times have clearly changed. I actually liked it a lot. The cinematography was surprisingly good – much better than the old ones you see on YouTube. It really is a huge industry here. The films are long
column16: too. There was even an intermission in the middle!

column1: Once the movie was finished it was time to grab rickshaws and get back to the hotel to get ready for the reception. It turns out the reception was at a different hotel
column2: which meant that we had to negotiate transportation again. We didn’t want to take rickshaws because we would be wearing nice clothes
column3: so we asked the hotel to call us a cab. Long story short
column4: we ended up having to get two expensive cars at 300 ruppees each for a trip which was seriously just down the road. We were cutting it close
column5: though
column6: and we just needed to get there. When the cars showed up we got in and confirmed the price. Then the drivers starting saying “ohhh LE Meridian? I thought you were talking about a different hotel” then he demanded 500 rupees! At this point
column7: Anjali lost it. We had been getting screwed by various drivers all day and she had had enough. She started yelling at the driver things like
column8: “no! That is unacceptable! It’s just around the corner! 300 rupees was the deal! I’ve had enough of these games!” etc etc. It was actually kind of funny
column9: especially since Anjali couldn’t speak Hindi well enough to get the words out when she was mad
column10: so the whole tirade was in English. And if you know Anjali
column11: you know she is really mild mannered in general so to hear her raise her voice at all was quite a change
column12: but probably didn’t seem that intense to a bystander. Anyhow
column13: we all calmed down
column14: we arrived
column15: we paid our 300 rupees and disembarked.

column1: The hotel where the reception was held was absolutely gorgeous. I’m sure it was one of the nicest in Bangalore. Sagar was waiting in the lobby when we arrived and it was great to get a chance to chat with him. It was the first time I had been able to talk to him since he picked me up from the airport. After some more photos we thought we should leave him to his hosting duties
column2: so we headed down to the reception. This event had even more people than the wedding
column3: and a huge ballroom was full of chairs. We managed to score a round table at the side though
column4: which made a nice home base. Sagar’s dad is an influential cardiologist here so there were many powerful people in attendance
column5: including various ministers and industry leaders. This event was a lot about photos (again!) but we also did another receiving line to wish the couple our blessing. The line seemed to never end! I don’t know how many people were there
column6: but it was a lot. There was also a ton of food. The buffet items stretched the entire wall length. We had been hoping for dancing
column7: but the crowd was waning and still nothing had happened. There was a good band playing a mix of Indian music and western covers
column8: but everyone seemed content to listen. We were just contemplating leaving when all of a sudden
column9: one of Sagar’s young cousins starting busting a move (she was a great dancer!). Next thing we knew
column10: Sagar’s DAD was breaking it down! I don’t think anyone expected that. Then even Sagar was heading over and beckoning us to follow. Now
column11: this was exciting. I have known Sagar for four years and I have never seen him dance ONCE. Before long
column12: everyone who was left had congregated in front of the band and a huge spontaneous dance party broke out. Sagar and Deepa looked great dancing together
column13: and they both seemed really happy
column14: which was nice to see. It was super fun
column15: and our group learned some excellent new Indian dance moves. I think Jeff was the best – he fit right in!

column2: after yet more pictures
column3: the night came to a close. Sagar arranged for some cars to take us back to our hotel. Oh
column4: and Sagar’s brother-in-law presented us with some Indian sweets to “take on our journey.” So nice!

column1: We had Friday free of wedding-related activities
column2: so we were hoping to head out of the city for a day trip. We had made friends with one of Sagar’s wedding guests the day before
column3: and she had offered to help us book a car to take us to a National Park just outside of town since we had such difficulty arranging transportation. Everything was all set up
column4: and for a great price. We work up
column5: had breakfast
column6: and got suited up for our safari adventure. The car was supposed to arrive at 9:30 for a 10am departure. Nothing at 9:30. Nothing at 10am. Nothing at 10:30… We weren’t entirely sure what to do. We didn’t have a number for the company
column7: and we foolishly hadn’t even gotten the number of our friend. So we asked the hotel to call Sagar to ask him to call his friend to find out what the deal was. We weren’t sure who exactly the hotel spoke to
column8: but the end result was that the person was going to try to sort things out and call us back. Thirty minutes later
column9: still no call back! I won’t go through everything
column10: but basically the plan changed around 15 times and it was a constant game of telephone tag and miscommunication
column11: with Sagar’s family and his friend doing their absolute best to help us. In the end
column12: a few hours later
column13: we found out the car company had all of their cars booked. This was fine
column14: as we were ready to give up anyway. By this point we were exhausted and decided to have a drink in the bar to chill out. The bar was actually pretty awesome – a hidden gem we hadn’t noticed before. It was called “Aqua bar” and it had this sweet underwater theme
column15: complete with a wall made of saltwater fish tanks.

column2: we were ready to leave the hotel lobby. We grabbed rickshaws to the Bangalore Palace which had been recommended to us. It turned out it was going to cost 400 rupees to go inside
column3: including an audio guide
column4: and not everyone was in to that. But we had come all the way there so we decided to bite the bullet and go for it. I’m really glad we did! The palace was giant and really neat. The audio guide was excellent
column5: as well. Basically
column6: it was a castle inspired by English architecture
column7: used to house the local rulers during British Colonial times. There were all kinds of cool artifacts
column8: including stools made of elephant feet and an ingenious bench which was actually a scale to weigh jockeys on. There were many old photos of palace life and exotic hunts. Quite a different time. Unfortunately it cost more than admission to be allowed to take photos
column9: so I don’t have any pictures to share.

column1: After the palace we wanted to head generally back to the mall from the day before
column2: because Vanessa needed to buy a cell phone and SIM card for use during her time here. We opted to walk in order to see more of the area. It was a bit of a journey but with the help of an iPhone map that Jeff had downloaded earlier and some persistent navigation skills by Vanessa
column3: we made it!

column2: the people in Bangalore are generally really great. We never get hassled here like I often do in other developing countries. No one is pulling at our arms and trying to sell us stuff
column3: or yelling at us asking where we’re from. They’ll maybe stare a bit and we’ll exchange smiles and hellos
column4: but that’s it. And they always are helpful when we need to ask directions. It ‘s really quite nice.

column2: we made it to the mall and all split up to acquire food and drink. We were exhausted! Vanessa attempted to buy her cell phone but was told to come back at 5pm because the man who sells SIM cards would be back then . When we came back
column3: we were told he would be back the next day. What?? How do you sell cell phones without SIM cards? Despite the whole area being full of cell phone shops
column4: none had SIM cards for her. Oh well.

column1: Next we took rickshaws to a McDonalds near our hotel. I always love to try the local cultural McDonalds specialty when I’m in a new country
column2: and it turns out the rest of the group is the same. This McDonalds had all kinds of exotic things to try! I went for the McTikki Ackaloo (I think that’s what it was called). It was kind of like a falafel patty with peas in it
column3: normal burger toppings
column4: and a spicy Chiptole-type sauce. It was great! Although on first bite I forgot I wasn’t eating and normal burger and was surprised when a pea popped in to my mouth.

column1: After MickeyDee’s we walked back to our hotel and chilled out for a few hours before heading out on the town. We wanted to check out a bar up on the 13th floor of a hotel. It was pricey
column2: but it was a fun atmosphere and the view was great. Interestingly
column3: the curfew for bars here is 11:30
column4: and by 11:00 pretty much everyone had left and the lights were coming on. Time to leave! We were a bit nervous about whether we would be able to get a rickshaw back but luckily some were waiting outside. We had to pay a bit more than we probably should have
column5: but I didn’t mind at all. We had just dropped a ton of money at that bar and it was raining and cold
column6: so I thought that rickshaw driver totally deserved the fare.

column1: The boys and Vanessa stayed up a bit more to finish of the “wine” from the other day
column2: but I went back to my room to update the travelblog.

column1: That pretty much brings us to today! Today should be really fun. We’re checking out of our hotel to head north to town where Deepa is from. I think Sagar needs to spend a night in their home as part of the ceremony
column2: and there will be another reception there. It will be great to see a smaller town. Right now we’re just waiting for a car to come get us… we’ll see if it shows up! =)
I’ve been a hermit all morning so I should probably go hang out with the others. I wonder if they’re in the Aqua bar….

column1: How to go Muthathi from banglaore
Muthathi is about 100 kms from Bangalore via kanakapura. You have to go to Kanakapura first (60+ kms)
column2: then from kanakapura to Sathanur (18 kms) on National highway 209
column3: from Sathanur take a left turn to Muthathi (18 kms). Bheemeswari is 5 kms from Muthathi on Halagur Road.

column1: If you are coming from Mysore in Mallavalli road
column2: you have to come to Halagur
column3: from Halagur take a right turn to Bheemeshwari (20 kms)
column4: from Bheemeshwari further 5 kms to Muthathi.

column2: but less frequent from Sathanur to Muthathi. Although one may go by bus
column3: it is better to go by own vehicle
column4: because there are 2-3 picnic spots 2 –3 kms before Muthathi
column5: where you can halt. Besides if you have own vehicle you can halt at hanuman temples on the way and go to bheemeswari (5kms).

column1: What is there to see near Muthathi

Muthathi is surrounded by hills from all sides. While going from Sathanur the road goes down steep with sharp bends from the hills 5 kms before Muthathi and again climbs up steep with hairpin bends after 7 kms on the other side (after 2 kms from Bheemeshwari) towards Halagur.
You will see nice hills view when you are on the hills 5 kms before Muthathi. The trees and environment will look like any hill station. This picture is taken on Sathanur-Muthathi road
column2: 5 kms before Muthathi.
the road will go down sharp to the valley. Thereafter you will find a temple of lord Hanuman
column3: called as Padadhara Anjaneya swami temple. This temple seems to be very popular as most passers by halt at this temple to have darshan of the lord.

column1: After hanuman temple you will find river Kavery on the left and 2 to 3 picnic spots on the river side before reaching Muthathi. If it is a holiday or picnic hour you can see people gathering in the picnic spot. Otherwise you can recognize these picnic spots by seeing pathway going down towards river and paper plates or other such picnic materials thrown here and there.

All these picnic spots before Mthathi and Muthati itself are Kaveray river spots. These are the pictures during summer in May when there is very less water in the river. The granite bed of the river gives very attractive view.
There is another hanuman temple in Muthathi
column2: known as Muthetharaya temple. This temple has some mythological importance. When Devi Sita was taking bath at this place
column3: her nose stud fell down in the river. Hanuman came to the place
column4: found the stud and returned to Sita devi. That’s why Hanuman got the name Muthetharaya here.

column1: It was early May when we went Muthathi this time. Because of summer season
column2: tThere was very less water in the river. We could see the beautiful black granite stones on the river bed and walk over them.

column1: The cows and bull s in Muthathi are very beautiful having extremely long horns (more than 2 feet)
column2: pointed and sharp
column3: looking very attractive.

column1: While in Muthathi we saw a crowd carrying some god on their shoulders for visharjan (dipping in water). The god was sitting on a tiger and the crowd was screaming as “Govinda..Govinda..”. They kept the palki near the river and did pooja and visharjan thereafter.

After spending some time in Muthathi we went towards Bheemeshwari. Bheemeshwari is 5 kms from Muthathi. There is also another Hanuman temple called “Rama Anjaneya swami temple” (picture below) on the way and a river spot in front of the temple.

The river Kavery in front of the temple is extremely beautiful (picture below). The temple is on the right side of the road and river is on the left side (while coming from Muthathi). The place is cool and nice to take bath.
After Ramanjaneya temple you have go further for Bheemeshwari. In Bheemeshwari
column2: you will find a temple called BheemaLingeswar Temple (below).

column1: On the other side you will find Bheemeswari Adventure and Nature Camp and Kavery Fishing Camp. They charge 1300/- per person for day trip and much more for night halts. You have to book before hand for the nature and fishing camps.
There is no food (no habitation) in Bheemeswari. Although there is no good hotel in Muthathi
column2: you can find a couple of places to take food. Besides you can get chips and cold drinks here. Sathanur is a bigger place having more places to eat
column3: although none of them is of good standard. Kanakapura gives you many good places to eat.

column1: We took south Indian meals at sathanur which was simple but ok. On the way back we took Masala Dosa on a better looking hotel in Kanakpura
column2: although the taste was just OK.

column1: There is no accommodation available in Muthathi or nearby. However
column2: accommodation is available at Bheemeswari Jungle lodges which is expensive and not worth for people who can return back on the same day.

column1: Thus we halted at and covered several points around muthathi which include the following.

column2: the main point

column1: - Ramanjaneya swami temple on Muthathi Bheemeswari road - the kavery view there too
- Bheemeswari nature camp and Kavery fishing camp (from outside only)
- Hills view 2 kms after Bheemeshwari towards halagur. The road climbs steep on the hills with hairpin bends and gives a beautiful view of the valley (picture below).

Muthathi like many other Kavery water spots look very calm and quiet. But there are strong water currents in many places and crocodiles too. Although it is very attractive to bath or swim in the river
column2: it is very dangerous to get into the water. Many people loose their lives every year in kavery baths.

column1: There are few other places which can be covered on the same day along with Muthathi.

column2: the confluence of river Arkavati and Kavery (40+ kms from Muthathi
column3: 95 kms from Bangalore)

column2: 100 Kms from Bangalore)
85 kms from Bangalore)
50 Kms from Bangalore)

column1: Note: You can read the original article at http://www.travelindia.tk/blog/view/628/muthathi-and-bheemeshwari-the-kaveri-water-spots-about-100-kms-from-bangalore

Yikes! Days have passed since I arrived in India and this is my first blog update. That means I'll inevitably forget tons of fun tidbits as I try to cram in all the craziness of the start of this adventure. Also
column2: it's late at night and I might just run out of steam... let's see how far I can get.
a little background on this trip. Basically
column3: I'm on a break between the end of medical school and the start of residency. Most everyone I know in my class has taken the opportunity to travel to some part of the world
column4: so I thought I would follow suit. As luck would have it
column5: my good friend from my class
column6: Sagar
column7: was scheduled to get married in Bangalore
column8: India
column9: during this time and the dates worked out perfectly for me to make the trek. A bunch of other close friends from school are here
column10: too. Josh
column11: Jeff
column12: Brodie
column13: and Vanessa are here for pretty much my whole trip
column14: and Anjali and Kamini met up with us for the engagement/wedding (more on that later). So overall
column15: it's a great crew for a great adventure!

column1: Bangalore used to be known as the Garden City of India
column2: but now it is more famous for its tech industry. It's considered the Silicon Valley of the region and is also home to a lot of call centers. Literacy levels are really high and the English language is prevelant.
Vanessa and I booked ourselves on the same flights from Toronto to Bangalore. The trip was pretty smooth and generally uneventful. We stumbled upon Mike and Matt
column3: also from our class
column4: in the departures lounge at YYZ
column5: though
column6: because the poor guys had been delayed over 12 hours trying to get to London. Luckily we didn't have anything like that on our trip! The big hiccup for me was the lack of internet access in Frankfurt during our stopover. Honestly
column7: what major airports don't have internet access these days? I had a bunch of emails I needed to send and reply to which I didn't get to before I left (it was a WHIRLWIND week prior to departure
column8: with writing my medicince licensing exam
column9: a marathon weekend of Scouts Board meetings
column10: conducting interviews for a hiring committee
column11: and then signing lease papers and sending money for my new place in Calgary). I have an even longer stop over there on the way back. Wasted time frustrates me.

column1: We arrived in Bangalore at 00:30. We were pretty sure that someone was going to meet us at the airport
column2: but we didn't know exactly who or where or... much (this would be a recurring theme). But once we landed I texted Brodie and he said they were waiting for us
column3: and sure enough
column4: after exiting the airport we had Jeff
column5: Josh
column6: Brodie
column7: and Sagar all there to welcome us with big hugs! What troopers - it was like 1:30am by the time we left and the trip back to the hotel took about 45 minutes. We had two cars: one was driven by a hired driver but Sagar drove the other one himself. If you could see the roads here you would know how impressive that is! At least traffic is way reduced at night time. The other car actually got lost
column8: but we all made it to our hotel eventually. I had slept great on the plane from Frankfurt
column9: but I had not trouble sleeping well in my hotel bed once I settled in
column10: too. I think I have two years of sleep deprivation to correct (before I get started on the next five years of sleep deficit!).

column2: I suppose
column3: later that same morning) we woke and had an excellent breakfast at the hotel. They have a huge breakfast buffet every morning which is included with our stay. It's a neat mix of Indian foods and sort of western breakfast foods
column4: but everything has a bit of a twist. Overall
column5: though
column6: it's good and we really fill up to start our day. My one complaint is that the coffee certainly leaves something to be desired... ah well.

column1: Our next challenge was to get Anjali from the airport. She was arriving at 12:30 in the afternoon on a domestic flight from Dehli where she has been staying with family for the last two weeks. That turned out to be a bit of a challenge. Sagar had arranged for another car to pick Vanessa and I up from the hotel to go to the airport to grab Anj and bring her back. The problem was
column2: I felt the timeline was pretty tight because the airport is at LEAST 45 minutes away
column3: more with traffic
column4: and the car was supposed to get us at noon
column5: get Anj
column6: come back to the hotel
column7: then we were supposed to go meet Kamini across town for lunch before massage appointments at 3pm. If you are confused
column8: you are still not experiencing the level of chaos that was experienced that afternoon. Basically
column9: Anj had arrived at the airport and still no car had shown up at the hotel to get me and Vanessa. We would discover this would soon be a reoccuring theme. The other issue was that without an Indian mobile (cell phone) we have a terrible time communicating with anyone. So when the car didn't come we had to get the hotel to call Sagar's mobile
column10: which they were hesitant to do for us (only some of the hotel staff are helpful. We have now figured out which ones are the enablers and which ones are to be avoided) to figure out what to do. Much texting was going on through a web-based text service because Anjali had wifi at the Bangalore airport
column11: but we were paying for wifi by the hour at our hotel. So we would text Anjali and attempt to call Sagar multiple times
column12: and it was all very confusing. Eventually Anjali just worked up the courage to take a taxi by herself to the hotel. It worked out find. Oh
column13: meanwhile we were doing the same web-based texting to Kamini
column14: who was wondering what the heck was going on. Kamini's aunt and uncle live in Bangalore so she has been here many times. In fact
column15: her parents were visiting right now
column16: as well.

column2: basically
column3: Anjali arrived
column4: ditched her stuff in Vanessa's room
column5: and then we attempted to get to the restaurant where we were supposed to meet Kamini and the other boys (they had headed out on their own for some exploring earlier). We asked the hotel to call us a taxi
column6: and when a car arrived we got it. As we were pulling away we tried to confirm the rate but the driver started quoting crazy prices. He wanted us to pay to hire him for 4 hours
column7: but we only wanted a one-way trip. There was much frustration and fighting and Anjali arguing in broken Hindi (she lived in India from ages 3-5) which eventually culminated in us asking to be brought back to hotel. So
column8: that was transportation fail number 2 for the day. It turns out that was a bit of a miscommunication and now we know the difference between a metered taxi and hiring a driver. The hotel clearly has a vested interest in hiring cars because they constantly push us to get them
column9: even though we don't need or want that. Finally we got a metered cab (again
column10: after craziness but I won't get in to it) and headed off. We texted the driver's mobile number to Kamini before we left the wifi zone of the hotel
column11: and she had someone call him to give directions. It took convicing to get the driver to pick up the phone because he didn't understand what was going on
column12: but eventually he did. Miraculously
column13: we ended up in front of the restaurant
column14: I and Monkey
column15: for a very reasonable 200 rupees. Phew!

column2: we were really late. It was almost 3:00 and the restaurant was closing at that time
column3: plus we were supposed to be at the spa then. Luckily the boys had only just arrived
column4: themselves
column5: because their rickshaws had no idea where to go. It turns out that Kamini's whole extended family was there and that her uncle knows the owner
column6: so they were lenient and stayed open a bit later for us. The food and service were fantastic! A cold beer was nice after the stress of the day
column7: as well. As an added bonus
column8: when we got up to leave we found out that Kamini's family had taken care of the bill for us - so kind! Even better
column9: they had left us two cars and drivers to get where we needed to go. The boys went shopping while us girls went off to a little local salon that Kamini knows well.

column1: I would never in a million years have known about that place myself because it really was just a business out of someone's house on a small side street
column2: but the ladies there cared about their work and paid a lot of attention to detail for a very reasonable price. I had my first mani/pedi
column3: which was... interesting. The manicure was nice
column4: but I'm really not that into people getting that invested in my feet
column5: I think. I may not get another opportunity to have a manicrue
column6: however
column7: because soon I'll be starting surgical training and you can't have nailpolish on when you scrub in to surgery. Flakes of laquer are not good things to get in a surgical field! I had been hoping for a massage
column8: as well
column9: but I didn't really have time in the end because the other girls were finished up their treatments and I didn't want to hold up the group.

column1: From there we swung by an Indian clothing shop because I wanted to get an Indian outfit for the engagment party that night. Sagar's family had purchased all of us beautiful Indian clothing for the wedding
column2: but I kind of wanted to wear something different for the engagement (Anjali had a bunch of outfits to choose from and Vanessa was borrowing something from Kamini
column3: but I'm about twice the size of them so I was on my own). Kamini said the shop we were going to had really well priced stuff so it would be a quick win. Well
column4: it turns out times had changed since the last time she was there! I went to try on a long shirt and pants which was * nice * but not a dream garmet of mine or anything
column5: and took a look at the pricetag in the changeroom. It said 7000 rupees. I stood there for a while thinking that jet lag or something must be prohibiting my conversion skills. How could this cotton shirt cost 7000 rupees? I must be missing a decimal or something. I came out with the outfit on and asked Kamini how much 7000 rupees was. She was like
column6: ""I don't know... $150 or something. Why?"" ""Because that's how much this costs!!!"" ""WHAT??!?!"" She exclaimined. ""OK
column7: well just take it off and let's get out of here! That's crazy!""

column2: too. She said we could by the same thing for $30 in Toronto. We're not talking silk sari or anything... this was just a cotton long shirt and pants with some embroidary embellisment. We are told that times have changed in the last few years. As Bangalore
column3: and
column4: presumably
column5: India in general
column6: has boomed the divide between upper-middle class and poor has increasingly widened. There has been an increased emphasis on material goods and prices have risen accordingly. Basic silk saris cost hundreds of dollars now.

column1: I decided to wear a western dress from home to the engagment party.
Before heading to the hotel and the party
column2: we swung by Kamini's aunt's house so that she and Vanessa could get dressed in their saris and we could have some tea. They looked gorgeous
column3: but my goodness they were a production to put on! It starts with a small crop top (the blouse) and a long skirt which ties up (the petticoat). These are basically foundation garments. Then a single gigantic piece of cloth is tucked in to the top of the petticoat and wrapped around the wearer multiple times. Finally
column4: it is brought up and around the shoulder
column5: pleated
column6: and pinned up. That probably sounds more simple than it actually is. Kamini's mom had to help and at times there were two people involved in the pleating and pinning. Apparantly they are very hot and heavy
column7: as well.

column2: we headed back to the hotel so Anjali and I could get dressed. Here
column3: the clothing ordeals continued. I slipped in to my dress no problem
column4: but Anjali had a wardrobe malfunction. She was wearing a long Indian dress/shirt (I should really know the names for these things) which had one of those small zippers running down the side which always gets caught. It continually got stuck and we could NOT get it to go down. The worst part was that it was sticking near the top
column5: so basically one whole side of her outfit was gapping open. Poor Anj was determined to wear that dress
column6: though
column7: because it had long sleeves and here arms were COVERED in terrible mosquito bites from Dehli
column8: some of which had actually blistered! So
column9: we tried and tried to get that zipper down
column10: unsure of what we were missing downstairs because events were already supposed to have started at this point. With Anjali's arm raised over her head
column11: Vanessa
column12: Kamini
column13: and I all worked away
column14: pulling at various parts of armpit fabric and zipper
column15: trying to close the seam. It was actually rather hilarious. Eventually brute force prevailed and the zipper went down
column16: but the upper part split open. Oh well. 80% was closed. Now
column17: though
column18: we needed a pin to secure that part to make sure no other part of the zipper seam pulled open. Kamini and Vanessa had safety pins on their saris
column19: but they were serving important functions and they couldn't be given up. No one else had any pins of any kind. After a search my bag and hotel room
column20: I managed to find one straight pin and a small ""BEAVERS CANADA"" pin with a safety pin style back. Anj was desperate at this point
column21: so the BEAVERS CANADA pin was employed. If someone looked closely
column22: they would have been rather confused with the latest accessories from Canada.

column2: we were ready to head down to the engagement party and meet up with the boys. I guess I haven't said much about it yet
column3: but this is an arranged marriage that Sagar is entering in to. He met his wife-to-be for the first time in December when he went home to India for a week. They were then going to get engaged through an elaborate ceremony this night and be married the next day. Short
column4: so no time to back out
column5: I guess!

column1: It turns out we hadn't missed much. Apparently Indian wedding ceremonies are fairly fluid events where people kind of come and go throughout. This ceremony was in very full
column2: hot room. There was a traditional band playing in the corner and Sagar and Deepa were on a beautiful stage with flowers all around. There were also big time bright lights with two video cameras and two still photographers - one set for each side of the family. The evening consisted of a lot of blessings and a LOT of photographers. Everyone was dressed beautifully in outfits shimmering with every colour of the rainbow. Sagar's family is extremely nice and made us always feel welcome and taken care of. His sister and her husband are especially great. They had recently done fellowships at McGill so they have a good handle of what our ""norms"" are and take care of us when we look confused. They are both doctors
column3: as is Sagar's father. In fact
column4: there are 17 doctors in their family! We know we have nothing to worry about while we are here. Many guests wanted to speak with us and find out what brought us all the way here from Canada
column5: and they
column6: in turn
column7: explained parts of the ceremony to us.

column1: After eating a delicious Indian buffet dinner we got a chance to give our blessings to the engaged couple. This involved us going barefoot up on the stage and waving a platter with lighted candles and fresh flowers around in a circle. Then we touched the rim of the candle holders with our finger and then touched the finger to the forehead of each Sagar and Deepa.

Eventually we snuck off to our rooms as things were winding down. The boys had attempted to acquire some booze earlier in the day for us. They did well on the beer (""Kingfisher"" beef is ubiquitous here) but we had requested wine
column2: and that was more difficult. When they told their driver they needed wine they were taken down an alley and dropped off in front of an enclosed cage with a small window. They asked for wine and a jug of ""local"" wine was produced. It was kind of sketchy
column3: and fortified. They boys bought three jugs. Haha. So
column4: that night we tried the wine. It was.... terrible. How were we going to drink 3 litres of this stuff! We tried mixing it with some soda water and that made it slightly more bareable. Eventually we discovered it was more tolerable if we stopped thinking of it as wine and more as just miscellanous alcohol. I still wasn't a huge fan
column5: but tonight (2 nights later) the last jug was finished off. I never thought we would do it.

column1: The next day was the wedding in the morning
column2: followed by a reception in the evening. I hope I get to write about it all but time is marching on! I should get a chance for some more writing tomorrow morning because we will probably have a bunch of time waiting for a car to pick us up (we are going up north to Deepa's village for a continuation of the marraige ritual stuff). I should probably stop here for tonight because it's almost 2am and we have a big day tomorrow. I have TONS of pictures. I'll try to get those up tomorrow
column3: too. Goodnight for now!
