column1: After having a wonderful first half clicking around at The Ranganathittu Bird Sanctuary
column2: I returned to my hotel room in Mysore. I still had the rest of the day to explore some more places in and around Mysore. I recalled
column3: some years ago when I was living in Bangalore
column4: I had a friend from Tibet
column5: Kalsang. Once he mentioned about Bylakuppe
column6: one of the largest Tibetan settlement in India and the beautiful monasteries around. My brain clicked and I checked with the Hotel reception immediately.

column2: I asked.
hotel manager replied.
I disconnected the intercom.

column1: Within 10 minutes I had my camera ready and I walked down to the City bus stand in Mysore. I love Karnataka not only for its beautiful destinations but also ‘The

Best’ transport connectivity in India. I was asking around about the buses to Kushalnagar. One guy pointed out to platform no. 3. I gradually walked to the platform no. 3 and I saw almost 5 buses were ready to start immediately. To go to Kushalnagar
column2: one has to take a bus to Madikeri.
conductor nodded.

column1: In next 10 minutes I was enjoying the beautiful and clean city streets of Mysore. And in next 20 minutes I was cruising through Bangalore-Madikeri Road. The first big stop was at Hunsuru
column2: a big sub divisional town in Karnataka. The turf between Mysore to Hunsuru was just a paradise to all the cruisers and my

column1: KSRTC 'Bus man' did live up to my expectation. The bus halted here for about 5 minutes and hit the road again. The road between Hunsuru to Kushalnagar took almost an hour and half and was so scenic that I was enjoying every bit of it. I was travelling with a Monk and his granddaughter. He was telling me the stories of Bylakuppe and the monasteries. The bus was roaring at the
top gears and climate was cozy enough to enjoy every moment of it. I was thinking about my next line of plans. This extension of Coorg is really eye pleasing. Lush green terrains
column2: long winding roads
column3: Aromas like fresh morning glory and drive

column1: Amidst coffee and pepper plantations which was aplenty. Around 4pm the bus dropped me at Kushalnagar bus stand. This place seemed to me like any other district town in Karnataka with all sort of modern amenities available. I was gazing around in search of a vehicle to drive me to Bylakuppe which was merely 2 and half miles away from Kushalnagar. I walked out of the bus stand and found a fellow in mid-forties waiting with his three wheelers.

column2: I asked
He asked further
I replied
he said
I hoped in.
he said
column3: ‘Ayub'. He took a diversion from the freeway and was asking about my whereabouts and reason for visiting this place. I got his 'between the lines' that he was trying

column1: to clinch a deal. I got the point and asked him straight.
'How many temples are here apart from the Golden Temple?'

column2: there are 4 more'
column3: he replied.

column1: 'And how much you are going to squeeze out of my pocket if I would make a visit to all four of them’
column2: I offered him a deal.
there is a long trip for 4 monasteries that would cost around Rs.400 and there is a short trip of 4 monasteries which would be lesser
column4: He got me thinking.

column1: I couldn't understand his offer. If there are four monasteries how come there are 'long and short' trips. Is he planning to rip me? I sank deep in my thoughts. He realized his answer was a kind of a riddle to me which I was playing a hard ball to decode. He went further describing the details.

column2: apart from The Golden Temple
column3: there are four more monasteries. Sera Je
column4: Sera Mey
column5: Kagyu and a newly built one. If you would like to visit all four except Kagyu which eventually isolated from the others

column1: would cost you Rs.250. Makes sense?'

column2: but to let others understand him in a better way
column3: there are 5 monasteries in this Bylakuppe-Kushal Nagar Sector. Namdroling (Which is known as the Golden Temple to the locals)
column4: Sera Jey
column5: Sera Mey
column6: Kagyu and a newly constructed one which neither him nor I was sure about the name. I was thinking what to do as it was almost 4:30pm and I eventually picked up an overcast day which would mean that the sunlight won't be available much longer to make good shots. I asked him to drop Kagyu this time and clinched the 'short deal' with Rs. 250/-. He seemed to be happy enough with that too.

column1: Drive from Kushalnagar to Bylakuppe was through narrow city lanes and didn't take more than 20 minutes to reach The Golden Temple. Unlike my other tours
column2: I found a bit of a crowd here as being a public holiday
column3: people from faraway places decided to take a short diversion to this place enroute Madikeri
column4: Coorg. Other than that I didn't feel anyone has any sort interest in Monasteries or how the monks lead their lives

column1: here. A typical South Indian crowd who really got messed up this place with any other Hindu Temple and was trying a make a fuss here.I love visiting monasteries mostly for the peaceful environment and tidiness which really a 'big miss' in any other Hindu Temple. I walked inside and found a 'Big Hostel' kind of building to me left
column2: indeed that was the place where the monks live. I walked further ahead and found that entire campus was huge and maintained with utmost creativity and serenity. I moved ahead to the main temple after clicking a few more shots. The main Buddha Idol was almost 80 feet tall and was crafted with a lot of colorful impressions. In front of the idol a natural sphere was tried to project and it was done with utmost neutrality that I could see a few birds were enjoying this wonderful place as well. As usual the 'messed up' tourists were trying to create a mess with packs of 'Frito Lays' and 'Gooddays'. I was really getting my 'apples hot' so decided to walk out of this place immediately. I was feeling pity for the monks that their purpose of practicing meditation really

column1: went for the day for these ‘immature’ tourists out there. I tried to pose a few shots with monks and they seemed to very humble people with a smile on their face always. Time was running out for me and I had 3 more to visit. Ayub was waiting for me and he clutched his ""Merc"" faster to Sera Je. Once we drove out of The Golden Temple
column2: I found that the bunch of tourists were not following this route which gave me a slight indication that their ""diversion"" was just for the Golden Temple not for the other monasteries here. From Namdorling to Sera Je may be a mile's drive and yes ! I was the only person to enjoy the serenity. I interacted with a few more monks and tried to learn about their routines and how they feel staying furthest from home. I really liked their answers and yes
column3: with a smile always. After spending sometime in Sera Je and Sera Mei I saw a small Tibetan Restaurant just outside the Sera Mei monastery. I realized that I didn't have a bite of grains to eat since morning. I was more curious to have 'Momo'
column4: 'Fing Sha' and

column1: 'Tingmo' after some years. I asked Ayub whether these monks allow other tourists to stay in their hostels then I could give it a try for a night. He said that they usually don't but if I say I was just alone and would like to do some research
column2: they might allow. I got his trick again. I spoke with one of the main administrators of the Sera Mei monastery and almost begged with utmost innocence to spend one night at the hostel. Since I was born I realized that my innocent face was the key to my success. My job
column3: my marriage everything went hassle-free because of my innocence and here I was a 'no exceptional' as well. I asked Ayub bhai to return to Kushal Nagar and to pick me up at the early am next day. Rest of the evening I spent time roaming around the places and sharing my travelling experiences with the monks. Since being requested by the administrator
column4: I am not sharing the routines and the other 'High profile but sensitive' discussions about Tibet and the Tibetans.

column1: I had a wonderful dinner with the monks and it was Momos
column2: Tingmo and Shapta.

column1: I was feeling like being in heaven. One thing for sure
column2: I need to visit this

column1: Place quite often. It's not a 'one time' place to come
column2: see and leave but a place which would give strength to your lungs to breath afresh. I am in love with this place. However
column3: unwillingly I woke up with Ayub bhai's honk
column4: next day around 7am. After expressing my sincere thanks and gratitude to the monks whom I

column1: Befriended with during my stay in Bylakuppe for just more than 16 hours. I am sure that the bunch of tourists seeking their 'Vacation' will not visit this place as it has nothing but the 'music of traquility
column2: peace and harmony' which I may have longed for years. Love you Bylakuppe. God bless all !!!

column1: Coorg is an awesome place to stay and enjoy the climate. We stayed in a resort which was beyond our expectations. We started from Coimbatore @ 8 AM in the morning and reached Coorg in the evening. Stayed there for 3 days and the experience was awesome. The place is also called Medikeri. Nearby airport is Mysore.
We visited the Golden temple and artificial park.

column2: Displayed: 12
Dandeli

column1: Mumbai – Dandeli – Sirsi – Yana-Hampi – Pattadakal – Badami – Aihole – Bijapur – Mumbai 20th – 25th March’2012

We left Mumbai by Mangalore Expresses at 10.15 pm scheduled to reach Karwar next day 8.30 am. The idea was to start our North Karnataka tour from Karwar with plans to enjoy about 2-3 hours of para-gliding and other beach activities at Deobagh Resort
column2: Karwar in the morning before proceeding further. However the train reached about 2 hours late forcing us to drop the idea and head straight for Dandeli by road.

column1: Lesson 1 learnt :- Kokan Railway operates on only one track and thus invariably trains run late
column2: so keep enough time margin on hand.

column1: For going to Dandeli from Mumbai
column2: better is to embark at Londa Station which is just about 38 kms from Dandeli. Your Dandeli hotel would invariably arrange for a pickup at a small cost or local taxis are available just outside both Londa or Karwar station for Dandeli.

column1: Karwar – Dandeli is about 112 kms but took us more than 4 ½ hours as about 25 kms of road in between is extremely

column2: almost non-existent! Even though this is supposed to be a state highway
column3: apparently the forest department is holding back permission for rebuilding of road due to ecological reasons as it passes through forest. But hello- somebody enlighten me
column4: what is bad for ecology and pollution and noise creation and vehicle maintenance? Number of vehicles traveling remaining same (as everybody is forced to take this road
column5: it being a state highway actually)
column6: vehicles traveling smoothly in 4th gear or vehicles forced to travel in 1st / 2nd gear for over a distance of 25 kms!

column1: Our booking was at Kali Adventure camp run by Jungle Lodge & Resorts and was for riverside facing tents.

column2: ask for tent number 3
column4: 5 as they offer best river view.

column1: The booking is on per person basis
column2: two sharing a tent which actually is a kind of permanent structure with attached bathroom. Gives you fairly an adventurous atmosphere without sacrificing the comforts we city people are accustomed to!
lunch
column3: dinner)
column4: 2 hours jungle safari (choice between morning 5.30 am and evening 4 pm safaris)
column5: coracle (round traditional boat) ride

column2: Dandeli

column1: in river. The food is on buffet basis and quality is Ok. The evening fish curry made from freshly caught Katla fish from the river was excellent with high local spicy tang.

People mainly go to Dandeli for river rafting. A 9 km rafting is provided in the river Kali and the rapids are not very “rapids” means everybody can do it. Apparently they are not even as strong as Kolad near Mumbai (though Dandeli is definitely more scenic)
column2: forget the north Indian Himalayan river rapids.

column1: Tip – As the river water flow is controlled by hydroelectric Dam nearby
column2: best season to enjoy would be just after monsoons when river would be naturally gushing through. At other times
column3: specially summer times
column4: you are at the mercy of the dam (no pun intended) people. So the moment you land at your Dandeli hotel
column5: first check for Water flow and immediately book
column6: don’t wait for next day. Who knows next day no water might be released from the dam to the river and thus no river rafting!

column2: there was a good water flow and thus we had a quick lunch and headed straight for
Dandeli

column1: rafting. The total time involved is about 3 and half hours as the rafting starts from a place called Ganeshguddi
column2: about 20 odd kms away inside forest. Rafting charges are not included in the hotel package and currently the rate is Rs 1300 per person. The hotel arranges for the tour including pick up and drop in a jeep to the rafting point.

column1: The rafting experience begins first with a lecture on safety precautions to be taken in case of emergency (yes
column2: accidents do happen
column3: in front of us about 4 passengers fell off another boat in the 9th rapid
column4: nobody was hurt). One is provided with a helmet and life jacket (so knowing swimming is not a requirement for rafting!). Jeans
column5: heavy clothing are not allowed as when wet
column6: they tend to drag you down if you fall in water. Best is half pants and Tshirt.

column1: The boat navigator is an experienced person (ours was an imported one all the way from Nepal) and guides you well. About 8 – 10 people are in a boat and first thing after reaching mid river is an order to jump into the river! This is mainly to drive away
fear of water from those who don’t know swimming. Your life jacket allows you to stay afloat
column2: so go ahead without fear and jump. Also another staff is always there in a kayak alongside ready to help anybody requiring help.

column1: Swimming in a flowing mid river is definitely a high adrenalin stuff. More so when the your guide quietly informs everyone that there are crocodiles in the river! No joke
column2: we actually saw two
column3: quietly basking on one of the river small islands. Apparently the crocodiles are satisfied with whatever fish they get in the river to bother any human beings sloshing around in the water. No human has ever been bitten / eaten by any crocodile in this river as per the locals.

column1: So after some swimming around in the river
column2: you are pulled back in the boat by the guide (pulling back in the boat is an art by itself
column3: try pulling a guy weighing upwards of 80 kgs
column4: straight out of water in a boat) and now its showtime
column5: the rafting is about to begin.

column1: First the guide asks all the rowers to pool together their paddles and do a high five with

column2: Dandeli

column1: them and asks them to shout out “Jack Ali”! Faithfully everybody shouts out Jack Ali. Jack Ali? Did I hear it right
column2: was it some kind of national integration programme involving people from different religions? I couldn’t resist and asked him again to speak it out slowly and now he says “Jai Kali”
column3: the river is kali river and by saying it you are paying your respects to the river to protect you. So from where this Jack Ali thing has come? Well
column4: it is just pronounced that way for the benefit of the foreigners!

column1: There are total of 9 rapids in the stretch
column2: the first and last are best
column3: the in betweens are rather tame once you have experienced the very first one. There is an “onboard” professional photographer who frequently gets down on river islands to take your snaps in action. Charges Rs 500 for it
column4: worth it
column5: go for it as you yourself are in no position to take your own photos while rafting.

column1: Its late evening by the time you come back to the resort but a nice surprise awaits you there
column2: campfire accompanied by unlimited hot pakoras and chicken tandoori barbqued right

column1: in front of you (part of the package
column2: no extra charge
column3: tho that does spoil your dinner lit bit later on) . Bring your own bottles if you want to enjoy more (offitially not allowed but everybody had brought one and kept hidden in paper bags!). There is a reasonably priced bar but it offers very limited range
column4: even Bacardi was not available.

column1: Woken up by staff at 5 for morning for jungle safari drive.
Tip :- If river water flow is not constraint
column2: do rafting in morning and jungle safari in afternoon as morning jungle safari was too foggy when we went. Jungle being absolutely thick
column3: you could hardly see deep inside or get the apparently excellent view of mountain valley side.

column1: Morning air was quite chilly and cold even though it was start of summer
column2: so if you are going in monsoons or winter
column3: be prepared with heavy woolens.

column1: There are apparently about 50 odd black leapords in Dandeli apart from tigers
column2: but as always you need all the luck on your side to spot any of them. We had to be content only with their foot prints but we did
jackal
column3: deers
column4: snakes and variety of exotic jungle birds.

column2: had a nice breakfast and headed for river in front for a Coracle ride. Coracle
column3: a round traditional boat made from bamboo is supposed to be so sturdy that it can carry 8 people and in villages it is used to carry even motorcycles across .

column1: The boatman takes you around for about half hour ride to a nearby river island where crocodiles come for basking. If you are brave enough
column2: he will help you to actually get down on the island for a photo opportunity (we did).

column1: We had booked only for one day
column2: it was time for us to check out . It might be a good idea to actually stay for two days
column3: one day for pure relaxation. However two things
column4: the resort is not in deep jungle as one expects it to be and second it is bit overpriced for the kind of facility and food offered (Rs 2
column5: 950 per person per day for tent accomodation). However the staff is very friendly and helpful. The counter got us extremely reasonable priced excellent taxi for further 5 days trip.

column1: Tip : You can get very cheap rates at Kulgi forest camp (Rs 400 per night) but it is actually nowhere deep in the forest
column2: so unless you have your own vehicle
column3: it may not be right choice plus apparently it requires advance reservation from Forest department which till last moment we couldn’t get (or didn’t know how to get all the way from Mumbai). Also not sure whether rafting and jungle safari can be organized from there
column4: your own vehicles are not allowed inside the jungle.

column1: Checked out around 11 as we had a long planned road journey. The plan was to go to Sirsi
column2: Yana and stay for the night at Jog Falls. Got a good rate from the resort for a Ford Toofan ( a 10 seater)
column3: very spacious and comfortable vehicle
column4: the guy charged us only Rs 7.50 per km
column5: not aircoditioned
column6: (minimum 300 kms a day) plus Rs 100 per night driver allowance
column7: a steal for us when compared with rates for other vehicles. We booked it for next 5 days.

column2: about 80 odd kms from Dandeli. About 15 kms before Sirsi is Sahstralinga. As the name
there are hundreds of big and small shiv lingas carved on boulders in a river bed.

column1: The story goes that few hundred years back
column2: local king Nayakan 1 did not have son
column3: heir to his throne. The court astrologer told him to do shiva puja by constructing 1001 shiv lingas. Hence the river bed is filled with them (sahsra is thousand)
column4: though now the big ones have got broken off over the years maybe due to flowing debris in flooded river during monsoon. So if you want to see them
column5: monsoon may not be a good time as they would be submerged in high river water level. Be prepared to wade through the river to see them and huge carved bulls alongside.

column1: It is not known whether all this construction of shiv lingas cured the problem in the king’s linga and he getting his much desired heir. But definitely worth a visit . Right side of the car park
column2: a path goes to a hanging bridge from which you can watch the river flow by below.
we proceeded to Yana
column3: another 60 odd kms.

column1: Tip :-Road to Yana goes through absolutely thick impenetrable

column2: most of it totally isolate except for one or two villages in between. So plan yourself such a way that you must reach there latest by 3 pm so that you can head out back to civilization by 5 - 6 pm
column3: i.e. before sun goes down.

column1: Yana is nature’s wonder. Huge towering rock structures
column2: apparently carved due to impact of flowing rainwater over them over millions of years. From car parking
column3: you have to walk down for about a km and half in a forest path and suddenly it opens in front of you.

column1: There is a 800 year old shiva temple inside a cave below one of the rock structure. The cave has running water from a stream bringing water deep inside from mountain. Apparently regardless of whether it is summer or heavy monsoon
column2: the water flow remains constant and volume doesn’t ever change.
you can go round through a natural opening in the rock structure. For climbing up
column3: proper staircase have been made but for coming down
column4: its still rough path
column5: So not advisable for elderly people. But for others
column6: definitely worth a visit. Religious people go around taking

column2: Hampi

column1: it as a pradikshna (going around) the temple. You are not allowed to wear footwear so be ready to get some painful jabs from stones. But don’t miss it for such flimsy reasons. As I said
column2: it’s a nature wonder. Going up and back down again takes about 20 odd minutes for young fast people though we took almost an hour enjoying the rock structure inside.

column1: Back to civilization but at Sirsi we were informed that going to Jog falls (highest waterfall of India?) would be futile as the water flow is controlled by dam on top and as per the local person
column2: at this time of the year (March) and till monsoon
column3: a cow pees more water than the water flowing in the falls. So we decided to drop Jog falls and head for Hubli for the night stay.

column1: This meant long drive of about 125 kms and we reached Hubli at about 9 pm
column2: dead tired. Nothing to see or do in Hubli
column3: only a night halt against our earlier planned night halt at Jog water falls.

column1: Started from Hubli and went to Hampi (110 kms)
column2: the glorius capital of Vijaynagara empire
column3: now

column2: Hampi

column1: Hampi is in two parts with Tungabhadra river flowing through in between. Modernisation has taken its toll and now the nostalgic coracle boat ride across is replaced by motor boat. While all the main ruins are on the side of Hampi village
column2: the other side
column3: actually an island in the river
column4: offers wonderful staying facilities.

column1: We decided to go across and stay at the island
column2: planned it as a rest day.

column1: Tip : The boat to Hampi island stops at 6 pm and there is nothing available for crossing the river after that
column2: so be planned and careful. There is alternative road 35 kms long to reach the island from Hampi village while the boat crossing hardly takes 10 minutes
column3: so makes sense to park your vehicle on this side and take the boat across if you want to stay on the island or visit the sites on other side. The other side had lines of back packer resorts one after another
column4: all targeted at firang backpacker crowd. We enquired at few places and finally settled at Mowgli Resort. What a good decision that turned out to be. It offers river facing hut

column2: neat and clean
column3: food was great. There are khatiyas (wood and coir beds) and swings in front of each hut and you could just laze through on them whole day. Even the dining area offers a separate floor sitting area under the trees and lined with cushions where you can have old Indian style floor sitting lunch / dinner. And all this is very reasonable priced (Rs 600 for a river facing hut having a double bed and attached bathroom)
column4: the room rates were much lower than next door resorts offering same kind of stuff. Though apparently season time (Oct – Feb) rates go upto Rs 2000 per hut.

column1: Tip – Hampi off season is from April – August
column2: actually some of the hotels close down during these months simply because the temperature crosses 45* C and since all the sites are in open
column3: you would be spending whole day out in blazing sun.

column1: Best is to go at March end or Aug-Sept
column2: i.e just before or just after offseason so that you get best of the rates
column3: atmosphere has improved and avoid the season crowd.

column1: Late afternoon we tied up with a
rickshaw to go around the island side. The standard rickshaw charges for a 3 hour ride around is Rs 350 – 400 and for a Tata Magic Rs 650 .
Tip – Don’t bother to take this ride
column2: compared to what is offered on main Hampi side
column3: this side has hardly anything worth seeing except for two things
column4: both of which you can actually walk through if you love long walks.

column1: The first thing is for the religious minded
column2: Pampa sarovar
column3: this lake finds its mention in old hindu mythology. Apparently this was where Ram came during his long 14 year old vanvas and met Shabri (the one who offered berries to him). His footprints are still there in the temple there. The name Pampa later became Hampa and then Hampi
column4: the modern name of the place. The lake is full of brilliant white lotus flowers.

column1: The second thing is for both religious as well as normal tourist
column2: Angini mountain. For normal tourist
column3: climb up this mountain is must as top offers a fantastic view of entire Hampi. Absolute must for everyone to watch sunset from there. On top
column4: there is kind of flat

column1: top and you can sit on any of the big boulders to watch the sunset. Any day
column2: there would be scores of people up there for it (mainly whites
column3: don’t know why there was no Indian except us). There are about 600 odd steps (properly made) to climb up
column4: takes about 30 - 45 minutes to climb up.

column1: Now for the religious people and the answer to why 600 odd proper steps have been made to reach top. On top is a Hanuman temple
column2: its birth place of Hanuman! This is where his mother Angini met his father Vayu. And from there the name
column3: Angini Parbat.

column1: After watching the sunset and visit to the temple
column2: climb down and back to the resort for a well deserved round of drinks and wonderful dinner
column3: unfortunately the resort has only a beer license!

column1: Cross over to main Hampi by boat and have a guide for full day. If you really want to see and understand Hampi
column2: a full day guide is must. Depending on who they think you are
column3: the asking rates differ between Rs 800 and 2000. One fellow asked for Rs 1500 and refused to bargain

column2: Hampi

column1: even at the cost of loosing us! Finally we found another (good one ) for Rs 800 (go to tourist information office for it
column2: just opposite main car park).

column1: Hampi was definitely one of the golden days of India
column2: after Chandragupta and Ashoka empires. To see it fully
column3: atleast 2 to 3 days are required but we settled for one and half days. The ruins tell the stories of how rich
column4: culturally / artistically / financially India was in those days.

column1: Vijayanagara empire lasted about 200 odd years from 1450 to 1650 AD and Hampi got built over this time
column2: massive temples
column3: palaces
column4: markets. They had gold and precious stones market 700 meteres long in front of the main temple
column5: the makets attracted business people from Iran
column6: Greece
column7: Arabia
column8: Chinese
column9: not forgetting the Europeans. Each of these nationalities have been carved in their exact details on the temple walls showing some business dealings (like horse buying etc)

column2: even during those days pin camera concept was there and you can see it inside the main temple where the inverted image of 20 storied high gopuram (temple tower) is seen on a
Hampi
with zero degree correctly marked (point where image inverts). On the roof there are 3 D carvings of various mythological stories. These are painted with paint still retained.

column1: The other main temple constructed was Vithala Temple
column2: a huge complex about 12 kms away
column3: you are taken inside by battery operated vehicle (to avoid pollution damage to sites) run by ladies only (all employed under Rural Employment generation Scheme of governement). This temple was constructed when Vithala Statue was brought over from Pandharpur (about 800 kms away) when Pandharpur was attacked by muslim rulers of Bijapur. Apparently after bringing over the statue
column4: the king found success in whatever he did and as gratitude
column5: built this massive complex. It has a stone chariot whose wheels still run
column6: though now they have been glued to floor as people did nothing but keep revolving this!

column1: Whole temple is built on Vaastu shastra concept and your guide (if he is good and knowing) will explain you those concept and once you see it
column2: you understand why the Vaastu shastra principles are what they are.

column1: The temple has both south Indian and north Indian temple styles signifying the vastness of empire

column2: Hampi Vithala Temple

column1: of vijaynagara empire. It has even a sun temple style konarka
column2: Orissa way.

column1: Main attraction of this temple was sangeet mahal
column2: a 57 pillared structure. Each of these pillar (about 2 storied high) was made from a single stone and carved in such a way
column3: that a musican could actually use his hand to play a particular musical instrument on it. Means when he tapped his fingers on it a particular way
column4: it would emit sound of that particular instrument like tamboora
column5: tabla
column6: pakhawaj etc. Apparently those days
column7: no actually musical instrument was used in the temple
column8: the whole music was generated by these pillars only. Its not allowed now to be shown at Sangeet mahal pillars (whatever remaining there are)
column9: but your guide will show (play) the music at a smaller adjoining hall with smaller pillars.

column1: There are carvings which are kind 2 in 1 and 5 in 1 etc
column2: means same carving when you see from different angle seem different. So two in one is like elephant from one angle and bull from other angle. The guide covers different parts of the carving one by one to show the different kind
Hampi

column1: thing worth seeing in Hampi are ofcourse the 20 - 30 odd high feet two huge gansha statues (much damaged) and narsimha statue (sort of reassembled now)
column2: they are really huge and made from one single block
column3: one wonders at the carvers imagination and skill to carve out these gigantic structures.with minutest details. One of the ganesha statues when looked from front is pot bellied ganesha
column4: but from behind looks like a lady sitting with her back
column5: the hair style
column6: curve of waist unmistakable. The explanation apparently is that from back it is supposed to be goddes parvati having her son ganpati sitting on her lap in the front.

column1: The other palace worth seeing is the queens palace which was the palace for queens when their husbands would go out for long drawn battles etc. It has a natural airconditioned palace where water used to get dropped at the top of the third floor and then flowed down all around bringing in the coolness inside. There is an elephant area outside capable of holding 11 royal elephants
column2: one dome for each elephant and each dome has got a different architecture and design.
the king

column1: fell in love with his court dancer and on her advice
column2: appointed her brother to a high court position. The dancer and her brother were actually spies for muslim rulers of Bijapur and over next few months
column3: collected all the vital military secrets of Hampi.

column2: Hampi was attacked by Bijapur around 1650 AD and over a period of six months
column3: they systematically destroyed everything that was there. To blow up the sangeet mahal
column4: they brought entire Gold market wood in front and piled up the wood in the center of the mahal and lighted it up. The extreme heat generated was the only way the stone structure could be broken. And now only few pillars remain
column5: the main structure gone
column6: all blown up.

column1: Similarly all the other structures of Hampi were destroyed
column2: palaces
column3: 18 – 20 foot tall well carved stautes (Ganesha
column4: Narsimha
column5: Vithalla)
column6: all in name of religion as this was deemed against the requirement of muslim religion. About 67 temples were looted and destroyed. Total of 600
column7: 000 people were massacred during this period. Only about 30% of original Hampi remains now
column8: but even this 30% shows how grand the city must have

column1: We saw a repetition of this recently when 2000 years old Banyam Buddha in Afganistan was blown up using canons by Taliban. So much hatred
column2: so much destruction towards something which one feels is not as per his religious belief
column3: what a loss of art and creativity. Certainly this is not what any religion really says.

column2: Hampi lay forgotten for next 200 years till late 19th century when one of the British Geographer stumbled on the ruins. Seeing whatever was visible
column3: he got so impressed that he got in touch with Royal Geographical Society
column4: London and asked them to send their best photographer who came over all the way and photographed entire Hampi and sent the photos to London. Based on those photos
column5: British governement declared it as a heritage site and so it is actually thanks to British that Hampi was revived again. The exploration still continues as much of Hampi apparently still is buried in sand. Apparently come monsoon
column6: the villagers go treasure hunting as water flow invariably brings up some or other treasures buried.

column2: 110 odd kms away. Actually
three tourist places within 20 odd kms of each other (Pattadakal
column3: Badami and Aihole)
column4: Each of these have stone temple structures prior to Hampi days.

column1: Badami was first when independent structures were yet to come and temples were carved out in mountains (5th Century AD). So it has 4 caves
column2: one for Jain
column3: one for shiva
column4: one for Vishnu and one normal. The third cave is the main and biggest one and the carvings are absolutely brilliant
column5: huge statues carved in the mountain side.

column1: Pattadakal was next in line of construction when individual standing temples started getting built. Unfortunatley again
column2: the muslim invasion destroyed most of temples and the stautes inside but a huge bull made of granite still survives showing the carving capability of the carvers during those days who had the capability to carve the hardest known stone to mankind.

column1: Stayed at Badami just opposite bus stand.

Tip : The Karnataka tourism hotel is way out of the place and not worth staying. It seemed like a ghost hotel where everything was locked up. Good food availability in Badami seems to be a big problem. Even

column2: Badami

column1: ordinary sada dosa seemed to be a big problem there from taste point of view.

column2: on the way took a halt at Kudala Sangama where two rivers merge and there is a shiva temple middle of the merged river bed! Now they have made a huge round tower (about 5 odd storied high) around the temple. You cross a bridge over the river bed to reach this tower and then climb down inside the tower to reach the temple
column3: as normally there would be river water all around outside it. Wonder in old days
column4: how this temple was built and how they reached it.

column2: the marvel of Islamic architecture
column3: Gol Gumbaj is the main attraction and is the largest free standing dome in the world (tho now the claim for the same is being made by Vipassana pagoda built in 2008 at Gorai
column4: Mumbai)
column5: built in 17th century
column6: it is HUGE and one really has to appreciate the architect who designed it.. Must be more than 15 storied high.

column1: It has got graves of the ruler with his wives and kids and very interestingly his

column2: Aihole

column1: hindu court dancer aptly named “Rambha”. The dynasty destroyed Hampi and its temples as it was deemed unislamic
column2: then how did the king enjoy hindu classical dance (music and dance are unislamic as per some interpretations) and also so loved the court dancer that she was buried with him? Also the muslim religion forbids building of huge remembrance structures over dead
column3: but we see this rule being totally forgotten by most of our muslim rulers. (both Gol Gumbaj and Ibrahim Rosa at Bijapur are actually mausoleums)

column2: gol gumbaj speaks of how advanced the muslim technology was when it came to architecture. You climb up the top through a narrow staircase and reach whispering gallery. Here if you whisper in a wall at one end
column3: the person exactly diagonally opposite with his ear to the wall
column4: will clearly hear it though the distance in between is as big as a football field and is totally empty. Unfortunately the crowd instead of whispering
column5: shouts and howls
column6: thinking the echo is the wonder
column7: not realizing that true wonder is the whisper. It was one of the guards who showed us actually how it works ( a small payment to him

column1: Climbing down the river bed to reach the temple
for the service worked for us).

column2: the memorial built for yet another ruler and has his and his family graves
column3: good Islamic carvings and a palace of arches.

column1: There is also a 55 ton canon called Malik a Maidan (ruler of battlefield) on one of the hillocks. It was the largest and heaviest built at that time to defent bijapur and was actually given as part of dowry when the queen got married. British tried to take it to London (just like everything else they could of india’s golden history). Luckily it was so heavy that the crane which was specially brought to lift it up from its place broke and thus the operation had to be abandoned. And thus the canon now lies little bit below from its original place where it fell after the crane broke.

The canon’s roar was supposed to be so loud that there was a specially built underground pit next to it. It was filled with water and the canon firing staff had 12 seconds after lighting the ignition to jump in this pit and stay inside the water. This was to protect their eardrums from

column2: Bijapur

column1: Unfortunately or fortunately the canon was never used in an actual war and rather than Malik a Maidan
column2: it remained Malik e Akhbar (ruler on paper!)

we went straight to Solapur (80 kms) to catch our night train to Mumbai. The highway is totally congested with truck traffic and takes good enough more than 3 hours against our expectation of 2 hours. So keep enough margin if you are traveling this stretch.
one gets Siddheswar Express starting at 10.45 pm and reaching Mumbai next day morning at 6.30 am
if you are traveling North Karnataka during the Ugadi (New year
column3: Gudi Padwa in Maharashtra) days (which was March 23 this year)
column4: better avoid the internal roads. This day and the next day (for 2 days) is actually celebrated as Rang (colour) panchami there and its exactly like Holi played in rest of country. Every few kilometers your vehicles will be stopped by rowdy gangs of boys carrying oil colour cans and unless you pay up (anything between Rs 10 to Rs 50 depending on crowd size and your bargaining capacity) you and your vehicle will

column2: Bijapur

column1: be painted by these oil paints which are very difficult to get rid of . And at some places
column2: inspite of us paying
column3: they still put colour on our poor driver and threw the colour on vehicle front glass and side body.

column1: That brought end to our short tour of North Karnataka
column2: a hectic but refreshing tour covering both natural as well as man-made wonders.

column1: Well now Gokarna. It was an interesting place to get to and I met some great people! The overnight 'delux' sleeper bus was supposed to be a special treat really for the journey from hampi to Gokarna. Getting to Hampi on the hard plastic chair of the standard public bus for 10hrs had not been comfortable in any way so i thought it was an investment to get a nights sleep on the trip back to the coast...

What I had not counted on was the 'delux' bus being full of cockroaches! And the part where they dumped all the people not headed to Goa (to Gokarna) in the middle of nowhere by the road at 2am to wait for an uncomfortable minibus to come collect us. Of course of the said minibus
column2: the driver was fast asleep at that hour and failed to turn up... After 2 hours of waiting and making a fuss with a local hotel owner who seemed to know the driver
column3: the hotel owner drove to the minibus driver's house to wake him up. So we were on the road again. With a whole lot of new mozzy bites.

column1: We got to Gokarna and then had the task of making it to the final destination: Om beach. Although it went against every mental calculation I made we actually managed to fit 6 women (and all their rucksacks and daysacks) onto 1 auto-rickshaw for the journey. Sure we were sitting on top of eachother and the girl sitting with the driver had to get out and push it to make it start going but eventually te tuk tuk moved! And it made it all the way (at about 5 miles an hour!). We got there about an hour before sunrise and we sat on Om beach watching it go up before finding a place to stay. Had an early morning swim too
column2: was brilliant.

column1: Then spent two whole days on Om beach
column2: which is pretty deserted
column3: just enjoying the company of the girls we met on the bus
column4: playing cards
column5: drinking beer and all-round chilling out. Was great.

column1: On the second day we did have a bit of a scare. Swimming in the sea
column2: me and a Brazilian woman I met
column3: Carolina
column4: were discussing our childhood fear of sharks after watching Jaws (ok for me this fear is still quite real!). We were the only people in the water and suddenly we notice we are being frantically waved back to shore by this policeman. PANIC set in- we both grabbed eachother expecting to see a shark fin circling us! Actually the truth was worse
column5: when we (suprisingly shortly!) got to shore he told us we should get out of the water because there might be a tsunami! Apparently there had been some bad earthquakes in Indonesia and the whole coast was preparing for a possible tsunami. Crazy. We slept so so well after that...!

column1: Cheri's driving ""gloves"" (thank you united 1st class for those free socks)

column2: but had to split the journey into 2 days due to significant traffic in Bangalore (yes

column1: Trucks loved to get really close

column1: first place we stopped was a tea shop on the Chickmagalur-Kemmangudi road. After a long time I rediscovered the taste of 'Masala Buns' which was special in the coastal Karnataka region. After driving for another 30 minutes or so we stopped at 'The Deviramma Temple'. The place so serene as if the clock forgot to move ahead with time. Gaurav was enjoying so far as his silence said so. The temple was closed as it was around 7am. I was clicking around and was in love with this place literally. But we had a long road to hit
column2: so unwillingly we both jumped in to the car and Mr.Ravi pulled the gear. This Chickmagalur-

column2: we were enjoying the aroma of early morning brezze and Mr.Ravi was getting excited too.Mr.Sun was up meanwhile and we had to stop in between to greet him warmly.

column1: Next stop was at Kalathi falls.I was pretty excited as I saw the photos earlier and was

planning to frame my creativity too.This falls is unique of it's type. There's a small temple at the base of this falls and the stream of water flows through temple.if you would like to make a visit to the temple

column3: 'oh ! my god' was my first interaction. I did expect the stream of water would be less as it was an early summer
column4: but I was more surprised rather frustrated to see a bunch of people taking bath
column5: washing clothes
column6: creating all sort of mess possible. I didn't take chance to click a single snap as it could have been a waste of time. Even Gaurav was frustrated too. I decided to go back to the car and continue for our next destination.

column3: we settled for a jeep

Wild Stream on the way to Hebbe Falls
the money was too high for a 15km drive

We were riding on a road where 'dust and boulders' were laid out.Somehow after driving for an hour we reached a small place.Chandu suggested that we had to walk about a mile from here to reach The Hebbe falls. he also warned us to cross three wild streams through. Gaurav was fiercely excited as it seemed an adventurous walk indeed. We started walking and then we got the first stream to cross. The feeling was amazing
column5: the water was freezingly cold.The track seemed utterly confusing but as suggested by Chandu

column1: I saw a few pics of Hebbe earlier but trust me none of them could do justice to this place. It was mesmerizing. Within a few seconds I started missing my sweetheart. I really don't have words to describe the beauty of this place.May Kalathi Falls have led us to frustration but this place have compensated more
with it's stature. It was depp inside thik lush green forests

My jeans was all dirty and I had to continue with the same pair for the rest of the day. But Hebbe took us to such a height that we forgot everything and were trying 'record' as many shots as

We stopped in a place at Attigundi for lunch and managed with steaming 'Chapathis and Chicken Masala'. Next destination was 'Dutta Peeth' at Bababudangiri Hill. But the beauty of Hebbe took us to 'sweeping feet' that we reamined much of 'silent pranks'.

column1: The road from Kemmangudi to Bababudan giri as mixed bag of 'Bounty and Bumpy'. Around 3:00pm we
reached Bababudangiri and drove further to Manikyadhara view point. There was a narrow stream but due to insufficiency of water

pack your cameras

this is a private place so make sure you go and come as early as possible'

It seems some waterfalls'

column2: It was a waterfall and

Again wherever we go serenity follows us. We were just the two 'souls' to enjoy the beauty of this 'mother
Nature's' marvel. When everything goes right something turns 'the table'. My Canon 60D blinked an unhappy warning of 'low battery'. Still we had the Mullayangiri left in our list. Left with no option

column1: Next stop was at Mullayangiri hills
column2: we had plans to experience one of the most scenic sunset amongst the Malnad Hills. We reached Mullayangiri hills and climbed around 300 steps. Mullayangiri is the highest peak between The Himalayas and The

Another day was over from 'a few days' left in life.Indeed

column1: By train : Nearest rail stations are Hassan and Kadur
column2: from which Chickmagalur is 50 and 40kms respectively.A taxi would cost Rs. 1000-1200 from either of these places.

column1: By road : Distance from Chickmagalur to Bangalore via Hassan-Tumkur is 245 kms. From Mysore 178 kms. The road condition is just amazing.
By Air : Bangalore - 245 kms and Mangalore - 151 km.
Where to stay; Chikmagalur has staying options aplenty. Starting from star category hotels to the budget family ones. We stayed at Hotel Soundarya Resinency.

column2: 500/- Deluxe Double Non A/C.

column1: town Chikmagalur has all the bank ATMs
column2: Hospitals
column3: Supermarkets. So you never run out of options.

column1: Chikmagalur to Kemmangudi can be reached via two routes
Best would be to follow route 1 to reach Kemmangudi and then follow route 2 while returning. Infact that's what we did.
Hope this blog finds you in a happy note and if you have questions any
column2: please let me know.

column1: Ramdevar beta is popularly known as Ramgad as pictorised in the famous Bollywood film Sholay. The place is a paradise for trekking
column2: rock climbing and photo shooting. There are two temples on the top of the hill
column3: viz
column4: Rama temple and Rameshwar temple.

column2: is about 50 kms from Bangalore
column3: on Bangalore-Mysore highway. While coming from Mysore
column4: it is about 90 kms from Mysore. While coming from Mysore
column5: you have to cross Srirangapatna
column6: Mandya and Channapatna to reach Ramanagara. Ramangara is famous for silk market and is know as the silk town.

column1: One may go upto Ramanagar town by bus and then take an auto to Ramadevar beta. There is no facility to stay there overnight. So one has to plan the return trip on the same day.
Sri Revana Siddeshwara Betta is also located in Ramanagara District about 70 Kms Away From Bangalore City. While visiting Ramadevar beta
column2: one may plan to visit Revena Siddeshwar beta on the same day.

column1: There is another place called Kengal hanumantharaaya temple which is also near to ramanagara City. Besides Janapadaloka and Kanwa resorvoir are nearby places which may be combined on a single trip.
There are about seven hills in 10Km radius of Ramanagara
column2: viz
column3: Yatirajagiri
column4: Sidilakallu Betta Shivaramagiri
column5: Krishnagiri
column6: Somagiri
column7: Revanna Siddeshwara Betta and Jala Siddeshwara Betta
column8: Randevara Betta. All these sites offer abundant opportunities for trekking
column9: camping and exploring the wilderness of nature.

column1: What is there on Ramadevar Beta
There are quite a few granite hills around Ramanagaram
column2: which are great attractions for adventure enthusiasts. Ramadevar beta is the same place known as Ramagad in the famous Bollywood film Sholay. The famous Gabbar Sing was sitting on this hill with Samba and Kaalia.

column1: While entering in to the area
column2: you will find a nice Arch welcoming you to the hills. There are plenty of places to climb and explore on both the sides of the road. Before reaching Ramadevar beta
column3: you will see a Lotus Pond on the left. The pond is full of beautiful lotus. You may find children selling lotus there.

column1: After seeing lotus pond and trekking nearby hill you may like to proceed further towards Ramadevar hill. The vehicle can go up to this place
column2: the foot of ramadevar hill. You have to park your vehicle here and take the stairs to climb to the top of the hill.

column1: From this entrance to the hill
column2: you have to start climbing. You have to climb a total of around 300 steps. The route is in the middle of the forest and is quite exciting. While climbing the hill after 250 steps you will come across a Hanuman temple on the way.

column1: Climbing is very exciting as because the stairs are very neat and clean amongst the dense forests and hills all around. This trekking is less risky and can be taken up by women
column2: children provided you have enough strength to go up.

column1: After climbing for about half an hour to one hour you will find Ramadevara temple on the top of the hill. The hill is famous because of this temple. The temple is more than 1000 years old as people say. Some people believe that Lord Rama had visited this place. From near the temple you can have a good view of the hills and places around.

column2: there is a natural pond on the hilltop
column3: called Rama Tirtha. It is interesting to see water at such a height. However
column4: the place is fenced and people are not allowed to go down to water for safety.

column1: There is another temple called Rameshwar Temple about 30 meters away from Ramadevar Temple. You have to climb up a little to reach that temple. The pond Rama Tirtha is in between these two temples.
Near the temples on the top
column2: there is a small tower. You can have a nice view of the hills from this place. The hills are 60 to 100 feet in height and very steep. Many professional rock climbers climb on these cliffs with equipments and proper safety measures. Many adventure groups come here for face climbing
column3: boulder climbing
column4: chimney climbing
column5: hill climbing
column6: rock climbing etc.

column1: Ramadevara beta has something for everyone of every age group. All the shooting points of Sholay are still there. You can see beautiful rocks and nature around. The religious people can visit the temples. Besides this is an awesome place for shooting pictures.
You should have sufficient time to move around the hills. The real pleasure is to climb and see. If you are lack of time
column2: you cannot enjoy much.

column1: Ramadevar beta and Siddheswhar beta are different
column2: about 20 kms apart from each other. Some bloggers confuse between them and mix up the photos of Ramadevar beta with Siddheshwar beta.

column1: Some bloggers mention Ramadevar beta as Randevar beta
column2: both are same.

column1: There are two temples on Ramadevar beta
column2: one Rama temple and other Rameshwar temple. Besides there is a hanuman temple on the way while climbing.

drive towards south till you reach Kanakapura road (you may take busy shortcut routes or long ring roads depending upon your location in Bangalore.). Now move on Kanakpura Road – the National Highway 209 – towards Kanakpura. After a few kms you will cross NICE ring road. Then after about 18 kms you will find a sign board to take a left turn for Buddha Pyramid.

column1: Note: if you miss the road to pyramid valley then you will reach Horahalli
column2: about 4 kms ahead. In that case you have to return back again.

column1: From Kanakpura road diversion the road is rather easy. You just have to continue for about 2 kms on Kebbedoddi Village / Pyraimid Valley road. The road is good and motorable.

Maitreya-Buddha Pyramid is world’s largest meditational pyramid. The size of the pyramid is 160ft. x 160ft. Height 102 ft (equivalent to 10 floor building). The pyramid was built in 2006. The capacity of the pyramid is to accommodate 5000 people for meditation.
There is accommodation available for halting in nights
column2: ranging from dormitories to VIP suites. The valley is spread over 26 acres of land.

column1: The energy in this Mega-Pyramid is amplified by over 640 natural Himalayan crystals fitted inside the hall. (Source: Pyramid Valley Brochure).
This Pyramid Valley has been selected as one of the 7 wonders of Bangalore
column2: survey conducted by Bangalore Mirror (published by the Times of India group).

column1: The Maitreya Pyramid is open 18 hours a day from morning till night. Buddha Poornima is the most auspicious day celebrated here. There is large gathering on the day with Aakhanda Dhyana (continuous meditation).
We were impressed to see the free services provided by the pyramid management. While in many other places you have to pay for everything
column2: pyramid valley provides many facilities for free.

column1: They give brochures and leaflets when you enter the valley as a token of greetings.
There is no vehicle parking fee in side the pyramid campus.
There is no money collection near the shoe stand.
There is no money collection for using toilets.
Free food is provided twice a day
column2: at 1 PM and 8 PM
column3: through annadana program.

column1: Free meditation classes on Sundays and many more weekly and monthly spiritual development programs.
What to see in pyramid valley
The Maitreya Buddha pyramid is the main attraction of pyramid valley.
Apart from that there is meditation teaching place
column2: an ampitheatre
column3: a research center
column4: a holistic health center
column5: tree of life
column6: bookstore
column7: tapasthal
column8: lake
column9: gardens and statues.

column1: It is believed that Meditations done inside a Pyramid is three times more powerful. Many people experience great relaxations after meditating in pyramid. All are welcome (rather encouraged) to do meditation inside the pyramid. We also did meditation for half an hour inside the pyramid.

At the center of the pyramid there is an erected spot called King Chamber. This is about 34 ft tall and can accommodate about 30 people to sit and meditate. But it is said that the meditation done on this pedestal structure is even more powerful. However
column2: this place is slightly hotter than the floor level because of its height. After meditating on kings chamber for some time we preferred to meditate on the floor which was much more spacious.

column1: (Kings chamber inside pyramid. Photo courtesy: http://www.pyramidvalley.org)

The entrance halls at the base of the pyramid has many statues of Buddha and scripts of Buddha’s teaching. There are portraits of Brahmarshi Partriji who founded the pyramid valley. Photography is not allowed in this area and inside pyramid. Children below 6 years are not allowed inside the pyramid as they might create noise inside.
There are many more activities inside pyramid related to meditation and spiritual development. Some programs are weekly and some monthly. For details please refer to their site www.pyramidvalleyorg.
You are not allowed to carry your food to do picnic in Pyramid valley. However
column2: you get free food twice a day there.

column1: Besides there is a cafeteria where you can buy foods of your choice. We took some idli
column2: bada
column3: fried rice etc. inside the cafetaria. It was good.

column1: The cafeteria is open since 6.30 in the morning till 7.30 in the evening.

The overall experience of Pyramid valley was excellent. The area is quite large and is enough to keep you busy walking and exploring various small items. You can walk near the lakes and gardens and enjoys statues here and there. The place is a must see for everybody staying in Bangalore and nearby.

You can follow any route to catch Bangalore Kanakapura main road – which is the National Highway 209. Go straight on the highway towards Kanakapura. After a few Kms you will cross NICE ring road. Go further on the highway. You will find “Art of Living” head quarter after 15 kms. Go further about 3 Kms
column2: you will find a place called Kagalpura. Take a left turn from Kagalpura.

go straight for about 1.5 kms till you find a hospital (?) / rehabilitation center where you have to take a left turn again. Better ask the locals otherwise you are very likely to miss this road as there is no proper landmark to explain. However
column3: if you miss this road and go straight you will still reach the other side of TK falls through CRPF camp. But this road is longer and extremely rough for driving.

column1: After turning left you have to drive 3 kms more to reach the fall
column2: In some places you can see the river on the right side of the road. I had a fear that the road could be bad as many bloggers mention their experience. But luckily the road condition was good till we reached the fall.

column1: There is a temple called “Muneswar Temple” at the entrance to the fall. A small temple under a big tree. The place is peaceful.

Then you have to trek further in to the forest and rocks. Trekking is interesting but tiring too. One should better carry some food and drinking water for emergency. While going down to the water we came across a beautiful spot. A stone painted as forest god and some traditional art – jhoti- near it.
The rocks inside water look very attractive. They are interesting to climb. However
column2: many of them are steep
column3: smooth and slippery. One has to be very careful while climbing.

column1: It was extremely hot and climbing too much was very tiring. We finished three bottles of water that we carried. Although there was no water in the fall
column2: the place was still enjoyable. It can be said to be a good picnic spot.

column1: We spent about 2 hours in the place and then proceeded for Pyramid Valley
column2: which is on the same Kanakapura road about 15 kms from TK falls.

Agara is in the south east side of Bangalore city. There is a rarely visited lake in Agara known as Agara lake. Agara area has been very well developed during recent years. There are quite a few temples in Agara
column2: two of them are notable
column3: one
column4: the Jagannath Temple and the other Hanuman temple. Both of them are build during recent years. The temple is actually small but the statue is extremely large. The 102 feet Gigantic statue of Lord hanuman is standing on a lotus pedestal.

column1: The statue is on the road side and visible from quite a distance. Although the temple opens in the morning and evening
column2: there is no timing for seeing the statue as it is always visible from any side. The statue is east facing
column3: so if you go in the morning the face of the statue will be lighted. In the afternoon the backside of the statue will be lighted.

column1: The temple is popular among the local residents from Agara
column2: Madivala and HSR layout area
column3: and is visited by hundreds of visitors every day. But many more just have darshan from the road pay their homage while passing by the road. There are also idols of Naga Devata under the peepal tree.

column1: There is one beautiful temple in front of the Hanuman statue – known as “Sita Rama Bhakta Hanumanta Temple” (picture below).
There is also another temple - Anjaneya Temple - behind the statue (picture below). The backside of the Gigantic Hanuman statue is visible from this place.
Don't forget to visit the Jagannath temple when you are going towards that side. The Jagannath temple is located next to the Hanuman temple
column2: on the other side of the road
column3: prominently visible from each other. The Jagannath temple is built recently and is quite popular in that area.

column1: You can read this article on freejournal at http://freejournal.heliohost.org/freejournal/?/articles/2012/03/24/agara-hanuman-temple-bangalore.html

column1: It doesn't seem like five minutes ago I was writing about Nepal and now it's time to give you the latest on our trip round India! Since Lewys' has already written his blog and told some of the funnier anecdotes I'll do my best to make this interesting...

column2: where do I start? Even as I'm writing I know how impossible it's going to be to describe our first two weeks in this amazing country. I had read about it
column3: I had seen pictures and I'd spoken to people who have visited
column4: but nothing can prepare you for actually being here.

column1: Delhi hits you like a ton of bricks. We thought Kathmandu was crazy but nothing compared to the mayhem that is Delhi. The city is just huge and and there are more people that you could possibly imagine - think rush hour in London
column2: only with a lot more people
column3: more noise
column4: more filth
column5: more traffic and more cows. Now imagine that as you walk down the street
column6: dodging piles of rubbish
column7: speeding motorbikes and wandering cattle
column8: you are also the centre of attention. Every person stares at you when you walk past
column9: asks you if you need a tuk-tuk
column10: a sari
column11: a USB stick or a pair of sunglasses (even though you are wearing sunglasses). ""Hello my friend...come into my shop"" echoes down the street and rickshaws crawl along beside you just in case after saying no five times you miraculously change your mind.

column1: Every day in India has been an 'experience'. Every day throws up new challenges to test your patience
column2: your level of tolerance is constantly pushed to the limit and your ability to cope with new situations is challenged. The stark contrast between the very rich and the impossibly poor is in evidence everywhere and poverty rears its ugly head wherever you go. Unlike Nepal
column3: where there isn't such a wealthy elite
column4: in India there is a clear divide between the haves and have-nots
column5: which is hard to reconcile.India has also been fascinating. The places we have seen have been unforgettable
column6: steeped in the history and the past grandeur of empires. The mighty subcontinent is vast and so far we have only seen a small part of it.

column1: Our first full day in Delhi
column2: still slightly shell-shocked
column3: we wandered down Chandi Chouk
column4: the main bazaar in Old Delhi. This huge street
column5: lined with sari shops and spice sellers
column6: leads up the majestic Red Fort - once the seat of the Mughal Empire. The guide book describes the fort as a ""sandstone carcass of its former self""
column7: but I thought the crumbling ruins gave a fitting glimpse into the decadence that once had its home here. We also saw the Jama Masjid Mosque
column8: which offers a relatively peaceful oasis in the middle of the crazy and crowded old city.

column1: After a day in the capital we started our whistlestop tour of Rajasthan - the desert state. The first stop was Agra (actually in Uttar Pradesh but near to Rajasthan). It turned out to be more difficult than we thought to get to (see Lewys' blog for full details of us turning up a month early for our train and a pigeon using my head as a toilet). Agra itself isn't much to look at but the main attraction
column2: the Taj Mahal
column3: doesn't disappoint. With its perfect goemetric shape and flawless white marble walls that shimmer in the dawn sunlight it looks unreal
column4: almost etherial. It manages to balance perfect simplicity with the most elaborate detail and is far more beautiful than I had imagined. Another
column5: more unexpected delight in Agra was the impressive fort
column6: which sits along the banks of the Yamuna River. Apart from the small Indian man of about 40 who asked if Lewys was my husband and tried to take pictures of me
column7: twice
column8: it was a beautiful place to spend the afternoon.

column1: En route from Agra to Jaipur we stopped for a night in Fatehpur Sikri
column2: a small town with an historic fort (yep
column3: another fort!). We got quite a bit of hassle here
column4: mostly from young guys who claimed they weren't guides but 'students' wanting to give a free tour to practice their English - a likely story! The highlight was sitting in the magnificent mosque and watching the sun set.

column1: Jaipur was not my favourite place. We were pestered a lot by tuk-tuk drivers and I was stared at constantly by Indian men because of my blonde hair and fair skin - I think we both found it pretty difficult to deal with sometimes. We visited the City Palace
column2: which was ok but compared with the simple elegance of the Taj Mahal it seemed gaudy and over the top to me. Climbing the 'Heaven Piercing Minaret'
column3: however
column4: gave us a spectacular view over the city. It was originally built so that the ladies of the court could watch the happenings of the city below
column5: and it still offers an amazing vista of the pink city.

column2: the pretty blue city which nestles below the imposing Mehrangarh Fort (that's 4 and counting). Jodhpur was much smaller and therefore more manageable than the other cities we had visited. The colourful bazaar that surrounds the clocktower and main square was a great place to wander around and haggle over silk scarves (Lewys was less interested in this
column3: not sure why..). The fort itself was also my favourite out of the many we saw in Rajathan because it was really well-maintained and there was a free audio-tour
column4: which was really interesting (yes
column5: I'm that cool). We ended up spending a few days longer in Jodhpur than we'd planned because Lewys was ill
column6: but it meant we could see the crazy Holi festival there. People have bonfires and throw colored powder and water over eachother - we got a soaking from some kids who threw a bucket of water over us from their balcony
column7: then they pulled faces and ran away!

column1: Our last city to see in Rajasthan was Jaisalmer
column2: a fort town that was even smaller again and on the edge of the Thar Desert. There we did the obligatory 'Jeep"" (closer to Lewys' Citroen ZX than any jeep I've ever seen) and Camel safari. We were a little short on time so we only spent an afternoon riding the Camels among the nearest available sand-dunes
column3: which was long enough I think (some people do it for nearly two weeks - I think saddle-sore would be an understatement!). It was a fun afternoon and it was really nice to get out of the city for the first time in 2 weeks. Our camel driver Nihal and his little son were great and made the experience really enjoyable. After a couple of hours riding around we stopped to watch the fiery sun set over the endless horizon - definitely worth it.

column1: Our trip around Rajasthan ended with a lovely 19 hour sleeper train back to Delhi
column2: which was surprisingly ok. Next we make our way to the South
column3: which I think is a lot more relaxed than the north and so will have more of a holiday atmosphere (so I'm told!). Rajathan is an amazing part of India and I think we were definitely thrown in at the deep end starting there. Despite all the 'annoyances' we've had an incredible couple of weeks.

column2: hope you enjoyed my ramblings!

column1: Bonjour and welcome to the second instalment of my Asia travel blog...
We arrived in Delhi on the 25th of Feb after a pretty scenic flight from Kathmandu. Although a seasoned traveller of the subcontinent (I visited for a few weeks with Dad
column2: Kylie and Andrew when I was 5 years old)
column3: this was to be nearly 3 weeks that I won't forget in a hurry.

column1: Delhi is without a doubt the busiest
column2: noisiest
column3: dirtiest and most abrasive place I have ever been. Once the jewel in the crown of the opulent Mughal Empire
column4: it's now almost impossible to picture the splendour and wealth that once existed here. We spent a couple of days looking around
column5: visiting the Red Fort and the Jama Masjid before catching the train to Agra. This wasn't quite as straightforward as it sounds. After spending an hour and a half at the mayhem that is New Delhi Railway Station attempting to book a ticket
column6: we gave up. 'Luckily'
column7: we managed to book a ticket through our hostel for the following morning. Rising at 7
column8: we set off in a taxi to Nizamuddin Railway Station only to find that our train was departing in a month's time. Cheers. To put the icing on the cake a pigeon relieved itself on Kat's head as we stepped out of the station. Welcome to India.

column1: There's no doubt that the Taj Mahal was worth all the trouble. The most beautiful building I have ever seen and so much bigger than you expect it to be. Amazing.
From Agra we caught the bus to Fatehpur Sikri
column2: once the capital of India for fourteen years. There's an incredible mosque and fort there but the amount of hassle we got from 'tour guides'
column3: 'students' and 'ticket sellers' was just ridiculous (even by Indian standards) and did spoil the experience somewhat. I've discovered that speaking Welsh to people who are particularly persistent helps quite a lot...

column1: Jaipur was the next stop (a 5 hour bus journey extended by a break down). Known as the Pink City
column2: it has over 3 million inhabitants and is everything you expect a big Indian city to be - noisy
column3: chaotic and unbelievably polluted. To be honest
column4: the highlight here was the cable TV in the hostel - cricket on 24/7. Indians are genuinely obsessed with cricket and if you ask any Indian who their favourite player is
column5: there is only one answer - Sachin.

column1: The train journey to Jodhpur was not particularly straightforward (noticing a trend..?). This one was delayed by 5 hours so we spent a thrilling afternoon in a waiting room at Jaipur Railway Station. Jodhpur is far nicer than Jaipur and has an incredible fort (known as Mehrangarh) towering over the city. We spent a few days here looking around Mehrangarh
column2: the Clock Tower bazaars and the winding back streets. I managed to find myself a fantastic waterproof
column3: glow-in-the-dark watch and a silly hat to keep the sun off my head for a grand total of 1 pound and 40 pence. The watch is still working if you're wondering...

column1: Sadly I was struck down by the inevitable travel sickness that comes with visiting India whilst in Jodhpur. The less said about that the better
column2: but it did mean I missed the Hindu festival of Holi - where everybody throws colourful powder and water on each other and get very drunk. Pretty gutting.

column1: The last stop on our whirlwind tour of Rajasthan was Jaisalmer (getting there involved an incredibly hot crowded 6 hour bus journey with no toilet or food stops. Painful.). It's almost impossible to visit Jaisalmer without going into the desert on a camel so
column2: after barely having put our bags down
column3: we'd booked an afternoon's excursion into the Great Thar Desert.

column1: Setting off in our 'jeep' (actually something resembling a Vauxhall Corsa)
column2: we travelled about 40km before hopping on a camel and travelling a bit further through the desert until we found some sand dunes (a rarity in the Great Thar Desert). From here we watched the sunset
column3: which was absolutely amazing. Incidentally
column4: riding a camel is not so different from riding a horse
column5: except you are a lot higher up and they have stupidly long necks.

column2: we hopped on the 19 hour sleeper train back to Delhi (only three quarters of an hour late!). Sharing a bed with both my bags isn't the most comfortable but we have 3 more sleepers booked for South India so I better get used to it!

column1: I don't think there's been an easy day in India yet. We've seen some incredible things and met some great people
column2: but I never thought that just being in a place could be such a test of personality and patience. I find that I'm pretty much constantly see-sawing between loving and hating this country... Quite an experience. There's so much more I could have written but I think that's probably enough for now as I'm in a very sweaty internet cafe (in Bangalore). We head off to Hampi tonight before making our way down to the beaches of Kerala.

column1: I hope all's well back home

column1: Le Holî est une fête religieuse dédiée au dieu Kâma
column2: qui souligne également l’arrivée du printemps
column3: et qui tient lieu à la pleine lune de février-mars. La tradition veut que l’on asperge nos amis de couleurs aux différentes significations : le vert pour l’harmonie
column4: l’orange pour l’optimisme
column5: le bleu pour la vitalité et le rouge pour la joie et l’amour.

column2: on porte nos plus laids vêtements
column3: on achète des poignées de poudres colorées que l’on étend ou lance sur les autres
column4: peu importe qui
column5: en dansant aux rythmes des tambours. Évidemment que Phil et moi y avons participé! Avec chacun un petit indien grimpé sur nos épaules

column8: le mauve dans mon cou et le rouge sur le bord de mon nez… mais tout le village est dans cette situation!

column1: Mais si nous sommes venus à Hampi
column2: c’est prime à bord pour son patrimoine archéologique au cœur d’un paysage lunaire : des dizaines de temples en ruines bordés d’une frange de palmiers et de bananiers
column3: le tout perdu dans une mer d’immenses rochers d’une couleur sable. Ces mastodontes arrondis par le temps sont empilés les uns sur les autres
column4: et leur origine demeure un mystère pour les scientifiques
column5: leur présence dans la région étant unique et isolée.

column1: Nous soupçonnons que ces rochers ont été coupés et façonnés en colonnes et poutres pour les temples

column5: chanceux comme on est

column7: alors que Phil respirait l’air frais

column1: Mysore is a beautiful clean city—lots of gardens. It is the home of sandalwood perfume. Enjoy the pictures!
We learned a little about Hinduism. Three levels: Gods—but there are many and you get to choose the one you like
column2: example
column3: God of trees or rain
column4: or whatever. Second come humans who can choose to be good or bad—issue of karma comes into this. Third group are demons. Demons aren’t bad—they are just silly. More powerful than humans because they can change their shape and appearance.

column1: A little more on cows. Cows are sacred in their importance. In the old days
column2: when a dispute was settled
column3: a cow was offered as a gift. Cows provide milk
column4: value as a farm animal
column5: their dung is insulation
column6: their urine is a cleaning agent. As well
column7: their urine is still valued in making medicines—as it has been for 3-4
column8: 000 years. A cow is not eaten—it must be cremated. It is bad luck to have a cow die on you (plus you have to pay for the cremation)
column9: so many people turn them loose. That is why there are street cows everywhere—even walking down the middle of busy highways.

column1: Cows are associated with Hinduism. This one is third biggest in India.

column2: the language spoken in this region is Kannada—pronounced just the way you would think.

column1: A note about security around here. We go through scanners everywhere—monuments
column2: public buildings and even our hotels. Often
column3: we go through a scanner
column4: our bags so through a scanner and then we get “wanded” and/or patted down. Women go through a separate scanner and female attendants frisk us behind a closed curtain. Takes a long time.

column1: The British gave India a postal system and an educational system
column2: but they also left them with a crazy bureaucracy. I learned that when I got my Indian visa in Ottawa—that was just frustrating! One incident here was at a high end hotel in Jaipur. This was the day I got up at 3:15 am to catch a 6 am flight to southern India. I handed in my room key and was handed a customer service questionnaire. It was a full page of fine print that appeared to cover every detail of the last few days. I wasn’t in the best mood
column3: and really wanted a coffee. I pushed it back and said
column4: “no
column5: everything was just fine.” They asked me to just put my name and

column1: But then there are street cows like this one. They are everywhere
column2: cars just swerve around them.

column1: room number. I scribbled that and handed it back. They said that I had to fill it out. I said that I didn’t have my reading glasses—I really wanted that cup of coffee and remember
column2: it is four o’clock in the morning. They suggested that I just check off everything in the “excellent” column. I took the form and when they weren’t looking
column3: I hid it under a plant. Even the street cows don’t have this hassle.
