column1: I was roused from sleep by the call to prayer this morning there are few things more exotic in my opinion or annoying if you are trying to sleep in. The shower doesn’t work so a wet one bath was all I could tolerate
column2: we left Badami after another crap breakfast of tiny pieces of toast and tea and headed further north to the predominantly Islamic city of Bijapur the former seat of the Adil Shahi kings (1489 - 1682).

column1: This crazy Indian practice of laying speed humps across the highways every bloody kilometre turned a reasonably short drive into a much longer one
column2: but we arrived around 11.30am and stopped on the edge of the city to admire the Malik-E-Maidan or in English the Monarch of the Plain an extremely large 55 tonne canon left to rust on one of the cities external walls before looking for a decent hotel room. I then accompanied Padraic to the basement restaurant where we consumed a spicy lunch consisting of chilli and other stuff before visiting some amazing Islamic fortifications
column3: mosques
column4: palaces and mausoleums.

column1: The first place we visited was the incredible Ibrahim Rouza built in 1580 by the Emperor Abdil
Malik-E-Maidan or The Monarch of the Plains

Shah 2 for his queen unfortunately he died first and was interred there. We then visited the graceful arches of the Bara Kaman an unfinished mausoleum followed by the interesting Jod Gumbad tombs all of which share the architectural grace common to Islamic constructs.
We then visited the 1557 Jama Majid which must have once been amazing but is now falling into disrepair and finally the richly decorated gateway known as Mihtar Mahal.
The highlight of our visit to Bijapur will be the Gol Gumbaz
column2: a mausoleum built in 1659 which stands seven metres high and has a 38 metre dome second only to St Peters in Rome. The building is supposed to have superb acoustics so we are going there early in the morning to avoid the crowds to check this out.

column1: Yes the Gol Gumbaz does have excellent acoustics I could hear the Russian tourists making silly noises from every direction at once. I took a few dawn photos of the tomb before returning to the hotel for breakfast. The Gol Gumbaz is such a massive building for one long dead man while millions of Indians live in hovels
column2: go figure.

column1: headed to the fortified town of Bidar another Indian city dominated by Islam and the home of a supposedly excellent 15 century fort I say supposedly because it was closed for maintenance when we arrived in late afternoon and wasn’t open in the morning when we again attempted to enter.
We travelled to Bidar via the town of Gulburga another town dominated by Islam visiting some impressive tombs
column2: the ceiling of one was decorated in mirror tiles and was an incredibly gaudy sight.

column1: I met a little girl probably twelve or thirteen years old at the Bidar Fort who had very good English and was visiting from Hyderabad
column2: she was with a man older than me and a number of other children when I asked her if the man was her father he answered saying she was his wife. India is a paradise for paedophiles it seems.

column1: We have decided to visit an impact crater at a place called Lonar which is in Maharashtra state
column2: so early the next morning we started driving

column4: unfortunately at the border there was no tax office so after much stuffing

column1: India can be difficult place in which to travel
column2: the dirt and the filth becomes depressing so I ensure that I bathe every evening no matter the water temperature. I can’t ever remember being so consistently filthy anywhere I have previously travelled.

column1: Next morning after another poor attempt at an edible breakfast we hit the road stopping briefly to look at an interesting temple in Hospet before negotiating about three hours of bad roads before eventually stopping briefly at a dodgy looking road side diner for a surprisingly cold Sprite and to watch a few minutes of the cricket on the beat up TV in the corner.
It was then on to Aihole pronounced Ay-hol-eh where we would see some stunning 6th century temples
column2: Padraic says we should have started here and travelled south as the temples are getting progressively older as we continue further north. The Durga Temple and the Museum were the highlights at Aihole and in particular the precinct where the temples were much simpler and more solid looking then later architectural designs.

column1: From Aihole it was only a few kilometres to the World Heritage listed Pattadakal complex which was once a capital of the
Chalukyas empire and has temples dating back as far as the 3rd century. It was an amazing complex although it was extremely hot and dusty; I was initially in my element.
A world heritage site and only a small crowd of visitors how refreshing
column2: until they all began following me around
column3: I couldn’t escape them. Every time I turned around there were at least thirty people following me
column4: Padaic thought it was hilarious
column5: eventually I agreed to a few photos with their kids and they left me alone.

column1: From here we headed to Badami along a rough road where we would spend the night
column2: stopping briefly at a very old Jain Temple which had fantastic carved elephant heads on each side of the entrance. Badami is an attractive shady town located in a canyon encircled by forts and old temples decorating the cliff tops. The down also has the lovely Agastyatirtha tank with the gorgeous Bhutanatha Temple jutting out from its shore but the real attraction here are the caves.

column1: The caves are early fifth century rock cut temples containing superb carvings of Hindu and Jain deities. I have always had a passion for rock cut cave
temples and would have enjoyed these more if not for the large crowds swarming all over the place.
There are four caves the first about ten metres up the rock cut stairs carved into the cliff
column2: these stairs then continue to the other three caves about fifty metres further up
column3: as I climbed up the stairs to the third cave I was surround by about forty school children all clapping and cheering me
column4: I have no idea why
column5: I was somewhat embarrassed and extremely confused.

column1: After the caves I walked around the tank visiting the old temples

column3: I had to go get a security guard
column4: as they were surrounding me the little hairy bastards.

column1: I was going to visit the museum but some kid was defecating in the entrance way so I wandered off into Badami's attractive old town
column2: Indians shit and piss anywhere they please
column3: while we were enjoying our breakfast this morning five little girls climbed the fence and all defecated near one of temples on Hemakuta Hill in Hampi

column1: The stunning city of Vijayanager is the capital of the destroyed Vijayanagara Empire is a showcase of fine medieval Indian architecture and a UNESCO World Heritage site. The city was around 26 square kilometres and was encircled by seven levels of defensive walls many of which can still be seen.
Our guest house is located within metres of the older temples on Hemakuta Hill
column2: which we visited immediately after Virupaksha Temple
column3: which dominates the small village and traveller enclave of Hampi Bazarre. I particularly like the older temples dating from the 9th century strewn amongst the boulder dominated terrain.

column1: We visited a number of smaller temples many of these were dominated by large effigies of various gods including Ganesh
column2: before striking of down a dirt track with the plan of looping back around to some of the other major sites. The scenery was extremely attractive as we followed the course of a canal identifying and photographing temples standing starkly on hill sides or buried in the undergrowth. Unfortunately we couldn’t find the path that lead to the river and the sun was setting so we had to turn around and walk all the way back. From here we grabbed

column1: a rickshaw and went to a village four kilometres away where we had a few beers before returning to Hampi for dinner (no booze in Hampi).

Saturday dawned hot and cloudless (when is it anything else) so we headed out to the Royal Enclosure visiting major sites such as the Queens Bath and Zenana Enclosure and the beautiful Lotus Mahal. We then checked out the brilliant Elephant Stables
column2: The Barracks and many more ruins. There were few people about so we wandered at will for several hours
column3: it is a shame Indians don’t value these monuments as they scrawl graffiti on everything and throw rubbish all over the place
column4: still we saw some fantastic architectural sites in that morning.

column1: Around 10.30am we arrived at Shiva’s Underground Temple where the driver was waiting and he showed us an ancient military dining area where a long line of plates had been carved into some rocks near an aqueduct. Before taking us to the museum where there was a large model of Vijayananagar
column2: we were able to see how close we had come the night before to a major road. The museum was surprisingly good
column3: we then headed to the fabulous

column1: Vittala Temple where we the left the driver and set off on foot.

This temple was built in the 15th century and looks fantastic sandwiched between rocky ridges and the river. The highlight of this complex was the magnificent carved chariot in the courtyard. We ate a couple of ice creams to try and combat the heat before followed the beautiful Tungabadhra River back towards Hampi Bizarre. We could see many of the Anegondi Temples across the river as we stopped at a restaurant for a meal and a cold drink.

column1: Bus trip from Bangalore to Kundapura and return. Local day trip by bus from Kundapura to Udupi
column2: autorickshawto Malpe and by boat to St. Mary's Islands.

column1: There is something very strange about beach destinations. I used to wonder
column2: what do all these people do when they stay near the beach? Of course
column3: there is the sea and you go for a dip
column4: but the charm runs out after a couple of hours and then what next? With hill destinations
column5: I get it. There is driving
column6: hiking up and enjoying the view from the top. This was until the trip to Agonda in south Goa. For three days it was nothing but eat-swim-relax-sleep-drink-swim-relax routine and by the end I had attained complete nirvana. It was about rediscovering myself. For one
column7: the vast expanse of the ocean and the power of nature puts things in perspective about the connection between us humans and nature. Second
column8: doing nothing is actually a good way to think through things
column9: relax and make decisions about life. It was a completely different experience for a person like me who always has to have something to think about.

column2: enough with the philosophical bullshit. I'll come to the trip I took with my wife
column3: Pavi.

column1: I had booked a round trip non A/C sleeper bus ticket from Bangalore to Kundapura by Karnatake State Road
View of the coast from the resort

Transport Corporation KSRTC (Rupees 400/person one way). The bus that we were supposed to travel in had had a breakdown and we were bumped up to A/C semi-sleeper bus after an hour of waiting. We were pretty tired and slept as soon as the bus took off. The bus takes the popular Bangalore-Mangalore highway through Hassan and reached Mangalore the next morning. From Mangalore the bus travels northwards to Udupi
column2: the popular temple town
column3: and as soon as we reached Udupi
column4: the air was waft with the smell of the sea (fish
column5: to be precise!). The next stop would be Kundapura about 90kms from Mangalore. Kundapura is a small non-descript town but is well connected on the West coast highway. We got down at the bus stop and hired an autorickshaw (tuk-tuk) and were charged Rupees 250 to take us the 12kms to the Turtle Bay beach resort. I had made a reservation online for a small standard room (Rupees 1000/night) for two days
column6: but when we got there we were told that the rooms were unavailable as the people staying there had extended the stay.The lady at the reception told us that they can give us a cottage room

column1: Entrance of the resort from the beach

right next to the beach for 2000 rupees/night. The room was clean and laid artistically with typical village style windows (check out the pics) and a cement slab cot. It was neat and comfortable and with the sound of the waves crashing against the rocks on the coast
column2: heavenly. The property's USP is the presence of rock boulders on the coast with crevices big enough for a person to walk-in and the resort is surrounded by fishing hamlets with boats neatly laid out. The fishermen take the boats out in the night for a catch and sell it in the nearby towns. A picture perfect place to relax for the weekend. We took a dip in the sea
column3: had food and beer. The food was not quite to our taste
column4: but the beer was heavenly as it always is near the sea.

column2: we decided to explore the place and headed towards Udupi and Malpe. We walked the kilometre from the beach to the bus stop and took the local bus to Udupi (Rupees 30 one way). Once there
column3: we took the autorickshaw to Malpe
column4: 6kms from Udupi. We got a ferry ticket to St. Mary's Islands

column1: Another view of the coast from the resort
which is about 6kms from Malpe. After a 30min wait
column2: the boat finally arrived and boarded 50 souls to be taken to St. Mary's Islands. The islands are made of volcanic rock formation with the rock arranged neatly like a column. The island coast is madeup of shells and not sand as I had assumed. What lies beneath the coastline - rock
column3: shells or sand
column4: I am unsure. I gathered that the formation of the island is geographically unique and resembles the Giant's causeway in Ireland. We explored the place and took a short dip in the water as it was crowded in the weekend. The view of the island and coast from the topmost part of the island was enchanting. We then took the ferry back to Malpe and the tuk-tuk to Udupi
column5: had a short look at the temple and the famous decorated idol of Lord Krishna. We could not see the idol as the Lord had taken time off for a shower
column6: and so settled to shop for some beads (Pavi is crazy about beads) in the little shops that line almost every temple in India. We then took the local bus back to the resort
column7: had

column1: food and drink and spent the remained of the day relaxing.

The third day was spent relaxing with usual food-drink-dip-sleep-food routine and that evening we headed back to the KSRTC depot in Kundapura to take the bus back to Bangalore. One tip that I learnt was that it is better to take a semi-sleeper bus (like the seats in an aeroplane) when traveling through hilly terrain as the position is good for sleeping. Full sleeper buses tend to rock front-to-back and can be quite merciless onthe neck.

column2: a very relaxing long weekend.

column4: but I suppose that's where it ends. Yes
column5: Venice are smelly too
column6: but you can hardly say the smells are the same. You would understand if you have been there 😊. You can take a whole day trip around the river canals (but it does get slightly boring after a couple of hours)
column7: people also do tours that take days
column8: hiring houseboats (beautiful and luxurious boats
column9: with 2 or more rooms on the boat
column10: but trust my word when I say the luxury costs as well).

column1: We arrived to Alleppey in the afternoon
column2: so we decided to go round
do the backwaters the next day
column3: and than leave for Gokarna. One thing I will definitely remember Alleppey for is The Great Battle – namely the battle between us and the really huge
column4: humongous mosquitoes. I swear
column5: they were huge
column6: I have never seen mosquitoes this size. And there were gazillions of them. Jan and I just sat in front of our room
column7: when they attacked
column8: biting us even through our clothes. So it started
column9: we were clapping our hands like idiots
column10: killing as many as possible
column11: but they had amazing back up
column12: and it was 2 of us against an army of them. We did not falter though
column13: and the pile of dead mosquitoes around our seats was getting bigger and bigger
column14: but so was the number of new arrivals. So for 2 evenings straight
column15: we were fighting for our mere existence. There was this Indian guy watching us and he said: “Mosquitoes
column16: ha? Yeah
column17: they come in the evening
column18: many of them. And they like your pale skin.” And then he laughed and left
column19: leaving me thinking I should of done a better effort of tanning my pale
column20: white skin. 😊

column2: as we were told it is best to look for and hire a boat by yourself than to have an agency organise your trip around the backwaters. So we found this guy
column3: who was offering us a motor boat for a decent price
column4: but once we got to the boat
column5: we saw he was just the middle man. He started fighting with the boatman and Jan assumed (correctly) they were fighting about how to share the money. So Jan took our money back from the middle man and we agreed for a different price with the boat man
column6: and off we were. It was quite nice and to be honest
column7: observing how the people live with the water was quite interesting. They do everything but cook with the river water. So we saw many people bathing and washing
column8: women doing the laundry...It was also very quiet
column9: because there is no traffic there
column10: apart from boats. Our boat man tried to give us some information about the backwaters
column11: but after an hour or so
column12: he kept repeating himself up to a point
column13: when Jan and I could hardly stay serious any more. We also made a

column2: where his wife prepared some chai for us. But that's when the guy started acting weird
column3: he was all cocky
column4: asking us same questions 6 or 7 times (how long will you stay in Alleppey
column5: where are you going after...)
column6: it was very obvious he was trying to show his wife and mother (who joined us later)
column7: how cool he was. And also
column8: I think he took something
column9: cause it was all gibberish coming from his mouth. So you can imagine we were more than happy when our 3 hour tour around the backwaters was over and we were able to get away from the guy.

column1: I can't remember when I was last so happy to leave a place
column2: but I was thrilled when we left for another overnight train to Gokarna. As there was no direct train from Alleppey to Gokarna
column3: we had to get off at an interim station of Kumta
column4: at 3.30 in the morning. I have to say
column5: I am starting to love the Indian trains. You could easily live there and lack nothing. There is always food available (fresh
column6: as they have a huge kitchen on the train)
column7: you

column2: snacks...And everything is so cheap. If you buy anything on trains around Europe
column3: it always seems to cost a fortune. We got the side bunk beds
column4: which were quite comfy
column5: so it seemed like we arrived to Kumta in no time. As it was only 3.30 am
column6: we slept on the train station and we woke up at about 7am
column7: ready to continue our trip to Gokarna. When we stepped out of the station
column8: we were like “What the hell?”
column9: the area seemed so isolated
column10: so quiet and so far away from any life. We walked to the road and asked around for the bus station. A guy just told us to wait at the side of the road
column11: where we were picked up by a sleeper bus
column12: on its way to Gokarna. An hour later
column13: we were finally there.

column1: Following Diego's recommendation we took a tuk tuk to the Om beach (it got its name following the fact that the beach is in shape of the Indian sign for “om”). The tuk tuk dropped us on the top of the cliff
column2: so a flight of stairs later
column3: we were on Om beach
column4: looking

column1: for the Dolphin bay hostel. I was so tired and soooooo in need of a long shower that I was quite taken aback when I first saw the huts behind the Dolphin bay cafe. They were the simplest huts
column2: put directly on the sand
column3: with a bed occupying pretty much the whole room. Wow
column4: I totally lost my spirit
column5: whereas Jan loved it
column6: there was this really easy going
column7: nice group of people sitting in the sand around a huge round table
column8: which was placed in the middle of the walking path
column9: a row of about 6 huts on each side. Jan joined them
column10: whereas I was fuming
column11: so I took some me time
column12: and went round the beach. When I came back
column13: I was shown how the “shower” works (there was a huge tank of water
column14: you had to drop your stuff in the so called bathroom
column15: grab a bucket and fetch the water from the tanker). After a “shower” (the place had no running water)
column16: I felt a bit better and I started to absorb the feel of the Dolphin bay “slum” (I don't really know who came up with the “slum” thingy
column17: but it was so right

column2: no running water and a bunch of hobbos 😊).
we felt as if the slum was colonised by the French
column3: pretty much everyone but us were French. But everyone was really nice so we felt like home very soon. Apart from walking to town one afternoon (climbing over a hill
column4: walking over Cudly beach and walking over yet another hill – about an hour's walk)
column5: we didn't do much. Well
column6: that's a lie
column7: I walked to town and back again
column8: as I managed to ruin one of our torch lights and lose another one
column9: so with the daily power cuts in the slum
column10: we really needed one.

column2: as Om beach is full of “free spirits” and new age hippies
column3: it wasn't weird to see people doing yoga on the beach early in the morning. I must admit something: I became one of them. Following the yoga course we did in Varkala
column4: I got into a habit of doing yoga every morning (still am
column5: here in Goa)
column6: although I am not into the whole “spiritual crap”
column7: I just like how my body feels after a full hour's stretching and bending.

column2: we got new arrivals to the slum
column3: that kinda became our own
column4: non – French “posse”. A German girl called Anna
column5: a couple from Sweden
column6: Jonas and Helene
column7: and the legendary couple from Yorkshire
column8: now pretending to be Scottish
column9: Julie and Steven. It was our posse versus the French contingency
column10: fighting for our spot around the slum table. We would pretty much just sit there and chat
column11: and thanks to Julie share some life wisdoms (for example why we should never have kids
column12: as they are pretty much a waste of time 😊). Julie was the life of our posse
column13: I really couldn't help but like her. The discussions we had...well
column14: repeating stuff that was said or talked about just wouldn't do it justice. So
column15: see Julie
column16: you ARE mentioned in our blog
column17: and you ARE still the QUEEN. 😊 Oh
column18: and do say “hi” to Posh and Becks for us
column19: and organise a small gathering. We will make sure we bring Tom and Katie. 😊. And Julie
column20: please keep practicing and follow Anna's advice 😊 by Jan

column1: Jan and I also got in a routine when it came to food. Lunch almost always consisted
of the huge and yummy Nutella pancakes. Erm
column2: my figure is still long and lean
column3: have no fear 😊.

column1: Another thing that became pretty routine were the rats crawling round and in our huts at night...we became so annoyed with them
column2: and having them on our bed one night
column3: we slept the last night with our light on.

column1: With all the delights and the easy going life we had in Gokarna
column2: it was yet again time to move. With sad hearts we said farewell to our posse
column3: and again
column4: off we were
column5: on our way to Goa. Oh
column6: yeah...new age hippies
column7: here we come!😊

column2: Displayed: 28

column1: Another short drive as we arrived in the ancient city of Mysore around midday and dumped our bags at the hotel I had booked the previous evening
column2: it is clean and comfortable and within just a few minutes’ walk of the palace. We decided that we would go visit the further afield sights immediately then dismiss the driver as we will be staying for a few days. The first of these sights was the star shaped Kesava Temple built 1268 in Somnathpur some thirty three kilometres east of Mysore
column3: which was totally covered in carved soapstone figures from the Ramayana
column4: Mahabharata and the Bhagavad Gita some quite pornographic. I found the temple fascinating
column5: it's a shame the Indians don’t build anything so pretty anymore.

column1: On the way back we visited the temple on Chamundi Hill not very interesting but the five metre carved statue of Nandi was interesting on the way down
column2: we then went to a couple of expensive shops so the driver could get commissions
column3: although he told us not to buy anything. The rest of the day was spent in a pub enjoying a few Kingfisher beers.

column1: Tuesday morning I rose early as usual
column2: my stomach

column1: is much better today although I may be getting Padraic's cold now
column2: I have never seen anyone eat as much as him
column3: he will eat anything and in huge quantities. I headed for the palace
column4: I was harassed by children asking for money as I walked to the palace then by the police when I refused to check in my camera on arrival
column5: they don’t seem to have anything useful to do
column6: I no sooner entered the palace and the Indians are snapping everything in sight with their mobile phones. The Palace is century old and well worth a look
column7: although it is gaudy and only a small portion is open to the public I then visited the shop where I purchased some souvenirs.

column1: First stop this morning is Sriangapatnam a fort town built in the middle of the Cauvery River by Tipu Sultan who was killed in a war against the British in 1799
column2: he built a summer palace in beautifully carved timber (Daria Daulat Bagh) only two kilometres from the Gumbaz (tomb) where his body is interred.

column1: We then visited Sravanabelagola (Monk of the White Pond) a Jain pilgrimage town which is dominated by an eleven

column2: 18 metre tall and perched on Vindhyagiri Hill
column3: the statue was naked and his penis is about three feet long. The six hundred and fourteen steps to the top were a bit of an effort as the rock was hot and we had to go bare foot
column4: the views were great from the top.

column1: We then travelled to Hassan an unpleasant busy town where we stayed the night
column2: I had to go see an Airtel vendor here to get some more credit on my phone then Padraic and I had a few beers and a meal.

column1: The next morning we visited the Hoysala temples at Halebid and Belur
column2: the Hoysala were the dominant Hindu empire in this part of India for a number of centuries managing to fight of the Muslims off for a number of years before eventually being defeated
column3: they also built the Devala Temple at Somnathpur.

column1: Of the two temples (both free entry) the Hoysaleswara (Halebid) Temple (1121) dedicated to Shiva was in my opinion the better
column2: it was more intricately carved and the interior had bats and beautiful sculptures
column3: there are also two large Nandi statues and a museum

column1: set in an attractive park near a lake. The Channakashava (Belur) temple dedicated to Vishnu took a century to build (1126) and is still a working temple with priests etc which is interesting
column2: as were the other temples on the site
column3: the tank and the well.

column1: On the way back to Hassan we stopped at a resort for lunch and decide to stay there the night rather than return to that ugly town. I am sick again my second nasty cold since I have been in India
column2: at least my stomach isn’t playing up today. We met our new driver Mani at the resort
column3: the food here is great
column4: I had a huge cooked breakfast before our departure to Hampi.

column2: Displayed: 24

column1: with some trepidation about landing on the hilltop in mangalore where sometime ago an air india flight had crashed
column2: we arrived at mangalore airport
column3: a newly built airport
column4: collected our luggage and proceeded towards taj gateway. they offered us a choice of rooms and we were upgraded to a club room with a view of the arabian sea. we explored the hotel and discussed a day trip with travel desk. We arrived at the coffee shop and i chose a mangalore thali with the fish and chicken
column5: my husband ordered a nasi goreng and after a little rest we left for sun and sand resort which was right on the beach. entry to the resort also came with snacks and we spent some time at the coffee shop overlooking the beach and viewed some of the rooms and then got into the water. there was a dog swimming in the sea and i must say he was such a powerful swimmer. we then left for someswara beach which was a rocky beach. we saw this beautiful sunset and returned to the hotel after a detour to see the docks.

column1: Dinner was at the indian restaurant and we turned in early

since the next morning we were leaving for puttur to attend a wedding. we arrived in puttur and started breakfast of idli and dosa and coffee. after the muhurtam and wedding we proceeded for lunch and the food was excellent. i specially enjoyed the sweet dosa and payesam and we met the bride and groom one last time and left for mangalore. On the way back we stopped at my husbands parents house when at some point of time they used to live in mangalore.

back to the hotel we packed and left our bags at the reception and sat in the coffee shop having club sandwiches and a beer. the food was very good in the hotel. i was happy to find a gateway hotel coming up in kolkata. i also picked up a fridge magnet from the hotel shop and we left for the airport. from the airport we could see the mangalore refinery and took some photographs of it. at the airport i managed to find the hotel keys in my bag and called them and left them with the jet airways counter. a short and sweet trip to mangalore ended with biryani.
